title: East Timors Declaration of Independence?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Waldo Cohn, 89, a Developer Of Plutonium for the Atom Bomb
description: Dr. Waldo Cohn, a biochemist involved in building the world's first nuclear bomb and later a pioneer in using radioactive isotopes for medical research, died on Friday at a hospital in Oak Ridge, Tenn., where he lived. He was 89.

title: JAPAN'S JOBLESSNESS STILL AT HIGH
description: Japan's unemployment rate remained at a record high of 4.9 percent in July for the second consecutive month on a seasonally adjusted basis, with joblessness for women rising two-tenths of a point to 4.6 percent, the Government said. In a separate report, the Labor Ministry said there were 46 job offers for every 100 job seekers, the same as in the previous month, equaling the lowest ratio since 1963. Calvin Sims

title: Shares End Mixed After Strong Manufacturing Report Adds to Fear of Fed Rate Action
description: Stock prices gyrated sharply yesterday, ending mixed in a session that traders said was almost impossible to interpret.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused Of Beating Girl to Death
description: A Long Island man was arrested yesterday on charges that he beat his girlfriend's 3-year-old daughter to death, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATCHEN, HARRY, RABBI
description: KATCHEN-Harry, Rabbi. Age 91. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Following ordination, he was rabbi of Beth El in Allentown, PA and until his retirement, he served in Outreach and Community Education for the Jewish Theological Seminary. After his retirement, he was High Holiday coordinator for The Rabbinical Assembly. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Selma, children Alan and Roberta, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

Pacharz, dear brother of the late Marie Marbach and his late twin brother Sidney, precious grandfather and great grandfather. Services at ''Kreitzman's Memorial Home,'' 1500 Morris Avenue, Union, NJ Wednesday at 12:30 PM. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, NY. Call 1-888-351-4414 for information.

title: Not Seen in Vampires' Gardens: Home-Grown Exotics
description: WHAT separates great homegrown garlic from just good garlic is a carefully tended garden, not too surprisingly. And garlic lovers have just a few weeks to prepare for next year's crop, which should be planted around the first day of autumn.

description: GOLDMAN-Rose. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center note with deep sorrow the death of Rose Goldman, beloved mother of I. David Goldman, M.D., Acting Chairman of the Department of Medical Oncology and Director of the Albert Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center. title: Early, Apple Shows Off New Mac G4
description: A buoyant Steven P. Jobs, the interim chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., introduced the latest, most powerful Macintosh today, describing it as a supercomputer for the desktop.

title: . . . And the Customers Never Talk Back
description: Been dying to meet the graduating class of the San Francisco College of Mortuary Science? Here's your opportunity. ''The Business of Death'' introduces several students who are mastering the art or craft of embalming, cremating, grief counseling and coffin-selling on their way to becoming funeral directors.

title: 'Tis Nobler to Synopsize
description: The TNT cable network has been building a reputation for acquiring rights to first-run movies and giving them their commercial television premieres. Normally they have been popular movies like ''Space Jam'' or ''Ghosts of Mississippi,'' but this Sunday night, TNT will present Kenneth Branagh's 1996 ''Hamlet'' in its full four-hour production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESS, BARBARA E., M.D.
description: BESS-Barbara E., M.D. New York Medical College was deeply saddened to learn of the death of our distinquished alumna, Barbara E. Bess, MD '65, who for many years was an integral part of the College's psychiatry residency training program at our University Hospital, Metropolitan Hospital Center. Dr. Bess, professor of clinical psychiatry and valued member of the faculty, was a wonderful teacher, much beloved by residents and staff. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D., Provost and Dean, School of Medicine Joseph T. English, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences Richard K. Stone, M.D., Senior Associate Dean and Medical Director, Metropolitan Hospital Center Ronnie G. title: DROP IN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: French unemployment fell to a six-and-a-half-year low as factories stepped up production, the clearest sign yet of accelerating economic growth. The jobless rate unexpectedly declined to 11.2 percent in July, the lowest since February 1993, from 11.3 percent in June. Another Government report showed production of everything from heavy equipment to household goods rose more than expected in June.

title: Accounts
description: Ionbeauty.com, New York, an on-line perfume retailer, to DiNoto Lee, New York to handle its first account. Billings were estimated in Adweek at $15 million to $20 million. The decision came after a two-month review that had been narrowed to DiNoto Lee and three New York-based finalists: Mad Dogs and Englishmen, Renegade and Yellow Card.

title: Even the Doggy Bags Really Care
description: ON a sultry Sunday night, two men fresh off the plane from Silicon Valley were getting the full Union Square Cafe treatment. ''Would you like ice water, Evian or a sparkling mineral water?'' the waitress asked. ''Ice water?'' one man asked, a little fearfully. ''Excellent!'' the waitress said, as if he had given the correct answer to a tough exam question.

title: A Letter and a Response
description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, wrote to 10 business executives on July 28 suggesting that they resign from a group promoting overhaul of campaign finance laws, which prompted a reply on Aug. 23 by three leaders of that group. Following is a letter sent to an executive, with the recipient's name deleted by the advocacy group, the Committee for Economic Development, and the group's reply:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, RUTH
description: SCHLESINGER-Ruth on August 31 in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Stanley Schlesinger. Dear mother of Murry (Beverly) Schlesinger and Ethel Schlesinger. Adored grandmother of Diana and Matthew. Graveside services Wednesday, 1 PM at Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: HYUNDAI UNIT SELLS ASSETS
description: An affiliate of South Korea's largest conglomerate, Hyundai Group, sold $300 million of assets to a major French water supplier. The unit, Hyundai Petrochemical, agreed to sell its waste-water treatment operations for $200 million to Vivendi S.A., while selling its power generation operations for $100 million to Sithe Energies, a United States affiliate of Vivendi. Earlier this month, Hyundai Petrochemical agreed to sell its assets to Mitsui & Company of Japan in exchange for an investment of 500 billion won ($422.7 million). Samuel Len

title: Congo Rebels Finally Sign an Accord but Real Peace Is Still Distant
description: The divided rebels in Congo finally signed a peace agreement today, a key step toward ending the fighting but only the start toward reconstructing one of Africa's biggest, richest and least stable nations.

title: What to Tip? Flip Over The Check
description: THE way John Schreadley tells it, the idea came to him one morning when he and his wife were having breakfast at a chain restaurant. When the bill came, Mr. Schreadley, a paramedic in Tampa, Fla., pulled a tipping chart he had bought out of his pocket. When he looked down and saw both the check and tip card in his hand, a light bulb went on. Why not, he asked himself, combine the two?

title: Complacency Amid the AIDS Epidemic
description: Disturbing new evidence suggests that the impact of powerful new AIDS drugs in reducing death rates has begun to wane at the same time that efforts to block the spread of the AIDS virus have reached a plateau. The task of bringing the AIDS epidemic under control will clearly require renewed vigor and new approaches to prevention.

title: Why Not Let Them Eat Big Macs?

description: PAGANO-Deborah. Debbie's indomitable spirit and strength of purpose remain an inspiration to us all. Dona Vaughn Raines, Co-Chair Allen Harris, Pastor

title: Our Towns; Orientation For Freshmen: Inner City 101
description: JAVIER SANCHEZ and Erin Walsh learned a thing or two by going to Trinity College for preorientation, ahead of most of the freshman class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDELL, LEONARD G.
description: WENDELL-Leonard G. On August 30, 1999. Dearest friend of so very many years. Generous of heart, enthusiastic and always ready to uplift. Condolences to his caring, beloved, loving Marilyn. Lloyd and Kappy Isler Wendy, Scott and Kenneth

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper climbed after France and Germany said their economies would grow faster next year, raising demand for wires and pipes. In New York, copper rose 3.05 cents, to 77.7 cents a pound.

title: Business Is Saving Schools, Not Tainting Them
description: This past year, children in some of Boston's most impoverished neighborhoods embarked on a dazzling excursion into cyberspace -- all while seated at their desks in public schools. And the scene was repeated at similar schools, public and private, across the country.

title: Judge Rules for New Board To Fight Police Corruption
description: Over the strong objection of the Giuliani administration, a Manhattan judge has ordered the city to establish an independent board to investigate police corruption.

title: Sweetness Close to Home
description: THE overhead door of the big shed at La Terre Garlic Farm was open as my car crunched over the gravel driveway on one of those perfect cloudless summer mornings last month.

title: U.S. Dollar Is Sliding Against Yen and Euro
description: As investors turn their attention to rebounding economies in Asia and Europe, the United States dollar has begun to slide against the Japanese yen and the euro.

title: Young, Nonwhite, Female and Complacent About AIDS
description: When she goes out dancing on Saturday nights, Mercedes Rios often finds herself listening to young women talk about how they will never get AIDS. It hurts her, she says, because they will never know by looking at her that she contracted H.I.V. well over a decade ago, and how vulnerable they really are.

title: Magazine Group's Head
description: Nina B. Link, a longtime executive at the Children's Television Workshop, has been named president and chief executive of the Magazine Publishers of America, an industry association. Ms. Link, 55, succeeds Donald D. Kummerfeld, who had been president since 1987. Ms. Link has been group president of publishing and interactive software for the Children's Televison Workshop, where she has worked for 21 years. For the last five years, she has been a member of the executive committee of the magazine association's board.

title: Business Travel; A system for a quick pass through immigration at airports has surprisingly few users.
description: AN automated system at eight airports now allows international business travelers to bypass long immigration lines and get on their way more quickly.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about teacher shortages in the United States referred imprecisely to the place where cash bonuses of up to $3,000 each are being offered to prospective teachers. It is Washington, D.C., not Washington State.

title: Crowds Seeking Clintons Put Spotlight on Chelsea
description: It was not the President of the United States. It was not even the First Lady. But when Chelsea Clinton turned the corner onto the main street of this beguiling Finger Lakes village this afternoon, unannounced and seemingly out of nowhere, it caused a commotion of Presidential proportions.

title: From IDT: 5-Cent Long-Distance Rate, at Any Time, $3.95 a Month
description: Undercutting the telecommunications giants, the IDT Corporation plans to begin offering domestic long-distance calls today for 5 cents a minute at any time with a flat monthly fee of $3.95.

title: 50 Candles And Gripes For Fassel To Ponder
description: The birthday cake was brought onto the field as the Giants' practice was ending. The cake was four feet long, a couple of feet wide, so big that it took two team employees to carry it on a wooden folding table.

title: Lower Back Injury Ruins Sampras's Bid
description: A devastated Pete Sampras, unshaved, unhappy and unable to make sense of the stabbing pain that settled into his lower back during a Sunday morning practice, announced his withdrawal from the United States Open yesterday because of a herniated disk in his lower back.

title: City Prepares for Year 2000 as It Says Not to Worry
description: Barges full of generator fuel will be tied to Manhattan piers. City hospitals will stockpile a month's supply of vital medicines. The Federal Reserve will have extra caches of cash to feed depleted automated teller machines. City emergency-management officials will be linked by a hot line to counterparts in New Zealand, where the dawn of the new millennium arrives first.

title: 3 Are Shot and Wounded After Argument in Bronx
description: Three people believed to be bystanders were shot on a street corner in the Bronx last night after an argument led to gunfire, the police said. None of the victims were critically injured.

title: 6 Murder Suspects Are Part of Gang, Police Say
description: Six people being sought in the killing of a retired New York City detective during a robbery last week are part of a well-organized gang and have been linked to other armed robberies, the police said yesterday.

title: Executives Press for Political Finance Change
description: Leaders of a committee of business executives who have endorsed a ban on unlimited campaign contributions said today that their members would not be intimidated by an aggressive letter-writing campaign led by Senator Mitch McConnell, one of the Senate's most ardent opponents of a bill that would overhaul the campaign finance system.

title: Cone Pitches Well, But the A's Hit Better
description: David Cone has admitted that the constant questions and doubts about his right arm have bothered him, which means that the questions and the doubts have really irritated him. Cone expects the questions, but lately he has felt like a lab rat. Poked and prodded, dissected and discussed, Cone is the perfect-game pitcher trying to validate himself all over again.

title: REBUKING GIULIANI, U.S. JUDGE ORDERS PERMIT FOR RALLY
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the leader of the New Black Panther Party, may hold a youth rally in Harlem on Saturday, saying that city officials had no right to use the content of Mr. Muhammad's inflammatory speeches as a basis for denying him a rally permit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLES, JAMES BELL, JR.

Mr. Welles is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Ann Thom Welles, and their children Nancy W. Leahy, James B. Welles III, Thomas B. Welles and Amy B. Welles. Son William B. Welles predeceased him. Mr. Welles has nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Thursday, September 2nd at 11:00 a.m. at St. Mark's Church, 85 East Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Camp Dudley, Westport, NY and the Emma Willard School, Troy, New York.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At least as frightening as the rhetoric of Mr. Muhammad is the possibility of a society where the right to speak publicly can be denied on the basis of administrative whim, personal dislike, or disapproval of anticipated content.''

description: To the Editor:

title: They Practice, and You Get a Free Meal
description: WITH nearly 50 restaurants opening in Manhattan this fall, the race for loyal customers has already begun. Few places simply fling open the doors and fill the reservation book. Instead, they embark on a ''soft opening,'' a transitional period that can mean anything from a series of high-profile fashion parties or big-ticket charity events to free or discounted meals in a half-empty dining room. With these trial runs, the staff can practice for what everyone hopes will be the rush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, MARC A.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Marc A. On August 30, 1999. Marcia, his one true love whom he cherished for 30 years. Adored father of Andy Sam and Jessie. Loving son of Irving. Dearest brother of Brian and Scot. Treasured brother-in-law of Phyllis and Neil Koenig. Devoted uncle of Rebecca and Gaby. Beloved son-in-law of Claire and Morty Rothberg. 25 years of devoted service to Cablevision Systems Corp. and the Dolan family. Box 2141, New York, New York 10116-2141.

title: Umpires Said to Be Close to a Deal
description: A long day in a judge's chambers in Philadelphia brought lawyers for Major League Baseball and its umpires close to a deal yesterday on the status of umpires who face the loss of their jobs today, a lawyer familiar with the general outline of the talks said.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN BANK BAILOUT COST
description: Standard & Poor's reported that the total long-term price for bailing out Mexico's banks stands at $105 billion, or 21 percent of this year's gross domestic product. The rating agency said its estimate, much higher than the Government's and that of an independent auditor, reflected high interest costs during the Asian crisis and the cost of the Government takeover of Banca Serfin S.A. in June. Mexico's bank assets will continue to deteriorate as long as the Congress is deadlocked over passing new bank insurance and bankruptcy laws, S.& P. said. Rick Wills

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMNEY, ANDREW F.
description: ROMNEY-Andrew F. On August 30, 1999 at age 74. Beloved father of Michael and Mark Romney and Sharon Scott. Devoted grandfather of Andrew, Matthew, Theodore, Lewis and Hannah. Dear brother of Henry Romney. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, September 3rd at 12 noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about a slowing in the decline of H.I.V. infection and AIDS misstated the results of a study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on new infections among people treated in clinics specializing in sexually transmitted disease. The rates were 8 percent among gay and bisexual men and 0.48 percent among heterosexuals, not 6 percent and 0.4 percent.

title: AT&T AND INTERNET PHONE PROVIDER REACH SERVICES DEAL
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would provide international networking services to Net2Phone Inc., enabling Net2Phone to expand its low-cost Internet-based calling service to 17 countries. The five-year contract is expected to generate more than $100 million in revenue, AT&T said. It covers countries in Asia, Europe and Africa, Net2Phone said. A dozen other countries will be considered for later expansion under the agreement, AT&T said. Net2Phone's shares jumped $12.375, to $85 in Nasdaq trading. The company, which is based in Hackensack, N.J., went public on July 29 at $15 a share.

title: 2 Suffolk County Boys Contract Malaria at Local Scout Camp
description: Two 11-year-old boys who attended a Boy Scout camp in Calverton on the North Shore of Suffolk County this month have come down with malaria, state and county officials announced today.

title: HOOPER HOLMES TO BUY RIVAL COMPANY IN HEALTH TESTING
description: Hooper Holmes Inc., which provides health information on policy applicants to insurance companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a unit of Pediatric Services of America Inc. for as much as $95 million, gaining control of its biggest rival. The unit, Paramedical Services of America, collects blood and urine samples from candidates for life and health policies and runs more than 200 centers nationwide. Hooper Holmes, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., has a similar number of offices. The price of the deal is subject to adjustment but is expected to be $85 million to $95 million, Hooper Holmes said. Hooper Holmes specializes in medical examinations and tests in homes and businesses of policy applicants.

description: LANZA-Baptist F. (Bobby). On August 30th, 1999. Former Co-Proprietor of Lanza Restaurant, Licensed Funeral Director for 50 years and Veteran of W.W. II Medical Corps. Beloved husband of Anna (nee Terrone). Devoted father of Vincent and Ann Marie Bisciello. Dear father-in-law of Maria & Neil Bisciello. Cherished grandfather of Anna Marie, Vincent, Michael, Neil Bisciello & Ana Francesca Bisciello. Dear brother of Antionette DeRobertis and Ida Abramo. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. title: Bottles That Only the Boldest Dare Buy
description: WOW, $380 for a Batard-Montrachet,'' I remarked to the wine steward at a New York restaurant as I surveyed the wine list. ''A lot of money for a bottle of white Burgundy. It must be a tough sell.''

title: Clintons May Have Taken Step Toward Buying a House in Chappaqua
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared to be in the final stages of negotiating to buy a house in Westchester County today, a rambling Dutch Colonial in the picturesque hamlet of Chappaqua.

title: Calpers Plans to Invest More Aggressively
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said yesterday that it would invest as much as $11 billion in hedge funds and other aggressive investments that have not been widely used by public pension funds.

title: A Light Look At the World In 'New Art' At the Tate
description: Helped along by the hype, gimmickry and raw talent normally associated with British pop music, the current boom in British contemporary art could hardly have gone unnoticed abroad. In 1996, ''Life/Live,'' a show at the Modern Art Museum of the City of Paris, introduced young British artists to France. Then, after drawing huge crowds to the Royal Academy in 1997, ''Sensation,'' the iconic exhibition of this generation, traveled first to Berlin and will soon open at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Gummy Lovers, All Grown Up
description: THE plain yet brightly colored package is not meant to grab a child's eye, and the flavors of the gummies inside -- muscat, litchi, peach, melon, pineapple, kiwi, orange -- might not appeal to children. These are gummies for grown-ups, resembling gelees served on petit-four plates in fine restaurants, as soft as marshmallows on the tongue.

title: As Economies Revive Abroad, Dollar Falls vs. Key Currencies
description: The United States dollar has begun to slide against the Japanese yen and the European single currency, as investors turn their attention to reviving economies in Asia and Europe.

title: You Can't Tell the Players, Even With a Program
description: With two of its star performers, Milt Jackson and Billy Higgins, scratched because of illness, Sunday's five-hour Charlie Parker Jazz Festival in Tompkins Square Park leaned on its walk-on guests to save the day. The singers Etta Jones and Andy Bey and the saxophonists Gary Bartz and Jackie McLean played a few songs apiece, focusing the crowd's attention and accurately defining the strengths of each musician.

title: Glass Slipper Is Hard to Fill
description: Though CBS has mainly invoked Cinderella as its preferred metaphor, the network has, in truth, turned the hunt for a female co-anchor to pair with Bryant Gumbel on its revamped morning show into a summerlong game of Clue.

title: ANTI-TAKEOVER MEASURE
description: The board of the largest Canadian airline, Air Canada, approved a poison pill plan to give the Montreal-based airline and its advisers more time to evaluate an unsolicited hostile bid from the Onex Corporation and consider other proposals. Under the shareholder-rights plan, an additional Air Canada share would be issued for each share held if any group makes an invited purchase of more than 10 percent of the company's stock. Air Canada also set a special meeting for Jan. 7 to consider Onex's offer. Last week, Onex, a Toronto-based leveraged buyout specialist, proposed to buy and combine Air Canada and the Canadian Airlines Corporation of Calgary, Alberta. Timothy Pritchard

description: A strong tremor shook already devastated towns in northwestern Turkey today, bringing several buildings crashing down and causing at least one death.

title: On Day 2, a Bad Case of Tennis Withdrawal
description: The United States Open extracted its usual emotional baggage yesterday from the combatants who took to the windblown hardcourts at the National Tennis Center: frayed nerves, gray hair, stage fright; the mean streak that flares when a defending Grand Slam champion finds a friend blocking her passage to the second round; the adrenaline that flows when a two-time defending champion finds himself in danger of becoming the first incumbent ever to fail in the first round. But Patrick Rafter, the two-time defending champion, suffered longest, hardest and last. Worse, he suffered in vain.

title: Capriati Easily Passes Another Test
description: At age 14, Jennifer Capriati became the youngest tennis player to be ranked in the top 10 world ranking. At age 19, Iva Majoli was seeded ninth in the French Open and became the lowest-seeded player to win a Grand Slam tournament in the era of open tennis.

title: A Palace Fit for a Fugitive And Ukraine's Ex-Premier
description: Even in a state familiar with jaw-dropping displays of wealth, a mansion set on 18 acres in northern California is opulent. Once occupied by the Hollywood star Eddie Murphy, the property in Marin County boasts two helicopter landing pads, five dog kennels, a barn-sized ballroom, granite floors inlaid with brass, and gold-plated doorknobs. And it was sold last September for $6.75 million -- in cash.

title: The March and the Constitution
description: The Federal District Court in New York ruled properly yesterday that the city's attempt to prevent the so-called Million Youth March violated the constitutional right to free speech. Instead of appealing to a higher court, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani needs to issue the necessary permits and concentrate on making this a safe and orderly gathering. To escalate the public statements and the legal battle would only inflame racial tensions -- and provide the archbigot Khallid Abdul Muhammad with free publicity and a wider audience.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Federal appeals court ruling that journalists' notes and other unpublished or unbroadcast materials are often protected from subpoena in Federal lawsuits -- a reversal of an earlier decision by the same court -- omitted the names of the judges who ruled. The panel in the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit comprised Joseph M. McLaughlin, Arthur D. Spatt and Pierre N. Leval. Judge Fred I. Parker was on the appellate panel that ruled on the case last September, but he recused himself from the reconsideration of the case without explanation. He was succeeded by Judge Leval, who wrote the new decision.

title: Secret To Cold Soup: Hot Melon
description: I LIKE gazpacho, but the ultimate minimalist technique -- pureeing a few tomatoes, a red pepper, some onion, oil and vinegar in a blender -- is not the best. This yields a pulverized salad that I find coarse, its raw flavor strong and entirely too lingering. The vinegar, which adds necessary acidity, is also overpowering.

title: F.B.I. Chief Says He Supports An Outside Inquiry on Waco
description: Hoping to head off any impression of a conflict of interest, Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. wholeheartedly supports an outside investigation into the bureau's failure to disclose the use of incendiary devices in the 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound, a bureau spokesman said tonight.

title: W.N.B.A. Finals: Liberty Showing Comets Respect
description: When the celebration finally ended on Monday night after the Liberty earned a berth in the W.N.B.A. finals with a victory over the Charlotte Sting, Teresa Weatherspoon placed a call to her college coach, Louisiana Tech's Leon Barmore. After complimenting her on her play and offering congratulations, he followed with a message that she knew was coming.

title: Keyes Draws the Few, but Devoted
description: As he wanders the nation prophesying a political apocalypse, Alan L. Keyes, the staunchly conservative radio talk show host, is the invisible man in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Profit Declines 83% at Neiman Marcus
description: Neiman Marcus Group Inc., the luxury department store chain that is to be spun off by the publisher Harcourt General Inc. later this year, said today that its fourth-quarter profit plunged 83 percent because it had marked down prices and moved up a sales promotion.

title: Argentine Jet Crashes on Takeoff; as Many as 80 Feared Dead
description: An Argentine Boeing 737-200 airliner carrying at least 100 people crashed on takeoff here tonight, slamming into a golf driving range and catching fire, officials said. Early reports estimated that as many as 80 people were killed and at least 23 people were injured, including motorists and pedestrians.

title: Prices of Gasoline Steady
description: Regular gasoline prices averaged $1.233 a gallon last week at the pump, little changed from a week earlier, as the busy summer driving season winds down, a Government survey showed. The average price for regular self-serve gasoline fell 0.1 cent from the week before, according to a Department of Energy survey of 800 gasoline stations. Two weeks ago retail prices were at $1.236, their highest in 23 months as refinery problems lifted prices.

title: Mayor Defends Police Shooting Of Violent Man
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the fatal police shooting of a mentally disturbed, hammer-wielding man in Borough Park, Brooklyn, which brought hundreds of angry Hasidic protesters into the streets of the heavily Orthodox neighborhood late Monday night.

title: Lawyers as Angels
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about an interruption of on-line trading at a discount brokerage firm referred imprecisely to the company. It was Charles Schwab; the mention of ''E-trade'' was not a reference to the E*Trade Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, PATRICIA E. (TRISH), RN, PHD.
description: GREENE-Patricia E. (Trish), RN, PhD. ''Cancer Practice'', an American Cancer Society publication, mourns the death of Trish Greene. Her vision of a multidisciplinary journal dedicated to promoting the highest standards of cancer care was the critical element in the founding of the journal. We pledge to carry on her dream. Gen Foley, Editor Tamar Wallace, Managing Editor

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-HOWARD 9/1/53-7/9/92 HAPPY BIRTHDAY. WISHING YOU WERE HERE... NOT ONLY TODAY... EACH & EVERYDAY. WE ALL MISS YOU SO.

title: C. Roland Christensen, 80, Professor of Business
description: C. Roland Christensen, an influential Harvard Business School professor who helped create the field of business strategy and was an authority on the use of the case method in teaching, died on Saturday. He was 80.

title: Israel, Syria and the Road to Peace Not Taken
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's brief visit to the Middle East this week bears a remarkable resemblance to the visit paid to the region six years ago by her predecessor, Warren Christopher. Like that visit, it is likely to determine the progress of the Israeli-Arab peace process along either the Syrian or Palestinian track for years to come.

title: Joan Braden Is Dead at 77; Hostess to a Capital Elite
description: Joan Braden, a former State Department official who was a hostess and friend to high-ranking Washington figures and whose eight children inspired the ABC television series ''Eight Is Enough,'' died on Monday in Alexandria, Va. She was 77 and a longtime resident of the Washington area.

title: Prisoner to Be Released Based on DNA Evidence
description: A man imprisoned for 17 years on a rape conviction was ordered released on Monday after DNA evidence exonerated him, his lawyer said last night.

title: Much More AIDS in Prisons Than in General Population
description: The prevalence of AIDS among prisoners in the United States is five times that of the general population, and the rates for some other sexually transmitted diseases are even higher, scientists said yesterday.

title: DaimlerChrysler Plans to Expand Plant
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the third-largest auto maker in the United States, plans to spend $624 million to expand its Wisconsin engine plant as part of a $3.5 billion upgrade of its United States power train operations.

title: Seeking a Lost Continent A Bit West of the Hudson; Geologists Comb Harriman Park for Clues To Rodinia, a Billion-Year-Old Mystery
description: About a billion years ago, or so the prevailing geological theory has it, the Earth's continental plates collided, pushing up mountains the height of the Himalayas and creating a supercontinent geologists call Rodinia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWY, THEA
description: LOEWY-Thea. We extend our sincerest condolences to our dear friend, Manfred Loewy on the loss of his beloved wife Thea. A longtime supporter and Golden Founder of our Medical Center, this kind and caring woman devoted her life to Tzedakah and Chesed. May the warm memories of this special individual bring solace to Manfred, her sister, Erika Weilburg and the entire family and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

title: Elvis's Temperature Is Rising, and They're All Shook Up
description: What would action-adventure screenwriters do without Elvis Presley as a reference point? To their credit, the writers of the comically tinged thriller ''Chill Factor'' have at least had the wit to dream up a variation or two on the cliche ''Elvis has left the building.'' In the movie's opening scene, as a deadly chemical defoliant (code name Elvis) is about to be tested on a remote Pacific island, a technician announces, ''Elvis is approaching the stage.'' Later in the film, we have ''Elvis on ice.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN SLEET LEVINE, BARBARA
description: VAN SLEET LEVINE-Barbara. Our beloved mother and friend Barbara Van Sleet Levine passed away on Saturday, August 28. She always put her children before herself. For further information, please call 908-889-7125.

title: BRITISH AEROSPACE SEEKS AID
description: As it tries to build the largest aircraft in the world, British Aerospace applied for $:500 million ($794.5 million) from the British Government to help pay for the endeavor. The double-decker planes will carry 600 passengers on long flights. The project is expected to create 22,000 jobs in Britain. British Aerospace will be responsible for building the wings in connection with its other partners in Airbus Industrie. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Militias Raise Tensions After Timor Votes
description: Anti-independence thugs who have terrorized East Timor for months reasserted themselves today, one day after an extraordinarily peaceful referendum on the region's future in which, officials said, 98.6 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots.

title: INSIDE
description: Argentine Jetliner Crashes

title: Sports of The Times; They'll Miss Pete Sampras Soon Enough
description: THE fans scurry around the premises, looking for upsets, looking for interesting new players, chasing down phenomena like Alexandra Stevenson suffering a sundown massacre. They can convince themselves that Master Pete is still in there, whacking down somebody in three sets, in front of a few thousand diehards in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Requiem for Beanie Babies. Or Maybe Not.
description: The maker of Beanie Babies, Ty Inc., created a frenzy yesterday when it posted this announcement on its World Wide Web site: ''All Beanies will be retired'' as of Dec. 31.

title: Prof. William A. Niering, 75, Expert on Ecology of Wetlands
description: Prof. William Albert Niering, an internationally recognized expert on the ecology of wetlands and tidal marshes, died Monday in New London, where he had just addressed the incoming class of 2003 at Connecticut College. He was 75 and lived in Gales Ferry, Conn.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL NAMES ITSELF AS BUYER OF AFC CABLE
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it was the unnamed suitor that agreed to acquire AFC Cable Systems Inc. for stock valued at $575 million. AFC, which is based in Providence, R.I., and makes electrical and communications cable, said on Monday that it had agreed to be taken over by a buyer it declined to identify. Tyco, based in Bermuda, is a diversified manufacturing and service company with annual revenue of almost $20 billion. AFC had 1998 sales of $272.8 million. Its stock rose $2.125 a share, to $43. Tyco agreed to buy the company for $45 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOSLER, CAROLYN ATLAS
description: SOSLER-Carolyn Atlas. April 10, 1940-September 1, 1993. The world breaks everyone and afterward many are strong at the broken places. But those that will not break it kills. It kills the very good and the very gentle and the very brave.'' Hemingway. You are always with us. Pop, Neil, Andree

title: London Journal; Two Years On, Diana Is the 'Forgotten' Princess
description: The death of Diana, Princess of Wales, on this date in 1997 marked the beginning of an outpouring of grief and national stock-taking that astonished no one more than the British themselves. They awoke to find that they lived in a country whose most famous lip was suddenly a trembling lower one.

title: People
description: Peter Boczar, account director at Leo Burnett Company, Hong Kong, was named senior vice president at the agency.

description: I ran into Kato Kaelin the other night.

description: THE CONTENDER

title: Top-Tier Firms On Wall Street Are Merger Shy
description: Though many investors think it is just a matter of time before America's big securities houses hook up with banks, Wall Street firms are proving to be reluctant merger partners.

title: Taking Tea and Lots of Meetings; Prince Edward, Producer, Comes to Hollywood as Pitchman
description: Hollywood is a town that, for all the mumbo jumbo about creativity, breeds a striking sameness -- in dress (Armani casual), in automobiles (anything outrageously expensive), in speech patterns (''Love ya!''), in ambition (multimillion-dollar guaranteed contracts) and even in the frequency with which people talk about seeking something different.

title: Young and Gifted Students Thrive in Summer Classes
description: Stephanie Monteiro spent the month of August in a college classroom with the likes of Einstein, Newton and Euclid as she investigated the everyday applications of algebra. She is an A student. Her math score on the College Board exams, 520, ranks her above the national average for university-bound seniors.

title: Putting a Poised Expression on the Face of Success
description: I HAD a panicky moment trying to make a reservation at Mignon, a sunny new Provencal restaurant in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, where new restaurants seem to bubble up weekly. I called and called one night, but nobody answered. I had greatly enjoyed the restaurant once. Could it have suddenly failed? I tried again the next day and got an explanation.

title: Metro Business; State Officials Mull Bid by Bell Atlantic
description: Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local phone company, made one last pitch to New York State regulators in an effort to gain permission to offer long-distance service to its customers in the state.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, MARION
description: GELLER-Marion. Age 84, formerly of Manhattan. Architect/designer, playwright, past president Rosehill Community Association, died August 25, 1999 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Wife of the late Abraham W. Geller, Architect. Survived by daughters Amy and Janice, son-in law-Kevin, grandsons Zevi and Owen. You are dearly missed and loved always. Memorial to be announced.

title: $18 Million Trading Loss at Kaufman & Broad
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, one of the nation's largest home builders, said today that it had lost $18.1 million from unauthorized trading of mortgages by an employee.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about a party for the East Hampton Day Care Center misstated the occupation of a board member, Nancy Goell, at the Eileen Fisher store in the town. She is the store's manager, not the owner.

title: Groups Sue School Board Over Promotion Policy
description: Two student advocacy groups filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to block the New York City Board of Education from holding back thousands of pupils who failed summer school.

title: 2 of 3 Tenors Pay to Settle Tax Dispute In Germany
description: Luciano Pavarotti has paid an undisclosed sum to a German court to settle a tax evasion case arising from a lucrative world tour by the so-called Three Tenors in 1996, the prosecutor's office in Mannheim, Germany, has announced. Placido Domingo reached a similar settlement last week.

title: Excerpts From Ruling Permitting Rally
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's ruling by Judge Denny Chin of Federal District Court allowing Khallid Abdul Muhammad to hold a youth rally in Harlem that he calls the Million Youth March (M.Y.M.):

title: Jets' Corners: Diminutive and Dogged
description: Once upon a time in Texas, Ray Mickens and Aaron Glenn had a dream -- they would both be playing in the National Football League. ''I never imagined, though, being on the same team with Aaron,'' Mickens said today.

title: Giuliani the Juror Calmly Hears the First Day of Testimony
description: There have been celebrity litigants and there have been celebrity lawyers. Now there is a juror who brings his own security team to court and stops to shake hands with voters -- er, courthouse employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, HARRIET
description: BLOOMBERG - Harriet, of Swampscott, Mass. and Palm Beach, Florida, August 31, 1999. Wife of Harvey. Mother of Jeffrey Bloomberg and Sandy Bloomberg. Four grandchildren. Services at Temple Emanu-El, Marblehead, Mass., Wednesday, September 1, 2PM. Remembrances to the Harriet Bloomberg Research Fund at Mass. General Hospital Development Office, 100 Charles River Plaza (suite 600) Boston, MA 02114.

title: ISS GROUP MAKES ACQUISITION TO ADD SECURITY SERVICES
description: ISS Group Inc., a maker of security software for Internet commerce, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy closely held Netrex Secure Solutions for about $57.1 million in stock to offer customers constant security monitoring services. ISS, which is based in Atlanta, makes the Safesuite security system. Netrex, which is based in Southfield, Mich., had revenue of about $21.8 million last year. It has about 150 employees. The company had revenue of about $21.8 million last year. The acquisition of Netrex enables ISS to monitor computer systems for Internet companies from remote sites.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cutting Through Fog of Growth for Net Retailers
description: Financial reports from Internet retailers are like the pronouncements of the Delphic Priestess: future focused and infamously inscrutable.

title: Why Genetically Altered Food Won't Conquer Hunger
description: In the debate over genetically altered foods, proponents like Senator Richard Luger, the Indiana Republican, argue that such products will be essential if we are to feed the world.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDRESEN, BERGTHOR F.
description: ENDRESEN-Bergthor F., a prominent aviation businessman, formerly of Rye, NY, and a resident of Fisher Island, Florida, died on August 25 at his home. He was 78. Mr. Endresen was born in Norway and served as a pilot with the Royal Norwegian Air Force during World War II. He later became the Chief Pilot to the King of Norway. After the war, he immigrated to the U.S. and settled in Rye. His interest in aviation led him to form Amnor, Inc., and later American Avitron, Inc. which he sold to Lear Siegler, Inc. Mr. Endresen was the former Chairman and Co-founder with his son of Aerotech World Trade Corp. in White Plains, NY. Mr. Endresen was a Board member of the Union Savings Bank of Mamaroneck and a member of the Wings Club and American Yacht Club. He is survived by his son, grandchildren, brother, and wife. His first wife and other son predeceased him. A memorial service will be held at American Yacht Club in Rye, at 4:30PM on Thursday, September 2; and one on September 6 on Fisher Island. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cardiac Prevention Center, C/O The Mount Sinai Medical Center Foundation, 4300 Alton Road, Miami Beach, Florida 33140.

title: Editorial Observer; Now It's the President's Turn to Gaze Adoringly
description: First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for Senate this week displayed what may be an unexpected new hazard -- her husband. The problem is not any new question of ethics or morality or bad taste threatening on the horizon. It is simply that President Clinton can play a political crowd the way Van Cliburn plays a piano. As the First Couple proved this week, no matter how well she campaigns with her spouse, she is still a political prodigy sharing the stage with a maestro.

title: Lucent in Deal to Develop Digital Radios
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said today that its radio division would join two other consumer electronic companies in developing radio receivers that can read digital signals.

title: Poised and Playful in the Legal Fast Lane
description: FOR an overachiever, Preeta D. Bansal is unusually merry. That's the luxury of one whose mind is efficient as well as dazzling, so that by day's end, she can indeed skip out of the office. ''There are day campers and sleep-away campers,'' Ms. Bansal said, referring to dedication to work. ''I've always been a day camper.''

description: The Days of Wine and Wieners

description: BONNER-Charles William III, 71, died Monday, August 30, Greenwich, CT. Father of Keith Bonner, Charles W. Bonner IV, Ian Bonner, Caroline Bonner. Brother of Michael Bonner, Christopher Bonner, Sharon Caulfield. Grandfather of two. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 P.M. on Friday, September 3, at Christ Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Meridian House, 929 Newfield Ave., Stamford, CT 06905

title: Successful 'Millionaire'
description: The success of ABC's summer game show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' has been so staggering -- it was the No. 1-rated show again last week and led ABC to a resounding weekly ratings victory -- and apparently so unexpected, that it left the air on Sunday night after its two-week run without being able to tell viewers when to tune in next.

title: The Fire and Ice Of Asian Noodles
description: THE Chinese have the perfect antidote to a late-summer heat wave: cold wheat noodles, served with a piquant sesame sauce. The soothing noodles are ice, the sauce fire, in the form of chili paste, ginger and garlic.

title: Though Japanese Save Diligently, The Nation Sinks Deeper in Debt
description: One of the striking paradoxes of Japan is that this is a country with the greatest savers in the industrialized world, and yet everywhere one looks there is debt.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERARD, FRED N.
description: GERARD-Fred N. With love, honor and respect. We miss you terribly. Daniele and Gregory

title: Strawberry to Join Yankees Today
description: Some of Darryl Strawberry's dry cleaning and boxes were already inside his corner locker at Yankee Stadium yesterday, the locker that he has not officially used since last September but that he will return to today. It should be an emotional day for Strawberry, who sometimes must have wondered if he would ever be back.

title: What's Up at Prep School? Culture Shock
description: ''Outside Providence'' is about the circumstances that plunk Tim Dunphy (Shawn Hatosy) into a Connecticut prep school classroom, where he winds up answering ''Hamlet'' when asked to name his favorite author. He also tries ''NASA'' when asked who launched the New Deal.

title: Some Question Police Guidelines on Confrontations With the Mentally Ill
description: When New York City police officers confront an emotionally disturbed person, they are required to take several clear-cut steps under the Police Department's guidelines.

title: Neighbors Ask 'Why?' After a Killing
description: After a night in which hundreds of Orthodox Jews poured from their homes to protest the police's killing of a mentally ill man in Borough Park, crowds congregated again yesterday at the scene of the shooting as officials in the community urged restraint and offered support for the Police Department.

title: Washington, Pressed by Inquiries, Tries Again to Justify Bold Economic Aid for Russia
description: The Clinton Administration, pressed by investigations into money laundering and capital flight out of Russia, is being forced anew to justify its policies of bold economic assistance to Moscow during the last seven years.

title: Giuliani's Response Shows a World of Differences Between Two Shootings
description: Within 15 hours of the fatal shooting by the police of a hammer-wielding man in Borough Park, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met with about a dozen of the neighborhood's Orthodox Jewish leaders yesterday morning at City Hall, where Police Commissioner Howard Safir and other top commanders briefed them on the case.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Begins Review
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn in Bridgewater, N.J., has placed the accounts of its Cortaid, Kaopectate and Pediacare brands into review. The accounts for Cortaid and Pediacare had been at Doner, in Southfield, Mich., and Kaopectate had been at FerrellCalvillo Communications in New York. Billings for the accounts were estimated at $12 million to $15 million. Mark Rothman & Associates is the review consultant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIKER, BERTRAM J.
description: DIKER-Bertram J. Died August 29, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Rhona. Loving father of Susan and son-in-law William. Devoted and loving grandfather of Alexandra. He is also survived by his brother Charles. Born in New York on April 6, 1931, he was the son of Helen Hoffner and Daniel Diker. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Business School. We was a retired New York investment advisor, businessman and philanthropist. He was a resident of Southampton, N.Y. and a Director of the Southampton Hospital. Funeral service Wednesday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Subway Service to Resume On the Williamsburg Bridge
description: Four months after a construction project stopped trains from using the Williamsburg Bridge, transit officials said yesterday that service would resume today on the J, M and Z lines.

title: Mr. Holbrooke's Return to Kosovo
description: Richard Holbrooke chose wisely in starting his new job as America's delegate to the United Nations with a three-day trip to Kosovo. Peace and democracy will take root in the province only if Washington and the U.N. closely coordinate their efforts. Mr. Holbrooke, an experienced Balkan hand, is well suited to help make that happen. He enjoys President Clinton's full confidence and is also on good terms with the U.N. Secretary General, Kofi Annan, and the organization's chief administrator in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AFFYMETRIX INC., Santa Clara, Calif., named its chief executive, Stephen Fodor, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding John Diekman, who will become vice chairman. Susan Siegel, senior vice president, will succeed Mr. Fodor as president.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about the Drudge Report's on-line disclosure of part of a preliminary article list circulated within the New York Times newsroom misidentified the Times division that distributes such lists to newspaper clients. It is The New York Times News Service, not The New York Times Syndicate.

title: Intel's New Processor Line To Focus on Internet Links
description: Trying to expand its core personal computer business into a new market, the Intel Corporation will announce a new family of processors on Wednesday capable of powering the devices that route data through corporate networks and the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONSTEIN, DR. MELVIN
description: BRONSTEIN-Dr. Melvin. We miss you and love you greatly. You're in our hearts and minds every moment. Your loving family and wife

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOS, MICHAEL
description: DANOS-Michael. Theoretical physicist, Visiting Scholar at the Enrico Fermi Institute, Univ. of Chicago, formerly of the National Institute of Standards & Technology. Born January 10, 1922, Riga, Latvia, died Washington, Aug. 30, 1999 after a stroke. Loved and honored by his wife, Sheila Fitzpatrick, daughters Johanna & Tamara Danos, son, Arpad, son-in-law Bill Danos, grandchildren Elvin & Elena, brothers Arpad and Jan of Latvia, and Victoria Danos. His quest was to understand Nature.

title: Respected Ump Faces End of Career
description: Rich Garcia has made judgments and rulings for the past 25 years as an umpire in the American League, and yesterday his career was at the mercy of a Federal judge in Philadelphia. The judge was meeting with lawyers for the umpires' union and Major League Baseball to discuss baseball's plan to release 22 umpires after today. The union had requested an injunction to keep that from happening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DAVID, DR.
description: SCHWARTZ-David, Dr. Mt. Horeb Lodge FS of I, announces with deep regret the passing of a devoted member, Past President, Secretary of the Insurance Fund, Secretary of Mt. Horeb Lodge for over 40 years. His devotion to the Lodge will be long remembered and his memory will be an everlasting tribute. To his wife Florence our deepest sympathy, and to his family our deepest sympathy. Nat Tallen, President

title: Planned French Merger Lifts Most European Retail Stocks
description: The planned merger of the French retailers Carrefour S.A. and Promodes S.A. sent shares of other leading European food retailers sharply higher today as investors and analysts wagered on the companies' chances of merging or being acquired. Fourteen of the 20 largest publicly traded retail stocks surged amid rumor after rumor that a show-stopping deal was in the works.

title: Underwood Surfaces With a New Attitude
description: Dimitrius Underwood finally surfaced at the Miami Dolphins' training camp today, shrugging off his tardiness but professing to have regained his dedication to football.

description: A Former Chief Out of the Shadow

title: Bomb Hits Moscow Mall; Some Tie It to Festering Caucasus War
description: A powerful explosion rocked Moscow's fanciest shopping center tonight, bringing the threat of terrorism close to the Kremlin.

title: Ceviche, in a Flash
description: SUSHI and sashimi opened the door to raw fish; salmon tartares and tuna carpaccios took it beyond Japanese restaurants and onto mainstream tables everywhere. Now, ceviche has expanded the world of flavors and textures created in fish when no cooking is involved.

title: Migliaccio Basks In Money and Title
description: Terri Migliaccio's victory at the women's Met Open last week was overshadowed by Mark Brown's six-under-par 65 that led to his victory in the men's Met Open.

description: AKPATA-Toks Gone from our soul. Forever in our hearts. Mom, Reggie, Family & Friends

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKMORE, JOAN
description: BLACKMORE-Joan, 64, died on Friday, August 27, at her home in Greenwich, CT. from cancer. She was the wife of Robert C. Blackmore. Born in Cape Town, South Africa, July 14, 1935, she was the daughter of Muriel P. Ruick and the late Felix DeCola. Mrs. Blackmore grew up in Los Angeles where she graduated from Westlake School for Girls and UCLA. She was the mother of Robin Jalajas of Newburyport, MA., and Karyn Hagy of Westlake Village, CA. Grandmother of four. A memorial service was held in Greenwich. Memorial Contributions may be made to Expedition Inspiration Breast Cancer Fund, PO Box 4289, Ketchum, ID. 83340.

title: A Squeeze and a Slam by Astros Leave Mets Feeling Whiplashed
description: This was going to be an antidote for those still feeling punchy from Monday's mashball marathon. This was going to be a pitchers' duel between the Mets and Astros that featured the execution of one of baseball's most fundamental -- yet still breathtaking -- plays.

title: Venezuelan Leader Names an Ally as Head of Oil Monopoly
description: President Hugo Chavez moved to solidify his control over the powerful state-run oil monopoly today by appointing an ally as the company's new chief.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I started experimenting with the wood-burning oven at Beacon, I found that the combination of high heat and wood smoke worked extremely well with fish, especially trout. Trout is relatively fatty, allowing it to take on the taste of the smoke while the flesh stays juicy. The fire crisps the skin, giving the soft fish a bit of crunch. It's a terrific cooking method.

title: In Detroit, Empathy for Striking Teachers
description: There is nothing like a last-minute teachers strike to throw parenthood into chaos, but in this heavily unionized city, many parents lined up today to support the strike that left lots of them unexpectedly spending the day with their children.

title: Gillette Says Big Holder May Sell Stake
description: The Gillette Company said today that the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, its second-biggest shareholder, may sell part or all of its 4.7 percent stake in the company, worth about $2.4 billion at current prices.

title: College Board Scores Vary Little From Previous Year's
description: Scores on the College Board exams remained roughly constant last year compared with the previous year, as boys continued to outscore girls by more than 40 points and white students continued to do better than underrepresented minorities, according to figures released yesterday by the College Board.

title: A Defendant Tied to Abuse Of Other Boys
description: A Westchester County man awaiting trial for allegedly molesting five boys has been indicted on additional charges that he sexually abused four other boys whom he met through Internet chat rooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOILLOT, LYNN HOCHSCHILD
description: BOILLOT-Lynn Hochschild. On August 29th, 1999. Beloved mother of Etienne, Paul, Dominique and Nicolas, mother-in-law of Lisa and Tanya. Attended The Brearley School in New York and Barnard College; received a Master's in Fine Arts from The Institute of Fine Arts. Served as a Trustee of The Adirondack Musuem, Paul Smith's College & The Langeloth Foundation; was an enthusiastic docent at the Whitney Museum. Her ashes will be scattered in the Adirondack Mountains and a memorial service will be held this fall. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to The Adirondack Museum, Blue Mountain Lake, NY 12812 or to Paul Smith's College, Paul Smith, NY 12970.

description: Despite a jump in crude oil prices, the Mexican Government will reap enough of a windfall this year only to stabilize its accounts, and it plans no spending sprees, Energy Minister Luis Tellez said today.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: CAR DISTRACTIONS -- And you thought it was dangerous to talk on a cell phone while driving. How about carrying on a videoconference? Brabus, a German auto company, is marketing the Megacar, a fully wired automobile that comes with a 150-kilobits-per-second wireless connection (more than enough for video phone calls), an Intel Pentium III chip, Windows NT and a 17-inch monitor. The price is $300,000, although the connections can be installed in any car for $90,000.

title: Financial Executive at Iridium Resigns
description: Iridium L.L.C., which filed for bankruptcy protection last month, said today that Leo Mondale had resigned as chief financial officer, the second occupant of the post to leave in five months.

title: Subaru isn't tampering with success; it's just going to do what it has been doing -- only bigger.
description: SUBARU is rolling out the largest advertising campaign in its history, but don't expect to see a new cast of characters or any other drastic changes to its existing theme. Instead, the company is sticking by an old adage: ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.''

title: Lightly Used Wingate Re-signs
description: David Wingate, who appeared in 20 games for the Knicks last season as a guard and forward off the bench after being signed as a free agent on Feb. 1, was re-signed yesterday.

title: Is a Renewed Japan a Threat to Its Neighbors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Click Here for the Ivory Tower
description: FOR almost as long as students have been going to college, educators have been trying to bring college home to them. More than 100 years ago at Cornell University, professors traveled to rural areas on horseback to teach farmers about the latest agricultural research. Correspondence courses have been available for decades, first through the mail and then through television and video.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITROS, MARA
description: BITROS-Mara. The staff and students of Career Blazers Learning Center deeply mourn the untimely death of our dear friend Mara Bitros. A compassionate and caring individual, Mara made a significant impact on those around her. Her strong commitment to assisting dislocated workers and disadvantaged individuals in finding rewarding careers is remembered and cherished. Mara's indomitable spirit and strength of purpose remain an inspiration to us all. Her friendship, warmth, kindness and professionalism shall be profoundly missed. We express our sincere sympathy to her beloved husband Jim and the entire family. We hope that your shared memories of Mara will bring comfort and solace to each of you at this time of sadness and loss. Paul Viboch, Exec. Vice-President Stella Garlick, Vice-President Iris Rivera, Vice-President

title: The Shooting in Borough Park
description: The fatal shooting of a mentally disturbed man in Brooklyn has raised concerns again about the use of excessive force by New York City police officers. Gidone Busch was shot 12 times by police in a confrontation on Monday evening. Six officers were called to the scene when Mr. Busch, an Orthodox Jew who lived in the largely Hasidic neighborhood of Borough Park, was behaving in a threatening manner to others on the street. The officers tried to use pepper spray to subdue him, but some opened fire after he struck one of them with a hammer and defied orders to drop it.

title: Applications to Medical Schools Decline for Second Straight Year
description: The number of applications to medical schools dropped nearly 5 percent last year, continuing a decline that began in 1997 after an all-time high in 1996, according to a study published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: For One Teacher, a Lesson About E-Mail and Privacy
description: IT'S 3 in the morning, and not a creature is stirring, except for the mouse. My mouse. I can't sleep, which is why I'm in my nightie, on line at the computer, my study dark except for the light cast by my monitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, CLAIRE (NEE SACHS)
description: MELTZER-Claire (nee Sachs), age 86 in Tamarac, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died August 28, 1999 at her home in Florida. She was the beloved wife of the late George (Max); mother of Michael and Martin, grandmother of Jessica, Melissa, Tracy, Deborah and Gary; great grandmother of Nina and Jacob. Mother-in-law of Laurie and Nancy. Her love, strength, guidance and wisdom will always be with us. Memorial contributions may be made to Hadassah or any other charity.

title: SECURITIES UNIT INVESTIGATED
description: The Republic New York Corporation, which owns Bank of New York, said yesterday that its securities unit was being investigated by Japanese regulators because of transactions with an unidentified client. Republic of New York said the investigation was being conducted by the Financial Supervisory Agency of Japan. Regulators in Japan are investigating the Tokyo branch of a company affiliated with a client of the Republic New York Securities Corporation's Philadelphia office, Republic said. Republic said it was also investigating and replaced management of the unit's futures division. It also suspended the securities unit's chief executive.

description: MANHATTAN

title: New Amtrak Train Delayed Because of Wear on Wheels
description: Amtrak's new 150-mile-an-hour express train, which was supposed to start service between Washington and Boston this year, will be several months late because the wheels on the passenger coaches vibrate at high speeds and are wearing out too quickly, the railroad and the builders said today.

title: Restoring the Future, 1862 Style
description: THIS was a summer of roses for Carol and Millard Prisant. The Long Island couple vacationed at home simply by stepping through screen doors onto a rose-bedecked porch and drinking in a view of the long harbor in their backyard.

title: Finding Love or Friendship
description: To the Editor:

title: Eugene Ostroff, 71, Guardian Of Photography's Treasures
description: Eugene Ostroff, a former curator of photography at the Smithsonian Institution, an authority on the history of photography as a technology and an influential lecturer and writer on photographic conservation, died on Aug. 26 in Washington, where he lived. He was 71.

title: Line Forming (Wealthy Bidders Only) for Jets
description: Shhh. The Jets are being sold. The new buyer probably won't be chosen soon, perhaps not until the end of the season. But in the quiet fashion that was the hallmark of the team's late owner, Leon Hess, his estate is receiving interest from at least 10 suitors, including Charles F. Dolan, the Cablevision chairman; John McMullen, the Devils' owner, and Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics heir.

title: MANAGEMENT-LED GROUP BIDS TO BUY GP STRATEGIES
description: The GP Strategies Corporation, a technical-training and management-training company, received an offer yesterday from its management and an investment fund to take the company private for about $149.6 million in cash. The management group and a buyout fund of Veronis Suhler & Associates Inc. in New York offered to pay $13 for each common share of the New York-based GP Strategies. They also offered $14.625 for each class B capital share. The common shares of GP Strategies rose $3.5625, to $11.375.

title: Economic Scene; Why all the fuss over pint-sized Ecuador? Brady bonds.
description: HAS the looming possibility that Ecuador will default on its foreign debts provoked an excessive amount of hand-wringing? At first glance, it surely appears so. Ecuador produces less output in a year -- about $15 billion -- than the United States produces in a day. The financial travails of such a pint-sized economy would not ordinarily threaten anyone beyond its own borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, SALLY RUTH
description: FRANK-Sally Ruth, 73, died on August 31 after a long illness. A retired New York City schoolteacher, she was beloved of her many friends and family. She is survived by her uncle, Ralph Sheffer, of Westport, Conn., and cousins Ann Sheffer, also of Westport; Douglas Sheffer of Aspen, Colo.; and Jonathan Sheffer of New York City; and Richard Frank of Laguna Beach, Calif. A funeral service will be held at 10:15 A.M. Thursday, September 2, at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in memory of Sally R. Frank to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, Lymphoma Research.

title: TELEFONICA PROFIT UP 32%
description: The big Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica S.A. said its first-half operating profit was 776.6 million euros ($825 million), up nearly 32 percent from a year earlier. The earnings soared on strong demand in the domestic wireless business, although Telefonica's profits grew more slowly in Latin America, where it is the dominant telecommunications carrier, because of sluggish performances in Chile, Argentina, Peru and Venezuela, which the company attributed to the region's economic problems.

title: New Yamaha Receiver for PC's Sounds Good and Looks Good
description: With the growing popularity of large computer monitors, high-fidelity sound cards and internal DVD-ROM and MP3 players, the quality of personal computer speaker systems is getting the sort of cachet once associated only with the latest microprocessors.

title: Remembering Their War, Germans Embrace the First Victims
description: Germany today marked the 60th anniversary of its invasion of Poland and the start of World War II by declaring that its eastern neighbor should have a place in the European Union as soon as possible.

title: HENLYS OF BRITAIN TO ACQUIRE BLUE BIRD FOR $428 MILLION
description: The British bus maker Henlys Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy the Blue Bird Corporation, a privately held United States school bus manufacturer, for around $428 million and $237 million in assumed debt. Blue Bird, based in Macon, Ga., also produces commercial buses and recreational vehicles. It is owned by its current management and Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. Blue Bird had 1998 sales of $626.4 million. Henlys said the purchase of Blue Bird would increase its annual revenue to about $1.17 billion. Henlys and Volvo A.B. of Sweden, which owns 10 percent of it, already own two North American bus manufacturers: Prevost of Canada and Nova Bus of Roswell, N.M.

title: The Best of Jurisprudence: Reliving Days in the High Court
description: The Supremes have a new compilation disk, but don't expect to hear Diana Ross on this one. Instead, the new CD-ROM platter is crammed with more than 70 hours of often passionate legal debate that was recorded on tape in the nation's highest court.

title: Respecting the Vote in East Timor
description: East Timor's long struggle to control its own destiny is at a decisive juncture. Monday's United Nations-supervised referendum on the territory's future status went off peacefully and with a remarkable turnout of nearly 99 percent. The outcome, to be announced next week, is expected to favor independence from Indonesia. But militias backed by the Indonesian Army have unleashed a new campaign of violence aimed at thwarting independence. Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, must act quickly and firmly to assert control over the military, rein in the militias and fulfill his promise to abide by the will of the Timorese people.

title: AUTOIMMUNE SHARES PLUNGE AFTER DRUG IS WITHDRAWN
description: Shares of Autoimmune Inc. tumbled 74 percent yesterday after the biotechnology company said it would discontinue the development of its rheumatoid arthritis drug Colloral because of disappointing results in clinical trials. The company, based in Lexington, Mass., said it would cut its work force and reduce operating expenses immediately as it formulated a new strategy. Autoimmune was conducting a Phase 3 study of Colloral -- the final phase of human trials that the United States Food and Drug Administration normally requires before it will consider approving a drug. The shares slid $2.50, to 87.5 cents.

title: Topsail Beach Journal; Helping Sea Turtles Cope With Birth, Sickness and Storms
description: During lunch today at the Topsail Beach Shop and Grill here, most people were checking with their neighbors to see how they weathered Hurricane Dennis and the evacuation. But anyone who walked up to Jean Beasley's table first asked how the sea turtles fared.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These judges have their heads in the sand. Thank goodness they don't have to govern a city, because things would be really dangerous.''

title: UTILITY MERGER PROGRESSES
description: Hoping to create Germany's largest utility, Viag A.G. and Veba A.G. said talks had moved forward after a ''constructive'' meeting with the Bavarian government, which owns 21.5 percent of Viag. If the merger goes forward, the combined company, which would be worth about 13.9 billion euros, or $14.7 billion, would become Europe's second-largest electricity company behind Electricite de France, with annual sales of 64 billion euros, or $67.8 billion.

title: Enough to Give a Savior Heartburn
description: Sitting on the credenza behind the desk in Lou Holtz's office at William Brice Stadium are three things that could make his inaugural season as the University of South Carolina football coach a little easier to handle: a bottle of Rolaids, a bottle of Excedrin and a bottle of Stress Tab vitamins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREIF, NETTIE
description: GREIF-Nettie, age 94, of New York City, died August 31. Former teacher of mathematics at Seward Park High School. After retirement, passed many fulfilling years in continued learning and teaching with friends at Institute for Retired Professionals and Quest. Avid painter and lifetime member of Art Student League. And still had limitless time and energy for family and friends. She leaves behind her loving son Paul (Madelyne), grandchildren Michaela, Sasha, and Daniel, adored brother Nathan Libby, beloved sister-in-law Shirley Libby, and dear sister Anna Smith, as well as treasured nieces, nephews and their children. Services will be held at 11AM, Friday, September 3, at Cedar Park-Beth-El Cemeteries, Paramus, NJ. Call family for details.

title: Five Are Injured as Car Hits Two-Story Scaffold
description: A car drove into a two-story scaffold on the Upper West Side yesterday evening, causing the collapse of the scaffold and five minor injuries, the police said.
