description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SURGES. Coffee prices increased on speculation that dry weather could reduce the size of next year's Brazilian crop, the world's largest. Coffee for December delivery rose 4.4 cents in New York, to 94.25 cents a pound.

title: High-End Digital Cameras Begin Moving Up a Notch
description: Just as digital cameras are dropping in price and consumers are growing more eager to squint into the viewfinders of relatively low-resolution point-and-shoot cameras, some manufacturers are preparing to offer new, more highly evolved digital cameras that have much more in common with their professional-grade, single-lens-reflex counterparts.

title: Clemens Still Leading Yankees in Questions
description: The Yankee players and Manager Joe Torre talked as if the Roger Clemens issue was largely a creation of the public's imagination before last night's game against the Oakland Athletics. They said that Clemens had been pitching well lately and that the perhaps unrealistic expectations that have been heaped upon his burly shoulders were responsible for the perception that he was struggling mightily in pinstripes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, GARY (GIDONE) STEVEN
description: BUSCH-Gary (Gidone) Steven, age 31, died Monday, August 30, in Boro Park. Beloved son of Doris Busch Boskey and Dr. Norman Busch. Much loved stepson of Dr. Howard M. Boskey & Lynn Busch. Survived by loving brothers Glenn and Gregg. Services at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Deer Park Avenue, Dix Hills, NY, Thursday, 10 AM. (516) 499-6060.

title: Once Dross, Now Dream: Wrecks Are Suddenly Hot
description: A FEW years ago, agents say, the smallish two-bedroom apartment overlooking Sutton Place South, with a sidelong glance at the East River, would have been priced at around $475,000 -- and labeled a wreck. The worn linoleum in its dark Pullman kitchen was starting to crack; the grout in the bathroom was falling out. Wind whistled through the old window sashes.

title: Early Dose of Tennis
description: The children on the playgrounds around the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn used to look with amusement at Levar Harper-Griffith. ''Hey, here comes Arthur Ashe,'' they'd call out to the kid who had to set up his own net on the ramshackle courts in the neighborhood.

title: Ex-School Administrator Is Fighting His Dismissal
description: One of two district Superintendents dismissed by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew in June in a shake-up of the city's worst-performing schools is contesting the dismissal, citing a lack of due process.

title: South Korea To Inject Cash Into Big Bank Left Unsold
description: The South Korean Government plans to declare the ailing Seoulbank insolvent on Thursday before injecting billions of dollars into it after talks to sell it to a foreign bank broke down, officials said today.

title: Malfunction Shuts Down Indian Point Nuclear Plant
description: Emergency officials have temporarily shut down the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Westchester County after a series of apparent electrical problems created the most serious situation at the plant in three years, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, WILLIAM MAYO
description: SULLIVAN-William Mayo. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend, Bill Sullivan, whose commitment to the Metropolitan Opera spanned nearly half a century of participation in the life of our company. Bill joined the Opera Club in 1950, served as president of the Club from 1967 through 1970, and as a Director of the Association since 1969, including service as a Managing Director from 1975 through 1980 and as an Advisory Director since 1980. Bill's caring and thoughtful stewardship of the Board's Benevolent Committee for more than a decade reflected his devotion to members of our company. He will be long remembered for his quiet kindnesses to so many in the Met family and his passion for opera at the Met, drawn from his love of music, his knowledge of Met history and his friendships backstage, as well as with artists performing with our company. We recall with deep affection Bill's joy at being at the Opera House, his gentle presence at opening nights, premieres and most Saturday matinees, and especially his determination to meet his Board responsibilities and attend performances despite serious illness. His decades of loving volunteer service to our company set an important example for others and will be fondly recalled by those of us who knew him. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Francoise, and his family. Louise Humphrey Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear Chairman Paul M. Montrone President

title: Corrections
description: A book review of ''Nightmare Town,'' by Dashiell Hammett, in Weekend on Friday included an erroneous identification, from the book's introduction, for the union involved when Hammett worked as a strikebreaker in 1917 in Butte, Mont. It was the Industrial Workers of the World, not International Workers of the World.

title: Among 14 Charter Proposals: Delaying Special Election for Mayoral Vacancies
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to put 14 proposed changes before New York City's voters on the November ballot but said that its most contentious initiative -- creating a special election to fill mayoral vacancies -- would not take effect until January 2002 if approved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESSO, CHARLES
description: PESSO-Charles. The Sephardic Temple, Congregation Emeth VeShalom of Cedarhurst, N.Y., & the Sisterhood of the Sephardic Temple, record with deep regret the sudden and tragic passing of Charles Pesso, President of the Congregation. A Founder of the congregation, he served in every capacity and on almost every committee. His dedication to the Sephardic Temple was exemplary. A proud Sephardic Jew whose philanthropic involvement reached every corner of our community, he labored indefatigably in the vineyard of our people. A humanitarian par excellence, his yeoman efforts on behalf of a host of institutions and activities earned for him an extraordinary place within the leadership of Sephardic Jewry. During the past three and a half decades he guided and assisted others in guiding the destiny of our beloved congregation. His direction, goal and purpose were ideal, addressing the contemporary needs of Sephardic Jewish survival in our country. His contributions to that end are manifest in the activities and reputation of our congregation. Warmest condolences to his sister Rachel Haleo, her husband Hy, his niece Ellen Moore, her husband Michael, and nephew Dr. Steven Haleo. May the family and Congregation be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Funeral services at Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Friday, Sept. 3rd at 9:30 AM Rabbi Arnold B. Marans Isaac J. Russo Chairman of the Board Estelle Ezratty Sisterhood President

title: Express Train Delayed
description: The start of Amtrak's 150-mile-an-hour express service between Washington and Boston will be delayed several months because vibrations at high speeds are causing the wheels on the passenger coaches to wear out too quickly. Amtrak is counting on the high-speed train to lure business from airlines.

title: Biggest Union at Boeing Votes To Accept Proposed Contract
description: The Boeing Company's largest union voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a proposed new three-year contract, averting a strike that would have dealt a blow to Boeing's efforts to recover from an embarrassing financial downturn.

title: U.S. Seeks Details on Russia's Use of Aid
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it wants assurances that international financial aid already sent to Russia has not been lost to corruption, but stopped short of calling for a halt in future loans to Moscow from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Finding Fashion And History On the Edges; Museums Look Again At Their Picture Frames
description: In a hushed gallery at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Elizabeth Easton, the curator of European paintings, and Jared Bark, the founder of Bark Frameworks in SoHo, were huddled around a Sisley landscape. The talk was not about the painting, but of its Louis XV-style reproduction gilt frame festooned with intricately carved flowers, swags and shells. ''Look how the frame overpowers the painting,'' said Ms. Easton. ''It's just too Louie-Schmooie.''

title: China's Subtle Spying
description: In the furor over the investigation of Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos National Laboratory scientist suspected of spying, the operating assumption of most people seems to be that where there is espionage there must be evidence of espionage. A corollary to this is that failure to produce such evidence is proof of either a bungled investigation or a rush to judgment -- in this case, a judgment that some say erroneously singled out Mr. Lee because of his race.

description: For the second time in two years, Conde Nast has plucked an editor of Hearst's Cosmopolitan magazine to run one of its magazines. Yesterday, Mandi Norwood, the editor of British Cosmopolitan, was named editor in chief of Mademoiselle magazine.

description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday for the fourth time in five days on concern the economy's strength and prospects for faster inflation might prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for a third time this year.

title: With Nothing to Lose, Tillstrom Doesn't Win
description: Here was the extra on the set chosen to stand in for the star. Arriving with fair hair, good posture and a clean shave, showing up with a ranking you could bench press and a wardrobe off the rack, Mikael Tillstrom was all wrong for the role of Pete Sampras.

title: CITY TO HOLD BACK 60% OF THOSE SENT TO SUMMER SCHOOL
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, painting a dramatically different picture from just two weeks ago, said yesterday that 21,000 students -- or more than 60 percent of the children assigned to summer school -- had failed to meet standards for promotion and would have to retake third, sixth or eighth grade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING V.
description: LEVINE-Irving V. Of Miami, FL. Beloved husband of Emma. Treasured uncle of Arthur, Harvey, Orrin, Janet, Shirley, Evalyn, Stephen and Howard. His greatest joy was bringing happiness to our lives and filing our days with laughter. Fond memories will remain in our hearts forever.

title: Deal by Cumulus Media
description: Cumulus Media Inc., which will be the third-largest United States radio station owner when it completes pending purchases, agreed today to buy Broadcast Software International, a closely held developer of digital audio software. Terms were not disclosed. Broadcast Software's main product, Wavestation, enables a personal computer to store a radio station's music and commercials and to manage its audio operations, replacing analog devices like record and tape players.

title: Louise Patterson, 97, Is Dead; Figure in Harlem Renaissance
description: Louise Alone Thompson Patterson, an advocate of civil rights and leftist causes, a participant in the Harlem Renaissance and a longtime associate of one of its leading figures, the poet Langston Hughes, died on Friday at the Amsterdam Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 97.

title: DUTCH COMPANY EXPANDS
description: The temporary-employment agency, Vedior N.V., acquired Select Appointments P.L.C, Britain's leading recruitment company, for $:1.15 billion, or $1.84 billion, in cash. Vedior hopes to expand in Europe and move into the United States. Vedior sold its cleaning-services business in May and was left with a war chest of almost $1 billion for acquisitions. The latest deal will give Vendior access to 25 countries, up from 9.

description: JABLON - David. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Mens Club mourn the passing of their beloved member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: I.R.S. Memo Appears to Oppose a Type of Pension Conversion
description: Cash-balance pension plans have drawn heavy criticism lately because they often reduce the pensions of older workers. In fact, a memo written by an Internal Revenue Service district director one year ago -- and released Tuesday by a member of Congress -- stated that one cash-balance pension plan may violate age-discrimination laws.

title: Justice Dept. Inquiry Into Sales Of Visas in Panama Is Denied
description: Accusations by Justice Department officials that the American Embassy undercut the department's investigation into visa trafficking and alien smuggling by high-ranking Panamanian officials are unfounded, according to several United States officials close to the case. The reason, they say, is simple: there was no investigation to disrupt.

title: Uncertainty Surrounds Isles. This Is Not a Recording.
description: When the Islanders open training camp next week, the team's uncertain ownership situation will cast its shadow for a fourth consecutive year.

title: On the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMENDOLA, ANTHONY JOSEPH
description: AMENDOLA-Anthony Joseph. On August 29, 1999. Anthony was born in Manhattan, New York on May 18, 1926. Served in US Navy and graduated from Columbia University. For twenty-two years he was an experienced marketing management executive. His background included a major role in creating one of the world's top ten advertising agencies, D'Arcy MacManus and Masius. During that time he was closely identified with Anheuser-Busch having developed all brands of beer. He joined Pabst Brewing Co. as President & CEO. He then joined Schlitz as Vice President, after 4 years he retired to Rancho Mirage, Calif. His life was extended with two heart transplants. Tony was working on a nationwide donor awareness program ''Pledge Your Heart, I have''. Survived by his wife Virginia, 3 daughters, 1 stepdaughter, ten grandchildren and 2 greatgrandchildren. Services will be held Friday, September 3 at 11AM at Frances P. Devine Mortuary, Oyster Bay, NY. Burial to follow at Calvary cemetery, Woodside. In lieu of flowers, contributions to be made to Amendola Heart Transplant Fund, C/O Dr. Jon Kobashigawa 100 UCLA Medical Plaza, Los Angeles, CA. 90095-6988.

title: A Clinton Day With a First Lady Agenda
description: As a likely Senate candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton set the agenda for today's activities with her husband. They visited sites that honored women's rights, the kind of place any woman running for the Senate would want to log on her campaign itinerary.

title: Global Crossing Is Expected To Sweeten Bid
description: In an attempt to reinvigorate its flagging effort to acquire the Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's biggest long-distance telephone carriers, Global Crossing Ltd. has offered to modestly sweeten its bid in exchange for Frontier's commitment to spurn other suitors, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Mercedes Dealers Award Account
description: Mercedes-Benz Retailers of Southern California said yesterday that it had named Merkley Newman Harty, part of Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Yellow Card in New York. Billings were estimated at $10 million for the association of 24 retailers.

title: A Tale of Sex and Disdain In Wharton's Berkshires
description: Stephen Paulus, just turned 50 and one of the few American composers of this century to make a living writing operas, first thought of Edith Wharton's 1917 novella ''Summer'' as a potential subject in 1980. But even with his success and clout in the opera field, Mr. Paulus did not get a company interested until the mid-90's, when he began discussions with Joel Revzen, the artistic director of the Berkshire Opera Company here. A commission came in 1997, and the world premiere took place on Saturday.

title: Software Might Make Users Talk to Computers Politely
description: Remember the scene from ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' when the evil computer Hal 9000 discovers the plot to disconnect him by reading the astronauts lips? In a few years, your PC will use the same technique to find out when you might pull the plug on it.

title: Showing Its Patriotic Colors
description: One of the best spots for a rendezvous in Times Square, the tiny United States Armed Forces Recruiting Station was a lot flashier than the clock at the Biltmore. The recruiting station is reopening on Tuesday with even more flair. Redesigned in red, white and blue by Stephen Cassell and Adam Yarinsky of Aro, the new 520-square-foot building is a patriot's dream, with 33-by-14-foot flags rendered in fluorescent bands of light. The no-frills interior will have stations for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines. And one bathroom, which is one more than the old place had. Who knows? That may bring in the recruits.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Proposed Rule Could Help Mask Commodity Trading Volatility
description: The regulator of the nation's commodities markets is proposing a rule change that would allow commodity trading advisers to smooth out past returns in the performance records they present to prospective investors.

title: They've Got the World in Their Palms
description: AFTER a summer of relative leisure, when jobs or camp ate up most of the day, the new school year can ring in a head-spinning array of classes, athletic practices and after-school lessons. How does the beleaguered student make sense of it all, and still remember to hand in a history project by its due date?

title: Twice Burned, Hilton Hotels Discusses Deal With Promus
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, which was left standing at the altar after its two most recent attempts to buy other hotel companies, confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to acquire the Promus Hotel Corporation.

title: Serbs Driven From Kosovo Live Crowded and in Want
description: Srbislav Bisercic, a competent, bluff and imposing figure who always wore a pistol when he ran the Podujevo municipal administration in Kosovo, is now a broken man, ashamed to be in a jobless exile and hunting for a cheap apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN OKIN, BABETTE
description: SLOTKIN OKIN-Babette. Of Palm Beach, FL and formerly of New York City and Detroit, MI, passed away on August 31, 1999 after a short illness. Beloved wife of Robert Okin. Devoted mother of Donald, Mitchell, Curt and Todd Slotkin, her children from her marriage to the late Hugo Slotkin. Cherished mother-in-law of Edie, Pamela, Carole and Judy. Loving grandmother of Douglas, Steven, Bobby, Daniel, Trevor, Elissa, Keith, Matthew, William, Thomas and Peter. Caring step-mother to Kenneth and Dennis Okin. Her wisdom, love and wit live on in our hearts. She will be missed by many dear friends. Funeral service will be held on September 2 1:30 pm at the Ira Kaufman Chapel (800-325-7105), 18325 W. Nine Mile Road, Southfield, MI. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Craft Gallery, 5911 S. Dixie Highway, West Palm Beach, FL. 33405, or charity of one's choice.

title: Editorial Observer; A Legacy of Conscience From Milton Rogovin
description: Three weeks ago an air-conditioned truck pulled up to Milton Rogovin's house in Buffalo and carted away his entire archive of photographic negatives, contact sheets and prints -- a lifetime of work. When artists allude to posterity, they often do so only half-believing in it, but this was posterity's actual moving van, come to carry Mr. Rogovin's archive to the Library of Congress.

title: In America; No Problem
description: We no longer have to worry about Gidone Busch. He won't freak out and frighten his neighbors in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn anymore. He's been taken care of by the police. He's dead.

title: Military Service Is Not a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: House Panel Subpoenas Records on Clinton's Clemency Offer
description: Congressional Republicans today stepped up pressure on the Administration over President Clinton's offer of clemency to members of a violent Puerto Rican nationalist group, subpoenaing White House and Justice Department records and raising the likelihood of Congressional hearings in the fall.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Got the Expressway Blues? Go South, Young Gardener
description: COME the weekend, when half of Manhattan is packing shorts and cell phones for a mass migration to the beach, two of its number are making a beeline for the South. About an hour's plane ride later (even as others, sustained by a kind of grim fatalism, are still inching along the Long Island Expressway), these same two are already enjoying the amenities of their weekend retreat in Richmond.

title: Youth, 16, Is Attacked By 20 Men, Police Say
description: A 16-year-old was attacked and critically injured by a group of more than 20 young men in a park in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, the police said.

title: LIBRARY/POLITICAL RESOURCES; Democracy Finds Fertile Ground on Line
description: VIEWS LEFT AND RIGHT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEAR, PETER JOHN
description: SHEAR-Peter John. In New York, suddenly on August 26, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Marcia, wonderful, loving Papa to Lisa, Eric & grandson Oliver. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Simon Wiesenthal Center, 9760 West Pico Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA. 90035.

title: Pope Repeats an Apology
description: Pope John Paul II asked forgiveness again today for past errors of the Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, HARRIET
description: BLOOMBERG-Harriet. Our deepest and most profound sympathy to our dear friend, Jeffrey Bloomberg, on the passing of his mother, Harriet Bloomberg. May beautiful memories bring comfort to Jeffrey and his family. Lynne and Mickey Tarnopol

title: Beijing Journal; Birthday Party in Wax: Guest of Honor Is Missing
description: China's Communist leaders have always loved a good anniversary, which gives them a chance to portray the country exactly as they want and to mobilize a good share of the population.

title: Students Look Ahead In Mars Plan for 2030
description: It may take a village to raise a child on Earth, but on Mars it takes a child to raise a village. The Mars Millennium Project, organized by the United States Department of Education, NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, is an interdisciplinary program in which students from kindergarten to high school will plan a Mars community, circa 2030.

title: Interstate Deal For Clean Air Falls Through
description: In the regional battle over air pollution that blows from the Midwest to the Northeast, states on both sides have rejected a proposed compromise, all but guaranteeing that the long-running dispute will be settled in court, not at a bargaining table.

title: Miami Beach's Bel-Aire Is Gone, And Some Don't Miss It.
description: Art Deco may rule in Miami Beach, but midcentury modern is being torn down. A few weeks ago the 1949 Bel-Aire Hotel (above, designed by Albert Anis) on Collins Avenue in the South Beach Historic District was demolished. Randall Robinson, a city planner for the Miami Beach Community Development Corporation and a defender of the hotel, said no construction is currently planned for the site.

title: Umpires Accept Deal, but Resignations Stand
description: Opting to choose safe over sorry, the umpires union accepted a settlement with Major League Baseball today that will retain pay for the rest of the year but not the jobs of 22 umpires whose resignations had been accepted following a union strategy that backfired.

title: Lemieux Is Finally the Emperor of the Penguins
description: Mario Lemieux's path to majority ownership of the Pittsburgh Penguins began in a most peculiar way: the owners of the team he led to two Stanley Cup championships defaulted on paying him more than $30 million in deferred salary.

title: And They're Waterproof, Too
description: A New York businessman toting a Vietnamese wicker laundry hamper down the street? Why not? Mark Calafatello, the president of EMR Imports, swears by his, which he uses as a backpack. He has coaxed a vast array of woven bamboo and rattan baskets from villagers in the mountains of North Vietnam. ''They think I'm crazy that I buy so many,'' he said.

title: NINE HYUNDAI EXECUTIVES SUMMONED
description: Nine executives of South Korea's largest business conglomerate, Hyundai, face possible charges of manipulating stock prices of a subsidiary, according to prosecutors. The Seoul District Prosecutor's Office said the nine had been restricted from leaving the country since late August, adding they would be summoned for questioning this week. Prosecutors contend that the chairman of the Hyundai Securities Company and other officers systematically manipulated the prices of Hyundai Electronics shares last year to amass around 2 billion won ($183 million) from three other Hyundai subsidiaries.

title: Out of Twilight Zone And Into Oblivion
description: When the home plate umpire Terry Tata called Eric Karros out on strikes to end today's game between the Milwaukee Brewers and the Los Angeles Dodgers, it signaled an end to his career and those of fellow umpires Tom Hallion and Bill Hohn.

title: The Digital Brain Drain; So Many Computers, So Little Interest in Hard Science
description: Jim Ivy fears that his son Jonathan, a freshman business major at Pennsylvania State University, will graduate from college without ever having taken a chemistry course. Montville High School, the New Jersey school he attended, did not require chemistry, and his adviser at Penn State says he can skip it there, too -- provided that he signs on for more computer science courses.

title: A Step to End Newark's Chapter in High-Rise Public Housing Projects
description: Built in 1959, the seven hulking 13-story brick buildings that are the Stella Wright Homes stand as a forlorn monument to another era of urban renewal. It was a time, said Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, when the nation was warring with itself over the impulse to integrate the poor and the impulse to isolate them.

title: Defining 'Classic Contemporary'
description: Crate and Barrel's fall furniture lineup looks as if it's trying to save you a trip to the flea market. ''There's a major thrust in the marketplace, a return to classic contemporary that's not hard-edged architectural retro,'' said Rob Pitt, a furniture product manager at the company. The Kane chairs, immediately below ($419 side, $499 arm), owe a heavy debt to Harvey Probber, the 1960's designer who is a current favorite in midcentury modern shops. The Kali line, middle (armchair, $99; stools, $109 and $119; available in mid-October), have the 1950's Polynesian cocktails theme down cold. The Grandmaster entertainment center ($2,499) and credenza ($2,199) were inspired by the elegant 1930's designer Jean-Michel Frank, Mr. Pitt said. But the entertainment center looks as if it could be hiding your grandfather's tube radio.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: H & R Block Agrees to Buy A Discount Brokerage Firm

title: Investors Seek Bargains Despite Worries About Fed
description: Stocks finished higher yesterday as bargain hunting overshadowed interest-rate jitters in advance of fresh statistics on the tight American job market.

title: An Unprized Fabric Turns a Corner
description: FELT has gone svelte. The ugly duckling of fabrics, best remembered for bulky poodle skirts of the 1950's and ubiquitous industrial padding, is finally taking its place in home furnishings as well as on any number of fashion runways. Addressing what seems to be a design craze, Monika Piatkowski, of the trendy London design studio Hive, said she suspects that designers, weary of plastics and other synthetics, are attracted to the fiber for its naturalness and versatility. ''Felt can be worked like paper,'' she said.

title: MASCO MAKES FIVE ACQUISITIONS FOR $3.8 BILLION
description: The Masco Corporation, the largest United States maker of kitchen cabinets and bathroom fixtures, said yesterday that it had bought five home-improvement products companies for about $3.8 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt. The two largest acquired companies have about $1 billion in combined revenue. They are Behr Process, a paint maker in Santa Ana, Calif., and Mill's Pride of West Palm Beach, Fla., a maker of kitchen and bath cabinets. The other companies are Arrow Fastener of Saddle Brook, N.J.; Inrecon of Birmingham, Mich., and Superia Radiatoren of Zedelgem, Belgium. The acquisition price includes about 106 million Masco shares, currently worth $3.08 billion. The shares rose 75 cents, to $29.0625.

title: Rookie Lineman Receives Not So Sentimental Education
description: For years, wise veterans and bright rookies have often ended up in side-by-side stalls in the Giants' locker room. Young running backs would sit next to Ottis Anderson and learn from the master. Young quarterbacks would dress next to Phil Simms and get a priceless football education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, PAULINE
description: CARTER-Pauline. Mom, life without you to talk to, and reminisce with, is unimaginable. You brought unbridled joy into my life. Your sense of humor ensured that every phone call and visit was filled with happiness. Your loving and sweet voice will be heard forever. The fullness of your life could be measured by the simple things that brought you pleasure: talking with your children and grandchildren. Knowing that you are happy is my sole comfort at this sad time. I will always think of you and remember your smile, your hugs and kisses, your exuberance, and your belief in me. You always said that you were my best audience. You are finally with Dad once again-the heavens will reverberate with the two of you trading stories! Rest in peace. With all the love in the world, Donny.

title: Is a Renewed Japan a Threat to Its Neighbors?; Sympathy for a Cult
description: To the Editor:

title: With Agreement at Hand, a Standoff on Prisoners Snags Mideast Peace Negotiations
description: By very early this morning, the optimism of Israeli and Palestinian negotiators had soured, and it seemed unlikely that a new agreement would be reached before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's arrival in Egypt later today.

title: All You Need to Add Is Air
description: In the eight years since college, Alison Ferber and her business partner, Maria Kojic, have moved for a combined total of 30 times. Now they have designed a product they wish they had had all along: an inflatable convertible sofa bed.

title: Mosquitoes, Malaria and Money; Don't Set a Date
description: To the Editor:

title: With Light Touch, Trade Chief Takes Over
description: Mike Moore of New Zealand began his first day as leader of the World Trade Organization today with a reminder of some nettlesome issues he faces as the top global trade arbitrator.

title: Vodka Ad Is Stopped After Racism Protest
description: Skyy Vodka said it would discontinue a print ad after a protest by members of an Asian-American Web site.

title: Cardinal to Reveal Medical Test Results
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, who has been hospitalized for a week, will disclose as early as today the results of the medical tests he has undergone, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: Grand Jury to Hear Case Of Brooklyn Man's Death
description: A Brooklyn grand jury will begin hearing evidence next week to determine whether the shooting death of a mentally ill, hammer-wielding man by the police in Borough Park, Brooklyn, on Monday night was legally justified, officials said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar declined against the yen on expectations that a rosier economic outlook in Japan would lure money from American stocks and bonds. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.05 yen, down from 109.59.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALAT, HERBERT
description: SHALAT-Herbert, Architect, died Sunday, August 29 at his home on Long Island. He leaves behind his wife of 48 yrs, Ann; his sons and their families, Edward & Sara, Neal and Fiorella, & Andrew and Charissa; and 3 grandchildren Dunham, Erik and Evan Isabel. We love him and we miss him. A memorial servie will be held at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, Thurs. evening at 7PM. In lieu of flowers gifts in his name may be made to The International Myeloma Foundation, 2129 Stanley Hills Dr, Los Angeles, CA. 90046.

title: Violence as East Timor Awaits Vote Count
description: With a jumble of swords, slingshots and automatic weapons, gangs of street toughs battled today outside the United Nations compound here, killing at least one person and trapping scores of United Nations officials and journalists inside for several hours.

title: SYMANTEC SETS MARKETING PACT WITH AT&T AND EARTHLINK
description: The Symantec Corporation, maker of the Norton brand of utility software for personal computers, said yesterday that it had entered promotional agreements with the AT&T Corporation and Earthlink Network Inc. that will offer consumers special deals for Internet access. The company, based in Cupertino, Calif., will bundle retail copies of its software with AT&T's Worldnet Service Internet software and with Earthlink's Totalaccess Internet software. In exchange, AT&T and Earthlink will offer one month of free Internet access to users who register for their services from one of the Symantec products. Symantec's shares were up $2.875, to $32.875.

title: Military Service Is Not a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Malaysia Ends Most Controls On Investment
description: Taking a major stride back into the world's financial mainstream, the Malaysian Government lifted a steep tax on the repatriation of foreign capital today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ABRAHAM A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Abraham A., 93, of Southbury, CT, formerly of NYC. Loving and beloved husband of Belle (Zap). Cherished father of Felice Yager (Henry). Proud grandfather of Alison and Jessica. Devoted brother of Lillian (Steinberg), Fannie (Hardy), and the late Harry and Bernetta (Smith). Affectionate uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. A graduate of City College and Ph.D. from Columbia University. Professor Emeritus, Brooklyn College. Author of short stories, novels and innovative graduate level textbooks. We will miss his warmth, wit, compassion, keen intellect and zest for life. Contributions in his memory may be made to Connecticut Hospice, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: A Long-Ago Celebrity Grabs the Spotlight Once More
description: She sits on a rustic throne like Britannia herself, clothed in a richly embroidered gown, with an enormous pearl necklace around her swan's neck. In striking half-profile this imposing figure stares upward as if transported to some far-off world. The woman is Sarah Siddons (1755-1831), the English tragedienne, and the view is that of Sir Joshua Reynolds, in his painting ''Sarah Siddons as the Tragic Muse'' (1784).

title: On the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Is Selected For Mindshare
description: Irwin Gottlieb was named to the new position of worldwide chairman and chief executive at Mindshare, the media management and services company of Oglivy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson units of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: Metro Business; Deal for Midtown Building
description: An investment group led by Goldman, Sachs has bought 1185 Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan for $195 million, strengthening the investment bank's hold on the Rockefeller Center-area real estate market.

title: Indictment Names Son Of I.O.C. Member
description: In the second criminal charge to emerge from the Salt Lake City Olympics bribery scandal, the son of one of the most influential members of the International Olympic Committee was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he fraudulently obtained United States residency and then lied about it to investigators.

title: Appeals Court Permits a Rally City Fought, Warning Both Sides
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday emphatically rejected the city's final legal challenge to a Harlem youth rally and, in an unusual step, explicitly ordered the Police Department not to oversee the event with ''undue rigidity.''

title: LIBRARY/POLITICAL RESOURCES; Democracy Finds Fertile Ground on Line
description: CONGRESSIONAL DATA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STOLBOF, BERNARD
description: STOLBOF-Bernard. 2/9/28-9/2/98. Husband, father, and grandfather. It was one year ago today that you left our lives. We think about you everyday, and miss and love you dearly. Your loving family, Betty, Paul, Edward, Jesse, Daniel, Lorie, Debbie, Stephanie, Andrew, Matthew, and Henry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, JANE
description: DRISCOLL-Jane, 73, on August 17th, 1999. Jane's family and friends will gather to remember her, Sunday, September 5th, 1999, at 12:30 PM, at the Cafe Torino, 139 W. 10th St., NYC. She is survived by her loving son, Roderick, and her three grandchildren, Kaitlin, Travis and Kiley, and by her devoted brother, Edward.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Unarmed Man Killed in Struggle With Police
description: An unarmed man fleeing the police was fatally shot yesterday when an officer's service pistol discharged during an attempt to wrest the man from a livery cab in Harlem, the police said.

title: Lineup's Reliables Deliver For Mets
description: The Mets have uncovered heroics from some rather unglamorous spots this season. Steely infield defense and the best bullpen in the league may delight a manager, but it isn't exactly the stuff of big-type headlines and video retrospectives.

title: SLOW AUSTRALIAN GROWTH
description: Australia's economy grew at its slowest rate in three years in the second quarter, as miners and other companies exposed to Asia's slump invested less and consumer spending slowed. Gross domestic product rose two-tenths of 1 percent from the previous quarter, the Bureau of Statistics said. Economists had expected a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent. Compared with a year earlier, the economy grew 4.1 percent in the second quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, STANLEY
description: BROWNSTEIN-Stanley. Beloved husband for 48 years of Hilda. Loving father of Elliot, Susan and son-in-law Steven. Cherished grandfather of Caryn, Matthew and Alexa. Services are at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Brooklyn (opposite Kings Plaza), Thursday, September 2nd, 11:30 AM. He will live in our hearts forever.

title: Officials Try To Find Origin Of Malaria In L.I. Boys
description: Federal, state and local officials joined forces today on Long Island to study the rare cases of two 11-year-old boys who became infected with locally acquired malaria while attending a Boy Scout camp last month in Suffolk County.

title: SCOTTISH DATA REPORTED
description: For the first time ever, the British Government began releasing quarterly gross domestic product data for Scotland in hopes of informing politicians and helping elevate economic debates in the Scottish parliament. The data showed that Scotland's economy grew a bit faster in the first quarter than that of Britain over all, rising five-tenths of 1 percent compared with one-tenth of 1 percent. Even though the parliament has now been handed precise economic information, the 129-member body cannot vote on macroeconomic issues.

title: Smarter Mouse Is Created In Hope of Helping People
description: In a major test of the brain's most basic mechanism of learning, a scientist has created a smarter strain of mice by manipulating a gene involved in memory formation. He believes his work lays the basis for eventually doing the same in people, whether in helping patients with memory loss, in counteracting the fading of memory in the elderly, or even in making healthy individuals smarter.

title: Comets' Strategy: Beat Liberty With Kindness and Confidence
description: If the Liberty was looking for something to get the competitive juices churning for tonight's opening of the Women's National Basketball Association championship series, it was not getting any 30-second bites from the Houston Comets.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Korda Must Pay Up
description: Now that Petr Korda has lost his final appeal, he owes a $660,000 fine assessed by the International Tennis Federation for the prize money he won after he tested positive for an anabolic steroid last year.

title: Evolving Digitally Into Respectability
description: RICHARD LENSKI, a biologist at Michigan State University, usually studies evolution by allowing bacteria to reproduce, generation after generation, in a laboratory dish. But in recent experiments, he just let digital organisms run rampant in a computer.

title: Calculators Throw Teachers a New Curve
description: LIKE hundreds of thousands of other high school students, Greg Myers, 16, began using a graphing calculator in freshman algebra. Graphing calculators, which bear little resemblance to their 1970's ancestors, are sophisticated devices that can run small computer programs and draw the graph represented by complex equations in an instant. In the last few years, they have become mandatory in many high school math classes and can be used on the SAT and advanced placement exams and other standardized tests.

title: RENO ORDERS TAPE SEIZED FROM F.B.I.
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered United States marshals to the F.B.I.'s headquarters to seize a previously undisclosed tape recording of voice communications between F.B.I. commanders and field agents during the 1993 tear gas assault at the Branch Davidian compound, Justice Department officials said.

title: Military Service Is Not a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Older People Want to Work In Retirement, Survey Finds
description: A new survey of older Americans has found that 40 percent are working for pay in retirement or plan to after they retire, while an equal percentage do volunteer work or plan to.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ivanisevic Remains Cautious Despite Victory
description: He has been trying for 11 years to deploy his serves like dynamite and crack this $14 million United States Open wide open like a safe. But when Goran Ivanisevic looked around yesterday and surveyed the wreckage of a tournament suddenly bereft of Pete Sampras and Patrick Rafter, the brooding, bearded Croat didn't think he was home free.

title: On the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: A Letter Arrives at the Wrong Door
description: A form letter seeking contributions was sent by President Clinton's legal defense fund to the father of Monica S. Lewinsky, whose affair with the President led to his impeachment.

title: Digital Theme Park Where Pokemon Roam
description: AFTER imitating the Magic Kingdom for years, Nintendo has finally out-Disneyed Disney. With Pokemon Island, the Japanese software company has taken the idea of a synthetic, self-contained tourist environment to its logical extreme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UMANS, SHELLEY BARNETT
description: UMANS-Shelley Barnett. Age 82. On September 1, 1999, at her home in Manhattan. She was the wife of the late Henry J. Umans and had served in the NYC Public School System for many years. Mrs. Umans was a graduate of Hunter College and Teachers College, Columbia University. She began her career as a reading specialist and served as Director of the Center for Innovation for the city's Board of Education. She later became Director of the Board's Regional Center for Educational Planning and Management. The author of several books on educational planning and management, Mrs. Umans was a consultant to school systems throughout the country on innovative approaches to school management, educational technology, and alternative forms of education. She is survived by her sons, Dr. Robert S. Umans, and Peter A. Umans, both of Boston, a grandson Christopher M. Umans of Berkeley, CA, a grand daughter Kate E. Umans of Boston, and a cousin, Ann Kurz of White Plains, New York. Visiting Thursday, 7-9PM. Service Friday 12:15 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Chappaqua Likes Rumors About Home-Buying Couple, but Braces Itself
description: As word spread here that someone perhaps the President -- had signed a contract to buy the Dutch Colonial that the Clintons toured on Saturday, a steady stream of cars looped around the tiny cul-de-sac called Old House Lane for a peek at The House, and a CNN camera crew descended on the hamlet.

title: GARTNER SAYS SHARE BUYBACK WILL COST $340 MILLION
description: Gartner Group Inc., which sells research and analysis on the computer industry, said it expected to pay $21.75 for each class A share and $21.50 for each class B share in its previously announced buyback plan. Gartner, based in Stamford, Conn., offered on July 27 to pay $21 to $24 a share to buy back shares in a Dutch auction that expired on Tuesday. Gartner, which had 1998 sales of about $642 million, now expects to pay about $340 million for 9.6 million class A shares and 6.1 million class B shares. The class A shares of Gartner rose $1.25 each, to $22.1875, and its class B shares rose $1.50, to $22. In a Dutch auction, a company establishes a price range, and holders specify prices within that range at which they are willing to sell their shares.

title: DEXTER TO SELL A UNIT, CLOSE A PLANT AND CUT 120 JOBS
description: The Dexter Corporation, which makes chemicals for the aerospace, electronics and medical industries, said yesterday that it would sell a unit and close a Texas plant, cutting 60 jobs, as it tries to become more efficient. Dexter, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., said it would sell its printed wiring-board materials unit, which sold about $43 million of chemicals used in electronics last year, as it finds it more difficult to compete with companies outside the United States. Dexter also said it would close a plant in Richardson, Tex., and make changes in its nonwoven materials unit's European division, cutting 60 jobs between the divisions. Dexter's shares were unchanged at $36.4375. The announcements were made after the close of trading.

title: Apple Is Now the Champ In Computer Speed Wars
description: Apple Computer humbled the rest of the personal computer industry this week by introducing a new desktop machine based on the Motorola Power PC G4 processor, which Apple calls ''a supercomputer on a chip.'' Using the Intel Corporation's own benchmark software, a 500-megahertz G4 Macintosh simply smoked the fastest chip in Intel's PC lineup, the Pentium III.

title: A Ruling, and Giuliani's Disapproving Response
description: Following are the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday, and a transcription of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's remarks after he learned of the decision. The ruling rejected the city's appeal of a lower court decision ordering a permit for the Million Youth March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, ELAINE
description: SILLS-Elaine. Died September 1, Brooklyn. Life-lover, caregiver, builder of a better world, rock to Herb and to all of us. Flowers cannot sing. Mountains cannot dance. Words cannot express how much we love and miss you. Your kids, Annie, Pep, Sam and Sarah, our families and your sister Carolyn

title: Zedillo Promises a Cleaner Presidential Election Next Year
description: President Ernesto Zedillo, in a State of the Union address delivered as the race to choose his successor reaches full swing, promised to insure a ''climate of freedom'' for the vote and to prevent Government funds from seeping into political campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVELLERO, BAILEY, KIM
description: CAVELLERO-BAILEY-Kim, Vice President & Director of Marketing and Sales of M.E. Sharpe Publisher, died along with her 8-year-old daughter, Jessica, in a tragic roller coaster accident in Ocean City, New Jersey, on August 28. She was 39. Known to everyone in the publishing trade as Kim Cavellero, she began her career as an Advertising Coordinator at Pergamon Press in 1984 and rose to the position of Associate Director of Marketing in 1991, before joining M.E. Sharpe in 1997. Ms. Cavellero was born in 1960 in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., where her parents operated Dick's Cabin, a restaurant begun by her paternal grandparents that was frequented by Broadway actors and professional baseball players. After graduating from Maria Regina High School, she attended the State University of New York at Plattsburg, where she met her future husband, John Bailey. A dynamic executive universally respected both for her intelligence and her genuine concern for all her colleagues, Ms. Cavellero was also a devoted wife and mother who invariably found time for family and friends, and was known to co-workers and neighbors alike as ''Wonder Woman.'' The Cavellero-Bailey home in Pomona, New York, was a frequent gathering place for neighborhood children and adults. She is survived by her husband, John Bailey; their 5-year-old daughter, Kathryn; her mother, Florence Muscavi Cavellero of Dobbs Ferry; her sister, Cheryl Cavellero of Croton, N.Y.; her brother, Arthur John Cavellero Jr., and her paternal grandmother, Catherine Cavellero, both of Dobbs Ferry; and three nieces and nephews. Her father, Arthur John Cavellero, died in 1980. A funeral service will be held at 10 A.M., today at St. Anthony's Church in Nanuet, N.Y. Donations/contributions may be sent to Kathryn Bailey Scholarship Fund, 3 Summitt Place, Nanuet, New York 10954.

title: John Hancock Plans Stock Sale
description: The board of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company approved plans today to convert the company, the sixth-largest United States policy-holder-owned life insurer, to a publicly traded company. An initial stock sale is expected by the end of March.

title: PURCHASE BY LIFE INSURER
description: A British life insurance company, Britannic P.L.C., will buy the fund-management arm and the life insurance arm of the Britannia Building Society for a total of $:346 million, or $554.9 million. Britannic will buy a 75 percent interest in Britannia Asset Management for $:150 million and all of Britannia Life for $:196 million. Britannic said the purchase would strengthen its ability to compete in the low-margin pension market and give it access to Britannia's 1.8 million customers.

title: Times Raising Price
description: The suggested newsstand price for Monday-through-Saturday issues of The New York Times in the metropolitan area will rise to 75 cents on Sept. 13, from 60 cents, the newspaper announced yesterday. The increase will not affect the Sunday paper, the national and Northeast editions or the price of home delivery when provided directly by The Times.

title: Baggage and All, Strawberry Comes Back Again
description: Darryl Strawberry folded his powerful arms, swayed in a blue chair and leaned forward when he spoke, using the dozens of reporters in front of him as amateur psychiatrists. Strawberry talked about making a serious mistake, about being an alcoholic and about the thrill of finally returning to the Yankees.

title: Think Tanks in Paris and Washington Aim to Improve Relations : In U.S. and France, New Effort to Listen
description: WASHINGTON  U.S.-French differences? Yes, there have been a few, Philip Gordon pleasantly conceded, as a reporter ticked off a long but quite incomplete list: U.S. trade sanctions against Iran and Cuba; the bombing of Iraq; handling of the Middle East peace process; leadership of the United Nations (and, it sometimes seems, of every other international body of note); various interventions in Africa; the U.S. "cultural invasion" on the one side versus French "cultural protectionism" on the other; mounting French resentment of U.S. "unilateralism"; and a series of snits over every sort of foodstuff, from beef to Roquefort to bananas.

title: Mayoral Group Agrees on Plan To Redevelop Governors I.
description: A mayoral task force has agreed on a proposal to redevelop Governors Island with a conference center, apartments, university housing, stores, two new branches of the Guggenheim Museum and a large public park, city officials said yesterday.

title: DNA Evidence Secures Release of Man Convicted of '82 Rape
description: Accompanied by the 78-year-old woman who worked more than a decade to overturn his rape conviction, Vincent Jenkins walked out of prison yesterday, 17 years older and two surgeries frailer than when he walked in.

title: Financial Software Slugfest
description: IN his stage play ''Millennium Bug,'' Steven Tomlinson, an economist and performance artist, describes a new software package called Veritas 2000 that not only manages your personal finances, but also your soul. Veritas 2000 promises to lead consumers out of debt and into affluence, but it does so by tracking the user's spending and savings down to the most minute level, spewing alerts and threats if a penny is spent unnecessarily.

title: Clinton Eager to Veto Tax Cut, Aide Says
description: The White House chief of staff today urged the Republican majority in Congress to send President Clinton its $792 billion tax cut bill so that he could promptly veto it.

title: Trial for Elusive Nazi
description: After a 12-year investigation, a French judge today ordered Alois Brunner, a Nazi war criminal who has not been seen alive since 1992, to be tried in absentia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARDEN, UNA
description: BARDEN-Una. On August 31, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late John & Elizabeth Barden. Loving sister of Nancy Jones, Kathleen Page and Sister Eileen Barden, C.S.J. Family receiving friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9P.M. Mass of Christian burial Friday, Sacred Heart Church at 10:15A.M. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Partnership for the Homeless, C/O Arnold Cohen, 305 7th Avenue, 13th flr, New York, New York 10001-6008.

title: Auto Sales Rose Sharply In August
description: In a sign that strong consumer spending continued to power the American economy last month, many auto makers announced today that their sales soared in August, with the biggest growth occurring for some of the most expensive models with the highest profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPELLOUTO, FORTUNEE
description: CAPELLOUTO - Fortunee. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing in Nice, France, of the beloved mother of Yvette (and Martin H.) Bockstein, Lillian Katz, and Rita Malka. Mr. Bockstein is the University's General Counsel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to them and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Min hashamayim tenuhamu! Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: William Mayo Sullivan, Philanthropist, 78
description: William Mayo Sullivan, a New York insurance broker and longtime benefactor of classical music in the city, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 78.

title: Paul Showers, 89, Author of Children's Books
description: Paul Showers, author of a series of science books for young readers and a former editor for The New York Times, died on July 17 at the home of his daughter, Dr. Kate B. Showers, in Orange, Mass. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMNEY, ANDREW F.
description: ROMNEY-Andrew F. On August 30, 1999 at age 74. Beloved father of Michael and Mark Romney and Sharon Scott. Devoted grandfather of Andrew, Matthew, Theodore, Lewis and Hannah. Dear brother of Henry Romney. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, September 3rd at 12 noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOILLOT, LYNN HOCHSCHILD
description: BOILLOT-Lynn Hochschild. The Trustees, faculty, staff and students of Paul Smith's, The College of the Adirondacks, mourn the loss of Lynn Hochschild Boillot, a leader among the College's Board of Trustees. An articulate advocate of the College's initiative to create a regional super-library, and a generous supporter of the College's scholarship fund, her insight and infectious spirit will be missed by the College community. She loved the Adirondacks and was passionate about the education of the region's young people. The combination, coupled with an enthusiasm and sense of humor matched by few, made her a joy with which to work. Our deepest sympathies are extended to her two sisters, Ann Poole and Patricia LaBalme, and her four sons and two daughters-in-law.

title: Insurer Name Change
description: The Equitable Companies, the largest publicly traded United States life insurer by assets, will change its name to AXA Financial Inc. tomorrow as the 140-year-old company seeks to highlight the broader range of services it now offers. The New York-based company was founded in the 19th century as the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States It is now a part of Paris-based AXA S.A., the world's largest insurance company, and offers investment management, brokerage and other services in addition to life insurance.

title: Mirer Wants a Chance, And Maybe a Few Snaps
description: The nameplate over his locker and the green and white jersey remind Rick Mirer of what city he is in.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Keeping the Mayor Uninformed

title: Lectures, Exhibitions And a Fair
description: Begin With the Bedsheets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIKER, BERTRAM J.
description: DIKER-Bertram J. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Bertram J. Diker, beloved brother of Charles M. Diker, a generous, dedicated supporter and cherished friend of the Jewish community. We extend our sincerest condolences to Charles; Mr. Diker's wife, Rhona; his daughter and son-inlaw, Susan and William; his granddaughter, Alexandra; and the entire Diker family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: An Unbiased Inquiry on Waco
description: Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, has urged his boss, Attorney General Janet Reno, to appoint a qualified group of outsiders to investigate the agency's failure to keep Ms. Reno and Congress fully informed about all aspects of its role in the 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex. This is the right thing to do, since it would be an appalling conflict of interest to have the F.B.I. and the Justice Department investigating themselves. Ms. Reno, who is said to have decided yesterday to mount an independent inquiry, should seek out and appoint qualified investigators as soon as possible.

title: Merrill Lynch Settles Dispute Over Hiring of Fund Manager
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had hired James McCall as a fund manager, ending a legal skirmish that pitted Merrill Lynch and Mr. McCall against his former employer, Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Ltd.

title: A Night at the Opera (With Music by MTV )
description: MTV and the Met? They may sound incompatible, but next Thursday MTV plans to present its 16th annual Video Music Awards in the elegant opera house at Lincoln Center.

title: Mosquitoes, Malaria and Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROYCE, MILTON E.
description: ROYCE-Milton E. Age 83, of Glen Cove, NY, August 30, 1999. Loving husband of Dolores. Father of Stephen Royce, Kyle Larsen and Tracey Stoever; grandfather of Gregory, Allen and Lisa Royce, Eric Riddle Larsen, Alex Larsen and Cady Ruth Stoever; loving brother of Lynn Goldberg. Memorial service 11:30 AM, Friday at Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. He will always be warmly remembered in our minds and our hearts as a guiding light and inspiration. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to charities sponsoring heart and cancer objectives.

title: Capturing Not-So-Still Life: Webcams in Many Flavors
description: SPAM decomposing on a plate, penguins falling on their faces and a cubicle dweller coping with day-to-day office life: Webcams have brought out an odd combination of the voyeur and exhibitionist.

title: Filling Up on Gas, and Web Ads
description: GAS pumps are no strangers to advertising. Their nozzle handles have long been adorned with junk food ads encased in clear plastic. And their sheet metal bases often serve as tiny billboards.

title: Village Chief Takes Clintons' Visit in Stride
description: A lot of things have happened in the 15 years that Jack McNeil has been the police chief of this one-square-mile village of Victorian homes, antique boats and 2,800 mostly well-behaved inhabitants.

title: Moscow Blast Tied to Anti-Materialist Group
description: An explosion on Tuesday evening at a lavish underground shopping mall opposite the Kremlin may be the work of a previously unknown group that opposes materialism and warns that it is dangerous to consumers, Russian investigators said today.

title: Test for Rafter Shows Small Tear in Shoulder
description: Patrick Rafter, the two-time United States Open champion whose latest title defense ended almost before it began -- with a sobering first-round default on Tuesday night -- underwent a magnetic resonance imaging test yesterday at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan that revealed a small tear to the rotator cuff of his right shoulder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLANDER, ROSE
description: HOLLANDER-Rose. On August 30. Widow of Aron. Beloved mother of Elliot. Mother-in-law of Susan. Grandmother of Emily and Aron. Aunt of Regina Kolber. Mourned by the Mark, Schwartz, Haworth and White families.

title: A Novelist Fills In Slavery's Blanks With Imagination
description: All the family photographs of the writer Connie Briscoe recently displayed in the HarperCollins lobby in midtown Manhattan burst with tales to be told. One in particular, though, captured at once the complexity of her family, American history and Ms. Briscoe's latest novel.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Partial-Shade Bonanza

title: Tenacity of 2 Played a Role In Reviving Inquiry on Waco
description: Michael McNulty and David Hardy refused to let go. In the six years since the Branch Davidian compound went up in flames on April 19, 1993, the two men have waged an obsessive quest to discredit the official account of what happened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAIA, ROSARIO
description: SAIA-Rosario. On August 30. Beloved husband of Providenza. Devoted father of Anthony, Dorotea De San, Lawrence, and the late Maria Polizzi. Loving brother of Dorotea Torchiano. Loved and cherished by nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Reposing Scalia Funeral Home, 28 Eltingville Boulevard, Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ROSE
description: GOLDMAN-Rose. We express profound sorrow at the passing of the beloved mother of our colleague, Dr. I. David Goldman, Director of the Albert Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center and the Susan Resnick Fisher Professor of Brain Tumor Research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. We extend our deep sympathy to Dr. Goldman and his family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz, Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORGES, WALTER
description: PORGES-Walter. On September 1, 1999 at 67. Beloved husband of Jean and loving father of Donald, Marian and Lawrence. Brother of Lisl Schick. Services on Friday, September 3rd, at 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial contributions may be made to The Porges Family Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 633 3rd Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10017 or Temple Beth Shalom, 740 North Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. 10706.

title: 36 Feet of Custom-Made Table
description: Assouline, the French publisher of design books and the Chanel catalogues, has arrived in New York with an office as elegant as the books it publishes. Prosper Assouline, the owner, was smitten when he saw a 3,500-square-foot loft in Chelsea: celestial light, views of river and sky, all framed by 1930's casement windows. Mr. Assouline made the focal point a 36-foot-long communal worktable, constructed in Paris and shipped to New York in three pieces. (The building's truck elevators go to the 18th floor.)

title: Military Service Is Not a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spring's Prospects Have a Town Smiling; In Cherry Valley, a Water Source Has a Story, and Perhaps a Future
description: Along the wooded glacial ridges of central New York, water burbles from the earth in countless torrents and trickles. It tumbles north to the Mohawk River, or south to the Susquehanna or the Delaware.

title: In Panama's New Dawn, Woman Takes Over
description: Mireya Moscoso, a schoolteacher's daughter who grew up in rural poverty, was sworn in today as Panama's President, the first woman to lead the nation. She will also become the first Panamanian President to lead a completely sovereign country once the United States withdraws its remaining troops and completes its handover of the Panama Canal on Dec. 31.

title: A Question of Equality; Some Schools Can't Afford Hardware and Training
description: IN private schools and suburban public schools, students usually buy their own graphing calculators, which cost around $100 each, or their schools provide them. But less-affluent students and poorer school districts cannot always afford the calculators, which educators say can put students at a disadvantage.

title: H & R Block to Buy Olde For $850 Million in Cash
description: Intensifying its push to become a broad-based provider of financial services to Middle America, H & R Block Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Olde Financial Corporation, the parent of the nation's fourth-largest discount brokerage firm, for $850 million in cash.

title: Indecisive? Printing 101
description: Q. If I've sent files from my Mac to the printer, how do I stop one from printing?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RUTH
description: GOLDBERG-Ruth. Beloved wife and friend of Bob. Daughter of Lillian Feder. Mother of Susan Holmes (Randy) & Bonnie Ellman (Dennis). Grandmother of Alex, Lindsay, Scott and Jordan. She also leaves behind her sister Barbara (Joe), her nephew Richard (Jody) and their children Jessica, Scott and Erik. She was preceded in death by her father Nathan, granddaughter Jennifer and nephew Scott. We will surely miss your laughter and spirit. For information contact Beeches Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: PVC Never Looked So Good
description: The vases from the American Plumbing series by Constantin Boym and his partner, Lauren Leon Boym, are found objects of a sort. ''I often go to Home Depot, my favorite store, in search of interesting bits and pieces of hardware to reintroduce as home product design,'' Mr. Boym said. The vases, made of PVC pipe, were first seen in a show, ''Conversation Pieces,'' in New York last May. Now they are available for $28 each at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street).

title: Toys and True Value
description: I pull the covers over my sweet boy and arrange his Beanie Babies at the edge of the bed: Tracker, Bones, Rover, Chip, Snip, Pounce, Prance and then the others. My 9-year-old son drifts off to a dream land of goofy faces and waggable tales.

title: AT HOME WITH: Esther Williams; Swimming Upstream
description: ON the spreading terrace of the hilltop house, there's a pretty blue pool and an Esther Williams-brand whirlpool spa. There's a panoramic view to the Pacific Ocean and a custom-made Esther Williams kick board propped on the lawn. There's Perry Como, on an unseen stereo, singing ''Fly Me to the Moon,'' and Judy Garland insisting, ''I've Got a Right to Sing the Blues.''

title: Sports of The Times; A Big Shot, An Old Shot, A New Shot
description: RICKY LEDEE was a wide-eyed 13-year-old when he got his first glimpse of Darryl Strawberry. Granted, it was mostly of the top of Strawberry's baseball cap, not the best of views, from a distant row in the corner of the right-field upper deck.

title: Beanie Move Giving Rise To Skepticism
description: The Beanie Baby backlash has begun.

title: LIBRARY/POLITICAL RESOURCES; Democracy Finds Fertile Ground on Line
description: ON a recent sweltering Monday evening, nearly 50 residents of the Bay Ridge neighborhood in Brooklyn jammed into the living room of a two-story brick row house to talk about problems like erosion and rats in Owl's Head Park, 27 acres of trees and grass on the Brooklyn waterfront. It was classic grass-roots organizing, more or less the way it has been done for generations.

title: 'Oh, That Sounds Like . . .'
description: Mayer Rus, the editor of Interior Design magazine, has put the gossip mill into high gear with a column he wrote for the August issue under the nom de plume of Addison DeWitt. His impertinently hilarious ''personal ads'' are loosely based on actual people, he said. There's an ''Orthodox Miesian'' who wants to take a walk on the wild side; a ''bicoastal designer'' interested in partners who can tell Italian cotton from Egyptian, jute from sisal, and an ''internationally acclaimed designer and sociopath'' who seeks a ''youthful sidekick to monitor my medication, micro-manage employees' lives, harass editors and berate vendors.'' Guess who? ''Sometimes it's necessary to prick that membrane of fabulousness,'' Mr. Rus said.

title: A Workers Compensation
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLER, NORMA MAYES
description: BUCKLER-Norma Mayes. Loving nurturer of all that grew on earth or walked on four legs. She leaves behind a grieving husband and family, many friends and co-workers. The light and support she brought will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

title: Comets' Cooper Excels, and Liberty Is in Deep Trouble
description: It was deep into the game against the Liberty last night before it looked as if Houston guard Cynthia Cooper had broken a sweat. By then the Liberty was out of breath, out of gas and seemingly out of chances to subdue the Comets in the first game of the Women's National Basketball Association championship series.

title: MIDEAST STANDOFF REMAINS UNSOLVED AS ALBRIGHT VISITS
description: On her first trip to the Middle East since Ehud Barak came to power as the Israeli Prime Minister, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has hit a snag, with the Israelis and the Palestinians failing to deliver an agreement for a signing ceremony in Egypt that she had hoped to preside over.

title: Army Demotes Retired NATO Commander Who Admitted Affairs With Wives of Subordinates
description: In the first such action against a retired officer, the Army today demoted a retired general who admitted at his court-martial in March that he had adulterous affairs with the wives of four subordinates.

title: Cancel Tolls During Jams, Lautenberg Urges State
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg urged state officials today to let New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway drivers glide through toll plazas without charge to ease traffic jams.

title: Mark Zebrowski, Islamic Art Historian, 54
description: Mark Zebrowski, a historian of Islamic art who specialized in Mogul culture of southern India, died on Aug. 22 in London. He was 54.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a joint concert performance by German and Israeli musicians at Buchenwald on Sunday misattributed a 19th-century Romantic tradition exploited by the Nazis. The passage in question should have read: ''This humanism and enlightenment of Goethe gave way during the 19th century to expressions of Romantic cultural nationalism that the Nazis would later seize on and distort.'' Goethe was not among the Romantic nationalist writers invoked by the Nazis.

title: Man Fatally Shot by Police Is Celebrated for Poetic Soul
description: A few weeks ago, after visiting his grandparents' graves, Gidone Busch wrote a poem about finding peace among the souls of his family at rest. Today, the man slain by the police Monday night in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was buried next to his Nanny and Papa after a solemn service that focused on his sensitivity and generosity rather than his violent struggle with mental illness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAULSON, DONALD L., M.D.
description: PAULSON-Donald L., M.D. Renowned thoracic surgeon passed away August 31st, 1999. A memorial service will be held at 10 AM, Saturday, September 4th, in Sparkman Hillcrest Northwest Highway Chapel, with Rev. Martha Thorson officiating. Memorials may be made to the Dr. Donald Paulson Cardiovascular Education and Research Endowment at Baylor Medical Center, Dallas, TX. 75214.

title: Next Fight for Umpires Is Over Control of Union
description: As the legal fight between the umpires union and Major League Baseball awaits arbitration over the fate of the 22 lost umpires, the next battle will be intramural -- between two factions for control of the union.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Sales Increased 8.1% In Industry's Best August

title: A Summer-Camp Flavor That Lingers All Year
description: A turquoise 1952 Chevy pickup jutted from the curb as we rolled into the old mill town of New Preston near the foot of Lake Waramaug in the western Connecticut highlands. What time warp was this? Had the gantlet of Route 202 antiques shops ended in the Brigadoon of an enchanted lake colony little touched by time 100 miles from Manhattan?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
description: * Keith Sherman was named senior vice president and account director at Publicis & Hal Riney, part of Publicis S.A., succeeding Andrea Alfano, who has joined Selfcare.com. Mr. Sherman had been account director at the Richards Group, Dallas.* John Rollins and Anne Welch were named co-presidents at Vibe/Spin Ventures, part of Miller Publishing Group. Mr. Rollins will retain the title of group publisher of Vibe/Spin/ Blaze, and Ms. Welch will remain general manager. Blaze publisher Raymond O'Neal Jr. was named to the new position of executive vice president.

title: NATO and U.N. in Kosovo Agree On K.L.A. Role in Civilian Force
description: After weeks of negotiations, NATO and United Nations officials have agreed to allow a part of the Kosovo Liberation Army, the guerrilla force of Kosovo Albanians, to survive as a lightly armed civilian emergency force.

title: Turkey's Bereft Carry Cynicism Back to Villages
description: When summer began, Remzi Tarhan might have been the happiest man in this sun-drenched town. Seventeen years after moving here from his native village on the Black Sea coast, he had finally realized his dream of opening a restaurant specializing in anchovy casserole and other Black Sea delicacies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWLEY, JAMES ROGERS
description: HOWLEY-James Rogers. 57, of Cincinatti, Ohio, a former New Jersey resident died in an automobile accident on August 31st while on business in Indianapolis, Indiana. Mr. Howley was the president and CEO of the Howley Group, Inc., a firm which specialized in investment banking and mergers and acquisitions. A Pittsburgh, PA native, Mr. Howley graduated from Villanova University and the Villanova School of Law. Surviving Mr. Howley are his three children; daughter Samantha and two sons, Joshua and Justus, as well as his sister Suzanne Ochiltree. A memorial service will be held for Mr. Howley in Yardley, PA at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, (NAMI), 300 N. Glebe Road, Suite 1015, Arlington, VA 22203.

title: Microsoft Names New Leaders For Troubled Net Business
description: Searching for a way to revive its beleaguered Internet business, the Microsoft Corporation named a new leadership team for its on-line group yesterday and indicated that it would emphasize its technology underpinnings and continue to move away from a media strategy.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Speech on Improving Education
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on education policy given yesterday by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to the Latin Business Association, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: A World of Passion, Stroke by Quivering Stroke
description: THERE is no art in the world more passionate than Chinese painting. Beneath its fine-boned brush strokes, ethereal ink washes and subtle mineral tints flow feelings and ideas as turbulent as those in any Courbet nude or Baroque Crucifixion.

title: Hirschfeld Jury Announces Deadlock, and Mistrial Is Declared
description: The tax fraud trial of the mercurial car-garage magnate Abe Hirschfeld ended in deadlock yesterday as a Manhattan jury announced that it was unable to reach a verdict after eight days of deliberations.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: With Daewoo, a Twilight Of Korean Conglomerates; Dismantling of Yesterday's Economic Engines
description: Transported by the whispers of workers and housewives, a sense of impending doom is descending on this auto factory town, whose fortunes have always marched in lockstep with those of the Daewoo group.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETERMAN, TOMMY DAVID
description: PETERMAN-Tommy David. September 3, 1992. In fond, loving memory. Douglas

title: Radio Acquisitions
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc., one of the largest owners of radio stations in the United States, has agreed to buy five stations in North Dakota and five in Washington State for an undisclosed price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING V.
description: LEVINE-Irving V. Of Miami, FL. Beloved husband of Emma. Treasured uncle of Arthur, Harvey, Orrin, Janet, Shirley, Evalyn, Stephen and Howard. His greatest joy was bringing happiness to our lives and filling our days with laughter. Fond memories will remain in our hearts forever.

title: Editorial Notebook; Living an American Life -- in Yiddish
description: This week in the Berkshire hills, 191 people gathered to play baseball, do yoga and tai chi, sing campfire songs, dance, listen to lectures and watch movies. title: Let VCR's Work On Labor Day

title: Chinese Glass As Stepchild
description: Antique Chinese glass is a stepchild in the family of Chinese decorative arts. There are only a handful of scholarly books on the subject, and few American museums have high-quality Chinese glass collections. (The outstanding exceptions are the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Corning Museum of Glass in upstate New York.) Much more attention is paid to Chinese painting, calligraphy and ceramics from ancient times through the Ming Dynasty (A.D. 1368 to 1644).

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Technology; Shifting Away From Prindle

In a new report, the Federal Aviation Administration confirms that things were just about as bad as everyone thought they were. The F.A.A. also assumes much of the blame. That shows commendable candor, but the important thing now is for the agency and the airlines to move quickly to unblock a clogged system.
