title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, WILLIAM MAYO
description: SULLIVAN-William Mayo. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend, Bill Sullivan, whose commitment to the Metropolitan Opera spanned nearly half a century of participation in the life of our company. Bill joined the Opera Club in 1950, served as president of the Club from 1967 through 1970, and as a Director of the Association since 1969, including service as a Managing Director from 1975 through 1980 and as an Advisory Director since 1980. Bill's caring and thoughtful stewardship of the Board's Benevolent Committee for more than a decade reflected his devotion to members of our company. He will be long remembered for his quiet kindnesses to so many in the Met family and his passion for opera at the Met, drawn from his love of music, his knowledge of Met history and his friendships backstage, as well as with artists performing with our company. We recall with deep affection Bill's joy at being at the Opera House, his gentle presence at opening nights, premieres and most Saturday matinees, and especially his determination to meet his Board responsibilities and attend performances despite serious illness. His decades of loving volunteer service to our company set an important example for others and will be fondly recalled by those of us who knew him. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Francoise, and his family. Louise Humphrey Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear Chairman Paul M. Montrone President

title: TIFFANY SAYS IT WILL STOP SELLING TO OTHER STORES IN U.S.
description: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it was ending its longtime policy of selling to domestic independent jewelers and department stores, turning its focus on developing its own network of stores and catalogues. Tiffany, based in New York, said the sales, which it started 14 years ago, had been only marginally profitable and generated less than 3 percent of its total revenue. The move will go into effect on Jan. 1. Tiffany operates about 130 stores worldwide. Of those, 37 are in the United States. The company has said it intends to keep expanding at a rate of three to five stores a year. Its shares were down $1.6875, at $51.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESSO, CHARLES
description: PESSO-Charles. The Sephardic Temple, Congregation Emeth VeShalom of Cedarhurst, N.Y., & the Sisterhood of the Sephardic Temple, record with deep regret the sudden and tragic passing of Charles Pesso, President of the Congregation. A Founder of the congregation, he served in every capacity and on almost every committee. His dedication to the Sephardic Temple was exemplary. A proud Sephardic Jew whose philanthropic involvement reached every corner of our community, he labored indefatigably in the vineyard of our people. A humanitarian par excellence, his yeoman efforts on behalf of a host of institutions and activities earned for him an extraordinary place within the leadership of Sephardic Jewry. During the past three and a half decades he guided and assisted others in guiding the destiny of our beloved congregation. His direction, goal and purpose were ideal, addressing the contemporary needs of Sephardic Jewish survival in our country. His contributions to that end are manifest in the activities and reputation of our congregation. Warmest condolences to his sister Rachel Haleo, her husband Hy, his niece Ellen Moore, her husband Michael, and nephew Dr. Steven Haleo. May the family and Congregation be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Funeral services at Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Friday, Sept. 3rd at 9:30 AM Rabbi Arnold B. Marans Hazzan David Abikzer Isaac J. Russo Chairman of the Board Estelle Ezratty Sisterhood President

title: DYCKERHOFF DEAL SENDS LONE STAR STOCK UP 42%
description: Lone Star Industries, a maker of cement and ready-mixed concrete, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Dyckerhoff A.G. of Germany for nearly $1 billion in cash, plus the purchase of warrants and the assumption of debt. The companies put the overall value of the deal at $1.2 billion. Dyckerhoff, a cement and building-materials company, offered $50 a share for Lone Star. The shares gained 42 percent yesterday, rising $14.5625, to $49.125, in Nasdaq trading. Dyckerhoff also said it would buy all of Lone Star's warrants at $81.25 apiece. The warrants entitle the holder to two common shares. Dyckerhoff said the purchase would diversify its business from its heavy emphasis on Europe. The company already has a 50 percent share in the Glens Falls Lehigh Cement Company, which serves the Northeast.

title: FRONTIER ACCEPTS REVISED OFFER FROM GLOBAL CROSSING
description: The Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's biggest long-distance telephone carriers, accepted a revised $10.5 billion acquisition offer from Global Crossing Ltd. yesterday, salvaging a purchase that was threatened by a plunge in Global Crossing's shares. Global Crossing agreed to pay 2.05 shares for each Frontier share, a 12 percent increase, to $49.20, based on Wednesday's closing price. It is also assuming about $1.7 billion in debt. Global Crossing shares have tumbled 50 percent in the last three months, slashing the value of the original transaction by about $3.4 billion. Global Crossing, a two-year-old international phone company, needs Frontier's customers, traffic and revenue to compete against the big phone companies.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: MARINE RESEARCH: ''Sounds From the Gulf Stream'' (K Records). With songs that start out cooing ''la la la la la'' or ''doo doo doo doo doo, ba ba bada pa,'' and guitars that bring back the reverb settings of 1960's spy soundtracks, Marine Research cheerily takes its place among the pop revivalists of the 1990's. Four of the five band members were in the English group Heavenly, and Marine Research retains Heavenly's old combination of cleverness and modesty. In genially imperfect voices, Amelia Fletcher and Cathy Rogers sing about the yearnings of the unglamorous and about romances that aren't quite working out, as lovers strive for ''the pretense at calm with the chaos inside.'' Meanwhile the tunes lilt through blithe, unaggressive pop, from early Merseybeat to syncopated French ye-ye. Marine Research doesn't pretend to be naive, but it's confident that heartbreak can be contained by insouciance.

Mrs. Ordover taught fifth grade English at The Lovett School for seventeen years and is remembered fondly by a generation of students and fellow teachers as a friend, mentor, and role-model. Her fierce loyalty, strong opinions, and great wit made her a unique presence wherever she went. She will be missed by all of those blessed enough to have been able to call her friend. Memorial service to be held at Post Theater at The Lovett School on Monday September 6th, 1999 at 4:00 P.M. Cremation is private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Carol M. Ordover Memorial Schorlarship Fund, care of The Lovett School. The family will receive friends from 7 until 9 P.M. Thursday and Friday at 22 The Prada, Atlanta, GA. For further information contact Wages & Sons, Stone Mountain, GA. 770-469-9811

On the day he and five friends made it here to Six Flags Marine World, two of the amusement park's three roller coasters were closed for repairs, including the now-notorious Boomerang, which jerked to a halt last week, leaving passengers hanging 70 feet in the air in 100-degree heat for up to four hours.

The Directors of The Langeloth Foundation extend their sympathies to her immediate family. John L. Loeb, Jr., Chairman Board of Directors The Jacob and Valeria Langeloth Foundation

description: WITH a maximum of self-congratulation and a minimum of public debate, the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission wrapped up its business in nothing flat the other evening. And to think that some people call democracy inefficient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRONS, MARY GOLDWATER
description: ABRONS-Mary Goldwater. Age 84, died on Thursday, September 2, 1999 at her home in New York City after a long illness. She is survived by her brother, James Goldwater, three children, a son, Dr. Henry Abrons, two daughters, Alix Abrons and Anne Abrons, and four grandchildren. Private memorial service. Gifts in her memory may be made to The New York Public Library.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; The Art of the Serve: Wielding an Extremely Potent Weapon
description: In tennis the serve is your most important weapon. Literally. Back when I was on my high school tennis team I found myself with this situation: a sore shoulder (too many overheads the day before), a girl named Barbara on the other side of the net (the opposing team couldn't find enough guys) and down a quick break in the first set (gallantry + sore shoulder = double faults). I faced a break point in my next service game. I understood what was at stake, which was the fitness of my shoulder and a reputation as the guy who lost to the girl.

title: A Steel-Drum Master Prepares for a Carnival
description: From Port of Spain in Trinidad to London to Miami, the exultant sound of the steel-drum band rings across carnivals and continents. Formed anew every Carnival season, giant steel drum (or ''pan'') bands rehearse daily for months to perform a short piece before enthusiastic crowds and tough competition judges.

description: An article on Wednesday about a New York City Council hearing on the possible local impact of the Year 2000 computer problem misstated the given name of the finance committee chairman. He is Herbert E. Berman, not Howard.

title: India Mob Said to Kill Priest
description: A Roman Catholic priest, asleep in a remote eastern hamlet where he had been counseling the poor, was slain by a mob early this morning, cut down by bows and arrows as he tried to escape an attack, the police said.

title: Leaving Out Cheese for Mice and Cockroaches? O.K.
description: Don't be deceived by the sweetly benign title of Jeremy Thomas's film ''All the Little Animals.'' This contemporary moral fable, dressed up as a heart-in-your-throat psychological thriller, accumulates the lingering force of an especially vivid and terrifying bad dream. The film, adapted from a novel by Walker Hamilton, suggests a modern-day Charles Dickens tale in which a young man cowering in the shadow of an implacably cruel and treacherous stepfather flees home to be rescued by an eccentric, life-loving woodland hermit.

title: Milton Jack Mirman, 84, an Authority on Stamps
description: Milton Jack Mirman, an authority on United States stamps who was once a major dealer, died last Friday at a hospital in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 84.

description: After a lifetime in daily journalism, I still worry when real news is treated as no news at all.

description: ''West Beirut'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27. The film -- in Arabic and French, with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: 'A Bit of Peace' for Swissair Crash Families
description: One year ago, a woman stared out at the cold North Atlantic waves where her husband died in the crash of Swissair Flight 111. She quietly handed her baby to a policeman, and then started running. Just before she could throw herself into the sea, another policeman caught her.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the World Business Briefing column in Business Day yesterday about a Japanese investigation of the Republic New York Corporation misstated a corporate affiliation. Republic New York does not own Bank of New York.

title: Compulsions and Obsessions, From Sad to Spooky
description: Kvetch, kvetch, kvetch. An overwhelming menu of neuroses, psychoses and emotional dysfunction is presented by the video dolls of Tony Oursler, needy misfits with limp cloth bodies and blank heads on which angst-ridden talking faces are projected by video cameras. Their behavior is off the wall: a monster movie director belabors those who fail to fulfill his conflicting commands; a woman half buried under a mattress profanely demands to be left alone; an androgynous couple exchange identities as each massages relentless obsessions and compulsions. ''Get a life!'' you want to yell.

title: Ex-Broker Faces Broader Federal Charges
description: Randolph Pace, the man who prosecutors say was the mastermind behind a big securities fraud in the early to mid-1990's, was charged yesterday with directing a wider conspiracy that involved three brokerage firms, the manipulation of 11 companies' stocks and $200 million in illegal profits.

title: Independent Inquiry Is Sought Into Killing of Man by Police
description: As police officials defended an officer who fatally shot an unarmed suspect Wednesday in Harlem, some community residents called yesterday for an independent investigation into the incident and said it was yet another example of why officers need more training.

title: Labor Day Drivers to Pay More for Gas Than in '98
description: As Americans indulge in the last great driving binge of summer, they are paying an average of 22 cents a gallon more for gasoline than they were around Labor Day of 1998, the Department of Energy says.

title: Don't Jettison Russia Just Yet
description: With the year 2000 bringing presidential elections in both the United States and Russia, the emerging scandal over the possible laundering of billions of dollars from Russia through the Bank of New York has, predictably, already prompted a politically tinged search for scapegoats. And in both countries, the leading culprits are the same -- the Democrats and the ''democrats.''

title: Finding Hints of the Painter to Come in Winslow Homer's Early Illustrations
description: Sometimes a dull museum exhibition has a more exciting one lurking within. That's the case with ''Winslow Homer: Illustrating America,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. The show presents 115 prints designed by this great American painter and turned into wood engravings by anonymous craftsmen for various popular periodicals between 1857 and 1878.

description: Dismissing most Federal education programs as failures, George W. But Mr. Bush also said school standards should be left up to states and school districts.

title: CANADIAN BANK EARNINGS
description: Canada's largest bank, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings were in line with expectations. Earnings rose 79 percent, to $394 million (Canadian), or 88 cents a share, from the quarter a year earlier. The results for the most recent quarter reflected a gain of about $580 million from the sale of shares of Global Crossing, a telecommunications carrier that merged with U S West earlier this year. Excluding that gain and write-downs in the quarter a year earlier, operating profit rose only 2 percent.

description: A New Jersey couple who had spent a year planning a trip to the Serengeti national park and a Connecticut financial consultant, his brother and their mother were among those killed Wednesday in the crash of a small plane near Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania.

description: Before its opening credits, ''Happy Face Murders'' displays this written prologue: ''Most of what you are about to see is true. The stuff that isn't true is the stuff that's most believable. Go figure.''

title: AVNET MAKES ITS SECOND ACQUISITION DEAL IN TWO WEEKS
description: Avnet Inc., one of the world's biggest computer-parts distributors, agreed yesterday to buy SEI Macro Group, a British-based distributor, for about $60.5 million in Avnet's second proposed European acquisition in two weeks. SEI Macro, based in Slough, England, is a unit of Diploma P.L.C. It had 1998 revenue of about $200 million. SEI Macro employs 384 workers at four plants in Britain and Ireland and also has 10 sales offices in Eastern Europe, Russia and the Baltic states. A week ago, Avnet agreed to buy Sonepar S.A.'s stake in a Netherlands-based distributor for an undisclosed price.

title: MEETING ON SEOULBANK
description: South Korea's financial watchdog agency, the Financial Supervisory Commission, will hold a meeting today to decide whether to declare the ailing Seoulbank insolvent and inject additional public funds. The move came only two days after talks broke down between the commission and HSBC Holdings P.L.C. of Britain over the sale of Seoulbank. Last year, the Government invested 1.5 trillion won ($1.34 billion) in Seoulbank and another ailing bank, Korea First Bank, effectively nationalizing them.

description: Labor Day weekend may be a good time to enjoy video rentals of movies that salute working people, from ''Blue Collar'' to ''Norma Rae'' to the romantic ''Working Girl,'' with Harrison Ford and Melanie Griffith (above).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT A.
description: SMITH-Robert A., 62, of Brielle, N.J., died Thursday, September 2, in Albany, N.Y. Mr. Smith, a former local builder, real estate developer, philanthropist and owner of Riviera Realty, was born in New Brunswick, N.J., and lived in Brick, N.J., prior to moving to Brielle. He earned a B.A. degree in 1959 from Seton Hall University and served for a time in the U.S. Army. Mr. Smith was active in local politics, operated an independent newspaper and was involved in numerous community organizations and clubs, including Sportsman's Island Marina. His extraordinary generosity and volunteerism benefitted New York's East Harlem School at Exodus House and Harlem RBI Programs, which made education and enrichment activities available to inner city youths. His philanthropic activities included support for Monmouth and Seton Hall universities, Allaire Multiple Sclerosis, Manasquan Brielle Sea Girt Tri Community Alliance, and Christmas in July, among others. An avid tennis player and golfer, he was a member of Manhattan Plaza Racquet Club, the Achilles Club, and Reebok Sports Club, all in New York City, and of the Atlantic Club of Wall Township, N.J. He was also a world traveler, humanitarian and friend to all walks of life. He is survived by his former wife, Patricia Smith; by his son and daughter-in-law, Craig and Karen Steensen of Manchester, N.H.; by his daughter and son-in-law, Debra and John Zelechoski of Toms River, N.J.; by a brother, Monte Smith, of Brick; and by his grandchildren Daniel, Shannon, Danielle, Craig and Chelsea. His sister, Gloria Ann Smith, preceded him in death. Visitation will be from 2-4 and 7-9 PM Saturday at Weatherhead Young Funeral Home, 885 Mantoloking Road, in Brick, with a funeral service at 11 AM Sunday, also at Weatherhead Young. Donations may be made in his memory to East Harlem School at Exodus House, 309 E. 103 St., New York, NY 10029 or Harlem RBI, PO Box 871, Hell Gate Station, New York, NY 10029.

title: Auction for a Kidney Pops Up on Ebay's Site
description: Bidding for a human kidney, described on the Internet auction site Ebay as ''fully functional,'' began at $25,000 and reached $5,750,100 before the company abruptly ended the auction yesterday afternoon.

title: NOKIA BUYS ROOFTOP COMMUNICATIONS FOR $57 MILLION
description: Nokia A.B., the Finnish telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that it had acquired the Rooftop Communications Corporation for $57 million in a move to strengthen its capabilities in Internet protocol technology. Rooftop Communications, based in Mountain View, Calif., produces radio systems that enable high-speed wireless access to the Internet. The company employs 20 people. Nokia said the acquisition would give it additional holdings in wireless Internet access, especially in wireless Internet protocol routers.

title: Viacom and CBS Reportedly Discuss Station Deal
description: Viacom Inc. and the CBS Corporation have held discussions in recent weeks about a deal that could involve their television stations -- possibly in some type of merger -- several executives in the entertainment industry said yesterday.

title: Henry E. Singleton, a Founder Of Teledyne, Is Dead at 82
description: Henry E. Singleton, a brilliant engineer who co-founded and built Teledyne Inc. into one of the nation's largest and most enduring conglomerates, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. The cause was brain cancer, his family said. He was 82.

description: This gritty town is the home of Oskar Lafontaine, Germany's former Finance Minister, and of a slogan he coined that has proved less ephemeral than his brief tenure in the Government: ''The heart beats on the left, and it's not yet listed on the stock exchange.''

title: An Obsession With Space, Sex and Fried Chicken
description: The rapper Kool Keith came on stage at Wedlands on Wednesday night wearing a spherical space helmet and a glittering cape. When he took off the helmet, he revealed a shiny plastic wig shaped like a 1950's ducktail. His getup manifested the title of his new album, ''Black Elvis/ Lost in Space'' (Ruffhouse/Columbia), the latest persona for one of the most polymorphous characters in hip-hop. Partway through the set, he and his backup rappers, Black Silver and Marc Live, tossed plastic baggies of fried chicken into the audience.

title: Umpires Ponder a Future With and Without Work
description: The umpiring crew that worked the game between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Cubs at Wrigley Field in Chicago yesterday was a shell of its former self. Jerry Meals was the lone remnant. Larry Poncino and Gary Darling were no longer working, a result of the umpires' mass resignation movement, and Steve Rippley was in Florida deciding whether he would end his career, too.

description: Support for Gun Control

title: Romanowski Named In Drug-Fraud Case
description: Bill Romanowski, a defensive captain of the two-time defending Super Bowl champion Broncos, was embroiled in a prescription-fraud case tonight while his team fought yet another obstacle toward its goal of winning a third consecutive Super Bowl.

title: AUTOCYTE SHARES RISE AFTER AETNA ANNOUNCEMENT
description: The shares of Autocyte Inc. jumped yesterday after Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said it would pay claims for use of Autocyte's Pap smear technology. Autocyte shares rose 42 percent, gaining $2.625, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading. Aetna announced on Thursday that it would reimburse customers for Pap smear systems made by Autocyte, the Cytyc Corporation and Neopath Inc. The smears are used to detect cervical cancer. Autocyte's system is used to prepare samples of cervical cells for analysis. Aetna's coverage of the technology, one of the first for Autocyte by a major United States insurer, bolsters claims that its system, though costlier than older technology, is more cost-effective in the long run and more accurate, analysts said.

title: A New Deal With the Palestinians
description: The peace accord to be signed tonight by Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, is technically a reaffirmation of the Wye River accords that Mr. Arafat signed with the former Israeli leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, almost a year ago. But in reality, this first agreement negotiated by Mr. Barak as Prime Minister is much more. Both sides have made important additional commitments, setting a target date of next September for reaching agreement on a final peace treaty. Israel has also effectively promised that it will build no new Jewish settlements, and the Palestinians have similarly pledged that they will not declare independence.

title: Republican Pitch Plays on Nuclear Fears
description: Fund-raising letters postmarked in this city have always used language that is hyperbolic. But in a recent ''urgent'' letter, a Republican fund-raising chairman asked for contributions of $25 or more to help the Senate protect the United States from a looming nuclear attack by North Korea.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Ostrich That Roared; Did Malaysia, Its Head in the Sand, Duck the Asian Crisis?
description: If you had not visited this city of dreamy minarets and dazzling skyscrapers before last week, you might wonder whether the Asian crisis ever happened.

description: MIRKIN-Ray Ruth. On September 3rd, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Lila and Sol, Harris and Kathy. Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. She will be deeply missed. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Swiss Freeze 59 Bank Accounts For Russian Corruption Inquiry
description: Swiss prosecutors investigating suspected money laundering by officials at high levels of the Russian Government have ordered Swiss banks to provide information on two dozen Russians who may have accounts here and have frozen at least 59 bank accounts over the past two months, officials said today.

title: Merger of Churches May Not Be a Sign That Faith Is in Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: Thailand Acts Anew to Sell One of Its Troubled Banks
description: The authorities in Thailand said today that they would sell the troubled Nakornthon Bank to Standard Chartered Bank of Britain, acting to revamp the financial industry in a long-awaited move that is widely seen as crucial to the nation's economic recovery.

title: At Stake Is His Ability to Maintain Authority and Push Reform : Schroeder Facing Nasty Months
description: SAARBRUECKEN, Germany  Out here in what's left of blue-collarland, Gerhard Schroeder, the Brioni chancellor, comes to town to plead he's not really one of the guys in sharp suits who closed the mines and the mills, but a friend whose heart still thumps with Social Democratic compassion.

title: Long, Rousing Crescendos Over a Ceaseless Pulse
description: The pulsation began even before the members of Mogwai took the stage at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday. At first, the fundamental vibration took the shape of a recorded loop of a crashing hi-hat cymbal. Soon, the guitarists Stuart Braithwaite and John Cummings massaged the strings of their instruments to life, and the pulse expanded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, TILLIE
description: FRANKLIN-Tillie. Beloved wife of Harry and treasured mother to Roger and Alfred. Family and friends mourn the loss of this special lady. Services 1:30, Sunday, September 5 at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Financial Engineering in the Clinton House Deal
description: The package that the cash-strapped First Family will use to buy a $1.7 million house in Chappaqua, N.Y., is a clever and unusual piece of financial engineering designed to avoid tax and other pitfalls, real estate and financial specialists said today.

title: Shuttle Fleet Is Grounded By Damage To Wiring
description: The nation's fleet of four space shuttles will be grounded until the end of October at the earliest while technicians continue detailed inspections that have already turned up numerous cases of wiring damage, space agency officials said today.

title: Michigan Stokes Fire of Notre Dame Rivalry
description: Start a feud, create a little intrigue over who your starting quarterback will be, then go out and punish your rival in the name of gentlemen's honor -- not to mention that your team can't afford to repeat last year's title-busting stumble in the opening week.

title: Indifferent to a Planet in Pain
description: As the hot sun sets on this long, odd summer, you might try staring into the nighttime sky. Several times in the last few months, observers in the lower 48 have seen ''noctilucent clouds,'' which develop about 50 miles above the earth's surface -- clouds so high that they reflect the sun's rays long after nightfall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIFRIN, HILDA
description: SCHIFRIN-Hilda. I love you and miss you always. Loi

title: A Meeting of Francophones, With Insults in Plain English
description: In the cultural odd couple that is Canada, the English were carping today as the French welcomed their linguistic in-laws from around the world for a summit meeting called the Francophonie.

title: In Fine Print, Punctuation To Puncture Pedants With
description: If footnotes, quotations and marginalia, beloved by pedants and bores, were suddenly to vanish from the planet, you might say: ''Yippee! Good riddance to all that received wisdom and tiny typeface. Farewell to the dutiful handmaidens of authority.'' But not so fast.

title: Of Freddie's Bondage: A Tale Of Maugham as a Kibitzer
description: The only leading literary figure who was a bridge enthusiast was William Somerset Maugham, who introduced the game into some of his short stories, notably ''The Three Fat Women of Antibes.'' It was therefore predictable that he would become a victim of contract bridge's premier parodists, Phillip and Robert King.

title: Mets Stay Silent on Reasons For Fight
description: Rey Ordonez pressed a huge pack of ice against his left eye as he walked from the trainer's room to his locker in the Mets' clubhouse yesterday. He tried to hide his bruised eye from reporters but realized it was useless, so he discarded the ice and the full extent of the injury became visible. It looked horrible.

title: NEWELL RUBBERMAID SHARES PLUNGE ON NEGATIVE REPORT
description: The stock of Newell Rubbermaid Inc., the maker of Rubbermaid household goods and other consumer products, plunged to a 52-week low yesterday after the company said its third-quarter earnings would be weaker than expected. The company, based in Freeport, Ill., blamed ''retail demand sluggishness'' in all its businesses. Newell said third-quarter earnings, excluding one-time items, were likely to be 43 to 47 cents a share, below analysts' estimates of 51 cents, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. In the third quarter of 1998 the company earned 46 cents a share, including one-time items. Newell's shares dropped $8.4375 each, to $32.875.

title: Despite Cancer, Bishop Prepares to Head L.I. Diocese
description: Two weeks after undergoing surgery for cancer, James. T. McHugh, the Coadjutor Bishop, said Thursday that there had been no change in plans for him to succeed Bishop John R. McGann as leader of Long Island's 1.4 million Roman Catholics.

title: From Spy to Statesman
description: Can a former spy make a good prime minister? As the longtime head of East Germany's foreign intelligence service, my answer is yes. In any case, all of us should hope I'm right, since Vladimir Putin, Russia's latest Prime Minister, is, like the two who immediately preceded him, a former intelligence operative.

title: $3.8 BILLION MORE FOR SEOULBANK
description: South Korea said it would spend another 4.5 trillion won ($3.8 billion) by about Sept. 20 to keep Seoulbank afloat after HSBC Holdings P.L.C. abandoned a six-month takeover bid. The Korea Stock Exchange suspended trading in the bank's shares, with the Financial Supervisory Commission declaring it a nonviable lender. The Government spent 1.5 trillion won in January 1998 to prop up the bank, taking a 94 percent stake in return. The Korea Asset Management Corporation has since injected 400 billion won in return for taking over bad loans.

title: Regulators, Suspecting Fraud, Shut a Bank
description: Federal bank regulators said this week that they had closed the First National Bank of Keystone in West Virginia after finding evidence of apparent fraud.

title: Excerpts From Statements By Reno on Waco Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference by Attorney General Janet Reno today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Clinton's Do-Overs, Off the Course and On; Public Doesn't Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH PHONE RATES CUT
description: Bowing to competitive pressures, British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced a new initiative to cut residential phone rates for British customers. The new plan includes a ''call allowance'' for local calls made on the weekend and reductions in prices, in some cases by as much as 50 percent, on local and national phone calls. Local calls in Britain had been metered by the minute. Charges for international calls have also been reduced. Analysts said the new plan might signify a larger move toward eventual adoption of United States-style local calling plans. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Valentine Says 'Darn' as Mets Let One Slip Away
description: Chuck McElroy was trying to tidy up Turk Wendell's mess last night, trying to keep the Mets breathing in extra innings and trying to do it against his former team. It was the type of tense spot that gave the Mets their daily dose of pennant fever. Bases loaded, two out, tie score, 10th inning, McElroy facing the Colorado team that traded him to New York five weeks ago.

title: Merger of Churches May Not Be a Sign That Faith Is in Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen and euro as a weaker-than-expected jobs report reduced concern the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month. The dollar settled at 110.05 yen, up from 109.11.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HANNAH
description: LEVIN-Hannah. Loving sister of Shulamis Friedman and aunt of Daniel Goldberg, Judith-Kate and Alan Friedman, Michael, Ruth and Jacqueline Levin. Great aunt of Jessica and Laura Goldberg and Jacob, Noah and Andrew Levin. Died suddenly September 2, 1999. She was a tower of strength to her family and legion of friends, and will be sorely missed. Services to be held 10AM Sunday, September 5th, Hirsch/Parkside Chapel, 167 Street and Jerome Ave, Bronx. Contributions may be made to YIVO in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, JOAN DEKEYSER
description: BARON-Joan DeKeyser. August 25, 1999. Of Manhattan. Adoring mother of Stacey and loving grandmother of Drew. Passionate 36 year career on Broadway as a theatre manager. Services on Thursday, September 16th, 11AM, Ethical Culture Society.

title: History Fueling Confident Comets
description: There are two particularly scary thoughts for the Liberty players to ponder as they prepare to take on the Houston Comets in the second of their two-of-three-game Women's National Basketball Association championship series here on Saturday afternoon.

title: Leaders of Harlem Rally Find Support Precarious in Rap World
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad had a lot of ground to cover during his five-minute speech at the spectacularly misnamed Million Youth March last year. Between his demands for black power, Mr. Muhammad found time to call Jews ''bloodsuckers,'' to describe several black politicians as ''sissified,'' and to denounce Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Police Department and the United States Constitution.

title: Younger Gotti Is Sentenced To Six Years
description: Five months after pleading guilty to racketeering and extortion charges, John A. Gotti was sentenced today by a Federal District Court judge to six years and five months in prison, a bittersweet coda to his alleged reign as the acting boss of the Gambino crime family.

title: DELAY IN SALE OF DAEWOO ELECTRONICS
description: A final contract on the sale of the Daewoo Electronics Company is likely to be delayed until some time after next Thursday, the previously announced date, Hanvit Bank said. The bank said the creditors of Daewoo Electronics had recently talked to Walid Alomar & Associates, a Beverly Hills, Calif., investment firm interested in purchasing part of the electronics maker, giving notice that creditors cannot approve any contract before assessing its assets and liabilities. With Daewoo Electronics under a debt-rescheduling program, the company's creditors have the right to manage its sale. Samuel Len

title: Police Find Body in Cellar Of a House in East Orange
description: The decomposed body of a woman who the authorities say could be a mother of three who vanished almost a year ago was found Thursday night buried in the cellar of a three-story house here.

title: Terminal Cancer Patients' Will to Live Is Found to Fluctuate
description: Proponents of a right to assisted suicide argue that choosing death can be a rational response to intolerable suffering, while opponents caution that inadequate treatment for pain, depression or other conditions can color the decision to die.

description: Dear President and Mrs. Clinton:

description: To the Editor:

title: Malula Journal; Passing On History by Word of Mouth
description: These days, Damascus lies just 45 minutes away, on improved roads that mean that the journey between this isolated village and the capital no longer strikes anyone as forbidding.

title: What Do St. Francis, Babe Ruth and Crocodiles Have in Common?
description: CRYING

title: Intrusions on Electronic Privacy
description: In trying to prevent criminals from using new electronic technologies in illegal activities, the Clinton Administration has been deaf to the privacy concerns of law-abiding citizens. The Justice Department argues that electronic surveillance by the Government would hurt only those involved in crime, not the law-abiding citizen. But erosions of privacy affect all Americans. As more people use computers and new technology to communicate and conduct business, balancing the need to protect electronic privacy against law enforcement requirements is crucial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN OKIN, BABETTE
description: SLOTKIN OKIN-Babette. Of Palm Beach, FL and formerly of New York City and Detroit, MI, passed away on August 31, 1999 after a short illness. Beloved wife of Robert Okin. Devoted mother of Donald, Mitchell, Curt and Todd Slotkin, her children from her marriage to the late Hugo Slotkin. Cherished mother-in-law of Edie, Pamela, Carole and Judy. Loving grandmother of Douglas, Steven, Bobby, Daniel, Trevor, Elissa, Keith, Matthew, William, Thomas and Peter. Caring step-mother to Kenneth and Dennis Okin. Her wisdom, love and wit live on in our hearts. She will be missed by many dear friends. Funeral service will be held on September 2 1:30 pm at the Ira Kaufman Chapel (800-325-7105), 18325 W. Nine Mile Road, Southfield, MI. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Craft Gallery, 5911 S. Dixie Highway, West Palm Beach, FL. 33405, or charity of one's choice.

title: As Pressure Builds, Reno Appears Calm
description: At this morning's weekly press briefing, Attorney General Janet Reno answered virtually every question by saying she was ''dedicated to finding the truth,'' wanted to ''use the process to get to the truth'' and planned to ''continue to pursue the truth.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, HUGH
description: WILEY-Hugh, 72, died Friday, September 3, 1999 at Oak Hill Farm, Palmyra, Va. Funeral service will be private. A memorial service will be at Oak Hill in Palmyra at 12 Noon, Saturday, September 11th. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Fluvanna County Rescue Squad, P.O. Box 96, Palmyra, Va. 22963. Information: Hill & Wood Funeral Home.

title: Unsettling the Art World for a Living; A Critic Resurrects Beauty as a Standard, and Finds It in Unexpected Places
description: The physical boundaries of Dave Hickey's world are clear enough. He lives in a nondescript apartment complex improbably called Country Club Towers, wedged in a triangle made by the Las Vegas Country Club, the Las Vegas Convention Center and the World Trade Center Hotel and Casino, a low-rent gambling hall with a line of faux Grecian statues in the front. He has a sunshine-to-neon, skyline-to-mountain view of that singular slice of the American landscape, the Las Vegas Strip.

title: FRANCE URGED TO CUT STAKE
description: The German Government is pressing France to reduce its stake in the aerospace company Aerospatiale Matra S.A., to clear the way for a merger with DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s aerospace unit. A spokeswoman at the German Economics Ministry confirmed a report in the newspaper Handelsblatt that Siegmar Mosdorf, Germany's air and space coordinator, had met this week with officials of the consortium Airbus Industrie and asserted that the French Government should reduce its 48 percent stake in Aerospatiale. DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, known as Dasa, wants no state involvement in Aerospatiale or Airbus saying that it slows vital decisions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a proposal for Governors Island by a mayoral task force misstated the landmark status of a building on the island that would become part of a conference center under the plan. The building is indeed included in a landmark district established by both New York City and the Federal government.

title: RENO VOWS TO GET AT TRUTH ON FIRE AT CULT COMPOUND
description: Attorney General Janet Reno, swept up once again in a furious law-enforcement controversy, said today that she would demand the facts to determine whether the F.B.I. played any role in starting a deadly fire that broke out during the 1993 assault on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex.

title: Mauresmo Continues Rise From Nowhere
description: Over the last year, Amelie Mauresmo has shed pretense like someone shrugging off an overcoat. With nothing to hide anymore, Mauresmo took her mark beneath the penetrating lights of Arthur Ashe Stadium last night as a player openly gay and visibly talented.

title: Of Paranoid Delusions And Some Other Troubles
description: There are unlikely-looking rock stars, and then there is Kevin Coyne. ''I'd like to be exciting and entertain you all, and dash around the stage, but I'm getting old and rather obese and I don't care,'' declared the veteran English singer to the small crowd greeting him at the Bottom Line on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORGES, WALTER
description: PORGES-Walter. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Walter Porges, the brother of Lisl Schick, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Walter O. Wells, 87, a Pioneer in Mobile Homes
description: Walter O. Wells, a former chairman of the Schult Homes Corporation, who helped start mobile homes on the road to what became the manufactured housing industry in the United States, died Monday at his home in Elkhart, Ind. He was 87.

title: WESTERN WIRELESS PURCHASES THREE NEW LICENSES
description: The Western Wireless Corporation, which provides wireless telephone service to rural customers in 18 western states, agreed yesterday to pay $195 million for licenses in Texas, Arkansas and Utah, to expand its service area. Western Wireless is buying the licenses, which cover an area with about 520,000 people and include about 27,000 subscribers, from K.O. Communications Inc., Netwireless L.L.C. and American Rural Cellular Inc. Cellular phone companies are rushing to create nationwide networks to better compete with the AT&T Corporation's wireless unit and Sprint Corporation's PCS Group. Western Wireless's shares, which have tripled so far this year, rose $1.0625, to $40.8125.

title: Beliefs; Seeking to bridge the gap between Catholic health institutions and labor organizers.
description: Since the late 19th century, the Roman Catholic Church has endorsed labor unions as an essential instrument of justice. But over time the church has found that it was one thing to defend the right of workers to organize in mills, mines and warehouses but a far more sensitive matter when it came to its own religious institutions.

title: Chrebet to Miss 6 Weeks With A Broken Foot
description: It was supposed to be a critical look at a backup quarterback, but tonight's final preseason game turned out to be costly for the Jets.

title: Hingis Dominates, and Then Reconciles
description: Martina Hingis's expression didn't change. With the smile of a barracuda that knows where its next meal is, she squashed her inexperienced opponent and then chugged to the next bit of stage business at the United States Open, a public reconciliation with Richard Williams.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Man Charged In Shooting Of Co-worker
description: A shooting at a financial services company in midtown Manhattan yesterday left one worker hospitalized, another under arrest, and dozens of others shocked and confused in the bustling business district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNBY, KATHLEEN
description: HORNBY-Kathleen, age 53, a longtime New York City resident and school teacher, died at her Santa Barbara home September 2, 1999 after a courageous battle with cancer. Survived by Geoffrey, Matthew, Louise and her dear dogs. Services will be held at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Santa Barbara, September 11th at 11:00AM. Donations may be made to a charity of choice.

title: Corrections
description: An On the Road column in Weekend on Aug. 27 about Montreal, where regulations mandate that French be the most prominent language in advertising, misstated the cause of a dispute over a stonecutter's sign. The sign was in Hebrew and French, not Hebrew and English, and the Hebrew letters were taller.

title: Political Notes; After Clintons Visit, Village's Name Twists Tongues Worldwide
description: After a last stop for a cup of ''Clinton Crunch'' ice cream in this village that has spent the last week in a jubilant uproar, the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton finally went home to Washington today, giving local citizens a chance to rest.

title: Prosecutors Argue Against Dismissing Conspiracy Charge in Louima Case
description: Federal prosecutors in the Abner Louima case yesterday disputed defense arguments that a criminal conspiracy charge against three police officers should be dismissed because it is legally defective.

title: Oregon Board Disciplines Doctor for Not Treating Patients' Pain
description: In what appears to be the first such action in the nation, the Oregon Board of Medical Examiners this week disciplined a doctor for insufficiently treating pain in his patients.

title: Swimming Ban Is Lifted At Three State Beaches
description: Swimming was again permitted yesterday at Jones Beach and other state beaches that had been closed because of the heavy undercurrents and other effects of Hurricanes Cindy and Dennis, officials said.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SLIDES. A forecast for Brazil's coffee regions showed an increased likelihood of rain next week, which could bolster production. In New York, coffee for December delivery settled down 1.8 cents, to 92.3 cents a pound.

title: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- Jobless Rate in August Again Dipped to a 29-Year Low; Markets Rally, Reflecting Hope on Interest Rates
description: Financial markets made a volatile about-face yesterday, as stocks and bonds rallied on the news that the economy generated fewer new jobs than expected last month.

title: Ending Weapon Spread
description: To the Editor:

title: Many G.O.P. Governors Now Pushing for Greater Gun Control
description: As each new high-profile shooting roils the national debate over gun ownership rights, advocates for greater gun control are winning a measure of support from Republican governors, an unlikely source.

title: Move Stirs Speculation In Malaysia a Snap Election May Be Called : Mahathir Bows Out of APEC Summit
description: KUALA LUMPU  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia has canceled plans to attend this month's meeting of Pacific Rim countries in New Zealand, a top Malaysian official announced Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians misstated which side, under the Hebron agreement of 1997, wanted an additional Israeli pullback in April 1998. It was the Palestinians, not the Israelis.

title: Smart Mice
description: The report that scientists have created a smarter strain of mice by inserting extra copies of a particular gene into fertilized mouse eggs is a neat technical advance with perplexing implications. When put through a battery of tests, the mice with the inserted genes turned out to have superior ability in learning and memory compared with normal mice. They were better able to remember the location of a submerged platform, recognize the shape of objects they had seen before, and associate tones with electric shocks administered at the same time. The differences were not huge -- these are no Einstein mice -- but they were measurable.

title: Tempering the Zeal for Historic Preservation
description: I n 1941, persuaded by the rallying cry of ''tout ensemble'' (we together), the Louisiana Supreme Court decided that the City of New Orleans had the authority to regulate what happened to buildings in the French Quarter. In so doing, the court saved this neighborhood from demolition and provided the legal basis for historic preservation.

title: Just How Uniform Must Uniforms Be?; For Many Public School Students, It's a Struggle to Mesh The New Dress Codes With Their Own Sense of Style
description: Chanel Gilpin stood unsmiling as her mother cooed how cute she looked in her new school uniform: a blue, pleated jumper with a short-sleeved yellow shirt.

title: 3 Admit Lying About Test For Gasoline Pollution
description: Three supervisors at a gasoline testing laboratory in Linden admitted yesterday to falsifying chemical analyses so that millions of gallons of gasoline appeared to meet Federal environmental standards, prosecutors said.

title: G.O.P. Letter Plays On Nuclear Threat
description: A recent fund-raising letter asking for contributions of $25 or more to help the Senate protect the United States from a looming nuclear attack by North Korea is raising some eyebrows in the nation's capital, where hyperbole is practically the native tongue.

title: SHOE SHARES ACQUIRED
description: The Italian shoemaker Diego Della Valle has increased its stake in Church & Company P.L.C., the British men's shoemaker, which said on Thursday that it was in talks with a possible bidder. A London Stock Exchange notice said Della Valle had acquired a further 25,000 Church shares, or 8.64 percent, at 885 pence a share. Diego Della Valle is an Italian fashion designer whose units make J. P. Tod loafers, above, and Acqua di Parma cologne. Last month, a Della Valle rival, Prada Holdings Ltd., acquired an 8.5 percent stake in Church.

title: ICG COMMUNICATIONS SELLS FIBER OPTIC HOLDING
description: ICG Communications Inc., a local telephone company, agreed yesterday to sell its fiber optic unit to closely held ACS Communications Inc. for more than $20 million in cash to focus on phone and data services. ICG said it was selling the unit, which installs and designs cable and had $65 million in revenue last year, to focus on providing phone, data and Internet service to businesses. ACS, based in Austin, Tex., also designs and installs cable for voice and data transfer and has 550 employees. ICG is based in Englewood, Colo.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You dig at it until you get it right and you get people telling you what actually happened. You don't run away from it. You don't say, 'Oh, me. I can't handle this.' You keep at it till you get to the truth.''

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY TO REORGANIZE SOFTWARE UNIT
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the world's No. 1 maker of computer disk drives, said yesterday that it would revamp its software unit. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., will buy the 6.5 percent of its Seagate Software unit it does not own for eight million shares, or about $280 million, and take a charge against earnings of $216 million. With the move, the company gains full control of the 61 million shares of the Veritas Software Corporation held by the unit, valued at about $4 billion. Seagate Technology, which is expected to report a loss this quarter, is cutting prices sharply to compete with rivals. The restructuring gives Seagate unhindered access to the Veritas shares.

title: In East Timor, Decisive Vote For a Break From Indonesia
description: After 24 years of brutal occupation by Indonesia, and defying a campaign of terror instigated by the military, the people of East Timor have voted overwhelmingly to become an independent nation, the United Nations announced today.

title: From Start to Finish, It's Doom for the Giants
description: On the second play, they lost their starting running back. On the last play, they lost the game.

title: A Time to Fight, a Time to Agree
description: As important as any concrete agreements reached today between Israel and the Palestinians is what the success in negotiating them portends.

title: ISRAEL AND P.L.O., WITH HELP OF U.S., REACH AN ACCORD
description: Israel and the Palestinians, prodded by the presence of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, reached a crucial agreement tonight that envisions finalizing the borders between them and resolving the future of Jerusalem in one year.

title: BELGIAN BANK SEIZES DAEWOO CARS
description: The second-largest financial concern in Belgium, Bank Brussels Lambert, has filed a lawsuit against Daewoo Group to secure the repayment of its $10 million loan to the conglomerate's overseas motor sales unit. The Belgian bank seized 60,000 Daewoo cars in lieu of its loans to Daewoo Motor Sales Europe, after the company had failed to repay the principal amount of the debt. It is the second foreign creditor to disclose legal action against the troubled enterprise in a bid to secure debt repayments. The South Korean Financial Supervisory Commission, the agency overseeing Daewoo's corporate restructuring, has said it will not repay the group's overseas debts for the time being. Samuel Len

title: CHILE LIFTS CONTROLS
description: As Latin American Governments increasingly move toward exchange- rate policies that allow freely floating currencies, Chile's central bank lifted controls on the peso for the first time in 15 years. The decision, viewed as more a technicality than a substantial policy shift, was accompanied by a weakening of the peso to a record low of 522.30 to the dollar before a slight rebound. Since Chile is seen as one of Latin America's healthiest economies, the peso has rarely come under the speculative pressure that currencies in some of the region's countries have faced in recent years. Simon Romero

title: Coca-Cola Offers Warning Of Weakness in Near Term
description: The Coca-Cola Company confirmed Wall Street's fears yesterday that near-term profits will suffer, as improving unit volume remains a challenge for the rest of this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 22 about Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss banker, misstated a United States Government assertion in a lawsuit involving money laundering. The Government asserted that proceeds from drug sales had been deposited in Antigua into the Swiss American Bank and the Swiss American National Bank, not into the Bank of New York-Inter Maritime. (The Bank of New York-Inter Maritime, a Geneva bank of which Mr. Rappaport is chairman, has no branch in Antigua.) The Government also asserted in the suit that all three banks, which it called parts of an ''Inter Maritime empire,'' have common ownership.

title: Brosius Returns to the Yankees After Precious Moments With His Father
description: The phone call will come and Scott Brosius believes it will be soon. Cancer is ravaging Maury Brosius, the father of the Yankees' third baseman, and over the last five days Scott Brosius left the team to be at the bedside of his living parent in Oregon, to talk, to trade thoughts and memories, to say goodbye. The son felt blessed.

title: French Magistrates Clear Photographers in Death of Diana
description: French judges today dismissed all charges against nine photographers and a press motorcyclist who were being investigated for their role in the Paris car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, two years ago.

title: With 25 States at Odds, Court Will Resolve Clean Air Issue
description: Twenty-five states have given up trying to negotiate a settlement in their dispute over pollution that blows into the Northeast from the Midwest and South, meaning that the issue will be resolved in court, state officials said today.

title: Heroism in Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: Labor Day

title: The Fighter Jet That Doesn't Need to Be Resurrected
description: Will decisions made in the heat of summer survive the cooler, crisper climate of fall? In the case of the F-22 fighter jet, we should all hope so.

title: Multiple Killing Inquiry Leads to Search of Store
description: About 20 law enforcement officers descended on a thrift store in Linden on Thursday afternoon in an effort to link a Linden man to the 1958 murder of a Rahway police officer and the killings of at least four teen-age girls.

title: A Mysterious Component Roils Microsoft
description: A cryptographer for a Canadian software firm, dissecting a piece of Microsoft security software, made an unexpected find: an element in the Windows operating system labeled ''NSAKey.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Dust-Up At the Top Of the Stretch
description: STEVE PHILLIPS stood between the Mets infielders Rey Ordonez and Luis Lopez yesterday in a scene out of a grade-school principal's office in the aftermath of a schoolyard brawl. Phillips, the Mets' general manager, was like the principal standing between two naughty students, forcing them to apologize to the student body for fidgeting.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Encephalitis Strikes 3 People, 1 Fatally, In Queens, City Says
description: An elderly resident of Queens died this week from a mosquito-borne viral disease known as St. Louis encephalitis, and city health officials fear that at least nine other people have been infected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Labor Goes to Capitalism's Citadel, and the Sky Doesn't Fall
description: The head of a movement that has often been the nemesis of business -- the labor movement -- did an unlikely thing in an unlikely place yesterday. He rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, LIONEL STEWART SR.
description: JACKSON-Lionel Stewart Sr. Former publisher of the New Haven Register and Journal-Courier Newspapers died peacefully at home in Montecito, California on September 1, 1999 after a long illness. His loving wife Patricia Hope Johnstone Jackson, sister Katherine Reece, daughters Susan Cartier, Sheila Leach and son Lionel Stewart Jackson Jr. and five grandchildren survive him. Born in New Haven on June 25, 1915, Mr. Jackson was the son of the late John Day Jackson and Rose Herrick Jackson, and was the sixth of a family of eight children. Mr. Jackson graduated from Kent School in 1933. One of his fondest memories of his years there was his membership on the rowing crew that brought the school its first ever to win in the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta in England. For fifty years prior to his retirement in 1987 Mr. Jackson was the CEO and publisher of the Jackson Newspapers based in New Haven, Connecticut. Mr. Jackson's father, John Day Jackson, purchased The Register in 1895 launching a publishing operation that was to become the New Haven region's dominant newspaper concern. Those who worked for Mr. Jackson recall him as a considerate boss who cared deeply about the newspapers, his employees and his community. ''Lionel Jackson was a gentle and thoughtful man'', said Walter J. Nester, former Vice President and General Manager at The Register, who knew Mr. Jackson for more than 40 years. ''He was devoted to the newspapers and the community they served. He enjoyed the challenge of publishing good newspapers. I know I share with many current and former employees who knew Lionel a deep sense of loss.'' Mr. Jackson was active in a wide variety of businesses, civic and cultural organizations. A list of organizations in which he served as a Director or member at one time during his life would include: the former Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, The Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, The President's Advisory Council of Quinnepiac College, Yale-New Haven Hospital, The United Way of Greater New Haven, The Salvation Army, and the Connecticut Blue Cross. Mr. Jackson also served as a Director of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, and as a member of the Central Housing Committee and the Connecticut Action Committee. He was also a strong supporter of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, and was named as an honorary director of that organization. Mr. Jackson was an accomplished pianist who once soloed with the New Haven Businessman's Orchestra. An avid boater, Mr. Jackson often commuted alone between his summer home on outer Long Island and Connecticut. He captained his small diesel powered yacht along Intercoastal waterways between Long Island Sound and Florida on almost an annual basis. Mr. Jackson was a member of several yacht clubs, including the Devon Yacht Club of East Hampton, Long Island and one in Delray Beach, Florida. Mr. Jackson was also one of the strongest supporters of New Haven Boys Clubs, Inc. Private services will be held on Tuesday in Montecito, California. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Francis Medical Foundation in Santa Barbara, California.

title: Ideas That Cross and Collide In a Chugging Counterpoint

How else would you explain a serious jazz musician whose set includes ''Joga,'' by the pop singer Bjork, as well as Nino Rota's theme for the assassination of Don Tommasino in ''Godfather II''? At the same time, the group style of Mr. Moran's trio is all rhythmic volatility and interactive, spontaneously created form -- the new sound, as far as nightclub jazz is concerned.

title: PROTECTION ONE AND LIFELINE END MERGER TALKS
description: Protection One Inc. and Lifeline Systems Inc., citing regulatory delays, said late Thursday that they had agreed to terminate their proposed $174 million merger. The companies cited a delay in completing the deal, caused in part by a Securities and Exchange Commission review of how Protection One amortized customer accounts. In October 1998, Protection One, a publicly traded unit of Western Resources Inc., agreed to buy Lifeline. The transaction would have merged Lifeline -- which is based in Cambridge, Mass., and operates a nationwide paging system that elderly customers use to activate pendants to call for help -- into Protection One, a home-security company based in Culver City, Calif. Western Resources is based in Topeka, Kan.

description: Advanced Technical Products Inc., which makes housings that protect aircraft radar systems, agreed yesterday to be bought by the New York investment firm Veritas Capital Fund L.P. for $135 million in cash and assumed debt. Closely held Veritas will pay $14.50 a share. Veritas will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. An earlier cash-and-debt offer of $143.5 million for Advanced Technical from an unidentified bidder was canceled June 15. No reason was given. Advanced Technical, based in Roswell, Ga., has 1,600 workers and its 1998 sales were $165 million. It also makes tanks for natural gas vehicles, portable military shelters and chemical-agent detectors.

title: DIGITAL LINK FOUNDER SEEKS REST OF SHARES
description: The Digital Link Corporation's founder and chief executive offered to buy the remaining shares of the company, a telecommunications and networking equipment maker, that she does not already own. The offer of $10.30 a share in cash would take the company private. The founder, Vinita Gupta, who already owns 50 percent of Digital Link, formed the DLZ Corporation to buy out remaining shareholders through a tender offer. The offer is subject to DLZ's owning at least 90 percent of Digital Link's outstanding stock, among other conditions. It is set to expire Oct. 15. The company has about eight million shares outstanding, which would value the offer at about $41.2 million. The stock of Digital Link, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose $1.6875, to $9.875.

title: The Zen of Alzheimer's
description: To call Alzheimer's disease ''a grace, a cocoon, an escape into the pure moment,'' sent shivers through me. Gettinger confuses a Zen moment with successive periods of mental blankness that engender no reflection at all. A patient in the end stages of this disease could be looking at a flower or a shoot-'em-up on TV and not know the difference. I understand that he needs to put the best face on the experience of dealing with his mother's disease, but saying that forgetfulness ''set her free'' is ludicrous. The sooner a treatment is found the better.

title: Enough Retirement! Kusturica Returns To the Gypsy Life
description: ''I JUST couldn't stand the attacks any more -- like I was one of the biggest criminals against humanity.'' And so, in 1996, at the age of 41, the Sarajevo-born director Emir Kusturica announced his retirement. The international film community was shocked: only one year before, ''Underground,'' his powerful, apocalyptic film that raged against the dissolution of Yugoslavia, had won him his second Palm d'Or, the top prize at the Cannes International Film Festival. Nevertheless, he was deeply affected when the film was vehemently dismissed by intellectuals both in Germany and his adopted France as mere Serbian propaganda.

Without missing a beat, the Taiwanese editor on my left said, ''Oh, don't worry, your Dell was made here, too.'' The others laughed. I couldn't resist turning my Dell over and looking at the bottom. It said: ''Made in Taiwan.''

title: In Alaska, Helicopters Alarm Environmentalists
description: WHEN the United States Forest Service issued a permit in 1984 for the first commercial helicopter to land tourists on the Juneau Ice Field, it limited the landings to 400. Today four helicopter companies are allowed a total of 19,039 landings a year on the 100-mile-long ice field, and have petitioned for twice that. They also want to land at two of the ice field's 10 zones that were declared off limits to helicopters in 1987.

title: Damaging Delay on a Test Ban
description: Negotiating the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty in 1996 was a triumph for American diplomacy. Its provisions, which prohibit all atmospheric and underground nuclear tests, would lock in the United States' current technological lead, prevent China from testing advanced new weapons designs and block non-nuclear countries that have signed the treaty from conducting future nuclear tests. It would also put increased pressure on countries that have not yet signed, like India and Pakistan, to avoid further testing and to accept the treaty.

title: Lips, Nails, Oh Yeah, Book Bag
description: Back to school once meant sensible shoes and No. 2 pencils, but today's students, especially girls, have become fashion overachievers. From high-end beauty treatments to high-altitude platform shoes, girls from 8 to 18 are flexing their style -- and purchasing -- muscles. For a back-to-school wardrobe these days, ''you want to start with the classic basics and accessorize with trends from there,'' said Sarah Crow, 14, a ninth grader at the Brearley School. She shops with girlfriends once or twice a week, but will go with her mother ''if, really, nobody else is around.'' Even girls as young as 6 have style agendas, said Lisa Higgins, the merchandising vice president of Delia's, the popular catalogue. title: Against Irony
description: Jedediah Purdy is out on what he likes to call a ramble. Walking through the wooded hills near his family's remote West Virginia house, he snaps up wild blackberries and feels the soil that has been punished by the summer's drought. He eventually reaches a high meadow and finds a sprawling ash tree that holds special meaning for him. ''I had vaguely animist sensibilities as a boy,'' he says, spreading his pale hand along the bark. ''I used to come and drink from this tree after a rain. Water would seep from its exposed roots. I had no predictive theory of what would happen when I drank from it. I just figured I would find out.'' If the natural world once inspired mystical thoughts in Purdy, it now brings out his professorial side. Pausing to examine a dry stream bed, he muses: ''Nature is a complicated and layered repository of human aspirations. It was a privilege to grow up in this landscape.''

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Big Drop in AIDS Deaths Begins to Slow
description: The substantial decline in AIDS deaths that began after newer combinations of drugs were introduced nearly four years ago has slowed -- to 20 percent from 1997 to 1998 compared to 42 percent from 1996 to 1997, Federal health officials reported. The newer therapies are benefiting many people infected with the AIDS virus, but have led many others to think that drugs alone will wipe out AIDS, experts said. They urged renewed efforts at prevention to overcome the complacency. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: The Russian Devolution
description: Joseph Stiglitz, the chief economist at the World Bank, is right when he says that the establishment of a legal and financial market infrastructure should have preceded ''flash cut'' privatization in our policy toward Russia. But not only do markets require strong courts, banks and contracts, they also require strong cultural traditions to make them work. The very pervasiveness of those traditions makes it too easy for us in the United States -- including economists like myself -- to take for granted that we live in a society that has regarded private property and stable currencies as givens, practically since the Magna Carta. No wonder we'd think that all we have to do is say, Ready, Set, Privatize, and no wonder we'd be wrong.

title: Petticoat Junction
description: Fashion moves to its own beat, not to the calendar. The space age millennium look envisioned by some designers has yet to take hold, as others borrow ideas from the past and reinterpret them to meet the present demand for comfort and speed in dressing. One of this summer's successes has been the one-size-fits-all drawstring petticoat, inspired by the underskirt of the Victorian age. In the 1880's, the petticoat was worn over a wire bustle and under an outer dress, creating a silhouette that was full in back and flat in front. Today, the once-hidden petticoat is worn on its own, for both day and evening, in a variety of fabrics, from silk to cotton.

''We're dealing with girls who have sophisticated tastes and incredible senses of style,'' said Mr. Madden, noting the influence of fashion-filled teen-woe shows like ''Dawson's Creek.'' title: Getting It in Writing
description: The Krueger-Scott Mansion, an outstanding example of Victorian design in Newark, is being restored an preserved and used as a cultural center. In the process, the life stories of many of the city's African-Americans are being preserved as well. Since 1995, volunteers from the center have been tape-recording interviews with 120 Newark residents age 60 to 115 on topics like migration to the city, the jazz movement, the 1967 riots and the election of the first black mayor. On Aug. 1, the New Jersey Council for the Humanities awarded $5,000 to the cultural center to transcribe 100 hours of the tapes, representing 30 or 40 interviews. The transcripts will be the first entries in a series called ''The Lost Years Recovered: Oral Histories of African-Americans in Newark, N.J., From 1910 to 1970.'' The transcript are due to be indexed and made available by 2001 at the Newark Public Library, the New Jersey Historical Society and Rutger University. Meanwhile, the center is looking for money to transcribe more of the tapes.
