title: Ideas & Trends: Eek!; The Hidden Traps In Fooling Mother Nature
description: NOW that researchers have shown that mice can be made smarter, a whole world of opportunities opens up. Those long-neglected inventors of smarter mousetraps will at last get their calls returned. Smarter cats will be needed. And everyone will have a list of humans who might benefit, starting perhaps with the baseball umpires or, in the case of most evolutionists, with the Kansas Board of Education.

title: Jocelyn Strauber and Mark Gordon
description: Jocelyn Emily Strauber, the daughter of Rachel and Donald Strauber of New York, is to be married this evening to Mark Gordon, a son of Ita and David Gordon of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Man Jabbed With Needle In a Subway Robbery
description: A 23-year-old man riding the subway in Manhattan yesterday was robbed by two young men who jabbed him in the arm with a hypodermic needle, the police said.

title: Flexing at Goldman, Sachs
description: Executives at Goldman, Sachs can burn off steam or steam off stress at the investment bank's custom-designed private health club. Goldman built the gym earlier this year in a loft space decorated with glass and blond wood fixtures at its offices in lower Manhattan. Employees can pay a nominal fee to use the club, which is closed to outsiders.

title: Katharine Procter, William Lewis
description: Katharine Wyman Procter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Procter Jr. of Darien, Conn., is to be married there this afternoon to William Henry Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Lewis of Cleveland. The Rev. E. Tucker Bowerfind is to perform the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Frustrations at Bellevue: Physician, Insure Thyself
description: Medical residents at Bellevue Hospital Center are accustomed to seeing patients without insurance -- they flow through the emergency room doors by the dozens daily. The residents never anticipated that they would be among them.

title: Backtalk; The Legendary Lemon Drop Kid Lives On Through a 3-Year-Old Colt
description: Al Capone was sitting in a steambath in Chicago one day when a stranger struck up a conversation. The stranger talked glowingly of an impending business deal and said that if mum was the word, Scarface, er, Al, could make a quick killing, so to speak. All Capone had to do was lend the stranger $2,000 until later.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 5, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Hirschfeld Pays Jurors After Trial
description: Prompting concerns that he might be trying to influence future juries that will decide his fate, Abe Hirschfeld, the parking garage magnate, paid $2,500 on Friday to each of the 10 members of a jury that deadlocked last week over whether he was guilty of tax fraud.

title: $35 Million for Atlantic City Housing
description: What Mayor James Whelan describes as arguably the worst neighborhood in Atlantic City sits right next to the pride of the city's redevelopment efforts, the Northeast Inlet area where hundreds of new housing units have been constructed along grassy lanes and modern streets in the last decade to create an economically and racially integrated neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DORIS R., M.A., R.N.
description: SCHWARTZ-Doris R., M.A., R.N. The staff and faculty of New YorkPresbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University are saddened by the passing of their esteemed colleague, Doris R. Schwartz. A long-time member of the faculties of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing and Cornell University Medical College, Ms. Schwartz was widely recognized for her pioneering role in developing training programs for advanced nurse practitioners, particularly in geriatrics and family medicine. As a teacher, she fostered the spirit of public health nursing in her students and emphasized the importance of meeting patients' needs beyond the walls of the hospital. Following her retirement in 1980, she continued to hold an appointment as Clinical Associate Professor Emeritus of Nursing in Public Health at the Medical College. Her many honors included election to the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences. New York-Presbyterian Hospital David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman, President & CEO Doris M. Glick Vice President, Nursing New York Weill Cornell Center Weill Medical College of Cornell University Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. The Stephen & Suzanne Weiss Dean

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Bad Trip
description: Mistreated adolescents have often squirmed at the center of the cartoonist Lynda Barry's strange universe, but never so disturbingly as in CRUDDY: An Illustrated Novel (Simon & Schuster, $23). The book, named for the favorite adjective of the 16-year-old Roberta Rohbeson, tells two intertwined stories set five years apart. We first meet Roberta -- a girl who claims she is so ugly that boys bark at her and offer her dog biscuits awhen she is 11, and she begins to recount a home life so unrelentingly horrific as to seem a hallucination. But we really come to know her only through a diary in which the teen-age Roberta, suicidal and seeking acceptance from a whacked-out girlfriend and a wan hippie called the Turtle, details, with an eerie calm, a nightmarish (and involuntary) cross-country road trip with ''the father,'' a man who addresses her as ''Clyde.'' This man may or may not be her actual father; Roberta is never quite sure. He's an out-of-work meatcutter who carries the tools of his trade -- a terrifying set of butcher knives, each with its own name (''Little Debbie'') -- and who goes insane while on the search for the three suitcases of his swindled inheritance, leaving a litter of bodies in his wake. How Roberta reacts to these events -- and to the psychological battering that precedes them -- is the crux of this story, which is populated with a cast of depraved (and often very funny) secondary characters. ''Cruddy'' can be uncomfortable to read -- Barry spares no repulsive description of the dark doings here, and a rotting stench and the swarming of flies seem to follow everywhere. But the author's ability to capture the paralyzing bleakness of despair, and her uncanny ear for dialogue, make this first novel a work of terrible beauty. Alanna Nash

title: Natalie Bottitta, Michael Barasch
description: Natalie Rose Bottitta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Bottitta of Sands Point, N.Y., was married on Friday to Michael Pisarro Barasch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Barasch of Rockville Centre, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Brendan Reardon at St. Peter of Alcantara in Port Washington, N.Y.

title: From the Venerable Cherry Lane A Stage for Fresher Voices
description: The Cherry Lane Theater had not staged a play in two years when Angelina Fiordellisi bought it in 1996. She and her staff quickly rehabilitated the 178-seat landmark at 38 Commerce Street, and within six weeks ''The New Bozena'' was playing to audiences. It was the rebirth of an Off Broadway theater founded in 1924 by a group that included the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay. Works by Samuel Beckett, Edward Albee and Sam Shepard have been performed there.

title: Venezuelans Applaud Leader's Assault on System
description: On the television screen in Jorge Navarro Diaz's small restaurant here, a member of Venezuela's shuttered Congress was complaining that President Hugo Chavez had breached the rule of law and was leading the country into a dictatorship. But Mr. Navarro wasn't buying that argument.

title: Gina Como, Marc Durland
description: Gina Frances Como, the daughter of Pamela and Dominick Como of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Marc Joshua Durland, a son of Teresa and Denis Durland of Kings Point, N.Y. The Rev. G. John Carcich, a great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Church in the Bronx.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THIS week, television viewers are treated to adaptations of a master playwright's works, a Kurosawa thunderbolt, a suspenseful cross-country train ride and a sizzler about twins who swap identities.

title: Corrections
description: The Lives column on page 82 of The Magazine today misstates the name of the Boston station for which Janet Wu, its author, is a reporter. It is WHDH-TV, not WHCH-TV.

title: Keeping an Eye on the Storm in Long Beach
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria barreled across Long Island in September 1985, the waters from the bay and the ocean met in the westernmost streets of Long Beach and some people had three to four feet of water and sand in their homes. Damage was in the millions. Islandwide, the Federal Government and private insurance companies paid $200 million for repairs.

title: Gimelstob Finds That Emotion Is Not Enough
description: A baby cried and startled the hushed crowd like a bump in the night. Right in the middle of Justin Gimelstob's second serve, right on cue to trigger an anxiety attack. But the baby didn't bother Gimelstob.

title: All the Presidents Stink
description: Rich reflects the opinions many outsiders hold of the Washington establishment. Sally Quinn's article in The Washington Post made it clear that she holds all politicians -- but especially poor boys -- in contempt. We outsiders understand that their arrogance extends to all who dwell outside their circle. And we return the favor.

title: What Do You Do About Mao?
description: In 1992, a retired book editor named zhu zheng read a short essay a friend of his had written about the Anti-Rightist Campaign of 1957. That year, more than half a million people were purged after they responded to Mao Zedong's invitation to criticize the revolution, only to find themselves branded enemies.

title: Angels in the Workplace; Selling Peace Lilies, And Handing Out Good Will
description: There is no doorman tending the lobby of 881 Tenth Avenue, a five-story brick apartment building in Clinton. But residents do have the florist next door.

title: In Newark, the Toll of Airport Rage
description: At Gate 115 in Terminal C at Newark International Airport, the Little Tikes log cabin is a conspicuous display of Continental Airlines' professed friendliness toward toddlers. And on a busy Friday afternoon recently, four little tykes ran giggling in and out of the plastic cabin as one mother looked on with a smile.

title: An Indo-Caribbean Bazaar, But Some Yearn for the Gap
description: For Jai Ramoutar, a tourist from Trinidad, a trip to Liberty Avenue is not what New York City is all about. The 20-block strip is packed with West Indian markets, sari palaces and shops selling roti, the tortillalike bread stuffed with curried meat and vegetables. Rather, Mr. Ramoutar said over his dinner at the Hot and Spicy Roti Shop, Liberty Avenue is too much like home.

title: And a Side of Schnitzel
description: That quintessential New Jersey icon -- the diner -- may soon become a defining part of the European landscape as well.

title: Waco, Forever Unresolved
description: Americans love investigations, not because they ask the right questions, though they often do, but because they address unanswerable questions: Is there a Communist conspiracy? What did the President know and when did he know it? What is the meaning of ''is''?

title: Sticky Fingers
description: THE HONEY THIEF

title: In Russia, a Power Play Acted Out on Television
description: If television is, as it increasingly seems to be, the weapon of choice in Russia's intense and ugly political battles, then Sunday night will offer Russian viewers, on two of the country's major channels, a journalistic rendition of ''Gunfight at the O.K. Corral.''

title: Arts Center in Distress
description: Financial trouble and a reorganization at the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill are responsible for the elimination by the board of trustees of two key positions, executive director and director of programming, Gladys Muller, the board president, said on Tuesday.

title: Near Goodspeed, an Eatery's Spirited Revival
description: WITH views of the Connecticut River as glorious as those from the Gelston House in East Haddam, the food doesn't have to be great. Fortunately, the food at the handsome old establishment is -- with very few cavils -- the best it has been in years.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Tavern Days

title: Edward Bassett, Architect, Is Dead at 77
description: Edward Charles Bassett, a widely praised architect whose work ranged from San Francisco's symphony hall to the United States Embassy in Moscow, died last Saturday in a San Francisco hospital. He was 77 and lived in Mill Valley, Calif.

title: The World: Diana's Dubious Legacy; Land-Mine Ban Has Trouble Getting Off the Ground
description: IT has been two years since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, gave a last, emotional boost to an international treaty to ban anti-personnel land mines, then being feverishly negotiated in Oslo. Many say her efforts to draw attention to the fiendish effects of mines before her death may be one of her greatest legacies.

title: In Cape May County, a Time of Growing Pains
description: GAIL DWYER, talking about the houses rising across the street from hers in Avalon, displacing the killdeer that used to roost there, wonders whether there will be an inch of green space left. ''I took my first steps in Avalon,'' she said. ''They're taking away too much of what people come here for.''

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Cars for the Credit-Challenged
description: Mel Farr, a Detroit car dealer, doesn't mind leasing used cars to people with bad credit, as long as they don't mind driving around with a gizmo on the dashboard that keeps their cars from starting if they miss a payment.

title: A Master of Silence Who Speaks in Grays
description: THE first impression is that Jasper Johns, on the cusp of 70, is looking great. He has shed that C.E.O.'s look of pressured prosperity that he wore in the months leading up to his retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York three years ago. Contemplating a work in progress in his studio, in stone-washed khaki's and black T-shirt, he's serene and trim.

title: Erin Grossman and Brian Eizenstat
description: Erin Lyn Grossman, a daughter of Sondra and Peter Grossman of Milwaukee, is to be married this evening to Brian Lee Eizenstat, a son of Fran and Stuart E. Eizenstat of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi F. Barry Silberg is to perform the ceremony with Rabbi Michael Berenbaum at the Brynwood Country Club in Milwaukee.

title: The Eminence Of Excess
description: Nina Munk's article (Aug. 15) about Thierry Despont was fun. I remember reading a similar article a few years ago in Architectural Digest about the mansions built for 1920's and 30's movie stars.

title: Resin in the Sun
description: THE AMBER FOREST

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Scarcity Makes the Heart Grow Fonder
description: HAIME KEDMI, the owner of the downtown street-wear store Transit, eyed his chaotic display of pink gel-soled running shoes, aerodynamic high-tops and aquatic socks. Gingerly he selected a Nike Air Lava Dome sneaker with a bright orange swoosh and a rounded, reinforced toe that gave it the look of a corrective shoe. ''Aren't they hideous?'' he said proudly. ''They're one of our most popular models.''

title: Brains That Fly
description: To the Editor:

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Israelis and Palestinians Agree to Agree
description: After shuttling between both sides, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced that Israel and the Palestinians had concluded an agreement to implement the land-for-security accord they reached nearly a year ago at the Wye River resort in Maryland.

title: Donna Pascucci, Richard Burger
description: Donna Marie Pascucci and Richard Dehan Burger are to be married this afternoon by Deacon Lawrence Hammel at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Norwood; A Miniature U.N. Bordered by Parkland
description: NORWOOD residents like to boast that their neighborhood is like the United Nations. All continents on the globe are represented in the population of the north central Bronx community. Even more to the point, longtime residents say, like the U.N.'s General Assembly, Norwood has a long tradition of vibrant, sometimes raucous, community meetings over issues ranging from the health of the trees on Mosholu Parkway to local hospital services and Bangladeshi cultural programs at neighborhood schools.

title: Political Briefing; No Salt Needed With McCain Book
description: One of the hoary givens in Presidential politics is that any book by a candidate that comes out at campaign time, especially an autobiography or memoir, should be read with a full shaker of salt nearby, or maybe not at all. The sole aim of such books, of course, is to sell the candidate.

title: Business Built on Flavored Fortune Cookies
description: HOPING to make her future in fortune cookies is the goal of a fledgling entrepreneur, Ann Marie Cuozzo of Croton-on-Hudson. Ms. Cuozzo, who has held such diverse jobs as bookkeeper for a country club and driver of heavy equipment for a construction company, said she always planned to start a business of her own.

title: Charming In TriBeCa
description: BOULEY BAKERY

title: That Tune You're Humming? These Two Probably Wrote It
description: IN 1938, Orson Welles and John Houseman were the hottest two-man act on Broadway, and a great many otherwise sensible people thought their innovative Mercury Theater productions might be laying the groundwork for a national repertory theater. But even the most vital theatrical partnerships can be short-lived, and the Mercury, having put on just five shows in 14 months, would close its doors before the season was over, in the process putting its 15-year-old switchboard operator, a chubby blonde named Judy Holliday, out of a job.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; A Teachers' Strike in Detroit
description: Teachers in Detroit's public schools went on strike, refusing to work without a contract. That left 178,000 students on an extended summer vacation, and many of their parents scrambling to find child care.

title: Judit Polgar Is First Woman to Make It to the Semifinals
description: The International Chess Federation's World Championship, just finished in Las Vegas, Nev., saw an achievement new in its annals: for the first time a woman has reached the semifinals. Judit Polgar of Hungary has for some time been in the world's top 20, but now she has a new honor to go with her many tournament victories.

title: Unexpected Pleasures Hiding in the Files
description: THE Jersey City Museum keeps a slide file, and artists are encouraged to send images of their work on the principle that one never knows who might be interested in it. Recently this resource turned out to be the museum curator's best friend. When an exhibition fell through, Alejandro Anreus drew out the work of three New Jersey artists and fashioned a show titled ''From the Slide Registry: Valeri Larko, Maria Lau and Henry Sanchez.''

title: Giants' Equipment Men Run a Marathon
description: The humdrum of the 50-pound capacity washers and 65-pound capacity dryers do not stop for 13 hours a day, a rhythmic purr and rumble that could lull the sleep-deprived to slumber. But there is no sleep in the windowless, subterranean Giants' equipment room at Giants Stadium.

title: E-MEDICINE -- A special report.; Hailed as a Surgeon General, Koop Is Faulted on Web Ethics
description: During the eight years he held the post of United States Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop became one of the country's most authoritative and recognizable public figures on the subject of health.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Retiring the Beanie Babies
description: In what toy industry experts say may be a publicity stunt, Ty Inc., the maker of Beanie Babies, announced on its World Wide Web site that ''all Beanies will be retired'' as of Dec. 31.

title: The Singer Solution To World Poverty
description: The Australian philosopher Peter Singer, who later this month begins teaching at Princeton University, is perhaps the world's most controversial ethicist. Many readers of his book ''Animal Liberation'' were moved to embrace vegetarianism, while others recoiled at Singer's attempt to place humans and animals on an even moral plane. Similarly, his argument that severely disabled infants should, in some cases, receive euthanasia has been praised as courageous by some -- and denounced by others, including anti-abortion activists, who have protested Singer's Princeton appointment.

title: A Tree Falls in the Forest . . . Could It Have Been the Stress?
description: TREES are dying. Leaves are prematurely coloring, wilting and falling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAY, ROSE B.
description: JAY-Rose B. September 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Loving mother and grandmother. Dedicated, inspiring, teacher, mentor and friend. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Tuesday, September 7, 2:30 PM.

title: The Spirit of the Pines
description: LIKE the whisper of the pines that tower around her churches, Pastor Susan Flicker speaks softly of things in a community that are everlasting. In so doing, she is breathing life and spirit back into a half-dozen towns in South Jersey.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Chardonnay's Shameful Past
description: The long arm of DNA that reached back into Thomas Jefferson's family history has drawn attention to another scandalous liaison, but this time in the family history of the chardonnay, one of the world's best-known grapes.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE HINDENBURG CRASHES NIGHTLY

title: Linda Mason And Sean Ross
description: Linda Marion Mason and Sean Darrow Ross are to be married today at the Hudson River Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald N. Brown is to perform the ceremony.

title: The Russian Devolution
description: The irony of the Democrats' bungling (or worse), which allowed the giveaway of the Russian people's resources into the hands of the rich, is that it is being used as a campaign weapon by George W. Bush and the party most responsible for the rich owning a disproportionate share of the United States.

title: East Timor Is Facing A Troubled Freedom
description: East Timor entered a dangerous period as swaggering thugs intensified their violence and menace after an announcement that the tiny territory had voted overwhelmingly for independence from Indonesia.

title: OPINION; A Long Weekend's True Meaning
description: CONSIDERING the long hours we have become accustomed to working and the stress of job survival in the era of corporate downsizing, perhaps Long Islanders can be forgiven for treating Labor Day as just another three-day weekend whose origin is lost in the mists of history.

title: The Nation: After Waco; Deja Vu: An Outside Counsel
description: BARELY weeks after the independent counsel law died and was bid good riddance by everyone from President Clinton to Kenneth W. Starr, Washington is astir with calls for a new round of independent investigations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ANNE AND DAVID
description: HECHT-Anne and David. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 11, 1999, at 1 PM, at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave. (corner of 71st St.), New York, NY 10021. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Anne and David Hecht Library Fund, Eaglebrook School, Deerfield, MA 01342.

title: Danger Rises as East Timor Faces Freedom
description: East Timor entered a dangerous period today as swaggering thugs intensified their violence and menace following an early morning announcement that the tiny territory had voted overwhelmingly for independence from Indonesia.

title: Catherine Walsh, Anthony Bugliari
description: Catherine Ann Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh of Albany, was married on Aug. 28 to Anthony Stewart Bugliari, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller A. Bugliari of Tewksbury, N.J. The Rev. James Lefebvre performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Albany.

title: Angels in the Workplace; The Elevator Operator At the Heart of the Building
description: Fernando Gomez has operated the old-fashioned birdcage-like elevator at 23 East 22d Street for nine years. Every Christmas and Halloween, he turns his elevator -- the kind with a lever and no buttons -- into an up-and-down holiday show, with music and lights and, depending on the season, ghouls and reindeer. Mr. Gomez has also been known to wear a mask to scare trick-or-treaters; this year, he plans to put on a Santa suit.

title: Seeking Mr. Potato Head In All the Wrong Aisles
description: IT was one of the first and biggest of the ''category killers,'' and in the early 1990's it expanded as rapidly as a 10-year-old in a growth spurt.

title: Tree Is Made an Exception To Water-Use Restrictions
description: Joyce Kilmer might have been prompted to write a poem to water now that the tree that may have provided the inspiration for his poem ''Trees'' has been declared an exception to the state water restrictions so that it can be watered for the remainder of the drought.

title: Priest Rebuked by Vatican Resumes Public Speaking
description: A Roman Catholic priest, ordered by the Vatican to end his ministry to gay and lesbian Catholics, has resumed public speaking, saying he can do so, within limits, and still respect the church's directive.

title: Family Business
description: I was delighted to see a column on ethics in the magazine, but dismayed by the answer given by Randy Cohen to L.C., who asked when she should tell prospective employers about her pregnancy (The Ethicist, Aug. 15). I see the need for extended leave as the issue, not the pregnancy itself.

title: Sadie Van Gelder, Joshua Rottenberg
description: Sadie Chamberlain Van Gelder, a daughter of Lindsy Van Gelder of Miami and Lawrence Van Gelder of New York, is to be married this evening to Joshua Aaron Rottenberg, a son of Rana Rottenberg and Dr. Robert Rottenberg of Montecito, Calif. Cantor Mark Childs is to officiate at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 1 about the release of a restored print of ''Some Like It Hot'' misidentified a movie that was given a preview screening along with that film in December 1958. It was ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' not ''Suddenly, Last Summer.'' The article also misidentified the producer of ''Suddenly, Last Summer.'' He was Sam Spiegel; Joseph L. Mankiewicz was the director.

title: He Travels, She Travels
description: Traveling on business can be a bother, but women are less likely to mind it than men, according to a survey of 606 business travelers by New York University's Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Travel Administration and Wyndham Hotels and Resorts. The survey found that while 55 percent of the men cited the hassle factor, only 40 percent of women did. And 63 percent of the men, compared with 52 percent of women, said they tried to avoid overnight trips. One clue to the differences: 68 percent of the women saw business trips as a way to incorporate leisure time; only 52 percent of the men did.

title: Habitats /Hampton Bays, Long Island; Recapturing His Youth With His Own Hands
description: THROUGH most of his childhood, Joseph Cibellis would leave his parents' home in Rockville Centre, Long Island, every June and travel to Maine, where he would spend the summer in his grandparents' house, by the ocean north of Kittery. The memories of that time are still strong, so strong that when his grandfather grew older and the family began planning to sell the house, Mr. Cibellis made a decision. He would build a house near the water so his two young children would be able to spend their summers the same way he had.

title: Roadkill Is Most Visible Sign of Suburban Sprawl
description: It is always gratifying to see suburbanites recognize environmental devastation, even if it has been going on for decades [''A Product of Expansion: Roadkill,'' Opinion, Aug. 22].

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHECO, WILLIAM M.
description: PACHECO-William M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Pacheco, associated with The Times from 1951 until retiring in 1991.

title: Harlem Rally Is Smaller and Nonviolent, in Contrast to '98
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, flanked by expressionless bodyguards in black jumpsuits, gazed late yesterday afternoon across a small but enthusiastic crowd of a few thousand people on Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem. There was not a riot helmet in sight. The only helicopters overhead had been sent by television stations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BELFER, PETER
description: BELFER-Peter. 1946-1971. ''HE CHERISHED THE GIFT OF LIFE.'' Jean and Ira

title: Jennifer Hale, Jarret Rackoff
description: Jennifer Rachel Hale, the daughter of Susan and Gerald Hale of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Jarret Rackoff, the son of Elissa and Steven Rackoff, also of New City. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated at the Rockleigh (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Where the Fed Goes, Mortgages Don't Follow
description: The Federal Reserve has made headlines this summer by raising interest rates twice, but if you are a prospective home buyer focused on getting a mortgage, maybe you haven't noticed.

title: DIAGRAM A CELL (PHONE)
description: Accessories are now part of the core curriculum. Barneys New York is selling child-size eyeglass frames by Alain Mikli ($140), far left, and Selima ($215) for fake or prescription lenses, as well as Frenpack's diagonal backpack with handy cell-phone pocket ($195), also far left, and Kate Spade's logo pencil kits ($35). Noir's wool flower book bags are $95 at Bloomingdale's, in pink, left. For young consumers on a -- gusty sigh -- budget, Gap and Old Navy have Prada Sport-inspired messenger bags in neons and neutrals ($19.50). And to tuck inside them, Motorola's new I700 cell phone with a durable face, targeted to teen-agers ($99).

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review on July 25, about Christopher Ogden's ''Legacy: A Biography of Moses and Walter Annenberg,'' misidentified a university where Walter Annenberg endowed a school and misstated the subject of study there; it also incompletely identified the subjects studied at a second such school. A correction in this space on Aug. 15 corrected the location but not the subject. The Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania (not Pennsylvania State) studies many aspects of communications; it does not teach journalism. That is taught at a division of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California.

title: Natural Born Philosopher
description: Kill Me First

title: Ms. McCaffrey, Mr. Hatchett
description: Cynthia Lillian McCaffrey and Michael Eric Hatchett were married yesterday at All Souls Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. John David Van Dooren performed the ceremony.

title: A Right to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: Falwell and Allies to Meet Gay Rights Supporters
description: If all goes as agreed, the Rev. Mel White, an outspoken supporter of gay rights, will take 200 people to Lynchburg, Va., next month, to meet with the Rev. Jerry Falwell, an outspoken critic of homosexual activity, and 200 people he has invited.

title: Carmazzi and Flying Dutchmen Keep UConn in Its Place
description: Connecticut, inspired by its first post-season appearance in school history last year, began its final season in Division I-AA tonight with a new coach and dreams of future success in Division I-A.

title: Spatial Relations
description: As a longtime rail-operations consultant in New York, I was eager to read David Childs's thoughts on the design of the new Pennsylvania Station concourse to be created within the Farley Post Office building. By the way, I would direct him to another Hitchcock masterpiece, ''Strangers on a Train,'' which provides unforgettable images of the old Penn Station.

title: Thinking Locally
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Typical Street Fair
description: THE Kitchen Center for Video, Music, Dance, Film and Literature has been part of the artistic explosion in western Chelsea since moving to West 19th Street in 1985, and is extending its reach this week with the Kitchen Street Fair. On Saturday afternoon, the long block between 10th and 11th Avenues will be a place of performances, art displays, informational booths from local galleries, and food and drink.

title: All the Presidents Stink
description: Thank you for articulating the contempt I feel for these Washington insiders. Thank you for spotlighting their imperious manners. And thank you for reminding us that Washington does corrupt -- it has spoiled the works of Bob Woodward, and quite possibly the man himself.

title: With Two Paddles, Still Up a Creek
description: THE canoe, as a form of practical transportation, went out of fashion with the Last of the Mohicans. But it survives as a romantic piece of recreational equipment. Canoeing looks so easy when you see it on tourist videos. The slender craft skims through roaring white water, paddled effortlessly by smiling models who scarcely seem to be breaking a sweat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 18 about art forgery misidentified a painting whose authenticity is under question. The painting is not Van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' purchased for $82.5 million by a Japanese collector in 1990, but an almost identical Van Gogh painting held by the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. The article also misstated accusations concerning Modigliani's widow. Modigliani never officially married his companion Jeanne Hebuterne; she died immediately after his death, and so could not have sold certificates of authentication to collectors. The article also misstated the circumstances surrounding the signing of blank pieces of paper by Salvador Dali. The blank papers were not signed on Dali's deathbed in 1989; according to an earlier notarized statement issued by the artist, the signings had ceased by Dec. 23, 1980. The errors were pointed out in readers' letters after the article appeared; this correction was delayed for checking and confirmation.

title: Trails Reopened
description: With the rains that came late last month, the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation has lifted a ban on open fires and campfires in parks in northern Westchester. Commissioner Salvatore A. DeSantis said that a heavy rain on Aug. 26 relieved parched conditions that had existed in the county for several weeks.

title: The Russian Devolution
description: Your article did not mention the absence of organized religion as a root cause of moral chaos in Russia. What would you expect after 70 years and two or three generations without faith? In the absence of religious institutions, who gives people credit for honesty, integrity, fair dealing and charity? Without religious practices to teach respect and celebrate people for doing right by their neighbors, it is not going to happen. It's no wonder there is no sense of community in Russia, now a country of fatherless children.

title: Corrections
description: An article about the designer John Galliano on Aug. 22 in Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified the Vogue magazine editor who telephoned him to arrange a meeting with potential financial backers. It was Andre Leon Talley, not Anna Wintour.

title: INSIDE
description: Commando Role at Waco

title: Crime
description: Tenderness -- sweet, sad and heavy with regret -- is not the customary feeling raised by a suspense thriller. But for all its dark artistry, Alice Blanchard's deeply scary first novel, DARKNESS PEERING (Bantam, $23.95), is not your off-the-rack genre thriller. Despite a plot that turns on a shocking suicide and some appalling murders, the emotional content of the story outweighs the horror of the events, inviting reflection on its rueful theme of needy people leading disconnected lives.

title: A Queens Factory Is Born Again, as a Church
description: THE new New York Presbyterian Church, which officially opens on Sept. 18, is as striking a piece of architecture as those we once had to go to Los Angeles to see. Situated in Sunnyside, Queens, the church can claim a place on the small list of projects that are helping to lift New York architecture out of its long creative slump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, STANLEY
description: BROWNSTEIN-Stanley. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Stanley Brownstein, associated with The Times from 1966 until retiring in 1996.

title: Pursuing Fall Colors On New England Rails
description: Travelers who aren't deterred by reports on how the drought may diminish New England's fall colors have at least two scenic train trips to choose from next month.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions last Sunday with an article about competition in the genomics industry reversed the photographers' credits. The picture of Dr. J. Craig Venter, founder of Celera Genomics Group, was by Marty Katz for The New York Times; the picture of three executives of Millenium Pharmaceuticals was by Rick Friedman for The New York Times.

title: Secrecy Mounting As the Cup Draws Near
description: A few months ago, before it moved to New Zealand for the challengers trials, America One, one of five American entries in the America's Cup, had an increasingly common problem. It needed to find a secure spot, away from the prying eyes of competitors, where its two training boats could be tested.

title: It May Be a Heavy Book, but It Sure Is a Page Turner
description: THUMP! Ouch! Er, sorry. I dropped my September Vogue. I know, I know. Jokes about the magazine's increasing heft are beyond cliche, but this year attention must be paid, for the thing is truly enormous. Four pounds and some 700 pages (''700+'' reads the gleeful cover line) of Lincolns and Apples and BMW's, of clothes made of weird animal skins like Chinese genet and pony skin and goat, and lots of really cheesy makeup (frosted pink eye shadow on Cindy Crawford).

title: Exhibition Becomes Coronation For U.S.
description: The United States women's soccer team, which captured the fancy of sports fans and the news media this summer, returned to action for the first time this afternoon since winning the World Cup. The players walked onto the Foxboro Stadium field waving their arms and blowing kisses to the crowd of 30,564 in an atmosphere reminiscent of the World Cup.

title: 'The Oresteia'
description: (Outside the royal palace at Argos.)

title: Piece by Piece, History in a Tile Mural
description: WHEN Old Saybrook resident Barbara Spargo first encountered the bright and colorful ''River of Names'' ceramic tile wall mural at the Westport Public Library, she was in awe, just like many other first-time viewers of the wall.

title: Audiences: Maddening or, Best of All, Mad?
description: THE audience is an unruly beast, to be tamed and kept firmly in its place.'' This was the advice given to a gathering of pubescent drama students more than 30 years ago by no less a figure than Sir Alec Guinness. I was one of those aspiring, pimpled thespians. At the time, I regarded his statement as being somewhat harsh. But over the years I have come a little way, though not completely, toward the noble knight's opinion.

title: Put Away the White Shoes, and Take Off the Blinders
description: WITH summer unofficially over come Tuesday, many investors may be hoping that the return to work will also mean a return to the bull market in stocks. Even though August brought a new high for the Dow Jones industrial average, most stocks are still trading well below their highs.

title: One Team Had to Win: It's Swarthmore Routing Oberlin
description: With 1 minute 17 seconds remaining in the game, more than 100 Swarthmore College students stood, cheered and waited for the final horn to blow, all the while bracing for their confrontation at the north side of Clothier Field. When the time came, they rushed from the stands and did what they have waited since 1995 to do -- tear down the goal post.

title: Scarlet Knights Struggle On Offense Out West
description: Rutgers traveled to California for the first time in its 130-year football history today, and the University of California was indeed the land of opportunity for the Scarlet Knights. The land of missed opportunity.

title: Ossining vs. Suit
description: It may be months before Renee Malone, the mother of an Ossining man who was shot to death by the police last summer, has her day in court. But David Lerner, a spokesman for the Center for Constitutional Rights, a civil rights group in Manhattan that represents Mrs. Malone, said that no matter how long it takes, the suit will highlight serious and continuing problems with the police in the village.

title: The Hats of Summer
description: A co-worker goes on vacation, and you're asked to assume her duties, often in addition to your own. You have no idea how to do her work - but, hey, you're a team player, right? It can be an opportunity to prove yourself, or a very short, very unwelcome course in skills you never thought you would need. Or it can be a total disaster. In a depopulated workplace, what have been your greatest adventures and misadventures? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Cozying Up, Italian Style
description: ALTHOUGH the Harlequin Cafe's green awning sticks out onto South Main Street, one could easily drive right by. Which would be too bad, since an evening spent there can transport you to another world.

title: Body Count
description: The New York Times favors diversity, by which it means people who look different but have identical viewpoints (Jacob Weisberg, Aug. 15). God forbid that anything other than a knee-jerk leftist view would be printed. And no, I'm not some right-wing lunatic, just somebody who has done more in life than get a soft master's degree in journalism and then smugly preach to the great unwashed.

title: Black Ministers Criticize Plan to Reform State Police
description: The leader of the New Jersey Black Ministers Council has warned Carson Dunbar, an F.B.I. agent who is expected to be nominated as superintendent to run the 2,700-member State Police force, that the job may not be worth taking.

title: Serving Up a Platter Of Danish Confections
description: IN the 1840's, when much of Europe was lacerated by bloody revolution, the most memorable event here was the opening of the Tivoli Gardens, that theme park to shameless frivolity. ''There will never be a revolution in Denmark,'' Danes like to say, ''because either it starts raining or someone starts laughing.'' Sustaining a seamless monarchy and moderate politics for a millennium, Denmark has remained peaceful, cozy and modest, content to be a footbridge between Central Europe and the inscrutable Scandinavian Peninsula, and famous for fairy tales and pastry.

title: Principal Arrested
description: A newly appointed Yonkers middle school principal has resigned after his arrest in Dutchess County on child-sex charges, Ray Willis, a spokesman for the district, said.

description: Founded nearly 20 years ago by Philippa de Menil and Heiner Friedrich, the Dia Center for the Arts had a mission from its inception to support art that might be too unorthodox for other arts organizations, including multimedia and electronic work. It is only a hop, skip and a jump from working with mixed media to the Web, which has similar conceptual, technical and esthetic problems.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-5-99; What They Were Thinking
description: ''When they took that earlier photograph, I was 14. They were making a documentary, 'Streetwise,' about the kids on the streets of Seattle and what we did to survive. The photo was the end of the movie. It was nominated for best documentary, so I got to go to the Academy Awards. People started recognizing me. I never had to pay for anything. It was like the rich-and-famous life. I met Willie Nelson. And I even had an agent there for a minute. I thought it was going to be my big break. I thought somebody might give me a chance to do something better with my life. But I was too attracted to streets and the money and prostituting.

description: Eat the Rich

title: Making the Holocaust Real for Inner-City Youths
description: TWO weeks after the shootings in Littleton, Colo., in April, 600 inner-city high school students from New York viewed the American theater debut of ''Sh'ma,'' my 1990 dance drama depicting unspeakable brutality and the pursuit of survival in its aftermath. The performance of this modern ballet, a tribute to my family's experience in the Holocaust, had been planned for months to complement these students' examination of the Holocaust. The timing now seemed eerie in the face of nearly inconceivable youth violence at home and the escalation of war in the Balkans.

title: Correction
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about signers of the Declaration of Independence referred incorrectly to Francis Lewis. He was not the only signer buried in New York City; another, Lewis Morris, is buried in a crypt beneath St. Ann's Episcopal Church in the Bronx.

description: Dianne Susan Festa, the manager of news partnerships at NBC News in New York, was married last evening to Stewart Farrell Wallace, a composer. Rabbi Ari Fridkis officiated at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Gary G. Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Nancy Fernandez And Jose Fuentes
description: Nancy Fernandez and Jose Luis Fuentes are to be married today by the Rev. Angel Arcilla at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, Queens.

title: Another White Castle Opens Its Gates
description: Manhattan's fourth White Castle opened on Aug. 20 at 525 Eighth Avenue, between 36th and 37th Streets. The restaurant, open 24 hours, sells hamburgers for 47 cents and cheeseburgers for 58 cents. A No. 1 meal, with four hamburgers, a sack of fries and a 20-ounce drink, costs $4.56. ''We're venturing into midtown Manhattan and even lower Manhattan as much as we can,'' said Vincent Reilly, the chain's manager for New York State. He said the company was looking to expand in Manhattan north of Delancey Street, and particularly on major crosstown routes like 23d Street.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Same-Sex Marriage Is the Crucial Issue
description: The civil rights movement had made spectacular gains in the courts -- including Brown v. Board of Education -- before Rosa Parks galvanized public opinion in a way that lawsuits had not. Ms. Parks became an emblematic figure when she was arrested in Montgomery, Ala., for refusing to sit in the ''colored only'' section of a bus. The sight of this dignified woman being denied the simplest courtesy because she was black crystallized the dehumanizing nature of segregation and rallied people against it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLMSSEN, MAX A.
description: SOLMSSEN-Max A. Died peacefully on August 10, 1999 at his Chilmark, MA summer home at age 91. Born in Berlin, Germany. Resided in Summit, NJ from 1938-1997 when he moved to a retirement community, Winchester Gardens, Maplewood, NJ. Former President and Owner of the Perolin Company, headquartered in NYC with offices in major ports worldwide and manufacturing facilities in Chicago, London and South Africa. Sold to General Signal Corporation. An avid sailor, he and his family have summered on Martha's Vineyard since 1945. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Marie, four children, Dick (Sharon) of Kamuela, HI; Hans (Sally) of Summit and Chilmark; Nora of Kamuela, HI; Mary (Roger) of Scottsdale, AZ; 15 grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Funeral services were held at Abel's Hill Cemetery, Chilmark. Gifts may be made to friends of Chilmark Library, Chilmark, MA 02535

title: Sacred or Profane, Odd or Mundane, It Has a Trademark
description: BOOM times have a trademarked feel. Literally. It is harder and harder to get through the day without tripping over the little ''TM'' sign that is the equivalent of a ''No Trespassing -- Violators Will Be Prosecuted'' sign in an empty swath of New England woods. It is not always clear who owns the property in question, but it is abundantly clear that you don't. Tread on it at your risk.

description: THE State Archives have been in crowded quarters for some time. Ten years ago, their storage space filled up and records, included those of the last three governors, have been in storage in Ewing Township.

description: Hillary Rodham Clinton called on President Clinton yesterday to immediately withdraw his offer to commute the prison sentences of 16 members of a Puerto Rican terrorist organization, saying they had failed to meet his demand to renounce violence in exchange for clemency.

title: The World; Arms Control Is Dying. Unless It's Reviving.
description: BY many measures, international arms control seems to be on the verge of unraveling.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; And the Hippo Begat the Whale
description: How did nature ever get the idea of making a whale? Biologists have found the answer by analyzing the DNA of whales and their nearest terrestrial relatives, the artiodactyls or even-toed ungulates.

title: Long Lost Sisterhood Reunited
description: THEY no longer speak the same language. But for the nuns of the Congregation of the Infant Jesus, God sometimes works in mysterious ways. When four sisters from Rockville Centre met their counterparts in France this summer, the reunion reestablished a link that had been broken for nearly a century.

title: Over the Mountains To Old Portugal
description: WHERE do you have to go to find the castles of yore, the kingdoms that came before Burger Kings, the pre-euro Europe of our fondest dreams? The answer may be ''behind the mountains.'' That's the literal translation of Tras-os-Montes, the province tucked into Portugal's most inland, far northeast corner.

title: Finding the Rhythm of a Ranch
description: WE were going to Hawaii, but that was all our family of three could agree on. I wanted to take our 13-year-old son, Rory, camping, a plan he agreed to as long as he could go boogie-boarding and mountain biking. My wife, Mindy, also wanted some of her natal wild surf and, in an effort to recapture her childhood fantasy of owning a pony, riding. Unspoken was the desire for serious downtime. Anywhere else but Hawaii, the odds would have been against us. But here it was not only possible to find everything we wanted, and then some, but all within the confines of one resort -- although, at 54,000 acres, the word ''confines'' is not one I'd use in describing the Molokai Ranch. In our three-day visit to this environmentally friendly adventure travel resort, which opened three years ago, we not only rode horses and mountain bikes and body boards but also slept on a firm bed in a safari-style tent with a full moon overhead, axis deer nibbling shrubs outside, and giant surf crashing on the beach below. Our only regret concerned a certain underutilized hammock.

title: Rangers Believe a Strong Start Is a Requirement
description: Early this morning, the Rangers' latest grand experiment will begin in Burlington, Vt. And during their weeklong training camp, Coach John Muckler hopes to etch a rough sketch of the team, which was profoundly altered by Neil Smith, the team's president and general manager, during a busy and expensive off season.

title: With a Touch of Glass, Liberty Stuns the Comets
description: The championship trophy had been wheeled into the corridor and the confetti had already begun to litter the basketball court as Liberty guard Teresa Weatherspoon took the inbounds pass with 2.4 seconds to play and her team trailing the Comets by 2 points this afternoon. With only enough time for two dribbles, Weatherspoon launched a shot from beyond halfcourt with four-tenths of a second left that put a major crimp into Houston's celebration plans.

title: Hit by Ailing Williams Punctuates Odd Day
description: When Joe Torre arrived here early this morning, Bernie Williams already was in the trainer's room, shirt off, his left shoulder under treatment, and Torre knew the news was not going to be good.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Hot Wheels in Rockingham
description: Craig McDean was born in Manchester, England, and grew up near an automobile race track. Living so close to such danger and excitement instilled in him a tremendous respect and admiration for race car drivers and their sleek, powerful machines. In I LOVE FAST CARS (Powerhouse Books, $40), McDean, now a fashion photographer in New York, goes back to the track and rekindles his youthful passion for speed with terrific results. Instead of focusing on the popular and glamorous worlds of NASCAR or Top Fuel drag-racing, McDean visits places like North Carolina's Rockingham Dragway, better known as the Rock, where he concentrates on the decidedly unsophisticated world of do-it-yourself drag-racing. His shots have a wonderful fly-on-the-wall quality, especially a picture of a group of shivering race fans passing around a bottle of Jack Daniel's, and a hysterical shot of a man crammed halfway down the rocketlike tail pipe of an enormous dragster. McDean treats man and machine with equal reverence. In his pictures, cars ooze raw power: a menacing shot shows a dragster peeling out so violently that all but its very tip is shrouded in an enormous billow of cottony white smoke. McDean shoots in both black and white and color, but it is in the latter that he achieves his best results -- some of the shades of orange, yellow and pink he captures have a brilliantly rich, cartoon quality that seems to soak the page. John D. Thomas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, DORIS M.
description: FORMAN-Doris M. Of North Hills, New York, on September 3rd, 1999, at age 81. Much loved wife of Harry N. Forman. Survived also by her sister, Elizabeth M.F. Cort of Wellesley, Mass.; a niece, Diane Coleman of Canton, Mass.; and a nephew, Dwight Fletcher of Bristol, R.I. Funeral private.

description: FINKELSTEIN-Leonard. 75. Loving husband of the late Bernice; devoted father of Ron, Linda, and Susan; beloved brother of Janice; caring grandfather to Bryan and Ian. We admire and cherish his strength, resilience, and devotion to family. We will miss him.

description: Surrounded by a panoply of Middle East leaders and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israeli and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, signed a broad agreement early today that the Clinton Administration hopes will quickly usher in a new era of peace across the region.

He was a director of the Shell International Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, not a member of Royal Dutch/Shell's board.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: IRISH AUTUMN -- CIE Tours International is offering seven-night driving trips to Ireland from Oct. 16 to Dec. 13, then again in January and February, starting at $591 a person, double occupancy, including air fare from New York. The price includes use of a minimum-category rental car with unlimited mileage for a week; seven nights' lodging with private bath at farmhouses and town and country homes; full Irish breakfast daily, local taxes and service charges, and a discount booklet for visitor attractions. A similar package including hotel accommodations with private bath or shower starts at $717; the company also has four-night escorted bus tours starting at $799, including air fare, with various departures from November through March. Information: (800) 243-8687.

description: All over Pristina, there is building and the noise of electric drills and cement mixers from every direction. Pedestrians walk an obstacle course over and around piles of sand, boards and scaffolding.

title: Capriati Moves From Shadows to the Spotlight
description: She has called her reincarnation close to complete. No longer the distraught teen-ager who turned to darker recreations when the scrutiny that came with tennis fame began to chafe like a pair of golden handcuffs, Jennifer Capriati ignored the leaden air yesterday and jumped for joy following her successful debut in the Arthur Ashe Stadium at the United States Open.

In Cavendish, we settled into the Anne Shirley Motel and Cottages, named for the protagonist, across from the cemetery where the author, Lucy Maud Montgomery, is buried. Though it was dusk, we walked by her grave, down ''Lover's Lane,'' through Willowmere to the clearing where stands Green Gables.

description: Ever check into a hotel and wish your room were blue instead of yellow? A new hotel in London will offer guests the opportunity to play interior decorator and change the color and mood of their rooms with the spin of a lighting dial.

title: Pools and Picasso By the Beach in Maui
description: IMAGINE for a moment a slow morning stroll to breakfast through bright, colonnaded galleries, past massive bronzes by Leger, Picasso lithographs and Warhol silkscreens. There is an embarrassment of choice as you dine on a sumptuous buffet under huge cast-iron chandeliers that seem to grow like vines downward from painted ceilings that vault 40 feet skyward. You then pad lazily toward the sea past the long, terraced reflecting pools. Just above them, realistically sculptured dolphins are permanently suspended in flight. Finally, beachside aboard your cushioned chaise, you look out at the picture-book ocean where a school of humpback whales playfully sounds not far offshore.

title: Bayreuth, Like Wagner, Survives the Critics
description: DOES Bayreuth's cult of Wagner still matter? Some mavens say no and stay away. Bayreuth, of course, is the poky Bavarian backwater where, in 1876, Wagner introduced his mighty cycle, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' all four evenings and 17-odd hours of it, before an audience of crowned heads, artists, socialites and intellectuals. The revolutionary Festspielhaus he built here, with its concealed orchestra pit and egalitarian amphitheater-style seating, was meant as a sketch for a more splendid theater of the future, yet it endured. The second season, in 1882, brought the first performances of ''Parsifal,'' a mystic ritual Wagner wished to reserve for his festival alone.

What most people don't realize is that those words are actually the first sentence of the 1830 novel ''Paul Clifford'' by the eminent Victorian Sir Edward Bulwer-Lytton. Since 1982, Sir Edward has achieved eponymous infamy as the patron saint of the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, an annual competition held by the English department of San Jose State University. The challenge is simple: ''to compose the opening sentence to the worst of all possible novels.''

description: Yes, there are endearing things that happen; even funny things. But, oh, the pain of watching that bright, glancing mind falter, fail, at last grow dark. Moments of childlike pleasure do indeed present themselves, but with such a pang for what once was. No, this vicious disease confers few blessings.

title: A Witness at Dachau
description: THE LAST SURVIVOR

title: Summer's New Bimmers, With 2 Doors or 2 Wheels; New 3-Series Coupe Fills Market
description: THE news that BMW has begun building two-door versions of its acclaimed 3-Series barely qualifies as news. The German company routinely introduces a new series in sedan form -- in this case, the so-called E46 platform, which arrived last year -- then elaborates at regular intervals with coupe and convertible models.

title: Marina Gurin, Erik Groothuis
description: Marina Gurin, the daughter of Vera Gurin and Dr. Mark Gurin of Fort Lee, N.J., is to be married today to Erik Scott Groothuis, the son of Anita and Jack Groothuis of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Chizever is to officiate at Oheka, the Otto Kahn mansion in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y.

title: The Greats of the Century, and a Few for the Year
description: THE past is the present, isn't it? It's the future, too,'' says Mary Tyrone in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' by Eugene O'Neill. Granted, she later says, ''I've never felt at home in the theater,'' but her immortal line is as much a critical analysis of the stage as a probing of life.

title: High Yield Nets Hopeful On Road to a Showdown
description: The monster of the freshman class, More Than Ready, was back in the barn resting for the battles of autumn at Belmont Park and the championships beyond. But in his place came the challengers led by High Yield, the West Coast star trained by D. Wayne Lukas, who gave More Than Ready something to think about when he won the Hopeful Stakes today at Saratoga by five lengths.

title: COMBINATION LOCKS
description: Salons around town are vying for young clients who have yet to develop salon loyalty with various back-to-school packages.

title: Into the Unknown
description: I agree that there tends to be a sameness to the kind of race-based arguments that are given time in the news media, but if Pat Conroy thinks that Thomas Sowell, Al Sharpton and Shelby Steele (just to name a few obvious examples) are all saying the same thing, then he isn't paying attention. He's missing (or dismissing) the nuances, and they are where the differences lie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINDLER, ALICE
description: KINDLER-Alice. On September 3, at the age of 92. Survived by sons Lawrence and Herbert, daughter Ann. Also survived by nine grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Memorial service to be held Saturday, September 11, at 3 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: A Neighbor Bearing Advice
description: One Skaneateles summer resident who missed Mr. Clinton last week was Kenneth Blanchard, author of the ''One-Minute Manager'' books. Mr. Blanchard was holding one of his ''feedback sessions'' on Thursday, using a dinner at the Skaneateles Country Club to lure his neighbors into critiquing a new manuscript on money-making.

title: What's Private? What's Public? Ask the Artist
description: During the last few weeks, Lise Kaufman, 27, an Australian artist, has gone out at night with pictures of herself crying or sleeping and pasted them up on building walls and plywood construction sheds in SoHo and Chelsea. Later she has returned to check out viewers' reactions, by interviewing passers-by who stop to look at the pictures or by examining what people have scrawled on them or done to them.

title: Q. & A.
description: Guidelines On Home Insurance

title: After the Trojan Horse
description: The Oresteia

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLUMBO, RUSS
description: COLUMBO-Russ. September 2, 1934; 65 years have passed but your voice lingers on. International Russ Columbo Fan Club Harvey Gittler, President Oberlin, Ohio

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Hunting Down Home

title: Facing 2000, Companies Stock Up On Money
description: EXPECT the unexpected.

title: A Bit of British Bathroom Humor
description: THE Right Size or, as this two-man comedy team prefers it, the right size -- is into more than typographical anarchy. With nine original shows to date, these British performers have acquired a sizable following since meeting at a clown school in Paris a little more than 10 years ago. Absurdist drollery with a sprinkling of Sartre and a dash of Beckett might describe their most popular show so far: about being locked in a bathroom with a stranger for 25 years.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I cannot be bought. I am an icon, and I have a reputation for honesty and integrity, and let the chips fall where they may.''

title: Harlem, in the Middle, Loses Quiet Weekend
description: ''The White Man Is the Devil'' buttons were on sale near an antidrug van labeled Mr. Crack, bow-tied men calling themselves ''messengers of Allah'' hawked Muslim newspapers, and as many as 30 of New York's finest guarded deserted corners as a sparse troupe of black teen-agers chanted: ''Whose street? Our street!''

title: Grandma's Guide to the Web
description: FOR Betty Fox of Bayside, Queens, 1998 got off to a bad start. In February, Mrs. Fox, now 69, retired when her employer, a medical billing company, relocated. To help her avoid boredom, her older son, Marty, set her up with WebTV so she could surf the Internet on her television set. That led to more frustration for Mrs. Fox, who knew little about computers and nothing about the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDRAKOS, LEO
description: MANDRAKOS-Leo. The Trustees, Fellows and staff of the Manhattan Institute greatly mourn the loss of our good friend Leo Mandrakos. ''He held his seat; a friend to human race. Fast by the road, his ever open door obliged the wealthy, and relieved the poor.'' Homer. We shall miss him-his passionate ideals and practical support-and our hearts and prayers are with his family.

title: A Developer Reshapes a Brighton Beach Project
description: TO draw a mirthless chuckle from the developer Joshua L. Muss it is only necessary to describe him as a man of patience. ''To be a successful developer in New York,'' he says dryly, ''you have to have patience.''

title: Technology Is Eighty-Sixing Fond Old 914
description: IMAGINE dialing an area code to call a new next-door neighbor. Picture installing a second telephone line at home and being assigned an area code different from your first number. Envision reprogramming your cellular phone and pager as well as changing the letterhead on your stationery because -- like it or not -- you have been assigned a new area code.

title: It's the Same Story
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region /Westchester; Backstage at the Cancer Club, a Comedian's Spirit
description: A STATELY brick colonial at 80 Maple Avenue that formerly housed professional offices is being transformed into Gilda's Club, a support center for cancer patients in which all services are to be free. The center, one of nine in the country, is named after the comedian Gilda Radner, who died of ovarian cancer in 1989.

title: Elderly Queens Resident Is 2d to Die of Encephalitis
description: As emergency management officials dispatched pesticide-spraying helicopters to northern Queens and the South Bronx, city officials confirmed yesterday that a second elderly Queens resident had died of St. Louis encephalitis and that 31 other people might have contracted the mosquito-borne viral disease.

title: Placing the Blame for the Disaster at Waco
description: To the Editor:

title: Covering More Partners
description: In the early 1990's, fewer than two dozen employers in the United States offered health insurance that covered the same-sex domestic partners of their employees. But a report that is to be released on Tuesday by the Human Rights Campaign, a gay and lesbian lobbying group, shows a big change. As of Aug. 6, the organization had identified 2,856 employers that offer such coverage.

title: Landmark's Demolition Angers Preservationists
description: A landmark building that had stood for 90 years on the grounds of the Farm Colony-Seaview Hospital Historic District was reduced to rubble last month at the request of City Councilman James S. Oddo, without the consent of the city's preservationists.

title: The Clouds Over Freddie And Fannie
description: THIS sounds like an outfit that should have a winning stock: It's one of only seven companies to post double-digit earnings growth every year since 1986; it has the power to borrow billions at rates almost low as the Treasury's; it is excused from paying state or local income tax, and it has posted 1998 profits that approach $900,000 an employee.

title: POSTINGS: Stockholm Clothier to Open a U.S. Store; From Sweden To Fifth Ave.
description: In 1947, inspired by his travels around America, Erling Persson opened a clothing store in Sweden with high turnover and low prices: Hennes (Hers).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGIURI
description: IMBARRATO-Aurelia Caligiuri. September 2, 1917-August 28, 1992 You are forever in the hearts of your family and friends. Valerie and Julia

title: Reluctant Evangelist for Modernism
description: When Duncan Phillips, the renowned art collector, saw the 1913 Armory Show in New York that introduced modernism in the United States, he called it ''stupefying in its vulgarity.'' Yet just a few years later, when he started buying art in earnest, he became an evangelist for modernism. In 1921, eight years before the founding of the Museum of Modern Art, he opened his 1897 Georgian Revival house in Washington as a museum.

title: After 129 Years, St. John's Adds Dormitories
description: When Jayare Lendor moved into his new dorm room, other students offered to carry his boxes just to get a look at the place. His friends became so envious that he tried not to make a big deal about it.

title: Corporation Walks Away From Tax Deal
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the third-largest media company in the world, has decided to walk away from $28 million in tax breaks for the new headquarters for its Random House publishing division rather than comply with a last-minute city request to conduct a full environmental review of the $300 million project.

title: New Homeowner Finds Body of Pregnant Woman in a Barrel
description: When Hamid Tafaghodi and his family moved into their new $455,000 split-level home here, they found a rusted 55-gallon drum. The drum was later discovered to contain the mummified remains of a pregnant woman.

title: The View From/Croton-on-Hudson; Train Whistle Blows Through Festival
description: WHEN he was a child, Robert W. Elliott 3d, now 55 and Mayor of this village, used to watch trains going by just for the fun of it. ''That was sort of our Sunday afternoon recreation,'' he recalled. Cars, he added, were not the sleek silver of today, but rather like steam locomotives followed by olive green boxcars, yet their color didn't matter: he loved the motion and the whistle and the clacking sound of the wheels on the track, which ran along the Hudson River.

title: Honolulu
description: While autumn is the low season for travel to Honolulu -- the wallflower period of the year -- savvy travelers await the benefits lurking in the aftermath of the frenzied summer, especially this one, the busiest in about a decade, when air fares to Hawaii rose sharply.

title: An Encore for the Voice of College Football
description: When Keith Jackson ambled out of the ABC broadcast booth on Jan. 4 at the end of the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe, Ariz., he thought that after 32 years behind the microphone, he was finally through with play-by-play announcing at college football games.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MODERN GIRLS, SHINING STARS,

title: Fugitive Financier Captured In Germany After Long Hunt
description: Martin R. Frankel, the Connecticut money manager suspected of defrauding insurance companies of hundreds of millions of dollars before fleeing overseas, was captured in his hotel room in Germany yesterday, Federal law enforcement officials said.

title: School Opens, And Educators Enlist the F.B.I.
description: THERE was a time when Ralph A. DiFonzo, a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Haven, provided hostage survival training to banks and corporations as a matter of routine.

title: Q&A/Dr. William V. Costanzo; Overseeing a World of Films and Talk
description: LEAVE your popcorn money home when you go to the Friday Night Film Series at Westchester Community College. It is definitely not part of the evening that Dr. William V. Costanzo, an English professor who runs the series, has in store for moviegoers.

title: Brown's Knee Injury Hurts Giants' Options
description: As expected, Giants running back Gary Brown will probably miss four games with a sprain of the medial collateral ligament in his left knee, an injury he sustained in the Giants' preseason loss to Baltimore last Friday.

title: Not Doing Better By Doing Good
description: For corporations, it looks like virtue may have to be its own reward after all.

description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring the Amazon, Without the Machete
description: PSSST! Pssst! Lady . . . excuse me. . . . ''

title: Welcome Back. Need Tickets for Graduation?
description: THIS Omnibus Reality Form is intended to assist your transition from the slothful, brain-softening condition known as summer to the coming fall season. Be sure your answers are legible and in ink, and returned in triplicate by last Thursday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-5-99: Shop Talk; Pressures of The Press
description: As editor of China's leading English-language newspaper, Jonathan Fenby developed a reputation for independent reporting and frank debate. Last month he was fired. Hamid Reza Jalaipur founded Iran's first prodemocracy newspaper. He was jailed last year for printing an editorial critical of the Government. Herewith, the two discuss what it's like to put out a newspaper where the press is not free.

title: The Nation: One Angry Man; What's the Verdict When the Mayor Is Also Jury Foreman?
description: WHEN Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani swore to serve as jury foreman in a Manhattan personal injury case last week, he set off down a path many citizens but few famous folk have trod.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Deaths on a Roller Coaster
description: New Jersey state investigators removed four cars from a roller coaster in Ocean City to determine why a woman and her daughter died on the ride. The woman, Kimberly Baily, 39, of Pomona, N.Y., and her daughter Jessica, 8, were at Gillian's Wonderland Pier when the car they were riding slipped backward down a steep incline, made a 90-degree turn and ejected them. There have been six deaths on rides at American amusement parks so far this year.

title: Tales of Sin and Salvation, Still Going Strong
description: JUST when the rapt, trembling audience thinks Bill Irwin's real-life tale of woe can't get any bleaker, it does. A drunk and a womanizer who was molested by an uncle as a child, Mr. Irwin (not the Broadway performer of the same name) loses an eye to cancer and then, in a freak laboratory accident, the tip of a scalpel breaks off and slices into his good eye. Eventually, he goes completely blind.

title: Into the Unknown
description: 'Because Stanley Crouch is black,'' Pat Conroy writes, ''I knew everything he was going to say because, sadly, I live in a time when all black people seem to be speaking in the same voice and saying the same kind of thing.'' Whatever else may be said of Stanley Crouch, it must be acknowledged that he has shown the courage not to say what many black people say. Conroy might know this, if he had bothered to find out anything at all about his subject. One hardly knows what to be more offended by: Conroy's intellectual laziness or the borderline racism revealed by his remark.

title: A Frugality Check
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-5-99: On Language; Ghost
description: ''Most individuals arrested by the Government,'' a Sudanese dissident told ABC News, ''are routinely taken to unmarked buildings we call ghost houses. In these places all forms of torture are practiced, and sometimes the detainees are killed.''

title: Uneasy Lies the Crowned Tudor
description: When the Crowne Plaza at the United Nations opened in early 1997 at the former Hotel Tudor on 42d Street near First Avenue, the new owners planned a number of renovations for the ornate landmark, including replacing the former hotel's neon sign with one bearing the new name.
