description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTER, VIVIAN
description: AMSTER-Vivian. 79, of Enfield, CT, died August 28, 1999. Survived by husband Sid, sons David and Larry, brother Herbert, and five grandchildren. Made her mark on every life she touched.

title: August 29-Sept. 4; Bush Outlines Plan To Fine Failing School
description: Texas Gov. George W. Bush has worked hard in his Presidential campaign to sound conservative but pragmatic, a line he tried to toe again in his first major address on education.

title: A Lifetime Ambassador For the Garden State
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM; Taking Film Out of Films
description: THE close of the 20th century is not being kind to poor old Thomas Edison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, PAULINE
description: CARTER-Pauline. Mom, life without you to talk to, and reminisce with, is unimaginable. You brought unbridled joy into my life. Your sense of humor ensured that every phone call and visit was filled with happiness. Your loving and sweet voice will be heard forever. The fullness of your life could be measured by the simple things that brought you pleasure: talking with your children and grandchildren. Knowing that you are happy is my sole comfort at this sad time. I will always think of you and remember your smile, your hugs and kisses, your exuberance, and your belief in me. You always said that you were my best audience. You are finally with Dad once again-the heavens will reverberate with the two of you trading stories! Rest in peace. With all the love in the world, Donny.

title: Sales Tax Frustrates Shoppers in Suffolk
description: DENISE MAHR of Huntington walked out of the T. J. Maxx clothing store in Commack a week ago with three of her children after having paid more for some back-to-school clothes than she had been counting on.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Aug. 1 about the marriage of Linda Beth Sweeney misspelled the bridegroom's first name. He is Cary Todd Torkelson, not Carey.

title: Toys and Items That Began As Found Objects
description: In 1993, Jimmy DiResta rented a ground-floor studio in the East Village that he used to design toys and furniture out of wood and pipes he found in Dumpsters. As he created more items, he waited for the right time to open a store where he could sell what he had made. ''We were waiting for the neighborhood to change a little bit,'' he said.

title: As a Ping-Pong Palace Lays Down Its Paddles . . .
description: Inside the West Side Billiard Club, beyond the rows of felt-covered tables and the thwacking sounds of colliding pool balls, is perhaps the last refuge in Manhattan for another sport, one whose featherweight orbs glide through the smoky air before getting whacked by a paddle.

title: Professor Smith's Advice to Colleges; Students as Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: All the Presidents Stink
description: As a lifelong resident inside the beltway and a sometimes amused and often infuriated observer of the political scene on Capitol Hill and Pennsylvania Avenue, I have to say that Frank Rich got it just right. Were it not for the foibles and ineptness of the politicians, Bob Woodward would have no grist for his mill. Rich has accurately analyzed and described the pundits and correspondents. He had the whole cast from Betty Beale to the current old-boy network pegged perfectly. The article was just what I needed for the dog days of August.

title: The Role of Rock
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, SANFORD
description: FINKELSTEIN-Sanford. On August 29, 1999. Survived by wife, Thelma, children, Janis and Mitch Novick, and Amy and Jeff Feibusch, and brother, Elliot Finkelstein, grandchildren, Jeffrey, Melissa, Eric, and Michelle.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Uneasy Lies Helmet With Broncos' Logo
description: It seems to be a tradition: Team wins National Football League championship. Team celebrates. Calamities strike team.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GINGOLD, JEFFREY
description: GINGOLD-Jeffrey. 2/19/48-8/31/87. We miss you so and love you always. Mom, Arlene and Bonnie

title: An Instant Fan's Inspired Notes: You Gotta Listen
description: Lester Bangs, who died in 1982 at the age of 33, was widely regarded as the great innovative, comic poet of rock criticism, a writer who sought to emulate in his rambunctious prose the spirit of the writers (William S. Burroughs and Hunter S. Thompson come to mind) and music he loved. Greil Marcus, who edited Bangs's selected work in the book ''Psychotic Reactions and Carburetor Dung'' (Alfred A. Knopf, 1987), called him ''rock's essential wild man, a one-man orgy of abandon, excess, wisdom, satire, parody.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Cecily Cook And Walter Isle
description: Cecily Disston Cook was married yesterday to Walter Ray Isle at the Pot and Kettle Club in Bar Harbor, Me. The Rev. William McP. Bigelow, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Jennifer Strum, Jeffrey Nuich
description: Jennifer Suzanne Strum, the daughter of Patricia and Jay Strum of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Christopher Nuich, a son of Nancy and John Nuich of Tinley Park, Ill. The Rev. Douglas L. Trees, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Estherwood Mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: The Russian Devolution
description: You won't find ''who lost Russia'' by looking among bureaucrats and academics (John Lloyd, Aug. 15). They don't have any real economic power. Your writer touched on the key when he stated, ''Just how much money has left Russia in the past seven years isn't known precisely, but estimates vary from $200 billion to $500 billion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIENZLE, WALTER A.
description: KIENZLE-Walter A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter A. Kienzle, associated with The Times from 1962 until retiring in 1987.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Transport in Spain

title: August 29-Sept. 4; A Beef Over Burger King
description: It is hard not to relish the idea of the humble Whopper innocently entangled in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: An Oasis of Riesling
description: The master sommelier Richard Dean has transformed Mark's Restaurant into an oasis of riesling for the third summer. His card for this month's ''riesling festival'' at the Mark Hotel (Madison Avenue at 77th Street) lists numerous whites at $3 to $10 bargains for generous two-ounce glasses.

title: Mars and Venus Do Better Together
description: There is bad news for partisans on either side of the battle of the sexes: A new study suggests that when it comes to investment clubs, those that include members of both sexes outperform those of the single-gender variety.

title: Skaneateles Sees Future, And It's Martha's Vineyard
description: Before the Clintons showed up, Skaneateles, the upstate New York town where the First Family vacationed last week, had gone mostly unnoticed since the 70's, when Charles Revson, the founder of Revlon, and his son Peter, a flamboyant race car driver, romped there. With just three traffic lights and a lake clean enough to drink from, Skaneateles has ''a life style that anybody would like,'' says Martin Cregg, president of Chase Design, a national industrial design company based there. Even the polo is low-key -- strictly club level, Mr. Cregg said.

title: Liberties; Viva Las Vegas
description: I'm strolling down a cobblestone street, beneath a cloud-speckled Paris sky. Past Le Village Buffet, past Napoleon's cigar and cognac lounge, past Parcage.

title: Yarnall Produces In Debut As Starter
description: Ed Yarnall joined the Yankees in spring training, and the pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, didn't like what he first saw despite the glowing reports he had heard. Yarnall, a 23-year-old left-hander, didn't look fluid in his delivery, he appeared to cut off his arm action too soon and the ball didn't jump out of his hand.

title: Political Memo; The First Lady's Minuet on Clemency
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is finding herself with the same problem as Vice President Al Gore. Both feel the need to distance themselves from President Clinton, but neither has quite figured out how far to go, or how close is too close.

title: China Puts More Power in Pockets of the People
description: The Chinese Government tonight announced sweeping increases in salaries, pensions and welfare payments for 84 million people, describing the move as a birthday gift as the country prepares to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic.

title: Unions Can Save The Workaholic
description: When it comes to vacations, unions still have mysterious clout. A soon-to-be published study by three economists in California reports that union workers in the United States get an average of three weeks off per year, while the huge nonunion majority gets only 1.8 weeks. And the economists -- Thomas Buchmueller, John DiNardo and Robert Valletta -- believe this gap is growing.

title: An Eye for Art in Unexpected Places; A Photographer Finds Esthetic Inspiration in the Workaday World
description: Can art be accidental, inadvertent, forged by artless men in the pursuit of utility or vandalism? Or is intent and discretion necessary to elevate even bits of prosaic flotsam into exhibits worthy of attention? And if so, whose intent matters: those who left the stuff behind or those who found it? (In this case the photographer Librado Romero.)

title: Lionel Jackson Sr., 84, Publisher Of New Haven Papers Until '82
description: Lionel S. Jackson Sr., the former publisher of The New Haven Register and The New Haven Journal-Courier, died on Wednesday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 84.

title: Encephalitis Threat Means an Indoor Holiday for Many
description: Loretta Sikiric was outside grilling sausages early Saturday evening when she heard the thucka-thucka of a helicopter flying low over her home in Whitestone, Queens. She watched it swoop in and dump its payload: a pesticide that officials say has mostly eliminated the mosquitoes responsible for an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, a viral disease that has killed two elderly people in Queens and may have sickened as many as 37 others.

title: As Old Soldiers Die, V.F.W. Halls Fade Away
description: The old soldiers talked about the days, not so long ago, when they skated across the dance floor here at the Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2378, swinging as if the songs would never end.

title: Schroder's Party Is Set Back Painfully in 2 State Elections
description: Voters in two German states handed a sharp rebuff to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder today, ousting his long-dominant Social Democratic Party in the western Saarland and ushering a far-right party into the state parliament for the first time in Brandenburg.

title: Turf Is Artificial; MetroStars' Despair Is Bona Fide
description: The MetroStars have been disintegrating piece by piece over the past two months. After today's 2-1 loss to the Chicago Fire, their 12th consecutive defeat, and a knee injury to their best player, Sasa Curcic, the MetroStars' playoff hopes all but vanished.

title: Synagogues, Responding to Violence, Add Security as High Holy Days Near
description: After a year of high-profile anti-Semitic violence, including a shooting at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles, Jewish groups in the New York metropolitan region are planning increased security for services during the approaching High Holy Days.

title: Anti-Federalism Measures Have Bipartisan Support
description: Hoping to shift political power back to the states, a broad bipartisan coalition in the Senate and House of Representatives is preparing legislation that would make it harder for Congress and the executive branch to adopt laws and rules that pre-empt the states on a wide range of issues, like drugs, the environment, health and worker safety.

title: A Familiar Chant Greets Grand Slam By New Met
description: At first the chants came weakly, perhaps even insincerely. ''Darryl, Darryl,'' a modest number of fans shouted yesterday as the Mets' Darryl Hamilton squared himself in the batter's box against Darryl Kile, his former Colorado Rockies teammate. In New York, be it Queens or the Bronx, such cheers are usually reserved for Darryl Strawberry, and Hamilton, a Met for barely a month, knew it.

title: The Look of Labor
description: In 1875, a photographer named Alphonse Deriaz took a picture of the Butchers' Festival in the Swiss town of Morges. The butchers, 26 of them, stand at attention in the town square, their aprons swept to one side like dashing military tunics. Each man shoulders one of the tools of his trade. Five of the butchers share a raised platform with an enormous white-faced bullock wearing a halter and a crown of flowers while townsfolk look down from the windows above. What is striking here, besides the soft expression on the bullock's face, is the very public way that each butcher identifies himself by his labor, by his apron and bone saw and by the fraternity, publicly attested, of fellow butchers.

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Major League Player's Life Of Isolation and Secret Fear
description: All-America Billy Bean burst into his 20's consumed by two driving dreams: to play center field in the major leagues and to deny his homosexuality. Eventually he would have to choose between his personal and professional lives.

description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Shoots Son, Officials Say
description: An off-duty New York City police lieutenant shot and wounded his son on Saturday night during a fight in their Queens home, the police said yesterday.

title: In America; The Baker's Slice
description: If you listen too long to the rhetoric you could begin to think we've stepped into some kind of economic nirvana. Things are going well, and maybe it is nirvana for the lucky ones at the top. But the economic reality for middle-class American families is somewhat more modest.

title: Canada's Other French-Speakers Cope
description: On a state visit to Montreal in 1967, Charles de Gaulle launched a famous war cry: ''Vive le Quebec libre!'' After a huge pro-independence crowd exploded in delirium, Ottawa encouraged the French President to pack his bags and return to Paris.

title: Should C.E.O.'s Play Teacher?
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson Recalls When Jews And Blacks Marched as One
description: His voice was all weary and worn out. But the church was hushed, and it was time to talk, time to resurrect the details of history -- those crucial moments during the great struggles of a fading century when blacks and Jews fought together for the same causes.

title: Some Huddles Hear More Than One Voice
description: Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr sounds as if he is singing the chorus of a country song when he warbles that he is a one-quarterback guy. Penn State's Joe Paterno gives the refrain a doo-wop flavor with his Brooklyn accent. Nebraska's Frank Solich marbles the harmony with Midwest roots rock.

title: Just Pals at a Relaxed House Party
description: ''Let me tell you what a Black Star show is like,'' said Mos Def of Black Star on Saturday during the first of this rap duo's three consecutive Knitting Factory performances. He described lovers meeting after time apart: the anticipatory phone calls, the nervous early chat at the airport and the exciting taxi trip home.

title: Internet Wars
description: With each new technological advance, the Internet beckons as a rich and competitive playing field for business, communication and entertainment. One of the most promising recent innovations is high-speed Internet access through upgraded cable television lines. Before long, these lines are expected to offer a nearly limitless variety of television programs, movies, music, face-to-face telephones, commercial transactions and other interactive services.

title: Nice Front Porches, Along With the 'Porch Police'

title: Misbegotten Charter Revisions

After heated criticism, the Charter Revision Commission has now postponed the implementation of that plan. But its final product remains a hodgepodge of marginal, meaningless or ill-advised proposals that ought to be rejected by voters.

title: Long Live Those Experts On Duplicate Movements
description: The first American authority to write a book on the arcane subject of duplicate movements was Alfred Maximilian Gruenther, who became more famous as a general in World War II and later head of NATO, reaching the age of 84. The second was George M. Beynon, who at the age of 100 was still conducting a correspondence school for aspiring duplicate directors. The third and perhaps the last in this long-lived line is Alex Groner of Poway, Calif., whose Duplicate Bridge Direction is still used by some directors. Its utility has diminished, however, since computer programs took over the task of planning a duplicate game.

title: When the Dream Factory Takes a Holiday
description: The summer movie season typically ends with something approaching a sigh, a little breather between the summertime crowd pleasers and the somewhat more adult-oriented autumn fare. And this one, which started with the ear-shattering cymbal clash of ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace'' and has produced an unprecedented number of $100-million-plus box-office hits, ended with just two relatively small-scale releases to attract audiences over this three-day weekend.

title: Op-Art; The Grindstone Awaits
Jeter Breaks Through, And Angels Pay Price
description: As he waits his turn for his first at-bat every game, Derek Jeter will turn toward the stands and hold up two fingers of his right hand, or one, or whatever signal happens to be appropriate. Mike Borzello charts pitches for the Yankees from a seat behind home plate, operating a radar gun, and he will respond in kind to Jeter's gestures -- perhaps two fingers, if the pitcher is throwing 92 miles an hour, or three fingers for 93.

title: Piece by Piece, a Faded Icon Regains Its Art Deco Glow
description: Shiny flecks of silvery foil drifted down from the third mezzanine at Radio City Music Hall, the 67-year-old icon of Art Deco glamour. They floated past two 30-foot tubular glass chandeliers, gold mirrors, Pompeian-red velvet-covered walls and marble wainscoting to settle in small mounds on the bare concrete floor of the Grand Foyer.

title: Enjoying Tennis And Life
description: The crowd loves it. Andre Agassi shaves his chest to match his shaved head -- ''I just got tired of being hairy,'' he said -- and the crowds follow him to the practice courts where he sheds his shirt. With injuries gutting the men's draw, Agassi has become the favorite of the United States Open.

title: 2 Car Bombs in Israel
description: Less than 24 hours after a new Israeli-Palestinian accord was signed, two cars packed with explosives blew up in two Israeli cities. The explosions were a reminder of the terrorist threats that hovered over recent negotiations, and a quick test of the newly restored Israeli-Palestinian link.

description: WALSH-James Walter Jr., 69. Of Ramsey, NJ, died suddenly on Friday, September 3, 1999. Mr. Walsh was the loving husband of Nancy and devoted father of James III and Victoria. Mr. Walsh was a graduate of Rutgers University and a retired Vice President of Advertising for Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York City. He served in the U.S Army as a member of the Berlin Command during the Korean War. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, September 7, 1999, at 2 PM, at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home in Ramsey, NJ. He will be dearly missed by his family and friends.

title: Deutsche Bank and Its Rivals Weigh Linking Some Operations

title: Artworks of the Discarded
description: Steven M. Cosentino, below and left, working on the mural of a homeless man on the roof of the Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corporation, a large drop-in center and shelter for the homeless. The center, at 152 East 44th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, is moving to smaller quarters; the building, mural included, is being demolished for apartments. ''I decided to do a mural on the roof to show that the homeless are being displaced again,'' he said. Mr. Cosentino, 50, created the 65-by-35-foot mural from more than 300 pieces of clothing the residents discarded when they arrived. He modeled his portrait after a 35-year-old formerly homeless man he knew. Another of his murals, above, depicting Bryant Park, hangs inside the building.

title: The Players, the Fans and the Cameras Were There, and It Rained
description: Football games are played in snow, rain or any other bad weather. Baseball games, which supposedly should not be played in rain, often are. But hardcourt tennis and rain do not mix, because even the slightest drizzle leaves a slippery coat on the court.

description: The veteran Marcus Buckley lost his starting job as the Giants' strongside linebacker yesterday. Ryan Phillips will take Buckley's place when the team opens its regular season at Tampa Bay on Sunday, Coach Jim Fassel said.

description: If you were a photographer, you might think it would be nice to have Time, Rolling Stone and Vogue on your resume. But you might also find it makes your life miserable, according to Photo District News.

description: Too much sex may be a bad thing. At least that is what British publishers of the so-called laddie magazine market seem to be confronting as recent circulation figures for magazines like FHM and Loaded, the originators of the men-behaving-badly genre, dropped almost across the board.

title: Mitchell Prepares Rescue Effort for Ulster Peace Settlement
description: Saying failure would be ''unforgivable,'' former Senator George J. Mitchell prepared today to begin a rescue effort to halt the disintegration of the Northern Ireland peace agreement he helped broker.

title: Sports of The Times; Years Later, Capriati Still Comes Up Short
description: EIGHT years ago, Monica Seles and Jennifer Capriati shared a court at the National Tennis Center like giddy kids sipping a soda from two straws. So adorable and wholesome, so talented and hard hitting, the teen-agers turned their riveting semifinal match at the United States Open into a classic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN OKIN, BABETTE
description: SLOTKIN OKIN-Babette. Of Palm Beach, FL and formerly of New York City and Detroit, MI, passed away on August 31, 1999 after a short illness. Beloved wife of Robert Okin. Devoted mother of Donald, Mitchell, Curt and Todd Slotkin, her children from her marriage to the late Hugo Slotkin. Cherished mother-in-law of Edie, Pamela, Carole and Judy. Loving grandmother of Douglas, Steven, Bobby, Daniel, Trevor, Elissa, Keith, Matthew, William, Thomas and Peter. Caring step-mother to Kenneth and Dennis Okin. Her wisdom, love and wit live on in our hearts. She will be missed by many dear friends. Funeral service will be held on September 2 1:30 pm at the Ira Kaufman Chapel (800-325-7105), 18325 W. Nine Mile Road, Southfield, MI. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Craft Gallery, 5911 S. Dixie Highway, West Palm Beach, FL. 33405, or charity of one's choice.

title: G.M. Offers Some Workers In Auto Union Jobs for Life
description: The General Motors Corporation has offered the United Automobile Workers union lifetime employment guarantees for many current workers as it negotiates a new contract, a G.M. spokesman confirmed today.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Music for the Queen or the Ale House
description: Elizabethan lute songs were born in a world that knew no strict division between art music and popular songs. But although they have been absorbed into the art-song repertory by virtue of their age, they have a great deal in common with modern pop. They were, after all, composed for everyday use by just about anyone, anywhere: their melodies are memorable, their subjects range from the business of everyday life to love (both bawdy and idealized) and spirituality, and they were sung both at court and in more modest homes, where amateur music making was a lively pastime.

title: Former HUD Secretary Goes on Trial
description: Henry G. Cisneros, a former Cabinet officer in the Clinton Administration, goes on trial in Federal court here on Tuesday in what is almost certain to be the last major trial of the two-decades-long grand experiment of the independent counsel law.

title: Media Talk; For a Reprint Series, an Unexpected Success
description: The New York Review of Books has vowed to reach a wider audience than the usual intellectuals with its new book-publishing venture, which salvages out-of-print classics. So far, 12 titles have been published in sleek paperback editions, including vanished titles by Anton Chekhov and Henry James.

title: Not Your Mother's Musical, and That's the Point
description: Puck is gliding on roller skates through a rather misty haze that fills the dance floor, making mischief, as Puck does, with the passions of Tytania, Sander and Dimitri. This isn't fairyland, but rather theater, and it's done to the pounding beat of such 70's dance hits as ''Disco Inferno.''

title: 3 Charged With Attack In a Cafe in Manhattan
description: The Cafe Figaro, the famous Greenwich Village coffeehouse that became a Beat Generation hangout in the 1950's and 1960's, was the scene of a severe beating early yesterday morning when several patrons assaulted another, the police said.

title: A Treat for Women: Cheering Women
description: ''Did you ever think you'd live to see the day,'' asked Sharon, an insurance adjustor, of her friend, Peg, ''when a women's bar would be showing sports?''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We didn't expect a lot from life, our generation. We wanted to get out of high school, get a car, get a girl, get a house, have some kids and just sit out on the front steps and talk. Kids today, they don't look at things that way.''

title: New Race But Old Walk On the Beach For Bradley
description: The storm-whipped winds had been lashing the beach all day today, driving dark clouds before them, roiling the surf and forcing summer's last vacationers out of the water when former Senator Bill Bradley stepped onto the boardwalk for an afternoon of handshaking.

title: With a Cry From the Horns And a Southern Birthright
description: Some American jazz musicians will always be fascinated with updating and expanding old vernacular Southern music -- music of honky-tonks and parades and funerals -- and for good reason: as jazz becomes increasingly shared by the world, both harder to define and easier to stumble across, the Southern sources remain an American's birthright.

title: Steel Band Winners Are Announced
description: The winners of the annual Panorama competition for steel bands, which is part of the lead-in to the West Indian American Carnival parade today in Brooklyn, were announced yesterday. Twelve bands participated in the event, which took place on Saturday night on the grounds of the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Making Hay With 'Custom' Magazines
description: Stacks of glossy publications compete for attention in the pane-glass vitrines of Universal News, a sprawling magazine emporium in Soho favored by the downtown intelligentsia. Wired and Vogue sit side by side in the front windows, sharing space with a new title: Sony Style, a quarterly that sells for $5.95 in the United States and $8.95 in Canada.

title: Schools Taking Tougher Stance With Standards
description: No more fun and games: As children across the nation head back to school this fall, many are encountering a harsher atmosphere in which states set specific academic standards and impose real penalties on those who do not meet them.

description: On a weekend when millions of Americans see Labor Day as little more than an opportunity to shop or go to the beach, the Rev. Judith Kelsey-Powell tried hard today to reconnect her congregation to Labor Day's roots.

description: Greece will apply to join Europe's single currency in mid-March next year, probably only days before a vote in Parliament for the nation's presidency that could topple the ruling Pasok party Government.

title: Prayer and Hope for Cardinal's Health
description: Their blue and white habits glowing against the gray sky, the Sisters of Life radiated joy outside St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. While the initial news about John Cardinal O'Connor had seemed grim -- a tumor on his brain -- subsequent word had been more uplifting. The tumor was confined to the brain's surface; the Cardinal was home from the hospital and might be at St. Patrick's to greet them.

title: Down So Long, Falcons and Buchanan Deal With Success
description: Thirty-three years of foiled plans and churning heartache were dissolved in one season for the Atlanta Falcons. In 1998 they won their first division title since 1980, won the most games in franchise history (16), scored their most points ever (511), were unbeaten at home in the Georgia Dome (9-0) and reached their first Super Bowl.

title: Security Council Presses Indonesia to Restore Order
description: The United Nations Security Council met last night to condemn ''in the strongest terms'' the violence in East Timor and to ask Indonesia to live up to its pledges to provide security to the territory, which has been torn by violence after a ballot there favored independence.

title: Patents; For people with only one telephone line, a way of routing incoming calls to a Web site.
description: FOR the last few years, telephone companies throughout the country have been busy adding new area codes to metropolitan regions to accommodate the rising demand for new phone numbers. In Seattle, where for decades one area code covered the area, there are now three. Callers in the two new areas must dial 10 digits for every call, and so must people in the city who phone the suburbs. Many of these new area-code calls are now billed as long-distance calls.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; Some on-line retailers are finding that customer reviews of products can help build loyalty to a site -- and sales.
description: E-COMMERCE companies fill their sites with reviews of products they sell, reviews that are generally taken from marketers or magazines. But they know that consumers often give more credence to the opinions of ''real people'' -- friends or peers who buy similar products.

title: Life Seems Like a Droll Duet With Empathy as the Theme
description: It all started, as David Dorfman and Dan Froot might say, in 1990 with a duet called ''Horn.'' Mr. Dorfman, a dancer and choreographer, and Mr. Froot, a composer and performance artist, were friends who both played the saxophone. In ''Horn,'' they explored their affection for each other and their competitiveness. As they continued performing the duet, in which they engage in slithering, lugging, slightly punch-drunk partnering while playing their saxes, the men discovered more facets of their friendship. That led to the creation of ''Bull'' and ''Job.''

description: As the outside world expressed horror and the Indonesian Government promised East Timor protection but evaded fulfilling those pledges, armed thugs systematically took over the island territory on Sunday, killing and terrorizing residents and trapping United Nations workers in their compound.

title: Compressed Data; Seattle Weekly Writer Turns Tables on Amazon
description: When Amazon.com Inc. came under fire recently for publishing lists of books and CD's popular with employees at major corporations, the company, which is based in Seattle, said that its so-called purchase circles were meant to be ''fun and positive,'' not an invasion of privacy.

description: Only a few players came to the Olympic Center this morning with guaranteed spots on the Islanders' roster. The rest -- more than three dozen journeymen, rookies and career minor leaguers -- know they will have to scratch and claw their way into the National Hockey League.

description: Jascha Zayde, a pianist, composer and conductor who for more than three decades gave weekly performances on WQXR, the radio station owned by The New York Times, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: At 18, Singer Seeks to Prove She's Not a One-Hit Wonder
description: Two stories above Broadway, in the MTV studio that looks out on Times Square, the cameras are rolling, flitting across an audience of girls in braces and ponytails, tank tops and shorts, and panning on the scene below, on the mass of people who have been gathering on the street for hours. ''Twenty seconds . . . 10 seconds . . . 2 seconds . . . And here she is! Christina Aguilera!'' Applause, big applause, and from the street giddy screams rise from the throng of fans herded with their homemade posters and banners behind police barricades.

description: ''It's fun to be a small-town editor, especially when you own the newspaper,'' Michael G. Gartner observed last week. ''You can say any damn thing you want. Plus writing the editorials -- it's more fun than one person should have.''

Dozens of matches were delayed by showers, dozens more were postponed, and according to the disgruntled players who got to experience the banana-peel conditions underfoot, their best efforts were sabotaged by Mother Nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASH, ALVIN
description: LUKASH-Alvin. 81, died Saturday, September 4, 1999 in Pompano Beach, FL. Born in New York City June 12, 1918, he was the son of the late Samuel and Bessie Lukash. He leaves his much loved children, Seth Lukash of Westport, and Laura Lukash Knee and her husband Thomas of Avon. Poppy Al also leaves his adored grandson, Samuel Knee. He also leaves behind his brother and sister-inlaw, Dr. Leslie and Gladys Lukash of NY, his nieces and nephew. Alvin was predeceased by his wives Selina in 1958 and Mildred in 1998. He also leaves behind his companion Bobbi Cohen who brought great joy and love to his last year. Alvin graduated from City College of NY. He started a company call Hi-G, Inc., in an old army barracks in Windsor Locks, CT that grew and prospered to a place on the American Stock Exchange. His passing leaves an empty place in our lives and in our hearts. We are all, family and friends far better for having known him. description: Royal Dutch/Shell announced that it had sold the landmark Shell-Mex House, which over looks the Thames River in London, to Witkoff Group, a privately held United States property firm. Terms were not disclosed. The British news media, however, reported that the Art Deco building was sold for 180 million [pounds], or $288 million. Last year, Shell said it would sell the building to cut costs when oil prices dropped. About 200 jobs are expected to be eliminated as the company redeploys the more than 2,000 staff members that worked at Shell-Mex House.

title: Prisons as Mental Hospitals
description: Rikers Island handles some 25,000 mentally ill prisoners in New York City each year. While in jail, even if only for a few days, they can get treatment and are housed in special units if their problems are severe. But afterward is a different story. Many have neither homes nor families, and carry histories of repeated arrests. It does not take a trained social scientist to predict what will happen to these people if they are left to their own resources after release. Nevertheless, for many of them the city's post-incarceration plan is brutally simple: They are put on a bus and dropped off at Queens Plaza before dawn, with $1.50 and a two-fare Metrocard.

title: Patterns; Hopefuls Spring Eternal
description: A bright young thing hits New York, and right away the mental clock starts ticking down those 15 minutes. Next! The thing is, there are so many famous hotshots around that Andy Warhol's original notion seems quaint. Yet, in the 30th anniversary issue of Interview magazine, which comes out next week, the old innocence prevails.

Born in Riga, Latvia, he was a highly regarded construction engineer, having taken degrees at both Berlin University and Columbia University in New York. As an avocation, he was a world-renowned philatelist. Ever dedicated to the service of those less fortunate, he was active in many charitable organizations in NYC and environs. Alexis Scherbatow, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, PALMER
description: DIXON-Palmer. Died suddenly of a heart attack on the morning of September 3rd at his home in Wilton, CT. He was born July 1, 1928 in New York City, the son of W. Palmer Dixon and Theodora Thorpe Dixon. He attended St. Mark's School, and graduated from Harvard College, Class of 1950. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army during the Korean Conflict, participating in the fighting as a forward observer for the artillery. After the Armistice, he returned to the United States in 1953, working at NBC before becoming a Partner at the Wall Street firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Co. He later worked as a Vice President at Moseley, Hallgarten & Estabrook, and then for a number of years at Standard & Poor's as Head of Programming. After retiring, he continued to work as a computer specialist and private consultant. He was a keen Court Tennis player, and was for many years an active member of the New York Racquet and Tennis club. He is survived by his wife, Heather-Mary Sharp Dixon, his two daughters, Alexandra M. Dixon of London, Olivia H. Dixon of Wilton, CT, his son Adam P. Dixon and daughter-in-law Gabriella Dixon Prinzessin zu Schwarzenberg of Vienna, and two granddaughters, Xenia and Daria Dixon; his brother, Peter T. Dixon of New York City, and his nephews, Peter M. title: In Ancient Bones, Researchers See Pictures of Health
description: A century ago, paleontologists began exploring a cave outside the town of Krapina, 30 miles north of Zagreb, Croatia. The place was littered with fossil bones of Neanderthals, the enigmatic human relatives that died out about 30,000 years ago, and stone tools and bones of extinct animals. By the completion of excavations in 1905, Krapina had yielded more hominid fossils than any other site known at the time, and the collection remains a treasure of Neanderthal research.

title: Beijing Picks Frenchman's Plan for Theater Complex
description: Chinese officials have settled on a stark modern French design for China's new national theater complex here in a startling denouement to an epic decision-making process that has lasted 40 years.

title: Mr. DeLay's New 'Killer' Tactic
description: With the House scheduled to vote on campaign finance reform this month, defenders of the corrupt status quo are up to some old tricks. The most pernicious is an attempt by Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, to amend the Shays-Meehan soft-money ban by exempting certain political activities on the Internet from Federal election fund-raising laws. Mr. DeLay knows that his amendment has a certain superficial appeal for Internet users, many of whom reflexively oppose cyberspace infringements of any kind. But his approach would not simply gut Shays-Meehan. It would circumvent laws in existence for decades by opening new avenues for abuse.

title: OVERCAPACITY IN JAPANESE STEEL

The NKK Corporation, the No. 2 Japanese producer, widened its net loss forecast 5 percent, to 42 billion yen, on sales 2 percent less than earlier forecast. As they released new forecasts, Japan's five largest steelmakers said recent gains in Asian exports had provided little respite from years of slumping sales. Asian exports had provided one bright spot for the industry. Exports to the region jumped 29.8 percent in the April-June period from the similar period a year ago. Yet, steelmakers said the rise was not enough, and might not be sustained.

Her father, Dr. Leon Luster was a famous dermatologist, and with Tyda's first husband started a cosmetics factory Miraculum which was confiscated during the Nazi and Communist eras and is today an important commercial enterprise. Shares of Vodafone, based in Britain, rose 48 pence, or 3.86 percent, to 1,290 pence ($20.72) after it confirmed that it was in talks with Bell Atlantic, the No. 1 United States local-phone company. The statement sparked optimism the two were aiming to resurrect their partnership after they agreed to split their existing wireless venture last month. A new venture between Bell Atlantic and Vodafone could create a nationwide American wireless phone network to compete with those of AT&T and Sprint. description: WHEN a field of genetically altered corn at the University of Maine was destroyed by protesters in mid-August, it was a rare hint that uneasiness over bioengineering in agriculture is growing among Americans. Such actions have become common overseas, with experimental fields burned in England, and the European Union and Japan decreeing that genetically engineered food must be labeled. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, MAUREEN
description: MCCARTHY-Maureen. Age 63, passed away at Memorial Hospital on September 3, 1999, succumbing to metastatic sarcoma cancer. She was born in Richmond, Virginia, to William and Florence Goggin. Resided in Beverly, Mass. graduating from Beverly High School in 1953. Graduate of Leslie College, Cambridge, Mass. in 1957. Taught in Newton, Mass. and Wallenford, Connecticut schools. Married Eugene G. McCarthy in June of 1958. Children, 3 boys, Joseph Gregory, 1959, John Ignatius, 1960 and Paul Eugene, 1963. Accompanied her husband who was Chief Health Advisor for the Alliance for Progress in Paraguay 1961-1964, appointed by President John F. Kennedy. Professionally she was an Innkeeper on the Maine seacoast-Smugglers Cove Motor Inn and the 1820 House Restaurant, Boothbay Harbor, in the late 60's and 70's. She established a nationwide Panel of Board Certified physicians for a national referral program for second opinions in the 70's and 80's. Her eldest son Joseph Gregory succumbed to schizophrenia in 1984 at the age of 25. The focus of her attention was the development of the gift of poetry - easy to read collections - exploring the basic human themes...solitude, love, pain, womanhood, aging and underlying it all, a call to faith. Her two books of poetry ''Catching the Spirit,'' 1994 and ''Prelude to Passion,'' 1999, address the fact that a lot of people are afraid of the intimacy with God. ''They are frightened.'' She felt that she had been given a gift to not only become aware of an intimacy but relish it. As a result of Joseph's death her activities were directed toward assisting the psychotic single homeless through the Franciscan Fathers in New York City, Visiting Professorships in Theology at Boston College, Pontifical Gregorian University and the Pontifical Biblicum University. Her spiritual life was continually nourished by her close association with the Trappist communities of St. Joseph in Spencer, Mass and St. Mary's in Wrentham. Likewise, she benefited from her nomination as a Dame of the Knights of Malta. She is survived by her husband Dr. Eugene G. McCarthy, Clinical Professor of Public Health, New York Weill Cornell Center, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Consultant to a number of Joint Trust Funds, John Ignatius McCarthy of Brunswick, Maine, two grandchildren, AnyaRose and Matthew Joseph, Paul Eugene McCarthy of Martinsberg, West Virginia, a sister, Sheila Goggin of Lowell, Mass. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday September 9th and Friday September 10th from 4-7 P.M. A Mass of Christian Burial will be on Saturday, September 11th at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, at 11:00 A.M.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC TO BUY KVAERNER UNIT
description: Kvaerner S.A., Europe's largest shipbuilder, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of its natural gas power plant business to the General Electric Company. Kvaerner is selling businesses that build natural gas turbines and design and maintain natural gas power plants. They have annual sales of about $260 million and employ about 670 people in Norway, Scotland, and elsewhere, the company said. Kvaerner said the financial details of the transaction would not be determined until the sale is completed. G.E. confirmed that its Power Systems division was in talks with Kvaerner as part of G.E.'s plan to expand its power business.

title: AMDOCS PLANS ACQUISITION TO INCREASE BILLING BUSINESS
description: Amdocs Ltd., which sells software to telecommunications companies, has agreed to buy International Telecommunication Data Systems Inc. for $182 million in stock, strengthening its billing services business. The acquisition, announced Monday, will add 4 cents a share to its 2000 earnings for Amdocs, a St. Louis company that makes software for telecommunications billing, call tracking and customer service, the company said. International Telecommunication, based in Stamford, Conn., handles billing and some other tasks for which Amdocs provides software. Shares of Amdocs fell $1.375, to $26.125, while International Telecommunication rose $1.1875, to $9.3125.

title: LONG, COSTLY CASE AGAINST CISNEROS ENDS IN PLEA DEAL
description: Henry G. Cisneros, President Clinton's former Housing Secretary, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor count of lying to the F.B.I. about payments to a former mistress. Under a plea agreement that brings to an abrupt end the four-year, $10 million investigation that led to his resignation, he avoids both a trial on 18 felony charges and jail time.

She had been a nurse and struggled for over 25 years with this cruel illness. Her family is dedicated to the hope that soon others will not have to suffer as she did. The funeral will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Chairman's Fund of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, PALMER
description: DIXON-Palmer. Died suddenly of a heart attack on the morning of September 3rd at his home in Wilton, CT. He was born July 1, 1928 in New York City, the son of W. Palmer Dixon and Theodora Thorpe Dixon. He attended St. Mark's School, and graduated from Harvard College, Class of 1950. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army during the Korean Conflict, participating in the fighting as a forward observer for the artillery. After the Armistice, he returned to the United States in 1953, working at NBC before becoming a Partner at the Wall Street firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Co. He later worked as a Vice President at Moseley, Hallgarten & Estabrook, and then for a number of years at Standard & Poor's as Head of Programming. After retiring, he continued to work as a computer specialist and private consultant. He was a keen Court Tennis player, and was for many years an active member of the New York Racquet and Tennis club. He is survived by his wife, Heather-Mary Sharp Dixon, his two daughters, Alexandra M. Dixon of London, Olivia H. Dixon of Wilton, CT, his son Adam P. Dixon and daughter-in-law Gabriella Dixon Prinzessin zu Schwarzenberg of Vienna, and two granddaughters, Xenia and Daria Dixon; his brother, Peter T. Dixon of New York City, and his nephews, Peter M. Dixon, John C. Dixon, and Mark T. Dixon. The funeral wil be at 10:30 AM on Thursday September 9, at St. James Episcopal Church at 71 St. and Madison Avenue in New York City.

But they wisely gave precedence to the principles that distinguish Israel from most of its Mideast neighbors, mainly the rule of law and respect for human dignity.

title: Giddy Farce From Japan Pokes Fun At Tradition
description: Comedy is certainly not the first thing that comes to mind when we think of Japanese cinema. But a few more films like Koki Mitani's hilarious screwball farce ''Welcome Back, Mr. McDonald'' could change all that. This movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is ostensibly a goofy comedy about a live radio drama that goes haywire after the imperious diva playing the lead insists on certain last-minute changes. Her demands set in motion a desperate chain of events that transform a sudsy romantic drama set in a Japanese fishing village into a ludicrous action-adventure fantasy set in the United States.

title: HYUNDAI CHAIRMAN ASKED TO TESTIFY
description: The Seoul District Prosecutor's Office ordered the chairman of the Hyundai Electronics Company, Chung Mong Hun, to present himself at their headquarters before the end of the week to answer questions on the Hyundai stock price manipulation scandal, officials said. Executives of Hyundai group are suspected of involvement in raising the stock price of Hyundai's chip unit by buying shares with about 220 billion won ($184 million) channeled from sister firms. The prosecutor's office said that Mr. Chung was being summoned because he was the subject of a lawsuit filed by a civic group, the People's Solidarity for Participatory Democracy, over the affair.

Mr. Tapias, 57, is president of Camargo Correa Industrial S.A. Most of his working career has been at Bradesco.

title: Wendell Shoulders the Blame in a Bullpen Collapse

Standing in front of his locker, getting dressed quickly and seemingly full of nervous energy, the spirited relief pitcher was hard on himself. Almost as hard as opposing batters have been on his inviting offerings to the plate.

title: E.D.S. PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO 27 MILLION SHARES
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the computer services company, said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 27 million shares, or 5.5 percent of its shares outstanding, and earmark them for stock options that employees will not exercise for at least another five years. The buyback will include five million shares from the General Motors Corporation's Hourly Rate Employees Pension Plan, E.D.S.'s largest shareholder. The company also will buy back 1.9 million to 4.5 million shares from the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation's Hourly Rate Employees Pension Plan. E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., and Delphi, of Troy, Mich., are both G.M. spinoffs.

title: DAEWOO GROUP GETS FUNDS
description: South Korean creditors of the ailing Daewoo Group agreed to provide 1 trillion won ($838 million) in new operational funds to seven key Daewoo units beginning this week. The seven firms due to receive financing are the Daewoo Corporation, Daewoo Motor, Daewoo Electronics, Daewoo Heavy Industries, Daewoo Telecom, Diner's Club Korea and Daewoo Capital. Lee Ho Kun, a managing director of Korea First Bank, Daewoo's major creditor, said the group of creditors would immediately provide funds for trade financing.

In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Turkish Earthquake Relief at the Red Cross International Response Fund 1-800-HELP-NOW Memorial Service TBA.

description: A burglar broke into the home of a 39-year-old Long Island woman while she slept early yesterday, stabbed her repeatedly and took several thousand dollars from her pocketbook, the police said.

description: ZAYDE-Jascha. WQXR mourns the passing of a valued member of our family: pianist, teacher and WQXR's first Staff Musician/Live Music Coordinator. He will be fondly remembered by his many fiends and former colleagues.

description: LEGG MASON INC., Baltimore, the brokerage and money management firm, is acquiring the investment advisory firm Berkshire Asset Management, Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Coming to New York, Bringing the Country
description: SOME restaurants seem to hit the ground running, and Della Femina is one of them. Only three months old, it already attracts a tony Upper East Side clientele that obviously feels right at home in a cool, restrained, Yankeefied setting straight out of Martha Stewart. It looks like a television commercial for the good life, late 1990's style.

title: The Day the Restaurants Rest
description: I USED to eat at home on Sundays. But the need to dine out constantly has disrupted my pattern -- and opened my eyes. I now routinely eat out on both weekend nights, and a creeping suspicion is growing into something like a firm conviction: for diners, Sunday is not a good bet.

title: Yawning as the Earth Warms

title: School Board Expected to End Social Promotion Today
description: Despite mixed results from this year's summer school, the Board of Education plans to put an end to the practice of automatically promoting failing students, and will widen a pilot policy to cover all grades from 3 through 12.

title: Avis Selects McCann-Erickson
description: Avis Rent a Car in Garden City, N.Y., yesterday named McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $30 million. The account had been at Bates USA in New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., for 15 years before the agency resigned in June rather than take part in a review.

title: East Timor Under Siege
description: Last week, in a referendum with nearly 100 percent turnout, East Timor's voters overwhelmingly supported independence from Indonesia. Now rampaging militias, with the backing and apparent complicity of Indonesia's army, are taking revenge against the inhabitants of this unlucky territory. They have set East Timor on fire -- murdering residents and driving tens of thousands of people to neighboring West Timor. Unfortunately, the proposals coming from Jakarta to stop the terror are less than reassuring. The United Nations Security Council should immediately endorse Australia's attempts to assemble a quick-reaction international peacekeeping force, and countries with economic influence should use it to press Indonesia to end the violence now or let the peacekeepers in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESIMONE, JIM
description: DeSIMONE-Jim. The staff and students of Stuyvesant High School mourn the sudden death of their beloved and respected swimming coach. We send our deepest condolences to his family. Jimmy will be sorely missed by the entire Stuyvesant community. Stanley Teitel, Principal Stuyvesant High School

title: Chief Executive of Sabre Is Resigning
description: Michael Durham, chief executive of Sabre Holdings Corporation,who led the spinoff of the company from the AMR Corporation three years ago, has resigned.

title: A U.S. Office Opens, Stirring Saigon Memories
description: In the heart of the old Saigon, on the site where the American Ambassador fled in a helicopter from his embassy roof 24 years ago, a new United States consulate was dedicated today, a symbol of a new but unsure relationship of old enemies trying to be friends.

title: Elegies, Minor Chords, Tolling Guitar Notes
description: Slow and steady was the rule when Godspeed You Black Emperor and LaBradford, two minimalist rock bands, shared a double bill at the Mercury Lounge on Sunday night. Both bands record for the same label, Kranky Records in Chicago; neither uses lyrics, and both let their material take its time. It was a night of rock elegies, replete with minor chords, tolling guitar notes and a tone of foreboding and desolation. Each band constructed patterns as a bulwark against collapse, sounding as if it knew all along that the effort was in vain.

title: BRITISH GROUP BUYS HOTELS
description: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels P.L.C. of Britain said it would buy 29 North American hotels from Regal Hotels International Holdings Ltd. for $725 million. Millennium & Copthorne currently owns three hotels in the United States, including the Plaza. In a two-stage deal, Millennium will buy 11 hotels from Alaska to Florida and will take control of Regent's management company, which provides services for all of Regal's 29 North American hotels and 20 others. In addition, for $445 million, Millennium will take a 50 percent share in Regal's other North American hotels through a joint venture arrangement. Millennium has the right to acquire the remaining 50 percent of the joint venture after two years. Millennium & Copthorne is a subsidiary of CDL Hotels International Ltd. of Hong Kong. Regal Hotels is 75 percent owned by Paliburg Holdings Ltd.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; MORAVIA BANKA LICENSE REVOKED
description: The Czech National Bank decided to revoke the license of Moravia Banka. The 1997 attempt to put Moravia Banka back on its feet through a $20 million financial injection failed and the money ''disappeared into a black hole,'' said Prime Minister Milos Zeman, pictured. His Government is due to discuss financial assistance to the bank's clients today. ''We might provide bridging loans to the clients, but not the bank itself,'' said Financial Minister Pavel Mertlik. Moravia Banka, established in the post-Communist euphoria of the early 1990's, is the 17th Czech bank to close since 1993. Ladka Bauerova

description: After John Cardinal O'Connor's recent surgery for removal of a brain tumor, the Archdiocese of New York said that the tumor was small, confined to the brain and on its surface, and that he would soon begin several weeks of radiation treatment.

description: ALONG the rugged hills of northern Italy, a grape called arneis has grown for more than 500 years. These are the same hills that produce great wines like Barolo and Barbaresco, wines that by the middle of this century overshadowed the arneis grape and its wine and nearly caused its extinction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, SHIRLEY
description: UNGER-Shirley, died peacefully at home on August 7 after a long illness. She was preceded in death by her husband, Richard Unger, and is survived by her brother, Melvin Zimet, and her nephews, John and Paul Zimet. Mrs. Unger was a former president of the New York Metropolitan Chapter of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials. She is remembered by her relatives and friends for her generosity, wisdom, devotion to her loved ones, and the fullness with which she lived her life. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at 12 Noon, on September 18, at La MaMa Annex, 66 East 4th St. (between 2nd and 3rd Ave.)

description: Hillary Clinton likes to think of herself as Eleanor Roosevelt. Bill Clinton likes to think of himself as Jack Kennedy. But the couple are a lot closer to Lucy and Ricky.

title: Martha Graham's Legacy: How the Dances Will Now Be Danced
description: As it prepares for the opening of its new season, the Martha Graham Dance Company has made a series of decisive moves that it hopes will nourish and protect its founder's artistic legacy and insure its own survival as a dynamic institution. Ron Protas, who succeeded Graham as artistic director on her death in 1991, will step aside next year to devote himself full time to running the troupe's new licensing program as well as to the preservation work as the chief of the Martha Graham Archives at the Library of Congress. He will continue to work with the company as its artistic adviser.

description: NEW YORK  Viacom Inc., the media conglomerate that owns the MTV cable channel and the Paramount film studio, said Tuesday it was buying CBS Corp., which operates what was long considered the classiest U.S. television network.

title: THE CHEF
description: SOMETIMES, a good dish is really just a lucky accident. I stumbled on the idea for my Hudson Valley succotash several summers ago, while I was working on a cookbook. My co-author, Molly Finn, and I had bought bags and bags of fresh vegetables at the farmers' market and were developing recipes.

title: Ford Loses Bid to Keep Documents Off Internet
description: Asserting that an Internet site has the same free-speech rights as newspapers and other traditional media, a Federal judge ruled here today that the Ford Motor Company could not stop the owner of the site from using information that he had gleaned from confidential Ford documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLOW, NATHAN
description: BELLOW-Nathan, 85, on Friday, September 3, 1999 of natural causes. A graduate of St. John's School of Law, served in U.S. Army Intelligence during WWII. Retired in recent years from executive position with a telecommunications company in New York. Survivors include his niece, Ruth Seigel, Great Neck and nephew, Philip Stein, Washington, D.C.

title: Backstage Drama Unfolds Over Taste-of-Broadway Show for Tourists
description: Three longtime theater producers are creating a 60-minute, $25-a-ticket Broadway production aimed at the tourists swarming through Times Square. But their project at the Lyceum Theater has run into intense opposition from the most powerful theater owner on Broadway.

title: The Cisneros Plea
description: It was reasonable for Attorney General Janet Reno to recommend that an independent counsel investigate whether former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Henry Cisneros lied to Federal agents conducting a background check in his confirmation process in 1993. Now the expensive, overly protracted investigation has ended in a negotiated wrist-slap for Mr. Cisneros. That seems an appropriate outcome for a case in which a Cabinet officer clearly erred but the prosecution was apparently unable to prove all its charges.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Coach Expands Flagship Store on Madison Ave.
description: As Coach broadens its product line to make the company a little less heavy into leather, it is also redesigning and more than doubling the size of its flagship store at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 57th Street.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper rose amid expectations of strengthening demand as factories increase production with the end of summer vacations. In New York, copper for December delivery rose 1.85 cents, to 82.65 cents a pound.

title: European Parliament And Prodi Reach Deal
description: BRUSSELS  Romano Prodi, the president-designate of the European Commission reached an agreement with leaders of the European Parliament on Tuesday that virtually assured that the assembly will confirm his team for a five-year term when it meets in plenary session in Strasbourg next week.

title: Insurance Service Company, and 770 Jobs, Leaving New York for Jersey City
description: The Insurance Service Office Inc., an information clearinghouse, will move 1,400 employees from five offices, including its Manhattan headquarters, to a building under construction in Jersey City, the company said yesterday.

title: Connolly Impresses
description: When Tim Connolly was chosen by the Islanders with the fifth overall pick last June, the team's scouts were confident they had found a future franchise player. Their plan on draft day was for Connolly to return to the juniors and maybe spend one year in the minors before playing in the National Hockey League.

title: Hingis and Venus Williams Refuse to Give In to the Wind
description: Rain or not, the remnants of Hurricane Dennis continued to menace the United States Open players who, unlike top-seeded Martina Hingis, had trouble recalibrating the tools of their trade inside a virtual wind tunnel yesterday. Time and again, the wind treated the tennis balls like stunt kites, snatching them from the launcher and sending them on wild trajectories that tried the receiver's retrieval skills. It made for ugly tennis, and uglier tempers -- all except for Hingis, who squeezed out just 15 unforced errors in her 6-2, 6-0 victory over Anke Huber to advance to the Open's semifinal round for the third consecutive year.

title: GOLD BANC IN STOCK DEAL FOR AMERICAN BANCSHARES
description: The Gold Banc Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Bancshares Inc. for $91.4 million in stock, entering the fast-growing Florida banking market. Gold Banc, based in Leawood, Kan., is paying $18.18 a share for American Bancshares, which is based in Bradenton, Fla. American Bancshares rose $1.875, to $13.875, while Gold Banc fell $1.125, to $10.75. American Bancshares, which has 10 American Bank branches on Florida's west coast, will continue to operate under that name. The purchase is the second in a month by Gold Banc, which will have more than $2 billion in assets when the acquisitions are completed. It agreed in August to buy the Denver-based Union Bankshares Ltd. for around $66 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAI, NARAYAN B., M.D., F.A.C.S.
description: PAI-Narayan B., M.D., F.A.C.S. It is with profound sorrow and a deep sense of regret that we, the Board of Trustees, Medical Staff, and the entire Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center family mourn the passing of Dr. Narayan B. Pai, Chief of Vascular Surgery, Attending Surgeon, Chairman of the Credentials Committee, and former President of the hospital's Medical Board. Dr. Pai was also Associate Professor in Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, as well as a former Governor of the American College of Surgeons and past President of the Bronx County Medical Society and Bronx County Surgical Society. Dr. Pai was widely recognized for his many contributions to the BronxLebanon cause. He was a compassionate, caring and dedicated physician and his sudden passing is certainly a tremendous loss to us. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Olga, his children Gregory, Sheela & Kiran, and his grandchildren Gregory, Richard and Gabriella. Miguel O. Martinez, Chairman, Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes Jr. President and CEO Milton A. Gumbs, M.D., Vice President, Medical Affairs/Medical Director

title: MOTOROLA HIRING 2,000 WORKERS FOR CELL PHONE DIVISION
description: Motorola Inc., one of the world's biggest cellular-phone makers, said yesterday that it planned to hire about 2,000 people in its digital cellular phone division to meet increasing demand for its products. It said the jobs would be added in the next six months at its plant in Harvard, Ill., which now has about 4,400 employees. Motorola is pushing to develop appealing models faster. The workers will be hired for about 30 different jobs, including assembly line, marketing and engineering positions. Shares of Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., rose $4.875, to $100.

title: Alan Clark, a British Scold, Is Dead at 71
description: Alan Clark, the outrageously acerbic Conservative Member of Parliament whose witty, waspish political diaries by turns skewered his colleagues, gave vent to his splenetic opinions, and unashamedly celebrated his love of women other than his wife, died suddenly at home in Kent on Sunday, three months after an operation to remove a brain tumor, his family said today. He was 71.

title: Pernod-Coke Hearing Set
description: Pernod Ricard S.A.'s planned sale of its Orangina beverage to the Coca-Cola Company will be examined by French competition officials at a Sept. 28 hearing, setting the stage for a final decision after almost two years of talks. A panel will oversee a private hearing with Coke and Pernod. Conclusions will be passed on to the Finance Minister, who rejected the deal last year on the ground that it would be adverse to competition. After failing to win approval for its first offer made in December 1997, Coke agreed this year to scale back its bid to 4.7 billion francs ($758 million) from 5 billion and not distribute the drink in French restaurants, cafes and hotels.

description: Kosovo's police school began training its first cadets today, with only one Serb among a sea of Albanians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLISKOW, MARK ALAN
description: PLISKOW-Mark Alan. Beloved husband of Stacie Bryce Feldman. Devoted father of Adam and Benjamin. Loving son of Janice and Morris Pliskow, loving grandson and owner of Wheatley. Loving son-in-law, brother, brother-in law, father-in-law and uncle. Mark was a zealous trial attorney who vigorously litigated his clients' rights as well as a reading enthusiast. He was deeply devoted to his family and friends. His wit, warmth, compassion and storytelling techniques will be deeply missed by all who knew him. title: MEDIACONSULT.COM AGREES TO BUY PHYSICIANS' ONLINE
description: Mediconsult.com Inc., which provides health information and services on the Internet, said that it had agreed to buy the privately held Physicians' Online Inc. for $166.5 million in stock and the assumption of $13.5 million in debt. Mediconsult.com focuses on patients with chronic health conditions, like diabetes and asthma. Physicians' Online, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., offers services to 80,000 doctors, including access to medical data bases and E-mail. Mediconsult.com, based in New York, said it wanted to combine the two audiences.

title: F & M BANCORP AGREES TO PURCHASE A MARYLAND BANK
description: F & M Bancorp, which operates more than 40 retail banks in Maryland and Pennsylvania, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Patapsco Valley Bancshares Inc. for $45.9 million in stock to expand its commercial banking services in Maryland. F & M, based in Frederick, Md., will exchange 1.18 shares of common stock for each share of Patapsco common stock, making the deal worth around $34 a share for Patapsco shareholders. Patapsco, based in Ellicott City, Md., is the holding company for Commercial and Farmers Bank, which runs eight branches in Maryland. CFBank will become part of F & M's commercial banking unit, Farmers and Mechanics National Bank. Shares of F & M fell 37.5 cents, to $28.50; Patapsco rose $1.50, to $29.

title: Bet You Can't Eat Just One Soybean
description: THE Chinese call them mao dou, or hairy beans. The Japanese call them edamame, or branch beans. Neither name, however, expresses even faintly the fondness those cultures have for the soybean. Like the peanut in America, the soybean is a humble home-grown legume that everyone eats -- often as a snack -- and most adore.

title: MAKING A MEDIA GIANT: Market Place; The New, Improved Redstone Still Knows How to Get His Way
description: The biggest deals of Sumner Redstone's life have featured bitter takeover battles, lots of debt and some of the strangest securities ever seen on Wall Street. But now, he says, things will be different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARENHOLTZ, STEVEN HOWARD
description: BARENHOLTZ-Steven Howard, 44, of Ossining, NY died suddenly on August 29 at his home. Born in New York City, he was an author, lecturer and consultant to the restaurant industry. Son of Evelyn Barenholtz of Syracuse, NY and the late Morton Barenholtz, he is also survived by brothers Jan of Southport, CT., and Paul of New York City, nieces Jeanne and Madeleine and nephews Daniel and David. title: Positive Spin on Y2K
description: Despite its cutting-edge culture, New York City sometimes struggles along on technology that predates the atomic era. The Department of Human Resources is still battling to get its records on computers. A whole industry known as ''expediters'' specializes in standing in line for developers who want permits from the Buildings Department. Computer systems in one government agency refuse to speak to systems elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTE, CHRISTIAAN J.D.
description: ROTE-Christiaan J.D., age 67, of Dallas and Santa Fe, on Monday, September 6, of cancer. Born in the Netherlands, he became a U.S. Citizen in Seoul, Korea in 1955 while on active military duty. His brokerage career began in Dallas in 1962 with Goodbody & Co. and continued in executive positions with E.F. Hutton, Rotan Mosle, and Merrill Lynch. While living in Manhattan, he served as president of the Private Client Group at Merrill and later moved to Chicago in that capacity where he lived until his retirement in 1996. He is survived by his wife Jane, his two sons Clayton and Chris, their wives Debbie and Anne, and four grandchildren, all of Dallas. Kindly send contributions to the Hematology/Oncology Research Fund at Zale Lipshy University Hospital, 5323 Harry Hines Boulevard, Dallas, Texas 75235. Please signify ''for myeloma research''. Final arrangements will be made in Santa Fe, New Mexico.

title: FEDERAL REALTY IN TALKS TO SELL STRIP SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Federal Realty Investment Trust said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its strip shopping center properties, one of the largest such holdings in the country. Federal Realty, a real estate investment trust based in Rockville, Md., also said that its board had approved a plan to spin off by year-end a unit that focuses on redeveloping downtown shopping districts. Shareholders would get one share in the unit, which would not be a REIT, for every share held. Federal Realty said it had received a bid to buy its shopping center properties for cash and securities worth $18 a share. The bidder, which the company did not identify, would also assume an unspecified amount of debt.

description: The group of umpires opposed to Richie Phillips's leadership of their union moved closer yesterday to forming a new union and seeking a National Labor Relations Board vote certifying it.

title: Men's Bracket Groans From All the Injuries
description: There have been so many injury defaults by men in the United States Open tennis championships that the trainer's room has the look of a MASH unit.

title: Toyota Set to List Shares in U.S. and Britain
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would list shares on the New York and London stock exchanges on Sept. 29 to increase investor awareness in the company.

title: Embracing The Octopus, Tenderly
description: A RAW octopus resting on ice at the seafood store is definitely the ugliest thing in the vicinity -- nothing like the many-hued snappers or even the white, pristine cleaned squid. No, this floppy, gray, suction-cupped monster seems to have been born with a natural defense aimed directly at the home cook. ''I am,'' it growls, ''too hideous to eat.''

title: I.B.M. TO OFFER SERVER FOR INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDERS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would introduce a server computer for Internet service providers, challenging Sun Microsystems in that market. The new computer, the Netfinity 4000R, will be just one and a half inches thick so it can be stacked with other servers in a small space, I.B.M. said. The machine, which will be available this month, will cost $3,000 to $4,000 and will be powered by two Pentium III processors from the Intel Corporation. Sun captured much of the market by introducing compact servers that can be easily added to a network as a company's Web business expands.

Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, Monday, September 13 at 10AM. For futher information please phone 516-922-1462.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; 3 Met Graduates Out on Their Own
description: Over the years many important singers have come through the Metropolitan Opera's Young Artist Development Program, including some prominent Americans like Dawn Upshaw and Dwayne Croft. It says a lot about the quality of the training and the prestige of the program that three of its graduates, the soprano Heidi Grant Murphy, the soprano Michelle DeYoung and the baritone Nathan Gunn, all young Americans now embarked on potentially major careers, can all be heard on fine new recordings in recital repertory.

title: Six Big Vitamin Makers Are Said to Agree to Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Pricing Lawsuit
description: Six of the world's largest vitamin makers have agreed to pay about $1.1 billion to resolve a class-action lawsuit that accused them of participating in a conspiracy to fix vitamin prices over the past decade, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: A Wife on the Run, for Good Reason
description: There is a moment in ''She's Out of Her Tree,'' a piece by the Philadelphia-based performance artist known as Paule Turner, Duchess, in which a loose collection of skits and shticks comes together with a breathtaking intensity and truthfulness. Mr. Turner plays a Kansas housewife on the run after murdering her husband in the piece, performed on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop on a Carnival series program shared with Molly Hickok. The housewife's journey has more shamelessly melodramatic twists than a camp remake of ''Imitation of Life,'' all of them played to the hilt by Mr. Turner.

title: Sport of The Times; Guga Leaves Sore Backs In His Wake
description: WATCH out for Gustavo Kuerten. He is the most gentle soul on the tennis tour -- a trace of the samba in his walk, a hint of a Brazilian beach in his smile -- but watch out for him, all the same.

description: New York State's new Regents requirements, which mandate that all public high school students pass a series of tough new exams to graduate, have been a source of controversy in New York education circles. CD's, $5.'' On the northwest corner another man offered the same deal. People crowded around as if someone was giving out free food.

title: Leniency and Silence
description: President Clinton's offer of clemency to 16 Puerto Rican nationalists has been accepted by 12 members of the group. Yet the furor over Mr. Clinton's action will not go away. Republicans are clamoring in protest, and Hillary Rodham Clinton has broken with her husband rather than be seen as soft on terrorism. One reason for the controversy is Mr. Clinton's silence. Although normally loquacious in defending his positions, he has not yet explained why he wants to shorten the sentences of members of organizations espousing violence and allegedly involved in at least 130 bombings during the 1970's and 80's.

title: Fresh Out of Bread Crumbs? Try a Small Global Locator
description: The technology that handles signals from the Global Positioning System is getting so small that soon people will be able to discern exactly where they are, where their children are and where the fish are biting -- just by looking at their watches.

title: Mrs. Clinton Denies Role in President's Clemency Offer
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she had played no role in any of the decisions that led to President Clinton's offer of clemency to 16 Puerto Rican militants, a move that has created problems for her campaign for the United States Senate.

title: DYNATECH TO BUY APPLIED DIGITAL ACCESS FOR $80 MILLION
description: The Dynatech Corporation, a leading maker of communications testing equipment, said yesterday that it would acquire Applied Digital Access Inc. for about $80 million in cash. Dynatech said it would pay $5.37 for each share of Applied Digital. Applied Digital, based in San Diego, makes network test and performance systems for high-speed telecommunications circuits. It had revenue of $29 million last year. Dynatech, based in Burlington, Mass., expects the purchase to strengthen its systems and software line. Major telecommunications companies use Dynatech's products to test and monitor their phone and other communications services.

title: Chrome and Leather Comeback
description: The ''20th Century Art and Design'' auction on Saturday and Sunday at the Treadway Toomey Galleries in Oak Park, Ill., has lined up the usual suspects from the midcentury modern mob: the Eameses, George Nelson, Florence Knoll. But the 1,552 lots also include up-and-coming names like William Katavolos, Ross Littell and Douglas Kelley, who designed as a team in the 1950's and 60's and whose chrome and leather seating -- the most recognizable is the sling T-Chair -- is becoming a staple for sophisticated dealers. Their sofa (above) is estimated to bring $500 to $700; the pair of chairs, $500 to $700. Laverne International, which commissioned designs from the team, is also represented, with the bench, at $700 to $900. Bidding will be held simultaneously on line at amazon.livebid.com. Gallery information: (513) 321-6742.
