title: The Latest Thing in Antiquity
description: Steven Heinemann's pottery has been described as traditional, contemporary, even forward looking. ''I'd say it's all of the above,'' Mr. Heinemann said from his home in Ontario. ''It reflects the meeting of contemporary art and the world of ancient, anonymous bowl makers.'' The bowl above ($4,500), 25 inches by 19 by 11, took two years and 12 firings. Mr. Heinemann's first solo show in New York, with 12 works priced from $1,200 to $6,000, begins today at Nancy Margolis Gallery, 560 Broadway (Prince Street), and runs through Oct. 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTEL, HARRY
description: BARTEL-Harry, 35, died at his home in Manhattan, on Sunday, September 5. He is survived by his spouse, Brian Landeche; his mother, Eileen Bartel, of Scottsdale, Arizona; his father, Harry Bartel, of Sarasota, Florida; his sister, Donna Bartel, of Seattle; and his brother, Michael Bartel, of Phoenix. Mr. Bartel, together with Mr. Landeche, opened Splash bar in 1991 on 17th Street in Manhattan. It was an immediate hit and was credited with helping to spark the transformation of Chelsea into one of the nation's most celebrated gay neighborhoods. As one of New York's entertainment guides put it: ''Splash was in Chelsea before Chelsea was cool.'' Mr. Bartel was a familiar face at the bar, greeting regular patrons as well as visitors from around the world. He was active in charity work, supporting the Gay Men's Health Crisis, God's Work We Deliver, Amfar, the Anti-Violence Project, the Gay and Lesbian Switchboard, and the Gay Games of 1994 and 1998. He was a Log Cabin Republican, and worked closely with the community boards in lower Manhattan. He had many interests and was an avid tennis fan, gardener and cook. Mr. Bartel was born in 1964 in Astoria, Queens. He was raised in Scottsdale, Arizona, and was a graduate of Arizona State University with a degree in finance. Services are to be held on Friday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue (at 112th Street). Viewing will take place from 10:30 to 11:45 AM and the memorial service will begin at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Stonewall Foundation for the maintenance of the Harry Bartel Scholarship.

But we were farming a long time ago. In Israel.'' Leanne Silverblatt affectionately calls her husband, Alan, ''a good ol' Mississippi Delta Jewish redneck.''

title: Essay; Welcome to Kremlingate
description: Surprise, surprise: corruption has been rampant in the Kremlin.

title: McEnroe Brings His Fire to Davis Cup Captaincy
description: He is more tightly wound than the button-down Davis Cup captains traditionally selected by the United States Tennis Association -- like leopards, firebrands don't often change their spots. But John McEnroe, paternal and patriotic at 40, got the nod yesterday to assume the Davis Cup captaincy in 2000 and attempt to restore the United States to the championship status it has held 31 times but not since 1995.

title: Sealed With Sorrow: Mary Lincoln in Letters
description: One hundred and seventeen years after Mary Todd Lincoln's death at 64 in 1882, six previously unknown letters written by her and one by her last surviving son, Robert, have just come to light. These rare letters, in their original envelopes, were owned by descendants of one of Mrs. Lincoln's doctors. They describe her use, and possible abuse, of pain-relieving medicines and her state of mind at the saddest time of her troubled widowhood when she had her own leftover life to kill.

title: Accusations of Bribery In the Kremlin Mount Up
description: One of the central figures in an investigation of corruption in the Kremlin said today that he had seen credit card bills and photocopies of credit cards bearing the signatures of President Boris N. Yeltsin and his daughters, and that the cards had been provided by a Swiss construction company that has done $1.5 billion worth of work for the Kremlin.

title: Rockport Leaving Kirshenbaum Bond
description: The Rockport Company in Marlborough, Mass., part of Reebok International, and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York have parted ways after three years.

title: La Guardia Removes a Runway Pavement Buffer Intended to Stop Out-of-Control Aircraft
description: It was supposed to act as a safety device to keep out-of-control planes at La Guardia Airport from smashing into the Grand Central Parkway. But the specially designed pavement turned into a threat, with blasts from jet engines breaking up the cement and blowing debris into crucial navigation equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STICH, CLAIRE
description: STICH-Claire. On September 7, 1999. Of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of 45 years to Saul. Loving mother of Stacey and Howard. Adored grandmother of Courtney and Scott. Special mother-in-law of Cindy. Cherished sister and aunt. You will be deeply missed by all of us. Services Friday, 10:00 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Instant Check on Gun Buyers Has Halted 100,000 of Them
description: The Government's instant background check system for gun purchasers stopped an estimated 100,000 convicted criminals, fugitives and people with a mental illness from buying a gun in its first seven months, according to a report by the Justice Department.

title: A New Stylish Carrying Case For iMac Users on the Go
description: Way back in 1984, Apple's brochure for the first Macintosh featured the no-bigger-than-a-breadbox computer in various smart poses all over the verdant Stanford University campus. But with today's popular iMac at 38 pounds, hauling it down to the quadrangle would cause even sports scholars to break a sweat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, ROSE ALBERT
description: GOLDEN-Rose Albert. Brookline Massachusetts, graduate of Hunter and NYU. Loving mother of Dee and Ben Trasen, and Michael McGill. Cherished grandmother of Jan, David, Robyn, Matthew, Dave, Cara, Erin, and Maxwell. Predeceased by adored husband Harry and daughters Jan Golden and Wendy McGill. Services Temple Ohabei Shalom, Brookline, MA, Friday at 10 A.M.

title: PROFIT UP AT CREDIT SUISSE
description: Credit Suisse Group reported profit rose 11 percent, to 2.7 billion Swiss francs ($1.8 billion), during the first half of the year compared with the comparable period a year earlier as its private banking and insurance businesses grew, making up for a slight dip in its investment banking business. Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment banking unit, lost 1.272 billion francs ($842.6 million), a widening of 4 percent from a year earlier as costs increased. Lukas Muhlemann, chief executive of Credit Suisse Group, said he planned to expand the company's private banking and insurance business through acquisitions. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND SOARS. The British pound jumped almost 1 percent against the dollar after the Bank of England unexpectedly increased its benchmark interest rate. In New York, the pound settled at $1.6192, up from $1.6049.

title: Economic Scene; Should Clinton embrace the China trade deal? Some say yes.
description: GRAB it. So say many economists, referring to the bold trade deal that China offered the United States in April and President Clinton rejected in what many deem a serious foreign policy blunder. Mr. Clinton can reverse course when he meets President Jiang Zemin on Sunday in Australia.

title: Red Storm Announces Schedule
description: St. John's announced its 1999-2000 men's schedule yesterday, highlighted by a late-season game at Duke on Feb. 26 .

title: Clinton Testifies in Inquiry on Labor Secretary
description: President Clinton testified for an hour today in the investigation by an independent counsel into accusations that Secretary of Labor Alexis M. Herman illegally solicited campaign contributions for Mr. Clinton's 1996 Presidential campaign.

title: 13 Podiatrists Named in Plot To Clip More Than Toenails
description: Judging by the number of colorful advertisements and fliers on the city's subways and buses offering podiatry services, one would think New Yorkers' foot problems have reached epidemic proportions.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Composers Who Defy Classification
description: 'Songs of Life'

title: Mets' Starters Auditioning For Post-Season Rotation
description: Octavio Dotel did it yesterday, Rick Reed did it Tuesday, Orel Hershiser will do it tonight and Masato Yoshii will be on stage on Saturday. The starters are working to keep the Mets in a comfortable position for the post-season, but they are also auditioning to keep themselves essential for October. This surely creeps into their thought process before every start.

title: A Generation of Precocious Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, JULES
description: ZIMMERMAN-Jules. On September 6, 1999. Husband of the late Shirley Zimmerman. Companion of Beverlee Boguslaw. Father of Laurie Goldstein and Randie Jarrett. Grandfather of Steven and Karen Gendal. Services will be held in Florida.

title: Internet Connects Inventors to Information (and One Another)
description: RODNEY LONG is an Alabama inventor who typically spends 16 hours a day on the Internet, logging on to things like inventor forums and an on-line patent database (www.patents.ibm.com /ibm.html) that has been sponsored by I.B.M. since 1997.

title: Where the Help Desk Goes for Good Advice
description: LOCKER GNOME

title: Calcutta Journal; Intellectuals' Pursuit: Putting English in Its Place
description: This great and grotesque city has been called many things, some of them not so nice. To Kipling, Calcutta was ''the city of dreadful night.'' And while such a literary moniker may have seemed acceptably poetic to Calcutta's storied intellectuals, there is one name they will no longer tolerate. Calcutta is never again to be called Calcutta.

title: Man in the News: John Clagett Danforth; Back in Public Arena
description: On most Tuesday mornings in his tenure in the Senate, Jack Danforth would slip away from Capitol Hill and travel a few miles to the small St. Alban's parish church at the National Cathedral to preach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, SCOTT
description: SCHERER-Scott. The Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates mourns the loss of Scott Scherer, former trustee, and extends its sincerest condolences to Leah and the children. Isabel Gros, President

title: Number of Victims of E. Coli Poisoning in Upstate New York Grows to Nearly 300
description: The number of people suspected to have been infected in a severe outbreak of E. coli poisoning in New York State almost doubled yesterday, making the outbreak one of the most serious to have occurred in the United States, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Herbert Stein, Nixon Adviser And Economist, Is Dead at 83
description: Herbert Stein, a free-market economist who used careful analysis and sharp wit to persuade the business community in the 1940's to rally behind the ''unnatural'' idea of using Federal budget deficits to regulate the economy, died yesterday at a hospital in Washington. He was 83.

title: Shows, Talks, a Festival
description: Early Prague Architecture

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Excerpts From Bradley's Announcement of Candidacy
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Bill Bradley in Crystal City, Mo., as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bullpen Is Shaky, but Benitez Regroups for Mets
description: Armando Benitez received the ball from Mike Piazza and began circling the mound, head down, mind working. He wiped his brow with his forearm, squatted behind the pitcher's rubber and stared at home plate. There were two outs and a man on first, and Benitez had just fired consecutive balls to J. T. Snow, who represented the tying run for the San Francisco Giants. The Mets' hard-throwing closer had two strikes on Snow but was losing control of his overpowering fastball and needed to reel himself back in.

title: As Support for Intervention Grows, Indonesia Persuades U.N. to Delay Evacuation of Mission
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan and the Security Council walked up to the brink of confrontation with Indonesia today, then backed away when President B. J. Habibie and his army chief, Gen. Wiranto, begged for more time to put East Timor in order.

title: In Shift, CUNY Says It Will Use Standardized Tests in Admissions and Placement
description: Trying to quiet the debate over the quality of its students, the City University of New York said yesterday that it was ready to use national standardized tests in its selection and placement of students for its four-year colleges.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Testifies Again

title: The Cycles of Opportunity; Mr. Bradley Enters the Race
description: Bill Bradley, who announced officially yesterday that he is a candidate for the Democratic nomination, has toyed with the idea of a Presidential campaign before. In 1992 his name appeared on the long list of Democrats that finally narrowed down to Bill Clinton. Almost four years later, after resigning from the Senate and declaring the political system ''broken,'' Mr. Bradley briefly flirted with Presidential possibilities again, hinting at a run as an independent candidate. Now, as a suddenly prominent alternative to Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bradley's timing is finally right. Since all the other plausible Democrats were scared away, he will get more than a fair chance to test Mr. Gore's staying power.

title: The Wind in Your Hair, Your E-Mail on the Dash
description: I'VE made the 16-mile trip from my apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side to a favorite restaurant on City Island in the Bronx dozens of times. Yet a recent drive there over the asphalt spaghetti of parkways and interstate expressways was, thanks to the latest injection of digital technology into our lives, like no other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSAF, ZIPORAH
description: ASSAF-Ziporah. On September 7, 1999. Survived by husband Mendel. Daughters Esther Gross and Ruth Nataf. Grandchildren Michelle, Elyse, Robin, Evan, Lea and Jonathan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Planet Hollywood Seen as Down but Not Out
description: Despite complaints about its food and difficulties attracting younger people and repeat customers, the glitzy Planet Hollywood restaurant chain can still flourish, by closing unprofitable outlets and by ''going back to the basics,'' says Robert Earl, its co-founder and chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Sunday Styles section this week about Chappaqua, N.Y., in the form of a letter to ''Senator and Mr. Clinton,'' referred incorrectly to traffic lights in the town. They indeed exist -- at least three.

title: DELL TO ACQUIRE DATA STORAGE COMPANY
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Convergenet Technologies Inc., a closely held data-storage company, for about $340 million in stock, the first acquisition for the biggest direct-seller of personal computers. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., agreed to buy the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., for 6.9 million shares. Dell said that it would take a charge of 5 cents to 7 cents a share for costs related to the acquisition. The purchase is part of Dell's push into the market for larger computers used by companies to run networks and store large amounts of data.

title: Buildings That Give Children Room to Play
description: IT'S the whining hour at the Watkins home. Liam, 23 months old, is wailing at an earsplitting decibel, and his parents are desperate to find a distraction. There used to be few options, especially on a rainy day. But the Watkinses, like more and more New Yorkers, are finding that their apartment building now offers one.

title: Dreamcast's New Games: Beauty That's Skin-Deep
description: THE Sega Dreamcast processor is fast, but a console is only as good as the games you can play on it. There are two dozen games scheduled for release before Santa loads up his sled, so the machine may be worth its $199.99 price tag by Christmas. But after spending days on end reviewing the debut titles, I didn't see much that blew my mind. And that's a bad sign because I'm easily amused.

title: A Merger or an Evolution?
description: Viacom's $37 billion acquisition of CBS has exquisite symbolism. Viacom actually began life 30 years ago as a relatively small cable television venture of CBS. Now it owns the VH1, MTV and Nickelodeon cable outlets, as well as Paramount Pictures and soon, of course, CBS itself.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Criticism Is Muted On Whitman Withdrawal
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's abrupt withdrawal from the United States Senate race in New Jersey flummoxed political leaders in both major parties, but Mrs. Whitman's advisers said yesterday that her change of heart was in keeping with her personality, which they described as stubborn and sometimes surprisingly naive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOSEPHINE ELIZABETH
description: HARRISON-Josephine Elizabeth. Of Palm Beach, Florida, died on Sunday, September 5, 1999 at Good Samaritan Hospital after an extended illness. She is survived by her husband, Ridgely Harrison; her two daughters, Christine Berry and Cynthia Shafer; and her two sons, Michael and Bryan Cozad. Additional survivors include her seven grandchildren and eight step-grandchildren who will miss her greatly. A private ceremony will be held at home. Interment will follow in Harbor Springs, Michigan at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to New York Botanical Gardens, 200th St. and Southern Blvd., Bronx, NY 10458.

title: Mexico's Banks Adopt American Credit-Reporting Practices
description: The usual reason given for the failure of about a third of Mexico's bank loans since 1995 is soaring inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLIR, WILLIAM
description: KALLIR-William. After a long illness. Husband of the late Edith Kallir, loving ''Dad'' of Peter, Zenaida and Melissa. Cherished ''Grandpa'' of William, David and Danielle. Please omit flowers. Contributions to Muscular Distrophy Association, 10 East 40th St., NYC 10016. Funeral services Thursday, September 9, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 180 West 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Concerts to Introduce Humanitarian Web Site
description: Three all-star pop stadium concerts on Oct. 9 -- in New Jersey, England and Switzerland -- are to introduce Netaid.org, a Web site that seeks to end poverty by bringing together relief organizations with donors and volunteers. In a news conference yesterday, Bono of U2 described Netaid as ''the Yellow Pages of aid in cyberspace.''

title: On East Timor, U.S. Can't Afford to Look Away
description: To the Editor:

title: When You've Got to Glow
description: With organic design in vogue, the aptly named Glow Worm lamp has been leaping out of stores since the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in June. Designed by Joseph Boron of Manic Lighting in Capitol Heights, Md., Glow Worm is made of lycra cotton over a fine steel frame and comes in white or lime green. Mr. Boron describes the 50-inch lamp as part of a line of ''higher-end products for the eccentric buyer.'' It is $198 at Jensen-Lewis, 89 Seventh Avenue (15th Street), (212) 929-4880. In Santa Monica, Calif., $175 at Highlights, 2427 Main Street, (310) 450-5886.

title: Business School Puts Courses In Hands of an On-Line Market
description: You have heard of on-line auctions for Beanie Babies, breakfasts with bigwigs and even spare kidneys. But what about bidding for seats in business school courses?

title: A Computer Beats Another But Can't Beat a Human
description: Whether computers, which do very well playing chess, will ever be a match for human beings in playing bridge is doubtful. But that time has not come yet, as was shown in London a week ago. Zia Mahmood, an outnumbered representative of Homo sapiens, played an individual competition against seven of the best computer programs and won narrowly. Unlike the computers, he did get tired, which was understandable after 16 hours of effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, JULIUS
description: FISHMAN-Julius. Of Palm Beach, Florida on Monday, September 6, 1999, served in the Army Air Corps as a gunner and radio operator during WWII based in England, cofounded Royal Dairy Foods Company, Inc., now a subsidiary of the Fleming Foods, Inc. and was active in many philanthropic causes. He is survived by his wife Ruth nee Berkowitz-Green, sister Libby Seskin of Delray Beach, Fla., son Ted Fishman of Clarksberg, NJ, daughter Joan Brown of New York and beloved grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Mel Karmazin, chief executive of CBS, which is being acquired by Viacom, misstated his role at Infinity Broadcasting, CBS's radio company. Mr. Karmazin joined Infinity as executive vice president in 1981 and was named president in 1986. He was not a founder; the company was started in 1972 by Gerald Carrus and Michael A. Wiener.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILNER, DAVID
description: WILNER-David. Devoted husband, father & grandfather died on September 8 of cardiac arrest at his home in NYC. He was a retired Superintendent of School District 24 in Queens, a retired Colonel in the U.S. Army and an active consultant for the Labor Relations Division of the Board of Education. Beloved husband of Stefanie; adored father of Paul, Gregg and Lori; loving brother and cherished grandfather of Jordan and Harris. Memorial service Friday 10:30 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street).

title: POLO RALPH LAUREN TO BUY EUROPEAN LICENSEE
description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, maker of Ralph Lauren, Chaps and Polo Sport clothing, said it would buy a European licensee, Poloco S.A., to gain more control of its brands and expand in Europe. Polo Ralph Lauren will buy Paris-based Poloco and some of its affiliates for $200 million in cash and $30 million in assumed debt. The businesses, licensed to sell Polo apparel, jeans and some accessories in Europe, had 1998 revenue of about $180 million. Polo Ralph Lauren will get a Polo store in Paris and six outlet stores in France, Britain and Austria. The transaction is expected to close in January and to add to earnings in fiscal 2001.

title: In Rubin's Shadow? Summers and the Dollar
description: In his two months as Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers has tried to leave no daylight between his policies and those of his predecessor, Robert E. Rubin.

title: 2 Marketers Select Agencies
description: Two big advertisers changed agencies yesterday.

title: A September Dress Rehearsal For the Year 2000 Computer Test
description: COMPUTER managers are dismissing once-widespread concerns that today -- the ninth day of of the ninth month of 1999 -- will provide a nasty preview of the kinds of disruptions expected from Year 2000 dates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUB, ROBERT CHARLES
description: STRUB-Robert Charles. 74, Bassett, Virginia died September 3. An electronics engineer with NBC in New York City; retired from ESPN; wife, Rita N. Strub.

title: Delta Air Lines dismisses Saatchi & Saatchi and hands its worldwide account to Leo Burnett.
description: ANOTHER giant airline is changing agencies. If only the planes would move as fast as the accounts do.

title: A Dome Where the Seats Move
description: Spectators in sports stadiums have seen plenty of roofs move. But the astounding Saitama Dome, north of Tokyo, will have an entire section of 10,000 seats, plus accompanying plumbing, lighting, concessions and ceiling sections, that moves on trucklike devices called ''bogeys.'' As a result, the dome can seat 30,000 (bottom picture) as a stadium, or 20,000 as an arena or even come down to 5,000 seats. The hybrid structure was designed by Dan Meis of NBBJ Sports and Entertainment, a Los Angeles sports design company that did the Staples Center Arena (opening in Los Angeles next month), in association with Ellerbe Becket and Nikken Sekkei Architects. The Saitama Dome, estimated to cost $750 million, will offer baseball, hockey, soccer, football, concerts, museums, shopping and restaurants. Mr. Meis beat out Rem Koolhaas, Richard Rogers, Kevin Roche and Arata Isozaki in a competition to design the dome. The building's stainless steel roof is intended to look as if it were racing along with the neighboring bullet train. Mitsubishi Heavy Industry is doing the engineering. The Saitama Dome is to open next spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLENBORG, JANET
description: HALLENBORG-Janet, 62, of New York City, died August 21, 1999 after a ten month battle with appendicile cancer. She attended Bennington College and graduated New York University with a B.S. in Art Education. A jewelry designer, flamenco dancer and world traveler, she leaves a mother in Hawaii, numerous devoted friends, her colleagues on 47th St., and her beloved Yorkie, whose care goes to her longtime friend and companion, David. She will always be remembered for her infectious spirit. There will be a memorial gathering in late November. Donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19th St., N.Y., NY 10003.

title: Officials Urge M.T.A. to Build Full Second Ave. Subway Line
description: Calling on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to show the vision and foresight they said were needed to protect the city's future, elected officials urged the agency yesterday to seek enough funds to pay for a Second Avenue subway line running the length of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUKENFELD, M. RONALD
description: BRUKENFELD-M. Ronald. Died peacefully the evening of September 7 at the age of 86. He was the beloved son of the late Morris and Sarah Brukenfeld and brother of the late Carl Brukenfeld, Frances Englander and Edith Hirsch. He spent his working life in the investment community, a Member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1935 to 1980 and was a former Governor of the NYSE. He continued to pursue his interest in the world of investments, going to the office past the age of 84, until the onset of his long illness. Throughout many years of his life, he had a great interest in Mt. Sinai Hospital and was a Trustee since 1961. Though diverted from his original plan to teach English literature, which he did at Columbia, he maintained throughout his life an avid interest in the written word, in books, the theatre and sports. He is survived by his longtime loving companion, Annette Edwards. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Chester Hirsch. He was the cherished uncle of Edward and DiAnne Hirsch, John and Elizabeth Hirsch, Richard Hirsch, Dick and Mimi Brukenfeld, Jane Holzer, Betty Jane and Alan Goldboro, and was the adoring great uncle of Douglas, Karen, Elisa, Nancy, Catherine, Mark, Bruce, Carla and Rustin. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's at 81 Street and Madison Avenue on Monday, September 13 at 11:30AM. Interment to follow At Union Field Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Mt. Sinai and/or Columbia College, Carl M. Brukenfeld Memorial Scholarships Fund. He will be greatly missed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLESPIE, RUTH REED
description: GILLESPIE-Ruth Reed, 86. Died on Sunday, September 5 at her home in NYC. Former head librarian at Collegiate School and Alumni President and Trustee of the Chapin School, survived by her daughter, Jane Brown Grimes of New York and Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania and her son, Samuel H. Gillespie, III of Washington, D.C., as well as seven grandchildren and her three sisters, Julia Reed Palmer of New York, Mary Reed Shepard of St. Paul, Minn. and Joan Reed Hudson of Southwest Harbor, Me. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Collegiate School library, 370 West End Avenue, NY, NY 10024. Services Friday September 10, 1999 at 10 A.M. at The Church Of The Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street.

title: Auto Workers Choose Ford For Canada Contract Talks
description: The Ford Motor Company will be the pattern-setting company in labor negotiations with the Canadian Auto Workers Union, the union announced today.

title: Amex Selects A New Chief
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. yesterday named Salvatore F. Sodano chairman and chief executive of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Where the Help Desk Goes for Good Advice
description: IN today's computer-driven culture, the once-derogatory term ''geek'' has been proudly reclaimed. Sure, you probably made fun of those guys on the audio-visual squad in high school. But when you can't get that printer to show up on the network and the deadline for your presentation is approaching fast, who are you going to call? The office computer geek, of course, the one who can mind-meld with the hardware, coax the software into working and make it all look easy. Let's hope for your sake that he or she (because they're not just guys anymore) doesn't know about those lunchroom nerd jokes you made.

title: Bush Criticized For Statements On Immigration
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas drew criticism today for recent remarks suggesting he did not believe that the Federal Government was obligated to reimburse states for providing services to illegal immigrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DAVID (DUVI)
description: COOPER-David (Duvi). Our sincerest condolence and love to the Cooper, Miller and Zepnick families. We loved Duvi dearly and we will miss his friendship. Beverly, Allen and Kenny Helfer

description: To the Editor:

title: One No. 2 Executive May Be No. 1 Elsewhere
description: With his vice president in demand, the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, is strongly considering promoting Mark Newman, a move that would naturally lead to a restructuring of the club's front office hierarchy.

title: Sony and Tivo Sign a Deal On Digital Video Recorder
description: The next generation of video recorders -- digital devices that save television programming on a hard drive instead of on a videocassette -- received a major lift yesterday when the Sony Corporation of America said it had agreed to manufacture one of three competing designs for the devices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KITTNER, KITTY
description: KITTNER-Kitty. 9/9/05-3/21/99. A pure spirit. A sad end. From those who loved her: Pauline, Pepi, Ruth, Alice, Charles, Eulene

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOERBER, WILLIAM C. JR.
description: KOERBER-William C. Jr. Beloved son of William C. Sr. & Genevieve (Jordan) Koerber, died unexpectedly of natural causes at his home in Lebanon, N.H. He was born in New York City on March 1, 1947. At the time of his death, he was employed at DartmouthHitchcock Hospital in Lebanon, N.H. He is survived by his parents of Burlington, VT.; two nephews, Robert C. & John M. Bamberger; and other family members. He was predeceased by a sister, Joan Bamberger. While residing in New York City, he had studied and been employed at the School of Social Work at Columbia University. Funeral services were held with family members in attendance on September 8, 1999. Burial was at Lake View Cemetery in Burlington, Vermont.

title: In America; Making Kids Safer
description: When kids pull out their guns at school and open fire on classmates and teachers, it tends to get our attention. Which is why school safety has trumped academic quality as the top concern of parents whose children are returning to school this month.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; HYUNDAI CHAIRMAN FACES ARREST
description: The chairman of South Korea's top brokerage firm faced arrest on charges of rigging share prices of Hyundai Group's chip-making unit, prosecution officials said. Lee Ik Chi, chairman of the Hyundai Securities Company, was taken into the custody of prosecutors and his status was changed from a witness to a suspect, prosecutors said. Mr. Lee was questioned overnight on charges of collecting 210 billion won ($178 million) from several Hyundai affiliates to manipulate the share price of the Hyundai Electronics Company. The Hyundai Group has denied the allegations. Samuel Lee

title: Controlling Students' E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cycles of Opportunity; Mrs. Whitman Withdraws
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's decision not to run for the United States Senate stunned New Jersey politicians and disappointed those who had hoped that a successful Senate campaign would give this personable, middle-of-the-road Republican broader national exposure. Her decision does not necessarily end her career in politics. By not running for the Senate she leaves herself available should George W. Bush want her as his running mate or, if he wins, in his cabinet.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS. Corn fell amid signs that the crop suffered less damage than expected from a dry spell just before the harvest began in most states. In Chicago, corn for December delivery dropped 4.25 cents, to $2.21 a bushel.

title: A Left Click for Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley, Starting Campaign, Extols Small-Town Values
description: Returning to his hometown on the banks of the Mississippi River, former Senator Bill Bradley formally opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President today, pledging to fight racial strife, restore trust in government and spread the nation's prosperity to the most downtrodden Americans.

title: Infocure to Buy Datamedic
description: The Infocure Corporation, a maker of health care practice management software, said today that it had agreed to buy the closely held Datamedic Holding Corporation for about $25.4 million in stock to add its ophthalmologists and oncologists to its customer base. Infocure will pay about 1.2 million shares for Datamedic, which is based in Waltham, Mass., and provides practice-management and clinical-systems services for 10,000 United States doctors.

title: With Prices Up and Joblessness Down, British Raise Rates
description: Britain's central bank raised a key short-term money rate today, for the first time in more than a year, in a pre-emptive move against inflationary pressure.

title: INTERNATIONAL AID IN JEOPARDY
description: The World Bank yesterday warned Indonesia that failure to curb violence in East Timor could jeopardize $5.9 billion in international aid. The bank noted that continued foreign assistance depended on Indonesia fulfilling a promise in July to support the United Nations in the province, which voted in a referendum last month to break away from Indonesia. Concerns that aid might be curtailed and that the instability could sidetrack economic reform programs helped send Indonesia's benchmark stock index down more than 4.5 percent and its currency to its lowest rate since April. Wayne Arnold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAI, NARAYAN B., M.D.
description: PAI-Narayan B., M.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our distinguished associate professor of surgery, an exceptional clinician and teacher. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Pai family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D., Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

description: Laboratory testing has confirmed four more cases of St. Louis encephalitis, including two in eastern and central Queens and one in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, offering the first indication that the epidemic of the mosquito-borne virus may be spreading geographically, city health officials said yesterday.

title: Betting the Farm On the Virtual Store
description: FOR eight years, Fred Parks says, he sold all manner of antiques and collectibles, ''everything but tube socks and T-shirts,'' from a series of stores in downtown Baltimore. About a year ago, he closed his latest store, but he didn't go out of business. He took his expertise in ceramics -- Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Arts and Crafts styles -- to Ebay, the largest of the on-line auction sites.

title: CHARLES E. SMITH TO ADD MIAMI APARTMENT COMPLEX
description: Charles E. Smith Residential Realty Inc., an owner and developer of apartment complexes, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 1,339-unit high-rise apartment complex in Miami Beach for $85 million to expand in South Florida. Smith Residential, based in Arlington, Va., will pay for the purchase in stock and cash from the sale of convertible preferred stock and will assume debt. The purchase is expected to be completed in 45 days. Smith Residential owns about 22,000 apartment units with more than 4,000 under construction.

title: Cruising Through Toll Plazas With the Windows Rolled Up

title: And the Singers Started Singing . . .; Accommodating Cadences of Drama, 'View From the Bridge' Nears Completion
description: In the Civic Opera House here, where Lyric Opera of Chicago will present the world premiere of ''A View From the Bridge'' on Oct. 9, the singers gathered in a rehearsal room on Tuesday for the first time, singing through the score accompanied by two pianos. The composer, William Bolcom, was on hand to hear a young tenor he had never met, Gregory Turay, move the assembled company to applause with his rendering of a melodic aria. And the director, Frank Galati, delivered an impassioned lecture on the history of the Arthur Miller play on which the opera is based before winding up with a flourish: ''Let us give thanks for the privilege of working together on this first great opera of the 21st century.''

title: YELTSIN DISMISSES GRAFT ALLEGATION
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia told President Clinton in a telephone conversation today that accusations linking Mr. Yeltsin and his family to a corruption inquiry were politically inspired, the White House said this evening.

title: Ford Will Sponsor A Singer's Tour
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would expand efforts to interest younger consumers in its new Focus line, made by the Ford division, by becoming a sponsor of the fall concert tour of the singer Ricky Martin. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Ford joins a roster of sponsors for the popular entertainer's upcoming tour that includes Pepsi-Cola.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INFOCURE CORP., Atlanta, a maker of health-care practice management software, agreed to buy closely held Datamedic Holding Corp., Waltham, Mass., a provider of practice-management and clinical-systems services for 10,000 United States doctors, for about $25.4 million in stock.

title: Van Ryn to Be Invited
description: Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president and general manager, said late yesterday that Mike Van Ryn, one of the team's first-round draft choices in 1997, would be invited to training camp as soon as possible.

title: A Toy, Yes, But a PC At Heart
description: SEGA'S new Dreamcast video game console, which goes on sale in the United States today, is the first of the next-generation home game machines to arrive on these shores. As a game machine its power is unrivaled, except by high-end personal computers costing more than 10 times as much, and it makes the graphics on the current market leader, the Sony Playstation, appear grainy and jerky. The Dreamcast is the closest thing to an arcade-quality game experience you can get at home.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture by The Associated Press yesterday about the father of an imprisoned Puerto Rican terrorist referred incorrectly to his son, Carlos Alberto Torres. The son was not among those offered clemency by President Clinton and will serve the rest of his 70-year sentence.

title: Israel Prepares to Transfer Land and Begins Releasing Prisoners
description: Moving to carry out its latest agreement with the Palestinians, the Israeli Government has approved the transfer of more West Bank land to Palestinian rule and has begun the release of Palestinian prisoners.

title: Video Game Deal
description: Electronic Arts Inc., a leading video game publisher, said today that it had agreed to acquire the on-line game maker Playnation Inc. for an undisclosed price to bolster its Internet game development efforts. Playnation, based in Carlsbad, Calif., has developed software that allows spectators to watch on-line golf matches.

title: HEINEKEN POSTS HIGHER PROFIT
description: Heineken N.V., the world's second-largest brewer, said its first-half profit rose 11 percent and should grow at least as fast for the full year as a marketing drive brings gains in the United States. Net income rose to 210 million euros ($223 million), or 0.67 euro a share, from 190 million euros, or 0.60 euro a share, in the year-earlier period. The brewer, second in size to Anheuser-Busch, which is based in St. Louis, expects full-year profit to grow ''well above'' 10 percent, helped by growth in Europe and a continuing increase in exports. Sales in the United States rose 15 percent.

title: Earnings at Heinz Down 3% in Quarter

title: CONCENTRIC NETWORK TO BUY BRITISH INTERNET PROVIDER
description: The Concentric Network Corporation, a provider of Internet services to businesses, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Internet Technology Group P.L.C. for $:146 million ($235 million) to enter the European Internet-access market. Concentric, based in San Jose, Calif., will pay 253 pence for each Internet Technology share in cash and new Concentric shares. Concentric, of which the Microsoft Corporation owns about 4 percent, is buying Internet Technology for its Internet protocol network, the most extensive of any independent British Internet provider. Spending on Internet access in Europe is expected to balloon to $12 billion in 2001 from $2.5 billion last year. Concentric provides Internet services that allow businesses to communicate with their offices, customers and suppliers.

title: Bulbs Will Brighten New Year's Glitter

title: PINNACLE HOLDINGS TO BUY COMMUNICATION TOWERS
description: Pinnacle Holdings Inc., which rents space on communication towers in the Southeast to telecommunications companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 552 towers and other sites for $50 million to continue its consolidation plan. Pinnacle, based in Sarasota, Fla., will buy the 136 owned towers and 416 managed towers and rooftop sites in 20 separate transactions. Buying towers in clusters allows Pinnacle to attract wireless carriers looking to expand their coverage in certain geographic areas, analysts have said. Pinnacle, which went public in February, will own or manage more than 3,600 sites after its pending purchases are completed.

title: EOTT ENERGY ENTERS TALKS WITH UNNAMED COMPANY

The oil company, based in Houston, signed an agreement that will give it access to confidential business information, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Investors commonly perform such reviews to prepare a bid for a target company or its assets. The company also said it might buy contracts. EOTT sells crude oil in the United States and Canada.

title: ESKIMO PIE SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE LIQUIDATION
description: The Eskimo Pie Corporation will sell its licenses and plants under a liquidation plan from its largest shareholder and suitor Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc., the Yogen Fruz chief executive, Michael Serruya, said yesterday. The plan was adopted at Eskimo Pie's annual shareholder meeting, Mr. Serruya said. Yogen Fruz, which owns 17 percent of Eskimo Pie, had sought to oust Eskimo Pie's board and install one friendly to its idea to break up the company and sell the pieces. title: BRAZIL'S INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT FALLS
description: Brazil's Industrial production declined unexpectedly in July, fueling concern that an already anemic economic recovery is losing steam. Output fell six-tenths of 1 percent from June and 5.3 percent compared with July of last year as high interest rates squeezed financing and reduced demand. Concerned that a fast drop in rates could lead to a weaker currency and higher inflation, the central bank has shown little willingness to bow to industrialist pressure to lower its benchmark rate, which is now 19.5 percent. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUSSELL, RAY E., M.D.
description: TRUSSELL-Ray E., M.D., MPH. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with great sadness the death of our highly esteemed friend and colleague, Dr. Ray Trussell, General Director of Beth Israel from 1968 to 1978, and General Director Emeritus and honorary member of the Board of Trustees thereafter. Dr. Trussell was a guiding force of Beth Israel during a critical period in its history, and was instrumental in the institution's evolution into a very highly respected academic medical center. His steadfast dedication to serving the diverse healthcare needs of all segments of the community led to the growth of many clinical programs at Beth Israel. A physician-epidemiologist by training, Dr. Trussell spent his career in service to the public. He served as Commissioner of Hospitals of the City of New York and Executive Director of the School of Public Health of Columbia University in the 1950's and 1960's. This great man leaves a tremendous legacy. His commitment and his contributions to our medical center will never be forgotten. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Dr. Trussell's wife, Beth Davis Trussell, M.D., his family and their loved ones. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Continuum Health Partners and Beth Israel Robert G. Newman, M.D., President and CEO, Continuum Health Partners Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO, Beth Israel Henry Singman, M.D., President, Medical Board Robert Salant, M.D., President, Doctors' Alumni Association

title: Hedge-Fund Withdrawal
description: The rescuers of Long-Term Capital Management L.P. said today that they were taking $800 million out of the hedge fund and had recovered half of their $3.6 billion bailout. The 14 banks, including Goldman Sachs Group and Merrill Lynch & Company, must redeem 90 percent of their money before the fund's founder, John W. Meriwether, and his partners can collect cash for a new fund. Long-Term Capital lost $4 billion during last year's rout in global financial markets, prompting the takeover. Since the bailout, the fund has gained about 14 percent, after management fees, according to a person familiar with the fund's performance, but is up less than 5 percent so far this year.

title: Jan Gorbaty, 84, Polish Pianist Known for Chopin Performances
description: Jan Gorbaty, a stylish, white-maned Polish pianist with a patriot's zeal for the music of Chopin who founded the New York chapter of the National Chopin Foundation, died on Monday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 84.

title: 3 Drug Makers Agree to Settle U.S. Charges
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that three Japanese pharmaceutical companies had agreed to plead guilty to United States antitrust violations and to pay more than $137 million to settle charges that they took part in a worldwide conspiracy to fix prices in the vitamin market.

title: New York Wins Transit Battle in Senate
description: The United States Senate effectively quashed an attempt to cut New York's Federal transportation subsidy yesterday, deflecting a potentially fatal blow to major city projects like a Second Avenue subway line and an East River tunnel linking the Long Island Rail Road and Grand Central Terminal.

title: Religion Leaders Call Housing a Sacred Right
description: An unusually broad group of religious leaders -- Roman Catholics, Protestants, Jews, Buddhists and Muslims -- has signed a letter to President Clinton, declaring that access to housing is a ''sacred right'' and asking the Government to take specific measures to help the poor obtain permanent shelter.

title: Tiny Treasures Stolen, Shells and All, at Zoo
description: Soon after the police first got the call yesterday that two extremely rare, extremely small tortoises had been stolen from the Bronx Zoo, the hypotheses began. Were they taken so they could be ground up and used as aphrodisiacs? Or as ingredients in some exquisite soup? More than one police official even suggested that a vengeful hare might be suspect.

title: Heights Filled With Grand Visions
description: There is a kind of isolation, almost a loneliness, about the northern reaches of Morningside Heights, even on a beautiful sunny day. Morningside Heights is a place dominated by grand institutions -- Columbia University; the Cathedral of St. John the Divine; the Union and Jewish Theological seminaries; Riverside Church. They sit upon the Heights overlooking the city, a Periclean vision glittering in the sun, both a part of the city and separate from it.

title: 51% Lang Stake Is Sold to Prada
description: Helmut Lang, the Austrian fashion designer who moved his business to New York two years ago, has sold 51 percent of his company to Prada of Milan. Although the sale was reported in March, neither Mr. Lang nor Patrizio Bertelli, Prada's chief executive, disclosed details until this week.

description: In a report to Congress that was prompted by public concern over advertising's role in under-age drinking, the Federal Trade Commission has recommended tightening the standards aimed at preventing beer, wine and liquor companies from marketing to people younger than 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ELLIOT BERNARD
description: SCHNEIDER-Elliot Bernard, 74, of Little Silver, N.J., died September 8 at home. He was an economist and a nationally recognized expert on government-sponsored securities, such as Fannie Mae. He was Director of Perspective Research and a senior vice president at Gruntal & Co., Inc., New York City. He was a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts, and was a Chartered Financial Analyst and member of the Association for Investment Management and Research. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Freda Rosenberg Schneider; by two sons and daughters-in-law, Adam and Pat Schneider of Long Branch, N.J., and Daniel and Linda Schneider of Irvington, N.Y.; by one daughter and son-in-law, Rebecca and Stuart Meiklejohn of Manhattan, N.Y.; by five grandchildren, David and Sarah Meiklejohn, Amy and Emily Schneider, and Isabelle Schneider; by a brother, Irwin Schneider of Chicago; and by a sister, Sophie Ruderman of Lakehurst, N.J. Donations in his memory may be made to Long Branch Habitat for Humanity, PO Box 3306, Long Branch, NJ 07740. For more information contact the Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapel, 2130 Highway 35, Ocean, N.J.

title: U.S. Report Details World's Religious Persecution
description: While the number of freely elected governments continues to grow throughout the world, there are still many countries in which people face harassment, imprisonment or even death for practicing their religions, a State Department report said today.

title: G.O.P. Tries to Fit Together Pieces of Spending Package
description: Congress spent today struggling over spending bills that President Clinton has pledged to veto, as Republicans searched for a strategy and the Administration assaulted their political priorities.

title: Helping East Timor, and Indonesia
description: Time is running out for Indonesia to disarm and disband the army-backed militias that have rampaged through East Timor for the past week, killing hundreds of people and sending thousands into hiding and exile. The violence subsided somewhat yesterday. But unless Jakarta can bring these militias to heel in the next few days, which is unlikely, an international peacekeeping force will be needed to save lives and make sure that the results of last week's referendum approving independence for the province is respected.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN INFLATION
description: Mexico reported yesterday that inflation in August, at 0.56 percent, was the lowest in five years. Prices were lower for consumers largely because the peso has remained stable against the dollar, officials said, but also because of falling prices for some agricultural products and sluggish consumer spending. Meanwhile, July's trade deficit of $185 million was the country's lowest in 21 months, mainly a result of rising income from oil exports. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: A Search for Truth About Waco
description: The naming of former Senator John Danforth to conduct an independent inquiry into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's disastrous 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., is a promising development. The need for such an inquiry has been obvious from the moment the F.B.I. acknowledged, after six years of firm denials by the agency and Attorney General Janet Reno, that it had used incendiary tear-gas canisters during the siege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MOSES H.
description: COHEN-Moses H. 82. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Joseph (Sally) and Ellen (Ken). Grandfather of Abraham, Isaac and Abigail. title: Martin and Pioline Are Surprising Semifinalists
description: It's not quite true that seventh-seeded Todd Martin, the United States Open's medical miracle man, has used an intravenous bag for a pillow since his feverish comeback from dehydration -- and a two-sets-to-none deficit against Greg Rusedski -- in the Round of 16. But Martin, who claimed he felt ''like a ton of bricks'' when he hoisted himself out of bed yesterday, soldiered into his second career Open semifinal last night thanks to a 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, 6-4 victory against a man with a hardcourts phobia, 95th-ranked Slava Dosedel of the Czech Republic.

title: More Smuggling Arrests at Miami Airport
description: Undercover agents working to bring down a widespread drug-smuggling operation at Miami International Airport thought that the arrests last month of more than 40 baggage handlers and food service workers on drug charges might force other suspects at the airport to be more cautious.

title: Spraying Expands in New York Encephalitis Fight
description: New York City vastly expanded its week-old air raid on mosquitoes yesterday with pesticide spraying scheduled over the next three days for all of Brooklyn and Queens and much of the Bronx, as the number of suspected cases of the potentially deadly St. Louis encephalitis grew to 60, including, for the first time, 3 residents of Manhattan.

title: Noirish, Stylish and a War of Nerves
description: Two old friends, Nick (Alessandro Nivola) and Bryce (Josh Brolin), are in a bar when a highly available-looking single woman named Kathy (Reese Witherspoon) catches their eye. Fade out, mysteriously, on the back of her head. Then it is hours later and Bryce is frantically summoning Nick to the house where he and the woman have had a sexual encounter that went very wrong. As proof of that, she is now gagged and handcuffed to the base of a pool table. She's upset. But maybe Nick is more so. Kathy was Lissa, Nick's devoted girlfriend, before this whole thing got started.

title: Indian Courts World's Riches and Poor's Vote

Moments later, as she and her invaluable accompanist and vocal partner, Richard Rodney Bennett, sail into ''Crazy Rhythm,'' a frantically upbeat Charleston by Joseph Meyer, Roger Wolfe Kahn and Irving Caesar, from the 1928 show ''Here's How,'' the essence of what we call the Roaring 20's is revealed to have been a beat.

title: ASIANA AIRLINE STOCK PLAN
description: Asiana Airline, South Korea's No. 2 carrier, said it might sell stock for the first time, a move that analysts said could raise an estimated $216 million to expand its fleet. Asiana, based in Seoul, plans to list its shares on the main board of the Korea Stock Exchange, Asia's fifth-largest stock market, by the end of this year. A share sale would raise Asiana's profile and give it a better chance of joining a global alliance as airlines seek partnerships to cut costs.

title: Jobs Named to Gap Board
description: Gap Inc. said today that it had appointed Steven P. Jobs to the 12-member board of the clothing chain. Mr. Jobs, 44, co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., currently serves as Apple's interim chief executive and is chief executive of Pixar Inc., the animation studio that created ''Toy Story'' and ''A Bug's Life.'' Gap, based in San Francisco, sells clothing, accessories and personal-care products through its Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy stores. title: Pluma to Close 4 Plants
description: Pluma Inc., a maker of fleece and jersey clothing under bankruptcy protection since May, said it would shut four plants and dismiss 950 employees as it closes down after failing to find investors. The company, based here, will shut two plants in Eden next week and lay off about 500 workers. In the next six to eight weeks, plants in Martinsville and Vesta, Va., will close with the loss of 450 jobs. Pluma's assets are about $107 million and it has about $118.9 million in debt, said the company's president and chief executive, John Wigodsky. Pluma filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors after slumping sales, the loss of a large customer and poorly performing acquisitions led to mounting losses.

He said he hopes to be ready for the season opener on Nov. 2, but avoided making predictions.

title: Too Sweet on Sugar

It also contributes to rising obesity rates.

description: Catfish Hunter, the Hall of Fame right-hander who helped pitch the Oakland A's and the Yankees to six pennants in the 1970's, hurled a perfect game and was part of an economic revolution in sports, died yesterday at his home at Hertford, N.C. He was 53.

title: An Era's Haut Monde Fashion, Just as Ingres Reported
description: Not only did the French painter Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres (1780-1867) turn out masterly portraits, he was also a gifted fashion reporter. No detail of with-it couture escaped his eye, from the viewer-friendly decolletage of the loud-patterned silk evening gown worn by Madame Moitessier, who posed for him in 1856, to the blue satin bows and marabou feathers that enhanced the coiffure of the Princesse de Broglie (painted in 1853). To gowns, suits, jewelry, caps, shawls, swords and shoes he brought the same sharp focus as the fashionable faces and bodies he painted.

title: The Full Second Avenue Subway
description: New York City began construction of its subway system 100 years ago, a fact that should not surprise any veteran customer, especially those using the old Lexington Avenue line along Manhattan's East Side. The oddly designated green line is too often excessively dirty, noisy and hot. Its cars are groaning with so many passengers that City Councilman A. Gifford Miller complained this week at a press conference before a City Council committee hearing that ''if the subway represents the arteries of our city, the Lexington Avenue line is about to cause us cardiac arrest.''

description: EUROPE

title: Dent Remembers Teammate
description: Bucky Dent, a Texas Rangers coach, was watching videotapes yesterday at the Ballpark in Arlington when Manager Johnny Oates entered the room with a somber look on his face. Oates asked Dent if he had heard about Catfish Hunter, and Dent lowered his head. He knew that meant that Hunter, his former Yankees teammate, had died.

title: Album of the Week
description: DOT ALLISON: ''Afterglow'' (Arista). Dot Allison's songs dream of escape. ''Close your eyes,'' she sings, ''let me take you to the sun.'' In a breathy, hovering voice, she seeks realms where time stands still: love, longing, heaven. The music wafts around her, full of wispy chords and muffled echoes and distant effects. Sometimes there's a stolid beat; sometimes there are no drums anywhere, only sustained sounds with disorienting electronic edges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUFF, ROBERT V.
description: HAUFF-Robert V. On September 8, 1999. Lifelong partner of the late John F. Dreeland. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Service Monday 10:30AM.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article yesterday about John C. Danforth, the former Missouri Senator who is to lead the independent investigation of the fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., misspelled his middle name and misstated his birth date. The name is Claggett, not Clagett; the date was Sept. 5, 1936, not Dec. 5.

title: State Street to Acquire Wachovia Units
description: The State Street Corporation, a leading custodian of investor assets, is buying the Wachovia Corporation's institutional trust and custody units for an undisclosed price to expand in the Southeast.

title: Beyond Malls and Toll Roads, the Pine Barrens' Peace
description: We were paddling an aluminum canoe under a canopy of trees on a narrow river that wound through cedar-smelling woods and swamps. The banks were mossy and dark. It could have been the Bayou or parts of the Everglades. But this unbroken forest, one of the largest on the East Coast, was within an hour of Philadelphia and two hours of New York City, in the New Jersey Pine Barrens. This was not what we think of when we think of the nation's most densely populated state, the New Jersey of suburban malls, office parks and 12-lane toll roads.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; The '49 Car That Saved Ford Motor
description: THE Ford Motor Company has been on a roll -- toting up record sales and profits, assembling a stable of foreign subsidiaries including Volvo and Jaguar, taking a lead in cutting pollution from light trucks, forging into uncharted waters with a strategy to offer an array of consumer services of which cars will be just a part. Only students of history or those with long memories will recall how this dynamic company has sometimes teetered on the precipice -- most notably just after World War II.

title: Memory Reignsx In Multiple Images
description: The annual artist-in-residence program at the Studio Museum in Harlem began just over 30 years ago and has been the springboard for a passel of distinguished careers, some now established, others still developing. David Hammons, Kerry James Marshall, Alison Saar, Leonardo Drew, Nari Ward and Chakaia Booker have all benefited from the program's gift of a year's worth of work space and collegial company, culminating in a museum show.

title: New Chinese Missiles Seen as Threat to U.S.
description: An intelligence report issued today predicted that within 15 years, China will be aiming missiles at the United States that will be fitted with small nuclear warheads developed with the help of espionage.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For some reason, the arts and fine dining don't seem to mix. The theater district has long been a byword for bad food in New York, and the Lincoln Center area has only recently begun to show signs of culinary life, with gems like Picholine getting a little company. Sapphire, a newcomer in the Lincoln Center neighborhood, may not be the last word in Indian cuisine, but it is good enough and good-looking enough to advance the cause.

title: U.N. Gives Indonesia a Troop Reprieve
description: Indonesia got at least another day's reprieve today as the Secretary General and the Security Council relaxed an informal deadline for action on troops after receiving reports that the situation in East Timor had begun to improve slightly.

title: For Denver Teachers, a Pay-for-Performance Plan
description: The school teachers' union in Denver is expected on Friday to approve a plan that for the first time anywhere in the country would link teachers' raises to the performance of the students in their individual classrooms. The proposed two-year pilot program here is part of a growing national trend to give teachers a financial stake in the academic performance of their students.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 21 about the fatal stabbing of a worker at the Hotel Carter in Manhattan misstated the reason for the hotel's temporary closing last December. It was ordered closed because an emergency fire exit was damaged, not because inspectors had found 200 violations. The error was pointed out in a reader's letter dated Aug. 24 and delayed through misrouting at The Times.

title: Schools Open To Face Maze Of Problems
description: With challenges posed by limited classroom space, looming high-stakes exams and the sudden threat of disease-carrying mosquitoes, more than a million New York City children began a new school year yesterday freighted with promise and anxiety.

description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a return to profitability after five quarters of losses. Excluding a one-time gain from a stock sale, National reported a modest profit. Analysts had expected another loss.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL IN $3.4 BILLION DEAL FOR PREMARK
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc., which makes construction fasteners and packaging systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Premark International Inc. for $3.4 billion in stock, adding kitchen equipment and building products to its diverse lineup of 400 businesses. Illinois Tool, based in Glenview, Ill., said it would pay the equivalent of $55 worth of its stock for each share of Premark. That is a premium of 60 percent above Premark's closing price of $34.25 yesterday and is Illinois Tool's largest acquisition. Premark is the latest in a string of acquisitions by W. James Farrell, the chairman of Illinois Tool Works, whose strategy is to buy companies, shed their weakest products and push for higher profits.

title: Public Interests; Traffic-Light Chic
description: One of the most frequently mentioned factoids in Bill Bradley's Presidential campaign is that when he was growing up, his hometown had only one stoplight. This is an excellent example of a modern American political phenomenon. Sooner or later, almost every candidate feels the need to demonstrate that he hails from someplace really, really obscure.

description: March Madness is about buzzer beaters, upsets by Princeton, Fab Fives -- and gobs of cash. With CBS Sports in control of televising the men's Division I basketball tournament, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has benefited mightily from the network's generosity.

description: New York State health officials warned yesterday that people who attended a second upstate fair last week might have been exposed to the same batch of E. coli bacteria that has already sickened nearly 500 people who were at a previous fair.

title: A Killer Who Has Poison in His Pickup
description: Imagine an overgrown John Boy Walton as a homicidal maniac and you'll begin to get a picture of Vann Siegert (Owen Wilson), the blond, affable drifter who is the central character in Hampton Fancher's quietly creepy film, ''The Minus Man.'' This small, moody portrait of a serial killer as the boy next door follows Vann in his blue pickup truck to an unidentified Pacific Coast town where he interacts with several unhappy souls who find in his blank, pleasant face and good manners a vision of their own lost innocence.

The West Indian American Day Carnival Association, which organizes the event, hired the truck and its driver to carry sound equipment, and the van was carrying costumes for group members, but the organization does not own either vehicle.

title: India Torn Apart, as a Child Sees It
description: Deepa Mehta's sorrowful film ''Earth,'' the second in a projected trilogy of fire, earth and water, is bathed in a deep golden light that at moments recalls the orange sky silhouetting the sweaty faces of Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable in ''Gone With the Wind'' during the burning of Atlanta. This amber glow gives the film, which remembers the tragic events surrounding the partition of India in 1947, a ruddy twilit sensuality along with a sense of nocturnal foreboding.

title: With a Party Trick, Supernatural Forces Enter Into an Ordinary Man's Life
description: ''Don't be afraid of it, Daddy,'' counsels wise little Jake (Zachary David Cope), yet another boy who can see dead people, in ''Stir of Echoes.'' You don't have to be psychic to know how hot movies about the occult will be in the wake of ''The Sixth Sense.'' With its soon to be way-too-relevant theme (the Baby Boom generation peeks into the next world) and child star with three names (uncannily good Haley Joel Osment), that film is sure to uncork a bottleful of copycats, but it's awfully soon to find one on screen. Fortunately, ''Stir of Echoes'' isn't entirely about Jake's extrasensory aptitudes.

Mr. Lee is accused of using 210 billion won ($178 million) from several Hyundai affiliates to manipulate the price of Hyundai Electronics shares.

title: Clerics and the Possessed (Hold the Spinning Heads)
description: Just in time for Armageddon, Y2K or the cataclysm of your choice comes ''Stigmata,'' a silly, roiling melange of special effects and overheated religious symbolism that at first seems to be about the Second Coming but turns out to be a half-baked anticlerical screed involving Vatican politics. Although the trailer for the movie presents ''Stigmata'' as a kind of ''Son of the Exorcist,'' its glimpses of hell have none of the force or ingenuity of its deeply scary forerunner. Instead of spewed pea soup, spinning heads and the harsh voices of the possessed growling obscenities, ''Stigmata'' gives us lots of broken glass, bird feathers, dripping blood and desperately fancy camera angles.

description: At least 32 people died in a deafening explosion that leveled much of a nine-story apartment building here minutes after midnight this morning, and the Mayor said there was a ''high degree of confidence'' that terrorists staged the blast.

Now they are faced with 10 consecutive days of meaningful games that will not very likely determine whether New York makes the playoffs -- the Yankees would have to crumble like feta cheese to miss out -- but will serve as their last serious test before the playoffs.

Certainly, the work of this idiosyncratic British neoclassical architect has had a broad impact on design professionals. But it has rarely shown up on popular radar screens like coffee-table books or shelter magazines.

title: Disappearing Ink
description: Hearing that a new Internet company is now posting free notes for core courses at 62 universities threw me back to a time in the 1980's when I was teaching a large class in a lecture hall at the University of California at Berkeley. The student government had approved a note-taking service called, for some arcane reason, Black Lightning. With the professor's approval, a graduate student would attend lectures, take notes and type them up, whereupon Black Lightning would duplicate the notes and offer them to students for a nominal fee (and to the professor for free).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITTMAN, KENNIETH
description: PITTMAN-Kennieth ''Ken,'' one of Manhattanville College's most beloved professors, died on September 8 at the Westchester Medical Center. He was 53 years old. Professor Pittman was an authority on social and political conditions in Mexico and Latin America, and he was widely published and often quoted on related subjects. As a professor of political science at Manhattanville since 1981, he was extremely dedicated to his students, sharing with them his personal experiences and perspectives developed over decades of living, visiting and working in Mexico, particularly in and around the village of Amacuzak. He opened students' eyes to the lives of villages of rural Mexico, so they could pursue their own research and their own opinions. In 1997, Professor Pittman earned the College's Distinguished Faculty Award. In 1998, he co-founded the Connie Hogarth Center for Social Action, which is located at Manhattanville, and he was instrumental in the creation of a Latin American Studies minor at the College. He also served as the faculty advisor to the Latin American Students Organization. Professor Pittman earned a BA from Duke University, an MA from North Carolina State University, an MA, MPhil and PhD from Yale University. He held a postdoctoral fellowship at Yale University, conducted research at El Colegio de Mexico, and held visiting associate professorships at North Carolina State University, Iona College and Purchase College (SUNY). Professor Pittman is survived by his wife, Carolina; daughter, Kenia; sister, Beth Johnson; and brother, James. A memorial service will be held at 7:00 PM on Saturday, September 11 in the O'Byrne Chapel at Manhattanville College, after visitation from 4:00 to 6:00 PM. His funeral and burial will take place in Mexico. Manhattanville College has established a Kennieth Pittman Memorial Fund.
