description: Apparently weary of the tugs of war inherent in his job, Ervin S. Duggan resigned yesterday as president of the Public Broadcasting Service, saying that after raising revenue and achieving other major goals he wanted to tackle new challenges.

title: The Indian Touch
description: India, of course, dominates South Asia, and its cuisine is a major influence on its neighbors. Here are restaurants with direct links to the Subcontinent. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: Quake Deaths In Greece Rise to 83; 1,600 Hurt
description: As much of Greece watched live television coverage of rescue efforts, the Government announced that the toll from the earthquake on Tuesday had reached 83 dead.

title: News From Pepperland: 'Submarine' Resurfaces
description: Sometimes the dippiest notions have the greatest potential. ''Yellow Submarine,'' the animated Beatles film that has just been thoroughly refurbished for its video release and is having a limited theater run beginning this week, started life as a vague idea for a song that occurred to Paul McCartney as he was falling asleep one night in 1966. In the light of day, Mr. McCartney decided that his song -- something about everyone living in a yellow submarine -- would make a cheerful children's tune that Ringo Starr could sing on ''Revolver,'' the album the group was then recording.

title: Sykora Won't Explain Why He Showed Up Late
description: Petr Sykora, the leading scorer for the Devils last season, refused to budge under the barrage of questions surrounding his holdout. No matter how many ways he was asked today why he reported to the Devils' training camp five days late, Sykora refused to answer. So did Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager, who had met privately with Sykora.

title: Jokinen in Doghouse
description: Less than a week after landing in New York, Olli Jokinen has already found a new home -- in the coach's doghouse.

title: 6 Decades of an Unconventional Legal Life
description: LAST week, a Buffalo man on whose behalf Eleanor Jackson Piel had pestered the courts for 10 years was released from prison, after DNA tests proved he wasn't a rapist. Later this month, she is going to Mississippi for a death row inmate. The date coincides with her 79th birthday.

title: When Depression Isn't as It Seems
description: To the Editor:

title: 14 Minority Officers Sue Police Force, Alleging Bias in Disciplinary Practices
description: A group of city police officers filed a lawsuit against the New York Police Department yesterday, charging that black and Hispanic officers are more harshly disciplined than white officers and asking that a Federal judge order sweeping changes in the way the department polices itself.

title: Tests and Fallacies
description: To the Editor:

title: Fever, Dash to Hospital and Long Wait
description: It took about three seconds for Bibi Sanaria to transform from a sleepy haze into a hysterical bolt for the stairs. Her son, who had wandered into her bedroom feverish and in pain at 2 A.M. yesterday, had just pointed offhandedly to a red and swollen mosquito bite on his leg.

title: MacManus Acquires Interactive Agency
description: MacManus Group in New York has acquired a majority stake in Novo Interactive in San Francisco, an interactive agency, and merged it with Blue Marble ACG in New York, an interactive agency that MacManus owns. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONGIONI, ELEANOR M.
description: ONGIONI-Eleanor M., 82 years of age, September 9, 1999 in the 60th year of beloved marriage to Edward. Loving mother of Adrienne, Diane, Marie and Regina and mother-in-law of Daniel Lamont and David. Devoted grandmother of Nora, Regina, Beth, Paul, Christopher, Mark and great-grandmother of Samuel, Eleanor and Maria. Mass Monday, 10AM at St. Saviour RC Church. Reposing at Joseph G. Duffy, Inc. 255 9th St., Brooklyn. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Burial Monday at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: G.O.P. Scrambles for a Whitman Substitute Voters Know
description: Struggling to regroup after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's sudden decision not to run for Senate, Republicans today surveyed a field of a half-dozen or more prospective candidates -- almost none of them known to the average New Jersey voter.

title: LTV AGREES TO PAY $650 MILLION FOR 2 IMETAL BUSINESSES
description: The LTV Corporation, a leading steelmaker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two units of France's Imetal S.A. for $650 million in cash. LTV, based in Cleveland, is buying Imetal's Copperweld Corporation and Copperweld Canada Inc. The companies make tubes for automobiles and farm equipment and are the largest makers of copper-clad steel and aluminum wire, rod and strand for the utility and telecommunications industries. They had combined sales last year of $711 million and have 13 plants in the United States, Canada and Britain. LTV is expanding its steel-tubing business to reduce its dependence on raw steel as cheap imports have driven prices to 10-year lows.

title: Danforth Says He'll 'Answer the Dark Questions' on Waco
description: John C. Danforth, named today to be the Government's special counsel investigating the fiery death of some 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult, as well as the aftermath, said his job would be ''to answer the dark questions.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel deares

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: ABC Raises Blinds And Says, 'Oops!'

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic to Seek Long Distance O.K.
description: Bell Atlantic Corporation will file its application with Federal regulators in a few days seeking permission to offer long distance service to customers in New York, Ivan Seidenberg, the chief executive, said yesterday.

title: The No. 2 Priority
description: Just about every day, the intimation is there. If the Rangers can find a second-line center, Coach John Muckler hints again and again, the team will pretty much be complete.

title: National News Briefs; 4 Governors Will Seek Funds for Waste Cleanup
description: The Energy Secretary, trying to convert traditional adversaries on environmental problems into allies, will meet with four Governors on Friday to ask for help persuading House Republicans to appropriate more money for radioactive waste cleanup and to stop trying to block waste shipments.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Cancer Group In Controversy On Stem Cells
description: The American Cancer Society is caught between a cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church and a Nobel laureate over the society's position on human embryonic stem cell research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, JOHN JAMES
description: DUFFY-John James. Died on September 8 on his 77th birthday. Devoted husband of Margery (Watkinson) Duffy. Devoted father of Patrick, Mary, Kathleen, Sean, John-Patrick, Joann Salomons and Eileen Bengyak. Also survived by sisters, Helen Robinson, Jean Murray, Kathleen Flaherty and Dorothy Murphy. Cherished grandfather of sixteen. He was a long time resident of Queens Village, Garden City and Basking Ridge, NJ. Former President and Man of the Year of the Notre Dame Club of New York. Veteran of WWII, President of John J. Duffy and Co., Marketing Manager of National Starch and Co. Viewing at Gallaway and Crane, 101 South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, NJ Friday September 10 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Call 908-766-0250. In lieu of flowers contributions to Ara Parseghian Medical Research.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Passionately Delirious With an Ambiguous Streak
description: Madness. That word can mean many things, mental illness, of course, yet it can also serve as a synonym for folly and can refer to states of excitement ranging from drunken giddiness to spiritual exaltation. Gabri Christa and Cynthia Oliver sought to explore many of these implications in ''Lukosimad,'' the program they presented on Wednesday night as part of the Carnival series at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Gazing in a Mirror: The Omnipresent Camera
description: IN the age of mechanical reproduction, the hatred that dare not speak its name may well be photophobia. In these image-saturated times, even the most devout lovers of photography can succumb, while acute sufferers may even long for heated discussions of ''the death of photography.'' After all, if other forms of human expression -- painting, sculpture, the novel -- are regularly pronounced dead, why is photography exempt?

title: Both China and U.S. Upbeat About Talks on Trade Group
description: Overcoming a serious obstacle in their soured relationship, the United States and China agreed today to resume negotiations on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, and both sides expressed hopes that China would join in less than three months.

title: BUSH IS DETAILING ALL CONTRIBUTIONS ON INTERNET SITE
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, began posting on his Internet site today a detailed list of the size and source of every contribution to his campaign, a gesture of voluntary disclosure that campaign finance experts said was unprecedented in Presidential politics.

title: Politics of Freeing Palestinians Aside, One Clan Feels Joy
description: Iftikar Tayeh did not know if her husband would be among the 199 Palestinian prisoners released today by the Israelis, but she and her 14-year-old son left their refugee camp before dawn just in case.

title: Numerous Zany Characters In Search of an Auteur
description: Here's what must have happened. A lot of talented, relatively famous people in Hollywood who loved Ed Wood's work -- or at least loved the 1994 Tim Burton movie ''Ed Wood,'' about the proud auteur of some of the absolutely worst films of the 1950's -- heard about this project and signed on for the sheer fun of it. The idea sounds fabulous: filming a long-lost script of Wood's, which he had planned as a silent movie, just the way he would have wanted it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAMWELL, MARY E.
description: BRAMWELL-Mary E. Of Manhattan on September 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George M. Bramwell. Loving mother of Elizabeth M. Ropell, Mary H. and George Y. Bramwell. Survived by four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island Saturday. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, 10AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery (Brooklyn).

title: Merrill Lynch Buys a Stake In Archipelago
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will buy a 14.3 percent stake in Archipelago, the electronic trading company, for about $30 million, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Clinton Says Clemency Plan Was Unrelated to First Lady
description: President Clinton said today that his wife's probable Senate campaign in New York played ''absolutely'' no role in his decision to offer clemency to 16 Puerto Rican militants. And he said that Hillary Rodham Clinton, whose exploratory candidacy has been engulfed in controversy over the clemency, had known nothing about the offer.

title: Prada in $170 Million Deal For Church, the Shoemaker
description: Fusing designer chic and straitlaced tradition, Prada S.p.A., the fast-expanding Italian fashion house, said today that it had agreed to buy Church & Company, a 126-year-old British shoemaker, for $:106 million, or $170 million, in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIEHL, MICHAEL R.
description: DIEHL-Michael R. The Partners, Associates and staff of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson deeply mourn the death of our colleague and friend, Michael Diehl, and extend our sympathy to his family and friends.

title: Backup at Texas Bides His Time
description: His teammates call him Limo, the Texas faithful call him the quarterback of the future, and Major Applewhite calls him his backup. It's all a bit confusing for Chris Simms.

title: Priests and Nuns Become Targets of Terror
description: Increasing numbers of Catholic priests and nuns are being killed in East Timor, Indonesia's only predominantly Christian province, according to reports today, while evidence is accumulating that the military command in Jakarta, under pressure from abroad, is slowly beginning to assert control in the territory.

title: For Rabbis, the High Holy Days Demand Sermons That Soar
description: When the final notes of the shofar ring out at the close of Yom Kippur on Sept. 20, marking the culmination of the High Holy Days, Rabbi Jay Rosenbaum of the Union Reform Temple in Freeport, N.Y., expects to do what he does every year: start worrying about the sermons he will give next year.

title: When Her Goal Is Marriage and His Sex
description: Seth should have known he was in trouble when he picked up Chelsea for their first date and saw her coffee table strewn with half a dozen brides' magazines. When he hired her as his decorator, she turned his guest room into a nursery. Then she bought him a puppy.

title: INSIDE
description: Ballistic Missile Report

title: Gene Federico, 81, Graphic Designer, Dies
description: Gene Federico, a graphic designer and advertising executive who helped introduce a style of typography to American advertising that made the lettering the star, rather than a supporting player, died on Wednesday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 81.

title: Yen Soars on Data Showing Growth in Japan's Economy
description: The yen jumped to a three-year high against the dollar on international markets today after the Japanese Government surprised analysts with a report indicating that the economy grew from April to June, expanding for two successive quarters for the first time in more than two years.

title: PRESIDENT UNVEILS GUN BUYBACK PLAN
description: Stepping up the Federal Government's fight against gun violence, President Clinton today announced a $15 million program to buy back firearms from private owners.

title: 31 Are Charged With Taking Jobless Aid Despite Working
description: The Bronx District Attorney said yesterday that his office had arrested 31 people and planned to arrest 160 more on charges that they collected unemployment benefits while gainfully employed.

title: On Death Row, Death Is No Longer a Stranger; New Jersey Prison Slaying and a Ruling Shake Up a Grim, Listless Way of Life
description: Since it opened in 1983, New Jersey's death row has existed in a kind of no man's land between life and death, a place of languid rhythms where condemned killers await execution by lethal injection, even though no one has been put to death since New Jersey reinstituted capital punishment in 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORGAIN, MARTHA CHASTAIN
description: ORGAIN-Martha Chastain. Born October 16, 1917 and deceased September 9, 1999, was the beloved mother of five sons, Benno C. Schmidt, Jr.; Ralph Schmidt; Thomas Schmidt, deceased; John Schmidt and William Schmidt. She was the devoted grandmother of eleven and the great-grandmother of one. She was the beloved wife of Benjamin Darby Orgain, deceased, of Beaumont, Texas, and the former wife of Benno Charles Schmidt of Abilene, Texas. She was the loving sister of Alma (Boots) Chase of Dallas, Texas and Eugenia Tucker, deceased, of Beaumont, Texas. Martha divided her time between her residences in Beaumont, Texas and Locust Valley, New York. All who knew her will remember Martha for her sparkling wit, her intelligence and great strength of character. Martha was a pillar of strength in the raising of her five boys, and she demonstrated that spirit to the end. She spent countless hours devoted to the nurturing of her grandchildren, whether in travel to far off places or on the tennis court, or over a card table, and she will be remebered most as a wonderful and constant mother and grandmother. Martha was a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin, where she graduated as a member of Phi Beta Kappa, Pi Beta Phi. She was a member of the American Contract Bridge League, The Garden Club of America, The Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, New York and the Beaumont Country Club, Beaumont, TX. Martha worshipped at the Trinity United Methodist Church in Beaumont, TX. The funeral is scheduled for Monday, September 13, 1999 at 10:30 AM at The Christ Church United Methodist Church, at Park Avenue and 60th Street. Her family asks that any contributions in her memory be made to the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, New York, NY 10003 to honor her favorite past time of ornithology.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the start of production work on a new opera based on ''A View From the Bridge'' at the Lyric Opera of Chicago referred incorrectly to one expense. It is the projectors that cost $20,000 each, not the onstage screens.

title: Spokesman for Dole Leaves Campaign
description: In a blow to Elizabeth Dole's Presidential campaign, her communications director said today that he was resigning to pursue opportunities in private industry.

title: National News Briefs; Fair Labor Group Elects Ex-White House Counsel
description: Charles F. C. Ruff, the former White House counsel, has been elected chairman of the board of the Fair Labor Association, a new organization, backed by apparel manufacturers and human rights groups, that will oversee a system of monitoring overseas garment factories.

title: A New Season, a New Sound
description: Last spring Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, was in the managerial doldrums. He was approaching the end of his third season with the company and by most measures had made striking progress in carrying out his vision. So what was the matter?

title: Diallo's Father Is Said To End Bid on Estate
description: The father of Amadou Diallo has withdrawn his petition requesting control of his son's estate, lawyers involved with the case said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAGHEUSIAN, LEILA
description: KARAGHEUSIAN-Leila. September 6, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Zabelle and Mihran Karagheusian. She was a philanthropist and president of the Howard Karagheusian Commemorative Corp. She was 96. Service Saturday, September 11 at 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

description: Salander-O'Reilly Gallery

title: A Merlin Visits the Coven In a Quick Quest for an Heir
description: Let's say it's four days before the Eve of Beltane. (It's an ancient Celtic holiday.) A mysterious visitor has just arrived in New Orleans. He is Jason, also known as the First Horn, descendant of Merlin, and he has these four days to choose the woman he will impregnate to carry on his ''enchanted bloodline.'' Luckily, this being New Orleans, an entire coven of witches has been eagerly awaiting his arrival, each one hoping to be chosen for the honor.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC IS CUTTING 1,400 JOBS AT INDIANA PLANT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,400 jobs at a refrigerator plant in Bloomington, Ind., or 44 percent of the plant's employees, and move some of the work to Mexico. G.E., one of Bloomington's largest employers, will also spend as much as $100 million to modernize remaining production lines at the plant, which makes side-by-side refrigerators. G.E. wants to shift production of high-end refrigerators to a joint venture in Mexico and keep mid-level models in Bloomington.

title: The New Russian Menace
description: Recent allegations that American and European banks have facilitated money laundering for Russian organized-crime figures underscore how intractable a problem corruption in Russia is and how vulnerable Western institutions are to the lure of servicing the world's most virulent kleptocracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODEN, SHIRLEY F.
description: BODEN-Shirley F. Sixth Avenue Credit Union extends sincerest condolences to the family. He will always be remembered and loved by all who knew him. His efforts brought about the revitalization of the Credit Union. Directors and Officers of The Sixth Avenue Credit Union

description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS JAKARTA MUST ACT OR ADMIT TROOPS
description: President Clinton demanded today that Indonesia permit an international peacekeeping force to try to restore order in East Timor if the Indonesian military is unable to end ''this madness'' -- the wave of violence that has taken hundreds of lives across the tiny province since it voted for independence last week.

title: Sports of The Times; The Crowd Follows The Sisters
description: THEY will practice together this morning because they are sisters. They might even practice together tomorrow if they should become opponents.

title: NBC Is Seen Close to Deal With Paxson
description: NBC is ''on track'' to complete a deal to acquire a 32 percent interest in the money-losing Paxson Communications Corporation as early as next week, an executive close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Poking Wounds Within a Family
description: ''If we're lucky enough, we work for and toward our weakest area,'' said the filmmaker Alan Berliner, who guessed it was the psychiatrist Carl Jung who first provided that observation. In any event, Mr. Berliner steered toward family, particularly his own, in three acclaimed documentaries, ''The Family Album,'' ''Intimate Stranger'' and ''Nobody's Business,'' to be released on tape on Tuesday by Milestone Film and Video.

title: NOVACARE EMPLOYEE SERVICES AGREES TO $75 MILLION SALE
description: Novacare Employee Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a private investment group for $2.50 a share, or $75.7 million. The investment group is made up of Patricof & Company Ventures, a New York-based private investment firm; Fidelity Ventures Ltd., a unit of the FMR Corporation's Fidelity Investments, and Aflac Inc., an insurance holding company based in Columbus, Ga. Novacare Employee Services, based in Norristown, Pa., provides services like payroll and benefits management for small- and medium-size businesses. Novacare Inc., a King of Prussia, Pa., provider of rehabilitation services, holds a 64 percent stake in the company.

title: Afghanistan Opium Record Raises U.N. Fears
description: Benefiting from a bumper harvest and wider cultivation, Afghanistan more than doubled its production of opium in the past year and now accounts for three-quarters of the world opium crop, according to a United Nations report issued yesterday in Vienna.

title: About New York; Flying Feet, Head Spins And Insights
description: ''WHAT you're seeing here is the end of white supremacy.''

title: xxx: Crusading Cleveland Suburb Bars Cell-Phoning Drivers
description: A growing number of countries have made it a crime to drive while speaking on a cellular phone, citing evidence that the distraction can pose a serious risk. But in the United States such bans are still limited to one small suburb of Cleveland, Ohio.

description: In percent

title: Andreessen Steps Down From AOL
description: Marc Andreessen, who became an icon of the Internet age as a co-founder of the Netscape Communications Corporation before it was acquired by America Online last year, is stepping down after seven months as America Online's chief technology officer, the company said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm sure that we'll be received as patriots in our country, not the criminals we've been labeled as in the United States.''

title: Novartis-Myriad Alliance
description: A Novartis A.G. research unit has agreed to pay Myriad Genetics Inc., a biotechnology company, $33.5 million to study cereal crop genes. Novartis Agricultural Discovery Institute Inc. said yesterday that it hoped to learn how to produce a wider variety of grains with improved resistance to insects and disease. Myriad and the Novartis unit, an agricultural biotechnology company, plan to share profits from data the institute sells to other companies. While Myriad has entered into other genetic-research agreements valued at about $323 million, the new partnership marks the company's first foray into agricultural research. Today, shares of Myriad fell 25 cents, to $13.75.

title: Jets' Jones Is Back and Revved Up
description: When Jets linebacker Marvin Jones lines up against the New England Patriots' offense in the season opener at Giants Stadium on Sunday, it will be the first time in more than a year that he has played in a meaningful game.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HURRICANE BLUNTS GAS RALLY. Prices fell on news that Hurricane Floyd was unlikely to hit the Gulf of Mexico. The October contract, up 9.2 percent on Thursday, fell 5 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $2.801 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: NEC Shares Soar on Report of an Overhaul
description: Shares of the NEC Corporation skyrocketed today after a report in Japan's leading business daily suggested that the technology and telecommunications giant would implement a sweeping overhaul that would consolidate business units, give division heads greater authority and responsibility for profits and losses and shed loss-making businesses.

title: WRESTLING FEDERATION SETS ITS NET WORTH AT $1 BILLION
description: World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc., which has turned televised mayhem into a media and entertainment sensation, plans to premier on Wall Street as a $1 billion company. The Stamford, Conn., company disclosed terms of its initial public offering yesterday, saying it planned to sell 10 million class A shares for $14 to $16 each. The company will have 66.7 million shares outstanding after the stock sale, including the 10 million class A shares and 56.7 million class B shares. At $15 a share, the company's initial market capitalization would be $1 billion. That estimate assumes the class B shares have a value equal to class A stock offered to new investors, though class B shares have 10 times the voting power. World Wrestling estimated that the stock sale would raise $137 million after expenses, and said it planned to use the money for general corporate purposes.

title: Stable Prices and Firm Dollar Push Treasury Prices Higher
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a report on producer prices pointed to tame inflation and the dollar climbed.

title: Indonesia Assisting Militias, U.S. Says
description: President Clinton accused the Indonesian military today of direct involvement in the savagery that has swept across East Timor and said that an international peacekeeping force must be allowed to restore order.

title: In Custody War, 'Moderately Luxurious' Has a Big Price
description: It would be the Taj Mahal of 4-year-old girls' bedrooms, with more than $130,000 in furnishings and decorations. There would be a $19,500 antique desk and chair, $13,000 upholstered walls, a $6,500 painted ceiling, a $6,500 bed and a $1,560 toy chest. The bathroom would have $10,400 curtains, $7,540 plumbing fixtures and $4,550 wallpaper. And the walk-in closet would have $6,500 carpet, $2,340 wallpaper and $3,900 in prints.

title: VIVENDI PROFIT RISES 29%
description: Vivendi S.A., the world's biggest water company, said its first-half profit rose a greater-than-expected 29 percent and raised its forecast for the year as investments in water, trash hauling and telecommunications start paying off. Vivendi earned 783 million euros ($825 million), or 1.32 euros a share, up from 605 million euros, or 1.02 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Vivendi is buying utilities and media companies after shedding assets worth 15 billion euros the last two years.

title: Russian Promises Help From Police
description: Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov of Russia said here on Friday that a team of Russian law enforcement officials would arrive in Washington next week, in an effort to prove Moscow's eagerness to cooperate with American inquiries into money laundering.

title: Opposing Approaches So Johnny Can Read; Finding the Answers in Drills and Rigor
description: The most interesting debate about American education concerns why the United States has not fulfilled the egalitarian aims of schooling as well as other democracies have. The main cause of inequality in American schools, I have argued, has been the dominance of the progressive-education tradition, which has seriously misconceived itself as the guardian of social progress and democratic ideals.

title: Cigarette Factory Closing
description: Tabak A.S., the Czech unit of the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco company, said today that it would close one of four Czech plants as demand in the former Soviet Union for imported cigarettes falls. Tabak said it had halted production at its plant in Novy Jicin in northeastern Czech Republic, which employed 373 people, as orders from former Soviet countries declined because consumers have turned to cheaper domestic brands after the ruble's fall.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: PATAGON.COM INTERNATIONAL Ltd., Miami, named Daniel J. Canel president and chief operating officer. He is a former senior managing director and head of Latin American and Eastern European emerging markets at Union Bank of Switzerland, New York. Gabriel Politzer was named chief strategy officer. He had been managing director and deputy head of emerging markets for the America region at ING Baring. Patagon.com offers on-line trading in Argentina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORBATY, JAN
description: GORBATY-Jan. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Jan Gorbaty on September 6, 1999 in New York City. A native of Poland, Jan Gorbaty was not only an acclaimed concert pianist, but also an indefatigable champion of the music of Frederic Chopin. Professor Gorbaty was President of the Chopin Foundation Council of Greater New York and a Vice President of the Chopin Foundation of the United States. A beloved teacher, he enriched the lives of countless young pianists in the United States and abroad. A Polish patriot in the truest sense, Jan Gorbaty will be deeply missed by all fortunate to know him. To his daughter, Zosia, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Grabouw Journal; Reality Check for Anti-crime Trekker
description: It was either an awful start or the best one he could have hoped for. But last month, on the second day of a 2,800-mile walk around South Africa to call attention to the nation's notorious crime rate, Roger Russell was mugged.

description: CAMHE-Morris. To the Camhe family. We offer our sincerest sympathy for the loss of our esteemed associate. His spirit will always be with us. S. L. Fashions Steve Grabow Mitchell Grabow Anthony Peroni

title: Puerto Ricans Clinton Freed Leave Prisons
description: After vowing to renounce terrorism, 11 members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group walked out of Federal prisons around the country today, freed under an act of clemency by President Clinton that sparked a political firestorm in Washington and in the Senate race in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, DONALD C.
description: PATTERSON-Donald C. Jr. Of Chatham on September 9, 1999. Husband of the late Marguerite ''Miggie'' C. Patterson. Father of Richard B. of Venice, FL; Gail Anne Yorkston of Boonton; and Donald C. of Hatfield, PA. Grandfather of Chris and Andrew Chappell, Ken and Susan Patterson, and Leah Patterson. Brother of Joseph Patterson of FL. Long-time caregiver and friend of Louise Montaque. He is also survived by two great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St. (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ on Tuesday, September 14th at 12PM. Visiting hours 10AM-12PM prior to the service. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to SAGE, 50 De Forest Ave., Summit, NJ 07901, or to Atlantic Home Care & Hospice, 33 Bleeker, Millburn Township, New Jersey 07041.

description: The slick posters, with their multihued Stars of David, came down as quickly as they had gone up.

description: Major league umpires opposed to Richie Phillips's leadership of their union agreed yesterday to form a new union and seek certification to represent all umpires.

description: During the recent Summer Nationals in San Antonio, youth and age both had their moments. title: Blaming Weimar's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: POTASH, FERTILIZER MAKER, CUTS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, North America's largest fertilizer maker, had the biggest one-day drop since it began trading 10 years ago after it said it would close two United States nitrogen plants and reduced by half its third-quarter earnings estimate because of falling prices and weak demand. Potash said it would take a third-quarter charge of about $20 million to shut its plants in Clinton, Iowa, and LaPlatte, Neb., and three other factories in Florida and Virginia whose closings were announced last month. The five plants employed 328. Shares in the company closed in Toronto trading down $6.20 (Canadian), of $3.96 (United States), to $78.40 (Canadian). The stock began trading in 1989 after the Saskatchewan government sold it to private investors.

title: SHARES OF HEALTHSOUTH DECLINE AS MUCH AS 42%
description: Shares of the Healthsouth Corporation, the biggest United States operator of outpatient rehabilitation clinics, fell as much as 42 percent after the company said profit margins were shrinking and it would take charges of $250 million to $300 million this year. Healthsouth also postponed a plan to spin off its inpatient operations to shareholders. Shares closed down $2.1875, to $5.6875. Healthsouth is losing some patients as it resists pressure from health insurers to lower prices and cancels some contracts with unfavorable rates. Analysts said earnings would be reduced as a result. The company will take the charges to reorganize its outpatient business and negotiate contracts.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLUMPS. The euro hit its weakest level against the dollar since late July on speculation that benign American inflation would lift demand for dollar-denominated assets. The euro fell in New York to $1.0364 from $1.0544.

title: Reputed Russian Mobster Denies Tie To Laundering, and Takes Umbrage
description: For several years, Semyon Y. Mogilevich has been hounded by American and European law enforcement agencies which have described him as a major leader of Russian organized crime, in control of a criminal network that reaches from Moscow to Philadelphia.

title: Supporters of a Drive to Reshape Venezuela Make a Retreat
description: Two weeks into a political crisis here, the assembly that was elected to draw up a new Constitution is backing away from further confrontations with rival institutions.

title: Annan Warns Indonesians That Inaction May Lead to Criminal Charges
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that if Indonesia did not accept immediate international military assistance to restore order in East Timor, Indonesian leaders might be judged guilty of crimes against humanity.

title: Peacekeepers and Protesters Clash Again in Kosovo Town
description: Violence exploded on the streets of this divided city for a second day, forcing French and Italian troops to disperse hundreds of stone-throwing demonstrators.

title: At Tight End, Giants Are Deep Thinkers
description: Pete Mitchell saw quarterback Kent Graham break from the pocket, and he knew what to do.

title: Sports of The Times; Worries Are The Cost Of Winning
description: WITH two days remaining before the start of a new season, Jets players moved loosely through the locker room. Players stuffed their oversized duffel bags with all the material for an overnight hotel stay tonight in preparation for their home opener at Giants Stadium tomorrow.

title: F.B.I. Report to Congress Left Off Page on Tear Gas
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent Congress in 1995 a laboratory report about the agency's assault on the Branch Davidian compound without a page that referred to the use of flammable tear-gas canisters, according to a Justice Department memorandum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUKENFELD, M. RONALD
description: BRUKENFELD-M. Ronald. Died peacefully the evening of September 7 at the age of 86. He was the beloved son of the late Morris and Sarah Brukenfeld and brother of the late Carl Brukenfeld, Frances Englander and Edith Hirsch. He spent his working life in the investment community, a Member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1935 to 1980 and was a former Governor of the NYSE. He continued to pursue his interest in the world of investments, going to the office past the age of 84, until the onset of his long illness. Throughout many years of his life, he had a great interest in Mt. Sinai Hospital and was a Trustee since 1961. Though diverted from his original plan to teach English literature, which he did at Columbia, he maintained throughout his life an avid interest in the written word, in books, the theatre and sports. He is survived by his longtime loving companion, Annette Edwards. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Chester Hirsch. He was the cherished uncle of Edward and DiAnne Hirsch, John and Elizabeth Hirsch, Richard Hirsch, Dick and Mimi Brukenfeld, Jane Holzer, Betty Jane and Alan Goldboro, and was the adoring great uncle of Douglas, Karen, Elisa, Nancy, Catherine, Mark, Bruce, Carla and Rustin. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's at 81 Street and Madison Avenue on Monday, September 13 at 11:30AM. Interment to follow At Union Field Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Mt. Sinai and/or Columbia College, Carl M. Brukenfeld Memorial Scholarships Fund. A man of great wit, charm and vibrant personalitiy, he will be greatly missed.

title: 1 Hit, 17 Strikeouts, No Way for the Yankees
description: Hitters gossip on the Yankees' bench during games, sharing information about the opposing pitcher's flaws. But there was no free-flowing exchange of thought last night, no tips, no insight. They said nothing in the dugout because there was nothing to say. Boston's Pedro Martinez humbled the Yankees in their home park in a manner never seen before.

title: Tokyo Slows Yen's Rally, at Least for Now
description: The Japanese Government sold yen for dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an effort to slow the rise in the value of the yen, which had jumped 2.8 percent on Thursday.

title: Opposing Approaches So Johnny Can Read; Analysis on One Side, Facts on the Other
description: Schools opened this week for most students, and so has another round of debate over how they should be run.

title: 2 Detained in Moscow Blast as Death Toll Hits 90
description: As the death toll in a huge apartment-house explosion reached 90, Moscow officials said late tonight that they had detained two men who worked in a ground-floor office of the building for questioning in connection with the blast.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS IS SET TO CLOSE ABOUT 18 STORES
description: The Heilig-Meyers Company, the largest United States furniture retailer, said yesterday that it would close 18 stores in the Chicago and Milwaukee markets and cut as many as 500 jobs as it sheds less-profitable assets. Heilig-Meyers said it would take a charge of about $31 million to $35 million in the fiscal second quarter ended Aug. 31 to cover costs tied to the moves. It expects the closings to save $8 million to $10 million a year before taxes. The company, based in Richmond, also expects to receive a total of about $20 million to $25 million from the sale of the stores' inventories and other assets, and from income-tax savings.

title: MILITIAS IN TIMOR MENACE REFUGEES AT U.N. COMPOUND
description: Moments after most of the staff had evacuated the besieged United Nations compound in East Timor today, men with hand grenades arrived to menace the remaining workers and the 1,000 terrified refugees taking shelter there. Witnesses said the men had looted supplies with the help of uniformed soldiers and fired at refugees who tried to flee.

title: Traveling Coach
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, DONNA R.
description: HENDERSON-Donna R. On September 10, 1999 in Rye, NY after a courageous battle with Lou Gehrig's disease. She was 72. Wife of Gordon Henderson, sister of Lois Johnson, mother of Barton and Paul Henderson, mother-in-law of Tina and Jane, grandmother of Stephanie, William, Emma, Olivia & Lily Henderson. Before having children, she had been a Girl Scout Executive Director in Yonkers, NY and Belmont, MA. She will be greatly missed. Services private. Contributions in her honor may be made to the ALS Association, 27001 Agoura Road, Suite 150, Calabasas Hills, CA. 91301-9817.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL ADDS GRAND PREMIER FOR $389 MILLION
description: The Old Kent Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Grand Premier Financial Inc., a suburban Chicago bank, for $389 million in stock. Old Kent, of Grand Rapids, Mich., has been expanding into the Chicago area with several acquisitions of late. The company said the addition of Grand Premier would expand its presence in greater Chicago to 79 branch offices and deposits of $5.8 billion, compared with 25 offices and $1.7 billion in deposits a year ago. Grand Premier, based in Wauconda, Ill., had assets of $1.6 billion and deposits of $1.3 billion as of June 30, 1999. The company operates 23 banking offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HERBERT
description: STEIN-Herbert. Loving husband of the late Mildred (Fishman). Beloved father of Ben (Alexandra) Stein and Rachel (Melvin) Epstein. Adored grandfather of Jonathan Epstein, Emily (Paul) Landau, and Thomas Stein. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Palo Alto Journal; Hackers Enjoy One Last Meal From the Master of .com Cuisine
description: In the mid-1970's, the social nucleus of many of the men who were creating both the Internet and the personal computer industry was a hole-in-the-wall Sichuan Chinese restaurant across the street from Stanford University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDI, MSGR. ANDREW P.
description: LANDI-Msgr. Andrew P. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired assistant director of Catholic Relief Services on Sept. 8. Mass of Transferral in St. Stephen Church, 142 East 29th St, Manhattan, Sunday, September 12, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Monday, Sept. 13, at 10A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Thursday about CBS News and the merger of the parent CBS Corporation with Viacom misstated the content of the article. The article referred in general terms to financial pressures caused by mergers involving networks, but it stopped short of forecasting that the news division of CBS ''may face more cuts.''

title: Lott Eases Opposition to Test-Ban Hearings
description: Reversing course, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that he now supports holding hearings this fall on a stalled treaty to ban nuclear testing and will try to have them scheduled soon.

title: Think Tank; Left Brain-Right Brain: The ABC's of Everything
description: Twenty years ago, psychologists had a field day ascribing various functions to either the left or right side of the human brain. Language was on the left. Drawing skills stemmed from the right. The left was a whiz at logic but not at intuition. The right could conjure up poetry but not arithmetic. Eventually things got so silly and inconsistent that the whole endeavor was dismissed as ''dichotomania.'' Careful researchers abandoned the enterprise.

title: A Night at the Opera: MTV Rocks
description: Popular music is experiencing what rappers might call a phat moment. The financial boom is subsidizing the rise of instant stars, and the public is fascinated with artists who indulge in celebrity's most obvious pleasures. It is a great time to be beautiful, rich and contentedly silly, especially if you're smart enough to give your superficiality a sardonic twist.

title: A Potent Texas Offense Comes to Rutgers
description: Ricky Williams left Texas to join the National Football League, but he left plenty of offense behind.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the expansion of mosquito spraying in New York City to combat an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis misstated the home borough of the third person to die of the disease. It was Queens, not Brooklyn. (Officials said Wednesday that they had confirmed a case of St. Louis encephalitis in a man from Borough Park, Brooklyn, but he has not died.)

title: ST. JUDE'S STOCK FALLS AFTER ACQUISITION REPORT
description: Shares of St. Jude Medical Inc., the No. 1 United States maker of mechanical heart valves, fell as much as 20 percent yesterday after it said it had agreed to buy Vascular Science Inc. for about $100 million. St. Jude fell $6.06, to $31.25. The company announced after United States markets closed on Thursday that it would buy closely held Vascular Science Inc., a surgical-device maker which is developing tools for heart-bypass surgery, for $80 million in cash and as much as $20 million based on product-development goals. St. Jude said the purchase would cut earnings by 4 cents a share in the fourth quarter, and as much as 15 cents next year. Most analysts responded by cutting their earnings estimates, though they still recommend the stock.

title: An Inadequate Arsenal for the Insect Invasion
description: If you think the current outbreak of mosquito-carried encephalitis in New York is bad, wait until you see what's coming. Global climate changes are producing warmer temperatures in northern climates, and short-term weather cycles like El Nino provide unusual opportunities for pests to extend their range northward.

title: Debt Reduction Gains Appeal In the Capital
description: Representative Baron P. Hill, a moderate Democrat from Indiana, spent a good part of August walking across his district, talking with constituents about what to do with the Federal budget surplus.

title: Pact Signed To Clean Up Nuclear Sites
description: Pledging a new era of cooperation, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson and Governors from four states with nuclear weapons plants today signed an agreement that would expedite cleanup of the nation's nuclear waste.

title: When Mosquitoes Bear Disease
description: The shocking element in the outbreak of encephalitis cases in New York City is not the size of the health crisis -- it is relatively modest and expected to remain so -- but the fact that the disease turned up there at all. These are the first cases of St. Louis encephalitis ever detected in the city. Indeed, in the 36 years that this has been a reportable disease nationwide, there had been only nine cases recorded in all of New York State, the most recent in 1978. So health authorities everywhere -- at the city, state and national levels -- were caught by surprise when a cluster of worrisome neurological cases detected in Queens were identified in laboratory tests as St. Louis encephalitis. So far there have been nine confirmed cases and three deaths, with an additional 60 or so cases under some degree of suspicion.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays will increase to 75 cents in the greater New York metropolitan area. The change, announced in the paper on Sept. 2, will not affect the Sunday price or the cost of home delivery obtained directly from The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALEMBADR, PENNY
description: SALEMBADR-Penny. Of North Adams, MA, on September 5. She was a devoted wife and the best friend I ever had. I will miss you. She is also survived by her sister Linda Bakey who loved you. We will always remember you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDI, ANDREW P.
description: LANDI-Andrew P., Rev. Msgr. On September 8, 1999. Survived by his sister Annette M. Landi and eight nephews and nieces. Services will be held at St. Stephen's Church, East 28th St. between 3rd and Lexington Aves., NYC. Mass of Transferral on Sunday, 7:30 PM, and viewing in Church, 6:30-7:15 PM and 8:30-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection on Monday, 10 AM, viewing hours 9-9:45 AM only. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Donations can be made to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette St., Baltimore, MD. 21201-3443 or St. Stephen's Church, 142 East 29th St., NYC, NY 10016.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Get Early Start, Adding Several Cases
description: Seeking to fill in the blank spots on a sparse docket, the Supreme Court jumped the gun on its new term by more than three weeks today by accepting a half dozen new cases, including a significant Federal-state dispute over safety regulations for oil tankers.

title: HUDSON UNITED BANCORP IN DEAL TO TAKE OVER LYON CREDIT
description: Hudson United Bancorp of Mahwah, N.J., agreed yesterday to buy the Lyon Credit Corporation, a United States commercial finance unit of France's Credit Lyonnais, to expand outside the Northeast. Hudson United said Lyon Credit makes about $200 million in commercial loans a year, specializing in financing for small energy projects. The purchase price was not disclosed. The acquisition of the Stamford, Conn.-based company would extend Hudson United's reach beyond New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Connecticut to Georgia, Texas and California. Hudson United has focused on bolstering its customer base by buying other finance companies. It agreed in June to buy Philadelphia-based Jeff Banks Inc., parent of Jefferson Bank and Bridgeton, N.J.-based Southern Jersey Bancorp, parent of Farmers and Merchants National Bank, for a total $386 million.

title: Director of New Jersey Forest Preserve Steps Down Under Pressure
description: The longtime director of the commission that administers New Jersey's 1.1 million-acre Pinelands National Reserve resigned under pressure today, and environmentalists charged that the move reflected the Whitman administration's preference for development over conservation interests.

title: First Lady Admits Stumbling Politically on Clemency Issue
description: Buffeted by criticism from some of her own supporters, Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged yesterday that she had mishandled her effort to distance herself from President Clinton's offer of clemency to members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group.

title: More Than Final Is at Stake
description: There is plenty up for grabs in the men's semifinals of the United States Open today: third-seeded Yevgeny Kafelnikov, who predicted this fate for himself, and 29-year-old Andre Agassi, seeded second, will fight for a spot in the final and the No. 1 ranking.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSKY, RUTH
description: DORSKY-Ruth. On September 10, 1999, in Denville, NJ, after a long illness. She will be remembered as a caring and loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister-in-law, aunt and friend. We shall miss you, Ruthie.

title: City Is Ordered to Create More Juvenile Group Homes
description: A state judge has ordered New York City to create more group homes for children awaiting trial in minor crimes, saying too many of the juveniles were being detained in tough jails and exposed to hardened criminals.

title: Clinton to Meet Jiang on Trade 'Mistake'
description: President Clinton arrived here today and prepared to repair the damage from what some of his aides call one of his biggest foreign policy mistakes this year: walking away from an agreement to get China into the World Trade Organization.

title: Rangers Seem Prepared to Jettison Ndur
description: Coach John Muckler of the Rangers indicated today that even if Rumun Ndur, an unsigned defenseman, agreed to terms immediately, he would probably not make the team.

title: LABOR IS DIVIDED ON ENDORSEMENT
description: The nation's labor movement is sharply divided over how to handle its coveted endorsement in next year's Presidential election because several powerful unions -- the auto workers, the steelworkers and the teamsters -- feel that Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic front-runner, is not sympathetic enough to their views on trade policy.

title: In France, Eat Like the French
description: To the Editor:

title: Newborn Discovered Dead in an Alley in Harlem
description: The body of a newborn baby, its umbilical chord attached, was found yesterday morning in an alley between two Harlem apartment buildings, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TOSCO CORP., Stamford, Conn., the oil refiner, said its board had authorized buying back as much as $300 million in stock.

title: Top Filly Heads Big Start at Belmont
description: After 36 days of high-performance racing at Saratoga, Belmont Park, 200 miles to the south, opened its doors yesterday for a 33-day autumn season with a herd of world-class horses led by the champion filly Silverbulletday, who will run this weekend as the track begins its countdown to the Breeders' Cup.

title: How East Timor Is Like Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Skips a Stop, And Gore Acts Fast To Take Advantage
description: Rhode Island may be a tiny state, but no place is too small for the Presidential candidates to wage a symbolic battle over education.

title: In France, Eat Like the French
description: To the Editor:

title: Principles in the Balkans, but Not in East Timor?
description: In Kosovo, the United States and its allies had to choose between two important norms of international relations: respecting a state's sovereignty and protecting human rights. When they chose to stand for the latter principle, and to use force on its behalf, it seemed that a new standard was being established at last -- that no state was allowed to commit gross human rights violations even on its own territory, and that those who were guilty of having ordered them and carried them out could be indicted as criminals.

title: Religion Journal; Violence in East Timor Touches a Noted Prelate
description: Before the violence in East Timor became a source of international concern a few days ago, many Americans gave little thought to the place, home to about 800,000 people on half of a large island at the Indian Ocean's eastern edge.

title: Man Admits to Fraud In Series of Phony Falls
description: After staging a nine-month spree of fraudulent slip-and-fall accidents in supermarkets and convenience stores across New Jersey, Ernest Woodson, 52, of Vineland, pleaded guilty to third-degree health care fraud on Thursday, admitting that he received nearly $10,000 from nine insurance companies after faking injuries from the falls, state officials said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Oppsosing Approaches So Johnny Can Read; Toward Good Thinking On Essential Questions
description: As one concerned with precollege education, I'm gratified by the attention paid to this topic over the last two decades. At the same time I have to signal my uneasiness that so much of the discussion centers on means: should we have charters, vouchers, teachers' unions, national tests, etc. I think it is essential that we step back, at least periodically, and ask about the ends or aims of education.

title: BID FOR DISTILLERY
description: Two privately owned Scottish distillers, Edrington Holdings and William Grant & Sons Ltd., announced they had acquired Highland Distillers P.L.C., the maker of Famous Grouse whisky, for $:601 million, or $979 million, in cash. Analysts said the acquisition was a defensive move against its rivals like Diageo P.L.C., the world's largest liquor company, and Allied Domecq P.L.C. The two Scottish spirit companies will pay 425 pence a share in cash and pay 100 pence each for convertible bonds for Highland, which is based in Glasgow.

title: No Seventh-Inning Stretch When the Score Is 9-9-99
description: Advance publicity for the concert of Friends and Enemies of New Music on Thursday evening at Christ and St. Stephen's Church seemed to suggest that extra innings were possible, but in the event, nine proved plenty. Indeed, as a premise for this 9 o'clock program on 9/9/99, however much intended as a lark, the number nine (and the humor) wore thin.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Producer Prices Jump, But Core Rate Slips

title: Turn Down the Elvis, Crank Up the Disco; Upstart With a Younger Twist Sets Off a Rivalry on Oldies Radio
description: The bratty newcomer in the battle for the future of golden-oldies radio boasts that it never plays doo-wop, Elvis or the Beach Boys. In fact, WTJM-FM has greeted Presley acolytes with the unthinkable slogan, ''Elvis has left the building.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ABRAMS, LOUIS G.
description: ABRAMS-Louis G. Lovingly remembered. Deeply missed. Never will you be forgotten. Libby

title: Editorial Notebook; Harry Potter and the Marveling Muggles
description: I am beginning to understand Quidditch, which is not a language but a game played by the students at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. It is played on brooms, over a field, in the sky, with four balls, one of them, the Golden Snitch, by nature elusive, self-propelled and worth 150 points. Quidditch is the main source of rivalry between Hogwarts's four residential houses, Slytherin, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw and Gryffindor. Harry Potter resides in the last and best of these houses with his friends Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger. All of the students at Hogwarts are wizards and witches in training, whether they descend from magical families or from families that dwell in the preposterous, obstreperously shortsighted, narrow-minded world occupied by people like you and me, who are called Muggles. Our world is that place where the people in photographs just stand there with frozen smiles on their faces instead of waving back.

title: $150 MILLION JET ORDER
description: In a display of improved political and economic ties between South American nations, the Venezuelan Air Force will acquire eight fighter jets from Brazil's Embraer S.A. in a contract worth $150 million. The order for the subsonic jets, which were developed in a venture between Embraer and Italian partners, is the Brazilian company's first significant military contract in Latin America. Venezuela and Brazil have been forging closer commercial ties, especially in the petroleum and electricity generation industries.

title: In Debut on Senior Tour, Watson Is Still a Leader
description: Everyone assumed that Tom Watson, making his anticipated debut on the Senior PGA Tour at the Comfort Classic, would seize the spotlight.

title: Giuliani's Challenge in Outbreak: To Warn but Not to Panic Public
description: Stephen Athineos, the manager of a bicycle messenger service in Manhattan, is perfectly clear on two things. The first is that the outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis is a total fabrication of city officials. The second is that they ought to be doing a much better job of containing it.

title: Language Not Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Death Tied to E. Coli From Upstate Fair
description: Health officials said they believe that a 79-year-old man who died at a hospital in Albany yesterday may have been the second victim of an outbreak of E. coli that has already sickened more than 600 people in upstate New York, in one of the most serious such epidemics to occur in the United States.

title: By Court Order, Busing Ends Where It Began
description: The school system that pioneered busing for desegregation three decades ago was ordered today to halt the program by a Federal judge who ruled that forced integration was no longer necessary because all vestiges of intentional discrimination had disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKINSON, CORRINE E. GOLDSMITH
description: DICKINSON-Corrine E. Goldsmith. title: Hingis Puts an End to the Williams Sisters' Act
description: The sequel sister, 17-year-old Serena Williams, punched her fist in the air yesterday and announced that she was ready to take on any and all comers for this 1999 United States Open title.

title: Alfredo Kraus, Lyric Tenor Revered for Phrasing, Was 71
description: Alfredo Kraus, a lyric tenor who was revered for the refinement of his phrasing and the artistry he brought to bel canto roles, died yesterday at his home in Madrid. He was 71.

title: Ray E. Trussell, 85, Hospitals Commissioner for New York City
description: Dr. Ray E. Trussell, a former Commissioner of Hospitals in New York City and later the general director of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: 3 Days After Quake Hit Greece, Rescuers' Hopes Fade
description: As a towering power shovel tore through the debris of what was once the Fourlis appliance showroom, the exhausted chief of the rescue team, Mihalis Gaitatzis, acknowledged what most Greeks accepted today.

title: $1.5 Million Roller Rink For Troubled Camden
description: There are no movie theaters, ice-skating rinks or bowling alleys in Camden. But Thursday night, the City Council voted unanimously to build a 22,000-square-foot roller rink in this troubled, impoverished city.

title: Tough Times in the Copper Pits; Excess Capacity and Sagging Prices Force Retrenchment
description: Thousands of feet below the scrub and cactus near this copper town is an unusual silence. The din of pneumatic hammers, conveyer belts and blasting that was music to the ears for many miners here in the Sonoran Desert has mostly subsided.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP TO BUY HERITAGE FINANCIAL
description: Old National Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Heritage Financial Services Inc. for about $63.2 million in stock as it expands in Tennessee. Old National, based in Evansville, Indiana, will pay 3.15 of its shares for each share of Clarksville, Tennessee-based Heritage Financial. Heritage Financial, which runs Heritage Bank, has $228 million in assets. Old National will have more than $7.9 billion in assets and 148 branches when this and another pending acquisition are completed.

description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: TOYOTA TO BUILD IN POLAND
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's third-biggest car maker, will invest 10 billion yen, or $92 million, in a car parts plant in Poland, its first factory in Eastern Europe, Toyota's president, Fujio Cho, said. Mr. Cho and Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek of Poland had signed an agreement under which Toyota would employ about 300 people to produce 250,000 gearboxes a year for its Avensis, Corolla and Yaris models. It will be Toyota's fourth European plant, after a car assembly and engine plant in Britain and an assembly plant now being built in France.

title: Tortoises Returned to Zoo As Police Seek Thieves
description: Two extremely rare Egyptian tortoises stolen from the Bronx Zoo on Wednesday were returned to their home early yesterday.

title: Medical Dilemmas
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blueprint for Ulster's Police
description: Northern Ireland's police force, the Royal Ulster Constabulary, has long been one of the region's most controversial institutions. It is viewed by many -- perhaps most -- Catholics as a Protestant Unionist force, and by many Protestants as a proud bulwark against Irish Republican Army terrorism. Last year's Good Friday peace agreement set up a commission to propose reforms. On Thursday that commission, headed by the former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten, delivered its report.

title: Amount of PBS Donor List-Swapping Grows
description: Nearly twice as many public television and radio stations as previously thought have swapped their donor lists with political organizations, according to a report by auditors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: In France, Eat Like the French
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing the Rock Star, In Boa and White Boots
description: Sometimes the story of rock seems to be two parts theft, one part creative misapprehension. Those were the proportions for the triple bill of Lenny Kravitz, Smashmouth and Buckcherry on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. Mr. Kravitz and Buckcherry dispensed blatant, straight-faced imitations of their favorite rock eras, complete with poses. Smashmouth, meanwhile, borrowed from all over the place to assemble wry, concise songs with their own point of view.

title: Without Ado, Israel Leaves Another 7% of West Bank
description: Ahead of schedule and with little fanfare, Israel completed its first set of obligations under the new peace deal today, transferring civilian control of a chunk of West Bank to the Palestinians a day after it released about 200 prisoners.

description: WELCOME BACK, McCOURT

title: Journal; Save Us From Our Saviors
description: Here's one unexpected dividend in being Jewish this New Year: No Presidential aspirant is going to use a Rosh ha-Shanah service as a campaign opportunity to advertise his or her piety to potential voters. While this is the election in which, as Alan Dershowitz has put it, the candidates are ''running for bishop rather than President,'' none of them want to be rabbi.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHONBERG, GEORGE

description: This was exactly the combination of events the Mets had managed to avoid for most of the season. When the starting pitching was shaky for three-quarters of the season, the bullpen was the stalwart. When, in recent weeks, the bullpen has suffered, the starters have frequently been good enough to keep the relievers in their seats. Rarely had the two gone wrong simultaneously and neither was disastrous tonight. But like an exhausted sprinter trying to make a clean baton pass, both ends of the Mets' relay team stumbled just enough to allow the Dodgers to eke out a 3-1 victory.

But many of them turned out on Wednesday night at the Blue Note to watch an encounter between Elvin Jones and Cecil Taylor. It was the second of three such late-night duets, a highlight of Mr. Jones's weeklong residence at the club during the week of his 72d birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORGAIN, MARTHA CHASTAIN
description: ORGAIN-Martha Chastain. Born October 16, 1917 and deceased September 9, 1999, was the beloved mother of five sons, Benno C. Schmidt, Jr.; Ralph Schmidt; Thomas Schmidt, deceased; John Schmidt and William Schmidt. She was the devoted grandmother of eleven and the great-grandmother of one. She was the beloved wife of Benjamin Darby Orgain, deceased, of Beaumont, Texas, and the former wife of Benno Charles Schmidt of Abilene, Texas. She was the loving sister of Alma (Boots) Chase of Dallas, Texas and Eugenia Tucker, deceased, of Beaumont, Texas. Martha divided her time between her residences in Beaumont, Texas and Locust Valley, New York. All who knew her will remember Martha for her sparkling wit, her intelligence and great strength of character. Martha was a pillar of strength in the raising of her five boys, and she demonstrated that spirit to the end. She spent countless hours devoted to the nurturing of her grandchildren, whether in travel to far off places or on the tennis court, or over a card table, and she will be remebered most as a wonderful and constant mother and grandmother. Martha was a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin, where she graduated as a member of Phi Beta Kappa, Pi Beta Phi. She was a member of the American Contract Bridge League, The Garden Club of America, The Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, New York and the Beaumont Country Club, Beaumont, TX. Martha worshipped at the Trinity United Methodist Church in Beaumont, TX. The funeral is scheduled for Monday, September 13, 1999 at 10:30 AM at The Christ Church United Methodist Church, at Park Avenue and 60th Street. Her family asks that any contributions in her memory be made to the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, New York, NY 10003 to honor her favorite past time of ornithology.

title: Herbert J. Alexander, 58, Mathematician
description: Herbert J. Alexander, an internationally known mathematician who had solved several complex problems that had baffled mathematicians for years, died on Aug. 27 in Evanston, Ill. He was 58.

title: Pesticide Spraying Slowed By Heavy Rain and Fog
description: Heavy rain and fog thwarted a plan to spray pesticide over much of New York City yesterday, but officials said that they still hoped to spray in every borough by the end of the weekend to curb the recent outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, a mosquito-borne viral disease.

title: British Travel Merger Has Uphill Battle
description: The European Commission seemed to be preparing today to block the proposed $1.4 billion merger of two leading British travel companies. The deal would create Britain's biggest single tour operator and narrow competition in a market that has been seeing price wars and falling sales.

title: ATOMIC POWER EXPORTS
description: The state-run Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Company, or Hanjung, said it would sell $50 million worth of nuclear power plant generators to United States-based ABB-Combustion Engineering Nuclear Power, a unit of ABB Ltd. Under the deal signed by both companies, Hanjung will deliver four steam generators by October 2002. It is the first instance of a South Korean company selling nuclear power plant equipment to the United States, Hanjung said. The generators will be supplied to a 1,200-megawatt, light-water nuclear power plant in Tennessee, operated by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, ALFREDO
description: KRAUS-Alfredo. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of a unique artist and beloved colleague, Alfredo Kraus. His impeccable sense of style, aristocratic stage presence, and great warmth made him an ideal exponent of the lyrical roles of the Bel Canto and French repertories. Of his 134 performances of twelve roles with the Metropolitan, perhaps the most memorable were his Werther, Hoffmann, and Romeo, as well as his Edgardo in ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' and Tonio in ''La Fille du Regiment.'' But it is not only for his artistry that we will remember him, for he was a true gentleman, whose charm, kindness, and grace endeared him to all who came to know him. From his Met debut in 1966 as the Duke in ''Rigoletto'' to his last Met appearance in our April 1996 Gala honoring James Levine, he was for thirty years one of the bestloved artists in our company, and it is with great sorrow that we extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Los Alamos Punishes 3 for Role in Spy Inquiry
description: The Los Alamos National Laboratory said today that it had taken disciplinary action against a former director of the laboratory and two other current or former officials for their roles in the Government's investigation of evidence of China's theft of American nuclear secrets.

title: MAPLE LEAF FOODS AGREES TO BUY LANDMARK GROUP
description: Maple Leaf Foods Inc., Canada's biggest meat processor, agreed to buy Landmark Group Inc., a hog and animal-feed company in western Canada, for about $150 million (Canadian), or $101.4 million (United States), in cash, shares and assumed debt. Owners of closely held Landmark would receive as many as 1.5 million Maple Leaf shares. Maple Leaf would finance the balance with lines of credit. Landmark is based in Landmark, Manitoba, near Winnipeg. Maple Leaf is based in Toronto.

title: Indian Tribes Approve Gambling Compacts With California
description: Gov. Gray Davis and more than 50 California Indian tribes agreed today to binding compacts intended to keep slot machines operating at Indian casinos around the state, and the State Legislature voted to put a referendum on the ballot next March to exempt tribes from the state Constitution's ban on casino gambling, paving the way for a substantial expansion of gambling in the West.

description: The concentration of New Jersey's overall wealth in terms of property value, income, employment and population has shifted away from the state's northeastern region to six counties stretching across the central part of the state, according to a Rutgers University report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAGHEUSIAN, LEILA
description: KARAGHEUSIAN - Leila. Union Settlement's Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Leila Karagheusian, who served as a Director from 1924 to 1995 and as an Honorary Director for the balance of her life. She was a graduate of Barnard College and Columbia University School of Social Work. As a lifelong resident of Manhattan, she cared deeply about the quality of life in the city and dedicated her time and resources to the East Harlem community. In the '20's she worked as a volunteer in the Union Settlement Thrift Shop. She was instrumental in securing a major gift for the construction of the agency's Leggett Day Care Center. She had a tender heart and a valiant spirit. She was selfless, thoughtful and generous.

Despite the slight rise in profit, the family-controlled bank is facing stiff competition from American behemoths like Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which have been making significant inroads in Britain's investment banking business, the hub of Europe's mergers and acquisitions activity. The investment banking unit has been fighting back, earning $:68.9 million in the first half of this year, up from $:60.3 million in the corresponding period last year. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

Tracinda Corporation, the investment company owned by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, holds about 89 percent of MGM's shares, and MGM said Tracinda may buy more in the offering. title: Bookend; Literary Crushes
description: A year or two ago, I fell in love -- with a prose style. As I wandered through a Midwestern museum one morning, I saw a painting by Fairfield Porter that spoke to me so strongly that I resolved on the spot to find out more about him. Stopping by the gift shop, I looked for a book about Porter; instead, I found a book he wrote, called ''Art in Its Own Terms: Selected Criticism, 1935-1975.'' I bought it, went to lunch and started flipping through the pages, waiting for something to jump out at me. My eye fell on this passage: ''Some art has a very open meaning, and can be written about in terms of this meaning; but the chances are that if the meaning is the most interesting thing about it, it does not stand alone, it does not assert itself. It leans on what it means. An implied meaning is richer.'' I immediately snapped to attention -- it was as if an invisible man had clapped his hands next to my ear -- and by the time I put the book down, my cheeseburger was stone cold.

title: Going to Extremes
description: 1. The Explorers Club was formed in 1905. Its members have included Admirals Robert Peary and Richard Byrd, Charles Lindbergh, Sir Edmund Hillary, Thor Heyerdahl, Chuck Yeager, Sally Ride and the oceanographer Sylvia Earle (pictured), though women weren't invited to join until 1981. The explorer Richard Wiese says the club still has an ''alpha male mentality.'' ''You get up to go to the bathroom,'' he says, ''and when you come back, some 80-year-old coot who used to be King Kong is hitting on your girlfriend. But seriously, these guys have shaped the 20th century, which I say with some jealousy because they've all 'been there first.''' 2. ''I guess my image is sort of disheveled/ outdoorsy,'' says James Prosek, who wore a Burberrys sport coat during his book tour for ''The Complete Angler'' (Harper Collins, $30). As he fished his way through Britain, Prosek was astounded by the uniform of the gentry-fishermen: a tweed suit, a cap and a wool tie. 3. At the fall men's wear collections, Giorgio Armani, Gianfranco Ferre and Nautica (pictured) focused on extreme weather gear, thus the preponderance of enormous turtlenecks, cowl-neck parkas and fur-trimmed hoods. 4. Norman D. Vaughan says that besides his caribou parka, the most useful piece of clothing he wore on Byrd's 1928 expedition was long woolen underwear. ''When you perspire in wool, it gets wet!'' Vaughan says. ''We'd change our underwear every three weeks, all at once. It was like a Saturday night bath. We'd make five more miles on the sleds, and I'd like to tell you, it was because of the underwear.'' Prada's silk and cashmere long underwear (pictured, $670 for a crew-neck top, $710 for a polo neck, and $600 for the bottoms) can be found at Prada, 841 Madison Avenue. 5. No styling products were used on this shoot, at the request of the photographer, Richard Burbridge, who wanted his subjects to ''look like themselves.'' One product that explorers use is Dermatone, a frostbite/sunburn protector. 6. Fred McLaren was part of the first baseball game played at the North Pole. ''It was late August in 1960,'' he says. ''We took great care to make sure the pitcher's mound was on the Pole. If you hit a home run, you'd circumnavigate the globe; if you hit into right field, you'd hit into tomorrow, and if the right fielder caught the ball, he'd throw it back into yesterday. Sliding took on new meaning, and I'm still not sure what day the game ended.'' 7. Interest in adventure has inspired ideas for everything from books (like ''The Perfect Storm'' and ''Into Thin Air'') to cars. Detroit's contributions include the GMC Denali (the Indian name for Mount McKinley). 8. Marcelo Mendez has been on an expedition on Easter Island. ''The island hasn't been contaminated,'' he says. ''It's like a microcosm of Earth, and we can use what happened there to think about what the future holds.'' On an expedition, Mendez is most concerned with what goes on his feet. On Easter Island, he wore Teva-type sandals. ''I'm more of a practical guy than a fashion guy,'' he says. An alternative might be these sandals ($140). At Kenneth Cole stores nationwide.
