title: 20 Years of Freedom in Dance
description: Twenty years ago Saturday night, Leonid Kozlov danced the role of Tybalt in ''Romeo and Juliet'' on the Bolshoi Ballet's closing night in Los Angeles, then went backstage and disappeared into the parking garage. The next morning, after spending the night in a Volkswagen bus, he and his wife, Valentina Kozlova, were granted political asylum ''in an improbable half-hour,'' he recalled. ''That's how our lives started, and then we had everything.''

title: Children's Books; Glorious Mosaic
description: As most every schoolchild does not know, Moses took a few detours before leading the Jews to the Promised Land. In one adventure, he traveled to Ethiopia, where he served as king and armed the Ethiopian soldiers with menacing storks. After some years, Moses returned to his own people in Egypt because he did not want to worship the Ethiopian gods.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL /Plymouth Prowler; A Street Rod Named Desire
description: YOU heard it here last: The Plymouth Prowler is a way cool set of wheels -- or at least it looks like a way cool set of wheels.

title: Standard Repertory, And the Not-So-Standard
description: AND there shall be musicals. So sang the muse of New Jersey's professional theaters, for it is the musical theater that strikes the dominant chord in the new season's repertory.

title: Made in the U.S.A.
description: In Praise of Hard Industries

title: Megan Sabado and John McLeod 3d
description: Megan Shea Sabado, a daughter of Joan and Maurice Sabado of La Jolla, Calif., was married yesterday to John Montgomery McLeod 3d, the son of Nancy LaRouche of Macedon, N.Y., and Mr. McLeod Jr. of Sarasota, Fla. Justice D. Bruce Crew 3d of State Supreme Court in Norwich, N.Y., officiated at the home of Joan and John Potter in East Chop, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna Cherished memories of my beloved mother after eight years & a lifetime of her giving devotion and joy to me & to my late esteemed father on her birthday & wedding anniversary.

title: The Nation; Pardons: Having To Say You're Sorry
description: THE Presidential power to issue pardons and reprieves represents the ultimate Constitutional act of forgiveness -- unreviewable and absolute. But as the outcry over President Clinton's offer of clemency to 16 Puerto Rican nationalists demonstrates, it is not immune from second-guessing.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for HARLEY S. SHAIKEN; Paradoxes Of G.M.'s Promise
description: A FEW short years ago, many working Americans worried about the seemingly constant downsizings by major corporations, and there was much hand-wringing about whether anyone could expect to join a company fresh from school and work there long enough to retire with a gold watch. In board rooms, the worry was the opposite: that decades of steady gains by unions on job security and work-rule issues in the prosperous 1950's and 60's had made the labor force in many American factories too expensive and inflexible to compete in the global economy, especially during recessions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBUGLER, CHARLES J. JR.
description: STEINBUGLER-Charles J. Jr. Of Garden City, NY on September 9, 1999. A man of intelligence and probity, loyally devoted to his family, his faith, the legal profession, Notre Dame and the Marine Corps. A loving husband to his wife Jane and a caring father to his daughters and their spouses: Sara & her husband David Cordon, M.D., Elizabeth and her husband Anthony Saltalamacchia, Kathryn and her husband Joseph Ronan, Mary and her husband David Ekeren, and Anne and Margaret; & a proud grandfather of eleven. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-5 Saturday, and 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10 A.M. Monday. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Brooklyn Prep Alumni Association, Loyola Hall, Fordham University, Bronx, NY 10458-5198.

title: Man Behind NFL's Instant Replay
description: WHEN the National Football League owners voted to adopt a video replay system this season to review controversial plays, it made sense for the league to tap Dennis Lewin to head the search for the best technology.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting tomorrow, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays will rise to 75 cents in the greater New York metropolitan area. The change, announced Sept. 2 by the newspaper, will not affect the Sunday price or the cost of home delivery obtained directly from The Times.

title: Asbury Park, Trying to Rebuild, Loses
description: It was not just the sight of the Toms River South High School football team running onto the field in perfect coordination that let the Asbury Park Blue Bishops know what kind of day they were in for today. The Blue Bishops saw that Toms River South had also brought a marching band; its members might have been bigger than the Asbury Park players.

title: Renovated galleries, a new spot for tapas
description: The Prado Museum inaugurated in July its ''definitive'' hanging of its unmatched collection of Velazquez paintings, in preparation for a winter exhibition celebrating the 400th anniversary of his birth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, BERNARD
description: PRICE-Bernard September 9, 1999, of Surfside, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Dear brother of Goldie Worth and the late Nathalie Cohen and beloved uncle. Funeral services Monday, 12 noon, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens.

title: A Marathon of Midnights In Times Square
description: SOMETIME back in the 80's, Peter Kohlmann and his wife decided to celebrate New Year's Eve with a couple hundred thousand strangers. Late in the evening, they made their way to Times Square, melted into the crowd and began to wait. Mr. Kohlmann, who was an aide to Mayor Edward I. Koch at the time, remembers little else about the event, but then there was only so much to remember.

title: Tea-Leaf Reading
description: Sometimes a good cup of tea is worth a timeout anywhere. If that place happens to be San Francisco, a new guidebook can help make sure it's the perfect blend of atmosphere and service. ''San Francisco in a Teacup,'' by Ulrica Hume (Blue Circle Press, $15.95), describes 50 places that serve tea, from the traditional (the Fairmont Hotel) to Old World (the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park) to the unexpected (the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art). Each listing gives a history of the establishment, address, directions and a roster of teas offered. Contact Blue Circle Press at (415) 552-2534.

title: THE NEW SEASON/THEATER; A Musical Isn't Built in a Day, but This Took 47 Years
description: TO anyone interested in the commercial theater, it is common knowledge that a musical, from conception to production, usually takes a long time. Two or three years is the average, but many have gestated for five, six or even seven -- periods of time often referred to as ''forever.''

title: Sorry, Wrong Numbers
description: IN the spring of 1998, around the time Manhattan was supposed to get its new 646 area code, the writers of ''Seinfeld'' decided to give Jerry's friend Elaine the new prefix. Her reaction? Horror.

title: Thefts at Holocaust Garden Spur Vigilance
description: The Holocaust Garden in Riverside Park, near 83d Street, has long held a special place in the heart of its principal benefactor, David Goldstick, a retired real estate lawyer who has spent his own time, energy and money to plant and maintain it. But a rash of thefts and vandalism is threatening the garden. Plants have disappeared and irrigation hoses have been cut. And Mr. Goldstick, 67, and the Parks Department are sounding the alarm.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-12-99: Phenomena; Priority Mailing
description: I just got my official United States Postal Service license to print postage. Soon you, too, will have a U.S.P.S. license, and it's a serious responsibility. ''It's akin to printing money,'' says Pam Gibert, U.S.P.S. vice president, retail. Anyway, it beats waiting in U.S.P.S. lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, FRANK
description: KAPLAN-Frank Beloved husband of the late Mildred. Loving father of Rhonda and Michael Plawner and Marc and Pamela Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Jordan and Dashiell. Devoted brother of Stanley and the late Beatrice and David. Active member of Williamsburgh Lodge I.O.O.F., Boy Scouts of America, Kings Bay Jewish Community League and owner of The Philip Press of Avenue U for over 50 years. Services Monday 1:00 PM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave.

title: Wall of Water
description: ISAAC'S STORM

title: Bush Factor Emerges in McCain Visit
description: It was the sort of highly publicized event featuring two politicians gearing up for major campaigns that under most circumstances would reflect their mutual endorsement: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor who would be Senator, and John McCain of Arizona, the Senator who would be President, chatting over antipasto and seafood marinara at Da Nico in Little Italy and pretending not to notice the photographers and television cameras all around them.

title: Media Deals, Written Larger
description: IN what is supposedly a business that fosters and rewards creativity, the people who run big entertainment companies certainly look like a bunch of copycats.

title: A Frequent Flyer Calls for Courtesy
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Aid
description: Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry and Purchase College have each received $800,000 grants from the United States Department of Education to begin a four-year program for high school students ''of diverse economic and educational backgrounds.'' Known as Upward Bound, the program will provide students with additional academic support so they are more likely to complete high school and pursue post-secondary educations.

title: Officials Ban Gun Shows On Los Angeles County Sites
description: In a significant setback for the nation's largest gun show, Los Angeles County has adopted a law banning the sale of weapons and ammunition on its property.

title: Streetscapes /127 East 73d Street; A 1904 Neo-Federal House, Built by the Gibson Girls
description: CHARLES DANA GIBSON entranced turn-of-the-century New York with his deft sketches of the habits of the upper class -- and those trying to get there. Gibson made a small fortune by constantly recycling his signature image -- a willowy, aristocratic young woman with a hint of mischief in her eyes. Now a new owner is about to turn the key on a complete renovation of the artist's 1904 residence, 127 East 73d Street, ''the House the Gibson Girls built.''

title: Ms. Jock Couture
description: In the world of extreme sports fashion, where ''large'' and ''phat'' are compliments, the smaller-framed sex can feel lost between the seams. ''It's frustrating to have to ride the slopes or pavement dressed like a garbage bag,'' said Tara Everston, 27, an avid snowboarder who last week opened Stackhouse, an extreme sports shop for women at 282 Lafayette Street (Prince Street). ''For a long time girls who wanted to participate in extreme sports had to make do with the men's gear because that's all they could find that wasn't covered with flowers and butterflies.'' Not surprisingly, the store, with its neighborhood clubhouse feeling, has a ban on selling pink, frilly things. Ms. Everston and her partner, Laura Stackhouse, 26, tracked down women's lines of high-performance sports brands including Volcom (snowboarding pants, $120), Alphanumeric (snowboard jackets, $250) and Etnies (skateboarding sneakers, $82). The shop also sells used surfboards and BMX bicycles on consignment and has turntables for shoppers to hone their deejay skills. Sports-inspired evening fashions for less than $100 include camouflage sandals by the French company No Name and waterproof miniskirts. JULIA CHAPLIN

title: The Best Things in Life?
description: Ed Zander, president of Sun Microsystems, called the market's reaction to his company's moves last week a ''sign of the times.''

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS -- TELEVISION/RADIO
description: September

title: 'God's Perfect Child'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cute Characters, Lots of Action, but No Comic Relief
description: THE first glimpse we get of the title character in director Hayao Miyazaki's extraordinary feature-length cartoon ''Princess Mononoke'' is of the teen-age, forest-dwelling princess in wolf-skin clothing clutching a knife, her mouth smeared with blood. She has just sucked the poison from a bullet lodged in the white wolf who reared her; the huge animal stands behind the young woman, and their eyes share a steady, angry, exhausted glare at the camera. Right away, an American viewer gets the message: Walt Disney and ''Tarzan'' this ain't.

title: Washington Police Begin To Enforce 1995 Curfew
description: Four years ago, the City Council approved a youth curfew. Then, after a long court challenge and a recent campaign to educate parents, children and the police, the District of Columbia started this week to enforce the ban on unsupervised children on the streets late at night.

title: INSIDE
description: Laundering or Tax Dodge

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMHE, MORRIS
description: CAMHE-Morris On September 9, 1999. Husband of the late Libby. Beloved father of Jack, Renee, Pamela, Louis, Mona and Samuel. Cherished grandfather of Mace, Todd, Charles, Sara, Robert, Lee, Lauren, Alexis, Melanie and Little Mace. Devoted brother and uncle. He will be missed by the many people whose lives he touched and by the fashion industry in which he was a potent force. Visiting Sunday 7:00-9:00 PM, service Monday, September 13, 1:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment immediately following at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. As a tribute to his generous nature contributions may be made to the Sephardic Home, 2266 Cropsey Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11214.

title: September 5-11; Another Russian Campaign
description: Imagine the United States lost a war with Alabama and sued for peace, only to see Alabama invade Mississippi, and you have a rough idea of the Kremlin's latest military plight. The Russian air force was hard at work bombing its own territory, the province-like Republic of Dagestan, after Islamic radicals from neighboring Chechnya marched in by the thousands, unmolested, with the aim of taking it over.

title: Marina Rust And Ian Connor
description: Marina Marshall Rust, the daughter of Fiona Field Kay of Amsterdam and David E. Rust of Washington, was married yesterday to Ian Christian Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Phelps Connor of Laona, Wis. The Rev. David Boulton, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Dark Harbor, Me.

title: Great Insight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 68 of Arts & Leisure today with an article about James Bond movies misidentified the actress shown with Pierce Brosnan in ''The World Is Not Enough.'' She is Sophie Marceau. (Elektra King is the character's name.)

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: Alexander Bregstein's odyssey doesn't strike me so much as pathological and problematic as normal, encouraging and perhaps even, yes, natural. Cultural critics overly influenced by post-modernism seem to conveniently overlook the fact that people have long admired muscular men. Your article would have us believe that boys' insecurities are determined by Calvin Klein ads more than by the attention they get or don't get from girls in high school. If there is anything disturbing about your article, it is that Alexander is being shamed by adults for exhibiting a healthy, harmless and normal self-consciousness, if it is tinged with a little vanity.

title: A century of art, up-to-the-minute dining
description: It is now a decade since the Berlin wall fell, time enough for the tremendous discharge of energy resulting from this city's unification to find expression in a host of new museums, restaurants and developments occupying the space that was long the cold wilderness of Europe's fault line. To wander this area is to discover Berlin's essential fascination: the city's restless flux.

title: Group Puts Disaster Data on Internet
description: Environmental advocates have published new information on the Internet about the risks of chemical accidents, outflanking a new law that suppresses this kind of information on the ground that the details could help terrorists.

title: A Season Flavored by Eastern Europe
description: ZDENEK MACAL, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's music director, came to the United States after fleeing his homeland, Czechoslovakia, during the 1960's upheavals. The concerts scheduled for the orchestra's new season hark back to Mr. Macal's roots and pay tribute to other musicians who left Eastern Europe for political reasons. They play to his strong suit, or else he's homesick. Probably both.

title: Why Are We Working So Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; If Replay Is Going to Succeed, League Must Make It Problem Free
description: IT'S a familiar phrase in pro football: rookie mistakes. And when the National Football League season opens today, mistakes are sure to be made by its most controversial rookie: the new television replay system.

title: Many Media Voices of a Few Merged Masters
description: IF the media and telecommunications giants have their way, decades' worth of Federal rules intended to guard the marketplace of ideas may soon fall, all in the name of the Internet.

title: When the Greener Grass Is Concrete; Some New Yorkers Find Suburban Life Is Far From a Dream Come True
description: SIX years ago, Elissa and Matthew Bernstein made the big move. The weekend they learned they would have to leave their Park Slope duplex (''a wonderful apartment,'' Ms. Bernstein recalled wistfully) because the building had been sold, they fell in love with a 1906 Dutch Colonial with a huge wraparound porch in Maplewood, N.J., and decided that they and their two daughters would give suburban living a try.

title: Reflections on a Secret Life in Professional Sports
description: Dave Kopay, the former running back known as Psych for his violent intensity, was choking on tears. ''I know this isn't politically correct,'' he said, ''but I wish I had outed Jerry Smith. He might be alive today.''

title: A Wunderkind Discovers the Wonders of Film
description: MY NAME is Lester Burnham. This is my neighborhood. This is my street. This is my life. In less than a year I'll be dead. Of course I don't know that yet. In a way I'm dead already.

title: Sports of The Times; Out There Somewhere Is the Heir Apparent
description: I HAVE to admit that I have not spent very much time worrying where the next great American men's tennis player is coming from, or if he is going to come at all before Y3K. Maybe this will become a concern when Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi are finished carrying the men's game around on their backs like a sack of potatoes, but, definitely, no sooner than that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDDARD, ANITA P.
description: BEDDARD-Anita P. September 10, 1999, of Manhattan and Watch Hill, RI. Beloved wife of Michael; adored mother of Devon and Fred; cherished daughter of Edith Flaacke Pescatello and the late Michael; beloved sister of Michael, Mary, Paul, the late Edward, and devoted twin sister of Marjorie. She will be deeply missed by all her nieces and nephews. Friends may call Wednesday, September 15, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, 2-5 and 7-9PM. For further information, call 212-288-3500.

title: Library Thrives With a Common Touch
description: TO Hollywood, Queens is a place of big hair, nasal accents and gum-snapping; a natural setting for a comedy about lowbrows. But library experts around the country see things differently. To them, Queens is the borough of the bookworm.

title: Modern art in a city of the ancient
description: In Rome, all roads seem to lead to ruins. By the time a visitor has toured the Colosseum, stumbled around the stones and columns of the Forum, and inspected the newly restored Nero's palace, the Domus Aurea, there is often little energy left to explore Renaissance palaces, let alone 19th- and 20th-century art collections.

title: Williams Wisdom
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Slight Paucity of Pumpkins
description: The news from the pumpkin fields of Orange County is a bit unsettling. Thanks to the hot, dry days of July, this fall's pumpkin crop will come in shy of bumper. Farmers say the outlook is not all that bleak. But it is not bountiful, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELL, ANN
description: TELL-Ann, 81 years, on September 9th, peacefully at her home in New York City. Lovingly cared for by the staff of Jacob Perlow Hospice. Beloved mother of Philip Busch and his wife Darilyn. Affectionate grandmother of Kenneth. Dear sister of Marguerite Simonson and Bernice Getty. Cherished family member of Jane and Carol. Devoted friend and teacher of many. Singer and Broadway performer. A celebration of her life will be held on Sunday, September 26th at 2 PM at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue at 60th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, Anne's family would appreciate that donations be made in her memory to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, care of Beth Israel Medical Center, 317 East 17th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: In Police Beating Trial, Each Side Places Blame on Other
description: In a Brooklyn courtroom this week, prosecutors will continue to claim that two New York City police detectives acted like ''common thugs,'' viciously beating a man who was later struck and killed by a train in a nearby subway station.

title: Nigeria at Dawn of a Democracy Finds Making Laws Is No Picnic
description: His cell phone rang with increasingly urgent calls from his constituents: The quelea birds are here! Locusts are coming!

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: I am pleased that the issue of outcasts in schools is being discussed. I have a suggestion. Teachers and parents should stop saying to victims (I can only assume that young people continue to hear this, because I heard it so many times): ''Just ignore them. If they know it bothers you, they will keep doing it.''

title: That Never-Ending Spending
description: THE stack of beautiful shirts on the cover of Roger Rosenblatt's book about why Americans buy (and buy and buy) is exactly right. A visual reference to ''The Great Gatsby'' -- specifically, the moment in the novel when Jay Gatsby tries to woo Daisy Buchanan by heaping his exquisitely tailored blouses on a table -- it neatly sums up both the style and the substance of the subject matter within.

title: New Sounds on the Seine
description: ON the Quai Francois Mauriac in Paris, on the banks of the Seine, two institutions are staking a claim to uphold the glory of French culture. One is the late President Francois Mitterrand's intimidating Bibliotheque Nationale. Most architecture critics agree that while you can't fail to notice it, it is flawed as the home for a working national library. But just across the street, dwarfed by the library's four giant glass and steel towers, a boat moored on the Seine, painted blood-red and illuminated by a bright star atop the mast, is in its own small way doing something for France.

title: Last Swing of Summer for Boys of Autumn
description: WHAT sweeter sound of summer than the thwack of a bat connecting with a ball?

title: Ms. Hawks, Mr. Lederman
description: Kitty Hawks and Lawrence Lederman are to be married today at Hawks Nest, their house in Chappaqua, N.Y. Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

title: A Team That Makes Bright Ideas Brighter
description: JUST about everyone can come up with an idea for a new product. The trick is how to make it and how to sell it.

title: Barcelona Brings Flair to Its Classics
description: A TRIP to La Boqueria market is proof, if proof is needed, that Barcelona is a great eating city. As 10 years had elapsed since my last visit, I decided my restaurant list needed updating before a return trip this May. So I called half a dozen knowledgeable friends and got enough recommendations to keep me eating for a month.

title: A Nice Sort of Place
description: EVERY weekday morning as traffic floods the downtown business district here, women blow kisses from their cars to Patrolman Bill Biolsi. Officer Biolsi, who directs incoming cars at one of this city's busiest intersections, the corner of Bank and Main Streets, has known for 27 years on the beat what 200,000 daily commuters and about 50,000 residents are about to learn, if they do not already know it.

description: The Evolution of Jane

title: Odd Jobs
description: ALL QUIET ON THE ORIENT EXPRESS

title: Weird Science
description: THE PROFESSOR

title: Graffiti as Vandalism; 'Quality of Life' Is No Cliche
description: To the Editor:

title: Kira Wilson, Gordon Gould
description: Kira Anne Wilson, a daughter of Kay Lamm of Palo Alto, Calif., and Donald L. Wilson of Aptos, Calif., was married yesterday to Gordon Roberts Gould, a son of Sydney R. Shuman of New York and the late Edwin Jay Gould. The Rev. Timothy Mills, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the gardens of the Annadel Winery in Sonoma, Calif.

title: Footsteps Grow Louder as Red Sox Edge Yankees
description: Hideki Irabu glanced toward right field to watch a ball zooming into the tier box section yesterday for a home run and then quickly turned away and gazed at the grass. Irabu trudged behind the mound, raised his arms high as if he was doing jumping jacks and then arched his back. It was only the second inning and Irabu looked like the poster pitcher for exasperation. He was not alone.

title: September 5-11; The Canals That Wouldn't Wash
description: Perhaps it was a yearning for a deeper sense of history that made city officials and developers in Scottsdale, Ariz., push so hard for a grand redevelopment project called ''The Canals of Scottsdale.'' They envisioned a sort of Venice of the desert, with little barges to transport countless new tourists to shops and restaurants along the banks.

title: The Russian Money Trail
description: Despite great infusions of outside assistance and promises to carry out reforms, Russia appears to be sinking ever deeper into bankruptcy and corruption. The latest allegations are that Boris Yeltsin and his family may have taken bribes. Mr. Yeltsin dismissed the charge in a phone conversation with President Clinton last week, but there are also growing suspicions that aid from the International Monetary Fund and other institutions may have gone into the pockets of Russia's new oligarchs. With elections approaching in Russia and the United States, investigators must follow the trails of corruption and money laundering and re-examine policy decisions that may have aggravated the problem.

title: State of Vigilance
description: Westchester health officials are on the alert for signs of St. Louis encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus that has killed at least three victims in New York City.

title: For Broncos, Controversy Swirls a Mile High
description: Two straight Super Bowl victories, trademark offense, glimmering endorsements and a striking transformation from being that team in the mountains with the funky orange jerseys to becoming the football franchise by which all others are judged -- yes, everyone in Denver agrees: Life with the Broncos is so royal, so regal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ROSE NATALIE
description: RUBIN-Rose Natalie On August 21 in Los Angeles, California. Mrs. Rubin lived in New York City and was the widow of William Morris Rubin. Mrs. Rubin graduated from Radcliffe College in 1929, traveled to the Ukraine in 1935 to visit the village of her family's origin, and worked with the Russian-American Institute and Russian War Relief during World War II. In December 1956, she and her partner, Mr. Michael Stillman, founded Monitor Records. Today Monitor Records continues as part of the Smithsonian Recordings Collection. Rose is survived by devoted family members Nancy B. Mikelsons, Adam C. Mikelsons and Donald H. Goldhamer of Oak Park, Illinois, and Susan Rubin and Charles Degelman of Los Angeles, California. Rose was a fighter of injustice all her life, a wonderful friend and an inspiring mother. In her later years, she took particular delight in encouraging and supporting younger generations as they started their life journeys. She will be deeply missed, and her life will be celebrated by people of all ages. A memorial celebration will be held at her home in New York City on Saturday, October 16, details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations to Monthly Review, 122 West 27th Street, New York, NY 10001 will be deeply appreciated by her family.

title: September 5-11; Gore Unveils Health Plan
description: Vice President Al Gore became the first of the current crop of Presidential contenders to lay out a detailed plan for health policy. He promised to guarantee access to affordable health insurance for all children by 2005, through a number of steps, including expansion of the 1997 Children's Health Insurance Program.

title: RUNWAY; As You Like It
description: You want to look hot this season? Wear some olive drab topped by a poncho, a strap-on pouch and a knit scarf -- and make sure the net effect is shiny, padded, funnel-necked and could work as well on Mars as it would have at Woodstock. Too cluttered? Then just pick two of the aforementioned trends and spin them into some kind of sensible ensemble. All right, just one -- but cap it off with a knowing attitude of the type that can make even the most ludicrous choice work. Comfortingly enough, the season's ideas draw liberally from the past and the future, the understated and the extreme. Sample what you will -- oh, but make sure it's sleeveless.

title: Two Voices in the Booth Might Comfort Esiason
description: A cardinal rule of television production: three announcers in the booth are definitely better than two if that is what you have got, but two in the booth are far better if you have just shed one of the previous three. Got it?

title: Nonstop Perfectionist of Few Words and Much Work
description: COMPACT and loose-limbed, with the energy level of someone much younger -- say, the average 3-year-old -- Al Pacino practically bounces around the kitchen of his office suite high above midtown Manhattan. He lives in Los Angeles and surburban New York, but this is his working base, Chal Productions, the company he started with the acting teacher Charlie Laughton, his friend and mentor.

title: September 5-11; Whitman Quits Senate Race
description: Citing the overwhelming burden of running New Jersey and campaigning for the United States Senate, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman stunned her Republican colleagues and Democratic foes by saying she no longer planned to run for the seat being vacated by Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic incumbent, who is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, FLORENCE J.
description: GORDON-Florence J., 83, of Miami passed away September 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving R., devoted mother of Dale (Gordon), Douglas, Jill (Stephen) Kandell. Loving grandmother of Fredric (Hilary) Freeman, Jon (Hillary) Freeman, Marc Freeman, Scott (Lena) Kandell, and Brett Kandell. Adored greatgrandmother of Peyton, Dylan, Seth, and Sabrina. Loving companion Susan Rahming also survives. Services were held. The family requests memorial contributions be made to The American Cancer Society, or The American Heart Association.

title: Children's Books
description: I ONCE WAS A MONKEY

title: Correction
description: A chronology last Sunday with an article about Indonesia's nationhood described General Suharto's ascension imprecisely. A Communist coup was thwarted in 1965 by forces under the general; he assumed power gradually and became President in 1968.

title: Mr. Eichmann and Ms. Pillsbury
description: Wendy Edwards Pillsbury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson C. Pillsbury of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Byrne Eichmann, a son of Dr. Mary E. Avellone of Chicago and Fred C. Eichmann of Deerfield, Ill. The Rev. Tracy Hindman performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest, Ill., with Dr. Ronald H. Miller, the chairman of the department of religion at Lake Forest College, taking part.

title: The Hostess With the Most (Best Friends)
description: IF Buddy Hackett had ever laid eyes on the likes of Serena Altschul, Lulu de Kwiatkowski and Alexandra Von Furstenberg before, he wasn't showing it at Moomba last Tuesday night.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-12-99: Expert Opinion; Brand Illusions
description: This year, several familiar faces -- the Jolly Green Giant, Charlie the Tuna and Mr. Whipple -- returned from lengthy sabbaticals to reclaim their position at the helm of major advertising campaigns. In the intervening years, they have all undergone makeovers -- some striking, some subtle, but all telling. Herewith, four scholars of the field -- George Lois, chairman of the Lois/USA advertising agency; Warren Dotz, co-author of ''What a Character,'' an anthology about advertising icons; Dottie Enrico, former TV Guide advertising columnist, and Marshall Blonsky, a professor of communications at N.Y.U. -- weigh in on the changes.

description: The same week that a Republican candidate for President spent struggling to compose ever more tortuous nondenials of his drug use as a young man, a former Republican Presidential candidate could be seen in full-page advertisements forthrightly acknowledging his own use of another drug. Oh, I know: two completely different and incomparable situations; how unfair to Robert Dole and the Pfizer pharmaceutical company even to mention them in the same paragraph as George W. Bush and cocaine. One concerns an illegal drug that people take strictly for pleasure. The other concerns a legal drug that people take . . . well, also strictly for pleasure, but (almost) always with a prescription.

Indeed, Mr. McKellar was so perturbed that he decided to make his own. The result, his feature-film directing debut, is cheekily titled ''Last Night,'' and opens Nov. 5.

description: Most of the towering structures along the Hudson here are recent arrivals, having sprouted after real estate booms of the past two decades rained cash on a waterfront that was fertile for redevelopment.

description: THE dreary slice of New Brunswick at the southern end of the city's reviving downtown is not much to look at. It is occupied by a timeworn 1929 hotel and a huddle of small shops covering a triangular block.

title: When an Expense Is Not an Expense
description: CORPORATE profits are surging this year, to the delight of those who thought a slowdown might crimp results at United States companies. Earnings at S. & P. 500 companies rose 10.5 percent in the first quarter, 14.7 percent in the second.

title: American Standard With a Tuscan Turn
description: TOM SCHAUDEL is a restless restaurateur. He has opened and sold Panama Hatties in Huntington, the Spring Close House in East Hampton, the Eatery in Montauk and Eli's Road House in Plainview. Typical of his ventures was yet another restaurant, the Downtown Grill. He opened it, made it into one of the best restaurants in Montauk and then sold out. He also started the splendid 107 Forrest in Locust Valley, wasn't quite satisfied and so made it into the even better 107 Ocean Bistro. His next project was Lemongrass, an Asian fusion operation in Roslyn that, like the Ocean Bistro, remains an innovative, successful restaurant. A former American pub-style spot, 660 West in Garden City, is his latest enterprise. Never quite comfortable with the restaurant's format (that was favored by his partners) Mr. Schaudel, displaying his usual flair and imagination, has changed it to Maxwell's (742-4745), a Tuscan-style steakhouse. His tinkering has once again brought positive results. Additionally, Mr. Schaudel's impeccable timing takes full advantage of the current steakhouse craze while its Tuscan turn sets it apart.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; Durham Farm Fair Is Sprucing Up for 80th Birthday
description: THE Durham Agricultural Fair in central Connecticut, which marks its 80th birthday this year, is in the middle of a $2.6 million renovation that will make it look much newer when fairgoers arrive on Sept. 24. Wood-frame barns that went up in the 1970's are coming down to make way for two steel-and-concrete buildings that will total more than 55,000 square feet, and after the fair ends its three-day run on Sept. 26, construction will start on two more totaling an additional 60,000 square feet.

title: Everyone Who Was Anyone Will Be There
description: ART attractions in Europe this fall come in two varieties. One centers on a single artist. Velazquez will be awarded the royal treatment in Spain during his quatrocentennial year. In Paris, Chardin -- an artist some of us would travel a very long way to see -- is being honored with a 300th-anniversary retrospective.

title: A Nonlinear Way to Grasp the Past
description: THE painter James Ensor, the great Belgian eccentric of 19th-century art, developed his style looking at Bosch and Bruegel. He was thoroughly European. Jose Guadalupe Posada, his contemporary, a native of Aguascalientes, Mexico, apprenticed in the workshop of a renowned Mexican broadsheet publisher, Antonio Vanegas Arroyo. He became a printmaker of big, cheap, mass-produced engravings in Mexico City.

description: Marking a clear break with the caution of German foreign policy since World War II, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has laid out a new vision of his country's international role, describing Germany as ''a great power in Europe'' that will not hesitate to pursue its national interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMITIN, GLADYS (NEE EPSTEIN)
description: AMITIN-Gladys (nee Epstein), 88, of Waterville, NY, died peacefully in her sleep. Born Brooklyn, formerly Bronx, Kiamisha Lake, Saddle Brook and Elmwood Park, NJ. Daughter of Joseph and Ida Goldberg Epstein. Spouse for 64 years of Ernest Amitin. Leaves behind her devoted husband, daughter Merle Joy Cenicola (Philip) and son Dr. Mark Hall Amitin; three grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. She worked diligently as volunteer for the Red Cross, Saddle Brook Hospital Auxiliary, Boy Scouts and SBRP Jewish Center Sisterhood. In lieu of flowers, make donations to Actors Fund of America or World of Culture for Performing Arts, C/O Amitin, 55 Bethune Street #

title: Try Rabbit Sauteed, Baked or Grilled Instead of Chicken
description: AS I was shopping in a country supermarket, a woman at the meat counter said to me, ''I've been shopping here for 10 years, and you're only the second person I've ever seen buy rabbit.'' I was surprised. Several years ago it was hard to find fresh rabbit in stores, but now it is widely available. It is also showing up with increasing frequency in restaurants. Chefs like it because it has more taste than chicken and adapts easily to all kinds of seasoning.

title: Sports of The Times; Parents Were Right; Serena Could Play, Too
description: HER parents said she was the tough one. In the way that some parents know their children, Richard and Brandi Williams suggested that Serena could catch her sister Venus, and sooner than people might think.

title: Donor Transplant
description: The Westchester Medical Center has performed the first living-donor adult liver transplant in the region, Carin Grossman, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said. Only about 100 such operations have been performed worldwide.

The Rev. Michael Long performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Anglican Church in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico.

title: Chinese Grandmaster Wins World Women's Title Again
description: After blows were traded throughout the Women's World Championship of the International Chess Federation last month, Jun Xie of China recovered her title by defeating Alisa Galliamova of Russia by 8 1/2 to 6 1/2. The first half of the 16-game match was held in Kazan, Russia, and the second in Shengyang, China.

title: Standing Up To Sexism
description: Q. A year ago, my supervisor fired his assistant -- a woman -- for what he said was poor performance. The assistant filed a sexual harassment suit, which was settled out of court for a lump sum. Soon after, the supervisor was promoted to department head. I and the other women who report to him, however, are uncomfortable talking to him, particularly behind closed doors. Even before the suit, we observed that he didn't take women seriously. We consider his promotion a signal that women aren't valued by the company. How can we protect ourselves in this environment?

title: Reviving Painting as a Viable Medium
description: PAINTING, a mainstay of traditional art making, has fallen out of favor many times, especially over the last 30 years or so. Representational painting has had the toughest time, in part because it is not considered progressive enough to keep up with the latest innovations in technology as evidenced by the popularity of video, film or sound installations, machines and robotics, performance art and computer-generated or enhanced images.

title: 99 Bottles of Beer on the Wall, Brewed With a Personal Touch
description: Some people think there is little better in the world than coming home to a cold beer after a long day at work. That experience is even better if the beer you come home to has your own label on it because you made it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORBATY, JAN
description: GORBATY-Jan The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Jan Gorbaty on September 6, 1999 in New York City. A native of Poland, Jan Gorbaty was not only an acclaimed concert pianist, but also an indefatigable champion of the music of Frederic Chopin. Professor Gorbaty was President of the Chopin Foundation Council of Greater New York and a Vice President of the Chopin Foundation of the United States. A beloved teacher, he enriched the lives of countless young pianists in the United States and abroad. A Polish patriot in the truest sense, Jan Gorbaty will be deeply missed by all fortunate to know him. To his daughter, Zosia, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: A Celebrity Web Site For Gauging Fund Costs
description: So how much does it really cost to own that sizzling technology stock fund? And what will it cost you down the road?

title: Cry From Besieged City: Don't Forget East Timor
description: On the steep hillside behind the United Nations compound, armed men were shooting at refugees who were trying to flee to safety. In the crowded courtyard below, a police adviser from New Zealand was teaching little boys to play cricket.

title: Russians Say Bank Scheme May Not Be What It Seems
description: Irritated by allegations of money laundering, some of Russia's leading businessmen insist that the West has overlooked a simpler explanation for the billions of dollars that have flowed through several suspicious accounts at the Bank of New York.

title: WORD FOR WORD/How-to-Sleep Books; To Read, Perchance To Drool on Your Pillow
description: SLEEP, while never exactly out of style, seems really in vogue now. The Wall Street Journal this year proclaimed it ''the new status symbol.'' Business superstars like Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com and Marc Andreesen, a founder of Netscape -- in contrast with past overachievers like Thomas Edison, who scoffed at sleep -- brag about getting eight luxuriant hours regularly, to the doubtless envy of legions of sleep-deprived stiffs.

title: The Global Ceiling?
description: Women account for about half of the United States work force, though only 14 percent of those posted abroad by corporate America. But researchers at two universities say the opinion of some American managers -- that women cannot be effective overseas -- is not shared by either women working abroad or foreign managers.

title: Upgrading A Building's Elevators
description: TWO weeks ago, this space contained advice for co-op and condominium boards negotiating elevator maintenance contracts for their buildings. As pointed out in that column, a carefully drafted contract with a carefully chosen elevator company is essential for the safety and convenience of residents.

title: The Precarious Triumph of Human Rights
description: David Rieff's article (Aug. 8) is incomplete in its omission of any reference to the larger dimensions of the human rights movement outside the United States and western Europe. The leaders of this growing movement are diverse, brave and imaginative. They possess a long-range view that increasingly sees that the only lasting solutions come through the patient development of organizations, laws and enforcement and monitoring capacities.

title: THE NEW SEASON/ART AND ARCHITECTURE -- LOOKING AHEAD; Millennial Visions And Old Favorites
description: GARY SIMMONSNew York artist

title: The Wanderers
description: Once, nomadic tribes moved to satisfy basic human needs: a livable climate, abundant food and a nice, cozy place to sleep. Their clothing needs were equally basic: a few animal skins, and beads for special occasions. Today men travel more than ever, for reasons as complex as their wardrobes. Whether for a business trip to Chicago, a millennium party in Tahiti, an adventure in the Arctic or just a long commute from Ronkonkoma, these pages offer the right clothes for the right place at the right time.

title: The Engine Can Search, But Can It Really Dance?
description: Alta Vista, the Internet search engine majority-owned by CMGI Inc., is running ads -- its first -- in magazines like Business Week. The ads feature a black-and-white photograph of an evocative scene -- a young girl at a ballet lesson, for example -- superimposed with intriguing queries in conversational English.

Grant of Homewood, Ill. Lisel Burns, a leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the society's headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: Clifton Declares English Its Official Language
description: The Clifton City Council passed a resolution Tuesday that made the municipality the first in the state to formally declare English its official language.

title: Blocking Is Rule in Interclub Regatta
description: It does not come easy for racers when a regatta calls for the greater good of sailing. But team racing -- where one boat's first-place finish may keep the team from winning -- calls for tactics that bend the rules in uncommon ways.

title: Atlantic City's Day in the Sun Is Clouded
description: In 1921, a few town fathers some would say hucksters -- wondered how they could extend the huckstering season another week. They settled on a beauty pageant, and in the best huckster tradition they called it ''Miss America,'' even though they basically just rounded up a few local beauties of varying vocations to parade on the Boardwalk the weekend after Labor Day.

title: Bell Atlantic and Vodafone Near Cellular Deal
description: Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local telephone company, appears close to an agreement to combine its national wireless operations with the United States wireless assets of Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's largest wireless telephone company, in a deal that would create a separate company valued at between $70 billion and $80 billion, said people close to the talks.

title: At Zoo, a New Residence And New Residents
description: AS the building of a new reptile house nears completion at the Cape May County Park and Zoo, Jonnie Johnson-Gove is trying to insure that there will be animals to live there. A fire last year destroyed the old reptile house and killed about 190 animals. The new one should open sometime next month with the addition of an aquarium and invertebrate exhibition.

title: Capturing New York's Promethean Fire
description: A WORD to the National Endowment for the Humanities, corporate underwriters like Chase, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and viewers like you: Ric Burns is running out of space.

description: THE top pick in architecture this season is New York, the city entire. Architects, planners, developers, policy makers, civic groups: we are watching you. You get one chance to make a difference. Don't blow it.

title: Deirdre Vedovino And Derek Rossi
description: Deirdre Rose Vedovino and Derek Stephen Rossi were married yesterday by the Rev. Sean Jordan McConway at Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Trips to Explore The Family Tree
description: In July, Rabbi Bennett F. Miller of New Brunswick, N.J., and two cousins took a 10-day tour to the family's former village, Sasov, now in Ukraine, and to Poland. The trip was designed and researched for them by Miriam Weiner, owner of Routes to Roots in Secaucus, N.J.

title: A Scandal, Then a Charade
description: Responding to the scandal over alleged Russian money laundering, the Clinton Administration has offered two basic defenses of its Russia policy: 1) that it has long known about crime and corruption (Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott), and 2) that we must stay engaged with Russia for our national security (Samuel Berger, national security adviser). Both of these statements are true. So what is wrong with this picture?

title: Welcome to Steakhouse Row
description: NIGHT after night, the parking lots are jammed with expensive cars as patrons crowd into four restaurants along the two-mile strip of Northern Boulevard between Great Neck and Roslyn. In the spring of 2000, another one will open on the strip, and a sixth is 10 miles down the road in East Norwich.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Garfield, N.J.; Where Immigrants Feel Right at Home
description: A 10-FOOT-HIGH bronze statue of Christopher Columbus, Queen Isabella of Spain and a woman representing the New World stands on the shore of Dahnert's Lake in Garfield, a 2.08-square-mile city in Bergen County. Three sets of crystals at their feet symbolize Columbus's three ships, which set sail for the New World in 1492. Like Columbus, most residents of Garfield have come from Europe, and heavy immigration continues to this day.

title: Megan Weeks and Warren Adams
description: IN the summer of 1997, Warren William Adams met Megan Elizabeth Weeks when both worked in a small dilapidated office building behind a church in Cambridge, Mass. She was on the first floor, helping start up Virtual Emporium, an on-line consumer shopping guide. He, a founder and the chief executive of Planet All, an on-line address and networking service, worked on the second floor.

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: Compelling storytelling and relevant research made for great articles by Stephen S. Hall and Adrian Nicole LeBlanc on the state of suburban white boys (Aug. 22). So now that we are reminded that the pre- and early- teen-age years can be excruciatingly painful, and reminded by Littleton that the pain can be lethal, what are we going to do about it?

title: Second Start for Vegetables, Namely Spinach
description: THE vegetable patch has been somewhat less than glorious this year. Those who have been able to water some of their crops have been slightly successful, compared to their neighbors who haven't. Yet the searing heat felled many a potential crop and the vegetable plants set seed all too soon, which is called bolting. This bolting was most prominent with the leafy salad crops.

title: Hail to the . . . Author
description: It was only a book party, of course. The book was ''Faith of My Fathers,'' a family memoir by Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who in real life is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination. The party was a gathering at Michael R. Bloomberg's Park Avenue offices on Wednesday evening, organized by Mr. Bloomberg, Henry A. Kissinger and Georgette Mosbacher, who in real life is co-chairwoman of Mr. McCain's campaign. Some of the fattest checkbooks -- er, that is, most avid readers -- in the business world were there.

For Ms. Hill, giving starts at home, and young people in Essex County are feeling her generosity.

title: Our Towns; Fast Food? Not So Fast, Suburb Says
description: IT can be tough, being new in the area, and rich, and a little uncertain about which fork to use, as it were. You spend a lot of time worrying about your looks, for one thing. That goes for people, and it goes for places.

And they're all on display on television this week, in movies that span the decades from the Depression to the 1990's. But this bumper crop of humor sprouts from story lines freighted not only with the funny but also with high drama, keen perception and sharp conflict.

description: WITH good reason, farmers, home gardeners and many others cursed the severe drought that hit the Northeast this summer.

title: The World; The Germans Want Their History Back
description: THE Buchenwald concentration camp, where the Nazis killed more than 65,000 people, later became one of the holy shrines of the East German Communist state. The camp was a statutory rite of passage for generations of schoolchildren, who learned here how the reactionary Hitler regime slaughtered socialists and Communists.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Quantum Mystery
description: Though set amid raucous, drug-fueled parties in a Glasgow student apartment, H. R. McGregor's first novel, SCHRDINGER'S BABY (Morrow, $22), is an intense, intricate psychological mystery framed by the paradox of SchrRated PG-13dinger's cat -- a knotty thought experiment that ultimately poses the question: must an event be observed to be true? Juliet, the novel's narrator, is a practical-minded veterinary student who moves in with a group of eccentric strangers: Petruchio, a secretive, deadpan pharmacologist; a sexy drama student named Billy; Chris, an aging hippie; and Kerry, who Juliet says is ''just the kind of girl that I most disliked -- a kind of hysterical wild child.'' A clever, unstable, promiscuous actress, Kerry is also a gifted liar. Despite herself, Juliet falls in love with Kerry, who starts making sordid, questionable confessions: that she was until recently a professional dominatrix; that she's avoiding her new high-profile agents, a handsome married couple, because they want her to act in a porn film. Juliet ignores Kerry's tales, until one morning she stumbles across a woman's corpse in their front closet; before Juliet can get help, the body disappears. Then Kerry's agents go missing -- and Juliet suspects that Kerry is somehow involved. What evolves is less a traditional mystery than an engrossing mind game between Juliet and Kerry, who are polar-opposite personalities: as Kerry's compulsive lying couples with Juliet's sexual jealousy and increasingly wild paranoia, the truth in ''SchrRated PG-13dinger's Baby'' proves a very tricky thing to predict indeed. Megan Harlan

Both father and son famously brooded, at times to the verge of mental exhaustion, over how hard it was to give away money in an intelligent and useful fashion.

title: Classic Woodies Recall Another World
description: Bette Davis and Clark Gable drove them, the Beach Boys sang about them, Southern Californian surfers of the 1960's cruised in them, and now, after a long public absence, the woodies of yesteryear are back in the limelight. The Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles is honoring these curious old cars through Jan. 17 in an exhibition entitled ''Surf's Up! The Great American Woody.'' Aptly named, woodies used a substantial amount of wood in their bodies, creating a unique look.

title: Summer's Torpor Is Lingering
description: The kids may be back in school, but Wall Street is still in a languid summer mood. Worries persist that the Federal Reserve Board will push up short-term interest rates again next month. But as the August producer price figures showed on Friday, inflation remains in check. That means it's all right to worry, but a bit rash to stampede out of stocks.

title: Why Do Big Stars Do Little Movies? To Be Actors

title: A Generation Moves Past 'Promising'
description: AS the year's most auspicious film season approaches, at least this is certain: the approach of the century's end will not go unexploited by Hollywood. But for sheer promotional chutzpah, it may be hard to beat the trailer for ''Lost Souls,'' which uses sci-fi ominousness to heighten its pitch: ''They had their 2,000 years,'' one character declares. ''Now it's our turn.'' That will be one extra reason to brace oneself for the movie onslaught this fall.

title: Hearts in Atlantis
description: Bobby Garfield's father had been one of those fellows who start losing their hair in their twenties and are completely bald by the age of forty-five or so. Randall Garfield was spared this extremity by dying of a heart attack at thirty-six. He was a real-estate agent, and breathed his last on the kitchen floor of someone else's house. The potential buyer was in the living room, trying to call an ambulance on a disconnected phone, when Bobby's dad passed away. At this time Bobby was three. He had vague memories of a man tickling him and then kissing his cheeks and his forehead. He was pretty sure that man had been his dad. Sadly missed, it said on Randall Garfield's gravestone, but his mom never seemed all that sad, and as for Bobby himself...well, how could you miss a guy you could hardly remember?

title: See You in Two Weeks!
description: A co-worker goes on vacation, and you're asked to assume her duties, often in addition to your own. You have no idea how to do her work -- but, hey, you're a team player, right? It can be an opportunity to prove yourself, but it can also be a disaster. In a depopulated workplace, what have been your greatest adventures and misadventures? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Sam Shepard In a British Translation
description: CARTER raises thoroughbred race horses in Kentucky. He wears expensive suits and alligator shoes, and he's never far from his cellular phone. A call on that phone summons him to the cruddy low-rent bungalow in Cucamonga, Calif., where his former partner, Vinnie, lives. Vinnie is in some kind of trouble and is calling in his chips. Fifteen years before, the two had pulled a race track scam involving look-alike horses. When the local racing commissioner discovered the switch, they lured him into a scandal that cost him his job. Carter left Cucamonga with his winnings and with Rosie, the woman he and Vinnie both loved; Vinnie stayed behind and festered.

description: IT looks like a top-heavy fraction whose value is a bit larger than Pi. But to trend watchers, the expression ''24/7'' has worked its way into the language as an abbreviation for a clock-defying world where financial markets run continually and news channels promise never-ending headlines (along with weather and traffic reports).

title: Just Dial S.O.S.
description: Carnival Cruise Lines now has a 24-hour telephone service that might prevent passengers from missing the boat -- literally. With so many cruise passengers flying to their port of embarkation, flight delays loom as vacation disasters. Carnival's hot line, (877) 885-4856 in the United States or (305) 406-4779 (collect) from other countries, offers advice and help in emergencies. If a call comes in after regular business hours, it will be forwarded by pager to a Carnival representative, who can then arrange the most expedient transportation from airport to dock, or -- in extreme cases -- put the passenger's airline to work on a flight to the ship's first port of call.

title: The Nation; The Face of Guns: Who Owns Them and Why
description: THERE are about 240 million guns in America, according to Federal estimates, a total that gives the country one of the highest per-capita rates of gun ownership in the world. For gun-rights proponents, the large numbers of guns are a reflection of a fundamental freedom and a sign of national strength.

title: Back to School, 1958
description: In the middle of March 1958, there's a notice in the paper, ''Vacancy for English teacher at McKee Vocational and Technical High School, Staten Island.'' The assistant principal, Miss Seested, examines my license and takes me to see the principal, Moses Sorola, who doesn't move from his chair behind the desk where he squints at me through a cloud of smoke drifting from his nose and from the cigarette in his hand. He says this is an emergency situation. The teacher I'd be replacing, Miss Mudd, has made an abrupt decision to retire in the middle of the term. He says teachers like that are inconsiderate and make life hard for a principal. He doesn't have a full English program for me, I'd have to teach three classes in Social Studies every day, two in English.

title: SHOOTING STARS; Take This Job And Shovel It
description: Horatio Sanz has the most dangerous job in the world, and if his predecessors are anything to go by, he might want to take out an all-encompassing life insurance policy. Sanz is going into his second season as ''Saturday Night Live'''s comic heavyweight, following in the deep footsteps of the former cast members and fellow Second City alums John Belushi and Chris Farley.

title: Miss Urbanski And Dr. Giller
description: Elizabeth Ann Urbanski and Dr. Graham Leslie Giller were married yesterday at St. Catherine's Church in Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. David Marcotte, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Mothers and Daughters, Tangled Together Anew
description: ALWAYS lurking in the wings, waiting for a lull in the conversation, jokes about mothers enjoyed a flurry of activity this summer. There was the New Yorker cartoon showing the corpse laid out in the funeral parlor, lifeless but not speechless, berating her son for not wearing a tie. And the joke making the rounds of the Hamptons might have come from a Woody Allen movie: What's the difference between a Jewish mother and a Rottweiler? The Rottweiler eventually lets go. Then real life supplied juicier fodder in the story of a Presidential toddler in Arkansas, torn between devouring mother and grandmother love -- and proved there's no ethnic monopoly on the stereotype of maternal excess. Even when there's a male parent who's a partner in dysfunction, the woman from Venus takes the hit.

title: September 5-11; Detroit Teachers End Strike
description: It was back to school for teachers in Detroit after a strike that lengthened summer vacation by more than a week for the city's 180,000 public school students and gave their parents child-care headaches. The teachers voted to return to classrooms after their union, the Detroit Federation of Teachers, reached a tentative three-year contract agreement with the Detroit School Board that gave them raises and promised smaller class sizes next year.

title: More Woes for Synagogue With Caterer Under Its Wing
description: Three months after the city ordered a catering business operating inside the Shaare Zion Synagogue on Ocean Parkway to scale back its cooking, officials have issued violations to the synagogue and the caterer for failing to move the business out of the residential area.

title: The Esthetics of Art And the Public Good
description: I read with interest the article ''Is It Really Art Or Is It Obscene?'' (July 11). Why are decision makers paying attention to individual complainers of what the public is permitted to see? When I had the privilege of seeing Michelangelo's David in Florence, it was with tears in my eyes at the sheer beauty and majesty of the statue.

title: The Battle Against Mold and Mildew
description: MOST people think of mold and mildew as minor household annoyances that can be dealt with by spraying with a bathroom cleaner. This is effective for small patches of mold, but it's not sufficient to deal with larger infestations, which can become a serious health hazard. Some environmental inspectors estimate that at least 10 percent of the houses in the United States have enough mold contamination to make the occupants sick.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-12-99: The Ethicist; Car Talk
description: I have been taking my car to the same great mechanic for years. Today I called to change an appointment; I'd forgotten a lunch date with a friend and, as I happened to mention, his boyfriend. Upon hearing this, my mechanic spewed forth a torrent of anti-gay rage. I was offended and horrified, and I told him so. Obviously, I'm not paying him for his personal beliefs. So am I justified in never taking my car to him again? Or should I overlook his nasty beliefs and keep patronizing his shop? -- E. S., Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Copenhagen Celebrates Historic Neighborhood

Created during Denmark's Golden Age reign of Frederick V (1746-1766), Frederiksstaden's elegantly geometric street plan was an architectural homage to the 300th anniversary of the Danish-Norwegian throne.

Interment immediately following at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastingson-the-Hudson

title: John McHugh, 87, Professor at Stony Brook
description: Dr. John Laurence McHugh, a former professor of marine resources at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, died on Aug. 20 at a hospital in Fairfax, Va. He was 87.

title: Three Years Later at Hilton, A Deal Maker Plays His Card
description: STEPHEN F. BOLLENBACH, president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, likes to make playful $1 bets with his company executives about the price of Hilton's stock. He stuffs the dollar bills representing those wagers into the frame of a picture -- of him and Barron Hilton, the company chairman -- hanging on the wall behind his desk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUKENFELD, M. RONALD
description: BRUKENFELD-M. Ronald Died peacefully the evening of September 7 at the age of 86. He was the beloved son of the late Morris and Sarah Brukenfeld and brother of the late Carl Brukenfeld, Frances Englander and Edith Hirsch. He spent his working life in the investment community, a Member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1935 to 1980 and was a former Governor of the NYSE. He continued to pursue his interest in the world of investments, going to the office past the age of 84, until the onset of his long illness. Throughout many years of his life, he had a great interest in Mt. Sinai Hospital and was a Trustee since 1961. Though diverted from his original plan to teach English literature, which he did at Columbia, he maintained throughout his life an avid interest in the written word, in books, the theatre and sports. He is survived by his longtime loving companion, Annette Edwards. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Chester Hirsch. He was the cherished uncle of Edward and DiAnne Hirsch, John and Elizabeth Hirsch, Richard Hirsch, Dick and Mimi Brukenfeld, Jane Holzer, Betty Jane and Alan Goldboro, and was the adoring great uncle of Douglas, Karen, Elisa, Nancy, Catherine, Mark, Bruce, Carla and Rustin. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's at 81 Street and Madison Avenue on Monday, September 13 at 11:30AM. Interment to follow At Union Field Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Mt. Sinai and/or Columbia College, Carl M. Brukenfeld Memorial Scholarships Fund. A man of great wit, charm and vibrant personalitiy, he will be greatly missed.

title: Talking to the Teacher
description: '''Tis'' picks up where ''Angela's Ashes'' left off, with Frank McCourt's return to New York City. He moves to a furnished room on Third Avenue, works for a while at the Biltmore and is drafted during the Korean War, which proves to be his salvation. He goes to New York University on the G.I. Bill and becomes a teacher, retiring in 1987. In August, he agreed to sit down with the magazine and talk about education and about writing.

title: Party to Divorce
description: Randy Cohen nearly always hits the mark on ethical questions (The Ethicist, Aug. 22). But this is one of the few times that he missed. I believe he should have advised M.M. to inform the wife that her plan to scare her husband was a sadistic and possibly dangerous trick and an expression of hostility that she ought to explore with a therapist. Then warn the husband. (The suggestion that he seek a divorce lawyer was clever but frivolous.)

title: Moss Preparing to Dance Through Special Attention
description: It was Jets cornerback Aaron Glenn who got an up-close-and-personal look at the next step in the evolution of a superstar. Before Glenn's eyes, Randy Moss, the Minnesota Vikings wide receiver, departed from his one-dimensional realm of being only a deep threat.

title: Coast Guard Studies Substance That Has Washed Ashore
description: Five to seven tons of an off-white rubbery substance that washed up on the beaches between Atlantic City and Strathmere in Cape May County has been cleaned up, and the Coast Guard is trying to identify it.

title: Ms. Boasberg And Mr. Bierly
description: Margaret Eve Boasberg, a daughter of Sarah and Emanuel Boasberg of Washington, was married yesterday to Christopher David Bierly, a son of Carol and Darryl Bierly of Nazareth, Pa. James E. Boasberg, the bride's brother and a civil marriage officiant, performed the ceremony at Chesterwood, the former home of the sculptor Daniel Chester French in Stockbridge, Mass.

title: A welcoming setting for appreciating Pushkin
description: You don't have to be Russian or a fanatic about Aleksandr Pushkin, the beloved 19th-century poet, to enjoy the ample and elegant museum dedicated to his life, his times and his work, situated in a stately mansion in the heart of Moscow. Having recently completed a three-year renovation, the museum, with a glass-covered atrium at its center, is an oasis of a Russia that disappeared after the 1917 revolution, a Russia of country estates and musical evenings, of ball gowns and card games, with an intriguing collection of Pushkiniana sprinkled throughout.

title: Currie Hamlin, Michael Keller
description: McCurrah Keller Hamlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Gordon Hamlin Jr. of Freeport, Me., was married there yesterday to Michael Roland Keller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Keller of Pacific Palisades, Calif. The Rev. Andrew Nagy-Benson performed the United Church of Christ ceremony at the South Freeport Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, PATRICK
description: BYRNE-Patrick Born Dublin, Ireland June 29, 1919. Died in East Surrey Hospital, Redhill, Surrey, England on August 8, 1999, age 80. Inquiries to: Magdalen Lawler, SND, c/o T4505 TIMES 10108.

title: Be Patient: The Best May Be Last, After the Fall
description: HERE is the season's only foolproof advice: take a deep breath and wait until January. That brings the debut of what promises to be one of the most engaging new series, ''Malcolm in the Middle,'' and the return of ''The Sopranos.''

title: Avoid the Status Quo With a Little Adventure
description: AM I the only one who finds the years yielding fewer opportunities for adventure? It is so much easier to slide by with the status quo. We avoid rocking the boat in our lives. If you see the show at the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan about the Shackelton Antarctic expedition aboard the Endurance, ''rocking the boat'' will take on new meaning.

title: Afloat but Not Adrift, Residents Call House Barges Home
description: SUE SANCHEZ and her 15-year-old son, Justin Spratt, are at home on the water. Standing on the floating deck that serves as their backyard, Ms. Sanchez looks out over Seaman's Creek and a breathtaking view of Fire Island, Jones Beach and the Atlantic beyond.

title: Coming Up in London, A Critic's Calendar
description: IF you want an example of the extent to which London has superseded New York as the capital of the English-language theater, and maybe also an indication of why we critics sometimes suffer from a medical syndrome known as drama fatigue, consider just one week of openings this fall. It's that of Oct. 11.

title: PULSE; Browsing to a Beat
description: Opening an after-hours bookstore next to a nightclub might sound like an earsplittingly bad idea, but at Incommunicado Books, it has its advantages. During breaks in the music at Tonic, a rock spot on Norfolk Street, clubgoers stroll to the adjacent bookstore to browse, drinks in hand. Customers flow the other way, too. When a reading by Henry Flesh and Lauren Sanders drew three times the store's 30-occupant capacity, Gary Hustwit, Incommunicado's owner, led the crowd to the dark stage next door. And so it goes from 6 to midnight at the pastel-painted literary salon, which opened in June. Graduate students share the couch and chairs with musicians like Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth and authors like Blake Nelson, whose ''Girl,'' a cult novel, is now a Cinemax movie starring Dominique Swain. The store carries titles from 30 independent publishers, including Mr. Hustwit's Incommunicado imprint. Skimming books like ''Bomb the Suburbs,'' an urban graffiti chronicle by William Upski Wimsatt, invites chat -- as long as you can hear it. DANA DICKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MOSES H.
description: COHEN-Moses H. We are deeply saddened by the death of our long time, dear friend Moe, who brought warmth, joy and sweetness into the lives of everyone who knew him. He will be missed by all. Naomi, Ed and Family

title: East Timor Isn't Kosovo
description: Because we bombed in Kosovo doesn't mean we should bomb Dili,'' said Samuel Berger, the national security adviser, about the atrocities in East Timor, which seem to have been committed by militias supported by elements of the Indonesian military. Well, why not?

title: Chekhov Without The Words
description: AS a conceptual director, Martha Clarke is a creative body in motion. On a recent morning in her airy Greenwich Village apartment (many years ago the home of Marcel Duchamp), she was brimming with activity. She was in the middle of casting ''Hans Christian Andersen,'' her deromanticized Broadway musical version of the 1952 movie. The show is planned for this season, and she was still looking for an actor for the now misanthropic title role (played in the film by Danny Kaye). The Irish playwright and novelist Sebastian Barry, who is writing the new book for the musical, had just arrived in New York on one of his periodic visits to work with Ms. Clarke, and he had narrowly missed running into Christopher Hampton on the stairway. Mr. Hampton had been there to confer with Ms. Clarke about their projected Broadway version of ''The Blue Angel,'' a play with music based on the Marlene Dietrich movie and the original Heinrich Mann novel.

title: Tuning Out, Painlessly
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bathtub of One's Own
description: MAYBE I saw the Audrey Hepburn movie ''Funny Face'' too many times in my infancy, and it caused some kind of profound subliminal imprinting. That would explain my lifelong fixation with hotel rooms. I love them. The Paris hotel room in that film -- with heart-stopping views, museum-quality antiques, and enough square footage for Fred Astaire dance numbers -- is what I yearn for each time I make a reservation on a toll-free line.

title: September 5-11; Yeltsin Shrugs Off Rumors
description: So, Boris, what about those rumors you might be caught up in the scandal involving money-laundering and the Swiss construction company that got a big contract to fix up the Kremlin? Yeah, that scandal.

title: More Women Are Taking to Waters
description: MARIE PASTORE of Avon said it was just dumb luck. While out with a fishing guide last year, she achieved the ultimate in fly-fishing nirvana: a super slam.

title: Despite His Early Self, a Poet Proved a Teacher Wrong
description: ''DON'T ever try to go to college; you'll never pass freshman English,'' Gerald Stern's high school teacher, Mrs. Preston, told him. He was ''a thug who hung out in pool halls and got into fights,'' he recalls. ''I read all the time, but never did any of the work and flunked all my courses.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A Chance to Reward Pure, Mature TV
description: IN 1948, when the Emmy Awards were first given out, the trade paper Variety wrote, ''Emmy Oscar's kid sister, made her debut.'' Poor little Emmy went reeling into an inferiority complex from which she has yet to recover. If Emmy were an actual person she would have spent the last decades on a psychiatrist's couch whinning that she'll never measure up to Oscar: she'll never give her winners the same commercial boost, the stars who come to her party will never be as glamorous or important and, the ultimate insult, not as many people will watch her television show. And television is supposed to be hers! It's enough to make a viewer shout: Grow up! (And while you're at it, lose the cutesy metaphor - you're not a real person.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Fighting Fiercely for a Job With No Office
description: The job carries no salary and no physical office, but the battle is fierce nonetheless over who will be the two district leaders for the Democratic Party on the Lower East Side. The central issue in the election, which will be held Tuesday, is housing.

title: Lives; The Home Front
description: April 29, 1999, Burrel, Albania. Florim Lajqi, a student at John Jay College, in New York, arrives in Albania with 200 other American volunteers to fight in the Kosovo Liberation Army. ''I have no fear, no hesitation,'' he says. ''I know I'm doing the right thing.''

title: The Slacker Temp
description: I read Randy Cohen's column (The Ethicist, Aug. 22) with disbelief. A temp is not doing his job and his supervisor wonders if he should do anything about it? No one put a gun to anyone's head in this scenario. A supervisor has a contract with his company: he does a job and he gets paid for it. Similarly, the temp has a contract, and the company has a right to expect competent work. Cohen suggests that the supervisor try to get the temp more money and a more interesting variety of responsibilities. It would be unethical to reward incompetence when others perform acceptably.

description: Annabelle Hoyt Karper, the daughter of Mrs. Stephen J. Karper of Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Karper, was married yesterday to Forrest Edwin Vultee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Vultee Jr. of Camden, Me. The Rev. Thomas M. Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket.

description: New York State and local health officials confirmed yesterday that a 79-year-old Gansevoort man was the second person to die in an outbreak of E. coli bacteria infections in the Albany area.
