description: Now you can always have Paris -- sort of -- even if you never get to France. New York, Venice, Monte Carlo and Luxor have all been paid homage in the form of Las Vegas hotels, so the Paris Las Vegas Casino Resort seemed overdue.

title: The Return of the Adjustable Mortgage
description: DAVID HOCHEISER, a loan officer at Bank of America Mortgage in Fairfield, N.J., is struck by how much the mortgage market has changed in recent months.

title: There's Ice Cream. Then There's Gelato.
description: A commuter heads home from the city, grabs a newspaper in the Weehawken ferry terminal and treats herself to a gelato cone, bought right in the New York Waterways' kiosk. A couple playing the slots in Atlantic City get their dish of gelato after dinner at Atrium in Trump Plaza. A shopper picks up his pint at the Fairway Market in Fort Lee.

title: Arrington Rises, Fending Off Pitt
description: LaVar Arrington, Penn State's much-admired linebacker, displayed diverse dimensions today in a 20-17 victory over Pittsburgh before 96,127 worried fans in Beaver Stadium. In the first quarter, Arrington acted like a wrestler, grappling with Pitt's punter, and then with a Pitt player who came to the punter's aid. This display earned Arrington two penalty flags and a few questions about his poise.

title: Susan Kelly and Jolyon Welsh
description: Susan Lynley Kelly, an editor at The New Yorker, and Jolyon Rimmer Welsh, a British diplomat, were married yesterday. The Rev. Darwin Price performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: The Herbal Connection
description: Open Louisa and Alex Hargrave's '98 Blanc Fume (sauvignon blanc) in the kitchen, take a sip, and your eyes alight reflexively on the s little spice bottles in the cupboard. The herbal association is inescapable.

title: Ellen Humphreys, Edward Dowd
description: Ellen Reilly Humphreys, a daughter of Henry J. Humphreys of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Eileen Kelly Humphreys, was married there yesterday to Edward John Dowd, a son of Margaret and Patrick Dowd, also of Bronxville. Patrick J. Ahern, a retired Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: When Suffolk Refused To Waive Sales Tax
description: What gives Steven Hackeling the right to unilaterally decide Suffolk should not take part in the week that sales tax abatement took place [''Sales Tax Frustrates Shoppers in Suffolk,'' Sept. 5]? I note his liberal use of the pronoun ''I'' in your quotes from him. We have a Legislature and it should make the decisions, no matter what he thinks is right or wrong, or what is prudent. We should all remember Mr. Hackeling and what he cost the shoppers and the Suffolk businessmen when election time rolls around.

title: From Sprawl to Crawl to Enthrall
description: When the cloverleaf interchange at Routes 4 and 17 here was built in 1932, it was considered a feat of engineering. In the decades since, it has become a symbol of urban sprawl as well as a source of congestion and colorful language.

title: ON THE MAP; In The Groove
description: Taye Diggs looks good in clothes. He looks good out of clothes. Dude or nude, he has a secret weapon in his arsenal of style: movement. He brings to mind another dancer/singer/actor whose reputation was made on Broadway: Fred Astaire.

title: Commercial Property/Long Island; From Shabby to Chic for Hotels in the Hamptons
description: WHEN Dede Gotthelf, a Manhattan developer, walked into the 90-room Southampton Inn, a seedy 1970's motel on Hill Street, in the spring of 1998 she looked beyond the dingy lobby and envisioned a sparkling transformation that has taken little more than a year to realize.

title: Carol Davidson, Matthew Cragoe
description: Dr. Carol Foote Davidson, the daughter of the Rev. Patricia Foote Davidson of Killingworth, Conn., and the late Robert Treat Hooker Davidson, was married yesterday to Dr. Matthew Frind Cragoe, the son of Desmond Cragoe of Edinburgh and Elizabeth Cragoe of Trawsmawr, Wales. The Rev. Dr. Martin Dudley performed the Anglican ceremony at the Church of St. Bartholomew the Great in London.

title: A Sampling From the Golden Age of the Woodstock Colony
description: WOODSTOCK will always conjure up a rock festival, but away from the clamor Woodstock means something else -- a community of artists that exists to this day. But its golden age was from 1902 to the 1950's. Work from that period is the focus of an affecting exhibition at the Bruce Museum, whose curator is the museum's executive director, Holister Sturges.

title: Novartis Plans to Close Its 88-Acre Site in Summit
description: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation, Summit's largest taxpayer, is selling its property there to consolidate its New Jersey operations in East Hanover, the company announced last week.

title: Who Stole Fashion's Show?
description: MARK MONTANO is a believer. A designer and New York boutique owner who is introducing his collection for spring 2000 today, he insists that the runway is still the launching pad that can send a fashion newcomer rocketing into the big leagues. No strategy, he argues, is too showy or shrill to help him reach that goal. ''You want to get as big a hoopla as you can at the show,'' said Mr. Montano, now in his second season under the tents in Bryant Park. ''If you run out on the runways naked at the end, all the better.''

title: The Slacker Temp
description: At first, I thought I was reading a spoof. Then I realized that your ethicist was serious. The manager should try to get the slacker more money to raise his morale but not report his poor performance! Or worse, redistribute the dull work. According to these egalitarian ethics, Cohen would have the publisher of your paper put in a stint each day delivering papers or sweeping floors so that delivery drivers and janitors can have a little variety in their jobs and try their hands at strategic planning.

title: For New Coaches, Ambitions Are Grand, Even if Teams Aren't
description: Nine head coaches are in new roles in the National Football League this season and all are intent on infusing their franchises with wisdom and style. In most of their situations, plenty of infusing is required.

title: Little Sister Becomes the Stardust Half
description: Using her racquet like a stun gun to pound and paralyze her savvy opponent, the No. 1-ranked Martina Hingis, into submission yesterday, Serena Williams, the 17-year-old follow-up act to her big sister phenom, Venus, captured the women's championship at the United States Open in her first appearance in a Grand Slam final.

The Postal Service moved out in 1990 to new facilities in Spring Creek, Brooklyn, and the building's only remaining user is a local post office branch.

description: Few issues vex humankind more profoundly than the question, ''What are you doing with your life?'' Happily, I've found the answer: ''Ask my shirt.''

description: MARGARITA RODRIGUEZ works as a clerk for Century 21, the discount department store. She is 22 and lives with her 9-month-old baby, Rafael Leroux. Most people her age, especially if they hold jobs like hers, don't own their living spaces.

title: Katharine Loos, Richard Thomas
description: Katharine Sherwood Loos, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Loos of Milwaukee, was married yesterday to Richard Henry Thomas, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. description: AFTER months of brushing off complaints that whistles on its new diesel locomotives are unnecessarily loud and intrusive, the Long Island Rail Road has agreed to investigate.

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: Hall's article was insightful and thorough. However, his conclusion -- that this trend ''seems to herald a dubious, regressive form of equality'' -- struck me as off the mark. Rather, I would argue that this obsession continues a tradition of male dominance. It seems to me that bodily socialization disempowers young women both literally and figuratively while empowering (at least some) adolescent boys to behaviors ranging from harassment to murder. Might it be that as women chip away at academic, professional and athletic terrain that was once exclusively male, men are feeling the need to assert their dominance in the bluntest and most obvious ways, and in the only area in which women truly cannot compete as equals?

title: Fixing Public Education Through Competition
description: In his attack on charter schools [''The Side Effects of Charter Schools,'' Opinion, Aug. 29], Marc F. Bernstein states that reduced financing for public schools will result in poorer academic results. The fact is that spending on public schools on Long Island has soared in the past decade with no improvement in student achievement. In reading tests given statewide in January, nearly 40 percent of fourth graders on Long Island scored below the state's academic standard. Close to half of the students entering Long Island's community colleges need remedial courses and many cannot follow written directions.

title: Incredible Hulks
description: THE MALE BODY

title: Brainstorming at 7. Kayaking at 11. Now That's Teamwork.
description: WINGATE INNS INTERNATIONAL wanted to hold its first chain-wide conference in a resort big enough to accommodate 305 people for four days, yet small enough to convey a sense of intimacy during meals and receptions. Because the working sessions would deal with financing, risk management and similarly unexciting topics, Wingate also wanted a range of recreational options where guests could unwind.

title: How to Strengthen Title I
description: Democrats and Republicans in Congress are thrashing out changes to Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, a program that has traditionally assured impoverished children special courses like remedial reading and math that they desperately need to succeed. Republicans are hoping to expand on a dismal proposal passed last year that gives the states too much discretion to redirect Federal education financing that was traditionally targeted at the poorest students. The Democrats, led by Representative George Miller of California, are fighting to maintain targeted financing and to strengthen Title I by requiring that states phase out the widespread use of uncertified teachers and close the yawning achievement gap that now exists between poor and middle-class students.

title: The World: Command Performance; America Talks and (Some) Others Listen
description: ON the very day that the United States helped bring one more Middle East peace agreement to fruition and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright witnessed its signing, a crisis broke out at the other end of the world. Again, Washington was called on to find a solution. But this time, in East Timor, the United States found it not so easy to make the problem go way by simply swaggering in at the opportune moment and brandishing its influence.

title: Miss Walker, Mr. Fioriglio
description: Rosemary Smith Walker, a daughter of Helen and Philip S. Walker of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Fioriglio, a son of Frances and Thomas Fioriglio of Seaford, N.Y. title: Bread and Water, and for Kayakers, Nourishment for the Soul

As yesterday's brilliant morning sun lit up the blue-green-gray river, Dr. Gluck took off his big floppy all-weather hat and put on a knitted yarmulke decorated with bright flowers. He produced two slices of wheat bread, tore a chunk off one and passed them around.

description: On several levels, there are signs the 1999 National Football League season will be the most pivotal one for the Giants franchise since the team's 1990 Super Bowl season.

title: Hey Folks, This Round of Oxygen's on Me
description: BREATHING is becoming a luxury. I stopped in Port Jefferson the other day, after a long drive down I-95 in Connecticut and up the Long Island Expressway. For several hours, I had been breathing an invigorating mixture of carbon monoxide and what the environmentalists call ''particulates,'' more commonly called dirt. My lungs hadn't tasted clean air for hours.

title: Wild Boys
description: 1. During the Great Depression, there were 250,000 teen-agers riding the rails in America. In 1933, Warner Brothers -- as part of its series of ''social conscience'' films of that period -- released ''Wild Boys of the Road,'' the action director William Wellman's vivid depiction of young itinerant men who hopped freight trains in search of work. 2. ''Riding the Rails,'' a 1997 documentary, put a new spin on the romantic vision of that time. By interviewing survivors, the filmmakers Michael Uys and Lexy Lovell retold the old hobos' stories. The film won several awards, including a Best Documentary Director prize from the Directors Guild of America. 3. These photographs were taken at the Black River & Western Railroad, a tourist and freight train operation running between Flemington, Ringoes and Lambertville, N.J. (908-782-6622). The attractions here include 10 diesel engines and some boxcars on an R.I.P. track. Depending on the day, explains a volunteer, R.I.P. means either ''repair in progress'' or ''rust in place.'' 4. Ralph Lauren may be the original purveyor of the fake weathered look associated with poor cowboys and genteel poverty, but now many of the men's clothes for fall are weathered, washed, pilled and even ripped. Call it distress for success. (Jeans from Polo Jeans Company Ralph Lauren, $58. At Polo Jeans Company stores nationwide.)

title: Crossing Fingers, Broadway Sings a Hopeful Tune
description: WHERE, you may well ask, do you find hope in a field of ashes?

title: The View From/New Canaan; Town-Wide Deer Hunt Polarizes Residents
description: WITH a make-believe arrow through his head and a T-shirt stating ''Bowhunting Is Not a Joke,'' Larry Greeley kept a vigil against deer hunters as he paced in front of the Fleet Bank on Elm Street in New Canaan. Holding a petition, he approached passersby on a recent Saturday morning, most of whom at first chuckled but then grew serious as Mr. Anthony, a New Canaan resident for 15 years, gave his pitch.

title: Going To Extremes
description: One went to the moon. One reached the south pole in 1928. explorers club members know how to risk their necks - And cover them in style.

title: Sherry Berenson, Richard Schriefer
description: Sherry Lynn Berenson, the daughter of Miriam Berenson and Dr. Conrad Berenson of Woodbury, N.Y., was married on Monday evening to Richard Hermann Schriefer, the son of Phyllis and Richard Schriefer of Syosset, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at Carltun on the Park, a restaurant in East Meadow, N.Y.

title: BENEFITS
description: John Glenn and the U.N.

title: At the Corner of Gridlock and Groan; Intersection Blockers Cry Foul, but Still the Tickets Fly
description: Randy Long and his big art delivery truck had been trapped, like a fly in amber, on Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets through three achingly long green lights.

title: POSTINGS: For One Buyer, the $11 Million Quadriplex Was Not Enough; Condos for E. 64th Street
description: The three multimillion-dollar condominiums in the new five-story town house at 9 East 64th Street won't be ready for occupancy until early next year, but all are in contract for sale.

title: A Day-Tripper's Delight
description: The smart money that values wine literacy, not snobbery, and weekend pleasures in Dutchess County finds its way, as do lucky day-trippers, to the Seyval blanc that Clinton Vineyards makes in Clinton Corners, N.Y.

title: Silverbulletday Wins Again
description: It may not have been pretty, but it was overpowering: Silverbulletday, after swerving at the start of the Gazelle Handicap, swept past her five rivals to win by nearly two lengths yesterday for her 10th straight success against fillies and her 14th in 16 career starts against both sexes.

title: America's Unmet Obligation
description: Though rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Al Gore and Bill Bradley are both trying to restore a shamefully neglected issue to its rightful place at the forefront of public debate. The issue is health insurance -- specifically, this country's grievous failure to provide coverage for nearly one-sixth of its population.

title: On Blubbering
description: CRYING

title: Breakthrough Seasons For Few Given Chance
description: Early last season, Brian Giles became part of the plan that has helped make the Cleveland Indians the perennial division champions they are. With less than two years of major league service, he enrolled in the club's long-term signing strategy, agreeing to a three-year contract worth a minimum of $5.45 million. Seven months later, however, the Indians traded Giles to the Pirates.

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: When I was a high-school freshman in 1973, I was placed in ''remedial gym'' (thanks to the collective wisdom of my guidance counselor and phys-ed teacher). This first-period class -- for the obese, the slow and the uncoordinated -- shared gym-floor and locker-room space with the varsity football team. I'd like to think that things have changed in the schools to prevent such opportunity for abuse. But there was nothing in Hall's article (''The Bully in the Mirror'') to suggest that they have. I'm glad Alexander Bregstein spends his waking hours at the gym lifting weights to boost his self-esteem. Some 26 years later, the scars of remedial gym haunt me in the mirror.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Stanley Kubrick Films

title: Wake Forest Runs by Army
description: Army and Wake Forest, the teams with the best and worst rushing attacks in Division I-A last season, met today at Michie Stadium, and the one with 1998's least potent ground game prevailed.

title: September Song
description: A horse show, dogs, trees, fashion, art, books and photos for summer's end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARTNER, ABRAHAM
description: PARTNER-Abraham, on September 7, 1999. Retired electronics executive. Best friend and adored husband of Lynda. Proud father of Adam Dorfman. Caring grandfather of Sara and Amanda Dorfman. Dear brother of Sunny Rosen. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral was held Friday, September 10, 1999. Interment was at Calverton National Cemetery. Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 718-353-5166.

title: Will DaimlerChrysler Allow Plymouth to Waste Away?
description: REPORTS of Plymouth's imminent demise have proved wildly exaggerated. Still, some new nails have been pounded into the coffin of Plymouth, the DaimlerChrysler Corporation brand aimed at budget-minded customers, and it seems increasingly likely that the patient will be allowed to expire quietly.

title: For Spraying, Calm Words and Criticism
description: As the city's pesticide-spraying operation expanded into all five boroughs this weekend, so did worries about the mosquito-killing insecticides used to contain the recent outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, prompting some elected officials to urge calm and others to use the issue to criticize Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Mets' Bats And Their Pitching Get Well
description: Mike Piazza sat at his locker before tonight's game looking at the ground, his teeth clenched a bit, his head shaking. He was not going to take this opportunity to vent his obvious displeasure with a newspaper report that said the Dodgers had made two overtures this season to reacquire Piazza, the catcher they let go in a trade that many fans blame for igniting the implosion of the Dodgers franchise.

title: No Letup Seen in Repairs And Construction of Roads
description: IF you feel as if road construction -- and the accompanying traffic headaches caused by closed lanes, detours and confusion -- is everywhere in Westchester, you might be right. And there is little letup in sight, officials say.

title: Tributes to the Stage, Steel Mills and Rock Star Style
description: Exhibitions

title: Fight Powdery Mildew, and Save Seeds
description: From dry to wet and cool, conditions favor growth of powdery mildew on dahlias, phlox, lilac, roses and many trees and shrubs. At first sign, spray weekly with a mix of one tablespoon of baking soda and three tablespoons of horticultural oil to one gallon of water. Make sure to drench plants and spray undersides of leaves.

title: Everyone From 'Whiteboys' to 'X Men' to 'My Mother'
description: AMERICAN BEAUTY

title: Miss MacCowatt And Mr. Sanford
description: Nancy Wallace MacCowatt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haskell Pawling MacCowatt of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Thomas McGirr Sanford, a son of Joan Newell Sanford of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Robert L. Sanford of Kent, Conn. The Rev. Robert N. Spalding, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: NEW HEROINES -- UP AND COMING: Gina Mckee; Taking the Road to Stardom, Quietly and Carefully
description: GINA McKEE played Bella, Hugh Grant's disabled friend, in the recent hit ''Notting Hill,'' so it seems appropriate that a movie obsessed with stardom should find Ms. McKee well on the road to it herself. It helps, of course, to possess Ms. McKee's singular, decidedly unglamorous beauty.

title: Fly-Fishing: It's the Art Of the Catch, Not Just The Catch
description: FIVE minutes from the roar of cars on Interstate 95, on dead calm waters, the sun rises like an orange planet. At the point where the Housatonic River meets Long Island Sound, sea birds are already seeking their breakfast. John Posh, sitting silently in his small boat, is there for the same reason the birds are: He wants to catch a fish.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LEAVING PICO

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZAGAT, EUGENE H.
description: ZAGAT-Eugene H. ''All I know of love is love is all there is.'' Liz, Lori, and Hill

title: September 5-11; Clinton Testifies Again
description: President Clinton was back before an independent counsel, giving testimony under oath in the investigation of Alexis M. Herman, the Labor Secretary. Lawyers said that the little-noticed inquiry into accusations of influence peddling and campaign finance violations by Ms. Herman appeared to be winding down. One of the President's lawyers said Mr. Clinton was only a witness in the case, not a criminal target.

title: Hollywood's Uneasy, Maybe for the Better
description: SOMEONE contemplating the list of films for most recent movie seasons might have been forgiven for wondering whether Hollywood had a hole in the bottom of its ideas bucket. Strip away the sequels, pare away the remakes, ignore the big-screen versions of television chestnuts, discard the book adaptations and the (increasingly rare) play adaptations and often there was not much left.

title: APPEARANCES; My Husband, I Think Ill Dress Him
description: My husband hasn't changed his style since prep school. Prep school was 30 years ago. You'd think he'd be embarrassed about this (or the fact that the sizes he wears are larger), but he's actually smug. It's odd to live in holy matrimony with a man who dresses in the same pants and shirts that my father (and his) has favored since World War II. Khakis in summer, cords in winter, wool slacks when business requires it. And from the same store, no less. What was the East Coast guy wearing before Brooks Brothers? At least my father's pants weren't always pleated and didn't resemble leg balloons.

title: INVESTING WITH: Edward P. Owens; Vanguard Health Care Fund
description: EARLIER this year, as worries piled up about everything from an overheating economy to possible Government price controls on drugs, the stock market took a scalpel to the health care industry. The Standard & Poor's health care composite index fell 20.4 percent from its peak in mid-April through early August.

title: As the Rains Finally Come, A Tally of the Tree Damage
description: Like a general in a Jeep inspecting the carnage on a battlefield, Dr. Kim Tripp sat behind the wheel of a golf cart Wednesday surveying the rocky knolls and grassy meadows of the New York Botanical Garden. In an area called the Pinetum she identified the first casualty, an Eastern white pine that looked less like a feathery evergreen and more like a brittle Christmas tree left on a curb in late February.

title: A Man of Many Women
description: When Pedro Almodovar learned that the Hollywood Madam, Heidi Fleiss, once employed a prostitute who went by the name of Norma Jean Almodovar, he was tickled no end. ''This is really something,'' he says, in his amusing, broken English. ''And she was police before she decided to become prostitute. This is very interesting and very honest.'' Only in Almodovar's strangely ordered universe would a cop-turned-whore seem honest.

title: A New School Year
description: In increasing numbers, students from 52 Westchester public schools returned to classrooms last week, administrators with the Southern Westchester and Northern Westchester-Putnam Boards of Cooperative Educational Services reported. At 35 southern Westchester schools, 134,344 students were enrolled last year, but the official number will not be known until October. In the northern Westchester and Putnam region, separate figures for Westchester were not available.

title: For Kate Winslet, Being a Movie Star iIs 'a Bit Daft'
description: KATE WINSLET likes to say that she is not one for planning ahead which is probably a good thing, since she could hardly have expected to land a lead role in the biggest money-spinner of all time just four years into her screen career. On the other hand, once ''Titanic'' thrust global fame upon her when she was all of 21, it was soon apparent that this strong-willed young Englishwoman was not about to allow stardom to dictate her life.

title: Record Crowd Watches Texas Blow Out Rutgers
description: It took Texas 62 seconds to get on the scoreboard. By halftime, the Longhorns had a 22-point lead over Rutgers. But it was not until 5 minutes 28 seconds was left in the game and Texas was up by 17 points that a New Jersey kid got to have his homecoming.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-12-99: Questions for Dick Wolf; Cop Show And Tell
description: Q: Your new show, ''Special Victims Unit,'' makes its debut this month. It's a spinoff of ''Law and Order,'' which seems to be on about 10 times a day now. Is this a plan to take over the entire true-crime genre? And what's the inspiration?

title: September 5-11; Danforth to Examine Waco
description: Attorney General Attorney General Janet Reno named John C. Danforth, the former Republican Senator from Missouri, to lead an independent reexamination of the F.B.I.'s tear-gas assault in 1993 on the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex. Mr. Danforth was granted full investigative and prosecutorial powers to charge Federal agents with crimes if he finds the law was broken. In part, the choice reflected an effort by Ms. Reno to quiet her Republican critics in Congress. But the outcry grew louder, with Republican Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, telling reporters, ''I am beginning to think that she should resign.''

title: Anne Longsworth And John Dallas
description: Anne Greybill Longsworth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Longsworth of Royalston, Mass., was married yesterday to John Gaston Dallas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Dallas of Cincinnati. The Rev. John Turner, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Carter's Grove Plantation in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Lydia Sanders, Richard Smyers
description: Lydia Hammond Sanders, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emory Wilson Sanders of New London, N.H., was married yesterday to Richard William Smyers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hayes Smyers Jr. of Wethersfield, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Stecker 4th performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in New London.

title: Reader, Press On
description: Good news, devoted readers of cereal boxes and shampoo bottles! Manufacturers of everything from soap to pants are offering copy-heavy packaging and labels that go well beyond ingredients or directions for use. Mixing irony and ironing, J. Crew's classic-fit chinos ($49.50 at J. Crew stores) come with laundering instructions tailored to the customer: corporate climbers are advised to take the garment to a professional dry cleaner, and Web surfers should neither fold nor hang pants, washing only if desired. Stella Pace's popular powerbead bracelets ($22 to $48 at Intermix stores) come encased in plastic pharmacy bottles with ''prescriptions'': ''Carnelian powerbead bracelet: favored to alleviate PMS and encourage planned reproduction; wear it and you will smile more.'' Brainy beauty consumers can enjoy literary quotations from Jane Austen and Emily Dickinson printed inside the lids of Stila eye shadows and blushes ($15 at Barneys New York). And Thomas Pink's Millennium Ties, a line of 10 ties, each of which depicts a century from the 11th through the 20th ($85 at Thomas Pink, Madison Avenue and 53d Street), comes with historical overviews. For the 11th century, a Norman Fleet tie provides commentary on the 1066 Battle of Hastings. For the 20th century, an Electric tie cautions, ''Although electricity was discovered prior to this century, its common use was not until the 20th century, where it has had a profound effect on modern life.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Jersey City to Lay Off More Than 1,000 Workers
description: Jersey City is facing a $27.4 million gap in its municipal budget that could force it to lay off 1,271 of its employees, including police officers and firefighters if additional money is not received from the state before the end of October, said Jessie Correa, a spokeswoman for Mayor Bret Schundler.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Susan Hoeft, Charles Youngblood
description: Susan Barbara Hoeft, the daughter of Barbara and Raymond Hoeft of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Charles Andrew Youngblood, a son of Patricia and Robert Youngblood of Hendersonville, N.C. The Rev. Bruce Carlson, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Vassar College Chapel.

title: After a Bar Owner's Death, Drug Fears Rise
description: The sudden death of a prominent businessman last week, a death that may have involved drug use, sent shock waves through gay social networks and had some gay men expressing concern about the dangers of recreational drugs.

title: Making Officials Take Action Before Hurricanes
description: Re ''Keeping an Eye on the Storm in Long Beach,'' [Sept. 5]: Hurricane planning on Long Island is a joke, but not a funny one. Long Islanders should insist that their village, town and county officials take timely effective protective action before the big storms strike; not after. People in each low-lying community should have a predetermined route to a nearby high-ground safe-haven hurricane evacuation destination in a public building prestocked with food, water, beds, clothing and generators.

title: Unadorned View of a Western Life Thought Long Gone
description: WHEN the billboards carrying cigarette ads came down a few months ago, a chapter closed in the saga of the American West. The Marlboro Man had come to represent the epitome of American masculinity or rugged individualism.

title: Q. & A.
description: Lost Space in Office Leases

title: A Treasure Hunt For Americana In the Galleries
description: A PIONEER at the outset and a trendsetter ever since, the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has advanced the nation's passionate interest in American art throughout most of this century. Now, on Nov. 10, it will mark to the day the 75th anniversary of its opening with ''Celebrating the American Wing: Notable Acquisitions 1980-1999,'' a yearlong exhibition of American paintings, sculpture and furnishings of the late 17th century to the early 20th century.

title: Truth and Reconciliation
description: DOG HEART

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, JOHN HUDSON
description: HALL-John Hudson Of Greenwich, CT, and Morris, NY, died on September 10, 1999. He was a direct descendant of Lewis R. Morris, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and the greatgrandson of William Andrews Clark, the first Senator from Montana and a noted art collector. He received a B.A. from Williams College and a M.S. in Geology from Queens College, Ontario. He worked as a portfolio manager for Carl M. Loeb Rhoades & Co. in NYC. He served as Chairman of The Philatelic Foundation in NYC and was a member of the Board of Trustees of The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. He is survived by his wife, Erika P. Hall; their two children, John H. Hall III of California and Carla Hall Friedman of NYC; four grandchildren and a brother, Lewis R.M. Hall of NYC and Morris, NY. A funeral service to be held in Morris, NY; a memorial service at a later date in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington, DC, or Glimmerglass Opera, Cooperstown, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDI, ANDREW P., REV. MSGR.
description: LANDI-Andrew P., Rev. Msgr. On September 8, 1999. Survived by his sister Annette M. Landi and eight nephews and nieces. Services will be held at St. Stephen's Church, East 28th St. between 3rd and Lexington Aves., NYC. Mass of Transferral on Sunday, 7:30 PM, and viewing in Church, 6:30-7:15 PM and 8:30-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection on Monday, 10 AM, viewing hours 9-9:45 AM only. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Donations can be made to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette St., Baltimore, MD. 21201-3443 or St. Stephen's Church, 142 East 29th St., NYC, NY 10016.

title: Some Birthday Cake For a Toothless Wonder
description: A DECADE ago, the rising powers of the Pacific organized a loose economic confederation known as APEC to bind together their fractious region. Each year since 1993, the region's leaders have donned silly shirts, flown to some spectacular setting and held a summit meeting. The latest one starts here this morning, in a country much more like England in the '50s than Asia in the '90s.

title: When Musicals Were Dizzy
description: THE jumpy overture to ''No, No, Nanette,'' led by F. Wade Russo, transports one to the best of times at the Goodspeed Opera House when musicals were dizzy and everybody danced madly.

title: Thumbing Through the Modern Century
description: THE new season, perhaps sensing the nearness of the millennium, has rushed to embrace the music of its time, lest it escape altogether. In a lineup high in adventure and substance, major musical institutions here will be presenting a lot of the important pieces of the 20th century and sending out important musicians to play them. If listeners take advantage of the next months, they will have gone a long way toward sorting out the failed experimentation, mediocrity and charlatanry that give ''modern'' music a bad name from the living tissue that has made this such an extraordinary time.

title: THE NEW SEASON/CLASSICAL MUSIC; Exploring the Last Bach Frontier: the Piano
description: THE year 2000 brings -- among other, more obvious events -- the 250th anniversary of the death of Johann Sebastian Bach. As in 1950 and 1985 (the 300th anniversary of his birth), there will be countless tributes and celebrations to honor the father figure of Western music. Today his star shines brighter than ever, and his unique position on Olympus has been universally accepted. Most musicians and music lovers revere him, and those who do not are rightly embarrassed to say so.

title: That Rascal Who Helped Invent America
description: Phineas T. Barnum. The name alone invites a good time, a combination of extravagance, merriment and harmless mischief. A century after his death in 1891 the man and his life seem so novel as to be more fiction than fact.

title: The Big Picture Show
description: KAZAN

title: Jennifer Biezup, Robert Leininger
description: Jennifer Lee Biezup, a daughter of Georgia Medley Biezup of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late John T. Biezup, was married yesterday to Robert Douglas Leininger, the son of Augusta Yuengling Leininger of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and the late Robert L. Leininger. The Rev. James A. Trimble performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Mount Pocono, Pa.

title: Watching Europe And the Theater
description: BILL T. JONES

title: Melancholy Babies: Angst Is In Again
description: POPULAR music, the id of American culture, market-tests attitudes along with rhythms and tunes. For most of 1999, the pop charts have been divided among four disparate, teen-centered moods: the gooey romance of groups like the Backstreet Boys, the peppy Spanglish pop of Ricky Martin (who is scheduled to perform amid bilingual squeals at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 28), the frat-boy boorishness of bands like Limp Bizkit and the action-movie nihilism of gangsta rap. Part of the audience is soaking up sweet nothings; another part fantasizes on lashing out.

title: Heavy Analysis In Capriati Affair
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Plunkett, Mr. O'Connor
description: Kathleen Anne Plunkett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Plunkett Jr. of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin James O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis E. O'Connor of Newington, Conn. The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, the president of Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown.

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: I believe that parents should find 1,000 occasions a year to tell children how much they are cherished. That school boy in Pearl, Miss., who murdered his mother and fellow students complained, ''She never told me she loved me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAYDE, JASCHA
description: ZAYDE-Jascha The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jascha Zayde, associated with The Times from 1936 until retiring in 1971.

title: A gondola view and an advertising museum
description: Many visitors come to Paris simply to look at it, and where better to do so than the viewing platforms at the Arc de Triomphe, the Georges Pompidou Center (which reopens on Jan. 1 after renovation), and, of course, the Eiffel Tower? Now, as part of millennium celebrations through the end of next year, the city's rooftops and monuments can be seen from a new angle. Four times an hour, a gondola attached to a large tethered balloon rises 490 feet above the Parc Andre Citroen, beside the Seine in western Paris. And, yes, the view is spectacular, weather permitting.

title: His Life as a Murder Suspect
description: This is what James R. Van de Velde -- high-school student council president, cold-war diplomat, popular Yale political science lecturer -- did after night fell last Dec. 4, according to James Van de Velde: he worked late in his Yale office; he went home and watched an episode of ''Friends'' that he had taped; he reheated a month-old burrito, and he surfed the channels, lingering on Discovery to watch the big cats.

title: Fall Foliage Optimism, Despite Forecasts
description: THE spring and summer drought lowered the water table enough so that Joyce and Ken Wood could finally dig a pond they had wanted for years, allowing them to add ice skating to the hay rides and other attractions they offer at Woods Acres, their farm here in the Litchfield Hills, in northwestern Connecticut. But as they surveyed the excavation at sunset recently, orange and yellow leaves fluttered down from a 50-foot ash, a good month ahead of schedule.

title: The Troubled Life of Boys
description: The pathetic specimens in your articles have nothing to worry about. All their material needs are taken care of. They have comfortable homes, telephones, computers and apparently unlimited budgets for clothes and athletic equipment. They are living in the most prosperous period in history, with no danger of military call-up and little danger of future unemployment or poverty. They have unlimited sex, drugs, music, entertainment. Their education is so anti-intellectual that schoolwork scarcely appears on their fuzzy mental radar screens. Their only real problem seems to be, Which clique do I join?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: T. S. Eliot An Imperfect Life. By Lyndall Gordon. Norton, $35.

title: The State, as Seen by Centuries of Tourists
description: THERE is a certain voyeuristic thrill in eavesdropping on people who are talking about us, especially when we learn that most of them really do like us after all. Now, a new book that reprints the writings of people who have traveled through the state since the 17th century shows that outsiders, from common folks to statesmen, have long been impressed, and sometimes unimpressed, with Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 17 of Arts & Leisure today about the choreographer Mats Ek includes an outdated reference to his mother, the Swedish modern-dance pioneer Birgit Cullberg. She died on Thursday, after the section had gone to press.

title: Barbara Conroy, Roger Yaseen
description: Barbara Jean Conroy and Roger Leonard Yaseen are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi David M. Posner in the couple's apartment in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILEY, IRVING
description: SMILEY-Irving After a long illness, on September 9, 1999, of the age of 85. Widower of Molly Moses-Smiley and cherished father and best friend of Stuart, Frank and Arlene Weisberg. Beloved father-in-law of Larry. The loss of this warm man is felt by all. He will be truly missed by everyone whose life he touched. Services Monday, at 1 PM, at the Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave., Riverdale. In lieu of flowers memorial donatons may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, NY. For information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1-800-468-3232.

title: Two Places Aim at Libido; City Sues the Love Shack
description: When Junior's, a topless bar, opened at 233d Street and Provost Avenue last month, the chairman of Community Board 12, the Rev. Richard Gorman, stood on the corner and cried out to anyone who would listen that the neighborhood was being ruined.

title: On Politics; Which Party Is More Dazed By Whitman's Bombshell?
description: Try as they might, it is hard for the Republicans to put a happy face on Governor Whitman's surprising decision to withdraw from the race for Senator Frank G. Lautenberg's seat.

title: An Open Book Full of Secrets
description: EGYPT puts the millennium in perspective. For 3,000 years before Christianity jump-started our calendar, civilization flourished along the Nile. People brewed beer, hewed rocks into huge statues of their kings and gods, and tried to keep the hippopotamuses from ruining their crops. With its towering pharaohs, its cool linen and its expressive typography, ancient Egypt has a special, favored place in the modern Western imagination.

title: Jewish New Year
description: Just in time for the Jewish New Year, clergy and members of Sinai Free Synagogue, Westchester's newest Reform Jewish congregation, carried their sacred Torah scrolls through the streets of Mount Vernon to their new synagogue building on North Columbus Ave.

title: Two Voices Rejoin the Opera Chorus
description: TWO sleeping operatic beauties are about to open their eyes. Both are historic theaters, closed for badly needed repairs. Both are about to reopen with a bang.

title: THE NEW SEASON: ANNOTATED LISTINGS -- DANCE
description: September

title: Ready-to-Swear Fashions
description: From his hideaway in Cabot, Vt., comes word that the David Mamet fall line will dazzle with its freshness and vitality.

title: A.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: Political Briefing; Ventura Can't Make Perot Say 'Uncle'
description: The forces of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota and Ross Perot are squabbling again over control of the Reform Party.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: REMINISCING IN TEMPO

title: New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: JAKARTA CONCEDES A LOSS OF CONTROL OVER TIMOR FORCES
description: Guarded by a tight cordon of security, the streets of East Timor's capital shattered and still smoking around him, the chief of Indonesia's armed forces, Gen. Wiranto, conceded today that he had lost control of elements of his military.

title: Bringing Good Things to Fiat?
description: FOR most of Fiat's 132,000 Italian employees, breakfast usually consists of little more than an espresso and a newspaper. But on a recent morning, Paolo Fresco sat ramrod straight in a dining room of Fiat's executive suite and, in vaguely accented English, ordered ''scrambled eggs, very soft, and a side order of bacon -- very, very crisp.''

title: The Bill Collectors
description: They are the keepers of the flame -- stylish members, one and all, of the Billy Haines fan club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, ROBERT TWEED
description: HERSH-Robert Tweed of Lawrence, KS and formerly of Cleveland, OH and New York City passed away on August 31 at the age of 71. Mr. Hersh graduated from Columbia College, NY in 1947 and worked as a Physicist at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital from 1947-1951. He completed his doctorate in biophysics from the University of California, Berkeley in 1956. Boys are learning what girls have long known: it isn't easy living in a 'Baywatch' world.'' Then I became distressed that this doesn't make the situation any better, but instead makes it worse. Is there any hope for a fulfilling relationship between a man and a woman when both are so concerned with how they look that they can't see the beauty of the other? It depresses me to think that with all of the therapists in lucrative practices and with the proliferation of self-esteem workshops, boys and girls are still profoundly and irreversibly affected by the molded plastic bodies of G.I. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Faces of the Nation
description: The nearly 200 images in AMERICAN CHARACTERS: Selections From the National Portrait Gallery, Accompanied by Literary Portraits (Yale University, $45) represent the scope of American portrait painting and popular illustration, including photographs and daguerreotypes, posters, sheet music, silhouettes, caricatures and sculpture. These, in the words of the editors, R. W. B. Lewis and Nancy Lewis, are men and women who have '' 'made a difference' in our history'' -- a wide blanket for a book that opens with Pocahontas and Cotton Mather and ends with Tallulah Bankhead and Walt Disney. Facing each portrait is a page of commentary, with a capsule biography by the Lewises. Some prose portraits were written for this book -- Edward Hoagland on John Muir, John Updike on Ernest Hemingway, Robert B. Parker on Dashiell Hammett, among others. But it is the range of comments that gives this book its particular flavor -- most historical, some hostile, all enhancing the impression made by the portrait itself. John Adams's snide appraisal of Benjamin Franklin is followed by Franklin's physician's description of Franklin's ''art of living'' in Paris. Franklin, in a striking 1785 portrait by Joseph Siffrede Duplessis, stares from the opposite page unsmiling, unabashed. A heavy-browed portrait of Nathaniel Hawthorne more than matches the words of Henry James Sr.: ''He had the look all the time, to one who didn't know him, of a rogue who suddenly finds himself in a company of detectives.'' The portrait selections are witty and full of surprises: a childhood painting of Edith Wharton, a photograph of Mathew Brady looking away from the camera, self-portraits in oil by George Gershwin and E. E. Cummings, a terrific photo of a smiling John F. Kennedy walking toward a wall of outreaching hands. This is a book you can get lost in for hours. Even the notes on the portraits and the commentary make fascinating reading. David Walton

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAGHEUSIAN, LEILA
description: KARAGHEUSIAN-Leila, a philanthropist and president of the Howard Karagheusian Commemorative Corporation, died on September 6, in her home. She was 96. For 66 years, Ms. Karagheusian was President of the foundation founded by her parents, Mihran and Zabelle Karagheusian, in 1921, in memory of their son, Howard, who was stricken by influenza during the worldwide epidemic of 1918. Her father was a successful manufacturer of carpets under the name of Gulistan. In 1922, Ms. Karagheusian was graduated from Barnard College, and subsequently pursued social work at the Columbia University School of Social Work. Many charitable organizations in New York City were on her list for contributions, she was most active in this regard and established an endowment at Columbia University School of Social Work. Upon her being elected president of the foundation in 1933, she continued what her father had started in 1921, that is, Mr. Karagheusian established an orphanage in Constantinople for Armenian orphan children: Leila began to emphasize more intensive attention to health, medical and social programs for Armenian refugee children and their families residing in Greece, Lebanon and Syriavictims of the Turkish massacres that took place during the First World War. Pediatric clinics, social centers and school health programs were established in those countries. This was all done without regard to the race, religion or ethnic group of any needy children, and that credo exists to the present day. Low income housing was initiated in Greece, Lebanon and Syria in order to uplift the families of refugee Armenians. The Foundation, was the first to provide vaccinations to children and be concerned with their nutrition. In 1988, Ms. Karagheusian made a substantial donation for Armenian relief immediately after the devastating earthquake. In 1992, she approved establishing dental clinics for children in Armenia. Up to that time, preventive dentistry did not exist in the countries of the former Soviet Union. But she insisted that all dental supplies, equipment and technology be American. Tens of thousands of children, over the years, have been treated, clothed, fed and housed. She was a very modest person, shunning all publicity, and was intolerant of those who did a lot of talking but did nothing. Her motto was ''Get it done.'' She was a lifelong member of the Armenian General Benevolent Union, and was a member of the Jinishian Memorial Program. She never married.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINN, JOSEPH T., SR., M.D.
description: McGINN-Joseph T., Sr., M.D. Of Breezy Point, Queens, on September 10 at home at age 74. Devoted husband of Rosemary (nee Smith) for 47 years. Beloved father of Rosemary Astakhova, Joseph Jr., M.D., William, Maryellen Power, Thomas, M.D., Clare Carrubba and Bryan. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McGinn of Stapleton, Staten Island. Dear brother of Dr. Thomas McGinn and Dr. Marion Patricia Warunek. Grandfather to 14, uncle and great-uncle to many more. Joe was a grateful graduate of Xavier High School in Manhattan (Class of '41); received his bachelor's from Fordham University and his medical degree from the State University of New York Health Science Center of Brooklyn (Downstate Medical School). He was a veteran of World War II and a lifelong aficionado of model trains. Throughout his career, Joe McGinn was a leader in both internal medicine and nephrology. He pioneered use of the artifical kidney machine (hemodialysis) in New York, developing and directing the dialysis units at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn and later at Staten Island University Hospital. He was Director of Medicine at Staten Island University Hospital and a founding member of the Kidney Association of Staten Island. In May, 1998, Staten Island University Hospital awarded Dr. McGinn its Career Achievement Award in recognition of over 45 years of exemplary teaching and mentoring in the clinical practice of medicine. Most recently, Dr. McGinn played a key role in developing the Coumadin AntiCoagulation Center at Staten Island University Hospital, which provides more than 500 patients with safe, effective treatment for vascular disorders. Dr. McGinn was certified by the American Board of Internal Medicine and a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. As Associate Professor of Medicine at Downstate, he taught generations of medical students and residents internal medicine, receiving numerous student awards for teaching excellence. Last month, he received the Downstate Division of Ambulatory Care Education annual faculty award for ''outstanding contributions and dedication to medical student education.'' Viewing Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 11 AM, Tuesday, at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, Queens, NY. Donations in Dr. McGinn's memory may be made to Xavier High School Scholarship Fund or SUNY Health Science Center, Brooklyn, Medical Student Scholarship Fund, both c/o Lorainne Loprete, Dept. of Medicine, Staten Island University Hospital, 475 Seaview Ave., Staten Island, NY 10305.

title: A Little Extra Magic For 'The Magic Flute'

I certainly found myself unable to think about much else during Sunday afternoon's matinee performance of Mozart's ''Magic Flute.'' And this popular opera, presented in the fairy-tale-like 1987 production by Lotfi Mansouri and performed here in Andrew Porter's English translation, provided a good test for the new system.

title: What Fuels Progress in Science? Sometimes, a Feud
description: The crabbed handwriting emerges from the fax machine like a communication from another time, a dispatch from a great battle that has passed into history. Yet Sir Fred Hoyle, the British cosmologist who, five decades ago, derisively coined the term ''Big Bang'' for a cosmic theory with which he did not and does not agree, makes plain in his faxed letter that for him, the battle lives on. And it is not just a fight against a theory.

The transaction has a cash value of $260 million, American Tower said. The 1,000 new sites to be developed will be completed as part of AT&T Wireless's five-year expansion plans. American Tower is based in Boston, and AT&T is based in New York.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES AGREES TO SELL SEALANT SUBSIDIARY
description: Harvard Industries, an automobile equipment and industrial products maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its sealant business to Hutchinson S.A. of France for $115 million. Harvard, based in Lebanon, N.J., announced in May that it wanted to sell the subsidiary, Kingston-Warren, saying the business did not fit in with the company's strategy. Harvard said Kingston-Warren, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., was expected to have 1999 sales of about $119 million. The unit makes the sealing materials used in automotive windows and doors. Harvard said it expected to use the proceeds to pay off debt. The company had revenue of about $505 million for the latest 12 months.

title: An Effective Force for East Timor
description: ''We cannot wait any longer,'' Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, said on Sunday. ''We have to stop the suffering and mourning immediately.'' With those words, Mr. Habibie bowed to world opinion and agreed to allow international peacekeepers into East Timor. But important questions remain about when -- and with what powers -- the force will go in. The international community needs to maintain political and financial pressure on Indonesia to accept a force large and powerful enough to protect East Timor's people -- and to do so immediately, before thousands more are killed.

title: SOLECTRON TO BUY SMART MODULAR FOR $2 BILLION
description: The Solectron Corporation, a leading manufacturing services company for the computer and electronics industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the memory chip maker Smart Modular Technologies Inc. for $2 billion in stock. Shareholders of Smart Modular, based in Fremont, Calif., will receive 0.51 share of Solectron stock, or $38.25. The stock closed yesterday at $24.3125, up 81.25 cents, in Nasdaq trading, where Solectron fell $3.75, to $73.75. The acquisition was announced at the close of trading in New York. Solectron has been making acquisitions to increase its products for computer companies. In April, Solectron said it would buy Trimble Navigation Ltd.'s manufacturing assets in Sunnyvale, Calif.

description: The aura of uncertainty surrounding Jayson Williams's leg injury became even more ambiguous yesterday when the Nets announced that Williams would undergo arthroscopic surgery today to remove loose particles from his right knee.

title: As Iraqis Starve, U.S. Asserts, Their Leaders Live in Luxury
description: The United States, which is seeking to force a new weapons inspection program on Iraq, said today that it had new evidence showing that President Saddam Hussein had spent money to build a sprawling amusement park to entertain his political followers instead of feeding hungry Iraqis.

title: Tony Duquette, a Decorator of Fantasy, Is Dead at 85
description: Tony Duquette, the designer whose lavish, whimsically baroque sets and costumes, interiors and jewelry made him a Hollywood favorite for more than five decades, died on Sept. 9. He was 85.

title: Was Clinton Right to Offer Prisoners Clemency?

title: Leonardo's Huge Horse Comes to Life, 500 Years Later
description: Five hundred years to the day that French soldiers destroyed a work in progress by Leonardo da Vinci of what would have been the largest equestrian statue in existence, a 24-foot-high, 15-ton silicon bronze sculpture of the stallion was unveiled today in a garden that forms part of the city's horse racing track.

title: Mother of 3 Is Charged in Daughter's Death
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday with killing one of her three small children, a bruised and battered 2-year-old girl who apparently had borne the brunt of her mother's secret abuse for a long time until Sunday night, when she fell unconscious after another beating and died, city officials said.

title: Total Fina Is Victorious With Its Hostile Bid for Elf Aquitaine
description: After fighting off a hostile takeover for the last two months, Elf Aquitaine S.A. of France capitulated today and agreed to be acquired for roughly $48.8 billion by a domestic rival, Total Fina S.A.

title: 3Com Plans To Spin Off Its Palm Unit
description: Exploiting the surging demand for calculator-size computers, the 3Com Corporation yesterday said it would spin off its Palm Computing subsidiary, maker of the popular Palm Pilot, as a separate company early next year.

title: 2 Recent Earthquakes Unrelated
description: For anyone who believes that airplane crashes and other disasters come in bunches, the earthquake that struck Athens on Tuesday, just three weeks after a major tremor about 400 miles away in Turkey, provided plenty of grist for debate.

title: 4 Leading Securities Firms Join Forces to Back Primex
description: The four largest securities firms in the United States have joined forces to back Primex Trading, a novel electronic auction system for stocks, giving Primex a jump-start in the static-filled world of electronic trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, EMILY S.

title: Leo Burnett is reorganizing itself on two fronts.
description: THE Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, the agency company known for warm, whimsical and character-driven campaigns for blue-chip brands like Hallmark, Keebler, Kellogg and Maytag, is making two big changes, a corporate reorganization and a realignment of senior management.

title: Laidlaw Selling 2 Businesses to Focus on Bus Operations
description: Laidlaw Inc., the Canadian-based operator of North America's largest bus fleet, including the Greyhound lines, said today that it intends to sell two major businesses that have depressed its stock price and no longer fit its core transportation strategy and to use some of the $2 billion in anticipated proceeds to buy more buses.

description: A hurricane that meteorologists said was four times the size of the infamous Hurricane Andrew and potentially even more destructive pounded toward Florida today, forcing the authorities to order the evacuation of at least one million people and leaving countless residents to hope that the massive storm would somehow pass their cities by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, DOUGLAS CHARLES
description: LYNCH-Douglas Charles. On September 10, in Westchester, NY, in his 85th year. Formerly of New York City, he was a senior executive with Phelps Dodge, Lynch Corporation, RCA and other international companies, and an author published in three languages. The son of an American Army Officer, he was born in the Phillipines, and served as advisor to the President of the Phillipines after World War II. He was a wise and unforgettable man who will be deeply missed by his wife Carolyn, his children Victoria and Clifford, and his grandchildren Chloe and Luke, and by his many friends. According to his wishes, no funeral service will be held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHELAN, WILLIAM EDWARD
description: WHELAN-William Edward. On September 9, 1999. Deeply loved and cherished husband and best friend of Agatha Munhall Whelan went to the God he loved so much. Also survived by his sister, Mary Whelan Phelan and his brothers, Charles and Robert and 15 nieces and nephews and 33 grandnieces and nephews. Resting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Viewing Tuesday, September 14, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St., Wednesday, September 15, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: MARK IV SELLS FILTER UNIT TO CLARCOR FOR $144.8 MILLION
description: Mark IV Industries, a maker of power-transmission and fluid-transfer systems, said yesterday that it had sold its industrial filter businesses to Clarcor Inc. for $144.8 million. Mark IV said the sale of the businesses -- the Purolator Products Air Filtration Company, Facet International and Purolator-Facet Filter Products -- was part of efforts to focus on core operations. In March, Mark IV, based in Amherst, N.Y., sold its Purolator Products automotive-filter business to Arvin Industries for $270 million. Clarcor, based in Rockford, Ill., said the purchase would increase the size and scope of its product lines and provide access to new markets. The businesses make a wide variety of filters used in industrial applications.

title: REBELLIOUS GOVERNOR RELENTS
description: Itamar Franco, the Governor of one of Brazil's largest states, said his administration would resume payments of obligations to foreign lenders to partly end a moratorium declared earlier this year that contributed to the country's currency crisis. The state of Minas Gerais will pay debt owed to the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank but will continue to halt payments to the central Government, said Mr. Franco, a former Brazilian President. Mr. Franco has been ostracized by investors upset by his actions. Simon Romero

title: DDT Complicates Debate On Pact to Ban Pesticides
description: Negotiators have hammered out a broad agreement to ban several toxic chemicals and pesticides, but were unable to decide the fate of DDT because of its use as a cheap means to combat malaria, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTUS, MICHAEL S.
description: MARTUS-Michael S. Beloved husband of Mirella; dearest father of Stephen & David; devoted brother of Marjorie Martus; adoring grandfather of Isabella; affectionate father-in-law of Sara. Services will be held Thursday, September 16 at 10:00 A.M. at the Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, N.Y. title: Corrections

title: Promise and Risks of Laser Eye Surgery
description: Dr. Mark Shulman, first fitted for glasses at age 5, was never happy about his dependence on them. They would fog up in winter or get clouded with sweat in summer when he pursued the outdoor activities he loved. To see clearly when he did his daily swim, he needed prescription goggles. Contact lenses didn't work for him. So at age 61 he invested about $5,000 in laser surgery to correct his myopia and astigmatisms by reshaping his corneas and to enable him to do everything but read without glasses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RABBI SAMUEL
description: COHEN-Rabbi Samuel. Jewish National Fund and its Executive and Administrative Boards are saddened by the untimely passing of a dedicated servant of the Jewish people and Israel. Throughout his career he served several different Jewish organization with commitment and tireless effort, but his greatest passion was reserved for the twenty years (1977 to 1997) that he labored on behalf of Jewish National Fund raising funds to enable Keren Kayemeth Lelsrael to continues its valuable ecological work in Israel. A true humanitarian, he was loved by all who had the good fortune of working along side of him. Sam was also a scholar, a committed Jew, and a devoted husband and father. He'll be sorely missed by the entire Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Mira, and his children, Baruch, Michoel, and Miriam Silberberg, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald J. Lauder, President Russell F. Robinson, Executive Vice President Executive and Administrative Board Jewish National Fund

title: Palestinians and Israelis Begin Final Round of Talks
description: Six years to the day after Yasir Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin shook hands at the White House and agreed on a blueprint for peace, Palestinian and Israeli authorities today formally began what both sides say should be the final but most difficult round of their protracted negotiations.

title: TYCO TAKES STAKE IN COMPANY BUILDING UNDERSEA CABLE
description: Tyco International Ltd. joined three investors yesterday to take a $345 million stake in Worldwide Fiber Inc. as Tyco, a leading undersea fiber optic cable company, tries to increase sales by investing in Internet and telecommunications providers. Tyco, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, now owns a stake of 8.2 percent, valued at $125 million, in closely held Worldwide Fiber, a telecommunications company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that is building a trans-Atlantic fiber optic network called Hibernia. Tyco is supplying the cables for Hibernia. Tyco's partners in the Worldwide Fiber transaction are Providence Equity Partners, DLJ Merchant Banking II Inc., and GS Capital Partners III L.P. Shares of Tyco fell $1.50, to $101.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, SAMUEL (DOC)
description: STONE-Samuel (Doc). Beloved son of the late Rose and Morton Stone, brother, brother-in-law, uncle and cherished friend, died peacefully on the evening of tenth September at the age of 83. Sam was a noble soul who brought joy into many lives. He leaves behind his sister, Shirley Stone Rod and husband Robert of Florida, niece Patricia Rod Jennings and husband Tim of New York, nephew Dean Rod and wife Rani of California, brother Tobias of Nevada, niece Leslie Stone Coren and great-niece Alexandra of Florida, dearest friend Kathryn C. McCarthy and twin Vera D. McCarthy, the entire loving McCarthy family, and lifelong friend Gene Radano and wife Edna. Sam's death marks the end of an era for New York. He spent his working life with the New York Parks Department and rose to the position of Assistant Commissioner of Parks and Recreation by the time he retired in 1983. His knowledge of New York was so extensive that he was frequently consulted regarding sites for movies filmed on location. He was recently awarded the ''Lifetime Friends of Parks'' from Henry Stern, Parks Commissioner. He will live on forever in the hearts of all who knew and loved him. Services Wednesday, September 15, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SYNAPTIC'S SHARES FALL AFTER DRUG PROGRAM IS SET BACK
description: Shares of the Synaptic Pharmaceutical Corporation fell 34 percent yesterday after its development partner, Merck & Company, ended efforts to develop an experimental Synaptic drug. Synaptic's shares fell $3.0625, to $5.875, in Nasdaq trading. Merck halted its development program for the drug, intended to treat a common enlarged prostate condition, because the oral version was too difficult for the body to break down and carried the potential for negative interactions with other drugs, Synaptic said in a statement issued late on Friday. Merck's move marks the second drug development setback for Synaptic this year. Eli Lilly & Company ended work in March on an experimental migraine drug that was at that time the most advanced compound in Synaptic's pipeline.

title: CURRENCY RESTRICTIONS LOOSENED
description: In a move to shed restrictions on foreign currency holdings, Brazil's central bank will allow companies investing in the petroleum and electricity industries to open domestic accounts in dollars. The move, a preliminary step in easing foreign currency restrictions held over from an earlier exchange rate policy, should make it easier for foreign companies to make investment plans. The Government hopes that increased direct foreign investment will provide relief to the economy after a sharp decline in short-term investment from abroad.

National Information Consortium said it would acquire Efed for $15 million in cash and 606,000 of its shares. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, ALICE F.
description: MARSH-Alice F. Died peacefully at home on Sunday September 12, 1999, at the age of 95. Growing up in Yorkville, the daughter of Alice Farley, a single mother, Alice knew poverty first hand. When others left to go to work, her mother insisted she continue her education, and she did. A fighter for social justice, she joined the Socialist Party with her husband John Marsh, and was a founding member of The United Federation of Teachers. Alice was a NYC elemen/jr HS teacher for 35 yrs, then became the first UFT Legislative Rep in Albany. For sixteen years she was instrumental in getting legislation passed that improved working conditions and pensions for teachers. She was a passionate believer in public education and the separation of church and state. A consummate storyteller, Alice could always command an audience. A true heroine and optimist to the very end. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROMER, LEON B. JR.
description: KROMER-Leon B. Jr., 87, passed away Sunday, September 12, 1999 at Sardis Nursing Home. Born July 17, 1912 at Fort Reno, OK, he was the son of Major General Leon B. Kromer, former U.S. Chief of Cavalry and Jane Stotsenburg Wainright. Mr. Kromer attended Georgetown University, graduated from Columbia University in 1934 and worked as an accountant for the LyBrand Co. until World War II. He served as a Lieut. Commander on the staff of Admiral Combs, assisting with labor relations at the Bureau of Yards and Docks in Washington, DC. It was here that he met his wife, Ensign Constance Rose Gomory. They were married in uniform in 1944. Following the war, Mr. Kromer continued his career in construction labor relations and was named Executive Vice President of the Mechanical Contractors Association of America in 1963. During his tenure, he served as a labor relations advisor to Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. He also collaborated on the landmark construction industry equal-opportunity employment legislation known as ''The Philadelphia Plan.'' He lectured at Cornell's School of Industrial Labor Relations, authored several publications and was named Engineering News-Record's Man of the Year. From 1971 to his retirement, Mr. Kromer headed the Construction Employers of the Hudson Valley and resided in Millbrook, NY. Mr. Kromer was an avid equestrian and tennis enthusiast. He also served on the vestry of Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, New York, NY and Christ Episcopal Church, Poughkeepsie, NY. Mr. Kromer is survived by a sister, Jane K. Kean, of Bethesda, MD; a son and daughter-in-law, William A. and Blanca V. Kromer, of Downsville, NY and a son, Jonathan M. Kromer of Charlotte. A memorial service will be held 11:00 A.M., Friday, September 24, 1999 at Christ Church, Poughkeepsie, NY where he will share space in the columbarium with his wife, Constance, who died in 1997. Harry & Bryant Company is serving the Kromer family.

But bringing China into the global trading community will yield big dividends, and the Administration should make a maximum effort to conclude an agreement.

description: FRECH-Hans A. On September 13, after a long illness. Born Rotterdam, Netherlands April 23, 1923. Son of the late Erhard Gustav Frech and Martha Popen. Graduated from College Montana in Switzerland. Spent W.W. II in a labor camp in Germany since he refused to sign the Nazi loyalty pledge. Left the family shipping business to pursue a career in the U.S. Associated as a chartering broker with A. Johnson & Co. Survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Patricia Hazard Powers and daughters Linda Taft of Belle Mead, NJ, Helen Kippax of Larchmont, NY, Patricia Young of Russellville, AK, 3 sons-in-law, eight grandchildren, adoring dog Pepper and devoted housekeeper, Margarete Ambrosius. In celebration of Hans' love for animals, please send contributions to Last Hope Animal Rescue, Inc., PO Box 61, Syosset NY 11791. Memorial service on Saturday, September 18 at the French Church du St. Esprit, 109 East 60 Street at 11 A.M.

title: A Higher Minimum Wage
description: With the economy strong and the unemployment rate at its lowest in more than 25 years, Democrats in Congress are right to push for an increase in the minimum wage. An increase now will boost income for the poorest workers without the danger of creating more unemployment. But Republicans resist the idea, even though the minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, has declined in purchasing power over the past three decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWER, JOHN F.
description: POWER-John F. Of Gulfstream, FL on September 13, 1999 at the age of 93. Husband of Margaret M. Power. Father of Mary, Jack, Pat, Peg, Catherine, James and Betsy. Grandfather of 28 and great grandfather of 25. Born June 3, 1906 in New York City. Graduate of Holy Cross College 1928. Retired senior partner of Blyth Eastman Dillon Union Securities and 25 year member of the New York Stock Exchange. Served as a director of many corporations including Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of New York, Palm Beach Co., Consolidated Cigar, Skelly Oil and Kewanee Oil. Former member of The Everglades Club, Gulfstream Golf Club, River Club, University Club and Ekwanok Country Club. Services private. Contributions in his honor may be made to Wayside House, 378 N.E. 6th Avenue, Delray Beach, Florida, or Friends of Karen, Purdys, New York.

title: Retail Sales Posted Gain Last Month
description: Retail sales surged in August as people bought up cars and clothing, Government figures showed today, indicating optimism about an economy that is closing in on a record expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, FRED
description: JOHNSON-Fred. The officers, staff and members of Local 2110, UAW, mourn the untimely passing of our beloved organizer and friend, Fred Johnson. His warmth, empathy and concern for our membership will never be forgotten. Fred never gave up on the struggle for justice for workers. We will all miss you. A funeral mass is scheduled for Friday, September 17 at 10am at St. Theresa's Church, 2078 Centre Street, West Roxbury, MA 02132. For further details, contact P.E. Murray Funeral Home, 617-325-2000.

title: AT&T Cost Cuts Could Trim Long-Distance Jobs
description: As the AT&T Corporation continues to cut costs amid its campaign of cable television acquisitions, thousands of employees in AT&T's core long-distance telephone operation could lose their jobs before the end of next year, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, ESTELLE
description: WOLFF-Estelle. Of Old Tappan, New Jersey on September 13, 1999. Beloved wife of Jay. Devoted mother of Lawrence, Adrienne and Richard. Adored mother-inlaw of Angie & Stacey. Dear sister of Herbert and Robert Rosen. Loving grandmother of Danielle, Jared, Jordan & Michael. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Wednesday at 1:30 PM. Contributions to pancreatic research in the name of Estelle Wolff care of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital would be appreciated.

title: In New Tactic, State Aims to Sue Utilities Over Coal Pollution
description: New York State is opening a new legal front in its fight against pollution drifting from coal-burning power plants in upwind states with an announcement today that it intends to sue 17 power plants to force them to clean up.

title: Treasury Prices Fall on Stronger-Than-Expected Retail Sales
description: A report yesterday of stronger-than-expected retail sales last month helped send bond yields higher, stoking investors' fears of further rate increases by the Federal Reserve.

title: Financial Shares Depress Dow; Technology Buoys Nasdaq
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as fears of rising interest rates continued to deter investors.

title: Italy's Biggest Insurer Makes Hostile Bid for a Competitor
description: In a move to further consolidate Italy's financial industries, the nation's largest insurer, Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A., announced a hostile $12.8 billion bid today for its domestic rival, Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni S.p.A.
