Dr. Rohozynskyj was a dedicated physician who always showed sincere concern for his patients and for Cabrini Medical Center; he will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Maurizio Daliana, MD, Pres., Medical Staff Morton Davidson, MD, Medical Director Raymond LaRaja, MD, Director of Surgery Jeffrey Frerichs, Pres. Cabrini Medical Center

title: Auto Makers Granted Extensions As Labor Negotiations Continue
description: As labor talks covering the nation's 400,000 auto workers continued past the midnight expiration of current labor contracts, the United Automobile Workers union granted contract extensions that allowed auto factories to keep humming without interrupting this year's record auto sales.

title: Dad's Dead, And He's Still a Funny Guy
description: Lester Burnham, played with heavenly finesse by Kevin Spacey in his wittiest and most agile screen performance yet, is a buttoned-down 42-year-old who desperately needs to stop and smell the roses. But he won't get much joy from the ones in his suburban yard. These fussed-over specimens are the handiwork of Lester's wife, Carolyn (Annette Bening), whom Lester introduces at the start of ''American Beauty'' with the same devilish acuity that keeps the rest of this satire so scalding. ''See the way the handle on those pruning shears matches her gardening clogs? That's not an accident,'' Lester remarks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Sells Yen to Curb Sharp Rise Against Dollar

title: The Lives of the Candidates
description: As if kissing babies, waving from balconies and cracking bad jokes at fund-raisers were not enough, politicians have now added the art of book promotion to their repertoires. Although Gen. Colin L. Powell decided not to run four years ago, he set a trend with his memoir, ''My American Journey.'' Now John McCain, Bill Bradley, Pat Buchanan and Dan Quayle are following suit with books of their own.

title: Metro Business; GPU to Sell Oyster Creek
description: GPU Inc. has agreed to sell its Oyster Creek nuclear generating plant in Lacey Township, N.J., for $10 million to AmerGen Energy Co., a venture between Peco Energy Co. and British Energy Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: Monster Storm Has So Far Danced Steps Mapped by the Experts
description: In one sense, Hurricane Floyd has been a well-behaved storm. Almost always, hurricanes deal out surprises that throw the experts off. But in the course of its two-week life, this storm has developed, grown into a monster, moved westward and then weakened somewhat, almost precisely as meteorologists expected it to.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MICHAELSON, MURRAY
description: MICHAELSON-Murray. 50 years and there is still a void in my life. Children and grandchildren don't fill it. Love always, Edith, Susan, Hilary; Ian, Mara and Benjamin.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile of Representative Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx on Monday misidentified the medal awarded to Frank Sinatra in 1997 with Mr. Serrano's backing. It was the Congressional Gold Medal, not the Medal of Honor.

title: Man Charged In the Shooting Of a Boy, 3
description: A 3-year-old Queens boy who was critically wounded Monday night was shot by a man who admitted that he was cleaning a gun in an apartment where there were three children, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

description: KLOHR-Rev. Paul McC. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Finbar's Church, 138 Bay 20th St., Brooklyn, September 13. title: Rules on Drought Are Eased in New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ended the drought emergency in eight counties in southern New Jersey yesterday but ordered most emergency rules on outdoor water use to remain in effect in the state's 13 other counties.

title: Travel Tip for Jan. 1, 2000: Stay Home
description: The people at the State Department did their best to be diplomatic today, but there was no getting away from the message: Saturday, Jan. 1, 2000, may not be the best day to travel abroad.

title: ONEX UNIT AGREES TO BUY NELSON METAL PRODUCTS
description: The Onex Corporation, a Canadian investment company, said its J. L. French Automotive Castings Inc. unit had agreed to buy the Nelson Metal Products Corporation, based in Glasgow, Ky., a maker of aluminum auto parts, for about $180 million. Nelson Metal, owned by Jim Humphrey and John Humphrey, produces aluminum auto parts. The transaction will add $204 million in annual revenue to J. L. French, based in Sheboygan, Wis. Onex also has investments in Dura Automotive Systems Inc. and Tower Automotive Inc.

title: Music and Marketing in Central Park
description: What noble cause could bring together Sheryl Crow, Keith Richards, Eric Clapton, Sarah McLachlan, Stevie Nicks, Chrissie Hynde and the band with the current No. 1 album, the Dixie Chicks, for a concert in Central Park? Famine relief, perhaps, or a political statement? Well, no. It was the introduction of a new credit card and the chance for prime time television exposure that united the musicians and provided a free show for 25,000 ticket-holders, along with radio listeners and viewers on the Fox Network. The full two-hour version is to be broadcast on the FX cable network on Sunday at 8 P.M.

title: Swiss Ask Whether Russian Used Aeroflot to Siphon Millions
description: In the Swiss investigation of possible Russian money laundering, the authorities have moved aggressively against two Swiss companies that worked for the Russian airline Aeroflot, where the powerful Moscow financier Boris A. Berezovsky had wielded considerable influence.

title: CNBC Invests In Electronic Stock Trader
description: CNBC yesterday demonstrated the new willingness of media companies to move out of the meat-and-potatoes business of news and into the world of finance itself, taking a 12.4 percent equity stake in Archipelago, the third-largest electronic communications network for trading stocks.

title: Giants' Weathers A Quick Study
description: For the last two months, the Giants' veteran and the rookie have talked every day. Phillippi Sparks, one of the best cover cornerbacks in pro football, was trying to educate Andre Weathers, a sixth-round draft choice this year from Michigan, on the nuances of playing a position where one mistake could lose a game.

title: U.S. Plans Big Aid Package To Rally a Reeling Colombia
description: With Colombia's Government buckling under the pressure of guerrilla attacks, a thriving drug trade and the worst economy in decades, the Clinton Administration is putting together a major new effort to prop up the country's democracy that will include hundreds of millions of dollars in economic and military aid.

title: A Catholic Women's College Prays for a Miracle
description: Last year, when reports of financial instability surfaced at Trinity College of Vermont, a small Roman Catholic liberal arts institution and the state's only women's college, people in the academic community gathered occasionally to pray for the welfare of the college.

description: To the Editor:

title: Going Beyond the 'Wow' Factor on Giant Screens
description: Shot with a 70-millimeter camera and chockablock with spectacular adventure and nature scenes, the giant-screen movie has become a hugely popular fixture at 300 specially equipped theaters worldwide, but it is experiencing an identity crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUSSELL, RAY E.
description: TRUSSELL-Ray E. Greater New York Hospital Association mourns the passing of Ray E. Trussell, M.D. In addition to serving as former Commissioner of Hospitals in New York City and former General Director of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, Dr. Trussell was also a dedicated Board Member and leader of Greater New York Hospital Association. He will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the field of health care in NY. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Elizabeth D. Trussell, M.D., his entire family and many friends. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth A. Raske, President Greater N.Y. Hospital Association

title: Campaign Finance Tactics
description: In one of its finest moments, the House of Representatives listened to its collective conscience Tuesday night and passed the Shays-Meehan campaign finance reform bill. Representative Christopher Shays reflected both the historic importance of the vote and the tremendous challenge ahead with an apt comparison to the great civil rights debates of the 1960's. As they did a generation ago, proponents of progress will now have to force an obstructionist minority in the Senate to face vote after vote to expose their motives. It may, therefore, be the moment to consider tactical changes in the legislation if there is a possibility of winning more Republicans on the next vote.

title: Metrocard Restrictions At Turnstiles to Be Eased
description: New York City Transit said yesterday that it had begun altering the electronic systems in its 3,200 subway turnstiles to eliminate some lockout periods for Metrocards.

title: Not Easy Being Clean
description: Odyssey Channel has only 29 million subscribers, but one of its owners, the Jim Henson Company, has a famous child-friendly celebrity, Kermit the Frog. Concerned that parents do not know how to use the V-chip blocking devices now being added as required equipment on all new televisions, Henson and Odyssey have made Kermit the national spokes frog for a V-chip awareness campaign of public service announcements, which Odyssey will permit all cable system operators to use. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Puzzling Then, Poignant Now: A Beckettian Festival
description: Wherever one turns at the Barbican Center, there is Samuel Beckett's eaglelike image: in posters, programs and in an exhibition of John Haynes's striking photographs of the writer and actors in memorable past productions of his plays. In the two theaters at the Barbican, the home of the Royal Shakespeare Company in season, all 19 of Beckett's stage plays are being performed, offering theatergoers the equivalent of a retrospective of a painter's body of work.

title: Legal Setbacks Could Mar Talks on Forced Labor in Nazi Camps
description: The dismissal Monday of five Federal lawsuits filed against German companies by survivors of Nazi labor and concentration camps could have its biggest impact not on judicial proceedings but on a series of negotiations the State Department has been coordinating in the last year, officials involved in the talks said.

title: In Spain, A Chef To Rival Dali
description: SOME say it is the best restaurant in Europe, possibly the world. No one mentioned that it is also so remote. A friend and I sped around hairpin curves on a pitted, single-lane mountain road northeast of Barcelona, with nothing above us and the Mediterranean a sharp descent below.

title: Undeterred by Past, Mrs. Clinton Sees Health Care as Senate Issue
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she would embrace the issue of health care coverage in her probable race for the United States Senate next year, asserting that public concern about the subject had grown since her campaign to change the system collapsed in failure six years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, ALEXANDER
description: SPERLING-Alexander. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Alexander Sperling, beloved husband of Mura and father of Carol Sperling and Nora Coblence. title: Whose Time Is It?
description: When one of the season's new shows gets yanked off the air before the television season even starts, it usually means that the network thought the show was so awful it engaged in a mercy killing.

title: Algerian Work for G.E.
description: The General Electric Company, the world's No. 1 maker of gas turbines for power generation, said today that its Italian unit had agreed to build a power plant for Algeria's state-owned oil company for $107 million. The GE Nuovo Pignone unit, based in Florence, makes compressors and gas and steam turbines for the oil and gas industry worldwide. The new plant for Sonatrach, Algeria's oil and gas research and distribution company, will serve the Ghadames oilfield in southeastern Algeria.

title: Smoke Gets in Your Meat, Not in Your Eyes
description: THERE is a single problem inherent in smoking food indoors: the smoke.

title: Simon Honored
description: William E. Simon, who as treasurer (1977-80) and president (1981-84) rescued the United States Olympic Committee from near bankruptcy, received the organization's Gen. Douglas MacArthur Award yesterday at a Manhattan luncheon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, MARY T.
description: McNAMARA-Mary T. On September 12, 1999. A longtime Newsweek employee, (retired) died Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. A native of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, PA, Ms. McNamara had been a Manhattan resident for over 20 years. She retired from Newsweek in 1991 as the Manager of Advertising Business Services. In 1986 Ms. McNamara was named Newsweek Employee of the Year and was inducted into the New York YWCA's prestigious Academy of Women Achievers. She was the beloved eldest daughter of the late Margaret and Frank McNamara and is survived by four sisters, a brother, 21 nieces and nephews, and many loving friends. Friends and colleagues wishing to make a memorial donation may send offerings in her name to The American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St. New York, New York 10019-3984.

title: Stanford President to Resign in 2000 and Teach Law Full Time
description: Gerhard Casper, the president of Stanford University, announced yesterday that he would resign at the end of August 2000, citing the perpetual need for fresh perspectives on campus and his desire to focus on teaching undergraduates.

title: Republicans Step Up Attack On Clinton's Russia Policy
description: Congressional Republicans ratcheted up their attack on President Clinton's Russia policy today, expanding the scope of hearings into the Russian banking scandal and Washington's dealings with Moscow.

title: SEAGATE, MAKER OF DISK DRIVES, TO CUT 8,000 JOBS
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the No. 1 computer disk-drive maker, said yesterday that it would cut 8,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its workers, as part of a plan to improve operations in the face of falling prices. Seagate plans to take a pretax charge of $200 million for the cuts, which will be made through dismissals and retirements at plants in Singapore, China, Malaysia, Thailand, Scotland and the United States in the next nine months. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., is expected to report a loss this quarter in part because it is slashing prices to compete with rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAFMAN, SOL
description: BRAFMAN-Sol. For more than fifty years served as a well-respected leader of various well known Jewish Organizations, died this past Friday of complications following surgery. Born in Vienna, Austria, Mr. Brafman, as a young man is credited with saving Torahs (sacred scrolls) from burning synagogues set ablaze by Nazi Stormtroopers on Kristalnacht (the night of broken glass). Soon after his arrival in the United States, Mr. Brafman enlisted in the United States Army where he fought with distinction for three years as a Sergeant in a combat infantry division stationed in the Philippine Islands. During the War, Mr. Brafman conducted a Passover Seder for 2,000 G.I.'s trapped in the Philippine jungles. After Japan's surrender, Mr. Brafman enlisted the help of Army engineers and helped rebuild the only synagogue in the Philippine Islands that had been destroyed by Allied bombing raids. Mr. Brafman is survived by four children, Rabbi Aaron Brafman of Far Rockaway, N.Y. Mrs. Malkie-Aaron-Brafman of Englewood, N.J., Mr. Benjamin Brafman of Lawrence, N.Y., Mrs. Shevy - Cooperberg - Brafman of Lawrence, N.Y.; a brother Morris Brafman of Miami, Florida; fourteen grandchildren and 22 greatgrandchildren. Mr. Brafman's wife of fifty-five years Rose FriedmanBrafman died in 1996.

title: Proud but Concerned, Tribunal Prosecutor Leaves
description: The head of the Bosnian Serb army was casually sipping coffee with colleagues in Vienna one morning in August when he was suddenly called away. The officer, Gen. Momir Talic, could not have expected what happened next: the Austrian police arrested him on charges of crimes against humanity.

title: Southeast Coast Braces as Hurricane Wheels Nearer
description: After days of worry and preparation, with much of the state's eastern coast boarded up and deserted, people here in Florida braced today for an encounter with monstrous Hurricane Floyd.

title: A Birthday Celebration One Day After the Fact
description: Bernie Williams stabbed at his steak a few times, he mumbled a few words and then he turned silent. It was Williams's birthday dinner on Monday night and he was supposed to be celebrating turning 31 with his wife, Waleska. Instead, Waleska spent an hour trying to pull complete sentences from her husband's mouth without success.

title: HERBALIFE SAYS CHIEF EXECUTIVE TO BUY BACK ALL ITS STOCK
description: Herbalife International Inc., which sells nutritional and weight-management products, said late on Monday that its founder and chief executive, Mark Hughes, planned to buy all the stock he does not already own for $486 million in cash. The offer is $17 a share for both class A and B shares. The class A shares rose 36 percent in Nasdaq trading, climbing $3.125, to $15.125, and the class B shares soared 59 percent, or $5.5313, to $14.6875. Herbalife's board approved the transaction after setting up a committee of its independent board members to review the offer and hiring Bear, Stearns & Company to help evaluate it.

title: Lawmaker Questions Principal's Selection
description: A state senator has called for an investigation into the hiring of the campaign manager for a slate of school-board candidates as the principal of Elizabeth High School.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: A Gift Shines Light Upon Ancient China; 5,000-Piece Art Collection Tells Some Unusual Tales
description: When the Smithsonian Institution announced this month that a trove of Chinese art amassed over nearly 60 years by the American collector Paul Singer (1904-1997) had been given to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery here, the details were rather staggering.

title: Corrections
description: The Television section on Sunday carried erroneous listings for the Metro Channel for each day this week. Correct listings will appear on the daily television page each day, starting today and through Saturday.

title: Mrs. Clinton Revisits Issue of Health Care
description: The First Lady said she would embrace the issue of health care coverage in her probable race for United States Senate. Her remarks signaled that she did not consider her close connection with the President's proposal for universal health care, viewed by many as one of his greatest failures, as a political liability.

title: Fatal Trust in Timor
description: Fleeing Dili before it was burned to the ground, I did not have the chance to say goodbye to friends. I have little idea what became of most of them. I heard from the few who escaped East Timor that Manuel climbed into the hills, Fernanda was missing after her house was looted and burned, and Olandina was killed. Every day I wonder who is dead, who is confined in a refugee camp in West Timor and who is eating roots and leaves on some hillside.

title: New Delhi Journal; An Octogenarian Mixes Politics, Sex and Scotch
description: ''With lust, you go kaput at a certain age,'' said Khushwant Singh, one of India's most popular writers and eccentric characters, who at 84 has just written a sexy potboiler that he said could have been called ''The Fantasies of an Octogenarian.''

title: Bagging the Endangered Sandwich
description: WHEN I first came to New York, at 17, I pestered the school friend I was visiting until he took me to Lindy's for corned beef and cheesecake. I figured that that was the closest an Ohio kid was likely to get to the fragrant, seductively shady world of Damon Runyon and Walter Winchell -- ''boxers, bookmakers, actors, agents, ticket brokers, radio guys, song writers, orchestra leaders, newspapermen and cops,'' as Runyon described them, ''still sleep-groggy'' as they gathered for breakfast at 1 P.M., ''but shaved and talcumed and lacking only their java to make them ready for the day.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Maytag's Lag in Disclosure Costs It Dearly
description: WERE some investors lucky or did they know something was awry last week at the Maytag Corporation?

title: National News Briefs; Top Waco Prosecutor Removes Staff From Case
description: The top Federal prosecutor in Texas responsible for handling all legal matters related to the F.B.I. tear-gas assault near Waco, Tex., has asked for and received permission from the Justice Department to be recused from the case, according to legal papers disclosed today in Texas.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL WITH NEW LIMITS ON CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: Defying the Republican leadership, the House late tonight voted for the second year in a row to limit the influence of money in politics and overhaul the way the nation's political campaigns are financed.

description: Bobby Valentine explained before the game what tinkering he wanted his rookie starter, Octavio Dotel, to do in his first outing in the pitcher-killing Coors Field.

title: Report Faults School District For Costly Site Near Oilfield
description: Internal investigators for the Los Angeles school district released a report today that criticized senior school officials, consultants and outside lawyers for their roles in the development of a $200 million high school that may never be finished because of environmental concerns about its site near an abandoned oilfield.

title: Bull's-Eye In Middle Of Potvin's Sweater
description: Playing behind the youngest defense in the league and burdened by the weight of trying to restore his reputation as one of hockey's top goaltenders, the Islanders' Felix Potvin is facing the biggest challenge of his career.

title: Syracuse Tries 2 Underclassmen to Succeed McNabb
description: Replacing Donovan McNabb as Syracuse quarterback would be difficult for even a highly touted upperclassman with obvious talent and impressive size. It would seem harder to replace a four-year fixture like McNabb with an undersized redshirt freshman who was lightly recruited at this position outside the Ivy League.

title: Cabernets for King And Commoner
description: DID I miss something? Weren't we all supposed to be drinking better wine than we did a decade or so ago? That is what the American wine industry promised us after thousands of acres of vines were replanted in the late 1980's and early 90's, after having been devastated by phylloxera, a microscopic bug that eats vine roots. Winemakers said the new vines would be stronger, the wine better, and wine lovers of all income groups would benefit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MARK

title: Information Industry Poses a Big Challenge : British Unions Seeking New Tactics in New Era
description: BRIGHTON, England  Martin McGrath related how his father was a lifetime union member who worked for 32 years in Britain's nationalized electricity industry, a closed shop in an era when a job for life and a union card were a reasonable expectation for most men.

description: The on-line auction site Ebay confirmed yesterday that it planned to prohibit the sale of alcohol and tobacco products on its service, asserting that the sales could subject some users to prosecution under a growing number of state regulations governing the sale of such products across state lines.

title: Benjamin Bloom, 86, a Leader In the Creation of Head Start
description: Benjamin S. Bloom, whose path-breaking 1964 research showing the profound impact of early childhood experience on adult ability helped lead to the creation of the Head Start program, died on Monday. He was 86.

title: Bad Knee Puts Williams Of Nets Out Till Jan. 1
description: When the Nets open training camp in Atlantic City on Oct. 5, Jayson Williams will be on crutches.

title: Liability Fears Sink Republic New York's Share Price
description: Fears about the Republic New York Corporation's liability in what prosecutors are now calling a huge fraud dragged down the company's stock for the third consecutive trading session yesterday.

title: Telstra of Australia in Deal With Frontier
description: Expanding into the United States telecommunications market for the first time, the Telstra Corporation Ltd., Australia's dominant telephone company, plans to announce today that it has an agreement to buy $20 million worth of long-distance phone capacity from the Frontier Corporation, which was formerly Rochester Telephone.

title: Olympus Isn't Big Enough for Two Sex Goddesses
description: Venus is one dangerous mother in ''Psyche,'' a theatrical concoction whipped up by Moliere and Corneille in 1671 on commission from Louis XIV. Outraged that men, with no help from herself, are falling in love with the young woman of the title, the goddess orders her son Cupid to mess up Psyche's love life. When he succumbs to Psyche's allure, Mama summons powers from Hades and Olympus to humiliate her offspring and wipe out Psyche. It all ends happily, of course, when Jupiter -- sounding not unlike Louis XIV in decree mode -- revives Psyche, makes her an immortal and declares her Cupid's for eternity.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Four Questions
description: Once again a vicious civil war. Once again the call for U.S. troops. This time to East Timor, which is one of the farthest places you can fly from Washington D.C. and still be on this planet. What to do? What criteria do we use when deciding whether to dispatch forces to small, distant corners where some outrage is being committed? I would start with the following four questions:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RABBI SAMUEL
description: COHEN-Rabbi Samuel. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, and, since 1926, partners with the Jewish National Fund in the reclamation of the land of Israel, mourns the passing of JNF's former Executive Vice President and longtime Zionist leader. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, HERBERT S.
description: FEINBERG-Herbert S. On September 13, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Devoted father of Brian. Cherished uncle and friend. Services Wednesday, 11AM, at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Seven Are Cited In Honors List
description: The American Advertising Federation will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives 40 and younger.

title: Scottish & Newcastle in $1.8 Billion Pub Deal
description: Scottish & Newcastle P.L.C., Britain's dominant brewer, said today that it had agreed to buy 868 pubs, restaurants and budget hotels from the ailing Greenalls Group P.L.C. for $1.8 billion.

title: I've Been Sleeping On the Rail Road; Long Island Morning Nightmare Is Medical Researcher's Dream
description: Clarence Simpson was ambitious this morning. He brought a newspaper, a glossy magazine and even a book to read during his hour-and-17-minute ride into work.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Maybe they need to consider living closer in. Or at least making sleep a priority, compared to something else they do in the week that's less important. It's usually the last thing people think about. People say they'll sleep when they're dead. But this way, they'll be dead sooner.''

title: For Australia, the Clock Is Counting Down
description: In exactly one year, the largest event in the history of sports will get under way here, where billions of dollars, national pride and international prestige will all be at stake at the 2000 Summer Games.

title: Con Ed Apologizes for Role In a Nuclear Plant Shutdown
description: After the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant unexpectedly shut down two weeks ago, managers focused on maintenance work that they wanted to do and did not pay sufficient attention to an electrical malfunction that eventually led to a low-level emergency, the Consolidated Edison Company said today.

title: Reviews/Fashion; And Now, a Gentle Nudge From Herrera and de la Renta
description: Back in the late 1980's, in that opulent birthday cake known as the Plaza, Oscar de la Renta and Carolina Herrera were putting on the kind of fashion shows that practically sealed their fate in swag. They were identified with it. A good-looking model, coiffed, swathed up to her skinny chin in bows, would come barreling down the runway, train her eyeballs on the room like a howitzer and pivot in an insolent rustle of taffeta.

title: Vietnamese Pork Chops Demystified
description: I WAS sitting in a Vietnamese restaurant a couple of years ago, when a beguiling aroma wafted by. The source was a plate of pork chops, which I immediately ordered. Some of the smells and flavors were fairly easy to identify: garlic, lots of it, and lime and nuoc mam, the Vietnamese fish sauce known more commonly by its Thai name, nam pla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ZELIK
description: KAPLAN-Zelik. On Sept. 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Bettie. Devoted father of Barbara Kessler and Michael Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Lori, Emily, and Peter. Loving father-in-law of Floyd and Barbara. Loving brother of Sara Farbman. Retired school principal of PS 62 and 113 of Queens. Services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, from ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer'' Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: It's a Hybrid In Sport Utility Clothes; A Car-Based Light Truck, It Obeys the Fuel Rules, and It Helps Make Money
description: Scheduled to go on sale next spring, the Chrysler PT Cruiser is not quite a sport utility vehicle and not really a minivan.

title: Clemency, From Bronx Leader to First Lady
description: ROBERTO RAMIREZ, the willful, shrewd, quick, powerful, autocratic and very entertaining Democratic leader of the Bronx, the one who arrived from Puerto Rico at the age of 19 speaking no English and then graduated from New York University's law school, handled Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent blowup with the city's Puerto Rican community like this:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday about the dedication of the new United States Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, referred imprecisely to a picture of the American helicopter evacuation of the city in 1975. The building shown housed employees of the United States Embassy, but was not the embassy itself.

title: After Years and Millions, City Starts Over in Computer Effort
description: Early this decade, the city's Police and Fire Departments, eager to keep pace with technological advances, committed millions of dollars to designing fully modern computer systems to help them respond faster and more effectively to emergencies. But after spending years and more than $20 million, neither department has produced the kind of dispatch system it had promised, and both have announced that they are, in effect, starting over.

title: Sale of Radio Stations
description: Regent Communications Inc., which owns 38 radio stations, said today it would buy three stations from New Wave Broadcasting L.P. for $23.5 million in cash in its fourth acquisition this year. The stations are in El Paso. KLAQ-FM has an album-oriented rock format, KSII-FM features alternative country and KROD-AM carries news, talk and sports, Regent said. New Wave also owns five stations in Honolulu and five in Monterey, Calif.

title: Idea of Rewarding 'Strivers' Is Opposed by College Board
description: For more than two years, the Educational Testing Service, the author of the nation's most widely used college entrance examination, has been working to devise a formula to help admissions officers identify disadvantaged students who score better than might have been predicted by racial, economic and other factors.

title: Accounts
description: * Gillespie, Princeton, N.J., was awarded the first accounts of two Internet companies with combined billings estimated at $15 million: Gobi.com, New York, an Internet service provider and computer leasing company, and Media and Beyond, New York, a computer and electronics retailer. Both decisions came without reviews. Gillespie is part of the MRM unit of McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: People
description: * Edward D. Powers, chief financial and administrative officer at BSMG Worldwide, New York, part of True North Communications, was named to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: Study Says Overweight Adults Push Up Cost of Health Care
description: Spending on health care for the growing number of adults who are seriously overweight accounts for almost one-third of the national cost of treating 15 important diseases, including diabetes, heart disease, stroke and hypertension, the Lewin Group, a health care research and consulting group, said yesterday.

title: On East Timor, the U.S. Abuses the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Troops for East Timor

title: Bouley Returns, Deft and Daring
description: DAVID BOULEY has always been a man with a plan. Too many plans, it sometimes seems. When he closed the four-star Bouley in 1996, he spoke of imperial ambitions that verged on the Napoleonic, right down to the wholesale conquest of Russia and Austria-Hungary. In partnership with Warner LeRoy, he planned to resuscitate the Russian Tea Room. He also envisioned a restaurant devoted to Austro-Hungarian cuisine, a cooking school and other ventures. And, oh yes, while these schemes unfolded, he would keep busy with a little place called Bouley Bakery.

title: G.O.P. Cool On Its Plan For H.M.O.'s
description: House Republican leaders, who directed junior members of the party to draft a bill defining patients' rights just five weeks ago, criticized the results of that effort today, saying the bill could expose health maintenance organizations to costly lawsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, ROBERT J., MSGR
description: KELLY-Robert J., Msgr of West Palm Beach FL on September 12, 1999. Pastor Emeritus of St. Charles Church, Oakwood Heights, Staten Island. Beloved brother of Sr. Agnes Kelly, SMR. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home, 2819 Hylan Boulevard, corner of Tysens Lane, S.I. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Reposing at St Charles Church, Thursday, 1:30PM-9:30M. Mass of Holy Eucharist Thursday, 7:30 PM; Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 10:30 AM. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Environmental Group Backs Bradley and Criticizes Gore
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley picked up the endorsement of a national environmental organization today, dealing a blow to Vice President Al Gore's efforts to cast himself as the clear choice of environmentally minded voters in the Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: Workers On Strike at 9 Casinos in Atlantic City
description: Hotel workers at 9 of Atlantic City's 12 casinos went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, three days before the finals of the Miss America pageant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEELE, LUCIE (NEE BELIN)
description: STEELE-Lucie (nee Belin). Of Haverford, PA., on Tuesday, September 14, 1999. Wife of James W. Steele. Mother of Thomas F. Steele II, L. Sherrerd Steele and James W. Steele Jr. Grandmother of four and sister of three. Memorial service Friday, September 17, 3P.M. Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 625 Montgomery Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA. Interment private. Memorial contributions may be made in her memory to the Arthritis Foundation, 117 South 17th St., Suite 1905, Philadelpha, PA 19103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPALDING, JEAN U.
description: SPALDING-Jean U., September 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John C. Spalding. Loving aunt of Dr. Ann Simon Koppelman and great-aunt of Erika and Sabrina Simon. A past member of the Colony Club, she was a linens buyer at Lord & Taylor and later operated a linens store on Park Avenue. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, September 15, 11:30-12:30 with a prayer service following. Interment, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

title: P.& G. to Tie Agency Compensation to Sales
description: The world's largest advertiser, the Procter & Gamble Company, plans major changes in how it pays the agencies that create campaigns for its 300 household brands around the world, which include Cheer, Crest, Folger's, Ivory, Jif, Noxzema, Pampers, Pringles and Tide.

title: Sports of The Times; How Torre Deals With The Boss
description: AS the Yankees squirm, George Steinbrenner is strangely silent, at least publicly.

title: INTERNET STAKE SOLD
description: A group of investors led by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company paid $100 million for a minority holding in Latin America's largest Internet company. The purchase of the 12.5 percent stake in the company, Universo Online, a Sao Paulo-based venture with close to 500,000 subscribers, provides some of the capital it needs to expand in the Spanish-speaking countries of Latin America. Universo Online faces competition in Latin America from companies like the Microsoft Corporation, Psinet Inc. and America Online Inc.

title: Albany's Lobbying Toll
description: With the tobacco industry under siege in recent years, New York State has offered cigarette manufacturers a legislative safety zone. There have been no extra taxes on cigarettes since 1993, and no extra burdens on tobacco companies that have faced tariffs and controls elsewhere on their hazardous products.

description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of Smart Car Division At Daimler to Step Down
description: Lars Brorsen, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s struggling Smart car business, will resign at the end of the month.

title: Demure and Brassy Mix (With a Cherry on Top)
description: Faith Prince wants us to know that she is a very different creature from her signature stage role, Adelaide, the flouncing, jouncing New York tootsie of ''Guys and Dolls.'' As she reiterated several times at Monday's opening night performance of her smart new cabaret at Joe's Pub (the show plays two more Mondays), at heart she's really just a wholesome Southern gal (from Lynchburg, Va.) who paid a lot of dues in summer stock before leaping to Broadway.

title: U S AIRWAYS DOES NOT EXPECT THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT
description: U S Airways Group Inc., the nation's sixth-largest carrier, said yesterday that it would not make a profit in the third quarter because operational problems were leading it to cancel flights and lose customers. The airline, based in Arlington, Va., did not issue a specific forecast. Analysts had expected it to earn 89 cents a share. U S Airways attributed its troubles largely to labor negotiations. The airlines and the machinists' union are in talks to replace a contract for mechanics and cleaners that expires Sept. 25. U S Airways has also struggled because of computer-system changes and severe weather. Its shares have lost more than a third of their value in the last three months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, IRVING J.
description: ROBERTS-Irving J., of Pompano Beach, Florida, and East Hampton, NY. Husband of Elaine (Fink), father of John and Nora, grandfather of Catherine and Daniel. Services private.

title: Baltimore Democrats Pick White Councilman in Mayoral Primary
description: City Councilman Martin O'Malley, a 36-year-old former prosecutor who has vowed to crack down on the city's alarming wave of drug dealing and homicide, was elected today as the Democratic mayoral nominee in a primary victory tantamount to final election in this Democratic bastion.

title: Napoleon Complex: The Scent of Exile
description: THE BLACK ROOM AT LONGWOOD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MRAZ, CHARLES
description: MRAZ-Charles. Age 94. Died September 13 in Middlebury, VT. He was an internationally known bee keeper and apitherapist. Funeral services are on September 16th at 10 A.M. at St. Stephens Church in Middlebury, VT.

title: Hurricane Threat Causes Cancellations
description: As daylight pierced the darkness this morning, the Miami Dolphins noticed something eerie as their chartered buses headed east on Alligator Alley toward Fort Lauderdale. They had the one-way road to themselves. Across a median strip, they could see bumper-to-bumper traffic going west -- and away from Hurricane Floyd.

title: Liberties; Trust But Verify
description: After W. dropped his handkerchief in June, he sat on the porch by the ocean in Kennebunkport. I asked him if it was scary to run for President, when he knew so little about foreign affairs.

title: CHANCELLOR CITES TEST SCORE ERRORS
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew revealed yesterday that significant errors were made in scoring the high-stakes tests given last spring to determine who would be assigned to summer school and that some children had been compelled to attend by mistake.

title: Slowly and Testily, Savannah Empties
description: The evacuation of Savannah began at dawn today, an endless motorized march of steaming engines and crying children fleeing the winds that threatened this old city's historic buildings and Spanish moss.

title: Nutritional Advice
description: The Devils spent yesterday at training camp in West Orange, N.J., talking to a nutrition expert about the kind of eating habits they should follow throughout the season.

title: Business Travel; A company aims to make it easier for executives to work while flying around in corporate jets.
description: ON occasions when retired chief executives and other corporate bigwigs run into one another, they seldom talk about how they miss the old grind at the office. But they can get downright teary when they talk about how much they miss that lovely airplane.

title: Kennedy Center Lauds 5 In the Performing Arts
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced the names of the recipients of its annual honors today. One, Victor Borge, received the official word while rehearsing for a performance with the Houston Symphony.

title: BROKERAGE SALE ADVANCES
description: South Korean creditors of the Daewoo Securities Company plan to sell the brokerage through private talks rather than through public bidding and the sale will be handled by Arthur Andersen Korea, according to its main creditor, Korea First Bank. Creditors took over Daewoo Securities from its parent Daewoo Group last month as part of an effort to save the conglomerate from bankruptcy.

title: Deja Vu All Over Again
description: Throughout the century the party-bolters have formed an interesting, if usually feckless, category in American politics. The latest Republican apostate, Patrick Buchanan, likes to compare himself to the noblest renegade of them all, Teddy Roosevelt. In his ideological zeal Mr. Buchanan also calls to mind a Democrat, former Vice President Henry Wallace, who quit his party to challenge Harry Truman from the left in 1948. But when it comes to rhetoric and even to his jackhammer speaking style, Mr. Buchanan is most reminiscent of George Wallace.

title: In Pinch-Hitting Role, Bonilla in Another Fix
description: He is booed as harshly at Shea Stadium as any of the visiting opponent. He was placed on waivers earlier this season, but no one bit, and he ended up stuck in New York, becoming more and more irrelevant with each Mets success.

title: First-Person Plural
description: All four nights of ABC's news magazine ''20/20'' will look different this fall, but the biggest change will be seen on Thursdays. On that night, dominated in recent years by NBC's ''E.R.''-anchored lineup, the program will be called ''20/20 Downtown'' and will feature correspondents roving far afield to tell first-person stories. To conjure up an imaginary example: John Miller, well known for reports on organized crime, might take viewers to the scenes of some of his reporting and recount how he learned what he did.

title: Dillard's Share Buyback
description: The department store company Dillard's Inc. said today that it planned to buy back up to $250 million of its common shares. The retailer, which is based in Little Rock, said some of the repurchased shares would be used for employee benefit plans. Some will be held as treasury shares or retired. The repurchases will be made in the open market or through private negotiations. Dillard's shares rose 44.73 cents today, to $21.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Yankees Overpower Jays in a Grand (Slam) Opera
description: The grieving began in the Yankees' dugout in the seventh inning tonight, after Toronto assumed a 6-1 lead. Looks like another loss, some of them thought. There were glances at the one-sided Boston result on the scoreboard. Looks as if the Red Sox will gain another game in the standing.

title: For a Place That Little Piggies Built, a New Lease on Life
description: I STILL remember how excited I was when Pig Heaven opened, 15 years ago. Not only did the kitschy barnyard motif with plump pink prancing piglets on the wall transcend the design cliches of Chinese restaurants, but the food, a combination of Cantonese and Sichuan with a couple of dozen pork dishes, was intriguing and satisfying. I particularly recall a Pig Heaven takeout meal one Fourth of July when my father was grumpily confined to a hospital room overlooking the East River. Though we could see the celebration going on outside, we were more thrilled by the fireworks on our plates.

title: More Changes In Pepsico Posts
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that it had named Al Bru president and chief executive of Frito-Lay North America and Brock Leach president and chief executive of Tropicana Products.

title: Republican Plans to Tap 2001 Surplus Now
description: Draining the budget surplus for 2000 and thirsty for more money to finance their spending bills, Republicans will tap the projected surplus for 2001 for $12 billion or more, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee said today.

title: Japanese Again Intervene, But Fail to Brake Yen's Rise
description: The Japanese central bank sold yen today for the second time in less than a week in an effort to curb the currency's recent heady rise, but the intervention barely managed to nudge the yen off its three-year high against the dollar.

title: STEAMSHIP COMPANY CHANGES COURSE
description: In a strategic move to shed ancillary businesses, the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company said it would sell its entire stake in Bovis Group when shares of the construction company are sold on the London Stock Exchange next month. Analysts estimate the sale could raise up to 300 million [pounds], or $481 million. P.& O. wants to refocus on its traditional core concerns: cruises, ferries and ports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, EDWARD J.
description: GALLAGHER-Edward J. Died September 12 at New Haven, CT, age 73. A writer of clever ad copy, funny sketches and touching poetry; father of Kevin, Michael and Lisa; WWII veteran; superb actor; comic genius of the Amateur Comedy Club. Memorial gathering at ACC to be announced.

title: THE CHEF; Pizza With a 'Push Button' Crust
description: AS much as I like pizza, I have never been able to serve it at my two bakeries. We just don't have enough space, time or people to get the pizza out for lunch, and pizza doesn't keep.

title: L.A. Flaws Put N.F.L. Plan in Limbo
description: In three weeks, the National Football League is supposed to award its 32d franchise to Los Angeles or Houston. On further review, it may defer the choice until November.

title: Oracle Posts Earnings Growth of 21% for Latest Quarter
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation dropped sharply in after-hours trading this evening after the company reported first-quarter earnings that met the published consensus estimate of analysts but fell short of the so-called whisper number.

title: When the Ownership of Guns Is Itself a Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner Offers Access To the Internet Via TV Cable
description: Seeking to capture a piece of the lucrative market in high-speed Internet services, Time Warner Cable announced yesterday that it is starting to give computer users in parts of Manhattan and Queens fast access to the Internet through the company's cable-television wires.

title: A Day of Debate and Forced Allusion
description: It was a rare moment on the floor of the House of Representatives, two Congressmen actually debating each other face to face rather than delivering monologues and sitting down.

title: U.N. Presses to Organize International Force for East Timor
description: A multinational force of up to 7,000 troops could begin landing in East Timor by the weekend, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today, as the Security Council prepared to vote on the resolution creating the military mission.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: 2 Fans Made To Feel Like Guests

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TO ACQUIRE ALLIANCE IMAGING
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the world's top leveraged-buyout firm, agreed yesterday to acquire Alliance Imaging Inc., the largest United States magnetic-resonance imaging provider, for $55 a share in cash, a total of $313.5 million. The firm, based in New York, will also assume Alliance's debt and pay an additional $17.8 million for its preferred shares. The company, based in Anaheim, Calif., had $520.1 million in long-term debt as of June 30. New York-based Apollo Management L.P. owned 83 percent of Alliance as of May. Alliance had $199.4 million in revenue last year. Its shares, which are thinly traded, soared $32.50 each, to $50.

title: AETNA U.S. HEALTHCARE TO SELL SOME TEXAS OPERATIONS
description: Aetna U.S. Healthcare, a unit of Aetna Inc. of Hartford, agreed yesterday to sell its NYLCare Texas commercial operations to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas for $500 million. With the transaction, Aetna U.S. Healthcare fulfills an agreement with the Justice Department and the Texas Attorney General to shed its NYLCare commercial health maintenance organization businesses in the Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston markets. Antitrust regulators required the sale in return for approval of Aetna's $1 billion acquisition of Prudential Healthcare, the health care unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, a nonprofit division of the Health Care Service Corporation, said the addition of NYLCare Texas' 551,000 members will increase its membership in Texas to almost 2.7 million.

title: Shocked and Appalled
description: William J. Bennett, the former Federal Education Secretary who has become a self-appointed pollution monitor for the nation's movie, music and television industries, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, held a news conference in Washington yesterday to express their outrage over two new Fox series, ''Action'' and ''Get Real.'' They gave their third Silver Sewer Award, a laurel they invented to dishonor people whom Mr. Bennett and Mr. Lieberman perceive as purveyors of cultural filth, to Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation, which owns Fox.

title: All of Mahler Fills Berlin With Sound
description: In this city in the making, where cranes fill the air and whole streets are impassable while block after block is rebuilt from the ground up, a lot of remembering is also going on. The 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin wall is being celebrated as if the city were a young child, and yet it retains, like a split brain, two strong sets of memories from the decades before the rejoicing of 1989. Reaching further back to before the division, books, plays and exhibitions re-examine the Hitler years again and again.

title: A Return and a Demanding Program
description: The conductor Vakhtang Jordania, who was born in the Republic of Georgia, made his conducting debut at Carnegie Hall some 15 years ago, shortly after defecting from what was then the Soviet Union. On Monday night he was back, leading the American Symphony Orchestra. Indeed, newspaper advertisements for the event read: ''Vakhtang Jordania Returns to Carnegie Hall.''

title: Panel Supports Use of Stem Cells for Research
description: A strong endorsement of research on human embryonic stem cells has been issued by the National Bioethics Advisory Commission, 10 months after President Clinton asked the group to weigh the ethical pros and cons of the new technique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, BARBARA
description: KELLER-Barbara. We were inspired by Bobbie's goodness and beauty and will remember her and her beloved Stanley forever. With our sincere condolences to her adored children and grandchildren, loving sister and her dear friends. We will miss you. Lilli and Jerry and family

title: Justice Bars Hirschfeld From Paying More Jurors
description: A judge has barred the millionaire real-estate developer Abe Hirschfeld from paying any of the jurors who will serve in his trial on charges of hiring a hit man to kill his former business partner.

title: Handspring Launches Rival to Palm Pilot
description: Handspring Inc. introduced a hand-held computer today that its says costs less and does more than the best-selling Palm Pilot, the 3Com Corporation's electronic organizer that Handspring based its new model on.

title: 1,300 Refugees From East Timor Flown to Safety in Australia
description: Haunted and huddling, more than 1,300 East Timorese refugees arrived here today on military evacuation planes after the United Nations abandoned its compound to the militias who had laid siege to it after East Timor voted for independence.

title: Many Salad Bars Are Found to Be Overcharging Customers
description: When most New Yorkers want a light lunch, they go to their local self-service salad bar and emerge with a medley of vegetables in a plastic container, closed with a rubber band.

title: What's Crunchy, Sweet and Tangy With a Radish Flavor?
description: THERE'S a gardener's joke from the 1950's about Russian geneticists trying to develop a cross between cabbages and turnips to double their harvest. They ended with a new vegetable that had the roots of a cabbage and the top of a turnip. In truth, as any East European could have told you then, the perfect double-crop vegetable already existed: kohlrabi.

title: Dark-Fleshed Fish: A Taste Worth Acquiring
description: EATING certain foods can be a gustatory badge of courage. Liver, for example, or sweetbreads or even some bitter Asian greens cause many diners to just say, ''Yuck!''

title: From Britain, Mosquitoes Look Like Scourge of Death
description: If you happened to be tracking New York City's encephalitis problems from Britain for the last week, you might be forgiven for recoiling in horror at the Black Death devastating Gotham.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE FALLS. Orange juice prices fell on speculation that most citrus groves in Florida will escape severe damage from Hurricane Floyd. In New York, frozen concentrated orange juice fell 0.45 cent, to 96.55 cents a pound.

title: MARKS TO SELL KINGS MARKETS
description: The once-expansive British retailer Marks & Spencer P.L.C. announced a major overhaul of its United States operations, saying it would sell the Kings supermarkets in New Jersey while promoting Brooks Brothers men's wear stores. In a statement, Marks & Spencer said that Brooks Brothers' 148 stores in the United States, along with 71 stores in Japan and six franchise operations in Hong Kong and Taiwan had ''the potential for growth both in the United States and internationally.'' Brooks Brothers' sales in its 1999 fiscal year totaled $550 million.

title: PUBLIC COMPLAINTS ARE PLAYED DOWN, POLICE DATA SHOW
description: Hundreds of New York City police officers found to have engaged in misconduct by an independent review board escaped punishment when their cases were summarily dismissed by the Police Department without any further investigation, according to a review of disciplinary files by the Public Advocate's office.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, HENRY, DDS
description: LEWIS-Henry, DDS. Beloved husband of Joy. Devoted father of Amy and Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Shana and Davida Rae. Services 1:00 PM Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, AL
description: SHAPIRO-Al. New Line Cinema mourns the passing of Al Shapiro, our beloved friend and colleague. We will miss his wit, wisdom, leadership, and laughter. While we have thirteen years of memories to cherish, we will forever remember a man with an infectious love of life who was equally dedicated to Honnie, his loving wife, and his family at New Line. title: Constructing Ivory Towers To Teach About the Sun and Stars
description: What is an architect to do when asked to design a university for a once nomadic people with limited funds and little knowledge of construction? That was the challenge facing Roto, a Los Angeles-based architectural firm. Roto was commissioned by the Lannan Foundation and the Sicangu Lakota tribe in 1994 to plan and build a campus on the Rosebud Sioux Reservation in Antelope, S.D., for Sinte Gleska, the oldest tribal university in the Americas. After five years of collaboration, a plan was derived that would orient buildings to features of the land the Sicangu Lakota tribe found significant and to the sun and stars. ''The building tells the stories that the curriculum teaches,'' said Clark Stevens, the vice president of Roto.

Autocam makes precision-machined parts for fuel systems, anti-lock brakes and electric motors. Autocam said it wanted to explore all options, including a sale of the company, an injection of equity or other transactions to increase shareholder value. Its shares rose $2.625 each, or 17 percent, to $17.625.

Combining mechanistic imagery (to reflect the high-tech eyeglasses) and soft colors, the shop, left, feels appropriately light. It has an uncluttered, exposed concrete floor and steel scrim shades, seen far left, made from a material manufactured for conveyor belts in a food processing plant. (The mesh can be ordered from the Lumsden Corporation, 717-394-6871.) The 1,400-square-foot shop runs parallel to the street, with the glasses displayed along the back wall. The Lyra bar stools with custom-painted white seats by Design Group Italia are from nearby Modern Living (8775 Beverly Boulevard). The stools, 35 inches in natural beechwood or stained black, are $255. Cynthia Leight, who sells Oliver Peoples, Paul Smith, Matsuda and Anne Valentine spectacles as well as the Cynthia Leight line, is at 123 South Robertson Boulevard; (310) 858-7399.

title: Rediscovering Laszlo

Born in Hungary, Laszlo was a contemporary of the Austrians Richard Neutra and R. M. Schindler, and like them, he studied in Europe but became successful here, winning commissions from Hollywood figures like Barbara Hutton, Fritz Lange and William Wyler. His style often fused clean lines with idiosyncratic, handcrafted textures, as in the lamps, inset, ($16,500 for the pair), designed in 1954 with fabric shades and reverse-painted glass tiles. The armless sofa with Maria Kipp fabric ($8,600) was designed in 1952. Now, Laszlo is being celebrated by Donzella Ltd., a New York store that will have an exhibition of his pieces at the end of the year. Donzella is at 17 White Street, (212) 965 8919.

title: BRAZIL-ARGENTINE TRADE TALKS
description: Brazil dispatched two high-ranking trade negotiators, Jose Alfredo Graca Lima and Jose Botafogo Goncalves, to Buenos Aires to meet with Argentine counterparts to discuss measures restricting imports of Brazilian shoes, textiles and steel and a possible limit on paper shipments. Brazil's currency devaluation earlier this year has made its exports cheaper and raised tensions with neighboring Argentina, threatening the unity of the Mercosur trade bloc, which also includes Paraguay and Uruguay.

title: Hurricane Aims at Coast of Carolinas
description: Having already caused the greatest evacuation in United States history, Hurricane Floyd skirted Florida and Georgia today and aimed itself directly at the low-lying coastal border of the Carolinas, where its eye was expected to come ashore early Thursday.

title: Review/Fashion; When Women Dress Girlish and Girls Dress Sultry
description: Long before there ever was a television show called ''Sex and the City,'' Nicole Miller seemed to exist for the woman who had written the script for it in her head. Such a woman may never have come into contact with an heirloom-tomato salad or a man who owned half of Anguilla, but she dreamed of the life. In a glaring I-won't-let-you-forget-me Miller print, perhaps she would have a shot at attaining it.

title: Glorious Glazes
description: Red Hots -- glorious ceramic tableware by Gaetano America of South El Monte, Calif. -- owe their color to an unusually bright formula for red glaze. ''Red is a temperamental glaze, and the reject factor is very high, so we charge 10 percent more for red than other colors,'' said Irving Chait, who owns the company and also makes the line in 23 other hot colors. Still, prices for Red Hots are affordable: the line includes plates, bowls, crocks, cups, dishes, dinner plates, platters and pasta bowls.

title: Prices on Treasuries Rebound As Fears of Rate Increase Ease
description: Treasury bond prices rebounded somewhat yesterday from the previous day's losses after tame consumer price data eased investors' fears that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates again when its monetary policy committee meets on Oct. 5.

description: Breaking ranks with Broadway's other major theater owners, officials of the Nederlander Organization have reached a separate agreement with the stagehands union.

description: KATZEN-Minnie Rich. September 11th, 1999 in Warrenton, Virginia. Beloved wife of the late Perry Katzen, M.D. Adored mother of Jay Kenneth. Dear mother-in-law of Patricia. Cherished grandmother of Timothy and his wife Debbie; David and his wife Holly; and James. Loving great-grandmother of Melanie. Services are private. description: Despite extensive damage to houses and land on some of the islands east of here, Bahamian officials said today that they were cautiously optimistic that they survived a pummeling from Hurricane Floyd with only one reported fatality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STALLARD, SEFTON
description: STALLARD-Sefton, of New Vernon, N.J. on Sept. 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Ann Wesson & father of Ann Sobine of Basking Ridge, N.J. and Sefton of New York City. Memorial service Saturday, Sept. 25, 1999 10:30 A.M. at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Morristown, N.J. description: YEN CONTINUES ITS RISE. The yen continued to surge against the dollar on expectations that investors will pour more money into Japanese stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.23 yen, down from 105.79 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERGER, HENRY V.
description: SCHONBERGER-Henry V. May 2, 1924-September 12, 1999. Longtime employee of New York Life Insurance Company. Honored member of the New York chapter of Jewish War Veterans. Resident of Pompano Beach FL. Henry was born in NYC to Joseph and Olga and attended DeWitt Clinton High School. Everyone whose life he touched should be grateful for knowing and loving him, ponytail and all. He was a generous, kind and gentle person and will be missed by his friends, children and many grandchildren. Please remember him by loving your family unconditionally. Stop Smoking Now!

They are: DiMassimo Brand Advertising in New York; Grace & Rothschild in New York; Hampel/Stefanides in New York, part of Envoy Communications, and PSK in Boston. A decision is likely this month. Pile & Company in Boston is managing the review.

description: Celeste Goring-Johnson would be considered a soccer mom if she were white and lived somewhere other than Brooklyn.

description: Even before she won the United States Open on Saturday, Serena Williams had a connection to the former tennis great Althea Gibson, the only other African-American woman ever to win a Grand Slam singles title.

description: From a play perspective, the diagramed deal was certainly the most fascinating in the Summer National Championships in San Antonio this year. Look at it first as a problem: would you choose to play or defend five diamonds, given the lead of the spade ace?

description: So far, Mr. Buchanan is only talking about bolting the Republican Party to join the Reform Party. But suppose he actually makes the leap, as seems more and more likely with each passing Buchanan lament about how the Grand Old Party has lost its conservative moorings?

title: Green's Criticism of Police Is Flawed, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed a report by Public Advocate Mark Green on lapses in the Police Department's disciplinary process yesterday, calling it an unfounded attack by a politician primarily interested in advancing his own mayoral ambitions.

title: League Presidents Out As Baseball Centralizes
description: From Morgan Bulkeley in 1876 to Leonard Coleman in 1999, from Ban Johnson in 1901 to Gene Budig in 1999, the National and American Leagues have had presidents who operated offices separate and apart from one another. No longer.

title: For Berliners, Real-Time Traffic Intelligence
description: THE countless construction cranes that hang over Berlin don't just change the skyline: with construction at 35,000 sites every year, getting across town by car is a serious challenge. The routing complications caused by the two separate road systems that evolved over the 28 years that the Berlin Wall divided the city don't help. Add the extra car traffic generated by the relocation of the German seat of Government from Bonn to Berlin, and the result is traffic snarls that can paralyze roads for hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, JOHN MCDONALD
description: MOORE-John McDonald. January 11,1919-Septenber 14, 1999. Cherished husband of Elaine Roberta Werblud Moore. Loving father of Johan North, adored and adoring parent to Marc Werblud, Monica Werblud Valenti, Debra Werblud Camerota and to their spouses: Tabitha Werblud, Angelo Valenti and Filippo Camerota. He was the most devoted, loving and beloved Baba John to Zachary Jonathan Valenti and Alexandra Meredith Werblud. Goethe defined genius as ''a productive power'' whose actions ''have consequenquences and lasting life''. John McDonald Moore as teacher and friend to thousands of students at The New School for Social Research University from 1968 to the present has affirmed this truth. His was a life of honor and dedication and supreme integrity. He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. His inspiration will remain. Service at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue Sunday September 19, 1999 at 12:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, JACK L.
description: HECHT-Jack L. September 14, age 89. We note with great sorrow the loss of our Chairman of the Board. He was our mentor, friend and partner for over 50 years. One of the three founders of Queens Lithographing Corporation. Beloved by our employees, customers and all who knew him. He taught us to treat all people with dignity, respect, integrity and humility. He will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Laura; children, Len and Eileen Hecht, Arlene and Jerry Sanders; and his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Board of Directors Queens Group, Inc.

Beloved son of Angela and the late Charles, devoted brother of Charles Jr., cherished uncle of Charles III, and adored nephew of Peggy and Stephen Finch. description: Amateur astronomers who cherish Vermont's dark night skies suffered a blow on Tuesday when residents of this economically depressed town voted to allow construction of a prison nearby.

description: WIPEOUT 3 is the closest a video game can get to fashion without actually strutting down a runway.

description: Even before the first insurance claims have been filed on Hurricane Floyd, changes in the way insurance companies have been covering such losses since Hurricane Andrew in 1992 are causing controversy and resentment.

title: Nets and Clippers Talk Trade
description: The Nets, who have been longing to trade one of their backup point guards since acquiring Stephon Marbury in March, may be nearing a deal that would send Eric Murdock to the Los Angeles Clippers for the journeyman small forward Johnny Newman, officials of both organizations said. ''It's something that's being discussed,'' said one official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''I could see it happening any time.''

title: Creator of Tetris Looks for New Ways to Dazzle and Beguile
description: IF ever there was a common touchstone of cyberculture, it is the engaging little computer game known as Tetris. This first truly cross-platform, cross-generational, across-the-sexes digital diversion is, some 15 years after its birth, still drawing players to all manner of computers -- from desktops to electronic organizers -- to play it.

title: Stock Networks Agree to Share Trading Data
description: In an effort to create a single market for after-hours stock trading, eight electronic stock trading systems yesterday signed a letter of intent to share price information and other market data.

title: Medical Guide From Harvard Has an On-Line Supplement
description: When Simon & Schuster releases the Harvard Medical Family Health Guide, a 1,300-page book, next month, it will have its own anti-aging prescription: a Web site to provide updates on the text chapters as they arise.

title: BRITISH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: In another sign of strength in Britain's economy, the Government said unemployment fell to a 19-year low of 4.2 percent in August, from 4.3 percent in July, largely because of hiring among service companies. The Government also said wage growth increased to 4.6 percent between May and July from 4.4 percent in the previous three months. Last week, the Bank of England raised interest rates for the first time in more than a year, and the Government said this week that inflation was at a five-year low.

title: For Stylish Millennium, Official Manhole Cover
description: It might seem excessive to trumpet as millennium art an item whose sole purpose is to be stepped on, driven over or otherwise abused.

description: HOW'S this for the next big American disaster scenario? The dollar, which has been sliding relentlessly against the Japanese yen all summer and hit a 43-month low yesterday, continues to fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBAUM, IRA
description: ROTHBAUM-Ira, 75. Passed away Sunday, September 12, 1999 in Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Westfield, N.J. Mr. Rothbaum worked as an Advertising Executive in New York City at N.W. Ayer and SSC&B-Lintas. After retiring to Florida in 1980 he started a new career in Financial Planning. He is survived by wife Eileen, sister Fran Coffman, children John and Peggy, stepchildren Cindy Goldsmith and Jeff Silver and five grandchildren.

title: 2 More Robot Kits From Lego Mindstorms
description: Lego Mindstorms may have managed to capture the market of pre-teen-age boys (and their fathers) with its line of buildable, programmable Lego robots introduced last fall. This year, the company wants to give 9-year-olds, too, a reason to pester their parents for Legos. And they won't even need a PC.

title: Big Keyboard Can Handle Small Devices
description: GETTING information into a palm-size device has become easier because handwriting-recognition software has improved. But a keyboard is still the preferred method for entering lots of text. Keyboards for palm-size devices are available, but until now, none have been the size of a regular keyboard.

title: Public Beliefs, Global Politics And Pesticides
description: HOW many deaths does it take to justify assaulting the environment with pesticides? Not many, if they're in New York City. As soon as three people died from encephalitis, public officials and environmentalists generally agreed that any risks from malathion were negligible compared to the threat from mosquitoes.

title: Charles Crichton, Film Director, Dies at 89
description: Charles Crichton, one of the brightest lights in the golden age of British film comedy in the late 1940's and 50's, and whose directing career faded and then blazed anew with his last film, ''A Fish Called Wanda,'' died on Tuesday in London. He was 89.

title: Storm Watch
description: To call the calm at the center of a hurricane an ''eye'' is a metaphor, and a peculiarly disembodied one at that. The image is barely anatomical, as the term ''eye wall,'' which has no anatomical equivalent, suggests. The eye wall is the tight, circular boundary of wind and cloud that separates the eye from the swirling body of the storm. Sometimes it shapes itself into a pantheon of clouds through which a lens of clear, blue daylight is visible at the very top. The eye wall is also the most violent region of the hurricane, the place where research aircraft flying into the storm are most severely buffeted and where heaviest damage is inflicted when a hurricane moves inland.

title: Behind 20th-Century Scenes
description: Let the quibbles begin. ''Influential Interiors,'' by Suzanne Trocme, a British design writer (Mitchell Beazley, $45), is a paean to 38 international designers, some of them interior designers like Elsie de Wolfe and Billy Baldwin, others all-rounders like Philippe Starck. The book is an introduction to the minds behind 20th-century design. (It quotes Sister Parish: ''If I can create a 'living' room, that is true success.'') But one suspects an East Coast or European bias. Jenny Armit and Yves Gastou are in the book; absent are West Coast stars like Tony Duquette, who died last week, and the late William Haines.

title: Mexico's Ex-Drug Chief, Indicted, Is Found Dead in U.S.
description: Mario Ruiz Massieu, a volatile lawyer who was the most prominent former Mexican official ever indicted on drug charges in the United States, died yesterday in New Jersey, apparently a suicide, his lawyers and Government officials said.

title: U S West Reduces Internet Access Price
description: U S West Inc., which provides local telephone service in 14 western United States states, said today that it was dropping the price of high-speed Internet access by a third to attract customers who now use slower connections.

title: Corrections
description: A Capitol Sketchbook article yesterday about the debate over campaign finance legislation misspelled the middle name of the author of ''Tell-Tale Heart,'' to which a Democrat compared the resilient measure. He was Edgar Allan Poe, not Allen.

description: What could the Red Sox have been thinking while watching the scoreboard in Cleveland the last couple of days? What about the Oakland Athletics -- what was going through their minds, as they followed the Yankees' progress here?

title: Even a Mouse That Roars Can Sit on the Sidelines
description: BUILD a better mousetrap, and the world will beat a path to your door. It stands to reason that the time-worn adage about innovation and capitalist reward would apply to better mice as well, at least of the computer variety.

title: Blast, Russia's 5th, Kills 4 And Hurts 70 in Southern City
description: A truck exploded next to a nine-story apartment building in the Rostov region in southern Russia early today, leaving at least four people dead and 70 hospitalized.

title: BECAUSE OF SBC TAKEOVER, AMERITECH ENDS BUYBACK PLAN
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the No. 5 local phone company, said yesterday that it was rescinding the remaining portion of a $2 billion stock buyback plan because of the SBC Communications Corporation's $76.9 billion purchase of the company. The Chicago-based Ameritech did not say how much stock it had repurchased under the plan. Ameritech began the plan in January 1998 to increase the value of its stock. SBC, the No. 2 local phone company, is buying Ameritech to form the biggest United States local telephone company. The purchase is under review by Federal officials. Ameritech's shares fell $1.5625 each, to $62.1875.
