description: Classic New York

title: Court Ruling Sets Guides on Use of Informers
description: In a ruling on a case with unusually broad implications for the murky world of criminal informers, a Federal judge today rejected a claim by an informer that he deserved blanket immunity from prosecution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONOMO, TICO
description: BONOMO - Tico. Philanthropist, Turkish Taffy maker, television producer, and Time-Out Family Amusement Center founder and CEO, passed away Sept. 14 at his home in Great Falls, Virginia, surrounded by his loving family. Tico lived a vibrant and exceptional 74 years during which he actively supported the Juvenile Foundation and the Jewish Council for the Aging. He is survived by his mother Zephra Bonomo, loving wife Simone, children: Deborah, Wayne, Tracey, Jordan, Alan, Barry, and Adrea, and grandchildren: Benjamin, Justin, Rebecca, Rachel, Joshua, and Brendan. Tico was a loving father, son, grandfather and friend. All who knew him were touched by his generosity and kindness, and his influence on all our lives was extraordinary. He will be greatly missed, and never forgotten. For information call Pearson Funeral Home 703532-1392. Memorial Services will be held today at Congregation Olam Tikvah in Fairfax, Virginia. Memorial contributions may be made to JDF, JCA, or Hospice of Northern Virginia.

title: Replay Networks to Appoint Ex-CBS Programmer as Chief
description: Officials at Replay Networks Inc., a company offering a new video recording device that some analysts believe will revolutionize the way viewers watch television, said it would name Kim LeMasters, a former chief programmer for CBS, chairman and chief executive today.

title: Oceanfront Luxury
description: An austere but luxurious style is the keynote of this house remodeled by the designer Lenny Steinberg for herself and her husband. Ms. Steinberg transformed two apartments into a 4,000-square-foot, three-story house with an almost monochrome interior. The aim was, she said, ''to alter the space for the ocean environment and create a sense of comfort.'' In the living room, above, which opens to the ocean, visitors can plop onto her Nine-Less-One sofa -- eight cubes covered in gray Mercedes automobile fabric -- which can be configured into almost any form of seating. Ms. Steinberg melds her own stark designs with Asian influences; in her husband's bathroom is her variation on a Japanese tonsu, top, a flexible stack of simple, cherry wood drawers and a cabinet. Lenny Steinberg Associates can be reached at (310) 827-0842. The house is at 2517 Ocean Front Walk, Venice, Calif.

title: Ex-Court Musician Now Courts the Japanese Public
description: At first glance, it is hard to imagine that Hideki Togi was once a court musician in the Japanese Imperial Palace, elaborately costumed and performing gagaku, a genre of ceremonial music that has a thousand-year history.

title: STAPLES PLANS STOCK TO TRACK THREE ON-LINE BUSINESSES
description: Staples Inc., the big office-supply retailer, said yesterday that it had approved plans to create a new class of stock to track the performance of its on-line businesses. The Staples.com ''tracking stock'' will cover all three of the company's electronic commerce units: Staples.com, Quillcorp.com and Stapleslink.com. Staples said it expected to register its plans with the Securities and Exchange Commission within a few weeks but has no immediate plans for an initial public offering of Staples.com stock. Staples, of Framingham, Mass., also said it planned to buy back an additional $100 million of its common stock, bringing the total authorized under its repurchase program to $300 million. The shares of Staples slipped 25 cents each yesterday, to $21.25.

title: Inflation Is Missing Despite Four Years of Boom
description: The boom that has given such a strong lift to the American economy is four years old this quarter, but the much anticipated rise in the inflation rate, which so often mars prosperous times, has failed once again to make an appearance.

title: Leadership Shift At Campbell Mithun
description: Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is making changes in its top creative leadership.

title: DELANCEY PLANS DEAL
description: The British property company controlled by the financier George Soros, Delancey Estates P.L.C., agreed to acquire a rival, Milner Estates P.L.C., for 390 pence a share, a total of $:173.4 million ($278.4 million). Delancey said the deal would expand its $1.09 billion property portfolio.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column on Tuesday about a sale by Fortis, a Belgian and Dutch financial services organization, to the Lincoln National Corporation of Fort Wayne, Ind., referred incorrectly to the business being sold. It is the employer medical stop-loss insurance business of the John Alden Financial Corporation, not all of John Alden.

title: What's Eating America? Weeds
description: NOBODY can remember the exact moment the giant cane, Arundo donax, went from being a nuisance to a state of emergency, but the day it lifted up a bridge in Norco, Calif., might do for starters. Sudden rains in 1993 had sent flood waters roaring down the Santa Ana river.

title: Wyeth-Ayerst Drug Advances
description: The American Home Products Corporation's Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories unit said today that its Sonata prescription sleep medication had received United States Drug Enforcement Administration scheduling, clearing the product for marketing.

title: East Timor Refugees Recall a Wave of Brutality
description: A day after they were evacuated from their smoldering homeland, the refugees from East Timor told harrowing stories here today of the terror that followed the province's vote to be independent of Indonesia.

title: A Step Toward a Versatile High-Definition VCR
description: THE first high-definition VCR is now on the market. But don't assume that the technology behind it will become dominant, the way VHS videotape rules the world today. In fact, the future looks quite messy.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Learn A Republican Trick
description: When Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah finally jumped into the Republican Presidential contest last summer, the leader, Mr. Bush, was somewhere up in the 50's in the polls and somewhere around the $36 million mark in raising campaign cash. The Senator predicted his message of solid conservatism would eventually enable him to overtake Mr. Bush in the polls. As for catching up with the Governor in the money-raising business, well, he had this hot idea.

title: Antacid Maker Picks Bates USA
description: TAP Pharmaceuticals in Deerfield, Ill., a joint venture of Tadeka Chemical Industries of Japan and Abbott Laboratories in Abbott Park, Ill., has named Bates USA in New York as the first agency to handle general market advertising for Prevacid, a prescription medication for ulcers and heartburn.

title: The Zsa-Zsa Decor War
description: TASTEFULNESS is not something David Bouley is used to worrying about. On the plate, it hasn't been a problem for Mr. Bouley, the chef and owner of the four-star Bouley Bakery. But he is standing in the entry of his new 3,800-square-foot restaurant, Danube, worried about the speckled Brazilian granite that he thinks looks like Gustav Klimt paintings, 3,000 copper leaves that canopy the ceiling like the Secessionists' dome in Vienna and every other detail of the $1.8 million establishment, opening on Monday at Hudson and Duane Streets.

title: The Kremlin's Keeper, the World at His Fingertips, Is Under a Cloud
description: By most accounts, Pavel Pavlovich Borodin is a nice guy. The Kremlin's property manager plays Ed McMahon to President Boris N. Yeltsin. He is self-effacing. He is loyal. Legend says he is the one person who can tell Yeltsin jokes to Mr. Yeltsin and come away with belly laughs instead of his head on a stick. He has five children, four of them adopted; three dogs, two chins and an agreeably crooked grin.

title: Talk and Point: Interactive Map Is Learning to Show the Way
description: IMAGINE a lone tourist standing on a subway platform underneath Times Square, asking a map not only to show the fastest route to the Bronx Zoo but also to highlight the closest deli that sells pastrami sandwiches and the cleanest nearby public bathroom.

title: Bank and Developer Seek to Buy Site for 42d Street Tower
description: A Canadian bank and a developer are in negotiations to buy a highly coveted development site for a new 35-story skyscraper at one of the most desirable corporate addresses in the city, Madison Avenue and 42d Street.

title: The Father Speaks As a Son Punches
description: Felix Trinidad Jr. has been here for almost two weeks, training for his welterweight showdown against Oscar De La Hoya on Saturday night. He has not been seduced by neon lights or tempted by casinos. Don Felix Trinidad, his father and trainer, has made sure there are no distractions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLSTEDT, RUTH H. MCCARTHY
description: MAHLSTEDT-Ruth H. McCarthy. Of Somers, formerly a 20 year Chappaqua resident passed away September 13, 1999. She was the widow of John Henry Mahlstedt, the devoted mother of John, Daniel and Peter. Loving mother-inlaw of Carol and Susan and the spirited, cherished grandmother of Lindsay, Lauren, Kristen, Sarah, Katie and John. Mrs. Mahlstedt was the former church secretary, and Elder of the Pleasantville Presbyterian Church. Her family will receive friends Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY. Service Friday 10 AM Pleasantville Presbyterian Church. Interment Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Pleasantville Presbyterian Church or the American Heart Association in her name would be appreciated.

description: Dianne H. Pilgrim, the director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, has resigned, the museum said yesterday. Her resignation is effective Jan. 3, when she will become director emeritus and senior adviser for special projects at the Cooper-Hewitt, a branch of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, NATHAN
description: STAHL-Nathan. On September 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Hannah. Loving father of Harvey, Robert and father-in-law of Jackie. Dear brother of Alex. Adoring grandfather of Lori, Kevin and Allison. Service Friday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside Park West'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: BASEBALL

title: The Renegade As Rejuvenator
description: Fourteen months before the 2000 election, the Presidential race is running in full gear and sinking from utter torpor. The two front-runners are conducting campaigns so cautious and so vacuous that they are virtually indistinguishable from one another. Nor have their principal challengers defined themselves clearly.

title: Corrections

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is a lead manager with Credit Suisse First Boston and Merrill Lynch. Bear, Stearns is a co-manager, not a lead manager.

Gates 3d, the co-founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, is pledging at least $1 billion to pay for full scholarships over the next 20 years for minority students in the fields of education, math, science and engineering.

title: Wider Americans Demand Wider Seats

At the top of the list, however, were not the antiquated restrooms and snack bars, the lack of revenue-producing sky boxes or even the rats that occasionally menaced television cameramen. The most criticized feature of the old stadium was the narrow seats.

title: For Most Floridians, Relief That a Monster Storm Pulled Its Punch
description: The roundhouse punch that Hurricane Floyd was supposed to deliver to Florida was more like a love tap, and while most people in this vastly relieved state thanked God and luck, a few, like Chad Fish, were almost disappointed.

title: Russian Blast Kills 4

title: RENT-WAY AGREES TO ACQUIRE RENTAVISION FOR $92 MILLION
description: Rent-Way Inc., the nation's second-largest rent-to-own company, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Rentavision Inc. for $92 million in cash and assumed debt and $6 million in stock. It did not specify how much of the deal was debt. Rent-Way, based in Erie, Pa., which rents home-entertainment equipment, furniture and appliances, said Rentavision operates 250 stores in 16 states. The acquisition gives Rent-Way 51 stores in New England. It also adds 62 stores in New York and 48 in Pennsylvania. Rent-Way already has 19 stores in New York and 25 in Pennsylvania. Rentavision, based in Oswego, N.Y., has annual revenue of about $90 million. The shares of Rent-Way, which operates 866 stores in 35 states, rose 43.75 cents, to $23.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUERBECK, HEIDI B.
description: DUERBECK-Heidi B. The members, counsel, associates and staff of Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green, P.C. note with profound sadness the death of our long-time member and friend, Heidi B. Duerbeck, who passed away on September 15, 1999. Heidi was born on July 19, 1947 in Duisberg, Germamy. She attended the University of Goettingen in Germany in 1967-68 and graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1968 with a Bachelor of Arts degree, Cum Laude, and in 1969 with a Master of Arts degree before earning her Juris Doctor degree in 1972 from Stanford University. At Stanford Law School she was the Articles Editor of the Stanford Journal of International Studies and the 1972 recipient of the Carl Mason Franklin Prize in International Law. In the late 1980s Heidi served on the Board of Visitors of Stanford Law School and was President of the Stanford Law Alumni Association. After practicing law with the firm of Sullivan & Cromwell for several years, Heidi joined our firm in 1977 and became a member in 1979, the first woman partner of the firm. Heidi will be remembered as a skilled and sophisticated corporate lawyer specializing in German American legal transactions. She represented a large number of prominent German industrial companies in their acquisitions, joint ventures, licensing and product distribution matters. Heidi's clients included many well-known names in the computer software, chemical, fashion and hotel industries. In addition to her law practice, Heidi was President of the German American LAw Association since 1982 and the first head of the Internation Section of Commercial Law Affiliates, one of the largest worldwide affiliations of independent law firms in the United States and around the world. Heidi also was a legal adviser to the New York State Department of Economic Development and to the New York City Chamber of Commerce with respect to the promotion of economic develpment through foreign investment in the State and City of New York and a lecturer on the legal aspects of foreign investment for the National Association of State Development Agencies. Heidi graced our firm with her intelligence, warmth, compassion and judgment. Her enthusiasm, unbounded optimism, strenth and loyalty will be greatly missed by us all. We send our heartfelt sympathies to her husband Jenik B. Radon, her daughter Kaara D. Radon and her brother, Dr. Norman Duerbeck. On behalf of the family, we request that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Heidi B. Duerbeck Breast Cancer Research Fund at New York Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032-3784.

title: Grasping the Obvious Pathology
description: The grim outline of the story is all too familiar: a gunman, a shooting, the dead, a search for motive and the realization that once again motive explains little. When the gunfire ended at Wedgwood Baptist Church in Fort Worth, Tex., Wednesday night, a familiar chasm opened -- the gap that divides the fact of such a shooting, and all the shootings it brings to mind, from the ability to account for it. By now, the shootings that have taken place over the last few months, in Atlanta, in Los Angeles, in Littleton, Colo., and elsewhere, begin to look less and less like distinct events and more and more like the recurrence of a single event, which leaves behind the taste of ashes and a mental numbness. Every shooting is troubling, but the ones that bother us most are the dispassionate, seemingly causeless ones. They mock our desire for explanation.

description: CRUDE OIL UP AGAIN. Crude oil rose almost 2 percent on expectations that producers will stick to their plan to limit output until the end of March. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 38 cents a barrel, to $24.51.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTORUTO, TONY
description: PETTORUTO-Tony. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 18, at 2 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St.

title: Scientists Point to New Evidence of Liquid Water on a Jupiter Moon
description: An analysis of striking scalloped fracture lines in the frozen surface of Jupiter's moon Europa has yielded the strongest evidence yet that a global ocean of liquid water once lay beneath the thick crust of ice, and may still be there.

title: Padres Name Simmons to Scouting
description: The San Diego Padres today named Ted Simmons their vice president of scouting and player development.

title: China's Internet Providers Remain Bowed, Not Broken
description: In private they are puzzled and angry but in public, China's fledgling Internet companies have pasted on brave faces the last two days, ever since an important Government minister said that foreign shares in companies providing Internet content or services were illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, JOHN MCDONALD
description: MOORE-John McDonald. January 11,1919-Septenber 14, 1999. Cherished husband of Elaine Roberta Werblud Moore. Loving father of Johan North, dear brother of Lyn Moore, adored and adoring parent to Marc Werblud, Monica Werblud Valenti, Debra Werblud Camerota and to their spouses: Tabitha Werblud, Angelo Valenti and Filippo Camerota. He was the most devoted, loving and beloved Baba John to Zachary Jonathan Valenti and Alexandra Meredith Werblud. Goethe defined genius as ''a productive power'' whose actions ''have consequenquences and lasting life''. John McDonald Moore as teacher and friend to thousands of students at The New School for Social Research University from 1968 to the present has affirmed this truth. His was a life of honor and dedication and supreme integrity. He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. His inspiration will remain. Service at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue Sunday September 19, 1999 at 12:30PM.

title: 3 Players Hurt
description: Three more Devils sustained slight injuries Wednesday. Forwards Denis Pederson and Vadim Sharifijanov left practice with what the Devils called slight groin problems, and defenseman Brad Bombardir had a bruised right shoulder.

title: Railroads, Buses and Highways Snarled but Subways Are Unaffected
description: Aided by days of advance notice and preparation, New York City's subway system weathered Tropical Storm Floyd yesterday with only scattered disruptions, but some of the regional systems faltered as the storm unleashed its greatest fury by nightfall.

title: Hurricanes, Politics and Those Ocean Views
description: The coastal disasters along the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico are like uninvited and terrifying houseguests. Hazel in 1954. Camille in 1969. Hugo in 1989. Andrew in 1992. Fran and Bertha in 1996. And now Floyd.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about potential layoffs at the AT&T Corporation referred imprecisely to an AT&T statement in August about its long-distance telephone operation. AT&T said that 1999 revenue for the long-distance unit would fall short of previous projections, not that the unit's costs were above expectations.

title: Nike Posts Gain Of 22% In Profit
description: Nike Inc. reported a larger-than-expected 22 percent rise in first-quarter earnings today, thanks to back-to-school sales and strong demand for its basketball shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWERSOCK, JEFFREY M.
description: BOWERSOCK-Jeffrey M., Sept. 1, 1999 at the age of 33 years. Beloved husband of the late Christine R. Welch-Bowersock. Dear son of Wallace J. and Kathleen M. Bowersock. Son-in-law of Kate Welch and Gene Welch. Grandson of Stanley and Charlotte Adamick and Elspeth Bowersock. Brother of Ruth Bowersock, Rachel (William) Morley, Roberta (David) Kleyweg and Wallace (Melissa) Bowersock III. Also surviving are nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, other relatives and friends. Funeral services will be Monday at 10:30 A.M. at The Victory Memorial Chapel at St. John's Military Academy in Delafield, WI. Friends may call on Sunday at the funeral home from 4 to 8 P.M. and on Monday at The Victory Memorial Chapel from 9:30 A.M. until time of service. Memorials would be appreciated to the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Greater Milwaukee.

title: Rubin Is Planning to Return to Wall Street
description: Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that he planned to return to Wall Street, though he has not decided where he will work.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN-Gladys. 22 years have gone by, and you will always be in our hearts and with the fondest of memories. Love, Irving, Leslie, and Keri

title: BRITISH ECONOMIC OPTIMISM
description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, forecast that British economic growth would reach 2.75 percent next year and 3.25 percent in 2001 in what he called a ''virtuous cycle of low inflation, high investment and high and stable levels of growth.'' Addressing the Council for Foreign Relations in New York, Mr. Brown said he had supported the quarter-point interest rate increase by the Bank of England last week. Alan Cowell

title: James R. West, 84, Diplomat Married to Mary McCarthy
description: James R. West, a career diplomat and the husband of the writer Mary McCarthy for nearly 30 years, died on Monday at Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor. He was 84 and lived in Castine, Me.

title: Caracas Journal; It's Sunday, and Venezuelans Have the Leader's Ear
description: On line 2, Yamile was calling from Puerto Ordaz to ask how she could help her father collect the pension due him. On line 1, Zuly from Guarenas was waiting for her turn on the air, hoping to get in a word about AIDS prevention campaigns.

description: Percy Ellsworth is the most prolific interceptor the Giants have had the last four years -- 14 in 15 career starts -- yet he continues to hear that he would be even better if he were a more ferocious hitter.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the actress Ally Sheedy's taking on the title role in the Off Broadway play ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch'' misstated the surname of her husband. He is the actor David Lansbury, not Lindsay.

title: 'Gulliver' Travels To DVD Format
description: This week DVD got its second megatitle, ''The Matrix,'' to go with its first, ''Titanic,'' released in August. Distributors say about one million copies of each are headed for the marketplace. At the moment, with two million DVD players in use, that divides into one ''Titanic'' and one ''Matrix'' for every two machines, a sales rate no DVD booster could logically complain about.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about Nassau County's proposed budget described a tax increase incorrectly. It is the overall budget that is increasing by 6 percent, not the taxes in it.

title: Lessons in the School Test Data
description: There is an encouraging bright spot buried under all the confusion and recriminations generated by New York City's comic-opera attempts to end social promotions in the public schools. It turns out, we are now told, that reading-test scores for the city's schoolchildren went up sharply this spring instead of remaining flat as originally reported. It would be dangerous to attach too much significance to such comparisons in a year when the standardized tests have been radically changed. But if these revised numbers mean anything, they offer heartening proof that something is beginning to go right at the classroom level in the beleaguered New York City school system.

title: Turning Old School Into Apartments
description: Work is nearing completion on a $10.5 million conversion of the turn-of-the-century St. Agnes elementary school in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn into a 90-unit middle-income rental apartment building.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: INDOSAT PRESIDENT RESIGNS
description: The head of the state-controlled Indonesia Satellite Corporation tendered his resignation in a move that may herald a more thorough investigation of wrongdoing at the company. Its finance director, Tjahjono Soerjodibroto, was removed from office last week over irregularities in a dividend payment to the Government.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ADAMS, ANTHONY LANE
description: ADAMS-Anthony Lane, 54. Died July 21, in Greenwich, CT. Son of the late Lane Webster and Elaine Evans Adams; Husband of Louise Rambo Adams; Father of Anthony Lane Adams and Isabelle Adams; Brother of Victoria Adams Quan. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM Tues., Sept. 21, in Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave. Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Quan Fund in Neurobiology c/o Mary Beth Pearlberg, Harvard Medical School, Bldg A, RM 306, 25 Shattuck St. Boston, MA 02115.

title: Stockman Forming Own Buyout Concern
description: David Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan Administration, is resigning as senior managing director and partner of the Blackstone Group to form a buyout concern focused on industries based in the Midwest.

title: CRITICISM OF SAMSUNG LIFE
description: A life insurance company owned by the Samsung Group faced a barrage of criticism for providing interest-free loans to its employees to help them buy company shares. For the purchase of 1.28 million new shares, the Samsung Life Insurance Company said it had provided 6.4 billion won, or $5.3 million, in loans last week to employees. With each employee entitled to an average of 180 shares, the payments would total 900,000 won, or $752, each worker. The interest-free loans sparked criticism that the family-owned conglomerate was trying to increase the management control of its owner, the chairman, Lee Kun Hee. Samuel Len

title: Metro Business; Bausch & Lomb Suit Is Revived by Court
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. has failed to end a lawsuit by two contact-lens wearers who accused the company of deceptively marketing its lens solutions.

title: VISUAL NETWORKS IN STOCK DEAL FOR INVERSE NETWORK
description: Visual Networks Inc., which develops software that helps telecommunications networks run more efficiently, agreed late on Wednesday to buy the closely held Inverse Network Technology Inc. for about $177 million in stock. Inverse Network, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes software for Internet service providers and their customers. Visual Networks, based in Rockville, Md., sells software that cuts costs and improves the reliability of wide-area communications systems, which send data over computer networks. Shares of Visual Networks fell 68.75 cents, to $38.75.

title: Bill Quackenbush, 77, Hockey Star Who Rarely Heard a Whistle
description: Bill Quackenbush, who proved that defensemen could play hockey without being excessively rough or committing penalties, died last Sunday in the Chandler Hall Hospice in Newtown, Pa. He was 77.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Rangers Searching for a Man in the Middle
description: A pessimist might say that this summer's drought left the reservoirs half empty. An optimist might argue that this week's hurricane left them half full. Just as perspective determines perception in weather and in life, so too does it apply to sports and to a hockey team in transition, a troubled team like the Rangers.

title: Study Details Smoking Fad Among Youth
description: Warning of a worrisome new trend in smoking among young people, Massachusetts health officials released the country's first official study today on the prevalence among teen-agers of smoking skinny, sweet-flavored and highly potent cigarettes called bidis that are hand-rolled in India and faddishly popular.

title: Timor Peacekeeping Force Gathers in Australia
description: Foreign troops, ships and planes converged here as an international peacekeeping mission prepared to depart within days for strife-torn East Timor.

title: Former Inmate Is Charged in False Threat to Bomb Grand Central
description: A former prisoner at Rikers Island was charged yesterday with making a false threat to bomb Grand Central Terminal while he was in the jail last spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, EDYTHE
description: STEINBERG-Edythe. On September 16, 1999. Beloved mother of Richard and Rona, mother-in-law of Renee and Howard, grandmother of Sarah, Jonathan, Stephanie, and Michael, and companion of Murray Savel. She lived life as a continually engaged and loving spirit, full of opinions, passions, and advice. Her intellect was keen and her heart warm all the days of her life; she will remain eternally young in our hearts and prayers. Service to be held Sunday, 10AM at Temple Emanuel in Westfield, New Jersey. A period of mourning will be held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Steinberg at 7PM on Wednesday.

title: Chekhov's Pairs in Motion
description: Dr. Chekhov or Dr. Laura? In ''Vers la Flamme,'' the choreographer Martha Clarke has focused her familiar brand of imagistic dance theater on sexual encounters and marital unhappiness.

title: Playoff Picture for Mets Starting to Get in Focus
description: The Mets are in that zone now where everything falls into place, where even ridiculous base running mistakes become nothing more than fodder for ribbing. Where the offense can virtually take the week off as if the players thought Los Angeles was for sunning and Colorado for skiing and the maligned starting pitching will kick in just in time.

title: Schroder Lays Fiscal Blame At the Feet Of His Foes
description: Bitterly blaming his Christian Democratic opponents for driving the country into debt, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said today that Germany could no longer ''devour the resources that should nourish our children.''

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 2
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Blithe Spirit As Life Force
description: NEVER had a nervous breakdown looked so glamorous. It was one thing to fall to pieces onstage; characters in plays had been doing that since ''Oedipus Rex.'' But it was something else to come unglued in exquisite evening clothes while stormily playing the piano, with a chic little gold box filled with something illegal in your pocket. Nicky Lancaster might be a petulant, mother-fixated egotist, prone to hysterics and addicted to drugs, but it was impossible not to be mad about the boy.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Factory Production Rose More in August
description: Production at factories, mines and utilities exceeded expectations in August, paced by surging demand for automobiles and trucks, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Belgrade a City in Need of Milk, and a Little Peace
description: At 6:30 A.M., the lines have already formed outside two food stores in New Belgrade, a district that houses hundreds of thousands of the Serbian capital's 1.5 million people. Residents are lining up for milk, which in recent weeks has been scarce.

title: Bush Blames 'Wave of Evil' For Shootings Across Nation
description: Gov. George W. Bush cut short a busy Presidential campaign swing through Michigan and beat a hasty, somber path back to Texas today, expressing outrage at what he called ''a wave of evil passing through America'' but asserting that gun control was not the solution.

title: The Best Investment the Pentagon Could Make
description: The Pentagon is having trouble recruiting qualified soldiers and thinks the solution is to declare war: a bidding war, against private industry. But if we're concerned about staffing in the military, we should concentrate instead on the nation's crowded classrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DAVID
description: COOPER-David. The Board of Governors and Members of Inwood Country Club record withdeep sorrow the passing of David Cooper, beloved husband of Adrienne and we extend deepest sympathy to the family. Robert Scharf, President David Gruber, Secretary

description: THERE are few things more enjoyable than spending more than you earn. Especially if you are convinced you can keep doing so indefinitely.

description: Riding with the waves, Fortune magazine in New York has come up with a terrific, with-it, win-win idea.

description: The man who sold millions of dollars worth of documents with the forged signature of John F. Kennedy will likely receive a stiffer-than-normal prison term because he designed a fraud that was intended to damage the reputations of the late President and other historical figures, a judge said yesterday.

title: Culture With Adobe
description: ''The City Different,'' they like to call it, and that it is, a heady blend of Hispanic, Native American and Anglo cultures, with a brisk topping up, these last few decades, of new money, big money, from Texas, California and New York.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Fressen plays it so cool that the only hint of its presence, deep in the heart of the meatpacking district, is a small printed strip beneath a tiny doorbell telling suppliers that they have come to the right place. The restaurant presents a frosty, hard-edge face to the world outside, with thick, translucent windows and an artfully bronzed steel facade. Undeniably handsome, Fressen walks the line between a minimum-security prison and a utopian factory designed by a Japanese disciple of Corbusier.

description: Staying Dry In 'Spin City'

title: World Cup Success Lifts College Game
description: If the University of North Carolina is any barometer, as it has always been, women's soccer at the college level is starting to feel the benefits of the triumph by the United States national team in the Women's World Cup this past summer. While the women's game has become more competitive in recent years with Notre Dame and Florida winning national titles and ending the dynasty at North Carolina, attendance at women's games so far this season has shown a huge increase.

title: Malaysia Jails a Journalist
description: Murray Hiebert, a Canadian journalist for The Far Eastern Economic Review, an English-language weekly magazine, has begun serving a six-week jail term in Malaysia for the crime of ''scandalizing the court.'' In the Hiebert ruling and others, judges have handed out prison terms to various people who have alleged that Malaysian justice is less than pristine -- thus unwittingly confirming the critics' charges. These rulings are not only an affront to free speech but an indication of a growing contempt in Malaysia for the rule of law.

title: DAEWOO'S CREDITORS SEEK SECURITY
description: South Korea's embattled Daewoo Group conglomerate said a committee representing its foreign creditors, though far from satisfied, did not reject its offer of 4 trillion won, or $3.34 billion, worth of collateral in exchange for a freeze on its foreign loan payments. ''The Committee of Foreign Creditor Banks did not reject the Daewoo Group's proposal, but the committee still seeks a preference over domestic creditors,'' the group said in a statement issued after a meeting with foreign bank officials. Daewoo said a ''preference'' could include loan guarantees or more collateral. Samuel Len

title: Tyson Says He Has Lost 45 of 60 Extra Pounds
description: Having trimmed 45 of the 60 pounds that he gained during a three-and-a-half month stay in a Maryland jail, Mike Tyson said today that he was close to being ready for his Oct. 23 heavyweight bout against Orlin Norris at the MGM Grand Casino here.

title: 2 Groups Fight Nuclear Incinerator Project Near Yellowstone
description: It started with a short letter to a local newspaper here four months ago, in which a woman from Ketchum, Idaho, warned Jackson residents that the Federal Government intended to build a nuclear incinerator 90 miles upwind from Jackson and Yellowstone National Park.

title: Clinton Is Sending 200 Troops for East Timor
description: For the second time in three months, President Clinton announced today that the United States would contribute soldiers to a peacekeeping force in a troubled spot thousands of miles away, dispatching 200 troops to East Timor.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The companies early on realized that with car sales at record levels and profits at record levels, they couldn't plead poverty. It is a generous contract.''

title: A Lifetime Assignment: Compare and Contrast
description: The strange career of Bill Brandt (1904-83), the German-born British photographer, invariably raises questions about a rift. Why did the photojournalist who documented the stark contrast between England's rich and poor before World War II suddenly abandon his social mission and start creating surreal, high-contrast nudes and landscapes? What links the man who photographed miners with coal-blackened faces and white teeth to the man who photographed women's blurry white limbs against black rocky cliffs? The quick answer is: contrast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, SHIRLEY MENDOZA
description: NATHANSON-Shirley Mendoza, on Sept. 15, 1999. Deeply loved wife of the late Jules Nathanson. Dear mother of Irwin ''Sandy'' (Karen) Nathanson and Howard (Sarah Anne Patz) Nathanson. Dear grandmother to Eric, Scott, Andrew, Rebecca, Brooke & Ariel Nathanson. Dear sister-in-law, aunt, cousin and friend. Life member of Temple Israel of Jamaica. Administrator 22 years, Long Island Jewish-Hillside Hospital. Volunteer Ronald McDonald House of L.I. and many other organizations. Resident of the Bronx, Jamaica, Forest Hills, East Quogue and St. Louis. A warm, lively woman and the heart of her family. Donations to the Ronald McDonald House of LI, 267-07 76th Ave., New Hyde Park, NY 11042. Funeral service Sunday, September 19, 10:30 AM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Interment Hungarian Union Fields Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: But Command Still Defends the Air War : NATO Lowers Its Tally Of Tanks Hit in Kosovo
description: PARIS  NATO destroyed significantly fewer Serbian tanks in Kosovo than the alliance had claimed at the end of the air war, General Wesley Clark said Thursday, acknowledging that only 26 actual wreckages had been found by allied troops who have been combing the province since June.

title: Jets and Bills Are Vying To Gain Victory No. 1
description: More or less laughing about how the Jets had manhandled him last season, Doug Flutie said: ''How are they going to line up now? Five linebackers? Ten defensive backs?''

title: Old Friend, Forever Mysterious
description: A FEW years ago there was a traveling exhibition, ''Egyptomania,'' which showed how Greeks and Romans, then Italians, French, Russians and Americans borrowed, copied and stole from ancient Egypt, or what they believed was ancient Egypt because after a while the copies and adaptations got mixed up with originals and became part of the evolving culture.

title: Fiery Violinist Living an Operatic Life
description: Not long after the phenomenal Italian-born violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg moved to the United States at the age of 8, she attended a class whose students were asked to play show and tell by talking about their favorite thing in the world. But when this brilliant young musician presented a recording of the Brahms violin concerto to the class, she was met with derisive laughter. She was so upset, she recalls in Paola di Florio's sympathetic documentary portrait, ''Speaking in Strings,'' that she angrily cursed her classmates and ran from the room in tears.

title: In Jakarta, News of Timor Is Barely a Blip
description: East Timor was on the news, but the passengers in an airport lounge the other day paid little attention. Then came a report on a major corruption scandal and the room fell silent; this was the news they cared about.

title: Big Internet Sites Joining Auction Network
description: Nearly 100 Internet sites, including three of the biggest -- Microsoft's MSN, Excite@Home and Lycos -- have agreed to share their auction listings so that an item put up for sale on one site will be available for bidding on all other sites.

title: SALES FORCE TO BE REALIGNED AGAIN THIS YEAR
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would realign its sales force for the second time in a year. The company plans to divide the force into six groups from the four created in a revamping in January, when Xerox decided to assign accounts based on the customer's industry instead of location. Xerox issued an internal memo last week announcing the change. No job cuts are planned for the 4,300 sales employees. The earlier reorganization constrained the company's sales effort and was cited for the disappointing second-quarter's sales growth of just 2.5 percent; analysts had expected 4 percent to 6 percent. The shares fell 9 percent yesterday, or $4.3125, to $42.75.

description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER BOMBING KILLS 18 IN RUSSIA
description: The threat of terrorism spread to Russia's heartland today, as a huge explosion tore apart an apartment complex in Volgodonsk, in southern Russia, killing at least 18 people and leaving more than 200 wounded.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Clinton Given Bill for Raise For Congress And President
description: Congress today passed and sent to President Clinton a spending bill that will increase its members' salaries, as well as those of Federal workers and the next President.

title: All at Once, Outpourings Of Asian Art
description: ''It's almost too much,'' said Jim Lally, a Manhattan dealer who specializes in Chinese works of art, discussing the many events scheduled for Asia Week, the name given by New York auction houses and dealers to this week's sales of Asian art, which end tomorrow.

title: More Wet Than Wild, Floyd Drops Up to 19 Inches of Rain
description: The heart of Hurricane Floyd raked across the mainland here at Cape Fear this morning, uprooting beach houses and leaving widespread floods as it set a rapid but steadily weakening course up the Atlantic coast.

title: Cleveland's Errors Help Yanks Get On a Roll
description: The Yankees' self-examination began last week, internal questions about whether they possess a consistent intensity, or whether their hitters are guilty of redefining themselves as Mark McGwire clones and trying too hard to hit home runs. Now that they have started winning again and their insecurities have been soothed, the Yankees can look around and realize that other teams in the American League aren't exactly perfect, either.

title: FREEDOM SECURITIES PLANS TO ACQUIRE A JERSEY CITY FIRM
description: The Freedom Securities Corporation, a retail brokerage and investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Hill, Thompson, Magid & Company, a privately held brokerage firm, for $45 million in cash and stock. Hill, Thompson, Magid will operate as an independent subsidiary after the acquisition. Freedom, based in Boston, is assembling a string of independent regional businesses that share administrative and operating costs. Hill, Thompson, Magid, of Jersey City, will be Freedom's fifth acquisition in the last year and a half.

title: Rebuffing an Early Selloff, Dow Still Falls 63.96 Points Traders Leave Early to Beat Hurricane
description: Stock prices pulled out of an early sinking spell yesterday to close with modest losses for two of the major gauges, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eked out a slender gain.

title: Storm Puts Off Several Events
description: Hurricane Floyd stomped all over the local sporting scene yesterday, leading to cancellation of a Rangers exhibition game at Madison Square Garden and the daily racing program at Belmont Park and leaving at least some question about tonight's Mets-Phillies game at Shea Stadium.

title: Sony, for First Time, to Sell Set-Top Boxes to Cablevision
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan yesterday made its first big move into the United States cable television market, with the announcement that the Cablevision Systems Corporation would buy more than $1 billion worth of Sony equipment to deliver advanced digital television services in the New York City area.

title: Beyond the Call of Duty, an Odd Couple of Civil Servants
description: An unlikely pair of sleuths, aided and abetted by the atmospheric Russian community of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, transform the familiar materials of ''Taxman'' into an offbeat little charmer of a mystery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, JACK
description: HECHT-Jack. On September 14, 1999, age 89. Beloved husband of Laura (nee Florman), devoted father of Arlene and Leonard. Dear grandfather of two, and great grandfather of four. Funeral services on Friday 2 P.M., ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer'' Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Little Sympathy in Yemen for Condemned Militant
description: Failing last-minute intervention by Yemen's President, the people of this ancient city may be summoned to a city-center square sometime in the next few weeks to watch a firing squad execute the leader of an extremist Islamic group that abducted 16 Western tourists on a desert road near Aden in December.

title: Faces of the Centuries, Famous and Far From It
description: Anthony van Dyck (1599-1641), meet Dawoud Bey (born 1955). This improbable conjunction and others equally unlikely occur in ''Here's Looking at You: Portraits From the Collection'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, a wild mix of artists and eras ranging from the 17th century to now.

description: O.K., movie fans. We're down to the final frames of ''For Love of the Game,'' and the big questions are still unanswered.

description: The AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that they would expand their global communications alliance by linking their wireless telephone operations around the world.

title: Stanton's Bad Back Is Cause for Concern
description: Mike Stanton is not in the habit of making excuses or letting small injuries prevent him from pitching. So when Stanton, the Yankees' durable left-hander, beckoned Joe Torre to the mound in the ninth inning to tell his manager of his sore back, it was a concern for the Yankees.

title: Guilty Plea in '87 Killing; Case Altered Competency Laws

description: AT&T and British Telecom To Link Wireless Operations

title: RAYMOND JAMES TO WEIGH OPTIONS FOR CHS ELECTRONICS
description: CHS Electronics Inc. of Miami, a microcomputer distributor, said yesterday that it had hired the investment banker Raymond James & Associates to help it explore options. The investment firm, a unit of Raymond James Financial Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., is reviewing CHS's operations and will recommend ways to increase the stock price. The options range from the sale of all or part of CHS to a merger or privatization, the company said. Shares of CHS, which once had a $1 billion market capitalization, have fallen more than 86 percent this year. They rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2.3125, giving CHS a value of $140 million. The company had 1998 sales of $8.55 billion.

title: FDX Says Earnings Hurt by Fuel Costs
description: The FDX Corporation, the parent of Federal Express, the package delivery service, said today that rising fuel prices hurt its first-quarter earnings and might keep it from meeting this year's profit forecasts.

title: Health Officials Confirm 12th Case of Encephalitis
description: A 12th case of St. Louis encephalitis was confirmed yesterday, although the person was among those infected before the city began spraying to kill the mosquitoes that carry the disease, city officials said.

title: An Angry Mystery Man Who Brought Death
description: The man who walked into the Wedgwood Baptist Church here on Wednesday did not look like he belonged to the congregation. No one knew what this man in blue jeans and a black leather jacket, Larry Gene Ashbrook, might want. People would later learn that he was a jobless loner, an ex-sailor prone to foul moods and feared by several of his neighbors.

title: In a Reversal, White House Will End Data-Encryption Export Curbs
description: Bucking pressure from the Justice Department, the F.B.I. and intelligence agencies, the White House yesterday essentially eliminated its complex controls on the export of data-scrambling hardware and software, handing a surprise victory to Congressional, high-technology and privacy groups that have spent years fighting for the change.

title: Reds Carry A Quiet Swagger
description: On the road, the most popular player on the team spends Sunday mornings in search of a Roman Catholic church. The dazzling second baseman is a better shortstop and is named Pokey. The bullpen is unknown and unbelievable. The manager is 68 years old and the general manager is 38. The team plays games in a park that is almost always half empty in a city that is ignoring a frenetic pennant chase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWERSOCK, CHRISTINE ROSE (NEE WELCH)
description: BOWERSOCK - Christine Rose (nee Welch), Sept. 1, 1999 at the age of 33 years. Beloved wife of the late Jeffrey M. Bowersock. Dear daughter of Kate Welch (fiance Stan Kuil) and Gene Welch. Dear sister of Steve, Owen, Dean, Gena, Mike, Erin, Eamon, and Tom Welch. Granddaughter of Marie Welch and J. Vincent Dunn. Daughter-in-law of Wallace and Kathleen Bowersock. Also survived by aunts, uncles, cousins, other relatives and friends. Preceded in death by her grandfather Edmund Welch and grandmother Mary Dunn. Funeral Services will be Monday at 10:30 A.M. at The Victory Memorial Chapel at St. John's Military Academy in Delafield, Wisconsin. Friends may call on Sunday from 4 to 8 P.M. at the funeral home and on Monday at The Victory Memorial Chapel, from 9:30 A.M. until the time of service. Interment at Arlington Memorial Park in Milwaukee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, DANIEL T.
description: McMAHON-Daniel T. on September 15, 1999 of Fort Lauderdale, FL. Formerly of Riverdale. Husband of Veronica. Father of Daniel Jr. and Marita McMahon. Brother of the late Winifred Jordan, the Rev. John J. McMahon, S.J. and Rev. Msgr. Thomas V. McMahon. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, September 18 at 10AM.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, SAUL I.
description: GREENFIELD-Saul I. Died on September 16th, 1999. Beloved husband of Vivian. Devoted father of Ronald and Shelly and father-inlaw of Allan Brandt. Cherished grandfather of Danny and Jacob Brandt. Loving brother of Miriam, Lillian, Evelyn, Myron, Vivian, Judy, Larry and Ruth. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, FREDERICK P.
description: ROSE-Frederick P., master builder and creative philanthropist, son of Samuel B. and Belle B. Rose, died at home on Wednesday, September 15, 1999. Husband of Sandra Priest Rose, father of Deborah, Jonathan F.P., Samuel Priest, and Adam Raphael Rose; brother of Daniel and Elihu; grandfather of Ariel, Rachel and Sarah leaves a legacy of enormous love, warm friendships and immense generosity. His joy of life was expressed in his work and play. The service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY, on Sunday, September 19, 1999 at 10AM. The family requests no flowers, and is not receiving visitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHRER, SOPHIA B.
description: MEHRER-Sophia B. In her 90th year, wife of the late Eugene Mehrer; survived by Joanna M. Kapner of New York City and Robert Mehrer of North Kingston, RI; grandmother of Sharon Goel, Miriam Kapner and Emily Gore-Mehrer; mother-in-law of John Lee Kapner and Mary Gore. Funeral service at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 12:30PM, Friday, September 17, 1999. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Congregation Rodeph Sholom or to Rodeph Sholom Food Drive, 7 West 83rd Street, NY 10024.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAPHIER, FRED
description: SAPHIER - Fred. 11/7/13 - 9/17/98. We miss you. We miss the family gatherings, the shared experiences, even the divergent opinions. Lilian, Judy, Bob and Evelyn, Christine and Eddie, and Lilia, our beloved great-granddaughte

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORIS, JULIUS
description: BORIS-Julius. The Officers and Directors of Elderplan, Inc., sadly mourn the untimely passing of Julius Boris, beloved husband of Pearl and esteemed Board member of Elderplan. His involvement with Elderplan dates back to our inception. A devoted volunteer, leader and ardent supporter, Julius will be greatly missed. May his legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom he touched. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to Pearl, his wife of 60 years, his three children and entire family. Howard F. Sharfstein, Chairman Eli S. Feldman, President Daniel Kasle, Executive V.P./COO and the Staff of Elderplan, Inc.

title: The Cash Registers Ring at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cash Registers Ring at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Ghost Dance
description: The important thing, of course, is not to get caught up in the substance of these periodic debates about the rules of the Miss America Pageant. Whether the issue is swimsuits or the personal histories of its contestants, the pageant is dependably late in getting to a sensible policy. It is that perennial lateness, in fact, that is worth some examination.

title: Ray Yoshida
description: Adam Baumgold

title: With Her Libido as Navigator, One Woman's Adventures
description: In her solemn, sexually graphic ''Romance,'' Catherine Breillat explores the nature of a woman's need for male attention and erotic love. Though many of her film's insights might be obtained from back copies of Cosmopolitan plus a smattering of the Marquis de Sade, watching it is a memorable experience for several reasons. Not least of these is its blunt, hard-core frankness. It's doubtful that the film's intellectual aspects would command the same attention if the camera did not make the actors' genitals as familiar as their faces.

title: Review/Fashion; Blass as Blass, Even Damp
description: Yesterday's Bill Blass show was supposedly his swan song, though he hasn't officially announced the sale of his business.

title: King's Not Complaining, But the Talent Is Dizzying
description: Unless blisters or backaches or some other unforeseen maladies invade her Fed Cup dream team before this weekend's final against Russia, the United States captain, Billie Jean King, is basking in the security of a lineup that includes four of the world's top five players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, WILLIAM PAYSON
description: FINCH-William Payson. Died suddenly September 15, 1999. Beloved son of Angela and the late Charles, devoted brother of Charles Jr., cherished uncle of Charles III, and adored nephew of Peggy and Stephen Finch. Memorial services will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Browning School or Sarah Lawrence College. Will, we miss you so much and love you always.

title: NATO Chief Still Directing Battle of Words Over Kosovo
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark, NATO's Supreme Allied Commander, ended the bombing of Yugoslavia more than three months ago. But this week he was still waging a high-intensity battle to convince allied public opinion that the bombing had been as effective in Kosovo as he said it was last spring.

title: Gates, 'Spreading the Wealth,' Makes Scholarship Gift Official
description: Making a commitment that the head of the United Negro College Fund described as ''earth-shattering, landscape-changing,'' William H. Gates 3d and his wife, Melinda, today formally announced a $1 billion scholarship program for minority students that will guarantee recipients full financing for college and advanced degrees. It is one of the largest philanthropic gifts ever made.

title: A Menage a Trois for the Good Looks and the Laughs
description: Gregg Araki's film ''Splendor'' is almost a textbook example of what can go wrong when an artistic bad boy decides to be good. Or rather half-good, since the romantic triangle ''Splendor'' explores -- a pretty woman living happily with two pretty men and sharing her bed with them -- is in its way transgressive.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about Alexey Pajitnov, the creator of the computer game known as Tetris, misidentified the maker of the Gameboy portable game player. It is Nintendo, not Sony.

title: In War a Bond Becomes an Erotic Epic
description: Who can forget that moment in ''Casablanca'' when Ingrid Bergman, carried away by passion, her eyes shining, surrenders her judgment to Humphrey Bogart and tells him that from now on he has to do the thinking for both of them? Echoes of that moment resonate through Claude Berri's stirringly romantic film ''Lucie Aubrac,'' except that the roles are reversed. This time it is the woman (the film's title character, played with a riveting authority by Carole Bouquet) who does the crucial thinking.

title: A New Strategy: More Bluster Before the Blows
description: Before his last big fight, against Ike Quartey, Oscar De La Hoya spent a lot of time thinking about losing.

title: The Affluent Society? Welcome to the Fun House
description: What could be a more fitting theme for Alan Rudolph's phantasmagoric screen adaptation of Kurt Vonnegut Jr.'s novel ''Breakfast of Champions'' than that flowery 1950's ballad ''Stranger in Paradise''? The song, which runs through the movie like an ironic leitmotiv, distills an Eisenhower-era mood of sanctimonious freeze-dried optimism tinged with paranoia that the movie conjures with a demonic fervor. Those were the days, the movie reminds us, when it was almost a heresy to disparage the booming affluence of a society that television, then in its infancy, promoted as an unfolding paradise on earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, NATHAN
description: STAHL-Nathan. On September 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Hannah. Loving father of Harvey, Robert and father-in-law of Jackie. Dear brother of Alex. Adoring grandfather of Lori, Kevin and Allison. Service Friday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside Park West'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SLIPS A LITTLE. The dollar rose against the yen amid concern that Japan may step in to sell its currency, which remains at a 44-month high. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.00 yen, up from 104.23 on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JEFFREY
description: GOLDMAN-Jeffrey. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member Jeffrey Golddman. We extend heartfelt condolences to his parents Marilyn and Mark Goldman & sisters Jill and Debra. Funeral service Friday, Sept. 17th, Temple Beth Sholom at 1:30PM. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Martin Kay

title: Sex in the City With Religion On the Side
description: Tara Greenway has certainly chosen the theater subject of the month for her one-woman show: vaginas. Up on 43d Street, Eve Ensler is preparing a return engagement of her alternately serious and funny 1996 one-woman show, ''The Vagina Monologues.'' Down on Grove Street, Ms. Greenway is appearing in ''Missionary Position,'' a one-act comic drama about vulvar vestibulitis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARTMAN, MAUREEN DOWNEY
description: HARTMAN-Maureen Downey. September 17, 1997. We miss you. Love, David, Sean, Brian, Bridget and Conor

title: A Price for Everything, Even Testaverde's Heel
description: When Vinny Testaverde collapsed to the Giants Stadium turf with a season-ending torn Achilles' tendon last Sunday, did the Jets' potential sale price plunge?

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; At a School, the Unbelted Go Unfed
description: HOW can teen-agers be persuaded to wear their seat belts? There is driver's education, the threat of a fine and parental nagging. To that list, Jolene L. McNally has added pizza, because she found, with a shock, that the first three were not sufficient.

title: INSIDE ART
description: 'Spiral Jetty' Given to Dia

title: A Custodian of the Lullaby of Broadway
description: When Barbara Cook recapitulates Broadway musical history in retrospective tributes that have become an institution at the Cafe Carlyle, you often have a sense of her tenderly folding the past in her arms and singing it a lullaby. Her gorgeous lyric soprano conjures up the color and texture of autumn leaves on a piercingly clear October day.

title: Gaze Deeply Into My Eye; A Public Fixated on the Weather Is Mesmerized by Floyd
description: For days, Bob Chartuk, a spokesman for the National Weather Service, had been answering an endless stream of phone calls from reporters as Hurricane Floyd rumbled up the East Coast. Perhaps the most unexpected call, he said, came from a radio station in North Dakota.

title: Mexican, in U.S. Suicide Note, Blames Zedillo for His Death
description: In a last, bitter attack on the political system he once served, a former Mexican justice official who apparently killed himself on Wednesday rather than face money-laundering charges in the United States blamed President Ernesto Zedillo for both his own death and the assassination of his brother.

title: Jury Decides Man Posed No Threat To City Hall
description: A self-styled gadfly who barraged the Mayor's press office with dozens of phone calls in 1996 was acquitted yesterday of charges of threatening the Mayor's press secretary and violating a court order to stay away from City Hall.

title: New Gains Cited in Anti-Cancer Therapy
description: Dr. Judah Folkman, the Harvard researcher who has pioneered the idea of starving tumors with factors that cut off their blood supply, announced today that he had discovered a third such agent. But the report comes at a time when the first two factors he identified, known as angiostatin and endostatin, have encountered setbacks and prominent scientists have begun to criticize publicly the quality of the work done in his laboratory.

title: Too Many Food Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE INTERNET VENTURE
description: Two Japanese companies -- the Softbank Corporation and the Best Denki Company, a leading Japanese retailer of electrical appliances, said they would set up a joint venture to sell appliances and other goods through the Internet. The partners predicted annual sales of $100 million within four years.

title: Advocates Of Gun Bills Plan TV Ads
description: With Congress locked in a pitched battle over gun control, a leading advocacy group for tighter restrictions will show a new series of television advertisements featuring the talk-show host Rosie O'Donnell and the actress Susan Sarandon.

title: BUY.COM TO SELL $165 MILLION STAKE TO INVESTMENT GROUP
description: Buy.com Inc., a closely held Internet retailer, agreed yesterday to sell a stake to a group led by the Softbank Corporation of Japan for $165 million to help it expand in Europe and Japan. Other investors include Vivendi S.A. of France, the big water company, which is building media businesses, and the News Corporation, the Australia-based media company. Buy.com, of Aliso Viejo, Calif., sells computers, music, books and other wares on its World Wide Web site. This is the third and largest investment by Softbank and its affiliates in Buy.com in about a year, the company said. Softbank will hold about a 31 percent stake in Buy.com if it converts its preferred stock into common shares.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: More Than A Hat Trick

title: Sports of The Times; Like Bird, Parcells May Decide to Go
description: LARRY BIRD does not plan to coach after next season, and this should surprise no one who saw the resignation in his face as his Indiana Pacers surrendered their championship dream, like the victim of a holdup on a dark New York street.

title: Adam Fuss -- 'My Ghost'
description: Cheim & Read

title: Cadillac Has a Date for the Prom
description: FOR several years, the rear-drive Lincoln Town Car has had the limousine business pretty much to itself. That is changing: Last week, the nation's largest privately owned limousine operator, Dav El Chauffeured Transportation Network, said it was ending a 35-year run with Lincoln to switch to the front-drive Cadillac DeVille.

title: New So Far This Year
description: With the onset of autumn, when a flurry of new restaurants open, it's time to look at those that have already arrived in 1999. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: J. F. White Sr., Political Strategist, 75, Dies
description: John F. White Sr., a political strategist and organizer whose leadership played a vital role in the election of black officials in Philadelphia, died on Wednesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MARK I.
description: FINKELSTEIN-Mark I. Women's League for Israel mourns the passing of a longtime friend and benefactor. We extend deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Gertrude, and his family. Harriet Lainer, President

title: Campaigns use flash, dash and Claymation to promote the TV networks' football coverage.
description: FOR more than a decade, the testosterone-driven network studio programs that precede National Football League games on Sundays have been battlegrounds for analysis, features and scoops on signings, suspensions and injuries.

title: Clinton Refuses Subpoena For Material on Clemency
description: Citing executive privilege, President Clinton today rejected subpoenas from Congressional Republicans to turn over records of private deliberations that led him to offer clemency last month to 16 members of a violent Puerto Rican nationalist group.

title: CVF TECHNOLOGIES CLEARS WAY FOR ITS TAKEOVER
description: The CVF Technologies Corporation, which finances companies in the information technology and biotechnology businesses, said yesterday that it has granted the closely held USA Global Link Inc. an option to acquire CVF for $76.7 million. The option gives USA Global, based in Fairfield, Iowa, the right to acquire CVF for $9 a share. As part of the agreement, USA Global granted CVF Technologies an option to purchase a stake of less than 1 percent of USA Global for $9 million. The options are intended to simplify the capital-raising activities that USA Global Link, a telecommunications and Internet company, has been pursuing. Both options can be exercised on or before Sept. 15, 2000.

title: 2-TV Beisbol: Ramirez and Sosa; Dominican Fans in Washington Hts. Love Their Star Problems
description: Each evening, as pitchers warm up in faraway ball parks, the regulars file into Peligro Sports, a small, crowded Washington Heights storefront. Video games squawk loudly along one wall, soulful bachata songs blast from the stereo and a steady stream of flat, Cuban-style sandwiches are served up in the back with Malta India, a molasseslike malt soda.

title: Surging Waters Force Thousands From Their Homes
description: A day after Hurricane Floyd gyrated up the East Coast, emergency personnel from North Carolina to New Jersey and the northern suburbs of New York City struggled to contain surging rivers and creeks that drove thousands of people from their homes and hobbled transportation and communications networks. At least 31 people died in drownings or storm-related car accidents, including 4 in the New York region.

title: OPTIMISM ON EUROPEAN RATES
description: European bond prices jumped and most European stock markets ended higher on optimism generated by a European Central Bank report indicating that there was no need to raise interest rates soon. The report, echoed by public comments from the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, concluded that annual inflation should remain comfortably below 2 percent despite some new upward price pressures. The more relaxed view about inflationary risks marked a subtle shift from Mr. Duisenberg's warning several months ago about a ''creeping bias'' in favor of rate increases.

title: N.B.A. Approves Business Merger
description: National Basketball Association owners unanimously approved the proposed merger of the business operations of the Yankees and Nets, a person familiar with the vote told Bloomberg News.

title: I.B.M. Does An About-Face On Pensions
description: In a major victory for opponents of a controversial type of new pension, I.B.M. said yesterday that it would allow 35,000 additional employees to retain their old pension benefits, backing down from an earlier move forcing them to accept what for many would be far lower benefits from a new cash-balance pension.

title: Frances Knight, 94, Director Of Passport Office for Decades
description: Frances Knight, who ran the United States Passport Office for 22 years with efficiency and conservative zeal, denying passports and entrance visas to those she regarded as enemies of the nation and surviving efforts to remove her and even mandatory retirement at 70, died on Sept. 11 in a hospital in Bethesda, Md. She was 94.

title: BENIGN INFLATION IN CANADA
description: Inflation rose at an annualized rate of 2.1 percent in Canada in August, the highest in two and a half years, the Government said, but that was largely because of higher gasoline prices. Excluding food and energy costs, the core rate of inflation rose at an unexpectedly low annualized rate of 1.6 percent, down from 1.7 percent in July.

title: Miami's Payton Aims to Show Talent Is Part of Family Trait
description: Like his father, Jarrett Payton did not start playing football until his junior year in high school. And like his father, he developed strong legs and endurance by running hills.

title: Rotation Gets Leaner as Dotel Goes to Bullpen
description: When Manager Bobby Valentine told Octavio Dotel that he was being eliminated from the Mets' crowded six-man rotation, the first question the rookie asked was, ''Why me?''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: JAPANESE DEAL FOR ARTEMIS
description: The investment company headed by the French executive Francois Pinault, Artemis, will buy Aoba Life Insurance of Japan for 25 billion yen ($238 million), betting its assets will rise in value as the Japanese economy improves. It will be the first Japanese life insurance takeover by a foreign investor and will bring Artemis assets that were valued at 1.2 trillion yen on March 31. Aoba Life was founded to succeed the Nissan Mutual Life Insurance Company, which failed in 1997. Japan's insurance market, with annual premiums of $500 billion, is the world's largest, twice the size of the United States market.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the suspension of Judge J. Kevin Mulroy from the County Court in Onondaga, N.Y., pending a disciplinary review, after he was accused of making racial remarks on the bench, misstated one condition. The suspension was with pay, not without.

title: SAMSUNG LIFE TO SELL SHARES
description: The South Korean conglomerate Samsung Group plans to sell 400 million shares overseas of its unlisted life insurance company that were donated by its chairman, Lee Kun Hee. Mr. Lee contributed his shares in Samsung Life to help cover 4.4 trillion won ($3.68 billion) in debts incurred by the group's failed car maker, Samsung Motors. Samsung has already chosen Goldman Sachs Securities as the underwriter.

title: 6 Inches of Rain Doesn't Faze
description: Nearly six inches of rain from Hurricane Floyd fell on Belmont Park, but intensive care of the racing strip and the arrival of high winds combined to produce a track that should be dry and fast for the weekend's five stakes races and their star horses.

title: To Sleep, Perchance, on the Commuter Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost Lives, Ruined Homes and Close Calls
description: From the crowded towns of Westchester and Rockland Counties to the wooded back roads of Putnam and Dutchess, the remains of Hurricane Floyd wreaked deadly havoc to New York City's northern suburbs, leaving tens of thousands of residents yesterday mucking out, groping for flashlights, and in at least two cases, retrieving bodies from flood waters.

title: The Food Poisoning Toll
description: Disquieting figures released this week by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta confirm that food poisoning is far more prevalent than earlier studies have suggested. The agency now estimates that about 76 million Americans contract some sort of food-borne illness annually -- more than double its previous estimate of 30 million.

title: Crane Secured for Storm Falls, Killing a Worker in Chelsea
description: A huge crane collapsed at a Chelsea construction site yesterday morning, killing one worker and injuring three others after the crane operator tried to hoist the boom without releasing special restraints intended to prevent an accident once Hurricane Floyd reached the city, officials said.

title: HYUNDAI TO SHIP TV'S TO NORTH KOREA
description: For the first time, South Korea will directly export color televisions to North Korea. The Hyundai Corporation, the trading arm of Hyundai Group, said it would ship 160 color TV's to North Korea later this month. Hyundai's Asan Corporation recently concluded a contract with North Korea's Asia-Pacific Peace Committee to export 30,000 color TV sets on a deferred payment basis. Since Hyundai does not produce televisions, it has outsourced 15,000 units to Samsung Electronics and another 15,000 sets to a small local TV manufacturer.

title: Brazil Demands $1.5 Billion From Bank
description: The tax authorities have ordered one of Brazil's largest state-controlled banks to pay fines and back taxes worth $1.5 billion, a decision that could delay until at least the middle of next year a privatization plan expected to draw bids from some of the biggest financial institutions.

title: RUSSIA CHICKEN DEAL
description: The USA Poultry and Egg Export Council signed a $12 million joint venture with Elinar, a Russian company, to produce 125,000 broilers a week. The agreement is an unusual act of cooperation given the dispute that broke out between Russia and the United States over American poultry exports three years ago. Claiming the dark meat pieces failed to meet health standards, the Russians banned American chicken for several months.

title: When the Mentally Ill Get Out of Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Journal; Still Smiling, New Geishas Pour Sake and Charm
description: As a high school student, Ringo had dreamed of becoming a member of her country's National Defense Force.

title: Capitol Hill Memo; New House Looking Old Very Quickly
description: When Representative J. Dennis Hastert became Speaker, he pledged to work for a new tone of civility in the House to heal the wounds from impeachment. In a move that went beyond symbolism, he even quietly reduced the Speaker's reserve fund that had been used under his predecessor to help pay for Congressional investigations of the Clinton Administration.

title: Mexico City's Bank Robbers Feel Police Chief's Iron Hand
description: In a city with so much crime that wealthy Mexicans barricade themselves into mansions and seldom venture out except in armor-plated cars escorted by bodyguards, at least one disturbing mainstay seems to be declining.

title: TRADE SANCTIONS ON NORTH KOREA ARE EASED BY U.S.
description: President Clinton today ordered a broad easing of economic sanctions against North Korea in what officials said was the first step in a long-term plan to induce the North to abandon its missile and nuclear programs.

title: Albany Tightens Standards For Teachers and Training
description: New York State set new higher standards for teachers yesterday that will for the first time require all teachers in middle schools and high schools to have completed college majors in the subjects they propose to teach.

title: Guessing an Ace by Solving The Riddle of a Risky Lead
description: The first electronic world championship, sponsored by OKBridge in cooperation with the World Bridge Federation, the American Contract Bridge League and The Bridge World, is nearing completion.

title: A Match Made in Disneyland
description: In a move widely hailed by Wall Street, the Walt Disney Company announced today that it was merging with the Periodic Table of Elements.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: NONPERFORMING LOANS TO BE SOLD
description: The state-run debt clearinghouse, the Korea Asset Management Corporation, said it would buy 4.6 trillion won ($3.8 billion) of nonperforming loans from Seoulbank today for 1.15 trillion won. It said it would buy bad loans with collateral at 49.26 percent of their face value and loans without collateral for 3 percent of their outstanding values. In addition, the state-run Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation said it would inject 3.2 trillion won into the bank to raise its capital adequacy ratio above 10 percent. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: An F-22's Worth of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Composite Up 2.2% As U.S. Dollar Strengthens

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, JOHN MCDONALD
description: MOORE-John McDonald. January 11,1919-Septenber 14, 1999. Cherished husband of Elaine Roberta Werblud Moore. Loving father of Johan North, dear brother of Lyn Moore, adored and adoring parent to Marc Werblud, Monica Werblud Valenti, Debra Werblud Camerota and to their spouses: Tabitha Werblud, Angelo Valenti and Filippo Camerota. He was the most devoted, loving and beloved Baba John to Zachary Jonathan Valenti and Alexandra Meredith Werblud. Goethe defined genius as ''a productive power'' whose actions ''have consequenquences and lasting life''. John McDonald Moore as teacher and friend to thousands of students at The New School for Social Research University from 1968 to the present has affirmed this truth. His was a life of honor and dedication and supreme integrity. He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. His inspiration will remain. Service at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue Sunday September 19, 1999 at 12:30PM.
