description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: U.S. Firm Has Control of Korea First Bank
description: After 10 months of tortuous off-again, on-again negotiations, the Government of South Korea signed a binding agreement tonight to sell a controlling stake in Korea First Bank to Newbridge Capital Ltd., a United States-based investment firm.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORDON, GLENN
description: GORDON-Glenn. Dearest daughter, it is 20 years since we lost you, but time cannot diminish the love you gave so selflessly nor erase the memories we cherish of times shared. ''What is beautiful is a joy for all seasons, and a possession for all eternity.'' Love, Always Mom and Dad

title: Ruth Ginsburg Has Surgery For Cancer
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court was operated on for colon cancer here today, the Supreme Court announced.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP, London, said its United States arm, Shell Oil Co. in Houston, would eliminate 150 jobs about 7 percent of its exploration and production work force of 2,100, as part of a consolidation intended to reduce costs.

title: Jobless Rate Falls to 2.1% in Connecticut, Lowest in Nation
description: The unemployment rate in Connecticut has fallen to 2.1 percent, the lowest level in the nation and the lowest for the state in more than 20 years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, ROBERT P.
description: MANDELL-Robert P., died September 15th, 1999. Beloved son of Arnold and the late Pearl, loving husband of Robin, devoted and adored father of Rebecca & Peter, dear brother of Jane Moross, uncle of 15 nieces and nephews. He will be missed and remembered by family and friends forever. Services Sunday, September 19th, at 10:45 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Nabokov Adds Grit To His Game
description: Dmitri Nabokov's talent has never been doubted. But the former first-round draft pick has spent most of his three-year career in the minors because he often played without intensity.

title: Sports of The Times; First Things First: Mets Need to Win
description: THE Mets keep getting ahead of themselves. On Thursday, the Mets' co-owner, Fred Wilpon, said Manager Bobby Valentine and General Manager Steve Phillips would be back next season, effectively breaking the internal tension that has kept the team uneasy for the last two months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANCELLIERE, M.A. (CANCY)
description: CANCELLIERE - M.A. (Cancy). Adorable scamp. Loving and beloved husband. Rest in peace. Leah

title: To Sleep, Perchance, on the Commuter Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Stanton Is Hurting, But Aims for Playoffs
description: Mike Stanton is usually good for a smile, but he spoke seriously and quietly to reporters today about the stiffness in the left side of his back. Stanton will probably not pitch in the final three games of this series against the Indians. ''I feel like I'm letting the team down,'' Stanton said.

title: Hell Is Getting A Makeover From Catholics; Jesuits Call It a Painful State But Not a Sulfurous Place
description: In ''The Inferno,'' Dante tells of his imagined journey into hell, his entry into a ''kingdom of eternal night'' where he hears the voices of the damned rise ''in a bestial moan'' and sees sinners stung by wasps, burnt by falling fire and frozen in a sheet of ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, FLORENCE ZIRINSKY
description: FRIEDMAN-Florence Zirinsky. Age 94. Died peacefully September 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Friedman. Wonderful mother to Bill & Lynne & the late Joan Laura. Devoted grandmother of Katie, Margo & Tom. Loving great-grandmother & aunt to many nieces & nephews. Loyal & special sister of Evelyn Kossoy & the late Doris, Sylvia & Lawrence. She was one of the founders of the AAUN Womens Division, president of Sisterhood of Union Temple & active Red Cross volunteer. Her sharpness and candor will be sorely missed. A Private funeral was held.

title: Disney Stage Embroiled in Middle East Politics
description: What began as an effort by the Walt Disney Company to present a brightly optimistic exhibition on foreign cultures has blown up in its face this week, with Arab, Israeli and American Jewish groups angrily reenacting on a theme park stage the bitterness of Mideast politics because of the way a new Israeli pavilion at Disney World was to describe Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TANNENBAUM, LONA
description: TANNENBAUM-Lona. 11/1/289/18/96. 1095 days-and countingwithout your knowing look, your distinguished and determined intellect, your singular humor, your prodigious loyalty and your lovin' arms. A.H.T

title: Laxity on Police Abuses
description: Public Advocate Mark Green's interim report on police misconduct cases gives disturbing evidence of how lax New York City's Police Department has been in past years in following through on citizen complaints. Under the present system, all citizen complaints are investigated by the independent Civilian Complaint Review Board. Only about 6 percent of all complaints are found to be substantiated by the board and forwarded to the Police Department for charging and disciplinary action.

title: A Troubled Man Went Free, As Long as None Were Hurt
description: Anybody who had been around Larry Ashbrook could tell that the man had problems.

title: When Too Much Success Plagues a Diamond Thief
description: High concept linked to a lower-middlebrow script creates the not-so-heady brew that is ''Blue Streak.''

title: Review/Fashion; McQueen's Audacity, Beene's Impishness
description: How like Alexander McQueen to have the clairvoyance to stage a fashion show in the middle of a wading pool while New York was battened down for a hurricane.

title: An F-22's Worth of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER CLIMBS. Copper rose more than 2 percent to a 16-month high after a Government report signaled robust demand. In New York, copper for December delivery rose 2.05 cents, or 2.5 percent, to 84.35 cents a pound.

title: The view that liberty and certainty are necessarily opposed raises serious questions.
description: Is certainty the enemy of human freedom and progress? That was a conclusion reached 300 years ago by many thoughtful Europeans appalled by the 17th century's bloody wars of religion -- and revived in revulsion to the 20th century's bloody wars of ideology. It appears to be a guiding theme of the lengthy ''Reflections on the 20th Century'' featured in the Sept. 11-17 issue of The Economist, the British magazine.

title: Greek Orthodoxy in U.S. Is on the Cusp of Change
description: When Archbishop Demetrios, new head of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, flew into New York from Europe on Thursday, he arrived amid the gusting winds and furious rain brought north by Hurricane Floyd. But yesterday, as he met with church officials and visitors, the windows in his office at archdiocesan headquarters on East 79th Street were illuminated by sunny skies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHAUGHNESSY, LUCY MARIE O'SULLIVAN
description: O'SHAUGHNESSY-Lucy Marie O'Sullivan. On September 15, 1999. A long time elementary school teacher and loving mother and wife. Educated at the Ursuline Academy and Maxwell Training College, she and her late husband, John Quinn O'Shaughnessy agreed that their primary role was preparing their four children as complete human beings. Her late sisters, Mary O'Sullivan Wood and Kathleen O'Sullivan Spalding spent their early years in Kenmare, Ireland before they came to the United States. She is survived by her daughters Sister Alice O'Shaughnessy, M.D., C.S.J., Kathleen O'Shaughnessy Hearn, her sons, J. Kevin O'Shaughnessy and Thos. E.B. O'Shaughnessy, Ed.D. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Nancy O'Shaughnessy Smith, Ellen Clelia O'Shaughnessy and Christopher Hearn. Also mourning her passing are her daughter-inlaw Laura Nuzzi O'Shaughnessy, her son-in-law Rex Alan Hearn, Sister Lauren Hanley, C.S.J., and her loving friend of 85 years, Loretta Coyne Donovan French. Lucy is remembered as a loving elegant lady of sharp wit who gave endlessly of herself for her loved ones. Friends may call Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 P.M. at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at RR Plaza), Floral Park, New York. Funeral Mass on Monday 10:30 A.M. at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In Lieu of flowers the family suggests donation to Mercy Hospice Uniondale, New York.

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS PLANS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday, the company's second split this year; shares of Sun, the fourth-largest maker of server computers, have more than tripled in the past 12 months. Shareholders as of Nov. 11 will receive two Sun shares for each one held, payable Dec. 7. The split will raise the number of outstanding shares to 1.56 billion. Sun's machines are among the most popular for running electronic-commerce Internet sites run by companies like Amazon.com, which are adding more computers as they process more purchases. The stock of Sun, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose $4 a share yesterday, to $88.6875.

title: Mayor Blasts Man Cleared Of Harassing City Hall
description: One day after a jury acquitted him of charges that he repeatedly threatened Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's press secretary, Christopher Brodeur infuriated Mr. Giuliani yesterday by calling his weekly radio program and asking for an apology.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: SCOTTISH POWER TO SELL SHARES
description: Hoping to cash in on the market's infatuation with telecommunication and Internet stocks, Scottish Power said it planned to sell shares of its communication unit, Scottish Telecom, to the public by year-end. The company will retain a majority stake in Scottish Telecom, which generated $:166.1 million ($269 million) in revenue last year. ''The board of Scottish Power believes it is now timely to realize value for Scottish Power shareholders through an initial public offering,'' said Ian Robinson, above, the chief executive.

title: Just Sit Back and Watch Sparks Fly
description: During the final news conference on Wednesday, Felix Trinidad, the welterweight champion, could not keep still in his seat. His legs, visible underneath the table on the dais, were jumping up and down at 100 miles an hour.

title: How Kevin Bacon Made His Way Back to Lead Roles
description: Kevin Bacon was green up to his elbows. And not just green but a hideous, Day-Glo green. He stuck out one of his Kermit the Frog hands. ''I don't think it rubs off,'' he said, shaking firmly and then flopping back onto the couch in his trailer behind a Columbia Pictures sound stage. Nearby a guitar leaned against the wall.

title: Giuliani Challenges Financial Arrangements of Clinton Mortgage
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday challenged the financial arrangements under which President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton are purchasing a house in Chappaqua, saying that the involvement of Mr. Clinton's chief fund-raiser in underwriting the $1.35 million mortgage raises ''lots of significant questions that will be pursued in the next three, four, five months.''

title: Judge Permits Washington To Count Vote On Marijuana
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the board of elections and ethics for the District of Columbia may count and announce the results of a referendum on the use of marijuana for medical purposes that was on the ballot in November.

title: WHISKY MAKER IS SOLD
description: The British distiller Allied Domecq P.L.C. assumed management control of the whisky division of South Korea's largest liquor maker for $120 million. Under the agreement, Allied will acquire a 70 percent stake in Jinro Ltd.'s whisky business, which will be divided into two joint venture companies: one overseeing bottling, distribution and marketing of Scotch in Korea and another to import and market other Allied Domecq spirits.

title: Australia's Mistake
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Gridlock: Better Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: IDT in $51 Million Deal
description: Integrated Device Technology Inc. agreed on Thursday to sell its microprocessor unit to Via Technology Inc., the computer chip-set maker based in Taiwan, for $51 million. IDT, which is based in Santa Clara, said the sale would allow it to focus on products for the communications industry and exit a business that has been hurt by stiff price competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, EDYTHE
description: STEINBERG-Edythe. The partners, brokers and staff of Ashforth Warburg Associates regret the death of Edythe Steinberg, mother of Richard Steinberg and motherin-law of Renee Bross, both of this office. The world will be a duller and less dynamic place without a woman who raised a son like Richard. Frederick W. Peters, President Ashforth Warburg Associates

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTAS, ATHENA
description: PETTAS-Athena. September 18, 1973. 'Earth to earth' began your immortality. Here, memory remains. Your Daughters

title: Correction
description: A letter on Monday misidentified the Connecticut police force that is screening applicants for too-high I.Q.'s. It is the New London force.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia Names Suspects

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A lot of these places got not only their rain, but everyone else's, too.''

title: Arafat Slips Across Border For Secret Talks With Barak
description: Under cover of darkness, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, sneaked into Israel on Thursday night to meet with Ehud Barak, the Prime Minister. Although their meeting place was kept secret even tonight, the Israeli media reported confidently that the two leaders got together in an unusually intimate setting, at Mr. Barak's home in Kochav Yair, a town on the edge of the West Bank.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the On the Street section of the Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday misstated the name of a parade, its route and the starting time. The event is the International Cultures Parade, not the International Immigrants' Foundation Parade; it will start tomorrow at 2 P.M. and go up Madison Avenue from 23d to 42d Street.

title: A Critical Station Drops Met Matinee Broadcasts
description: For 33 years the live Saturday matinee broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera have been carried in eastern Massachusetts by WCRB-FM, a 50,000-watt commercial radio station based in Waltham, a Boston suburb. But WCRB, the largest commercial station for classical music in the state, has terminated its association with the Met, citing disagreements over broadcast format and unacceptable losses of commercial revenue.

title: Anti-Abortion Law Is Roiling Missouri
description: After the Missouri Legislature overturned a veto, a new law went into effect, criminalizing one type of late-term abortion and prompting women seeking abortions in St. Louis to cross the state line to Illinois for the procedures.

title: Writer as Character in Reagan Biography
description: Fourteen years have passed since the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Edmund Morris gingerly assumed what he calls the ''dread title of authorized biographer'' for Ronald Reagan, who with his savvy political advisers anointed him the President's bard.

title: Red Tape vs. Green Cash: Making an Economy Thrive
description: John Stossel comes out tomorrow night fervently in favor of capitalism American style. Abetted by conservative theorists, he argues in ''Is America No. 1?'' that it's freedom that makes countries rich and government red tape that keeps them poor.

title: MANAGEMENT CHANGES AT FEDERAL-MOGUL
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, the world's largest maker of engine seals, shook up its management this week as Gordon Ulsh, its president and chief operating officer, quit after a profit warning earlier on Tuesday. Mr. Ulsh, 52, was named to the two posts in February; the chairman and chief executive, Dick Snell, took over the jobs. Frank Tomes, executive vice president for the former general products division, and Edward O'Leary, vice president of aftermarket sales for the Americas, also resigned. Federal-Mogul's shares fell 23 percent on Tuesday after it said third-quarter profit might be 20 percent below analyst forecasts. Federal-Mogul's shares fell $1.125 yesterday, to $26.4375.

title: Parmalee's Pursuits Gaining in Importance for Jets
description: All the hand-wringing about a quarterback aside, a 32-year-old backup running back who became a Jet only 10 days ago could be a significant factor in how well the season goes.

title: Microsoft Covered Cost of Ads Backing It in Antitrust Suit
description: Newspaper advertisements that a California institute presented as independent views supporting the Microsoft Corporation's position in its antitrust trial were actually paid for by Microsoft, the institute said today.

title: Kosovo Rebels' Political Chief Calls for U.N. Representation
description: The political leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army said today that the Kosovo Albanians want to be represented at the United Nations, one more step toward their goal of complete independence from Serbian-led Yugoslavia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: A New Law on Abortion Is Roiling Missouri
description: Women seeking abortions in St. Louis were sent across the state line into Illinois this morning, until Missouri's new law criminalizing one type of late-term abortion was stayed this afternoon by a Federal judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BARBARA ANN
description: LEVINE-Barbara Ann, of New City, NY, age 55, on September 17, 1999, after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife of Larry; devoted mother of Robin, Jeffrey and Brian; cherished mother-in-law of Paul and Samantha; adored ''Baba'' of Jonah and Matthew; daughter of Estelle and the late Jack Vinikoor; and sister of Mark and Joel Vinikoor. An artist, an arts educator, Barbara loved her family, friends and work. She shared her knowledge and talent with boundless energy, enthusiasm and passion. Services will be held Sunday, September 19, at 10 AM, at Hellman Memorial Chapel, Spring Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, Ste 1720, NY, NY 10036, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Ending Gridlock: Better Solutions; Guessing Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal on Tower Allows Kennedy Airport to Get Wind Shear Equipment
description: Kennedy International Airport will get radar equipment for detecting deadly wind shear, about seven years after the Government started installing the first such devices at 43 other major airports, under a deal announced today that ended years of political battles over where to put a tower.

title: A Step Forward With North Korea
description: After months of threatening behavior by North Korea and tough warnings by the United States, the two countries have stepped back from a potentially dangerous confrontation. Yesterday President Clinton ordered an easing of economic sanctions against North Korea in response to the Pyongyang Government's decision to freeze its testing of long-range missiles. The Administration's move is not without risk, and much needs to be done to monitor the North's behavior and to reach even broader accords to reduce tensions. But this was a welcome development that could lead to further progress toward stability in the region.

title: Gore Assails Bush on Texas Law That Permits Guns in Churches
description: Vice President Al Gore attacked Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today for signing legislation that permitted guns to be carried into churches as concealed weapons. Starting in Los Angeles this morning, at every public stop the Democratic Presidential candidate spoke of the shootings in a Fort Worth church on Wednesday and asked, ''How can we allow guns in churches?''

title: Atlantic City Hotel Workers End Strike Against Casinos
description: More than 12,000 hotel and restaurant workers in Atlantic City will return to work Saturday, union officials announced today, ending a three-day strike that left many casino restaurants understaffed and thousands of hotel guests without maid or room service on the eve of the Miss America pageant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, JAMES R.
description: CHERRY-James R. Of Chappaqua, New York, on September 16, 1999, at the age of 92. He is survived by his sister, Rosalind, his children, Kaye, Jim and Sylvie, his beloved granddaughter Justine and his long time companion, Dorothy Arnof. A memorial service will take place in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to New York University Medical CenterDepartment of Surgery-in honor of Dr. S. Arthur Localio, c/o Dr. H. Leon Pachter, 530 First Avenue, Suite 6C, New York, NY 10016.

title: Bringing Back The Insouciance Of a Golden Age
description: Hurricane Floyd's torrential rain may have noticeably thinned the crowd attending Thursday's opening night show of a two-night Carnegie Hall tribute to Betty Comden and Adolph Green, but those who braved the weather found themselves at the warmhearted concert equivalent of a nostalgic home musicale. These lyricists, who have collaborated for more than six decades, embody what might be called Old New York: not the shuttered upper-crust world of Edith Wharton but the exuberant melting-pot city of Leonard Bernstein.

title: Russians Name a Chechen as the Chief Suspect in 5 Bombings
description: The Russian police said today that they had determined that a 29-year-old Chechen man organized the recent spate of deadly bomb attacks in Moscow with the assistance of an Uzbek national, but they do not have either man in custody.

title: After 7 Are Killed, Texans Look for Meaning
description: There is a small blood donation center in a brick strip mall just a mile from the church where a gunman killed seven people at a Wednesday night prayer service. In the two days since, more than 450 people have come to give blood, some driving from towns an hour away. When told there is a five-hour backup, they wait outside, sitting on folding chairs as the sun goes down, sharing cold pizza and theories about why a man opens fire in a sanctuary full of children.

title: Ex-Clinton Lawyer Says Politics Had No Role in Clemency
description: The President's former chief counsel, who recommended the offer of clemency to 16 Puerto Rican nationalists, said today that political considerations regarding Hillary Rodham Clinton's likely Senate race had played no part in the President's decision.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN TUMBLES. Expectation that Japan will persuade other leading industrialized nations to intervene to weaken the yen deflated it versus the dollar and the euro. In New York, the dollar rose to 106.86 yen, from 105.19.

title: Summer 2000
Plan to Strengthen Colombia Nudges U.S. for $3.5 Billion
description: Responding to concern in the United States about surging drug production and guerrilla activity here, the Colombian Government today unveiled a plan for ''peace, prosperity and strengthening the state'' that calls for $3.5 billion in assistance from the United States and other allies during the next three years.

title: Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. Is Dead at 79
description: W. Arthur Garrity Jr., the Federal judge whose school desegregation order led to the racial turmoil that tarred Boston as a place of busing infamy in the 1970's, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 79.

title: Mercury From the Midwest Lands in New York's Waters
description: Catskill officials were astounded last year to learn that the renowned game fish of the Neversink Reservoir had mercury in their flesh at double the level considered safe by the Federal Government.

title: Leiter Struggles Early Again and Piazza Gets Hurt
description: Al Leiter watched Hurricane Floyd howling through Manhattan from the 38th floor of his Upper East Side apartment on Thursday. It left Leiter with a strange feeling of solitude. He saw the strength of the storm just outside his windows, but still felt comfortable and safe.

title: OLD EYES AND NEW
description: Much of what the world knows about the last 1,000 years it has learned from artists. In a special issue of The Times Magazine, the fourth of six reflecting on the millennium, respected painters, photographers, sculptors and choreographers around the world reimagine historic milestones. Their works form a modern time line, a way of seeing distant history through new eyes.

title: Emily Nathan Public Relations Executive, 92
description: Emily Solis Nathan, a journalist who later became a public relations executive specializing in art and museum projects in New York, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: An F-22's Worth of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLEY, CHRISTINA
description: BUCKLEY-Christina. Of Cold Spring Harbor. On September 15, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Julian G. Buckley; loving father of Sarah B. Warner, Christina B. Hoff and James L. Buckley. A private cremation was entrusted to A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc. Memorial service Saturday, September 18 at 11AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. Donations may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church in lieu of flowers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Television section on Sunday carried erroneous listings for the Metro Channel for each day this week. Correct listings are appearing on the daily television page.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHRER, SOPHIA
description: MEHRER-Sophia. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved longtime member, Sophia Mehrer. We will miss her loyalty to our Congregation and deep commitment to our Homeless Shelter and issues of social justice. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her daughter, Joanna Kapner, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President Jay Kranis, Community Concerns Chair

title: Major Effort Rescues Hundreds From Flood Waters
description: A flotilla of boats from canoes and small fishing craft to big police launches -- urgently crisscrossed the flood waters today above a submerged Main Street, rescuing hundreds of residents from second-floor windows and rooftops where they were trapped.

title: Strategy for a Charlatan in China: Claim Deity, Then Steal and Seduce
description: A delicate-looking man with bright eyes showed up in this dusty town a few years ago, preaching that he was a resurrected god, though with a scraggly beard and a preference for plastic flip-flops, he hardly looked like one.

title: Students Seek Some Reality Amid the Math Of Economics
description: On my first day as a graduate student in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the professor introduced the discipline by intoning, ''All of economics is a subset of the theory of separating hyperplanes.'' (You don't want to know what that mathematical term means.)

title: Political Notes; Big Battle for a Relatively Little Job
description: This week's primary election was, for many New Yorkers, a sleepy affair. But in Washington Heights, a race for Democratic district leader drew more than 2,000 voters and was, by any standard, furiously fought.

title: Richter Positive Despite Troubles
description: Even though he has a stiff back, Mike Richter said would be ready for the Rangers' season opener, Oct. 1 at Edmonton.

title: Those Who Perished Beneath the Deep Water
description: One was a father of five who tried to get home after his car stalled by walking across a flooded bridge. Another was a 9-year-old girl who wanted to escape the rising tide that was inching toward her home. Two others did not want to leave their flooded home.

title: Kennedy Papers' Forger Sentenced to 9 Years
description: The man who sold hundreds of forged documents supposedly written or signed by John F. Kennedy was sentenced to nine years and seven months in prison yesterday, a stiffer term than usual, and ordered to pay $7 million in restitution to victims of his scheme.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Part ABC Studio, Part Disney Billboard
description: It may have started out as ABC's answer to the highly successful on-the-street studio that NBC built for the ''Today'' show in Rockefeller Center, but the new double-decker home for ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' which opened on Times Square this week, has mutated into much more than that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, JAMES
description: NELSON-James. On September 15, 1999. Longtime resident of Locust Valley, N.Y. Father of Gary and Craig. Visitation will be from 3-5 and 7-9 PM Sunday at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc., 293 South St., Oyster Bay, N.Y. Funeral service at 11 AM Monday at the funeral home. Interment at Westbury Friends Cemetery.

title: High Water Strands 1,000 And Closes Roads in State
description: The eastern third of North Carolina was declared impassable today when scores of rivers and creeks rose to record levels in a delayed reaction to Hurricane Floyd, engulfing thousands of homes and cars. At least 10 people died in drownings or storm-related car accidents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Emmy Awards ceremony gave the network incorrectly in some copies for ''Law and Order,'' a nominee for best dramatic series. It is NBC, not ABC.

title: Ellington in Casual Mode, With the Not-So-Famous Pieces
description: Duke Ellington had more levels of intent than perhaps any other performing artist of the 20th century. He enlarged the medium of jazz by imagining all kinds of audiences for his work, from symphony buffs to North Dakota teen-agers on a dancehall date to middle-aged Harlemites reflecting on a Southern past; he recorded large-gesture sacred works occasioned by his religious devotion and unpretentious riff-driven bagatelles occasioned by nothing more than marketplace demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOCOLOW, EDITH GUTMAN
description: SOCOLOW-Edith Gutman, 88. On September 16 in Eugene, OR, after a decade of decline under tender care. Widow of A. Walter Socolow; sister of Daniel Gutman (New York, New York) and the late Alfred Gutman (Taunton, MA); mother of Robert (Princeton, NJ), Daniel (Atlanta, GA and Chicago, IL) and Joan Bayliss Noparstak (Eugene, OR); grandmother of Dagan Bayliss & David, Ari, Seth, and Joshua; mother-in-law of Jane Socolow, Susan Socolow, and Irwin Noparstak; step-grandmother of Eric & Jennifer Pitt & Jacqueline Noparstak. A New Yorker into her 70's, Barnard and Teacher's College graduate, remedial reading specialist. Remembered by all for her grace, brilliance, and beauty. Burial in Eugene, September 17.

title: Ending Gridlock: Better Solutions; Rulers of the Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: Headed for Trouble; Insurers Deploy Legions of Adjusters to Areas Hit by Storm
description: As Hurricane Floyd roared up the Atlantic seaboard this week, America's biggest insurers mounted military-style operations to cope with the expected wreckage.

title: Spurrier Sounds the Alarm for the Volunteers
description: This is how Florida Coach Steve Spurrier, while signing off on his hourlong radio-television broadcast the other night, explained Hurricane Floyd's right-turn pass on the Sunshine State: ''God smiles on the Gators. We know that.''

title: Indians' Wright Loses Location as Clemens Takes Command
description: From the perspective of Umpire Brian O'Nora, pitchers Jaret Wright and Roger Clemens must have looked like entirely different species tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNUNZIATA, DOROTHY ''DOLLY'' (NEE ANTOS)
description: ANNUNZIATA-Dorothy ''Dolly'' (nee Antos). Passed away peacefully in her sleep after a long illness of emphysema on Sept. 17, 1999. Dear wife of the late Anthony Annunziata. Loving mother of Beverly Wolcson & loving motherin-law of Mickey Wolcson. Devoted sister of Lois and Timothy. Cherished grandmother (Bocky) of Jessica, Nicole and Anthony Wolcson. Beloved and devoted family member to numerous nieces, nephews, grand nieces, grand nephews and cousins. Dolly was a retired employee of American Airlines & was known for her spirited personality and love of travel. She will be deeply missed by her family and her many, many friends who loved her. She will always be remembered. Interment will be private. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Memorial donations can be made in her memory to the American Lung Association.

title: Vanguard Founder Declines An Offer to Stay as Director
description: Stung by a backlash from investors who felt that the founder of Vanguard Group, John C. Bogle, was being treated shabbily, the mutual fund company's board of directors voted yesterday to allow him to remain a director past the mandatory retirement age of 70.

title: Acuson to Purchase Ecton
description: The Acuson Corporation, a maker of ultrasound systems, has agreed to buy the closely held Ecton Inc. for as much as $40 million to enter the market for low-cost, small heart-imaging machines. Acuson said it would pay stock now valued at $23 million and might pay $17 million more if Ecton achieves certain goals through 2003. Ecton, based in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., is expected to generate sales of at least $15 million in 2000 and $50 million within four years, said Samuel H. Maslak, Acuson's chairman and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LEON JULES
description: LEVY-Leon Jules. After a valiant battle. Beloved son of Georgette and Morton J. Levy, dearly loved brother of Ellen Levy and Tobi Lanciano, loving uncle of Jonathan and David Dahari. Services will be at Hevreh of Southern Berkshires in Great Barrington, Mass., Sunday, September 19, 1999, 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Leukemia Society.

title: Sehorn Goes Full Speed, But Fassel Isn't Rushing
description: Jason Sehorn was given a private workout today at Giants Stadium. After Sehorn had participated cautiously in the team's regular practice, Giants Coach Jim Fassel, the assistant coaches John Fox and Johnny Lynn and the head trainer Ronnie Barnes took him to the team's indoor practice facility, where Sehorn ran full speed for the first time in a session closed to reporters.

title: Floyd's Necessary Discomforts
description: When a storm like Hurricane Floyd fails to live up to its advance billing, some people actually seem disappointed, as if they had been suckered into an overrated movie. Others, having been asked to abandon their jobs and homes, whine about the inconvenience of it all. But on balance the relocation of more than two million people in the last few days -- Federal officials called it the largest mass evacuation in the nation's history -- was a sensible precaution. It saved more than a few lives, and it demonstrated that state and local governments are fully capable in emergencies of moving great numbers of people in orderly fashion, without panic or serious discomfort.

title: The Great Mall
description: Whatever harsh judgments history may render on Mao Zedong, he transformed China into a modern industrial nation, and at an amazingly rapid rate. Production, consumption, literacy, health care and much else multiplied exponentially within only a few years of the Communist takeover, in 1949. Even so, other aspects of Maoism proved disastrous. His neglect of agriculture in favor of industrialism led to widespread famine and the death of millions. Millions more perished in the 60's during the Cultural Revolution, which burned a wide swath through Chinese culture. And while Mao effectively abolished capitalism, he never correspondingly established anything that could be called Socialism either. China under his regime was a pure example of rule by the state, in which there was no private ownership of the means of production, and no bargaining power for workers. It took Mao's successor, Deng Xiaoping, to fully transform China's economy. Though Deng will most likely be remembered for having sent in troops to mow down the Tiananmen democracy movement in 1989, he did much to encourage the pragmatic private market system that has rapidly changed the face of China. That new reality radiates from the two suns shown rising in this lacquer-on-wood panel creation by the three Luo Brothers of Beijing -- Wei Dong, Wei Guo and Wei Bing -- who are best known for blending images from Western culture and Chinese New Year calendars into their art. The larger sun rises over the young people who make up the country's consumer society. Western skylines, soft drinks and boomboxes meld with traditional dress of past centuries and inspirational Socialist realism of past decades. The smaller sun that casts a hopeful new light on Tiananmen Square is technological, appearing on 55 television monitors.

title: The Drug Wars
description: Tea could be called the original gateway drug. Approximately 30 million pounds were consumed annually in the British Isles in the early 1800's. All of it came from China, shipped to England by the British East India Company. When inflation overwhelmed Europe in the 1820's, the firm was unable to raise the hard currency demanded by Chinese tea merchants. Faced with ruin, it hit upon a devious but lucrative solution. In India, the company controlled the cultivation of opium, a drug banned in China since 1729. Parties officially unaffiliated with the company simply took opium shipments to Canton and secretly traded them for silver coin. The money was sent to London, laundered and returned to China, where it was used to buy tea. Quickly, the volume of opium coming into China increased a thousandfold. When China tried to stop the traffic, Britain blockaded Canton. The conflict escalated into war, with other Western powers, eager to colonize China, joining in.The Opium Wars began in 1839, continued on and off for more than 20 years and resulted in the fall of China's empire. The wars also sparked the drug epidemic that plagues us today. It is the modern consequence of a long-ago act that the fashion photographer David LaChapelle highlights in this photomontage. Models lie dazed in an opium den transformed into a steam room. They are in thrall to a giant syringe, which reminds us that profits grew even larger when the lowest grade of opium was converted into heroin. Of course, tea, which nominally started it all, is only mildly addictive. But then, perhaps, no substance is as addictive as money.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Accidents Will Happen, Repeatedly
description: Echoes of Muriel Spark (''The Driver's Seat'') and John Fowles (''The Collector'') sound throughout COLLECTORS (Random House, $19.95), Paul Griner's nevertheless distinctive literary thriller. Its protagonist is Jean Duprez, an art director for an advertising agency in Boston and a collector who cruises flea markets seeking (her specialty) antique fountain pens. When she attends the wedding of her cousin Claudia, and meets an attractive widower named Steven Cain, Jean's carefully managed life starts to unravel. After a satisfying day aboard Steven's sailboat, he accidentally slams her hand in a car door, then sends Jean, alone, to the hospital. Somehow, Claudia's disclosure that Steven ''has a lot of accidents'' only deepens Jean's fixation on her charismatic new lover. He is also a collector (binoculars), and it turns out that his former wife died in an accident Steven refuses to discuss. ''Collectors'' builds tension swiftly and skillfully, layering in ominous foreshadowings (a wrong-number phone call by someone seeking a funeral parlor, a smell of burning coal detected while at sea) as it teases us with conflicting explanations of its central mystery. Is Steven Cain a suave psychopath? Is Jean compulsively drawn to the danger he poses? Or is he the avenger calling her to account for the sins of her youth, the most flagrant being a house fire accidentally set during one of her childhood ''games'' with Claudia? Paul Griner, who is also the author of a short story collection titled ''Follow Me,'' juggles such alternatives ably, in a first novel whose deftly sketched characters and frissons of surprise and menace elevate it beyond simple imitation. Bruce Allen

title: Duck and Cover

It probably reached its peak with the Cuban missile crisis, in 1962, when people the world over understood that the United States and the U.S.S.R. were poised to rain thousands of nuclear missiles on each other. In this sculptural montage, the artist Sandy Skoglund seeks to evoke what she calls the ''damp feeling'' that seeped into every facet of ordinary life. The standard official advice to ''duck and cover'' notwithstanding, everyone understood that there was no escape -- that nuclear war would mean the end of the world.

title: Engine of Change
description: The Industrial Revolution was no sudden eruption. It occurred in fits and starts over more than half a century, starting in the 1700's. It was a revolution nevertheless, overturning many rooted assumptions. One was about work: before the Industrial Revolution, the word ''industry'' referred exclusively to an attribute of character. Another was about man's place in nature. Gregory Crewdson's photograph pays homage to O. Winston Link's railway photography. But while Link's pictures of trains celebrate the power of technology, Crewdson presents a darker outlook. Here, the animals have erected a blockade to stop the train. They are wise to be fearful, for the railroad did far more than speed up travel and commerce. Previous means of transport had followed nature's rules: the boat navigated currents, the carriage adapted its journey to the landscape and to the strength of its four-legged engines. The railroad, however, required a level surface. For it to work, nature had to be reconfigured. So hills were shaved, gaps filled in, tunnels blasted. The contract between humans and nature was suddenly voided. There was a paradox, though. As humans were besting their environment, they were also subjecting themselves to the rule of machines. Cotton gins and steam engines only briefly lightened laborers' tasks before creating new burdens, among them widespread pollution. The Industrial Revolution itself is now being superseded by the information revolution, which will inevitably create its own burdens. There is, however, no turning back.

title: The Many Faces of Islam
description: Based on the form of a Persian miniature, this work by Shahzia Sikander, a Pakistani artist who now lives in the United States, shows some of the paradoxes that attend Islam today. As Sikander and her collaborator, Sameer Butt, observe, despite political and cultural differences, Islam is one faith the world over. Islam, the law that the prophet Mohammed revealed in the seventh century, governs all aspects of life and, unlike Christianity, does not admit any dichotomy between church and state, between sacred and secular. Islam overrides nationality; Western notions of political left and right do not apply. Difficulties, of course, arise from interpretation and behavior. The Judeo-Christian world today has only a partial and deeply distorted view of Islam. For one thing, we tend to forget the vast contributions made by Islam in the Middle Ages -- the philosophical writings of Averros and Avicenna, advances in astronomy and mathematics, the preservation of ancient Greek manuscripts.For another, we overlook the religion's contemporary strains of thought and practice, a point Sikander makes by constructing a galaxy of Islamic leaders. Packed into her picture are mystics like the Pakistani qawwali singer Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, politicians like Hanan Ashrawi, the Christian Palestinian activist, and religious leaders like Ayatollah Khomeini. The artist included Menachem Begin to signify what she regards as Israel's role in uniting Muslims against a common foe. (See identifying diagram, page 146.) Non-Muslims often think that a jihad is meant to be carried out by force of arms, but many of the faithful believe, rather, that it consists of following the path of righteousness and setting a good example. Indeed, it is this side of Islam, not the extremism so prominent in recent years, that Sikander's visualization suggests will prevail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRINKAUS, CHARLES EDWARD
description: TRINKAUS - Charles Edward. Professor Emeritus of History, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Died in NYC on September 15, 1999. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, on October 25, 1911, and received his BA from Wesleyan University and his Ph.D. from Columbia University. He was a member of the Sarah Lawrence College Faculty from 1936-1970, and Professor of History at the University of Michigan from 1970-1982. He was a Life Associate of the Columbia University Seminar on the Renaissance and a longtime member and past president of the Renaissance Society of America. A member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was the author and editor of many influential studies in Renaissance and Reformation religious and intellectual history. He is survived by his wife Pauline Moffitt Watts; his brother John Philip Trinkaus; his son Dr. Peter Mark Trinkaus; daughter-inlaw Dr. Martha Morrell and three grandchildren, Emily, Samuel and Madeline.

The words are emblazoned on an old-fashioned fortunetelling machine. As the steam organ tootles and the painted ponies go round and round (most of them riderless, thanks to the weather), the 44-year-old filmmaker -- a grin splitting her moon face and her eyes as blue as the sky should be -- accepts the offer of a quarter and squeezes the brass levers.

title: That $24 Real Estate Deal

title: Making Time
description: Time has changed in the last 1,000 years, from an abundant, undifferentiated flow to a finite, disputed commodity. The clock as we know it was probably invented shortly after 1275, though the all-important minute hand didn't come along until the late 1500's. Before the mechanical clock there were sundials and water clocks, but they weren't much good at night or when the sky was cloudy. How could you tell when it was 3 A.M.? Monks needed to know, because of their fixed devotional hours. The workday was determined by light; in Paris, tanners worked until two coins of similar appearance but different denomination could no longer be told apart. All measurements were vague and subjective then - an inch was the width of my thumb, which was not the same as yours - but time was the most indeterminate category of all. The calendar was equally fluid. For a long time Venice and Florence did not observe the same year. Even literate nobles dated their letters by the year of the king's reign. Few people had more than a rough idea of their own age. The mechanical clock, a complex contrivance of toothed wheels and weights, began what was to be a long and laborious process of standardization as the world slowly agreed to hold certain conventions in common, like time zones. (Less than a century ago, noon in New York fell a bit after noon in Hartford and a bit before noon in Newark.) In this clocklike sculpture built by Arthur Ganson, an engineer, inventor and artist in residence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, time runs on an electric motor. But it is the gears, pulleys and springs that direct the nervous dance of the figures on top. As we learned to master time, the sculpture reminds us, we also fell under its yoke.

title: Seeing Faster
description: We learned to see, at long last. Partway through the millennium, we figured out how to shape and polish glass so as to see far and to see small, and we dug back into dead languages of previous millenniums to name our new aids to seeing -- telescope, microscope, spectroscope, spectrophotometer, spectroheliograph and, eventually, television. We figured out the art, the geometry and the semantics of perspective. No wonder our superheroes had X-ray vision; so did we. And infrared vision, and ultraviolet vision, and gamma-ray vision and nuclear-magnetic-resonant vision.We extended our sight far beyond the tiny spectrum our unaided eyes could handle, from violet to red.

title: New World Order

Man, no longer the center of the universe, is in motion around the sun. He rises up beyond his limits, beyond the skeletons of past ignorance, and then, suddenly, subject to gravity, falls. Possibly, too, he rises from ignorance to understanding, but after that, dazzled by his own power, he overreaches, whereupon he tumbles downward like Icarus, a victim of his overweening hubris. His fall is not an end, however, but a prelude to a new rise.

title: Revolution
description: Haiti, 1804: This tormented country stands at the intersection of two historical developments. One is the wave of revolutions that included the American and the French. The other is the wars for colonial independence that dominated Latin America later in the 19th century and continued on in Asia and Africa in the 20th. In this painting, the noted Haitian artist Ernst Prophte reimagines the proclamation of Haitian independence on Jan. 1, 1804, in the town square at Gonaives, by Gen. Jean-Jacques Dessalines. American schoolchildren remember Haiti's liberator as Toussaint L'Ouverture, but that extraordinary man, who led a population of ex-slaves to victory over French, Spanish and British armies, had by then died of pneumonia in a French prison. Since the revolution, Haiti's example has been alternately inspiring and dispiriting. The success of its popular uprising against overwhelming odds demonstrated to the world the mettle and power of a race barely accorded human status at the time. That Haiti was just the second independent nation in the Western Hemisphere deepened the triumph. Haiti's achievements, however, were overshadowed by formidable difficulties. The country was instantly plagued by economic problems. Warfare, for example, had ruined the irrigation system that made the island France's richest agricultural outpost. Furthermore, while its new leaders subscribed to the revolutionary ideal of liberte, they dispensed with fraternite and egalite. Democracy was not part of the program. Dessalines soon named himself Emperor; two years later he was killed by his own generals. Subsequent regimes did not fare much better. In recent years, Haiti has sought to renew its democratic promise. Whether it will remains an open question -- a fact underscored by this painting, which reminds the viewer that Haiti's most hopeful moments have only been preludes to disappointment.

title: The City Life; Crossing Times Square
description: Last week, while Hurricane Floyd was howling northward, I finally grasped the direction Times Square -- a howling chaos in its own right -- is heading. Soon it will be the first place on earth that offers the visceral equivalent of being on line with a high-speed connection. Even now Times Square makes me feel like a homunculus, almost small enough to saddle an electron and ride off into the silicon distance, to rocket at light speed from one source of virtual infotainment, one virtual brand-vendor, to the next. Except that in the canyon of light and mirrors and cameras that Times Square is becoming, the main illusion is that there is no distance to escape to, no escape from the blinding solipsism of the place at all.

title: The Look of Fear
description: Many authoritarian movements have darkened the 20th century, and the word ''Fascism'' has been hurled at most of them. But Fascism is a specific phenomenon. It is a form of totalitarianism that is antiliberal and anticonservative as well as anti-Communist -- a form of populist ultranationalism of a racist and militaristic character. It is not, strictly speaking, reactionary. It pursues modernization by summoning up mythic images of a grand and heroic past. The ultimate aim is a hyperefficient state machine, with citizens as its cogs, held in place by private fear, collective rage and tribal enthusiasm. Benito Mussolini, probably the first effective popularizer of Fascism in this century, began as a socialist, but his brand of socialism brimmed with violence and vanguard action. Even he could pass for a moderate, though, in comparison with Adolf Hitler, whose national socialism surpassed every other version of the Fascist ideology in mechanization, cruelty and mad horror. There have been other forms of Fascism and other campaigns of extermination and racist hysteria -- millions were killed and terrorized in Stalin's murderous Soviet Union, for example. But the savagery of the Nazis leaves the bloodiest stain of the century. Aware of Fascism's greatest weapon, its atavistic lure, the photographer Gerald Slota consciously avoided creating a picture ''that could be interpreted as heroic.'' Instead, he blurred specific images to make them universal, and then centered attention on the silent, fearful vigilance of the victims' eyes.

title: Hello, Columbus
description: When Christopher Columbus made landfall in the Bahamas on Oct. 12, 1492, he set in motion a vast ecological transformation. The tide that conveyed Europeans to the New World also brought their cattle, horses, cats and pigs; their wheat, oats, grasses and nettles; their rats, insects and bacilli. Because the Americas had stood in splendid isolation for millenniums, the continent's diverse life forms were no match for the invasion-hardened genes of the Old World. While Europeans lacked the knowledge to carry out biological warfare intentionally, Cortes's conquest of Mexico and Pizarro's conquest of the Inca empire were made easier by smallpox, which preceded their armies and decimated the native populations. Meanwhile clover and thistles, peach trees and dandelions, opportunistic species all, conquered the fields and forests of the untrammeled continent. Christianity, firearms, the Roman alphabet, European styles of clothing, housing and protocol were imposed with minimal difficulty on the dazed and weakened natives. And what did the Old World receive in return? As punishment, only syphilis; very few American weeds were sufficiently aggressive to win retribution on foreign soil. The rewards that traveled east, however, were great: vanilla, maize, tobacco, potatoes, sunflowers, peanuts, tomatoes, indigo, chocolate. European diet and life style were altered profoundly; what started out as novelty quickly became immemorial tradition. These works by Catherine Chalmers depict one of the shock troops of the European invasion, the cockroach, fastening upon the bounty of the New World, represented by the tomato. The insect shown in these photographs, painted with an image that festooned Columbus's sails, did so well in its new home that it is now called the American cockroach.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; 'Calculated Nonchalance'
description: Like the wealthy subjects of his famous portraits, Anthony Van Dyck (1599-1641) was no stranger to good fortune. Almost everywhere he went, success followed. In Genoa he became the darling of a thriving merchant class who sought not only his skills as a portraitist but his amusing company and refined ways. In England, he lived in royal luxury as court painter to Charles I. Even in his native Antwerp, Van Dyck made a small fortune supplying grand altarpieces to a clergy in the throes of a redecorating frenzy brought on by the Counter-Reformation. For most of his life Van Dyck lived, as one early biographer put it, ''more like a prince than a painter.'' Success impaired neither Van Dyck's prodigious output nor his flair with a paintbrush. VAN DYCK: 1599-1641 (Rizzoli, $75), with essays and analysis by nine art scholars, contains more than 100 reproductions of the artist's paintings, including religious masterpieces like ''The Lamentation Over the Dead Christ,'' as well as the remarkably sensitive portraits of Europe's elite, on whom Van Dyck bestowed what Hans Vlieghe, an art historian and expert on Flemish art, calls a ''calculated nonchalance.'' One chapter, which is devoted to the milieu of 17th-century Genoa, scarcely mentions Van Dyck, but gives one a welcome understanding of how an artist of his talents could take an entire city by storm. An introduction by Christopher Brown, director of the Ashmolean Museum at Oxford, gives a succinct account of Van Dyck's life: his childhood genius, his apprenticeship to Rubens, his obsession with Titian, which led Van Dyck to Italy and to the refinement of his lush, highly Baroque style. And then it's on to England and the court of Charles I, where in one seven-and-a-half year period Van Dyck produced some 400 portraits; when we envision the age of Charles I, it is most likely through Van Dyck's eyes that we see it. Suzanne MacNeille

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, JEANNE
description: TENENBAUM-Jeanne. Died of ovarian cancer on September 15, 1999, she was 90. She was a teacher. All of her fifty or more working years were spent in New York public schools in the education and defense of high school children. She developed ''Project Able'' which brought together local schools and community businesses to enable students in trouble and in financial need to continue their schooling while acquiring work experience. She was a dancer. When she was young she danced with Charles Weidman and followed modern dance, ballet and classical music with lifelong concert and performance subscriptions. She studied piano in her youth with occassional hiatuses but it seemed almost most seriously when, in her late 80's, she studied with Sophie Feuerman, who was in her 90's. She never lost an active interest in the lives of her friends and family as well as the life of her neighborhood, the Upper West Side, and her city, New York. She was married to Samuel Tenenbaum for many years. They had no children, but she was devoted to her nieces and nephew, her grandnieces and grandnephews. She worried about them, encouraged them and in the authoritative voice of the matriarchal aunt, could speak quite sharply. She offered her friends, her agemates and those younger deep loyalty and concern. It was as though she had a great gift, true attentive friendship. She is survived by her older brother, Dr. Victor Goodside and his wife, Ray, by her younger sister, Grace Paley, and those nieces and nephews from five to 60 who will not forget her. A memorial service will be held in about three weeks at a place to be announced.

It was a good choice. Green Grotto, in New Burnswick, offers a taste of authentic Jamaican cuisine. Although I was wary of tasting the oxtail, served in a brown sauce ($12), the result was a melt-in-the-mouth bite. The oxtail was complemented by the salty calaloo, or Jamaican collard greens. I washed the meal down with a glass of sorrel ($4), a hibiscus-flavored nonalcoholic beverage traditionally served during the winter holidays in Jamaica.

title: New Found Land
description: This tranquil scene at the water's edge is probably what Norse seamen saw around the year 1000, after sailing west from Greenland. Vinland, they called it; Newfoundland, we call it today -- a haven where the Vikings lived for a while until chased away by harsh winters and unfriendly natives. Where, exactly, did they come ashore? Geoffrey James's photograph shows Epaves Bay at L'Anse aux Meadows, in northernmost Newfoundland, where in 1961 the remains of six sod houses were found, the first hard evidence of a Norse presence. The site, James notes, ''is remarkable for its lack of drama,'' which is precisely what the Norsemen would have been looking for: an easy place to land, with room to graze their cattle. As demonstrated by the telltale rivets, nails, bits of iron and soapstone and a bronze pin found there, L'Anse aux Meadows was indisputably a Norse settlement. But it was probably not the only one in North America. The sagas describe Vinland as a place of great forests, where wild grapevines had to be cut down before ax men could get at the trees, and where salmon also thrived. Salmon and grapes coexist only in a narrow geographic corridor along the Atlantic coast between the Hudson River and northern Maine. Recent scholarship suggests that Vinland may have been off Passamaquoddy Bay, between Maine and New Brunswick. Wherever it was, it was the birthplace of Snorri, the first European child born in America. It was also where Native Americans first tasted milk and first encountered a snorting bull. Though the Norse adventure may not have lasted long, its mystery reverberates still.

title: Proof Positive
description: Abelardo Morell's photograph shows a camera obscura, a simple lens-and-box device, reflecting upside down the image of the Englishman William Henry Fox Talbot, who might be considered the inventor of photography. Talbot successfully exposed his first negative in 1835, although he then waited four years before announcing the fact, thus allowing himself to be upstaged by Louis Daguerre of France. Talbot is, however, credited as the inventor of the fundamental negative-positive process, which permitted multiple prints to be made of a single exposure, as well as of calotype, the first method for producing images on sensitized paper. He therefore has a greater claim to the title of father of all subsequent photography than Daguerre. Though the Frenchman's method was refined more quickly, it was more cumbersome (it required a silver plate) and fell into disuse long before the end of the century. Talbot was a polymath who patented a linear motor and translated Assyrian cuneiform. He was also an artist of considerable stature. The image of leaves here comes from his 1844 book, ''The Pencil of Nature.'' It is ostensibly a showcase demonstrating the many uses of photography, from copying manuscripts to documenting architecture. Beyondthat, the book remains valuable for its quiet, carefully composed scenes of English country life. In its best-known image, ''The Open Door,'' a broom leans against the frame of a darkened cottage doorway. The picture has an austere but inviting beauty. It is both a record of a time and place -- and an appropriate metaphor for photography's ability to sweep the cobwebs away from vision.

Soon morning will break on a year zero and maybe that will give us the impression that we are starting from scratch, hurtling naked into the new. But the measure is an arbitrary one; it'll be the same old world, and we overlook that fact at our peril. The eye in the palm of Francesco Clemente's watercolor reminds us to be mindful of the immediate moment -- even as we look back over the past, even as we preoccupy ourselves with the future. In the picture, the artist has tied a bow on not one but two fingers of the hand. Sketched in the shape of infinity, the bow says remember, and it says forever.

title: For God's Sake
description: The Crusades began just over 900 years ago, and although they nominally ended about two centuries later, when Saladin expelled Christ's soldiers from Jerusalem, they are in a way still proceeding. The Crusades defined Western civilization in terms of righteous warfare and conquest of foreign territories, and they also initiated Western suspicion of the inhabitants of the Middle East, who had to be viewed as forces of evil in order to justify European conquest. Carroll Dunham's painting shows the two cultures locked in mutual incomprehension. Fervent belief, here underscored by intense and vibrant colors, is inseparable from deep hostility: the blades of the Crusaders seem interchangeable with their crosses, while the scimitars of the Saracens can be taken for the Muslim crescent.

title: Political Briefing; An Interfaith Appeal For Old-Time Ethics
description: There is nothing new about Presidential candidates talking about religion and faith and values and suddenly showing up for a worship service somewhere. But this time around there seems to be more talk and worshiping than usual, perhaps because personal character, personal conduct and personal views on touchy issues like abortion and guns now loom so large in the campaign.

Services will be at Hevreh of Southern Berkshires in Great Barrington, Mass., Sunday, September 19, 1999, 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Leukemia Society.

title: Here a Bushbuck, There a Crane
description: I WAS driving along the R572 between Messina and Pontdrif when I spotted the large blackbreasted snake eagle perched on a telephone pole. I braked, reversed and stepped slowly out of the car so as not to startle it. I used my binoculars for a moment, out of habit, and then put them down. There was something about looking through them that made the eagle seem as if it were in a separate world. It wasn't. Barely 20 feet of hot asphalt separated us.

Most people will quickly forget about the storm; for me and others in this part of the country, however, that's an impossibility. Hurricanes are part of our history, remembered for the damage they caused. Hurricane Floyd, suffice it to say, will be remembered for a long, long time.

title: Haunts of a Poet
description: DRIVING across the industrial belt of South Wales is a disconcerting experience. Steelworks and gray conurbations alternate abruptly with expanses of brilliant green farmland, while the sea, glimpsed just occasionally, glints on the horizon. At Port Talbot, the grim steel town that brought forth Anthony Hopkins, the actor, the cantilevered M4 motorway passes within only a few feet of people's bedrooms. I am here in search of one of my father's literary idols, Dylan Thomas, Wales's most famous poet. As the car speeds through a muddle of housing, shops and railway lines, I can recognize a landscape that would have amused Thomas, a lover of humanity in all its eccentric guises.

Now there is an exhibition at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan, featuring exquisite examples of pottery, textile and glass work, that seeks to broaden the idea of Indian art beyond blankets and buckskin.

title: The Art of The Deal
description: More than one layer of historical parallel glistens in this collage painting by the American artist George Condo. Here, an affable Bill Gates appears as a Renaissance grandee and Michael Eisner of Disney stands genially beside a cartoon creature in an illuminated page from ''Les Trs Riches Heures du Duc de Berry'' (1413-16), by the Limbourg brothers. At one level, the towers of Disneyland evoke those of the Duke's castle; in 1994, Gates made the celebrated acquisition of Leonardo da Vinci's ''Leicester Codex'' (1506-10). At a deeper level, the Renaissance was a time, like ours, of capital building and trade expansion. Europe's kings and nobles, for all their outward show of wealth and power, were often hugely in debt to merchant bankers like the Medici family of Florence and Jacob Fugger of Bavaria. Culture rode the coattails of money: vain patrons commissioned monuments that have endured, in some cases much longer than any memory of the patrons themselves. Paintings dazzled the eye not only with their genius but also with the richness of their settings and the rare ultramarine and gold of their pigments. The fortunes made in the spice trade allowed for cultural exchanges between East and West, opening doors -- in the Ottoman Empire, for example -- that the Inquisition tried unsuccessfully to slam shut. The materialism of the Renaissance justified itself by the splendor of the artwork and by the vigor, depth and solidity of the humanist ideas it permitted to flourish. Only time will tell whether anything similar can be said of the modern Medicis and our opulent era.

title: We've All Got Mail
description: Our descendants will inevitably find their own name for what we now call, somewhat misleadingly, the Information Age. For the focus today is less on information itself than on the rapid profusion of devices for exchanging, storing and manipulating it. Multiple strands of technological development, some many decades old, have been coming together in ever more advanced incarnations, with complex results. The computer has a dense genealogy, going back to Joseph Marie Jacquard's punch-card loom (1804), Charles Babbage's Difference Engine (1833) and Herman Hollerith's census-data calculator (1890), before achieving a preliminary synthesis in the work of Alan Turing and John Von Neumann during World War II. Similarly, vacuum tubes gave way to transistors, which led to integrated circuits and, finally, to microchips. Satellites now draw on older technologies like television and the telephone to form another weave of relays and terminals for communication. These technologies affect almost every aspect of life, in ways that still appear radical, perhaps exhilarating, perhaps threatening. Nam June Paik, the electronic-multimedia artist, here suggests a cave painting for the present era: Samuel Morse's dots and dashes change into binary zeros and ones, satellites hover overhead and, down below, humanity remains, blissed out and plugged in.

title: Out of Africa
description: The first African slaves arrived in the Americas, in Hispaniola to be exact, in 1502. In 1619, ''20 and odd'' black people disembarked in the Jamestown colony in Virginia, the first slaves in the future United States. Over the next 250 years, about 14 million Africans survived the ''middle passage'' and were consigned to forced labor in the fields of North and South America. They came largely from tribes on the west coast of Africa: the Ibo, Mandingo, Yoruba, Fulani, Wolof, Ashanti, Whydah and Coromantee. Somehow, despite overwork and disease, beatings and murder and the enforced breakup of families, their cultures managed to survive. This survival was patchwork, granted, but profound. Some of its manifestations were local: the Gullah language, the raked dirt yard, the cultivation of the yam. Some -- in dialect, in the style and employment of clothing and in religious practice -- had a national or hemispheric range. In music, the influence was global. We can hear it in blues, jazz, gospel, samba, rumba, merengue, reggae and zouk, of course, but also in styles of syncopation, instrumentation and vocalization that have infiltrated other musics high and low, east and west. If the African influence were somehow removed, what we think of as American culture would be unrecognizable. Kara Walker, who practices the art of cutting silhouettes out of paper (a technique that reached its peak in the early 19th century), has here made a complex tableau, which pointedly mimics the usual perception of the African diaspora. Though the viewer's focus is initially drawn to the reverse-cut white male at center, it quickly becomes clear that blacks are at the four corners of the world and that, as Walker puts it, the character in white is simply ''being reshaped by an African hand.''

title: Triumph of The Image
description: The paintings in the caves at Lascaux in France are the oldest things we can call art -- not simply the oldest figural representations, but the oldest things made by humans that have no clear, practical value. That also makes them arguably the most mysterious human productions. We don't know who made them or why, who saw them or under what circumstances. We don't know whether such daubings were common and intended for viewing by all, a census of beasts or a record of hunts, or ceremonially esoteric and restricted to the purposes of a particular caste. Their mystery prefigures the tension between documentation and transcendence that marks art of more recent centuries. The fact that they date from prehistoric times, meanwhile, has given us the idea that pictorial representation was as basic as language in the development of the human species.

title: Big Brother's Eye, Mother Russia's Tears
description: This piece by Rimma Gerlovina and Valeriy Gerlovin, conceptual artists who left Russia in 1980 and are now American citizens, is an allegorical description of the Soviet Union. The hands are painted with the laurel crown that the Soviet empire awarded itself in grandiose emulation of its Roman antecedent. The three figures on the woman's face signify the three judges of the tribunals that consigned millions to the gulag or the grave: the central figure represents the all-seeing eye of the state; the two that flank it depict tears running down the face of Mother Russia. The history of the Soviet Union is a chronicle of disastrous failure on a monumental scale. Lenin's ambition in 1917 of turning feudal Russia into a modern industrial state, while establishing Socialism and simultaneously collectivizing agriculture, was the very definition of hubris. With the war against Hitler and several hard winters thrown in, it was a wonder, in retrospect, that the nation's collapse was not total and immediate. Nineteenth-century thinkers had imagined the triumph of Socialism as an apotheosis of human possibilities; the Soviet state saw things quite differently, for it tried, in effect, to reduce people to machine parts. Stalin, cruder than the wily Lenin, sought to rid his world of all the parts that didn't fit, at the cost of countless lives. Right up to the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, the state was still trying to watch, control and shape individuals, as if subjugation and fear could bring about the same results as consent. Communism's legacy is a modern Russia afflicted by a volatile, despairing mix -- a country whose structure is in ruins and where chaos is in the wind.

title: Great Leap Forward
description: At the dawn of this millennium, China was centuries ahead of the West in science and technology. The Chinese, after all, had already invented paper, printing, gunpowder, the magnetic compass, the wheelbarrow, the kite, the crossbow and the sternpost rudder. But because of China's geographic and cultural isolation, it was centuries before its intellectual and technological bounty reached Europe. It took 600 years for the clockwork escapement, for example, to reach the West; the iron chain suspension bridge and the rotary fan took more than 1,000 years to make the trip. Doug and Mike Starn's scroll-like installation, which is meant to be read from right to left, represents the transmission of knowledge from scroll to book, from East to West. The scroll is laid out on two translucent tables, one of Chinese design, the other European in style. The work begins with Chinese drawings and calligraphy from the seventh century, accompanied by a portrait of Taizong, a renowned emperor of the period. These images then blend into a painting of a tree branch from 1360, titled ''A Breath of Spring,'' which stretches up and into a Western book. This volume, in turn, is composed of detailed medieval illustrations of fabled Western travelers who ventured to the East: Marco Polo, William of Rubruck and Giovanni Carpini. These 13th-century pioneers, who made their journeys during the reigns of the Great Khan Mangu and Kublai Khan, opened Europe's eyes to Asia. On first glance, what the West saw were silks and spices. It took longer for China's deeper store of wisdom to unfold and be revealed. Doug and Mike Starn's installation is about 17 feet long, 14 inches tall at the short end and 3 feet high at the book end. The Western-style manuscript table is acrylic, as are the two tables of Chinese design that the scrolls rest on. The luminosity of the piece, a trademark of the Starns' work, is the result of more than a dozen lamps placed beneath the scroll. An electronic scanner was used to transfer the images to the scroll, which is made of Mylar. It took four months to complete the piece.

title: The Plague Years
description: Epidemics have been a part of the human story since settled populations first attracted parasites and then trade conveyed them to other vulnerable places. The plague that fell on Europe in the 14th century was distinguished by its ferocity and its longevity. From its origins in central Asia, it was carried by rats aboard ships, reaching Italy in the fall of 1347 and quickly spreading as far as Britain and Scandinavia. The Black Death killed about a quarter of Europe's population and recurred periodically over the next three centuries. (The 17th-century plague that Daniel Defoe chronicled was essentially the same beast.) The concept of germs was unknown then, and the virulence of the contagion was beyond all experience. To speak with an infected person, to attend the sick, to bury the dead virtually guaranteed death. Whole cities were emptied; houses stocked with riches stood undisturbed; crops rotted in the fields. The plague's contemporary parallel is AIDS, which came out of nowhere, apparently, around 1979 and decimated a generation. Gay men, hemophiliacs, needle users and people living near the major trucking routes in Africa were among the most affected; to date, 14 million people have perished from the disease worldwide. AIDS is a deadly mystery, and its threat has provoked panic, blame and superstition. Joel-Peter Witkin's illustration, which juxtaposes the bones of a 14th-century plague victim with a living sufferer from AIDS, is a reminder that the threat remains. As sophisticated as our medical science may be, a cure continues to be out of reach. Even more dispiriting, perhaps, is this: another plague doubtless lies in wait, though no one knows where it will come from or when.

Do you want to get a place?''

Two dates into his first solo tour, Mr. Cornell, the former Soundgarden singer, seemed thoroughly pleased to be in a theater instead of a sports arena, playing to a fairly small group of attentive fans instead of a big, rowdy rock crowd. He acknowledged the man who stood and waved his fists, heavy-metal style, for most of the performance, but he was just as grateful to those who sat back and absorbed his new sound.

title: Patents; New wireless systems try to do away with the tangle and restrictions of speaker cables.
description: TO an audio purist, the cables that link speakers to an amplifier can be as important as the quality of the speakers and the amplifier themselves. A length of specialty cable can cost hundreds or even thousands of dollars and can spark serious debate among aficionados over whether the wire should be copper or silver, braided or straight. High-end audio magazines review speaker cable, and routinely report that some produce better sound than others. Yet most people are content with the kind of speaker wire they can buy at Radio Shack. Either way, cable is a nuisance. It can crimp anyone's style, limiting where speakers can sit, and even preventing whole-house music systems.
