title: Bill Gates Shares the Wealth
description: Educators, social scientists, labor-market specialists and politicians in both parties have been sounding the alarm for decades about the perils of failing to improve educational opportunities for disadvantaged minorities, particularly African-Americans and Latinos. Microsoft's co-founder and chairman, William Gates 3d, took an impressive step toward closing the education gap last week when he announced that the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation would spend $1 billion -- the largest education grant in American history -- on college scholarships for minority students over the next 20 years. By bringing attention to this problem, the Gates Millennium Scholarship program could have an impact well beyond the money it will spend, principally by raising student aspirations in the country's poorest neighborhoods.

''What Next?'' was paired with Arnold Schoenberg's ''Von Heute auf Morgen,'' and if this twosome will never rival ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci,'' the contrasting works made easy bedfellows.

title: A Bold Tactic in the Pollution Wars

Mr. Spitzer announced last Wednesday that he intended to sue 17 coal-fired power plants in five Midwestern and border states in an effort to force them to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide. These pollutants, which are carried eastward by prevailing winds, are major causes of urban smog and of the acid rain that has caused so much damage to New York's forests and waterways.

title: 2 Westchester Encephalitis Cases Prompt Plan to Spray in County
description: Two people in Westchester County have contracted the potentially deadly mosquito-borne disease St. Louis encephalitis, county officials announced last night, in the first cases in the current outbreak reported outside of New York City. The officials said that they would begin spraying pesticide on the southern third of the county on Thursday.

title: Welcoming Mom and Dad to the I.C.U.
description: When children are treated in an intensive care unit, their parents are often asked to wait outside. But a new study by researchers at a Rochester children's hospital suggests that allowing parents to stay may be better for them and for their children.

title: To Gain More Ground, It Pays to Improvise in the Running Game
description: Several teams entered this season puzzled about how their running games would evolve, but the Denver Broncos were not supposed to be in that group.

title: Two Reassigned

title: Here She Is, But Where Is She From?
description: IT didn't take long for Miss New York to fall by the wayside at the Miss America Pageant the other night, not that it came as a great shock. New York's standard-bearers have not usually fared well at the pageant, and Brandi Burkhardt, 20, was no exception.

title: Review/Fashion; A Personal Vision Proves Elusive
description: Last Thursday morning, as rain beat against the windows, Calvin Klein was in his office giving a reporter a preview of the spring collection he planned to show the next day. He mentioned Babe Paley, as a model appeared in the sort of sheath she might have worn, except it was in trendy nylon. As Mr. Klein went on, making a lot of hip references to the nerd style now in vogue with London teen-agers, but blandly, without obvious personal associations, it was hard not to notice a photograph leaning against a wall.

title: Second Man Convicted in Dragging Death
description: After a week of testimony that detailed a crime of almost unimaginable brutality, a Texas jury today found a racist ex-convict guilty of capital murder in the beating and dragging death of a 49-year-old black man last year.

title: Public Interests; Buchanan's Longest Day
description: Pat Buchanan's Presidential candidacy is looking swell. Within the last few days he's made friends with Lenora Fulani and gotten into an argument about whether it was a good idea to go to war against Hitler.

title: McGwire Hits 59th In Sosa's Backyard
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Mark McGwire insists that there is no home run race. ''It doesn't matter who finishes first,'' he said. ''I was in a race with Ken Griffey several times, and no one cared.''

title: Landmark for Ex-Slaves Felt Brunt of Storm
description: Of the 10,000 North Carolinians driven into shelters by Hurricane Floyd, more than 2,000 have occupied a teeming building here that until recently was Tarboro High School. It is surrounded by lakes of stagnant brown water, but there is not a drop for toilets, showers or laundry.

description: Asarco Inc. filed an antitrust lawsuit in United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday to block the Phelps Dodge Corporation's $2.6 billion hostile takeover bid for both Asarco and the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company.

title: Kindly Mourning the Old Certainties
description: In a mythic rural American Eden, nature was unspoiled, children minded their parents and work was hard but virtue was rewarded. The idealized memory of that simple life is in the sound of the Carter Family's songs: the simple strumming and fingerpicking, the comforting foursquare melodies, the words that reaffirm faith and family. John Prine and Iris DeMent, who shared a double bill at Town Hall on Thursday night, write homespun songs that echo the Carter Family's music but speak about a world where the old certainties have fallen away.

title: For Atlanta, It's Crucial to Stay on Top
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20 -- Forget unacceptable. For anyone associated with the Atlanta Braves in the 1990's, anything less than a division title is inconceivable. This is, after all, a team that has won an unprecedented seven consecutive division crowns.

title: In Bradley Game Plan, Early Victories Buy Time

title: DOLE FOOD SAYS IT MIGHT HAVE LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: Dole Food Company, the world's largest producer of fresh fruit, said yesterday that it might report a third-quarter loss because of falling banana prices in Europe. Dole said the best its continuing operations would do in the quarter was break even. The company was expected to earn 13 cents a share, the average estimate of four analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Shares of Dole, based in Westlake Village, Calif., fell $2.75, to $21.25. The stock has dropped 33 percent in the last year.

title: VOICESTREAM TO BUY AERIAL COMMUNICATIONS
description: Voicestream Wireless Inc. moved toward becoming a nationwide wireless phone carrier yesterday with an agreement to buy the Chicago-based Aerial Communications Inc. for about $3 billion in stock and cash. The deal follows the Bellevue, Wash., company's agreement to buy Omnipoint Communications Inc., a New York wireless company. Voicestream appears to be close to cobbling together a national network that could compete with AT&T, Sprint and Nextel Communications or with a possible joint venture between Bell Atlantic and Vodafone Airtouch. VoiceStream, Omnipoint, Aerial and Powertel Inc. all operate with a technology known as global system for mobile communications, or GSM, which is the dominant system in Europe and much of the rest of the world. Analysts have long expected a consolidation among the GSM carriers in the United States, and Voicestream has seemed most likely to be the buyer. Shares of Voicestream rose $5.875, or 10.5 percent, to $61.9375. Aerial shares rose $6.625, or 33.1 percent, to $26.625.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 10 about New Jersey's death row misstated the name of a lawyer in some editions and referred incorrectly to his role in the legal appeals that led to the clearing and release of Raymond Kise, a prisoner condemned to death on murder charges. The lawyer is Paul Casteleiro, not Raymond Castiliero. He represented Mr. Kise throughout the five-year appeals process, not just for the retrial.

title: Floyd's Selective Damage
description: At the end of last week, after Hurricane Floyd had come and gone, most observers breathed a sigh of relief that the storm had not been as dangerous and damaging as predicted. But the good fortune that spared millions of residents along the Eastern seaboard did not shine equally on everyone. Streams and rivers in North Carolina and parts of Virginia and New Jersey began rising ominously, then jumped their banks, leaving thousands of people homeless, inundating entire towns, paralyzing commerce and causing damage that could run into the billions of dollars.

The National Economic and Social Development Board said the economy was on target to grow 3 percent to 4 percent this year, after contracting 10 percent in 1998, supported in part by increased government spending. The news helped send the Thai baht to a one-year low against the dollar.

title: A Soviet First Lady
description: When Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost began to allow the Soviet people to complain openly, his wife was one of the first targets of bitter, public debate. Raisa Gorbachev, who died of leukemia yesterday in Germany, was too glamorous to be a Soviet leader's wife, her people grumbled. She wore spiked heels and fox furs at a time when most women her age were standing for hours in Soviet bread lines. She was too arrogant, they groused, unwilling to keep her pedantry, as professor of Communist philosophy and sociology, safely confined to academia. Once, after she prodded her husband to say hello to a youngster who came to see the Soviet first couple, the citizenry reeled. This bit of wifely intervention, so normal for any political helpmate in America, brought a wave of visceral disapproval, even in a country that repeatedly issued empty proclamations about the equality of Soviet women.

title: HELP FOR BOND MARKET
description: South Korean banks and insurance companies responded to a weekend announcement by the Government of measures to prop up the sagging bond market. With contributions from local banks and insurance companies, the financial watchdog agency, the Financial Supervisory Commission, said it would form an $8.3 billion fund to stabilize the bond market. The fund will begin buying in the bond market next Monday. The commission said contributions to the fund were voluntary. It said the immediate goal is to attract capital, which has left investment trusts, back to the bond market. The ultimate goal is to lower long-term interest rates. Most of the funds will be channeled into corporate bonds.

title: A BUYER FOR EATON
description: Sears Canada Inc. agreed to pay $20.4 million for T. Eaton Company, the insolvent department store chain that for more than 100 years was Canada's best-known retailer. Under the deal, Sears Canada, which is 55 percent owned by Sears, Roebuck of Chicago, will take over leases on 8 stores and has options on 5 more among Eaton's 64 stores, and will retain about 1,000 of Eaton's 13,000 employees. The sale is subject to approval by shareholders, who may collect a few cents a share for shares that sold for as much as $10.20 just 15 months ago, and creditors, who are owed about $225 million. Liquidation sales are being held at all Eaton stores and operations are to cease by the end of November.

description: DUNN-Francis ''Frank'' Joseph, of Topsail Beach, NC died Saturday, September 18, 1999 at his residence. Mr. Dunn was born on April 26, 1939 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of the late Deputy Inspector Frank Dunn, NYPD, and Bernadette Kearns Dunn. He was an Institutional Stock Broker in New York City for twenty-five years. He served in the Army as a 1st Lieutenant with the 106th infantry. He was a devout Catholic and was a member of the St. Mary Gate of Heaven Catholic Church. He graduated from St. John's Prep in Brooklyn, NY and went on to graduate from Villanova University. He was a member of the Downtown Athletic Club, NYC and Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, NY. Mr. Dunn was an avid horseman and swimmer, loved Maritime History and had a great sense of humor. He was a truly good human being, adoring father and stepfather and ''the best husband in the world''. Surviving are his wife of eighteen years, Patricia McGinnis Dunn of the home; two daughters, Deirdre Dunn Haddad of Staten Island, NY and Alana Dunn of Newton, MA; two stepdaughters, Alicia Slook of San Diego, CA., and Jennifer Dames of Atlanta, GA; two step-sons, Peter Dames of Mimbres, N.M., and Mark Dames of Atlanta, GA; seven grandchildren; and one brother, William T. Dunn of Rumson, NJ. Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 10:00 A.M. Wednesday, September 22, 1999, at St. Mary Gate of Heaven Catholic Church, Surf City, with the Father Terrence Collins officiating. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Emma Anderson Memorial Chapel, 1100 S. Anderson Blvd., Topsail Island, NC 28445 or Pender East Rescue Squad, 16660 HWY 17, Hampstead, NC 28443 or St. Mary Gate of Heaven, 420 N. Topsail Drive, Topsail Island, N.C. 28445.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES AGREES TO BUY NICHOLS RESEARCH
description: Computer Sciences Corp. of El Segundo, Calif., agreed yesterday to buy Nichols Research Corp. of Huntsville, Ala., for about $391 million in stock to bolster its business in the government and health-care markets. Computer Sciences will pay about 0.423 share of its stock, or about 6.08 million shares in total, for Nichols. That is $27.20 a share based on Computer Sciences' closing price Friday, a 6.7 percent premium. It is the biggest acquisition this year for Computer Sciences, which also has bought several consulting and outsourcing companies to bolster its consulting operation. Nichols shares rose $18.75 cents, to $25.6875. Computer Sciences rose 8.75 cents, to $65.1875. Nichols supplies engineering and technical information and services to the Defense Department, health care groups and other businesses. It has about 3,000 employees in 30 locations in the United States and had revenue of $455 million in the year ended May 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEBEN, SIDNEY
description: ZWEBEN-Sidney, 90, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Lakewood, NJ, died Monday, September 20. Born August 22, 1909 in New York City, his family moved to Lakewood, NJ in 1921. He worked at his father's hotel and graduated from Lakewood High School as President of his class. With his loving wife, Jeannette, who passed away in 1966, he owned and operated The Dorset Hotel in Miami Beach, Florida (1946-1950); The Mayfair Hotel in Belmar, New Jersey (1951-1955), the LaReine Bradley Hotel in Bradley Beach, New Jersey (1956-1966); and The White House and Stanley Hotels in Lakewood, NJ (1954-1960). Mr. Zweben also owned and operated, with his sons, The Homestead Restaurant in Spring Lake Heights, NJ and Shadowbrook in Shrewsbury, NJ. Mr. Sidney Zweben served as the Magistrate of Lakewood, NJ for nineteen years from 1933-1952. From 1952-1956 he was Chairman of The Zoning Board. He served as Executive Director and President of The Lakewood Hotel Association in its ''heyday'', (1952-1962), as well as serving as President of B'Nai Brith and The Congregation Sons of Israel. He was the Chairman of The International Biddy Basketball Tournament and was responsible for the first tournament that turned a profit. In 1980 Mr. Zweben retired and became active in The March of Dimes, The Red Cross and Heart Fund. He retired to Florida in 1985 where he was President of Eastgate at Hunters Run for four years. He is survived by two sons, Sandy Zweben of Stuart, Florida; Robert Zweben of Holmdel, NJ; and by a daughter, Barbara Kernoff of Pampano Beach, Florida; eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Funeral service will be held at 2:30 today at Mt. Sinai Cemetery on East 7th Street, Lakewood. (Located next to Lakewood High School).

title: NORTON, SAINT-GOBAIN SUBSIDIARY, BUYING FURON
description: The Norton Company unit of the French industrial giant Compagnie de Saint-Gobain said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Furon Company, a polymer manufacturer based in Laguna Niguel, Calif., for $25.50 a share, or about $472 million. The transaction also includes the assumption of $116 million in debt and the purchase of $29 million in outstanding options. The companies said the acquisition price represents a 56 percent premium over Furon's Friday closing price of $16.31. Furon shares rose $8.8125, to $25.125. Furon had revenue of $238.7 million in the six months ended July 31. Norton, based in Worcester, Mass., manufactures abrasives, ceramics, plastics and chemical products. The combined company will have sales of $830 million and 5,500 employees, Norton said.
