In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Wolf Medical Education Fund, Brigham and Women's Hospital, 75 Francis Street, Boston, Massachusetts 02115.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, JAMES R.
description: CHERRY-James R. The NYU Community mourns the passing of its long-time member, James Cherry. He served this institution with distinction for more than thirty years as a member of the Medical Center Board of Trustees, the University's Board of Trustees, the NYU Institute of Fine Arts' Board of Trustees, and a past chairman of the Albert Gallatin Associates. He was a kind and generous man, and he will be greatly missed. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.N. Oratory: Pleas for Help, Pride in Democracy
description: Following are excerpts from five of the addresses given yesterday at the General Assembly :

title: In Defense of Lasik
description: To the Editor:

title: As Cashman's Star Fades, Newman Rises With Yanks
description: As Derek Jeter ascended through the minor leagues, his contact with Mark Newman was like that of student and principal. Jeter was learning how to play shortstop and hit, and Newman was among those responsible for his instruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, NANCY MANN
description: MURRAY-Nancy Mann. Died peacefully at home in her sleep on September 18, 1999. She is survived by her beloved husband, Edwards B. Murray; two daughters, Bettina Pyles Nelson of NY, and Courtney Pyles Kahn of San Francisco; a grandson, Alexander Pyles Nelson of St. Andrews, Scotland; and a brother, William H. Mann of Richmond, VA. She was the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Mann of Richmond. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, on Tuesday, September 21, at 2 PM. Burial will be in Richmond at Holly Wood Cemetery on Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. James' Church Spring Festival, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: MORE FREE NET SERVICE IN ITALY
description: Wind S.p.A., the Italian mobile phone company that began operations in March, signed an accord with Yahoo Italia to provide free access to the Internet, matching offers made by its larger rivals, Telecom Italia and Tiscali. Phone companies are promoting Internet use in an attempt to capture a share of Italy's rapidly expanding Internet market. In 1998 there were only 640,000 Internet users in Italy, but the number is expected to rise to 1.55 million by the end of 1999 and to more than 3 million by the end of 2000. Wind is 51 percent-owned by Enel S.p.A., Italy's 100 percent state-owned electricity company, with the rest split between Deutsche Telekom A.G. and France Telecom S.A.

title: Inactivity Is the Real Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan on Shaky Ground
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Even Beyond the Big Guys, A Wealth of Auction Choices
description: EBAY, Amazon.com and Yahoo are the 800-pound gorilla and two 400-pound siblings in the auction business, but there are hundreds of similar sites.

title: E-Commerce
description: The frenzy to start new businesses on the Internet has not resulted in big profits, but it has meant bargains for shrewd consumers, Saul Hansell reports.

title: Yankees And Nets Closing In On Merger
description: George Steinbrenner is expected to complete the merger of his Yankees with the Nets over the coming week, the first step in creating a regional sports and entertainment company and a financial windfall for the team owner.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: JIM McDERMOTT, Co-founder, Stamps.com
description: Actually, I've been using the Internet a lot lately to solve one of our largest relationship problems -- my complete dislike of shopping in malls. Deb, my fiancee, just gives me a list and a price range and I hit the Web. My favorites are: Macys.com, Williams Sonoma, Shopping.com and Bluemountainarts.com. I am considering a membership in Gentlehints .com, which allows users to send anonymous E-mails to alert employees, friends and family that they have bad breath, body odor, dandruff, etc.

title: Conde Nast Pays Woman Injured by Executive
description: Ever since he joined Conde Nast Publications as an advertising salesman, Richard D. Beckman has been known as a firebrand in the magazine industry, even earning the nickname Mad Dog. A hard-charging former rock promoter, he rose to the upper ranks of Conde Nast as publisher of GQ and now Vogue, and many regarded him as heir apparent to Steven T. Florio, the chief executive of Conde Nast.

title: Coming Soon to a Web Site Near You: A Simpler Sales Tax
description: IF you are hoping that the Internet will become a tax-free zone, dream on. Business leaders know that would distort the economy, creating an uneven playing field that would benefit some companies while damaging their competitors. Also, state and local governments are not about to concede a chunk of their single biggest source of revenue, sales and use taxes worth $189 billion last year.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: TAXES TO BE CUT
description: The Australian Government plans to cut business and capital gains taxes to make the nation more attractive to investors. The business tax rate will be cut by six percentage points, to 30 percent, on a par with Germany and below the United States, the Treasurer, Peter Costello, said. The Government will also cut the highest rate of capital gains tax for individuals by half, to 24 percent, and exempt United States and British investors from paying capital gains tax on venture funds.

title: Prospects Rise for Curbs on Cash-Balance Pension Plans
description: The fight over cash-balance pensions has moved to Congress, where lobbyists and Congressional aides say the dispute over I.B.M.'s pension switch will probably help spur legislation to rein in the plans.

title: For a Perky Do-It-Yourself Web Site, the Price Was Right
description: HAVING your own electronic commerce Web site does not have to be hard or expensive. I know, because I helped my friend Dave Wolff -- who runs a coffee shop but doesn't know from Java -- put his business on line, with lots of links and pictures and other bells and whistles, for next to nothing. Since then, the price has gone down. And Dave still doesn't even own a working computer.

title: Metro Business; Bestfoods Acquisition
description: Bestfoods said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Case Swayne Inc., a sauces and seasonings company with annual sales of about $150 million.

title: Trouble in Paris? Ducasse Says No
description: Alain Ducasse, the only chef with two restaurants given top ratings of three stars by the Michelin Guide, said today that there was no truth to persistent rumors that his Paris restaurant was losing money and that he might have to move it from the posh Hotel Le Parc on the Avenue Raymond Poincare.

title: High-End Leather, Low-End Labor; Handbag Workers Embroiled in Bitter Contract Dispute
description: By nearly all accounts, the last year has been a great one for Kate Spade, the handbag designer of choice for chic girls at private schools on the Upper East Side and ladies who lunch at Barneys.

title: An Advertising Power, but Just What Does Doubleclick Do?
description: LOU DOBBS seemed like an alien on a very strange planet. Carefully coiffed and immaculately pinstriped, the former CNN newsman stood ready to pitch his new Web site, Space.com, to a sea of goatees and unpressed jeans -- the sales force at Doubleclick Inc. Most weren't born when man set foot on the moon, yet they were eager to ask him about space -- the advertising kind.

title: THE FINE PRINT: The Military Spending Bill; Senate Leader Presses Navy On a Ship It Does Not Want
description: Congress is about to break its self-imposed spending limits again. To help understand why, consider the LHD-8.

title: Harlem Homeowners Exult at Neighborhood Prison's Closing
description: Parkside Correctional Facility, for years scorned by many of its Harlem neighbors, is officially a prison no more. By the end of the day yesterday, all of its inmates had been moved out, and soon the staff will be transferred as well.

title: $64 Million Earned From Pay-Per-View
description: The world welterweight championship bout between Felix Trinidad and Oscar De La Hoya in Las Vegas, Nev., on Saturday night generated $64 million in pay-per-view revenue, a record for a nonheavyweight fight.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: 3Com Earnings Exceed Wall St. Estimates
description: The 3Com Corporation reported first-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street estimates, a result the company attributed to strong growth in hand-held computing products and improved operating efficiency.

title: Scoop on an Owner's Deal Raises Issue of Favoritism
description: The featured article in the first issue of The Daily Deal, American Lawyer Media Inc.'s new journal for the world of mergers and acquisitions, broke the news that the Voice-stream Wireless Corporation was ''in the midst of negotiating a new acquisition.'' It added that ''analysts agree that Aerial Communications is the likeliest candidate.''

title: Latest Hit on Campus: Crescendo in E-Major
description: WHEN it comes to offering degrees, the halls of academia are not immune to fashion. Colleges and universities bank on blue-blazer classics like history and philosophy. But they also like to try what's hot every now and then.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvest of Discontent; Low Cranberry Prices Shake Farmers' Faith in Ocean Spray
description: Cranberries have been good to Betty Brown's family for generations. Her grandfather staked out cranberry bogs here on the sandy shoulder of Cape Cod in the 1930's, and now Mrs. Brown and three of her cousins farm the land they are in the process of buying from their parents.

title: Maggert Cannot Hide His Confidence
description: Jeff Maggert raised eyebrows today when asked about possible Ryder Cup pairings.

title: Exiting Stanford, Noting Many Challenges Ahead
description: When Gerhard Casper, a German-born constitutional lawyer, was tapped seven years ago to be president of Stanford University, people at the Palo Alto campus were skeptical. He had a degree from Yale, the Gothic antithesis of sun-dappled Stanford, and once taught at Stanford's hated rival, the University of California at Berkeley.

title: NAOMI NARI NAM, 14-year-old 1999 U.S. Figure Skating Championship Silver Medalist
description: CDNow (www.cdnow.com) and Music Boulevard (www.music boulevard.com) -- I download the music of the Backstreet Boys, 'N Sync and Britney Spears. I also look up classical music for my skating programs.If I'm looking for something, I can track it down to see whether it's sold there and go right there instead of going to every single store.

title: CARTER BREY, Principal Cellist, New York Philharmonic
description: Frank Music Company (www.frankmusiccompany.com) -- The Frank Music Company is to New York City musicians what the Louisville Slugger Company is to baseball players. Life would be conceivable without it, but why bother?

title: In the First Act, Jones Takes the Lead Role
description: The Braves entered the series one game ahead of the Mets, but well behind the image of invincibility they had constructed during the decade. As their disabled list began to look like a social registry for baseball players, the Braves had struggled to hold off the Mets in a frantic race for the division lead. When Chipper Jones stepped to the plate in the eighth inning the lead of the National League East rested on his bat.

title: Bush Announces Initiative on Gun Crime
description: Less than a week after the fatal shootings in a Fort Worth church prompted scrutiny of his record on gun control, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today announced a two-year, $1.6-million program to improve prosecution of gun-related crimes in the state.

title: Yemenis' Khat Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi Awarded Pet Food Accounts
description: The Iams Company, the pet food maker in Dayton, Ohio, and its new parent, the Procter & Gamble Company, said yesterday they had awarded the worldwide accounts of the Iams and Eukanuba brands of dog and cat food to Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

title: GLENN LOWRY, Director, Museum of Modern Art
description: Audible.com (www.audible.com) -- They have thousands of books and lectures that you can download to your computer for a fee, or you can acquire a device that lets you download the stuff and listen to it like books on tape. You can delete it after you're done listening to it.

title: All the President's Quips: Levity at the White House
description: With politics on television ranging all the way from the staid to the raucous, from C-Span to Geraldo Rivera's verbal equivalent of chair-tossing, ''The West Wing'' should occupy a plummy central location, where entertainment and politics meet. Aaron Sorkin's idea for a series set behind the scenes at the White House predates the Lewinsky scandal, but should benefit from its fallout. Saturation coverage has made Washington intrigue almost as familiar as ''Entertainment Tonight'' and its many clones have made the box-office grosses and inner workings of Hollywood. If politics has crept closer to entertainment, why not an entertaining show about politics?

title: Make a Quick Purchase. Wait for the Delivery Man.
description: IT'S a fitting paradox for the on-line age that Internet shoppers can order up a virtual storm in minutes but have to wait days to get the goods. Buying on line, no matter how fast and convenient, still means relying on, and paying for, snail mail.

title: Kosovo Rebel Leader Basking In Warmth of Deal's Reception
description: As NATO and United Nations officials released details about the force that will replace the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army, the guerrillas quietly congratulated themselves today on winning the deal they wanted.

title: TLC ADOPTS MEASURE TO THWART HOSTILE TAKEOVER BIDS
description: TLC-The Laser Center, an operator of eye-surgery clinics, adopted a measure yesterday aimed at thwarting unwanted takeovers after the stock lost more than half its value in the last two months. The plan, subject to stockholders' approval, will make a hostile acquisition prohibitively expensive by flooding the market with new shares if anyone acquires more than 20 percent of company shares without the board's permission. TLC said it was not aware of any bids being planned. Shares of TLC, based in Mississauga, Ontario, fell 18.75 cents on Nasdaq yesterday, to $24.5625.

title: Should Disney Decide the Status of Jerusalem?
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO BANK OVERHAUL
description: Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria of Mexico announced stringent regulations to strengthen domestic banks. Under the plan, to be phased in over the next few years, banks must increase their reserves as a cushion against unpaid debts and will not be permitted to invest in businesses unrelated to banking. The measures were announced as Mexican banks were beginning to show signs of recovery from the peso devaluation nearly five years ago, which led to extensive defaults on bank loans and a Government bailout of the banking system that cost about $50 billion. Rick Wills

title: DIANE VON FURSTENBERG, Fashion designer
description: Google.com (www.google.com) -- It's not officially out, but this is simply a great search engine. It's quick. It's fun to use. I want to check on a movie, read about an actor, find out who directed a particular film, this is where I look. It is very clever.

title: HarperCollins Cuts 74 Jobs at Morrow Books
description: More than two months after formally acquiring the publisher William Morrow & Company, HarperCollins announced a series of moves yesterday to consolidate its imprints, resulting in layoffs of 74 employees and the departure of top executives from Morrow.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Welcomed in Timor

title: LEAP WIRELESS IS IN 2 DEALS FOR EQUIPMENT AND SERVICES
description: Leap Wireless International, the phone service provider spun off from Qualcomm Inc. last year, rose as much as 38 percent yesterday after it said it would buy $660 million in wireless equipment and services from Lucent Technologies Inc. and Ericsson A.B. Leap rose $5.375, to $22.875. Earlier, the shares touched $24.0625. The San Diego-based company said it would pay the phone equipment makers $330 million each for gear to expand its Cricket Communications wireless service, which provides local phone service at flat rates in Tennessee.

title: Brosius Back With Yankees
description: Scott Brosius pulled his pinstriped uniform pants down to his ankles after returning to the Yankees last night, eschewing the routine of wearing his pants above his thigh to show more of his blue stirrups. He had worn his pants like an old-timer to give his father something to focus on.

title: Serving Up Enough Refinement, Genuine and Bogus, to Please a King
description: Hybrid creations like the comedie-ballet ''Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme,'' with text by Moliere, music by Lully and choreography by Pierre Beauchamp, are by their nature difficult to stage, let alone revive at a distance of three centuries. So fanciers of Baroque music, theater and dance must have thrilled to the news in Lincoln Center's preseason announcement that the great revivalist William Christie and Les Arts Florissants, from Paris, would be presenting the work in November.

title: It's Five Years and Counting In a School Board Standoff
description: If the teachers' union and the administration of a small special education district here were a married couple, they would have cut their losses, divorced and gone their ways long ago. But the laws of tenure -- and the sheer stubbornness that sometimes characterizes union and management relations -- seem to be more durable than the bonds of marriage.

title: Should Disney Decide the Status of Jerusalem?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Internet Beginner Learns as She Goes
description: THOUSANDS of Americans are leaving established jobs or working in their spare time to turn an idea into an on-line business. Last spring, Suzanne Richie joined their ranks, quitting her job as a photo editor at The New York Times. She spoke from her home in Woodstock, N.Y., first in June, as her preparations were moving into high gear.

title: Tahia Carioca, 79, Dies; A Renowned Belly Dancer
description: Tahia Carioca, the Egyptian belly dancer often called the Marilyn Monroe of the Arab world, died of a heart attack in a Cairo hospital on Monday. She was 79.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., owner and operator of energy operations worldwide, agreed to buy a 77 percent stake in Grupo Companhia Paulista de Energia Electrica, Sao Paolo, a group of power companies in southern Brazil, for $85 million in cash.

title: S.I. Hospital Sets Payback Of $45 Million
description: Staten Island University Hospital has agreed to reimburse the state Medicaid program $45 million for improper bills it submitted over a five-year period, state officials said yesterday.

title: End of an Odd Couple Jolts Hollywood's Talent Agents
description: Hollywood partnerships, like Hollywood marriages, often don't survive the high-pressure strains they're subject to. Michael Ovitz and Ron Meyer, once best friends who helped found the Creative Artists Agency, barely speak. Jeffrey Katzenberg, formerly of Disney, and Michael Eisner loathe each other. Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer's successful producing partnership was virtually over even before Mr. Simpson died after years of drug abuse. And Bob Daly and Terry Semel, a successful and enduring partnership that ran Warner Brothers, left the studio two months ago and may now go their separate ways.

title: Damnation's New Face Is No Easier to Take
description: To the Editor:

title: Reconsidering the Radish: New Ways to Tame Its Bite
description: RADISHES have been cultivated for so long that they actually predate written history. By the time Confucius wrote about them in the fifth century B.C., they were a staple crop in Asia.

title: Scientists Detect Encephalitis at 2 Connecticut Sites
description: State scientists said tonight that they had found the potentially deadly St. Louis encephalitis in mosquitoes trapped at a country club here and in a crow from a backyard in Westport. Greenwich officials immediately said they planned to restrict outdoor activities from 5 P.M. to dawn, including youth football and soccer practices.

title: Untangling the Grocery Web
description: WHEN I was a child, my mother used to phone the green grocer in the morning and read her shopping list to him. The groceries would arrive that afternoon, and my mother would tip the delivery boy a nickel (it was a long time ago). She paid the bill once a month.

title: In Brazil, Big Bank, Big Portal
description: BRAZIL'S 165 million people know the name Bradesco well: it belongs to the nation's largest bank. But now the company has used its considerable power to create Latin America's most comprehensive electronic commerce site at www.bradesco.com.br/comercio, which brings together more than 60 cyberstores. That number is expected to double in the next few months.

title: Rescuers Sift Rubble of Taiwan's Cities
description: With the death toll from the devastating earthquake on Tuesday rising by the hour, rescuers worked through the day and night to reach thousands of people still trapped inside the rubble of toppled buildings and houses across the island.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Hip Gather and the Food Is Fun
description: POP is a funny name for a restaurant. It's a happy sound without much sense. It could be the noise of a Champagne cork, a fizzy soft drink, the deadpan, all-encompassing cool of Andy Warhol, or the artful synthesis of styles that translates into a catchy tune.

title: 5 Hyundai Group Executives Indicted
description: Prosecutors indicted one of the most prominent figures in South Korea's securities industry today, as well as four other executives of the nation's largest business group.

title: GTE TO SELL NEBRASKA PHONE LINES TO CITIZENS UTILITIES
description: The GTE Corporation, which is being acquired by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, agreed to sell its 58,723 phone lines in Nebraska to the closely held Citizens Utilities Corporation for $204 million as it sheds slower-growing businesses. As part of the transaction, which includes 37 telephone exchanges, 72 GTE employees will be offered jobs with Citizens. Earlier this year, Citizens, based in Stamford, Conn., agreed to buy 186,839 GTE lines in Arizona, California and Minnesota. GTE plans to sell as many as 1.6 million lines and has agreements that cover about 1.4 million lines in 11 states.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on Monday about the formation of an on-line music company, Myplay, misstated the name of a venture capital firm that is backing it. The firm is Integral Capital Partners, not Interval Capital.

title: Once a Secret, Now a Disaster Area
description: On the day that Patrick and Bettina DeCaumette got married at their art gallery three years ago, this small community on the banks of the Raritan River happened to be holding its annual parade to honor its volunteer firefighters. So caught up did the couple become in the joint festivities that they hopped into one of the fire trucks as the parade made its way down Main Street.

title: Federal Agency Chief Tours Regions Ravaged by Floods
description: James Lee Witt, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, toured flood-ravaged sites here and in Ossining, N.Y., today, appealing to flood victims to register for the Government's programs of loans and grants.

title: Venture Planned for Wireless Internet Link
description: Expanding from cable modems to the airwaves, the Excite@Home Corporation announced a venture yesterday with Airflash Inc., a small private company based in Redwood City, Calif., to deliver Internet information using wireless links.

title: The Next Big Thing That Just Wasn't
description: In 1997 electronica was belatedly discovered by the mainstream music business and hastily touted as the next big thing. Despite a few novelty hits, it wasn't. Yet that suits the music just fine, putting it back in the clutches of people who care about it. There are plenty of them; throughout the CMJ Music Marathon, appearances by electronica's big names drew wall-to-wall crowds.

title: For Asian-Americans, a New Political Resolve
description: As the chairman of Al Gore's Presidential campaign, Tony Coelho routinely meets with wealthy Democratic fund-raisers to offer encouragement and listen to their views. But these feel-good pep talks are rarely as blunt or as riveting as the one held with about two dozen Asian-Americans here late one afternoon last month.

title: AMAR GOEL, Chief Executive, Chipshot.com, a golfing-gear site
description: Amazon.com (www. amazon.com) -- I shop at Amazon.com because they've got good selection and I like the user reviews. While I think they could improve their community a lot, the user reviews definitely help me decide if a book is worth getting. And the ease of use of one-click ordering is unparalleled. One-click ordering is way underrated.

title: Corrections
description: The credits yesterday with a television review of ''Seeking Solutions With Hedrick Smith'' on PBS misstated the day of the broadcast. As noted in the review, it is tonight; it was not last night.

title: European Allies to Spend More on Weapons
description: NATO defense ministers, meeting for the first time since the end of the Kosovo air war, agreed today that the European members of the alliance have to spend far more money on modern arms and equipment to carry their share of the responsibility in war.

title: What's Your Bid on Peanut Butter? Groceries Join Big Items on a Name-Your-Price Web Site
description: Priceline.com Inc., an on-line bidding site for big-ticket purchases like airline tickets and automobiles, plans to begin offering consumers in the New York area cut-rate prices on groceries like applesauce and cereal.

title: Metro Business; Aerospace Unit To Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: United Technologies Corporation, owner of one of the world's top aircraft-engine makers, says it will eliminate 1,500 jobs at its Hamilton Sundstrand unit by the end of next year to cut costs after its purchase of Sundstrand Corporation in June.

title: On-Line Trading Changes Landscape for Old-Line Brokerage Firms
description: LAST year, John (Launny) Steffens, the vice chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, gave a speech at a computer trade show, warning of the financial risks of zealously trading stocks over the Internet. In March, he started doing it himself.

title: One-Stop Site Offers Menorahs and Mates
description: FEEL like greeting Rosh ha-Shanah with a blast from a rabbinically approved shofar, made by Israeli hands from the horn of an Israeli ram? Would you like to share this iconic experience with a new special someone, preferably young, Jewish and open to prospects of marriage?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: Metro Business; Publisher Consolidates
description: HarperCollins Publishers said yesterday that it had restructured and consolidated its operations, combining William Morrow, Avon Books and HarperCollins into one publisher.

title: Modern Wins Ruling on Art Seizure
description: Almost two years after two paintings by Egon Schiele, looted by the Nazis, arrived in the United States from Austria for a three-month exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, New York's highest court ruled yesterday that a grand jury subpoena keeping the works here while their ownership is investigated is invalid.

title: Hewlett-Packard Is in Deal To Lift Its Internet Presence
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, long a laggard behind Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. in computer systems for electronic commerce, took a step toward strengthening its Internet presence with the announcement today of a deal with the Oracle Corporation to collaborate on developing and selling Oracle's electronic commerce software on Hewlett-Packard computers.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ripe Target for Web Retailers, Teens Keep Heading to the Mall
description: TIM GEISENHEIMER, a computer savvy 15-year-old, has read most of the books of Iain Banks, the British novelist. But some of the surreal tales by the author are difficult to find in the United States. So a few months ago, the adolescent New Yorker checked in with Amazon.com, ordered what he wanted from England and paid for it with his mother's credit card. He gave his mother, Susan, cash when she received her statement. But she was aghast to discover the cost because the two paperbacks were shipped by air freight.

title: Taiwan's Chip Plants Left Idle by Earthquake
description: The earthquake that shook Taiwan has also shaken up the global semiconductor industry.

title: A Feeding Frenzy Made for Consumers
description: IT'S hard not to look at all the money being made on Internet stocks and wonder, ''How do I get my share?'' Well, you could bet your life savings on a company started by teen-agers that has never had a dime of profit, with a stock that seems to follow the course of the Coney Island Cyclone. Or maybe you could dust off that recipe that was always such a big hit at the bake sale, open SuperFudgeBrownies.com, and then sell stock to all your friends on the P.T.A.

title: Protest Over Princeton's New Ethics Professor
description: Demonstrators opposed to Princeton's hiring of Peter Singer, who has written in support of euthanasia for some disabled infants and is the university's first professor of bioethics, protested his inaugural day of teaching yesterday by chaining themselves to the administration building.

title: CALENDAR
description: Who Was That Ladle?

title: In a Legal Gray Area, Blackjack Is a Click Away
description: KEVIN LACEY, a 41-year-old architect, was no gambler. He had never even been to Las Vegas, Nev. But when he saw a magazine advertisement about playing blackjack on the Internet, he was intrigued.

title: Brunson Re-signed
description: The Knicks re-signed the free-agent guard Rick Brunson, who played sparingly after joining the team last January. Brunson, 27, played in 17 games, averaging 5.6 minutes of action. Contract terms were not announced.

title: Drug Agency Approves Antibiotic
description: With drug-resistant bacteria on the rise, doctors have watched helplessly as patients died from germs that cannot be cured by vancomycin, long considered the antibiotic of last resort. Today, the Food and Drug Administration approved a new antibiotic that promises to rescue some patients when vancomycin fails.

title: New York Divorces Going Back 7 Years Tainted by Bribery
description: For $10 a case and up, prosecutors say, the top clerk of the Manhattan matrimonial court routinely rushed divorce cases through the court, no questions asked -- including cases in which husbands forged wives' signatures to win uncontested divorces.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Builder Chooses Victoria's Secret Over High-Rise
description: Real estate developers in prime Manhattan neighborhoods almost always think big, no matter how small the parcel. An available lot, especially on the thriving West Side, usually becomes home to a high-rise co-op or condominium, or perhaps to an office building for a company willing to pay millions for a prime address.

title: The Harm in Wine Markups
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Politics Of Inequality
description: If anything is a truism in American politics, it is that people do not care about income inequality. And as most such truisms eventually are, this one may be about to be contradicted.

title: Lingering Hazards Cover Carolina's Sea of Trouble
description: There were whitecaps on the water rushing through the lobby of the Best Western Riverview Hotel -- a name that no longer signifies a choice location -- but Fire Chief Greg Smith noticed something even more ominous floating behind the building this afternoon: a large tank of liquid propane, about to break loose from its moorings.

title: Deluxe Dilemma: To Sell Globally or Sell Haughtily?
description: CLICK on Gucci.com and what do you get? A Web site under construction. Point that browser toward Prada.com? There is a picture of a smoldering model, but no handbags are available for purchase. Perhaps, you think, a dress from Christian Dior.com? Oh, you crazy fool-for-fashion you.

title: A Question of Rebuilding Houses on the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: East Timorese, First Wary, Then Jubilant, Greet U.N. Troops in Village Near Capital
description: Panic seized the refugees in this mountain hideout this morning. Soldiers were coming. Screaming and scrambling, the refugees tumbled down the hillside seeking safety.

title: Venezuelan Leader Pledges Payment of All Debts
description: In an effort to reassure foreign investors, Venezuela's President said yesterday that his Government would make all its debt payments while at the same time work on a market-friendly proposal that would allow it to pay off its current debt over a longer period of time.

title: The Plight of the Ph.D.
description: To the Editor:

title: Ladies And Gentlemen, The Roast Chicken
description: AS a diner in search of the extraordinary at Lespinasse, you could easily overlook it on the menu. But it is there, poulet roti a la broche, chicken roasted on a spit, without pretense and without apology.

title: Buy Here, and We'll Tell You What You Like
description: HOLLYWOOD agents, literary agents, real estate agents, travel agents -- now meet Internet agents.

title: Damnation's New Face Is No Easier to Take
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDERSEN CONSULTING'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE IS RESIGNING
description: Andersen Consulting said George Shaheen, its chief executive, was leaving to join an unidentified Internet company. Executives of the management consulting firm have started a search to replace Mr. Shaheen. John T. Kelly, a worldwide managing partner for the firm's North and South America practice, will act as interim chief. Andersen Consulting is trying to separate from its accounting partner, Arthur Andersen. They are a part of Andersen Worldwide.

title: At Cornell, a Vintage Study of Behavior
description: An official-looking man with a note pad greets cars at the Delaware state line: ''I'm sorry, but Delaware is closed. We have too many people. I'm afraid I can't let you in.'' Drivers obediently turn back.

title: Memories of Tentacles Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Raise Intervention Abilities, Clinton Urges U.N. Members
description: President Clinton today urged other members of the United Nations to strengthen their collective capacity for intervening to prevent the kinds of mass killings and ethnic repression that ravaged Kosovo and East Timor, saying that there are limits to what individual nations can accomplish.

title: Immigrants From Taiwan and the Mainland Unite to Show Concern
description: Surrounded by spools of brightly colored thread, Ling Li and a half dozen other Taiwan women sat around a table yesterday, trying to watch as their teacher demonstrated the day's project. But the women, students enrolled in a traditional macrame class at the Taiwan Center in Flushing, Queens, had other things on their mind.

title: Bankruptcy Bill Is Blocked In Fight Over Minimum Pay
description: Trying to force a vote on a measure to increase the minimum wage, Democratic senators today blocked Republican legislation to revamp Federal bankruptcy laws, at least for the time being.

title: SUPERMARKET PROFIT UP 20%
description: Britain's largest supermarket chain, Tesco P.L.C., reported that profit rose 20 percent, to 274 million [pounds] ($401 million), in the first half of the year as sales rose. The company is in a deep price-cutting campaign as it tries to fend off Asda Group P.L.C., the British supermarket chain that Wal-Mart Stores Inc. acquired in June. In Britain, Tesco's sales rose 7.3 percent, to 8.3 billion [pounds], while sales at Tesco's European stores rose 18 percent, to 633 million [pounds].

title: Medicare H.M.O.'s to End Free Drugs, Report Says
description: The Clinton Administration said today that health maintenance organizations would no longer provide free drug coverage to any Medicare recipients next year, and White House officials expressed alarm about the trend toward fewer benefits and higher prices.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES SALE OF ANTIBIOTIC FROM RHONE-POULENC
description: The United States subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's No. 1 drug maker, won approval from the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to sell Synercid, a new antibiotic billed as a promising weapon against drug-resistant infections. The drug is the first approved to treat Enterococcus faecium infections that do not respond to the current drug of last resort, Vancomycin made by Eli Lilly & Company. Tom Brakel, a Mehta Partners analyst, said the drug could bring $250 million a year in peak sales, though Synercid could be challenged by antibiotics from the Warner-Lambert Company and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, which are awaiting F.D.A. action.

title: National News Briefs; Clinton Declines Offer To Give Scholarly Talk
description: Bowing to protests, the White House announced today that President Clinton had declined an invitation to give the annual Jefferson Lecture, an honor usually given by the National Endowment for the Humanities to one of the nation's leading scholars.

title: Confronting Police Misconduct; A Tough Challenge in New Jersey
description: Correcting the long history of racial discrimination in the New Jersey State Police will take more than the appointment of a new superintendent. But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has made a positive move by nominating Carson Dunbar, an administrator in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, to lead the troubled department.

title: Weary Floridians Endure New Storm, a Tame One
description: As Floridians asked themselves how anyone could be all that afraid of a tropical storm named Harvey, people in the southern tip of the state wearily endured this latest bout with bad weather with more impatience than trepidation.

title: Rutgers Suspends 5 Players, Including Its Top Rusher
description: The Rutgers football team's head coach, Terry Shea, suspended five players yesterday, including the leading rusher, Jacki Crooks, for Saturday's Big East Conference opening game against Boston College, citing undisclosed violations of team rules.

title: Should Disney Decide the Status of Jerusalem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Letters on Commutations
description: Following are excerpts from two letters about President Clinton's commutation of prison sentences of Puerto Rican nationalists. The first is a draft of a letter that was not sent after being written by aides to the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh. The second is a letter dated today from Mr. Clinton to Representative Henry A. Waxman.

title: Hopes to Find A Compromise For Iraq Fade At the U.N.
description: Hopes faded today that the Security Council could agree this week on a new approach to Iraq, with the United States and Russia still far apart on how to monitor Iraqi weapons programs and on when -- or if -- to begin lifting sanctions.

title: A New Hangout on the Block
description: THOUGH READY TO EAT, a takeout shop in Greenwich Village, opened its doors just six weeks ago, customers already behave like old friends.''We're an institution,'' said Judy Schiff, a co-owner with Stephen Hoerz. ''It's like we've always been here.''

title: MALAYSIA TAX RELIEF
description: Responding to appeals by foreign fund managers, Malaysia's central bank eliminated a two-tier tax on stock market gains by foreigners that had resulted in a 30 percent tax on profits of investments held less than one year. Instead, all profits by foreign investors will be taxed at 10 percent regardless of how long the stocks are held.

title: GOODRICH SAYS IT WILL EARN LESS THAN EXPECTED FOR YEAR
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said it would earn less than expected this year because rising oil prices are hurting its chemicals business and litigation has driven up the cost of buying the aircraft-parts maker Coltec Industries. Goodrich, the No. 1 American maker of aircraft landing gear, said it would have per-share earnings this year of $3.20 to $3.30. The company was expected to earn $3.50 a share in 1999. Goodrich's restated 1998 earnings were $346.3 million, or $3.07 a share. The company said in November that it would buy Coltec for $2.2 billion. Allied Signal Inc. sued to block the move, which caused Goodrich to incur unexpected legal fees and delayed the transaction's completion by four months. Shares of Goodrich fell $1.125 yesterday, to $29.875.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Federal investigation into possible money laundering at the Bank of New York referred incorrectly to Leonid Dayachenko, a son-in-law of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. He is not an influential political adviser to Mr. Yeltsin; that is Mr. Dayachenko's wife, Tatyana, who is Mr. Yeltsin's daughter.

title: Goldman Earnings Strong For Its First Public Quarter
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. reported surprisingly strong earnings yesterday in its first full quarter as a public company, a striking reversal from a year ago when fallout from Russia's economic woes forced the firm to postpone plans for its initial public offering of stock.

title: STEVEN PINKER, Cognitive Neuroscientist, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
description: Amazon.com (www.amazon.com) -- Originally I scoffed at the idea that on-line shopping would significantly change people's buying habits -- ''People like the social experience of shopping; they like to browse books and come across surprises; they like the look and feel of books, etc.'' -- until I actually bought something on line. Now, most of my book and CD shopping, I am ashamed to say, is on line.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD SOARS. Gold jumped after the Bank of England auctioned 25 metric tons of bullion at prices that were unexpectedly above market rates. Gold for December delivery rose 2.35 percent, or $6, to $261.80 an ounce.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Morrells to Add Wine Bar At Rockefeller Center Site

title: Man Emerges, Still Breathing, After E-Cave Confinement
description: AS humanity moves to the 21st-century method of grocery shopping -- over the Internet -- I see key limitations of old-style, walk-in markets. For one thing, they never told me that the banana is considered an herb because it lacks woody tissue.

title: Major Indexes Hit by Selloff; Dow Plunges 225.43 Points
description: Stock prices were pummeled yesterday, pulled down by a further slide in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen, warnings about third-quarter earnings and worries about the earthquake in Taiwan.

title: Freud Could Be the Key to the Giants' Season
description: If these Giants are happy, it's likely that they will soon be miserable.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: An Ode to Austria

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: One Man's Siberia
description: To the Editor:

title: Condolences And an Offer Of Support To 'Province'
description: Saying that the people of China and Taiwan are ''as closely linked as flesh and blood,'' President Jiang Zemin of China offered condolences and aid to Taiwan's earthquake victims today in a statement issued by the Foreign Ministry.

title: FRENCH-GERMAN STRENGTH
description: Europe's two biggest economies provided more evidence of accelerating growth, with exports booming and German business confidence climbing sharply. In Germany, a widely watched monthly survey of business confidence by the IFO Institute for Economic Research jumped nearly two percentage points in August, more than many economists had expected. In France, the Government reported that exports surged 4.5 percent in July, fueled in part by rising sales of Airbus planes.

title: Click Here for a Few Well-Chosen Words
description: THE Irish have long been known for their gift of gab, so perhaps it is not surprising that one of the E-commerce pioneers here is a one-woman shop that offers a few suitable words on any subject for any occasion for anyone, anywhere in the world.

title: He's 19, Skilled and Maybe N.H.L. Pioneer
description: Scott Gomez is so good skating with the puck, passing and scoring that he has some members of the Devils raving about his abilities. Gomez almost made the Devils last season as an 18-year-old. His chances have increased as his skills and maturity on the ice have improved, along with his physical strength.

title: Digital Dressing Rooms And Other New Twists
description: THE Internet has become a giant laboratory for new technologies intended to bring shoppers and sellers closer together, and consumers will encounter a much improved environment when they go shopping on line this fall. As befits a marketplace based on technology, electronic retailers, or E-tailers, as they are known, are hurling technological solutions against many of the most common criticisms of Internet commerce.

title: Japan Bank Clings to Monetary Policy
description: The Japanese central bank voted today to leave monetary policy unchanged, defying Government officials and economists here and abroad who have been demanding that the bank take aggressive steps to reverse the yen's heady rise in value.

title: Profit Almost Doubles at Pepsi Bottling
description: Pepsi Bottling Group Inc., the largest bottler of Pepsi soft drinks, said its third-quarter profit more than doubled as it raised prices on sodas.

title: Moynihan to Endorse Bradley, Favoring Friend Over the Vice President
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the four-term Democrat from New York, will endorse former Senator Bill Bradley for President tomorrow in New York City, potentially providing Mr. Bradley a lift in the state's crucial primary and among independent Democrats across the country.

title: What Sex Sites Can Teach Everyone Else
description: WHERE can an E-business struggling to fend off rising competition turn for a model of how to make money on the Web? To the entrepreneurs who were the first to make E-commerce pay and whose businesses are still the most profitable sector of the Internet: the on-line pornographers.

title: Two Home Runs Add To Solid Case for M.V.P.
description: News usually travels quickly in baseball. If somebody's assistant general manager is interviewed for someone else's general manager's job, the word goes hurtling through the game's unofficial network of officials and scouts. If a young phenom is suddenly found to have trouble hitting breaking balls, he might as well head for the minors yesterday because the scouts record it in their notebooks and instantly spread the word on the network.

title: Journalist Killed in a Still Unsettled East Timor
description: A Dutch journalist working for the Christian Science Monitor and the Financial Times was killed here on Tuesday, apparently by armed men who pursued his motorbike from a rogue checkpoint, witnesses said today.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Insurance Woes and Memories of Manicured Lawns
description: Michael Martone, veins popping at his temples, was shouting into the telephone in the corner of his ruined auto repair shop. ''Inside nothing is left; outside nothing is left,'' he sputtered to a sweet-voiced but not-very-helpful insurance agent. ''The cars washed into the river. In the office there's no files, no nothing.

title: Treasury Chief Defends U.S. Aid to Russia, but Calls for Safeguards
description: Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers today vigorously defended the Clinton Administration's policy of supporting aid to Russia, but warned that the Russian central bank had to comply with safeguards to maintain American backing for assistance.

title: Reformers Party On
description: Perhaps it is the sober nature of the upcoming Presidential race that allows the Reform Party to suddenly seem less about reform and more about party. The dean of Reformers wears a boa to his wrestling gig. One possible candidate wonders in print why Americans fought Hitler, another made a name for himself building casinos designed to rival the Taj Mahal, and then there is the glamorous Hollywood movie star who seems oddly somber in comparison.

title: For Chicken, A Quick Trick For Roasting
description: ROAST chicken is one of the most basic dishes in home cooking, but most cooks have problems with it. Indeed, there are a couple of very real challenges: You need high heat to brown the skin, but superhigh heat may burn it. You need to cook the thighs and legs through before the breast dries out.

title: Taiwan's Strict Codes Reflect California's Rules
description: Both Turkey and Taiwan have effectively adopted the California building requirements for earthquakes, which are intended to enable occupants to get out alive in a major earthquake even if the structure is rendered unusable, American experts said today. The difference is in enforcement.

title: Anybody in There? Sites Strain To Build In Customer Service
description: CUSTOMER service is the key to business success on the Web. That is the conclusion of a growing number of experts in the field of electronic commerce. ''Too many businesses think that it is enough to throw up a Web site and the money will start rolling in,'' said Craig Settles, the president of Successful.com, a consulting company in Oakland, Calif., and the author of ''Maximizing Your Business Online'' (ABS Group). ''But keeping the customer happy is what generates repeat business.''

title: Direct Marketers Find Some Familiar Ground
description: BEFORE there was anything electronic about commerce, there were companies selling goods directly to retail customers who could neither touch their purchases nor see those from whom they were buying -- the same businesses filling mailboxes with catalogues day after day. The catalogue companies pioneered innovations like database marketing, relationship marketing and advertising accountability.

title: Corrections
description: A picture and caption with the Guide column in the Long Island section on Sunday, about the pop band 10,000 Maniacs, were outdated. The band's concert scheduled for Friday night at the Inter-Media Art Center in Huntington has been canceled.

title: Present at the Creation (but Too Embarrassed to Admit It)
description: BACK before there was a dot-com on every bus and the word Internet could stir an Elvis-caliber frenzy in the hearts and minds of investors, I saw the light of the coming interactive revolution in the television control room at Silver Cup Studios in Queens. It was in the form of a roll-on personal waxer, which we sold on a shopping channel called Q2.

title: Kofi Annan's Critique
description: This century's last General Assembly debate at the United Nations opens as a U.N.-sanctioned peacekeeping force lands in East Timor. The timing is appropriate, because the U.N.'s role in conflicts around the world is perhaps the most important -- and most complex -- issue facing the institution today. Secretary General Kofi Annan made U.N. intervention the subject of a provocative opening speech on Monday. It should focus attention on a growing consensus that the world cannot simply watch mass slaughter when effective action is possible to prevent or stop future Kosovos and East Timors.

title: Singapore Expected to Sign New Contract to Buy Natural Gas From Indonesia
description: SINGAPORE  Despite the East Timor crisis and political uncertainty in Indonesia, Singapore is expected to sign a new long-term contract Wednesday for a supply of Indonesian natural gas estimated to be worth $7 billion.

title: Business Travel; Fliers may have missed it, but the nation's airlines have pledged to improve their customer service.
description: BECAUSE concern about Hurricane Floyd crowded out much other news last week, few people appear to have noticed that the nation's airlines filed with the Transportation Department their pledges to improve customer service.

title: From Poussin to Capon, a Chicken in Every Size
description: YOU don't have to be a farmer to know that chickens come in various sizes. Even cooks who know these birds as only plastic-wrapped packages in the supermarket can distinguish a three-pound broiler from an eight-pound roaster.

title: A Little Civility, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Arguments Are Offered in Microsoft Case
description: Almost a year after it began, the Microsoft antitrust trial wound to a close today with final arguments from lawyers for the company and the Government that ranged from scornful to contemptuous of the other side's case.

title: A Winery Owner Reinvents Himself Again
description: AGUSTIN HUNEEUS was between jobs, and enjoying it thoroughly. He had just sold Franciscan Estates, his Napa Valley winery, for $220 million to Canandaigua Brands, an upstate New York wine and spirits conglomerate. And once again, he was about to embark on a new career.

title: Only Jets' Record (0-2) Is the Same as Last Year
description: The Jets go back to work today in worse shape after two games -- statistically and physically -- than at any comparable point in the Bill Parcells regime.

title: Take My Name, Please! Just About Everybody Else Is Using It.
description: IN today's marketing-crazed world, your name is your fortune. It is also your Web site, television program, candy bar, fragrance and corporate logo. Easy work for Oprah, Sting, Martha Stewart or Puff Daddy and old news for Prince, who has moved on from a regal title, preferring iconic status.

title: MIAMI
description: Dolphins punter Brent Bartholomew may miss the rest of the season after suffering a knee injury in Sunday's 19-16 victory over Arizona. Bartholomew tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee in the third quarter and is expected to need surgery. Miami's sixth-round draft choice in the 1999 draft, Bartholomew averaged 44 yards on seven punts before the injury. The Dolphins will bring in punters for tryouts this week.

title: On Many Travel Web Sites, a Limited View of the Beaten Path
description: AMID great fanfare, 9,800 independent travel agencies joined together earlier this year to set up a new Internet site called Vacation.com. They billed it as ''the leading source of active, fun vacations on the Web.'' Users presumably could find whatever vacation opportunities they might crave.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about allegations of irregularities in a New Haven election for alderman referred imprecisely to an action taken by Isaiah Wilner, the editor of The Yale Daily News. Mr. Wilner, who had campaigned for the winning candidate, has removed himself from the daily operation of the newspaper pending the resolution of a legal challenge of the election result. But he has not resigned as editor; he is continuing his administrative duties at The News, and retaining editorial control over its other publications.

title: A. K. Haldenstein, 74, Broker And Devotee of Brownstones
description: Austin K. Haldenstein, a real estate broker whose enthusiasm for brownstones helped start New York City's town house revival, died on Monday at a nursing home in Rye, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 74.

title: Crucial Victory Is Secured by Pettitte
description: The infamous right-center-field bleachers at Yankee Stadium were almost empty last night as fewer than 100 people paid $7 to sit in soggy seats and watch the best team in the American League play. It was a blustery night, and the rain that had fallen throughout the day put the game between the Yankees and the White Sox in peril.

title: Habibie Defends Entry of Foreign Troops
description: Disliked at home, discredited abroad and discounted by virtually everyone, President B. J. Habibie trudged into Parliament today to explain his allowing foreign troops in East Timor.

title: Executive Privilege vs. Our Right to Know
description: President Clinton's former counsel, Charles Ruff, says that he did not consider New York politics when he made his recommendation to the President concerning clemency for members of the F.A.L.N.

title: New Job for Ex-President of Big Bank
description: David Coulter, who quit as president of the BankAmerica Corporation a year ago after it posted a surprise loss, was hired by the Beacon Group, a private equity and merger firm, to run its West Coast business.

title: Drugstores Scramble to Find Choice Corners in Cyberspace
description: NOW that the big pharmacy chains seem to have built facing drugstores at every intersection in America, the competition to sell aspirin, shampoo and antibiotics is moving onto the Internet just as aggressively.

title: G.O.P. Says $72 Million for Clinton Trips Goes Too Far
description: Releasing a report showing that President Clinton's travels to Africa, China and Chile had cost the Government $72.1 million, the Senate's third-ranking Republican today accused the President of traveling overseas to an extent that was ''almost abusive of the right and the privilege and the responsibility'' of his office.

title: Frank Wagner, 77, Director and Choreographer
description: Frank Wagner, a director and choreographer who worked in theater, dance and television, died on Sept. 12 in the Health Park Care Center in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 77 and lived on Sanibel Island, Fla.

title: Damnation's New Face Is No Easier to Take
description: To the Editor:

title: Can It Be?Venerable Eton Takes a Tumble From Its Lofty Tower
description: WINDSOR, England  When Alan Clark, the calculatingly outrageous Conservative politician who died just over two weeks ago, was asked about his days at Eton, he replied that they were remarkably useful, providing him with "an early introduction to human cruelty, treachery, and physical hardship."

title: What Price Will Be Paid By Those Not on the Net?
description: THE latest Federal survey of who is using the Internet presented some sobering results. The ''digital divide'' is widening, the Commerce Department said in July, and the gap is on its way to becoming a ''racial ravine.''

title: Israel's Premier Is First State Visitor to 'Berlin Republic'
description: Accompanied by survivors of a Nazi concentration camp, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel arrived in Berlin today on the first state visit to the German capital since the Government moved here last month.

title: Connections That Are Fast, Faster, Fastest (and Even Faster)
description: JUST how many times can you watch the comets streak by the Netscape logo as the download goes on and on and on before you run out of the house screaming and go to the mall instead?

title: Accounts
description: * Expressautoparts.com, New York, to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, to handle the first account of the on-line auto parts retailer. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

title: Deal to Create Biggest U.S. Wireless Network
description: The ink is barely dry on the agreement, but already the newest entrant in the nation's cellular phone wars is emerging as a formidable competitor.

title: What Web Retailers Really Need Is a Whole Lot of Shelf Space
description: IN a clever advertising campaign promoting itself as ''Earth's biggest bookstore,'' Amazon.com emissaries were portrayed earlier this year as searching for storage space in famously huge places like the Pyramids, the Taj Mahal and even the planet Mars. But about the same time, in the real world, the company was quietly settling into an anonymous-looking warehouse about 30 miles east of here.

title: A Fork in the Road Ahead
description: As a two-sport athlete, with one of the sports outside his university, Michigan's Drew Henson has more leverage than most sophomore quarterbacks. But he does not plan to use it to force his coach, Lloyd Carr, to choose him as the starter.

title: Ford in Pact With Canada's Auto Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company reached a tentative, three-year contract this evening with the union representing its Canadian workers, three hours before a threatened strike at midnight.

title: The On-Line Consumer? Tough, Impatient and Gone in an Blink
description: FOR generations, American shoppers have been passive, long-suffering creatures, dutifully absorbing every whim and fancy that merchandisers cared to throw their way.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Closing the Doors To the Thin Cats

title: Rallies in 20 Towns Ask Milosevic's Ouster
description: In a modest beginning to a campaign by a divided opposition to oust the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, tens of thousands of people attended rallies in some 20 Serbian towns this evening, hearing pleas to keep marching until Mr. Milosevic goes.

title: FOUNDER AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF PEOPLESOFT STEPS DOWN
description: Peoplesoft Inc., a maker of business-management software that has been struggling to lift revenue, said yesterday that its founder, David Duffield, had stepped down as chief executive and would be succeeded by the president, Craig Conway. The move was expected when Mr. Conway joined the company in May. Mr. Duffield, 58, will remain chairman. Shares of Peoplesoft, which is based in Pleasanton, Calif., have plunged 44 percent in the last year on investor concern that corporations are delaying software purchases to fix Year 2000 computer problems. Peoplesoft shares were unchanged at $17.375 yesterday.

title: DANCE NOTES
description: Exit a Troupe, Enter Another

title: For This Supplier, the Sum of Its Parts Adds Up to Success
description: PEOPLE looking for fast-paced, cutting-edge careers tend not to think about manufacturing valves, maintenance products and replacement parts for industry. Even less exciting would be cataloguing and distributing such mundane wares, which is how W. W. Grainger Inc. makes a living.

title: Top Rider Banned For Eight Months
description: McLain Ward, the 1998 American Grand Prix Assocation rider of the year, was given an eight month suspension from international horse sports on Monday. after the Judicial Committee of the Federation Equestre Internationale, the world-wide governing body of equestrian sports, found the 23-year-old horseman from Brewster, N.Y., guilty of abuse of the horse.

title: Alcohol Bureau Chief Resigns After Drunken Driving Arrest
description: The director of New Jersey's Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control resigned today, two days after he was arrested on charges of driving while intoxicated, according to state officials.

title: Justice Dept. Plans Tobacco Suit Seeking Billions in Health Costs
description: The Justice Department is about to file a civil suit against the tobacco industry, seeking to recover billions of dollars in health-related expenses that cigarette smoking has cost over the decades, a Government official said tonight.

title: Some Surprises From Southern Italy
description: I SPENT a substantial portion of Labor Day weekend cooking from ''Regional Foods of Southern Italy'' by Marlena de Blasi (Viking, $28.95) but could have devoted a week to it. Both the evocative text and the recipes promise much and deliver more.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Flux in Pop Music Has a Distinctly Download Beat to It
description: A LOT of words have been used to describe David Bowie, but ''conventional'' is not one of them. So it is probably not too surprising that yesterday Mr. Bowie released his latest album -- ''hours . . .'' -- not in record stores but on the Internet. Just download in Liquid Audio or Microsoft Audio 4.0.

title: Mexico City Journal; The Billboard War: Were Lingerie Ads Selling Sex?
description: Anna Fusoni Ponthier, a television executive, was driving home from work along one of Mexico City's major thoroughfares in May when she saw a towering billboard photograph of a blond model, clad only in bra and panties, promoting a line of lingerie.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a fire on 42d Street near Seventh Avenue misstated the site. The fire was confined to an underground electrical transformer; it never spread to the basement of the nearby Reuters Building, which is under construction.

title: Can Defendants Cry 'E-Sanctuary' and Escape the Courts?
description: THE prosecution of Kevin Jay Lipsitz, who was accused of trying to peddle magazine subscriptions from Staten Island, would have been a garden-variety consumer fraud case. But because it involved the Internet, it has become a watershed.

title: TRADE DEFICIT RISE PROVOKES CONCERN OF RISK TO DOLLAR
description: Another leap in the United States trade deficit in July fueled fears today that the continuing surge in imports was threatening the health of the dollar.

title: New Leader Picked for Buffeted Suffolk Republican Party
description: Suffolk County Republicans tonight elected Anthony Apollaro, who for the last eight years has served as a troubleshooter and deputy for County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, as the new leader of their troubled party.

title: A Misuse of Auditors
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Bradley Bandwagon, the Doctor Is In
description: ERNESTINE SCHLANT grew up in the Bavarian city of Passau, where the Jews had all disappeared by the time she was 7 and one did not speak of the forced labor camp down the road. Her father was in the Luftwaffe -- although not, she says, in the Nazi party -- at the same time that she was bringing tea to the wounded German soldiers whose hospital had taken over her school.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I was a child, my mother made lunch boxes that were the envy of my friends, mostly because they always included a homemade cookie, often these butterscotch cashew bars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Growth in Trade Deficit Prompts Concern for Dollar

title: The Upper West Side Has Something to Samba About
description: BOSSA NOVA was in the air the other night at Viva Brasil, where a piano player segued effortlessly from ''Misty'' to ''The Wave,'' imbuing the handsome paneled dining room with the light, flowing rhythms that have so often drawn pairs of lips together. A hostess swayed past a table that had just ordered another round of caipirinhas, those sweet but potent cocktails, which are made of fresh lime juice, sugar and cachaca, a sugar-cane liquor.

title: Woods Hopes He's at His Best Against Best
description: When Tiger Woods's approach shot landed on the first green this morning, a cheer went up from the large gallery.

title: 3 Brothers, 4 Months, 1 Fortune In an Early Success in Germany
description: SITTING at a makeshift confer ence table a white table top supported by cardboard boxes -- in the Spartan Berlin headquarters of Ebay Germany, the 26-year-old chief executive, Oliver Samwer, can barely contain his excitement as he outlines his company's spectacular and, in Germany right now, singular success story.

title: Pork With a Pedigree
description: LAST week, for only the second time in my life, I tasted pork so delicious it needed no seasoning beyond salt and pepper. Both times the meat was superior heirloom pork, suffused with a bright, clean flavor, with none of the unpleasant aftertaste pork often has. Not coincidentally, both pieces came from pigs raised in a manner vastly different from that of ordinary supermarket pork.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; A Family and a Newspaper Entwined

title: Long Island Lab May Do Studies Of Bioterrorism

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nasdaq, Once Hot for a Public Issue, Now Heading Private

title: BCE UNIT IN $160 MILLION DEAL FOR 2 CANADIAN COMPANIES
description: BCE Emergis Inc., a Canadian developer of payment systems and other products for electronic commerce, agreed to buy two closely held companies for $235 million (Canadian), or $160 million (United States), in cash and stock to strengthen its position in health care and financial services. The unit of BCE Inc., Canada's biggest telecommunications company, will acquire the SNS/Assure Corporation and Assure Health Inc., both based in Toronto. BCE Emergis said the purchases would add $50 million (Canadian) in revenue in 2000 and aid cash flow.

title: Night of the Living Bid: Four Tales From an Hour of Ebay

An auction on Ebay was minutes from closing, and Mr. Clayberg wanted to be the final bidder. Over the last month and a half, he had perfected his strategy, a nimble mix of patience, quick clicking and good timing.

title: A Faster Way Of Shuffling The Data Cards

In the wake of the latest Israeli-Palestinian agreement there are several reasons to be just a tad optimistic about the prospects for a final settlement. I could go down the whole list, but the most exciting thing is the silence -- the deafening silence with which the silent majorities in both Israel and the Arab world have embraced this latest deal.

title: Corrections

description: Air Canada rejected a hostile takeover proposal today from the Onex Corporation, a conglomerate that wants to merge Air Canada with its weak rival, Canadian Airlines International.

Five years ago Roddy Doyle caused an uproar with a hard-hitting television series called ''Family'' that portrayed domestic violence and alcoholism among the Irish working classes. ''Even my old teachers' union complained that I had a teacher striking a child,'' he recalled. ''But I'm fairly convinced that if 'Family' were broadcast tonight, it wouldn't cause half the fuss that it did in 1994.''

It should be no surprise, then, to learn that the global marketplace that has sprung up on the World Wide Web has drawn its share of crooks.

title: Confronting Police Misconduct; Corruption Inquiry in Los Angeles
description: An expanding corruption scandal in the Los Angeles Police Department bodes ill for a city where residents in poor minority communities have long complained of police arrogance and brutality. A dozen officers have been suspended in an investigation that has produced allegations of breathtaking misconduct. The scandal widened into public view when one former officer, Rafael Perez, agreed to cooperate with authorities in exchange for a lighter sentence on his conviction for stealing cocaine from a police evidence locker.

description: Minutes from the Bank of England's meeting on Sept. 8 that raised interest rates after a string of cuts disclosed that the panel voted 7 to 2 for the raise. Two committee members, Sushil Wadhwani and DeAnne Julius, dissented, arguing that an increase might slow growth. The increased division reflected in the minutes led some economists and analysts to speculate that another rate increase might come soon. Andrew Ross Sorkin

The look is definitely bold and graphic. ''Aliens, thunderbolts and bull's-eyes are on backgrounds of brilliant oranges, apple greens and electric blues,'' Ms. Verin said. ''They're the canvases of young artists.''

The companies will then sell 22 of the properties to a group led by GE Capital Canada Inc. for $216 million (Canadian). Most of the office buildings, processing and operations centers, including the bank's gold-flecked headquarters building in downtown Toronto, are in Ontario. Royal Bank said it would lease back all the space it occupies.

title: Girls Soak Up Technology in Schools of Their Own
description: ONE morning soon after the start of the school year in Teri Putnam's sixth-grade math class at the Julia Morgan School for Girls here, each student took a turn at the white board, explaining how she had arrived at the answer to a tricky problem. Ms. Putnam invited others to chime in, and nearly all of them did. No one stopped to raise her hand, and the discussion became a lively yet well-mannered free-for-all.

Then came money-laundering investigations in the United States and Europe that have implicated high-ranking Kremlin officials. And in a two-week period, five terrorist bombings in Moscow and two other cities have left hundreds dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, ELIZABETH
description: PORTER - Elizabeth Berrien Krauss Dyer. After a prolonged illness, passed away quietly in the presence of her family at Black Rock Farm, Watertown, Connecticut, where she had resided at the home of her son, Richard H. Dyer Jr., M.D., and her grandchildren Sean and Amy Dawson, and Richard H. Dyer III. Born April 9, 1912 in Chatham, New Jersey, she was the first of two daughters born to the late Fletcher Irvin Krauss and Margaret Price Berrien. Mrs. Porter attended Kent Place School in Summit, New Jersey and Sarah Lawrence College. She was a direct descendant of John Berrien, former colonial governor of New Jersey. She studied art at the New York Central School of Art. Later, as a member of the Association of Interior Designers, Mrs. ''Betty'' Porter became a respected interior designer, and painted creatively in many medias, first in Chatham, New Jersey, and subsequently in Siesta Key, Florida and Tryon, North Carolina. She married Richard H. Dyer of Summit, New Jersey with whom she has two children, Patricia Jean Dyer (Kesselring) of Rochester, New York, and Richard H. Dyer Jr., M.D., of Watertown, CT. She later married Mr. Ralph C. Porter, Jr. also of Summit, New Jersey. She is survived by her sister Mrs. Robert B. Lee (nee Ruth Berrien Krauss) of Greenville, South Carolina, her daughter Patricia Jean Dyer Kesselring, her son, Richard H. Dyer, Jr., M.D., her step-children Ralph (Robin) C. Porter of Wickford, Rhode Island, James M. Porter of Mendham, New Jersey, and several grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces and nephews. She was pre-deceased byher third stepson, David S. Porter. A memorial service will be held by the family at Fairmont Cemetery, Chatham, NJ, 11:00 AM, October 16th. Remembrances can be made to the American Red Cross.

title: CITY NATIONAL TO BUY PACIFIC BANK FOR $153 MILLION
description: The City National Corporation, a Southern California bank holding company, agreed to buy Pacific Bank for $153 million in cash and stock to enter Northern California markets. City National, based in Beverly Hills, will pay $29 for each Pacific Bank share, half in cash and half in stock. That is a 42 percent premium to Pacific Bank's closing price on Tuesday. Pacific Bank, with 292 employees, has $728 million in assets and 12 offices, including branches in Hong Kong and the Cayman Islands. City National, with $6.7 billion in assets, expects the acquisition to add to earnings next year if it closes in the first quarter.

description: Brazil's state-controlled oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro S.A., said exploratory drilling off the southeastern coast had tapped into a field with the potential to produce 700 million barrels of oil worth roughly $10 billion. The discovery in the 2.5-mile-deep Santos basin could allow Brazil to become self-sufficient in its petroleum needs within six years, according to Government estimates. The announcement of the find came after Brazil said it was considering restricting imports of oil and other products from neighboring Argentina. Simon Romero

title: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS DECLINES
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell to its smallest level in six months in August, as consumers and companies bought more imports and export earnings fell. The surplus narrowed 23.6 percent to 941.6 billion yen ($8.9 billion), seasonally adjusted, in August from July, the Ministry of Finance said. Imports jumped 7.9 percent, and exports fell 1.5 percent. The surplus shrank 22.6 percent, to 689.4 billion yen, from a year earlier. The surge in imports is the latest sign that demand is rising and underpinning economic growth. The stronger yen is making imports cheaper, though it may already be starting to erode export earnings.

description: Jason Sehorn was finally practicing today with the first-string defense at Giants Stadium, and from 200 miles or more away -- across four states -- Drew Bledsoe felt the impact. Tibet has ''uplifted rock, flowing ice,'' said Raveevarn Choksombatchai. So, she designed Folded Plate, right, with Ralph Nelson, her partner at Loom in Berkeley, Calif. The shares closed at $45.1875 on volume of 9.5 million shares. That would give the company, with its 25.8 million shares outstanding, a market value of more than $1.1 billion. These choice titles are embargoed. In this fall season, less than one month old, there have already been four interesting examples.

title: Bashing John McCain
description: Senator John McCain is a conservative Republican who favors tax cuts and opposes abortions and most gun controls. So why are right-wing groups like Americans for Tax Reform, the National Rifle Association, the American Conservative Union and the Christian Coalition saying terrible things about him? The answer is that Mr. McCain is pushing for a ban on unregulated ''soft money'' donations to political parties. These groups would not be affected by Mr. McCain's legislation, but the Republican Party is urging them to line up against it and help keep wavering Republican senators in line.

In 1980, Muji (the full name, Mujirushi Ryohin, means ''No Brand Goods'') opened its first store in Tokyo. Now, there are 260 stores, most in Japan, with 12 in England and 2 in Paris. The aluminum cart, above, is 17 by 17 inches and 15 1/2 inches high ($135); a version 29 1/2 inches long is $195. Prices include shipping to the 48 contiguous states. The site is www.mujionline.com.

description: I.B.M. agreed yesterday to buy the Internet-security company Dascom Inc. for an undisclosed price to strengthen its on-line commerce business. Dascom, a closely held company with about 100 employees that is based in Santa Cruz, Calif., develops technology to help businesses safely connect computer systems to the Internet. ''Security has been at the forefront of the discussion about E-commerce,'' said Megan Graham-Hackett, an analyst at S.& P. Equity Group who rates I.B.M. a ''buy.'' She added: ''It's definitely an area where they need to own that technology. They've probably discovered that.''

description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's biggest Internet equipment maker, agreed yesterday to buy Webline Communications for $325 million in stock to offer more on-line products that help businesses streamline operations. Webline, a closely held company with 120 employees in Burlington, Mass., makes equipment that allows users to work together or shop together over the Internet. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., is seeking to offer packages of services and products to compete with companies like I.B.M. for businesses with high-end computers and on-line services.
