title: CHEMDEX SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF PROMEDIX PURCHASE
description: Shares of the Chemdex Corporation, which sells laboratory chemicals and equipment on the Internet, rose 16 percent after it said it would buy the closely held Promedix.com for about $388.7 million in stock to begin selling medical products to hospitals. Shares of Chemdex, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose $4.50, to $32.125, increasing the value of the purchase by more than $50 million. The company, which went public in July, will pay 12.1 million shares for Promedix.com., which is based in Salt Lake City.

title: BOEING WINS BIG ORDER FROM HAWAIIAN AIRLINES
description: The Boeing Company, the world's biggest aircraft maker, won a $430 million order yesterday for at least 13 of its 717 jetliners from Hawaiian Airlines Inc. in the first sale of the 100-seat plane this year. Hawaiian Airlines also took options for seven more 717's, which it plans to use on short routes among Hawaii's islands. The jets will replace older McDonnell Douglas DC-9 aircraft, saving $200 million in operating expenses over 10 years, Hawaiian said. The order is an important boost for the 717, a derivative of the DC-9 that Boeing inherited in its purchase of McDonnell Douglas. It has struggled with slow sales, winning only 115 firm orders until yesterday in more than four years on the market.

title: Study Finds Shortcomings In Care for Chronically Ill

But a new study suggests the burden is greatest when the death is due to chronic illnesses like heart and lung disease, perhaps because society has paid disproportionate attention to people who die of cancer.

title: Art and Computers Meld at the Met As Geeks Now Perform With Tenors

There the tenors still wear velvet capes, swear vengeance and sing their arias without any help from electronics. But backstage, even the Met has accepted the microchip. The hydraulic elevators, rigging and old-fashioned electromechanical systems in use since the Met opened its doors at Lincoln Center in 1966 are gradually being joined by their digital counterparts.

title: SPRINT PCS TO BUY MOTOROLA PHONES FOR $250 MILLION
description: Sprint PCS, the wireless division of the long-distance carrier the Sprint Corporation, will buy more than $250 million worth of Motorola Inc.'s new digital wireless phones for its wireless Internet service. Motorola will provide phones like its new Startac model that let customers use Sprint PCS's digital wireless network to make calls and access the Internet, as well as make analog-signal calls in areas the digital network does not cover. The network serves 4,000 United States cities and communities and has licenses to offer its service to 270 million people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, LOUIS E.
description: ALLEN-Louis E., 81, of New York City and Floral Park, New York, passed away on September 21, 1999. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and brother. He is survived by his loving wife, Harriet; daughter, Amy; son, Andrew; granddaughter, Emily; grandson, Paul; daughter-in-law, Beverly; sister, Betty; brothers Harry and Morris; and his sisters-in-law, many nieces and nephews. Lou served his country during World War II and was a past Grandmaster of the Masons. Lou, along with his sister, Jessie, and brother, Sam, created Housner Co. stationery and printing, which has operated since the early days of the New York City garment district. His friends in business knew him as ''Mr. Housner.'' Famous for his quick attention and service, nothing was too hard for Lou. His work ethic and loyalty were always admired. After his retirement, Lou participated in his community through theatrical activities and later at functions for the Senior Center in Floral Park. Lou was always a gentleman of deeds. His actions in helping others always spoke volumes. He will be greatly missed by everyone he has touched. Services will be held at 12 PM, Thursday, September 23, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffers, Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. For further information, please call 718-263-7600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, STEPHEN B.
description: PECK-Stephen B., 70, was born in Zurich, Switzerland, June 21, 1929 to Sam and Lydia Peck. A resident of Destin, Florida since 1994, he passed away surrounded by his family on Sunday, September 19, 1999, at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas. Stephen is survived by his wife of fourteen years, Sue Peck; son, Michael, and Roser Peck, and their daughters Tatiana and Alexia; son, Thomas, and Meg Peck and their children, Austin, Julia, and Chloe; step-children, Jerry & Lynda Harrison; stepchildren, Charles & Susan de Boisblanc and their children Joshua and Kristin; step-children, Darren & Jana Ebanks and their daughter Jillian; and his beloved dog, Murphy. Stephen graduated from Columbia University and served as an Army officer in the Korean War. Later, he became an entrepreneur starting a number of environmental consulting and technology companies in the North East. Prior to his retirement in 1994, he served as the Mid-Atlantic Regional Manager for the Okonite Company. From 1995 to his passing, Stephen served as an active Director on the boards of Washington Cable Supply Incorporated, and Michael A. Peck Associates, Incorporated. Stephen was very active in several leading Internet online forums. In lieu of flowers and in line with his interest in defending our natural environment, a fund has been created in Stephen's memory to plant an oak tree with an inscription at the Jesse H. Jones International Rotary House (part of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center) where Stephen received such excellent personal support and friendship during his final months. Contributions can be made to the following address: Stephen B. Peck Memorial Fund, c/o M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Attn: Nan Duhon, Box 541, 1550 Holcombe Blvd., Houston, Texas 77030-9989. Phone: 713-794-5966.

President Clinton will need to answer these contentions, as they form the core of law enforcement objections to his act of mercy.

The city, which had a population of 1.2 million in 1990, is ancient. The oldest site is Prague Castle, started in the ninth century and shown at top in a 15th-century woodcut by Michael Wolgemuth and Wilhelm Pleydenwurff. At the Old Town Square, left, the Catholics executed Protestant aristocrats in 1620. One of the most recent and controversial buildings is Ginger and Fred, right, with one tower leaning flirtatiously against the other, designed in 1996 by Vlado Milunic and Frank O. Gehry.

Despite lagging sales for much of the decade, the company said it might have turned a corner, albeit a slight one: sales in stores that have been open longer than a year rose 1 percent in the first seven weeks of the second half of the year. Laura Ashley is in the midst of a major redesign of its stores, a move analysts hope will revive sales.

title: A Treasure Trove of Eames Fabrics
description: Charles and Ray Eames, the midcentury modernists, created chairs of molded plywood, Fiberglas and wire; kept an octopus in their office in Pacific Palisades, Calif., and watched it feed on hermit crabs -- and designed textiles. Five of the designs, done as drawings and collages in the 1940's and 50's, have been reinterpreted by Maharam, a fabric company in Hauppauge, N.Y. The upholstery fabrics -- Dot Pattern and Small Dot Pattern (below left), Circles (inset, below) and Kites and Crosspatch (not shown) -- will be in ''The Work of Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of Invention,'' a show of more than 500 artifacts, opening Oct. 12 at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. In 1947, the Eameses designed Dot Pattern, shown with Ray (above), for the Museum of Modern Art's ''Competition of Printed Textiles.'' Mary Murphy, director of design at Maharam, who worked with Lucia Eames (Charles's daughter) on the fabrics, calls them graphic and honest. They will be available to the trade next year in cotton and polyester or rayon and polyester, for $63 a yard. Information: (800) 645-3943.

title: Tobacco Becomes a Federal Case

That has left the Clinton Administration no choice but to seek change through the courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, J. HAROLD
description: GARFUNKEL-J. Harold, 93, on Sept 21, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Florence Rubin Garfunkel, cherished father of Marjorie Baker Bachrach and Robert Lee Bachrach and Deborah G. Bloch and Robert W. Bloch; adored grandfather of Jeffrey M. Bachrach, Alexandra Bloch Jeydel and the late Clifford Bachrach; loving great grandfather of Adam, Daniel and Eric; dear brother of Florence Roswell and Julian Garfunkel and the late Esther Gottesman, Elsie Gottesman and Mildred Levy. Mr. Garfunkel, retired President of J.H. Garfunkel & Co., originally a textile firm founded in 1892 and for the past forty years a private investment company, was a pioneer in mental health rehabilitation. In the latter capacity he was instrumental in the establishment of programs for shifting the intake from tuberculars to the mentally ill, thus establishing sheltered workshops for them. He was a longtime trustee and officer of Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services, an agency of the former Federation of Jewish Philanthropies now UJA-Federation, of which he was a Life Trustee. He was a founder of Overing House, a half-way house for the mentally ill. Mr. Garfunkel was a Founding Member of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism in 1922, the Jewish Reconstructionist Foundation in 1940 and in 1968 the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College. Born in New York City, Mr. Garfunkel was educated at Townsend Harris High School and New York University. Friends may call only at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St Wednesday, Sept. 22nd from 7:30 9:30 P.M. Funeral service will be held Thursday Sept 23rd at 2 P.M. at funeral home. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to UJA-Federation, 130 East 59 St., New York, New York 10022.

title: A Pilgrimage on Behalf of Chimpanzees
description: O.K., we're going to see what Jane Goodall has been up to lately, and at first you may find it a little icky-poo.

title: CIGNA BOLSTERS STOCK-BUYBACK PLAN BY $2 BILLION
description: The Cigna Corporation, the giant health insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, said yesterday that it had increased its stock-repurchase program by $2 billion. Since the start of the year, Cigna has repurchased 17.1 million shares of stock at a cost of $1.5 billion. A further $2 billion buyback would represent 11 percent of the company's $17.8 billion market capitalization. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding.

title: More Trouble With Rebates
description: To the Editor:

title: New Executive At ABC Television
description: Chris Moseley, a well-known cable television executive, has been named executive vice president for marketing at the ABC Television Network in New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Mum, Dad and Not Always So Merry Old England
description: ETHEL & ERNEST

title: Silicon Valley Research Laboratory Is Changing Its Direction
description: A Silicon Valley research laboratory, established seven years ago to leapfrog generations of computer technologies, is taking a narrower direction that reflects the changing interests of the Microsoft co-founder who financed it.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about a proposal by Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux to acquire Trigen Energy misstated the plan's status. While Suez has made the offer, there has not yet been an agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, JAMES R.
description: CHERRY-James R. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and the Israel Museum, Jerusalem, are deeply saddened by the death of their friend Jim Cherry. As a Trustee of the Billy Rose Foundation, Jim Cherry helped foster the growth of the Israel Museum for three decades. He will be sorely missed. Our condolences to his family and to his fellow trustees. Teddy Kollek, President, I.M. Judy Steinhardt, Pres., A.F.I.M.

title: Dole Emphasizes Strict School Discipline
description: Weighing in on an issue where rivals for the White House had staked out positions weeks ago, Elizabeth Dole today proposed streamlining the Federal Government's role in education by giving states and local districts the power to determine how Federal money should be spent and academic targets met.

title: Parks Chief Says Permits Rarely Needed
description: The New York City Parks and Recreation Department's review of its rules governing the use of public parks has set off a groundswell of criticism over a little-noticed and rarely enforced requirement that large groups must obtain permits before holding events.

title: Barriers to College
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Hungry Minds.com, San Francisco, to the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, a unit of True North Communications, to handle the first account of the Web-based continuing-education service. Billings are estimated at $10 million.

title: Hazardous NASA Site?
description: To the Editor:

title: Scalpel Precision
description: Eberhard Hagmann's industrial ceramic knives are harder than steel, never need sharpening and slice effortlessly. In 1989, Mr. Hagmann, the managing director of Ad Hoc, a manufacturer of household products in Mannheim, Germany, began designing the knives, which are similar to ones used for surgery. Introduced in the United States this year, the knives are breakable only if dropped on a hard surface. ''In the end, it's still ceramic,'' Sabine Graef, a sales manager at Ad Hoc, said. A seven-and-a-half-inch knife is $85; a nine-and-a-half-inch knife is $108 at the MOMA Design Store, 44 West 53d Street, or www.momastore.org.

title: In the Pilots Seat
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: State Dept. Expert Upbeat About Russian Fund Case
description: With President Clinton's top Russia expert testifying today before his toughest critic in the Senate about accusations of Russian corruption and possible American complicity, the advance billing promised a dramatic confrontation.

title: Now Starring: A Picasso Nude
description: The art collection most intensely sought after by both Christie's and Sotheby's this season was that of Madeleine Haas Russell, one of San Francisco's most important philanthropists, who died at 84 in April. After months of discussions with both auction houses, the executors chose Christie's. Since the resolution was made just as the catalogue for Christie's important 20th-century sale on Nov. 9 was going to press, Christie's decided to present the collection in its own special catalogue, which features a group of 12 paintings, sculptures and drawings by such artists as Picasso and Matisse. Experts at the auction house estimate that the collection -- which will be sold with other works of 20th-century art -- should fetch $50 million.

title: It's Youth vs. Seniority In a Delaware Race
description: It may be one of the smallest states, but Delaware seems likely to be the site of one of Election 2000's biggest Congressional battles.

title: Worse Odds Than Roulette: Buying Trump Casino Stock
description: DONALD TRUMP, the latest would-be Presidential candidate, was bragging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, ILSE
description: WINKLER-Ilse. Beloved wife of the late Harry, devoted mother of Bea and Mitchell Bayer, Henry and Stacey Winkler, loving grandmother of Cheryl and Jordan, Lauren and Frank, Jed, Alison and Jonathan, Zoe, Max, great-grandmother of Jake and Ben, dear sister of Jean Adra. Service 11:15 today at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to Sisterhood of Congregation Habonim, 44 W. 66 St., NYC 10023 would be appreciated.

title: London Law Firm Is Target Of Russia Banking Inquiry
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office is looking into a now-defunct London law firm for clues to the genesis of the Russian money movements through the Bank of New York that are now under Federal investigation, according to officials with knowledge of the investigation.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cutting Through Cynicism in Art Furor
description: So the culture wars continue unabated, tragedy long ago having turned to farce. This time Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is playing the role of stern dad to a group of British artists whom he seems to regard as naughty teen-agers.

title: Milken-Supported Libel Suit Against a Writer Is Dismissed
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan dismissed a $35 million libel lawsuit yesterday against the best-selling author James B. Stewart that had been pursued for seven years and had been subsidized in part by the brother of the fallen junk bond investment banker, Michael R. Milken.

title: Young Woman, Older Man (But There's More to It)
description: Audrey Wells's ''Guinevere'' is the affectionately told story of an impressionable 21-year-old who grows up under the sexual and intellectual tutelage of an older man. Ms. Wells, who wrote the barbed screenplay for ''The Truth About Cats and Dogs,'' may well have only the most impersonal interest in this subject. But her beguiling film has a persuasive been-there, done-that knowingness. And it has the luminous young actress Sarah Polley in its central role, with Stephen Rea as the seasoned flirt who takes her into the well-populated space under his wing.

title: Russia Bombs Chechnya Sites; Major Step-Up
description: Russian warplanes bombed the Grozny airport in Chechnya today and set an oil refinery ablaze on the outskirts of the city, as the Kremlin took its military campaign against Islamic rebels deep into Chechen territory.

title: Democrats' New Chairman Is Sign of Al Gore's Power
description: With an eye on the growing pile of cash that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is accumulating for the 2000 Presidential election, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have moved to strengthen the Democratic National Committee's fund-raising ability by bringing in Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia as the party's new general chairman.

title: One Killed and 24 Hurt at Restaurant
description: One person was killed and 24 others were injured last night when the driver of a car leaving a midtown parking garage lost control and her car suddenly accelerated and plowed into an Italian restaurant across the street, the authorities said.

title: Basil Rodzianko, 84, Bishop in Orthodox Church
description: Bishop Basil Rodzianko, a retired Bishop of the Orthodox Church in America who was known for the broadcasts on religious topics that he made from Britain and the United States to what is now Russia for more than three decades, died last Friday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

title: In Chelsea, From Parking to Tower
description: The long-empty blockfront on the west side of Seventh Avenue between 25th and 26th Streets is to become a 356-unit rental apartment building under plans being advanced by the new owner of the two parcels. The lots, long used for parking, were bought earlier this year by the Rockrose Development Corporation, which has built several apartment houses in the nearby West Village in recent years.

title: Bradley Retires After Head Injury
description: The former Tampa Bay Lightning center Brian Bradley retired from the National Hockey League after 13 seasons because of post-concussion syndrome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, RAE
description: WEINBERGER-Rae. Green Brook Country Club members and staff extend their condolences to the family and friends of our belovedmember Rae Weinberger who passed away on Wednesday, September 22, 1999.

title: Biographer as Hitchhiker in a President's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Mars Orbiting Craft Presumed Destroyed By Navigation Error
description: A $125 million robotic spacecraft, the first ever dispatched especially to investigate weather on another world, was missing yesterday and presumed destroyed just as it was supposed to go into an orbit around Mars.

title: Accounts
description: * Govworks.com, New York, a company that will offer on-line links to local government agencies for tasks like paying taxes, to Fallon McElligott New York City, a unit of Fallon McElligott, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings for the service -- to be introduced in local markets in the fall with a planned national introduction in early 2000 -- were estimated at $40 million.

title: Murder, Suicide and a Trail of Admirers
description: An investigation of killings that shocked Appleton, Wis., in 1995 opens a new season of PBS documentaries, ''Independent Lens.'' John Whitehead, the producer of ''Wannabe: Life and Death in a Small-Town Gang,'' returns to his hometown in search of what led to a murder of a teen-ager and the deaths of his three killers in a murder-suicide. He produces no revelations but confirms that middle America is not immune to the violence usually associated with big cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAGER, ELEANOR
description: YAGER-Eleanor. Of New York City on September 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Ralph Yager and cherished mother of Roger and Susan. Sister of Howard Golden and loving mother-in-law of Bob Berkowitz. Her charity, insight and intelligence will be greatly missed by all who knew her. A graveside service will be held on Friday, September 24, at 11:00 AM at the Mt. Carmel Cemetery in Ridgewood, Queens. Those who wish may make contributions in her memory to the Friends of the New York Public Library, 476 Fifth Ave, Room M6, NYC 10018-2788.

title: After Touring Bronx, First Lady Urges Congress to Raise the Minimum Wage
description: After briefly touring a commercial neighborhood in the Bronx and praising the borough's economic redevelopment efforts, Hillary Rodham Clinton urged Congress yesterday to raise the minimum wage.

title: A Symphony of Sticks, Ever So Loudly
description: In the hands of the bucket drummers of ''Keep Bangin','' drumsticks are automatic weapons. Streams of rhythm erupt like gunfire from the floors, pipes, bottles, chairs, suitcases and drums they pound, so much so that it feels as if the reverberations might show up in the results of a spectator's electrocardiogram.

title: U.S. Charges Lefrak City Denies Jobs to Women
description: Federal officials filed suit yesterday against Lefrak City, the largest apartment complex in Queens, contending that its management discriminated against women by refusing to give them jobs on its maintenance staff.

title: Album of the Week
description: GONZALO RUBALCABA: ''Inner Voyage'' (Blue Note/Capitol). The pianist Gonzalo Rubalcaba has worked in several different idioms over the last decade, including straight-ahead jazz, Latin jazz and fusion, but the one quality most associated with him is muscle. Like a lot of other trained Cuban musicians, he puts a premium on technique, and his ability to improvise on harmony with clear articulation at high speed and with dramatic flourishes is both his strength and his downfall; there's often something interior missing amid the formidable skill.

title: All Song, All Dynamo, And Cuban All Over
description: The stage at the Blue Note on Tuesday night could barely hold Albita, the Cuban singer and songwriter who is performing there through Sunday. She danced rumbas across the narrow space in front of her seven-piece band; she attacked songs as if the whole city were listening. She was determined to bring the Cuba she had left behind into the room.

title: When Betrayal Mattered
description: The British, who love a spy scandal, have not had a good one for years. Now they do. In the last two weeks, eight Britons, of whom six are still alive, have been described in the press or on the BBC as agents for the Soviet Union during the cold war. The source of most of these revelations is a new book co-written by a former archivist for the K.G.B., Vasily Mitrokhin, who defected to England in 1992, carrying six trunkloads of sensitive documents.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Samuel L. Clemens Would Love This

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My dad used to hear talk about the land going sour. But he never saw it smelling as sour as this.''

title: MANNESMANN SPLIT
description: The German conglomerate Mannesmann A.G. said it would split its engineering and telecommunications businesses, enabling the two units to trade separately by 2001 and making it easier to pay for acquisitions with stock. Analysts said that the split would free Mannesmann for mergers in the telecommunications market and that among the companies that could be interested in Mannesmann was Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's largest wireless phone service.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RISES. The yen rose against the dollar on expectations that Japan would get little help from other industrial nations in arresting its currency's recent surge. The dollar fell to 103.95 yen from 104.17 in New York.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Man, a Plan And a Film

title: Taiwan Begins Looking at Timetable and Cost to Rebuild
description: The destruction from the earthquake on Tuesday and its aftershocks will significantly reduce Taiwan's economic growth for 1999, Government officials said today. And they warned that repairing the many damaged buildings, highways, power generators and other structures could take years.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 3
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Sykora Not Ready
description: Petr Sykora may have to pay the price for reporting five days late to camp by missing the season opener and perhaps more. Sykora skated for the first time yesterday after missing another five days because of a bruised left shoulder he suffered while lifting weights.

title: Clinton and Walesa Pay Tribute to Kirkland
description: President Clinton eulogized labor leader Lane Kirkland today as a ''giant of a man, a true hero'' who rejected political labels and fought for workers around the world.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Dance Notes column on Wednesday about staff changes at Dance Magazine misspelled the surname of the design director, who resigned. She is Diana Leidel, not Lydell.

title: Medicare Cheating Spreads Its Harm Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunting Industrial Hazards Carried Off by Flood Waters
description: Cleanup crews trawling for hazardous materials set adrift in the overflowing Raritan River during Tropical Storm Floyd have come up with a mixed catch. It includes more than 1,000 items, ranging from an easily identifiable 1,000-pound propane tank to unlabeled drums of industrial chemicals to bottles of household solvents and pesticides.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: A Flicker Of Hope Sustains The Ghetto
description: In a Holocaust film to make Roberto Benigni look like Primo Levi, Robin Williams plays the clowning but compassionate title role in ''Jakob the Liar.'' Based on a book by Jurek Becker, this well-intentioned tragicomedy has a good cast, a whiff of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and a strangely inappropriate spirit of bonhomie, under the circumstances. While its Holocaust hot buttons are so familiar that the cast even includes a little girl resembling Anne Frank (Hannah Taylor Gordon), this is a film whose Anne may just live happily ever after.

title: A Resignation Is Expected From Chrysler's President
description: Just 10 months after the trans-Atlantic merger that created DaimlerChrysler A.G., the president of Chrysler is about to resign in the wake of a bruising management clash, company executives confirmed last night.

title: In an Endorsement of Bradley, Moynihan Dismisses Gore
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York endorsed Bill Bradley's campaign for President yesterday, and bluntly dismissed the prospects of Mr. Bradley's main opponent for the Democratic nomination, Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Moynihan said that Mr. Gore had no chance of winning the Presidency.

title: Leader Tries to Brighten Algeria's Image
description: When leaders gather here each year to set out policies and debate world issues, some use the spotlight to draw attention to their countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, J. HAROLD
description: GARFUNKEL-J. Harold. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of J. Harold Garfunkel, a cherished friend who was deeply devoted to the Jewish community. As a dedicated leader, he embraced the compassionate commitment of his father, who was a founder of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the predecessor to UJA-Federation. Following in his father's footsteps, he served as a life trustee of Federation, and was a longtime officer of Altro, one of our earliest beneficiary agencies. We extend our sincerest condolences to his daughter and son-in-law, Marjorie and Robert Bachrach; his daughter and son-in-law, Deborah and Robert Block; and his entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Most Wanted chart in Business Day last Monday and on Sept. 13 misstated the number of households represented by each rating point in the television audience data compiled by Nielsen Media Research. Each point equals 1.008 million households, not 100.8 million.

title: Giants' Rushing Is Thrown For Loss
description: Since the mid-1980's, the Giants have thrived behind their running backs.

title: Senate Backs Clause To Save Companies On Royalties for Oil
description: The Senate tonight narrowly approved a measure that saves oil companies from paying more than $5 million a month in royalties that the Government says they owe to the public.

title: Clemens Helps Yankees Clinch Tie for Playoffs
description: Hearts may be palpitating in Flushing these days, but the beat in the Bronx is steady as a metronome. The Yankees are winning with regularity again, advancing toward the post-season methodically, their improvement gradual and relentless.

title: A Big Birthday Finds the Chinese Prospering
description: In 1949 Yang Yuena was an illiterate 17-year-old peasant, living in a straw hut and farming for an absentee landlord, when the Red Army entered her rural hometown. This month, dressed in fashionable silks, she feted a U.C.L.A.-bound grandson in the family's second home, a lavish apartment in Beijing with a television that takes up an entire wall and a bar stocked with wine and cognac.

title: As Jakarta Troops Leave, Peacekeepers Face Gunfire
description: As the last elements of the Indonesian Army began their final pullout from East Timor today, smashing and burning their barracks and headquarters behind them, international peacekeepers had their first tense encounters with armed men in Dili.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNING, LAWRENCE J.
description: DOWNING - Lawrence J. Oceanside, NY, Sept. 23, 1999 after a short illness. Retired New York City Police Department. Decorated Police Officer with 27 years of service assigned to the 79 Precinct and 69th Precinct in Brooklyn & the 101st Precinct in Far Rockaway. Mr. Downing was a devoted family man and is survived by his loving wife of 48 years June Downing. Cherished father of Larry Jr. and his wife Ruth Miller and their daughters Lucy and Sally, Gloria Orlando Downing and her daughter Gina, Timothy and his wife Carolyn and their children Madeline Rose, Shannon & Tim Austin, Terrence and his wife Tracey and their children Cameron, Terrence John (TJ), and Brian. Dear brother of Richard, John and William. Family will receive friends Sunday 2-5, 7-9PM at the Moore Funeral Home, 54 West Jamaica Ave, Valley Stream. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 9:45 AM at St Christophers RC Church, Baldwin. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELL, ANN
description: TELL-Ann, 81 years, on September 9th, peacefully at her home in New York City. Lovingly cared for by the staff of Jacob Perlow Hospice. Beloved mother of Philip Busch and his wife Darilyn. Affectionate grandmother of Kenneth. Dear sister of Marguerite Simonson and Bernice Getty. Cherished family member of Jane and Carol. Devoted friend and teacher of many. Singer and Broadway performer. A celebration of her life will be held on Sunday, September 26th at 2 PM at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue at 60th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, Anne's family would appreciate that donations be made in her memory to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, care of Beth Israel Medical Center, 317 East 17th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Mignon Garland Dies at 91; Disciple of Isadora Duncan
description: Mignon Garland, a dancer and teacher who played a major role in keeping Isadora Duncan's legacy alive in the United States, died on Sept. 15 at her home in San Pablo, Calif. She was 91.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BACCARAT INC., Edison, N.J., the American subsidiary of the French luxury goods company, named Corinne Coombe president and chief executive, replacing Jean-Luc Negre. Ms. Coombe is the former president of Gianfranco Ferre.

title: Euro RSCG Creates New Planning Post
description: Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, has named Patrick Palmer to the new position of director for consumer insight and planning, bringing together the agency's media planning and account planning functions.

title: TEXTRON FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY LITCHFIELD FINANCIAL
description: Textron Inc.'s Textron Financial Corporation, an aircraft, equipment and golf financing company, agreed yesterday to buy the Litchfield Financial Corporation for about $183 million in cash to increase its resort-financing business. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., is to pay $24.50 a share for Litchfield, 38 percent more than Litchfield's closing price on Wednesday. Litchfield, with more than $550 million in managed finance receivables and a 20 percent annual earnings growth over 10 years, provides financing to time-share property and rural land developers. Shares of Litchfield, based in Williamstown, Mass., rose $6.25, or 35 percent, to $24.

title: Yutaka Sone
description: David Zwirner Gallery

title: Drug Makers Are Taken to Task for Criticism of Clinton Plan
description: The Clinton Administration summoned six drug company executives to the White House this week and reprimanded them for running advertisements critical of President Clinton's plan to offer prescription drug benefits to everyone on Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSINSKY, DOLLY
description: ROSSINSKY-Dolly. The League of the Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation mourn with profound sorrow the loss of our most dedicated gift shop manager, Dolly. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. May her memory be a blessing.

title: WESTWOOD COMPLETES ITS PURCHASE OF METRO NETWORKS
description: Westwood One Inc., one of the largest United States distributors of radio programs, completed its purchase of Metro Networks Inc. of Houston yesterday for $1.2 billion in stock, making it the No. 1 provider of traffic news. In addition, Westwood, based in Culver City, Calif., said it approved the buyback of as much as $200 million of its stock, or about 8 percent of its shares outstanding. The CBS Corporation owns about 25 percent of Westwood One.

title: Till Freiwald
description: Jack Shainman

title: The National Football League's latest campaign stacks its legends against today's stars.
description: IN an effort to rally fans, the National Football League is bringing together its past and present as the 80th professional football season gets under way.

title: Conrad F. Taeuber, 93, Scholar Who Directed 2 Federal Censuses
description: Conrad F. Taeuber, who directed the Federal census in 1960 and 1970, died on Sept. 11 in a nursing home in Nashua, N.H., where he had been living for several years. He was 93.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Undercurrents at a Safe Harbor; Isle of Man (and Corporations) Is an Enclave of Intrigue
description: With glittery new steel-and-glass offices, an imposing mansion and a high profile in yacht racing, Peter M. Bond has never quite been shy about his success.

title: Disney Promotes Executive
description: The Walt Disney Company named Sanford Litvack as vice chairman, a title he will share with Roy Disney. Mr. Litvack, 63, a key adviser to the company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, joined Disney in 1991 as general counsel and later added the role of chief of corporate operations. The appointment comes as Mr. Eisner -- under pressure from stockholders who have watched their shares decline about 10 percent this year -- tries to reverse a slide in earnings by cutting costs and slowing investments in some areas of the business.

title: A Romantic Who Has A Rational Side, Too
description: It is tempting to regard the pianist Abbey Simon as one of the last links to the school of Romantic pianism that flourished in the early decades of the century, and it is easy to justify that connection on purely biographical grounds.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about missions to Mars misidentified the craft that first used atmospheric friction, or aerobraking, to achieve orbit around a planet. It was the Mars Global Surveyor. (The Mars Pathfinder made a direct descent to the planet's surface, also in 1997.)

title: Public Service Ads, Or Self-Promotion?
description: Call it good governing. Or call it clever timing. Or call it coincidence.

title: Excerpts From S.E.C. Chairman's Prepared Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech last night by Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at Columbia Law School in Manhattan:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Peacock Alley, the sumptuous, resolutely old-fashioned dining room in the Waldorf-Astoria, may seem like an odd place for a revolution, but that's what Laurent Gras, its executive chef, seems to have in mind. Mr. Gras, in a sweeping move worthy of a Jacobin, has decreed an end to the old order of appetizers, main courses and desserts. In their place he has proposed a new system based on liberty, equality and fraternity among the food groups. Last week diners were presented with a menu that divides courses into these categories: ocean/river, field/forest and farm. Diners may order a single course, three courses, six courses or more as they assemble what Mr. Gras calls ''a gustatory mosaic.''

title: 2 Providers Of Net Access Set to Merge
description: Earthlink Network Inc. and Mindspring Enterprises Inc., two pioneers in the business of selling Internet access, announced a merger agreement yesterday, with hopes of more effectively challenging America Online.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Medievalism, All in Jest

title: Ex-Treasurer In Connecticut Pleads Guilty
description: Paul J. Silvester, who left office in January as Connecticut's State Treasurer, pleaded guilty in Federal court today to accepting cash kickbacks in return for placing $500 million in state pension investments with certain equity funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFEL, GEORGE
description: RAFFEL-George. September 23, 1999, of Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of the late Renee and brother of Anne, father of Jeff and father-in law of Joanne, grandfather of Allison, David, Lori, Tom and Ken, great-grandfather of Nicole. Loved by his extended family and friends. Graveside services, New Montefiore Cemetery, today, 2:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to American Heart Assocn.

title: Like Dust, Mets Are Swept Aside
description: With the debacle done and the chagrin mounting, it was left to Mike Piazza to explain just how the Mets had imploded in Atlanta, how the team that had hoped to leap into first place during this series instead skidded toward its final nine games of the season with its playoff future clouded and its confidence waning.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, KERWIN
description: FARKAS-Kerwin. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, New York, on behalf of its membership, wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member, Kerwin Farkas. He will be sorely missed.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday about two people who died in Maine after being swept into the Atlantic from a scenic point in Acadia National Park misspelled the name of the place from which they fell. It is Schoodic Point, not Shoodic.

title: 17 Are Charged In Operation Of Betting Ring
description: Seventeen people were indicted yesterday on charges of conducting a multimillion-dollar illegal sports gambling operation that grossed up to $30 million a year and was headed by a reputed member of the Genovese crime family, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLAMANA, JOAN SPENCER
description: VILLAMANA-Joan Spencer of Bronxville and Patterson, NY died at home on Tuesday, September 21, 1999. Mrs. Villamana is survived by her husband, Tom; her brother, Don Harris; her daughters, Luci Krusz, Kim Spencer and Molly Marshall; and four grandchildren, Robbie, Ronnie, Emily and Troy. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Bronxville on Saturday, September 25th at 2 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to The Hole in the Wall Gang Fund, 555 Long Wharf Drive, New Haven, CT 06511. The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp is a camp for cancer and blood illnesses.

title: Parental Approval Law On Abortion Survives Test
description: A Superior Court judge rebuffed yesterday a request by abortion-rights advocates to block a new law that requires doctors to get written approval from a least one parent of any girl under 18 seeking to end her pregnancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEY, IRVING, MD.
description: SHEY-Irving, MD. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father of Janet (Jeff), Audrey (Bernard) and Andrew (Rita). Adored grandfather to Amber and Samantha. Donations to the Alzheimers Foundation appreciated. Services Friday, September 24, 11AM, Community Synagogue, Rye, NY.

title: A New Market, Disturbingly Fragmented
description: Knowledge is power, in the stock market as well as other places. And until recently, regulation had insured that anywhere in the United States that major stocks were traded -- whether on the New York Stock Exchange or in some competing market -- investors could learn almost immediately about the size and price of each trade.

title: Saga of a Criminal Band (Of Runaway Musicians)
description: Reminiscent of ''Thelma and Louise,'' the German-language film ''Bandits'' is a celebration of liberated sisterhood and the rebellious, anarchic spirit of youth that animates the best of rock-and-roll.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL THAT WOULD LIMIT CLASS-ACTION SUITS
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would make it difficult, if not impossible, to bring large class-action lawsuits against tobacco companies, gun makers and a wide variety of other businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASSER, GEORGE THOMAS
description: MASSER-George Thomas. On Monday, September 20, of Rockville, MD, formerly of Flushing, NY. Loving brother of Thomas and James Masser; brother-in-law of Andrea and Madeline, uncle of Lauren and James. Services and inurnment will be held at Arlington National Cemetery on Friday, October 1, 1999, at 2PM. Everyone will assemble at the Administration Building at 1:30PM. title: Lehman Shakes Off '98 Woes And Reports Strong Earnings
description: Just one year after rumors of its impending demise swept around trading desks on Wall Street, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. is on its way to its most profitable year.

title: A Building With a Song In Its Heart and Vaults
description: You might think you are hearing wind across an empty plain, or the ringing of railroad tracks as a train approaches, or a choir performing somewhere high above, or the reverberations of a great bell, but in fact you will be in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, where every day until Monday Jeff Talman's electronic piece ''Vanishing Point 1.1'' is being played repeatedly.

title: Three Surprise Cuts
description: The Islanders trimmed their preseason roster to 25 players yesterday, sending left wing Josh Green, center Jason Krog and right wing Dmitri Nabokov to the Lowell (Mass.) Lock Monsters of the American Hockey League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARESTY, JULIAN J.
description: ARESTY-Julian J. The officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee send heartfelt condolences to our dear colleague and friend Jane Silverman on the death of her beloved father, Julian Aresty. Jane, a long time member of our AJC family and wife of our late Executive Director Ira Silverman, serves as AJC Secretary and as a member of our Executive Committee and Board of Governors. At this time of sorrow, our thoughts and prayers are with Jane, her children Jacob, Rachel and Sarah, and the entire grieving family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

description: In percent

title: Policing A Sore Spot In Brooklyn
description: DEPUTY Inspector Donald P. O'Donnell of the New York Police Department talksreally fast, coming up for air only on occasion. But then, he has a lot to say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEIKES, ROBERT
description: CHEIKES-Robert. On September 18, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rosamonde. Loving father of Vicki, Stephen and Brant. Dear brother of Henry. Devoted uncle of Jane Peters, Lance and Robert Cheikes. Memorial service Friday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stratton Oakmont Executives Admit Stock Manipulation
description: Two former principals of Stratton Oakmont Inc., a defunct Long Island brokerage firm, have admitted that they oversaw a vast seven-year scheme to manipulate the stocks of at least 34 companies, costing investors hundreds of millions of dollars, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Ode to Well-Made Books And the Art of Printing
description: One of the topics bandied about by the Typophiles, a New York group of book lovers, at their irregular luncheons in the 1930's was the ampersand, the useful connector that signifies ''and'' in Latin. Enamored of its whimsical curves and curlicues, the Typophiles finally put together in 1936 ''Diggings From Many Ampersandhogs'' (ouch!) a lively volume of tributes to the ''&'' by American printers and designers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBLATT, MICHAEL ALBERT
description: LORBERBLATT-Michael Albert. 58, of NYC on September 2, 1999. Born in Brooklyn. Son of the late Isaac and Myra (Herman) Lorberblatt. Survived by his wife, Jean Nizalowski-Lorberblatt and son, Joshua D. Lorberblatt; his sister, state representative Phyllis Kahn and brother-in-law Donald Kahn of Minneapolis, MN; an aunt and uncle Fried de Metz Herman and Albert Herman of Larchmont, NY. Graduated Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn; B.A. University of Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. A sculptor and painter who relished artistic challenges and athletic adventures; skier, scuba diver, and avid Tribeca tennis player. Private funeral services were held in Newark Valley, New York. A memorial service will be November 20 at 5:00 P.M. in the home of Richard Barnet, 66 Grand Street, New York City (SOHO). Contributions to the Newark Valley Historical Society, (Youth Education), Box 222, Newark Valley, New York 13811, would be greatly appreciated.

title: G.M. AND UNION ARE SAID TO BE NEAR A CONTRACT
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union hope to conclude a new labor contract as soon as Sunday or Monday, several people close to the talks said yesterday. The contract is likely to resemble closely the union's agreement last week with DaimlerChrysler A.G., they said, adding that Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, had been personally leading the talks this week at a G.M. office building in Michigan. A peaceful agreement would be an accomplishment for G.M., which has endured crippling strikes, including an eight-week walkout a year ago in Flint, Mich., that cost the company $2 billion in after-tax profits.

title: Kashmir Separatists Stopped By India on Way to the U.N.
description: Indian immigration authorities today prevented leaders of an alliance of Kashmiri separatist groups from leaving the airport here for New York, where they had planned to seek support for their cause at the United Nations, alliance officials said.

title: Stocks Plunge Over Remark On Microsoft
description: Stock prices, already weighed down by fears about interest rates and the dollar, fell hard yesterday after the president of Microsoft said high-technology companies like his were considerably overvalued.

title: Sure, the Doctor Is In: In Demand and in Trouble
description: Lawrence Kasdan's likable semi-screwball comedy ''Mumford'' has two big pluses on its side. In tackling psychotherapy, a subject Hollywood has traditionally treated with a quaking solemnity, it sustains a tone that is refreshingly commonsensical and irreverent.

title: It Was Police Work That Made Crack Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley Is Ordered To Produce Bias-Suit Files
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has lost a round in its legal battle with an employee who complained to the Federal Government that the investment banking company discriminated against her and other women.

title: As Carolina Floods Recede, Farmers Are Faced With Devastated Crops
description: The Swift Creek finally returned to its banks today, flowing pleasantly downstream as if it had not just caused an agricultural catastrophe in Pitt and Craven Counties. But the mud and the stench and the endless ruined crops it left behind will never be forgotten by the Stancill family and the other farmers who used to depend on its water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, RAE (NEE GLANZER)
description: WEINBERGER-Rae (nee Glanzer). On Wednesday, September 22, 1999 of Verona, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Weinberger. Devoted mother of Sandra Castelbaum, Mimi Korn and Donald Weinberger. Adored motherin-law of Martin Castelbaum, Stuart Korn and Sue Weinberger. Cherished sister of Charlotte Fischer Gular. Loving grandmother of Arthur Castelbaum, Amy Benedikt, Jill Azulay, Susan Rona, Tracy and David Korn, Marc, Jay and Glen Weinberger. Great grandmother of Julie, Emily, Lauren, Elana, Robert, Drew and David. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. Friday, September 24th, 11:30AM. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey.

title: The Government's Selective Memory
description: With great fanfare, the Federal Government has announced that it and the American public have been duped in an adroit campaign by tobacco companies, a deception that has forced Medicare to spend billions of dollars in treating tobacco-related illnesses. The gist of the Government's racketeering and fraud lawsuit, which was filed on Wednesday, is that for the past 45 years, the industry concealed the health hazards of smoking and the addictive effects of nicotine.

title: Sale of Japanese Bank Likely to Private U.S. Equity Fund
description: The Japanese Government is close to selling the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan to an American-led investor group, a transaction that would put a financial icon of the country's postwar reconstruction in foreign hands.

title: Odds Worsen in Hunt for Low-Income Rentals
description: In a negative side-effect of the robust economy, more people with low incomes are struggling to find rental housing that they can afford, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: Newman Sent Back To Meadowlands
description: The Nets obtained the veteran forward Johnny Newman from the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday in a deal for guard Eric Murdock.

title: George C. Scott, Celebrated for 'Patton' Role, Dies at 71
description: George C. Scott, an actor of extraordinary range and daring, celebrated for his performances as Gen. George S. Patton Jr. in the movie ''Patton'' and as Shakespeare's Richard III (in Central Park) and for his roles in countless other films and plays, died on Wednesday in his office in Westlake Village, Calif., near Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: 3 COMPANIES ARE BUYING $400 MILLION IN NEWBRIDGE GEAR
description: The Newbridge Networks Corporation, a Canadian maker of networking equipment, said yesterday that it would sell at least $400 million of gear to France Telecom S.A., the Toshiba Corporation of Japan and an Argentina-based unit of the BellSouth Corporation. Newbridge has been counting on rising sales of devices that speed network traffic to increase profit, and has been trying to parlay its expertise in asynchronous transfer mode technology to sell new wireless gear that lets telecommunications companies offer a variety of Internet, voice and video services.

title: William Eckert, 73, Medical Sleuth in Major Cases
description: Dr. William Eckert, a forensic pathologist who worked on major and often bizarre murder cases including the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the re-examination of Jack the Ripper's killings, died on Friday at a hospital in New Orleans. He was 73 and lived in Terrytown, a suburb of New Orleans.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Mummy

title: Clinton and Arafat Confer Again on Peace Negotiations
description: In what are becoming almost regular sessions, President Clinton and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, met at the White House today to discuss how to proceed on negotiations that are to define a final peace settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: It Was Police Work That Made Crack Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Threatens to Evict Museum Over Exhibit He Dislikes
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stepped up his attack on the Brooklyn Museum of Art yesterday, threatening to terminate its lease with the city and possibly even seize control of the museum unless it cancels a British exhibition that features a portrait of the Virgin Mary stained with elephant dung.

title: Presumed Guilty
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting Monty Python
description: As he did regularly on the BBC and later on PBS, the wild-eyed old fellow with the scraggly beard staggers up to the camera seemingly ready to expire. ''It's,'' he gasps. ''It's . . . It's . . .'' Actually it's ''Monty Python's Flying Circus,'' available from A&E on Tuesday in an extensive recycling of material from a show that, along with ''Saturday Night Live,'' took over television comedy for a time in the 70's and still lingers in spirit.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENMAN, PHILIP AND EVELYN
description: GREENMAN-Philip and Evelyn. 9/24/39-9/24/99. Happy 60th Anniversary in Heaven. Cherished and missed. Lind

title: Exile Says U.S. Plans Genocide Charges for Saddam Hussein
description: A leader of Iraq's opposition movement in exile said today that United States officials are planning to pursue genocide and war-crimes charges against Saddam Hussein.

title: Hampton, Not Grambling, Is a Power Now
description: They are no longer the class of black college football, no longer a professional scout's dream, no longer intimidating and awe-inspiring to opponents. But the Grambling State Tigers have a history of nearly unmatched excellence on their side, and that is enough to create both excitement and concern for Hampton Coach Joe Taylor.

title: S.E.C. Chief Wants One Site For Posting All Stock Prices
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a system yesterday for displaying electronically all orders to buy and sell United States stocks and called such a central posting essential to preserve the integrity of the nation's stock markets.

title: Kaufman & Broad Earnings Climb 36%
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, the nation's second-largest home builder, said yesterday that its earnings for its fiscal third quarter rose 36 percent, beating expectations as the company continued to benefit from a strong housing market.

title: First She Keelhauls Him, Then She Invites Him to Dinner
description: If you want to be Jack Kerouac, you don't even have to leave the island of Manhattan to go on the road. That's the whimsical conceit of Art Jones's film ''Going Nomad,'' a comic ode to urban night driving, puffed up with quasi-Beat poetry and peopled with the contemporary equivalents of William Saroyan characters spouting Tom Waits-style riffs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Europe Exchanges Pledge To Start a Unified System
description: Threatened by looming competition from new electronic trading networks, Europe's eight biggest stock exchanges rekindled efforts today to create a pan-European system.

title: Where Leaks Can Hurt The Cause of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Clothes Are Sloppy, But Their Copy Is Pretty Neat
description: Intended to poke fun at the advertising business, ''Suits'' turns out to be an unsophisticated satire. Clearly based on observed behavior, it founders on its inability to invest its truths with inspired comedy.

title: Suit Claims Pokemon Is Lottery, Not Just Fad
description: It seemed harmless enough last winter when little Alex Silverman started asking his mother for extra money to buy packs of Pokemon trading cards, the children's craze that has swept schoolyards and stationery stores across the country.

title: Clein & Walker To Break Into Two
description: Clein & Walker Inc., an entertainment public relations agency that has offices in West Hollywood, Calif., and in New York, is being dissolved as two new agencies take its place.

title: Concert Review; Philharmonic Is Overture To 1999-2000 Music Season
description: Greeting guests at the door with hard questions is not the New York Philharmonic's idea of hospitality. So Thursday evening's opening of the season at Avery Fisher Hall -- a prelude to dining and dancing and a subject of scrutiny by Public Television -- became instead what pop songs of old used to call ''a warm embrace.''

title: Direct Hit Awards Branding Account
description: Direct Hit Technologies Inc., a search engine developer in Wellesley, Mass., has awarded its branding account to Gearon Hoffman in Boston. Billings for the account, which had been at Heater Advertising in Boston, were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Biographer as Hitchhiker in a President's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Sets Shifts in Internet Strategy
description: The Microsoft Corporation disclosed several pieces of its new Internet strategy today, saying that it would offer the public a piece of its most successful on-line effort, the Expedia travel site; would significantly redesign its MSN portal, and would introduce a network computing device.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL JUMPS 3.1 PERCENT. Crude oil rose after the American Petroleum Institute reported that gasoline demand last week was 4 percent higher than the year's average. November crude gained 75 cents, to $24.875 a barrel.

title: Top-Rated Dogs to Be Invited
description: A year after one of the country's top basset hounds was left out of the Westminster Dog Show because of the rapid-fire entry process, the Westminster Kennel Club will now invite the top-rated dogs.

title: Clinton Vetoes Tax Cut but Seeks Accord
description: President Clinton vetoed the $792 billion Republican tax cut today, but called on a skeptical Congress to reach a bipartisan compromise with him on taxes, domestic spending and the long-term financing problems facing Medicare and Social Security.

title: Bush Vows Money and Support for Military
description: Describing the world as a dangerous place with unpredictable threats to American security, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas outlined a plan today for additional spending to increase military salaries and fashion a new generation of more technologically sophisticated weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, MARTIN E.
description: DANZIG-Martin E. Of Tamarac, FL and Merrick, LI. On September 23. Born in Jerusalem. Son of Rabbi David and Chaya Sarah Danzig. Graduate of Yeshiva University Teacher's Department and NYU. Professor of Sociology at CUNY and author of numerous articles. Organized Migdal David Synagogue. Executive Director of YMHA, Manchester, NH, and Perth Amboy. Survived by his loving wife, May Berg, devoted sons Larry, Fred and Arnold; adoring grandchildren Elizabeth, Talya, Matthew, Dasi, Joshua David, and Sydney Malvina; loving daughtersin-law Valerie and Lori. Graveside services Friday, 11:30 AM at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. I.J. Morris 1-800-332-8484

title: Sports of The Times; Whispers Are Getting Louder
description: FOR the first game in this series against the Mets, Atlanta fans came to Turner Field with cautious confidence; for Game 2, they came with quiet arrogance. Yesterday, they came with brooms. Anticipating a sweep of the little-brother Mets, Braves fans talked trash and brought sweeping utensils to clean it up. In the ninth inning, the chants resumed.

title: Time to Tee It Up
description: The United States faces off against the Europeans in the Ryder Cup today at The Country Club in Brookline, Mass. The U.S. is out to avenge defeats in the last two matches -- in 1995 and 1997.

title: Sega Sells 514,000 Units of New Game
description: Sega Enterprises Ltd., the video-game console maker, said it sold 514,000 of its new Dreamcast game machines in the United States, topping the company's projections for the machine's first two weeks on the market.

title: House G.O.P. on Creative Accounting Spree
description: Creative accounting by Congress reached new heights today as House Republican leaders, desperately seeking money for their spending bills, used budgetary devices to manufacture nearly $17 billion out of thin air.

title: Lundmark, Not Brendl, Rangers' Rookie of Choice
description: The Rangers open the season next Friday in Edmonton, and Jamie Lundmark and not Pavel Brendl was in the lineup for last night's preseason contest against the Philadelphia Flyers. How expectations have changed in three weeks for a pair of 18-year-olds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, PHILIP
description: BROWNSTEIN-Philip. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend and Block Island comrade. For 45 years, he enriched our lives with his charming warmth, his humor, and his quietly blazing intellect. Goodness, integrity and a rare unshakable decency were his hallmarks. His life of dedication to our shared values was an inspiration. His going is a tear in the fabric of our lives, but the memories of summer laughter, gardens, and starlight on the ocean will be with us always. Zenith, Katherine, Peter, Kenneth, Melinda, Larry, Rose, and the grandchildren

title: Plea in Pension Scheme
description: Paul J. Silvester, a former Connecticut State Treasurer, pleaded guilty in Federal court to accepting cash kickbacks in return for placing $500 million in state pension investments with certain equity funds. Officials said that the state pension money was never in danger.

title: Peco and Unicom to Merge In Big Bet on Nuclear Power
description: The Peco Energy Company, Philadelphia's electric utility, and the Unicom Corporation, the owner of the electric company that serves Chicago, announced yesterday that they planned a $16 billion merger that would create the nation's largest collection of nuclear plants.

title: Jets Need Offense To Rescue Defense
description: They have been frozen by the run and burned by the pass. And now all the Jets' defense has to do is stop the highest-scoring team in pro football from doing either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSE, RUTH
description: PERSE-Ruth. On September 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Benjamin. Loving mother of Larry & Harold. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Service Friday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Thursday, 7-9PM. Interment Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about GTE's sale of Nebraska telephone lines to Citizens Utilities misstated the ownership of the buyer. Citizens Utilities is a public company, with shares traded on The New York Stock Exchange; it is not closely held.

title: Little-Known Works of a Renowned French Pianist
description: Most pianists who also compose have been eager advocates of their own works. Not Robert Casadesus, the great French pianist who was born 100 years ago and died in 1972. To him the idea of performing his own music was somehow immodest. In manner he was direct and elegant, qualities that were beautifully reflected in his playing. Much of the public that admired his playing was not even aware that he had composed some 60 works, including seven symphonies. His music remains little known today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, HELENE E.
description: CALLAHAN-Helene E. On September 21, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Patrick and Delia Callahan. Loving sister of Sister Miriam Helen Callahan S.C. and the late Michael Callahan. Friends may call Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM, at Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel'', 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, September 25, 10AM, Church of the Epiphany, 2nd Ave at 22nd Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, New York 10471.
