description: R.S.V.P.'s For a 'Party' . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, HY
description: ROSENBLATT-Hy. Died September 21, in Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of North Shore Towers. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Arlene and Allan Suchman, Marcia and Brian Meyer. Grandfather of Ian and Seth Suchman. Brother of Fay Ball, Pearlie and Howie Rosen, Willie and Claire Rosenblatt. Brother-in-law of Mimi Rosenblatt. Uncle and great-uncle to many nieces and nephews.

title: Public Interests; Yes, We Have No Hazelnuts
description: Jimmy Carter knows more than most people about problematic relatives. But he still must have been startled to hear that a member of his extended family had been arrested for scalping a ticket to the ex-President's 75th birthday gala. Lewis Patrick Harrison Jr. is a nephew by marriage of the late, fabled Billy (''I have no embarrassment'') Carter. He not only allegedly sold the ticket for 10 times its $50 face price, he broadcast his eagerness to make money on the event with an ad in a local shopper.

title: Piano Ventures With Interludes of Fantasy
description: Sometimes the difference between downtown music and uptown music is all in a foot or two of skirt length. For example, the program that the pianist Kathleen Supove gave at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa on Tuesday evening, built around big ostinato pieces by Frederic Rzewski, John Adams and Alvin Curran, could easily have been played by, say, Ursula Oppens at Weill Hall. Ms. Oppens, though, would probably not have performed it in fishnet stockings and a hand's breadth of leopard-skin print below tuxedo jacket and evening shirt.

title: Jacques Villegle
description: 50 Years of Decollage

title: The Music Is Sweet, the Words Are True
description: A comedian with a voice, KT Sullivan likes to come at the past sideways. Finding a workable balance between her comic pose as a jiggly, eye-batting, not-so-dumb blonde and a studious pop nostalgist hasn't been easy for her. But when the elements mesh, the result can be the cabaret equivalent of whipped cream atop a surprisingly nutritious dessert.

title: Tension at Stuyvesant
description: To the Editor:

title: Newspaper Prize Awarded to Goodby
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors, winning the $100,000 grand prize, in the Athena Awards competition sponsored by the Newspaper Association of America for creative advertising in newspapers.

title: Two Bombings Viewed as Racist Unsettle Largely Black College
description: A pipe bomb exploded on Wednesday at the predominantly black Florida A & M University here, the second blast in three weeks, and students expressed fear and frustration today about the possibly racial motivation behind the bombings.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: From Dainty Little Wife to One Reckless Avenger
description: Early in the touristy thriller ''Double Jeopardy,'' Nick Parsons (Bruce Greenwood) proves himself a wealthy art bore by browbeating a young man who mistakes Nick's Kandinsky for a Picasso. This is reason enough for Nick to meet a violent end. Photogenically, he happens to have bought a nice new sailboat for the occasion.

title: New Indonesian Security Law Sets Off Protests by Students
description: In a hastily arranged vote just before it was to go into recess, Indonesia's Parliament today approved a security law that opponents say could grant strong new powers to the military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTON, WILLIAM H.
description: BUTTON-William H. On the morning of September 24, 1998, William H. Button passed away at his home in Sarasota, FL after a five month battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Katharine B. Button, stepmother, Mrs. William H. Button 2nd, sister, Judy B. Keyes, three children, and five grandchildren. Mr. Button will be remembered as a loving, generous and gentle soul. He possessed a wonderful sense of humor and a great, active intellect. The family requests that donations in his memory be sent to: Century Foundation Nursing Education Fund, 1838 Waldemere St., Sarasota, FL 34239

title: RITE AID SHARES FALL AGAIN AFTER FLORIDA FILES LAWSUIT
description: Shares of the Rite Aid Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday after Florida's Attorney General accused the company on Wednesday of overcharging customers. Rite-Aid fell $2, to $12, in trading of 12.3 million shares, making its shares the fourth most active in United States markets. They have fallen for three consecutive days, and one analyst said offers to acquire Rite Aid were possible. Florida filed a racketeering lawsuit against the company, saying it overcharged 29,000 uninsured prescription drug customers. The company said that Florida's suit was groundless and that it would vigorously defend itself.

title: Coolly Elegant Portraits And Views of the Surreal
description: Fashion photographers born 40 years apart, Irving Penn and David Seidner would not be expected to have much in common. But from current exhibitions of their work -- Mr. Seidner's at Staley-Wise in SoHo and Mr. Penn's at PaceWildenstein and PaceWildenstein MacGill -- they do.

title: EUROPEAN RATES HOLD
description: At a meeting, the European Central Bank held interest rates at record lows, giving the recovery in the 11-nation euro economy more time to take root before raising borrowing costs. Though growth is accelerating in the three biggest economies, Germany, France and Italy, annual inflation in the region stood at 1.2 percent in August, well below the central bank's 2 percent ceiling. Officials have stressed that inflation is likely to remain quiescent, cooling concern they will follow the United States Federal Reserve and the Bank of England by raising rates soon.

title: When Book Sales Top Political Expectations
description: The early buzz in political and publishing circles about Senator John McCain's family memoir, ''Faith of My Fathers,'' was that it was a different kind of campaign book, one with real literary merit and sales promise -- hardly the case with most campaign books. There was even some speculation that the book, published by Random House, might help the Arizona Republican's quest for his party's Presidential nomination.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Vosburgh to Be Key Test For Breeders' Cup Sprint
description: It will be a shakedown race for the Breeders' Cup Sprint, and seven speed horses were entered in it yesterday at Belmont Park, led by the favorite, Crafty Friend. But to his trainer, John Kimmel, it was not yet certain that the $250,000 Vosburgh at Belmont Park tomorrow would lead the 6-year-old star to the $1 million Breeders' Cup championships five weeks later.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: R. R. DONNELLEY & SONS CO., Chicago, the largest United States printer of telephone directories, plans to buy back as much as $300 million of stock, in response to the drop in its share price in the last 12 months.

title: Shirazeh Houshiary
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: The Elite Rub Fenders With a Fast Crowd
description: IMAGINE the kind of swell Manhattan party where Princess Grace might have rubbed elbows with a Daytona 500 trophy queen. The automotive version of such a soiree is the fourth annual Louis Vuitton Classic, a juried car show today through Sunday in Rockefeller Center.

title: Metro Business; Executives Plead Guilty
description: The former chairman and the former president of Stratton Oakmont Inc., a defunct brokerage firm in Nassau County, N.Y., have pleaded guilty to an expanded series of stock-fraud charges, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: ITT INDUSTRIES IS BUYING A BUSINESS FROM STANFORD
description: ITT Industries Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the space and military communications operations of Stanford Telecommunications Inc. for $191 million. The purchase would be ITT Industries' sixth acquisition this year as it moves to transform itself after selling most of its automotive operations in 1998. ITT Industries, based in White Plains, said the transaction was subject to completion of the $280 million merger between Stanford and the Newbridge Networks Corporation. That deal is expected to close in November. Also yesterday, the Intel Corporation said it had agreed to buy Stanford's Component Products division, which makes silicon elements for cable companies and high-speed wireless service providers, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: The Mayor as Art Censor
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has expressed his personal outrage by publicly criticizing the contents of an exhibition called ''Sensation,'' a collection of recent British artworks scheduled to open at the Brooklyn Museum of Art on Oct. 2. The show contains highly controversial works by Damien Hirst, including a partially decomposed shark and a bisected pig preserved in formaldehyde, as well as a dung-stained, faux-naive portrait of the Virgin Mary by Chris Ofili. After seeing the exhibition catalogue, Mr. Giuliani called these works ''sick stuff,'' which, indeed, is a phrase that may have been uttered by many of the visitors -- critics and ordinary art lovers alike -- who saw the exhibition in London or Berlin.

title: World of Country Music Is Confronted by Choices
description: More than performers of any other style of popular music, country musicians see themselves as part of a unified community. Unlike their rock-and-roll counterparts, they accept their music's past and understand that if the roots are destroyed, so is the tree. Unlike rappers, their center is undisputably one city, Nashville, thus avoiding territorial rivalries. And while recent years have seen the rise of national superstars like Garth Brooks and Shania Twain, selling more than 10 million copies of their albums, for the most part country musicians have maintained the illusion that they are the men and women next door.

title: In Westchester, Many Welcome Insect Spraying
description: As residents of lower Westchester waited for an overhead blitz of insecticides today, they draped their backyard furniture in plastic, herded their children indoors or just went about their business, assuming a practical but fighting stance.

title: Nary a Picasso, But oh, for The Mick's Last Bat
description: With Babe Ruth and Shoeless Joe Jackson taking the spot at Sotheby's East Side Auction House that is normally reserved for Picasso or Monet, it brought an odd assortment to the spacious new auction hall. Bidders dressed in suits worth the price of a 1913 Chief Bender Philadelphia Athletics jersey (it went for $24,000 last night) sat beside hopeful Yankee fans in worn-out T-shirts that weren't worth the price of a program here last night.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: At 34, Worldly-Wise and on His Way Up
description: ON the wall of Fareed Zakaria's office hangs a great trophy of his trade: an autographed copy of George F. Kennan's historic ''X'' article, published in 1947 in Foreign Affairs, that first articulated America's policy of Soviet containment. Nearby is a signed copy of Henry A. Kissinger's ''Reflections on American Diplomacy,'' published in 1956 in Foreign Affairs, which launched the would-be Secretary of State as a public intellectual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, MICHAEL
description: ALBERT-Michael. ''See LORBERBLATT - Michael Albert.'' NYC sculptor, painter and avid Tribeca tennis player .

title: You Just Can't Curl Up With a Good Web Site
description: As the years go by you fall into the habit of believing that apples do not taste as sharp as they used to and that candy bars are not as big. They do not, in fact, and they are not; thanks respectively to fruit genetics and marketing margins.

title: When Context Outshines Content
description: ''AMERICA TAKES COMMAND.'' These jarring, jingoistic words, redolent of a Marshall Plan approach to cultural influence, appear on a large sign in the first gallery of ''The American Century: Art and Culture, 1950-2000'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art. They float above paintings by Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning and sculptures by David Smith, and they refer, of course, to what is often called the triumph of American art, specifically of Abstract Expressionism, after World War II.

title: PEROT IS LEANING TOWARD BUCHANAN
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's expected bid for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination has won the tacit approval of Ross Perot and the explicit encouragement of close Perot advisers.

title: Woods and Garcia in a Kodak Moment
description: Friday morning will be electrifying at The Country Club, for those who can't wait for the Ryder Cup to begin, and for those who can't wait to see Tiger Woods versus Sergio Garcia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, SANDY
description: DAVIS-Sandy, September 24, 1997. It is two years since you have gone and we all miss you terribly, yet the joy and laughter you brought to our lives lives on in our hearts forever.

title: Scant Data and Unlikely Findings on Belts in School Buses
description: SEAT belts save lives in cars, so why not on buses? And especially on school buses, which carry vulnerable children through crowded streets and over twisting country roads?

title: Soweto Journal; Where Apartheid Ruled, Tourists Are Swarming
description: ''In Soweto,'' a tour guide named Chris Gumbi said, ''we have one of the most popular cars, the German car, the BMW. We have many names for it. You can say: Beat My Wife. Break My Window. Bob Marley and the Wailers. Bicycle of Soweto. It is the easiest car for the mafias to have.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORGA, ALFONSO
description: GORGA-Alfonso. September 23. Beloved husband of the late Ada. Loving father of Joseph and Grace. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, September 25, 1999, 10:30 A.M. at the Church of St. Thomas More, East 89th Street, NYC.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange said Wednesday that a seat on the exchange had sold for $2.55 million. That was down $100,000 from the last sale, on Aug. 23.

title: To Watch This Team, Don't Watch the Clock
description: If you intend to watch the Yankees on television in the playoffs, it might be a good time to check your VCR or prepare an excuse for being late to work. Once again, the Yankees are playing very slow games.

title: British Paper's Sting Nets an Earl and a Scolding From a Judge
description: In a harsh challenge to a news-gathering technique used by some British newspapers, a judge criticized a paper on Wednesday for allowing two of its reporters to dress up as rich Arabs, pretend to want to buy motor scooters from a peer, and then ply him with expensive food and alcohol until he sold them cocaine.

title: Samuel Gottscho -- 'New York: Night and Day'
description: Allan Klotz Photocollect

title: Seeking a Position In Campaign, Bauer Calls for a Flat Tax
description: Gary L. Bauer called today for a flat tax on incomes and sought to stake out a conservative populist position in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, saying that his plan would make the Republicans the party ''for the working American, blue collar and white collar, not just for the big corporate interests.''

title: Buoyed by the Strangeness of Kinship
description: WHEN Pedro Almodovar gleefully established himself as ''Spain's most reputable disreputable young filmmaker'' (in Vincent Canby's words), it was the dizzy hilarity of ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' that marked him as an avatar of outrageous, sexy humor. Eleven years later he is back at the New York Film Festival in a ravishingly different mode. The antic fizz and bold, theatrical exaggeration of his earlier work have blossomed (as was clear in the haunting 1997 ''Live Flesh'') into a newly sophisticated style that is far more passionate, wise and deeply felt.

title: Campaigning Under Onus of Super Wealth
description: Jon S. Corzine, the retired investment banker, had barely finished announcing his formal candidacy for the United States Senate today when he was asked the $300 million question:

title: South Africans, Isolated No More
description: Apartheid shaped the course of contemporary art in South Africa. It dictated that blacks and whites had unequal access to museums and schools. It inspired a huge body of protest work in every medium. And it insured that much of that work remained invisible outside the nation itself, which was shunned as a pariah.

title: Newsprint Mill to Be Sold
description: The Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation agreed today to sell a newsprint mill in Newburg, Ore., for $220 million, nearly completing a plan to sell $2 billion in assets to reduce debt and concentrate on its packaging business. The mill will be sold to the Southeast Paper Manufacturing Company, a partnership of Cox Enterprises, Media General and Knight Ridder.

title: Advisers to Gore Are Concerned Over Rapid Campaign Spending
description: Some aides and advisers to Vice President Al Gore are concerned that his campaign for President is spending money at a dangerously rapid pace because it is top-heavy with costly political consultants and devoting far more to travel than its rivals.

title: Wei Dong
description: Jack Tilton

title: Biographer as Hitchhiker in a President's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: At Wimpole, Keeping Up Appearances
description: You no longer need to be to the manner born to be lord of a manor, at least in England.

title: Bribe Inquiry May Delay Hundreds of Divorces
description: Hundreds of New York couples whose divorces are the focus of an investigation into bribes accepted by Manhattan's chief divorce court clerk may not know for months whether they are, in fact, legally married or legally divorced, court officials said yesterday.

title: Sampras's Manager Joins Ovitz's Group
description: Artists Management Group, the Los Angeles-based firm created by the former Disney head Michael Ovitz with Rick and Julie Yorn, announced yesterday that it has retained Jeff Schwartz, an attorney who manages the world's No. 1 tennis player, Pete Sampras, to head the company's newest division, A.M.G. Sports.

title: Take an Old Hit. Make It New.
description: Much of television is one giant recycling bin; a glance at Nick at Nite, TV Land or half a dozen other cable channels with shows older than their viewers is enough to tell you that. And as the first week of this new season comes to an end, it is obvious that recycling has gone far beyond cable's endless loop of ''Happy Days.'' Repurposing (the latest code word for recycling) is the story of the season's supposedly fresh network shows, too. Several series that begin this weekend test the theory that what works for old Coke cans and milk cartons may also work for ''Charlie's Angels'' and ''The Wonder Years.''

title: No Radio Contact With NASA Spacecraft : Orbiter Believed Lost Upon Arrival at Mars
description: WASHINGTON  A NASA spacecraft billed as the first interplanetary weather satellite was presumed to have been lost Thursday while entering a Mars orbit in what is a serious, if not crippling, blow to efforts to determine once and for all whether the red planet ever harbored life.

title: On My Mind; McCain's Fresh Air
description: Speaking with clean clarity, Senator John McCain has become the only Republican Presidential candidate to accept and pass a political and moral challenge that faces them all. He said exactly where Patrick Buchanan belonged in the Republican Party -- out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDNER, ROSWELL
description: WEIDNER-Roswell. September 22, 1999 of Philadelphia. Artist and teacher. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Kemp). Memorial services are to be conducted at a later date. For information Rachubinski Funeral Home, 215-468-7344.

title: The M.T.A. Removes 4 Huge Plaques From the Coliseum
description: Four enormous works by the sculptor Paul Manship, best loved for his golden Prometheus at Rockefeller Center, were taken from their perch above Columbus Circle before dawn yesterday and spirited off to Connecticut.

title: New Owners of Grizzlies Have Ties With St. Louis
description: When Commissioner David Stern awarded Vancouver a National Basketball Association franchise, the hope was that the sport would catch fire in Canada and spark more global interest in the game.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Centralized Price System Proposed for Stock Trading

title: Prosperity Doesn't Age Well
description: I am not sure how to break it to my students as they boot up their computers and get back to studying American history this fall. But I do feel compelled to tell them: Enjoy this remarkable boom while it lasts, for your historical reputation is toast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, BEULAH
description: KATZENSTEIN-Beulah. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of our devoted member, Beulah Katzenstein. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her daughters, Barbara and Marjorie, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 16 about the pressures that threaten Broadway's smaller theaters misstated the number of balconies in the Helen Hayes Theater. It is one, not two.

description: THE GREAT SHAME

title: Police Are Criticized for Responding More Slowly to 911 Calls
description: As New York City has experienced a historic drop in crime in recent years and its Police Department has grown to its largest size ever, the amount of time it takes police officers to respond to 911 calls has become longer, according to separate reports from the Mayor's office and the City Council.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Police Used in Stings to Weed Out Violent Officers
description: The New York Police Department, long under fire from critics and Federal prosecutors who contend that it coddles abusive officers, has been quietly running an unusual program in which undercover officers pose as angry citizens in elaborate sting operations intended to weed out officers with a propensity for violence.

title: North Carolina Radio Sale
description: Cumulus Media Inc., an owner of radio stations in midsize markets, has agreed to buy six North Carolina radio stations -- two in Wilmington and four in Fayetteville -- from the Cape Fear Companies for $47 million in cash and stock. Subject to regulatory approval, the acquisition will give Cumulus, based in Milwaukee, a total of 261 stations. That would make it the nation's third-largest owner of radio stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROY, FLORENCE W.
description: TROY-Florence W. On September 22, 1999. Devoted wife of the late William A. Troy. Loving mother of Aileen and Alan Janover. Proud Ranny of Tom and Sarah, Jim and Marcy. Adored great Ranny of William, Kate and Leah. Friends may call on Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services Friday, September 24, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

description: THACHER-Peter Shaw. A memorial tribute to the life of Peter Shaw Thacher, a longtime international civil servant and lifelong defender of the environment, will be held at 3:15 P.M. on Monday, Sept. 27, at UN Church Centre, 777 UN Plaza, New York City.

description: Washburn

title: Sports of The Times; New U.S. History for an Old Site
description: WITH the Ryder Cup matches not far from where Paul Revere rode, the United States golfers should have a historical home-course advantage. This is where America teed off. British tea was dumped into the Boston harbor. Lexington and Concord are just down the road. So is Bunker Hill.

title: Editorial Observer; Falling Under the Thrall of Ronald Reagan
description: Edmund Morris's ''Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan'' has yet to reach its publication date and is being embargoed by Rottweilers at Random House -- but has already become the most reviled political biography in recent memory. Fair-minded people will read the book before deciding whether or not to call for the author's literary head. But it is clear from portions of ''Dutch'' being secreted around Manhattan that something went terribly wrong between Mr. Morris and the President whose ''authorized'' biography this was meant to be.

title: A Taste for Clatter, Including Popping Bubble Wrap
description: David Parker and the Bang Group danced boisterously away in ''Beat-if-ica-tion,'' the program they offered on Tuesday night in the Carnival series at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ROSALIND
description: ROSENTHAL-Rosalind. Wife of the late Morton Rosenthal. Mother of Judy Rosenthal, Jane Goldman, Sarah Hart and John Rosenthal. Mother-in-law of John R. Goldman and Nancy S. Rosenthal. Grandmother of Bruce and Carolyn Goldman, Jill and Kate Hart, Linda and Charlie Rosenthal. Services are private.

title: Earthquake Survivors Ponder the Future
description: The front half of Wang Chong-shih's third-floor apartment has disappeared, but the rear half remains intact.

title: New Year's Sights to Startle Even the Sober
description: On Dec. 31, the crush of people expected to gather in Times Square to see in the year 2000 will encounter some startling sights: an undulating, 40-foot-long snake puppet, fabric ants and butterflies with 40-foot wingspans, as icons of the rain forests of the Amazon. Also, a 22-foot-long elephant, symbolizing India, and artificial cherry blossoms raining down, for Japan.

title: Regions of Italy
description: Italian restaurants are no longer simply Italian, or even southern or northern Italian. More and more they emphasize the food of a particular region, as these 12 restaurants do. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: REUTERS SHARES HIT HARD
description: Shares of Reuters Group P.L.C., the financial information provider, dropped 15 percent in London, devaluing the company by $2.95 billion, after analysts downgraded their forecasts for the company. Analysts said that after a meeting with company officials on Wednesday they were concerned about growth at Reuters electronic trading division, Instinet. Shares of Reuters fell 127.5 pence, or $2.09, to 726 pence. In the United States, the shares fell nearly 11 percent on the Nasdaq market, dropping $8.75, to $71. The company said that nothing was said at the briefing that could be construed as a profit forecast or warning and that it had not released any price-sensitive information.

title: $350 MILLION INTERNET STOCK SWAP
description: The Internet venture fund company CMGI Inc., based in Andover, Mass., and Pacific Century Cyberworks Ltd., a high-speed Internet provider in Hong Kong, said they would swap $350 million in stock in CMGI's first investment in Asia. CMGI will take a 5.5 percent stake in Cyberworks, and Cyberworks is buying about a 3.5 percent stake in CMGI. CMGI also signed a letter of intent to become a tenant of the Cyberport, a technology park in Hong Kong that Cyberworks is building. Pacific Century Cyberworks is a unit of the closely held Pacific Century Group. Richard Li, a Hong Kong Internet entrepreneur, is a major shareholder in Pacific Century Group.

title: Medicare Cheating Spreads Its Harm Around
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Jones Makes Opponents Pay for Not Walking Him
description: Ten cases of Korbel California champagne sat on a hand truck in the Atlanta clubhouse waiting to be loaded with the rest of the Braves' equipment for their trip to Montreal and New York. The champagne was accompanying the Braves in anticipation of their celebrating their eighth consecutive division championship.

title: NESTLE HAS SLIGHT GAIN
description: Nestle S.A, the world's largest food maker, said first-half profit was little changed as it spent savings from efficiency gains to promote products like Nescafe coffee and Kit Kat candy bars. Net income rose to 2.08 billion Swiss francs ($1.37 billion), or 53.5 francs a share, from a restated 2.07 billion, or 52.6 francs. Earnings per share rose faster than net after Nestle bought back some of its own stock. The company also repeated a forecast of higher full-year earnings and sales.

title: A Struggle Over Culture And Turf at Auto Giant
description: When Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation merged nearly a year ago, a buzz of excitement went through Detroit on the report that Thomas T. Stallkamp, the president of Chrysler, would become the president of the new company, DaimlerChrysler A.G., and might someday become the chairman.

title: Open Arms at Season's Opening Night
description: Greeting guests at the door with hard questions is not the New York Philharmonic's idea of hospitality. So Thursday evening's opening of the season at Avery Fisher Hall, a prelude to dining and dancing and a subject of scrutiny by public television, became instead what pop songs of old used to call ''a warm embrace.''

title: Clinton Asked Ex-Aides' Help To Buy House
description: In the tense days and hours before and after they signed an agreement to buy a white house in Chappaqua, N.Y., for $1.7 million, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton sought financial assistance from former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and two former White House chiefs of staff, according to several people with knowledge of the arrangement.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: George Plans to Continue But With Two Fewer Issues

title: Novelists Get Back at Hollywood, Mostly Gently
description: The idea of the work of a great novelist being destroyed by Hollywood is something of a cliche in American culture. But in fact, most of the writers on an Authors Guild Foundation panel at the Ethical Culture Society on Thursday night seemed quite happy to take the money and run. They included Scott Turow, Russell Banks and Walter Mosley, as well as the screenwriter Stephen Schiff, who adapted Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lolita'' for the screen and has made a career of performing that kind of surgery. The lone holdout of the group was E. L. Doctorow, the author of ''Ragtime,'' which Milos Forman turned into a film in 1981.

title: Improve Bus Service and Soon, Blunt Judge Tells Los Angeles
description: A Federal District Court judge took a further step in directing the operations of one of the nation's largest mass transit operators with a bluntly worded decision late Thursday ordering the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority to acquire 248 more buses to ease overcrowding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSFORD, IRVING B.
description: KINGSFORD-Irving B. age 80 On Sept. 22, Princeton, N.J. Survived by his wife Martha Kingsford, children Daniel, Michael, Kathleen Davis, stepdaughters Anne, Betsey & Eleanor & three grandchildren. Memorial Service Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, at 10 AM Saturday, September 25.

title: Ex-Premier Andreotti Acquitted of Mafia Murder Conspiracy
description: Jurors today acquitted Giulio Andreotti, a towering figure in postwar politics who was Prime Minister seven times, of conspiring with the Mafia in the 1979 murder of a muckraking journalist.

title: Ivan Goff, Writer and Producer, Is Dead at 89
description: Ivan Goff, co-creator of the television series ''Charlie's Angels'' and co-writer of the films ''White Heat,'' ''Captain Horatio Hornblower'' and ''Man of a Thousand Faces,'' died on Thursday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 89 and lived in Malibu.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Third in Mexican Polls, a Leftist Campaigner Manages to Project Optimism
description: Near the end of one of his last days as Mexico City Mayor, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano was in his office, reviewing a dismal newspaper poll that showed that far more city residents disapproved of his City Hall performance than approved.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, ILSE
description: WINKLER-Ilse. Sisterhood of Congregation Habonim mourns the passing of our devoted member and past President. We wish to express our sympathy and condolences to the family. We will always fondly remember her.

title: After the Tax Cut Veto
description: Now that President Clinton has vetoed the Republicans' $792 billion tax bill as expected, Congress and the White House can settle down to the difficult business of negotiating on next year's budget. Time is short. With the budget year starting officially in less than a week, few of the spending bills needed for the start of the fiscal year have even passed Congress. Washington seems poised for another last-minute showdown or a series of continuing resolutions to keep the Government going.

title: Re-entry to Index Could Lure Back Funds : Is Malaysia a Safe Bet?
description: KUALA LUMPUR  In a perfect world, stock market investors would pick companies purely on the basis of economic fundamentals.

title: Abortion Laws Voided
description: A Federal appeals court in St. Louis ruled that laws in three states banning a type of late-term abortion were unconstitutional. The court said the laws were too broad.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN JOINS WORLD BANK
description: Dr. Mamphela Ramphele, the head of the University of Cape Town, was named a managing director of the World Bank, making her the first African to hold a senior post at the bank. A prominent black consciousness advocate, anthropologist and physician, Dr. Ramphele, 51, will direct the bank's efforts in health, education and social protection when she joins the Washington-based institution next year. As vice chancellor of the University of Cape Town since 1996, she has presided over the university's transition into the post-apartheid era, pressing forward with integration while trying to uphold standards. Henri E. Cauvin

title: OFFER FOR INSURER
description: AMP Ltd., Australia's biggest fund manager, is offering to buy the remaining 43 percent of GIO Australia Ltd. it does not own for $827 million (Australian), or $536 million (United States), to tackle losses at the general insurer. The offer, which equals $3.05 (Australian) a share, comes less than nine months after shareholders rejected a bid of $5.35 a share from AMP for GIO, one of the country's top six insurers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JOE
description: SHAPIRO-Joe, 52. Born in New York, December 5, 1946 to Abraham and Harriet Shapiro. Died September 23, 1999, Los Angeles, CA. Loving and beloved husband of Pam Shriver, tennis champion and professional tennis commentator. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and received his law degree from Harvard with honors. Before his death he taught at Cal State University Los Angeles. Previously he served as Executive Vice President of Walt Disney Company. His passing is mourned by his wife, his in-laws, close friends, his sister Beth Shapiro and her family.

title: Sigrid de Lima, 77, Whimsical Novelist of the 50's
description: Sigrid de Lima, a writer whose early works won praise but who withdrew from public life in midcareer, died on Sunday at a hospital in Nyack, N.Y. She was 77 and lived in Valley Cottage, N.Y.

title: Press Freedoms in Zimbabwe
description: As he struggles with economic ills and an unpopular war in Congo, Zimbabwe's President, Robert Mugabe, is cracking down on the independent press and its ability to question his authoritarian rule. The most egregious violations of human rights were committed against two journalists who were detained and tortured by the military in January. Mark Chavunduka, editor of The Standard, a weekly newspaper, and Ray Choto, a reporter for the same paper, were taken into custody by the military after they published a report about the arrest of 23 members of the army who were plotting an overthrow of the Mugabe Government.

title: Striving to Be the Best At Something, Anything
description: Benoit Mariage's wry and accomplished first feature, ''The Carriers Are Waiting,'' is a deadpan, minimalist fable about perfectionism gone haywire. It takes place in a drab Belgian factory town and concerns the family of a dour tabloid photographer (Benoit Poelvoorde). In his line of work, one occupational hazard is never being quite satisfied with the ordinary world. The photographer feels a constant urge to embellish reality, as when he tries to take a picture of an old couple whose cornfield was ruined by a hailstorm. Not much drama to that once the storm is over.

title: Hurricanes on the Hudson
description: As a kid growing up on Long Island's South Shore in a largely glass house surrounded by tall trees, I always envied people who lived in Manhattan. I saw the city as a fortress against foul weather, the kind of place where a guy could enjoy a hurricane rather than worry about it.

title: Togetherness in Solitude: A Fertile Chemistry; Art Colonists Learn Creativity Can Be Communicable
description: Eric Moe, in T-shirt, baggy pants and running shoes, stood before the baby grand piano in the MacDowell Colony's well-worn library, ready to play his work-in-progress, ''Dance of the Honey Monkey.'' But first he wanted insight from the audience, two dozen or so writers, poets and visual artists who were also in residence at the famed colony here in the pine groves of southern New Hampshire.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Internet companies' use of stock options to attract freelance writers misstated the age of Rufus Griscom, editor in chief and chief executive of Nerve.com, one of those using the incentive. He is 31, not 28. The article also misstated a description his site has used about itself in the past. The phrase is ''literate smut,'' not literary smut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONLEY, JOHN
description: CONLEY-John M.D. The Department of Otolaryngology/Head & Neck Surgery at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and New York Presbyterian Hospital mourn the death of Dr. John Conley on September 21, 1999. Dr. Conley, Professor Emeritus of Clinical Otolaryngology/ Head & Neck Surgery and former Director of Head & Neck Surgery at Columbia, was internationally recognized as the Father of Modern Head & Neck Surgery. Lanny Garth Close, M.D. Professor and Chairman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST, Rockville, Md., and Regency Realty Corp., Jacksonville, Fla., said they had ended talks on the sale of Federal's strip shopping center properties after being unable to agree on a price.

title: A Top Expert on AIDS Policy Is Appointed to Run Medicaid
description: The Clinton Administration has chosen one of the nation's leading experts on AIDS policy to run Medicaid, the health insurance program for poor people and the disabled, Administration officials said today.

title: CENDANT TO SELL UNIT TO DOUGHTY HANSON OF LONDON
description: The Cendant Corporation, the direct marketer and hotel franchiser, agreed yesterday to sell a subsidiary that runs on-line clubs for golfers, hunters, and gardeners to Doughty Hanson & Company of London, one of Europe's largest private equity funds, for about $150 million. New York-based Cendant will receive about $140 million in cash for North American Outdoor Group, which is based in Minnetonka, Minn., and will retain 6 percent. Cendant expects to have a $107 million pretax gain in the fourth quarter, when the transaction is expected to close. The sale is part of plans by the chief executive, Henry Silverman, to sell businesses he says are not crucial to Cendant's strategy.

title: Religion Journal; Finessing a Conflict Regarding Homosexuality
description: Ten weeks ago, the Vatican ordered an American priest and a nun, the Rev. Robert Nugent and Sister Jeannine Gramick, known in Roman Catholic circles for their ministry to homosexuals, to halt that work.

title: Aged Upstart, College Board, Is Joining Gold Rush on Web
description: Under threat by the rapidly growing on-line industry that helps students prepare for and select colleges, the College Board, the nonprofit organization that administers the SAT, voted yesterday to create its first for-profit subsidiary in a move to establish a flashy full-service Web site of its own.

title: Ex-Chief of Staff Accuses Montana Senator of Sexual Harassment
description: Senator Max Baucus was accused of sexual harassment today in a complaint filed by a woman he dismissed last month as his chief of staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MARVIN
description: GOLDMAN-Marvin. The Covenant Foundation mourns the passing in Jerusalem on September 24 of Marvin Goldman, beloved father of our esteemed trustee, Ari L. Goldman. May the mourners find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Eli N. Evans, Chairman Dr. Judith Ginsberg Executive Director

title: Hostile Bid Brings an Investment Banker Back to the Fray
description: Don't expect executives of National Westminster Bank to shake hands with their former colleague Eric Gleacher anytime soon. They may have to wait for the bite marks to heal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, ADAM
description: RICHARD-Adam. Loving husband, father, stepfather, son, and brother. Died September 23rd. A memorial service will be held at Innis Arden, Old Greenwich, CT. Tuesday, September 28, at 11 A.M.

description: To the Editor:

title: O'Meara Rides the Bench
description: While the United States was being whipped at The Country Club today, Mark O'Meara and Steve Pate watched helplessly from the sideline.

title: Short Pieces That Travel the World and the Emotions
description: Rebecca Juliet Lazier, who comes from Nova Scotia, spent much time studying and dancing in New York, then went off to teach and choreograph in cities from Hartford to Istanbul. She celebrated her return to New York with ''Six Years Later'' on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo.

title: Baptists' Evangelism Concerns Jews
description: In a polite but pointed exchange of letters over the last two days, a Jewish organization in New York has protested the decision by the president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, to help convene a conference in Manhattan on evangelizing Jews.

title: Straining at the Leash, Humans Sniff at Love
description: It's all very simple. When Andy and Cheryl broke up, she took their dog, Mogley. Now Mogley is traumatized from watching Cheryl and her new boyfriend, Trevor, having wild sex.

title: PROFIT WARNING BY KROLL-O'GARA, SECURITY FIRM
description: Shares in Kroll-O'Gara Company, a leading security and private-investigation firm, fell 45 percent yesterday after it said it was considering selling itself and warned that third-quarter earnings would miss estimates. Kroll, based in Fairfield, Ohio, fell $11.50, to $14.3125, as 2.93 million shares changed hands, 21 times the average volume of the last three months. The company said Thursday night that it had hired Bear, Stearns & Company to explore alternatives, including a sale. It also said it would defer acquisitions originally planned for the third quarter and, because of that, earnings in the period should be reduced by a 12 to 14 cents a share.

title: LVMH ACQUIRES SHIRT MAKER
description: The luxury goods behemoth LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. announced that it had acquired Thomas Pink Holdings Ltd., the British retailer and maker of fashion shirts. Terms were not disclosed. The move is the latest in a spate of deals by the Paris-based company as it seeks to create efficiencies by controlling many premium brands. LVMH hopes to expand the Thomas Pink retail store chain in the United States and Europe. Thomas Pink currently has 20 stores, including 13 in London and one on Madison Avenue in New York.

title: INDIA TV VENTURE AMENDED
description: Star Television Ltd., a part of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said it was exiting its ventures with Zee Telefilms Ltd., which runs the most popular television network in India. Zee said it would pay $296.5 million in stock and cash for half of the stakes Star owns in Asia Today Ltd., which broadcasts Zee's programs; Siticable Ltd., which distributes its fare, and the Programming Asia Trading Company, which makes soap operas and sitcoms in the Hindi language for Zee.

title: Teen-Ager Pleads Guilty in School Shooting
description: Just days before his trial was to begin, Kipland P. Kinkel, the Oregon teen-ager who went on a shooting rampage last year, killing his parents and then two students at his school, abandoned his insanity defense today and pleaded guilty to the charges.

title: Clinton Tries to Reassure Party on Gore Candidacy
description: In a passionate political speech, President Clinton today tried to reassure his fellow Democrats that Vice President Al Gore was a strong Presidential candidate, that Mr. Gore had an unusually positive economy to run on and that it was way too early to worry about his prospects.

title: The Mayor as Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert G. Heath, 84, Researcher Into the Causes of Schizophrenia
description: Dr. Robert G. Heath, a physician and medical researcher at Tulane University who was best known for his ground-breaking work on schizophrenia, died on Tuesday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 84.

title: Jakarta Delays Security Bill as Riots Rage
description: Yielding to a wave of violent unrest, President B. J. Habibie said today that he would delay signing an unpopular security law that was rushed through Parliament on Thursday.

title: France Shops for Another Pretty Face
description: Early statues show a young woman with a helmet on her head and armor over her breast. Later, Marianne looked virginal in a translucent dress. Brigitte Bardot and Catherine Deneuve have posed for statues of her. Those versions -- replicated in the workshops of the Louvre -- grace city halls across the country.

title: Giuliani Criticizes 'Catholic Bashing'
description: As lawyers for the city plotted strategies to block a controversial exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani angrily offered another argument yesterday for why the show is unacceptable: he said it reflected a widespread acceptance of ''Catholic bashing.''

title: Asians Worry About Cost of East Timor Role
description: Trying to extricate themselves from a long-running financial crisis, Indonesia's Southeast Asian neighbors are concerned about how long their presence will be needed in East Timor and what their participation in the international force will cost them, Thailand's Foreign Minister said today.

title: Elementary Schools Still Overcrowded
description: For months, Miriam Correa looked forward to the opening of school, elated over a state and Federal program that she heard would keep class sizes small and maybe help her daughter, a second grader, with her reading.

title: SECURITY FIRST TECHNOLOGIES ADDS VERTICALONE
description: The Security First Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Verticalone Corporation through a stock transaction valued at about $166 million. Security First, which is based in Atlanta, builds and operates Internet applications for financial institutions. Verticalone, also of Atlanta, consolidates and presents personal account information via the Internet. Security First already is in the process of acquiring FICS Group N.V. of Belgium, a financial software company, and the Edify Corporation, a software company in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: For Higher Scores, N.B.A. Tweaks Defense and the Clock
description: The no-harm, no-foul National Basketball Association is on the verge of becoming a ticky-tack league. And depending how soon players and referees adjust, the game may get uglier before it gets prettier.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Saddam Hussein of Iraq misidentified one of the three permanent members of the United Nations Security Council that want less stringent conditions for easing sanctions on his country than those being advocated by Britain and the Netherlands. The member, along with France and China, is Russia, not Britain.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIPS. With currency traders on edge before the Group of Seven finance ministers' meeting this weekend, the dollar edged up against both the yen and the euro. The dollar rose to 104.17 yen from 103.95 in New York.

title: What It Costs to Make a Handbag
description: To the Editor:

title: Tupa Hits the Heights: Praise by Parcells
description: Tom Tupa wears a helmet like no other punter's: it has a microphone so he can listen to the plays being sent in to the quarterback.

title: In the Man-Versus-Nature Battle, This One Went to Nature
description: Looking at Michael Powell's 1937 film, ''The Edge of the World,'' you would hardly guess that this early work by the great British director emanated from the same hand that 11 years later gave us the balletic opulence of ''The Red Shoes.'' Exquisitely photographed in black and white, the film gazes with such concentrated awe upon the steep, craggy landscape of Foula, a remote, wind-and-rain-battered Scottish island in the North Sea, that certain sequences produce a sense of vertigo.

title: The Opera Is New, But Is It Good?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEY, IRVING
description: SHEY-Irving, Dr. The Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine records with profound sadness the loss of our beloved Associate Clinical Professor Emeritus, Irving A. Shey, M.D. He was a true role model for our discipline. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Evelyn, and to their children and grandchildren. Irwin R. Merkatz, M.D. Professor & University Chairman

title: Wisconsin's Humble Candidate
description: Eddie Faulkner and Chris McIntosh have been there for every one of Ron Dayne's 5,087 yards at Wisconsin.

title: The Attack on Campus Drinking
description: Few parents could have missed a tongue-in-cheek advertisement for ''binge beer'' in 17 newspapers this month that was signed by the presidents of 113 colleges and universities. Intended to alarm parents about the ''thousands of college students'' who ''binge,'' it was a novel effort by universities to get parents involved in a dialogue with their children before they leave home. It is estimated that half the students who engage in high-risk drinking in college begin drinking heavily in high school.

title: France and Australia Grab Early Leads
description: Australia and France took early leads yesterday in the Davis Cup semifinals. Wayne Arthurs and Lleyton Hewitt put host Australia in front of Russia, 2-0, in Brisbane, on opening day of the three-of-five-match semifinal. France led Belgium, 2-0, in the other semifinal.

title: Electrician Is Found Guilty of Punching a Police Horse
description: A member of the jury called the case ''ridiculous,'' a ''waste'' and a ''big joke,'' but yesterday he and his peers found James Hornacek, a 35-year-old union electrician, guilty of punching a police horse named Snewser in midtown Manhattan last June.

title: British Airlines Join in Venture
description: British Airways P.L.C., Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd. and seven other British airlines have formed a group that plans to bid for 51 percent of Britain's air traffic control system.

title: Ballerina's Ovarian Tissue Transplant Gives Hope to Other Young Women Facing Infertility
description: An operation that appears to have restored fertility to a young woman whose ovaries had been removed has offered hope to thousands of other young women facing infertility brought on by cancer treatment or benign conditions like ovarian cysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, MOLLA
description: JAFFIN-Molla. On September 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Abraham (Al). Dear sister of the late Nettie Karp. Devoted cousin and friend. Her warmth and generosity will be greatly missed. Service Sunday 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: North Korea Says It Will Halt Missile Tests During U.S. Talks
description: In a terse announcement that seemed to confirm recent diplomatic advances, the North Korean Government today publicly stated that it would refrain from further missile tests while talks with the United States are underway.

title: Mixed Outlook in Latin America
description: NEW YORK  The battle cry of portfolio managers who invest exclusively in Latin America might well be, "Wait until next year."

title: Bill Moyers and the Poets, Talking and Listening Both
description: Television is a lot of things, but it is very rarely nourishing to the soul. Leave it to Bill Moyers, that journalistic seeker of wisdom, to find a way: ''Fooling With Words: With Bill Moyers.''

title: PLUS: N.H.L. -- PRESEASON
description: Devils 6, Penguins 1

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELSKIN, ESTELLE
description: BELSKIN-Estelle. Sept. 25, 1899Dec. 1, 1992. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, cherished mother, darling grandmother of the late Eric, devoted mother-in-law of the late Sam. Lovely remembered always. Jeanne

title: Herbert V. Shuster, 75, Consumer Products Tester
description: Herbert V. Shuster, a food scientist who founded one of the nation's oldest consumer product testing companies, died Monday at a nursing home in the Brighton section of Boston, where he had been for several days. He was 75 years old and lived in Waban, Mass.

title: African Virus May Be Culprit In Mosquito-Borne Illnesses
description: The mosquito-borne illness that has killed three people in New York City may not be St. Louis encephalitis, as experts have thought, but rather a similar disease that has never been diagnosed in the Western Hemisphere, Government scientists said yesterday.

title: Talking to Mother and Other Totems
description: The notion of an intrinsic national or regional character is investigated in ''Sicilia!,'' Jean-Marie Straub and Daniele Huillet's austere and pretentiously minimalistic screen adaptation of Elio Vittorini's celebrated 1939 novel, ''Conversazione in Sicilia'' (''Conversations in Sicily''). The Sicilians who discourse in the film, sometimes casually and sometimes in intense personal conversations, tend to speak in cadences that echo the fervency of Italian opera. The culture they evoke is proudly earthbound, its values rooted in long-standing pre-modern traditions of honor and warfare and a stereotypically Italianate machismo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSNER, ROBERT
description: ROSSNER-Robert. On September 13. Age 67. Teacher and writer. Loving father of Jean Katherine, Daniel, Talya and Zoe. Brother of Janet Shepard and grandfather of Jacob & Matthew. His wit, humor, intelligence and spirit will live on for the many who loved him.

title: The Astonishing Giant
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times listing in some editions of Weekend yesterday about the Kids 'n' Comedy Show tomorrow at Caroline's, Broadway at 49th Street in Manhattan, misstated the starting time. It is 3 P.M., not 4.

title: Millennial Opportunities At Team Events in Bermuda
description: Many of the world's top players are already looking forward to 2000, when they will gather in Bermuda in January to compete for the Bermuda Bowl and the Venice Cup. In these events they will represent their countries, but many more will compete in the Transnational Teams, which is not restricted in this way.

title: Humanitarianism Without Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Pedal to Be Examined After Fatal Midtown Crash
description: The gas pedal of the car that plowed into a midtown Manhattan restaurant on Thursday night, killing one and injuring 21, might have been stuck, investigators said yesterday. The driver, Marcia Feltingoff, 51, of West New York, N.J., has not been charged.

title: I.B.M.'S $810 MILLION ACQUISITION OF SEQUENT COMPLETED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation completed its $810 million purchase of Sequent Computer Systems Inc. yesterday, giving it parts and software for advanced computer servers. Sequent's components and software string together processors from the Intel Corporation to handle big data bases and process on-line transactions. I.B.M. will sell Sequent servers alongside its own, providing machines that run both the Microsoft Corporation's Windows NT and the rival Unix software. I.B.M. rose $3, to $125. Sequent is based in Beaverton, Ore.

title: Flecks of the Moon on the Market? Irate NASA Steps In
description: To the untrained eye, the black plastic desk set resembles a tacky paperweight: a glob of plastic stuck on top is speckled with brown spots, and peeling strips of foil border a photograph of men on the Moon.

title: A Spiritual Vision Imbues The Trials Of a Blind Boy
description: In one way or another, the cinema of every nationality addresses the tenuous relationship of man and nature (in the United States it tends to be through bloated disaster epics like ''Twister''). But in Iran this grandest of themes is almost a national obsession. And in Majid Majidi's stunningly beautiful film, ''The Color of Heaven,'' that relationship is evoked with an ecstatic sensuousness along with an awed awareness of nature's destructive power that are nothing less than extraordinary.

title: HIGHER UNEMPLOYMENT IN BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian unemployment rate rose to 8.3 percent in August from 8.1 percent in July, despite a gradual reduction of interest rates by the central bank intended to stimulate economic activity. The news came a day after the central bank in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, cut its base rate for the 11th time this year, to 19 percent from 19.5 percent. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, ELAINE SURUT HERMAN
description: FENTON-Elaine Surut Herman, on September 24, 1999 at age 77. Mother of Tom Herman and Kerry Herman. Grandmother of Dyanna Elizabeth Hallick. Motherin-law of Marilyn Lytle Herman and Ned Hallick. Wife of Robert E. Herman, who died in 1966. Wife of David Fenton from 1974 until he died in 1985. Daughter of the late Ruth and Louis Surut. Family will greet visitors at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Sunday, Sept. 26, 4-7PM. Services Monday, September 27, 9:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St. In lieu of flowers gifts may be sent to The Browning School, Development Office, 52 E 62 St, NYC 10021 or The Berkeley Carroll School, Development Office, 181 Lincoln Place, Bklyn. NY 11217.

title: Investigation of Kickbacks Is Believed to Be Widening
description: Paul J. Silvester, the former Connecticut State Treasurer who has pleaded guilty to taking kickbacks, is providing Federal investigators with detailed information about possibly illegal payments to politicians in an attempt to dramatically cut his prison time, according to officials and lawyers involved in the investigation.

title: Seeking Buzz, Museum Chief Hears a Roar Instead
description: Arnold L. Lehman, the aggressive, Barnumesque director of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, need not look far for an artistic expression of what is at stake in his standoff with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has vowed to deprive the museum of public money because of his distaste for a coming exhibition of contemporary art.

title: Day of High Expectation Ends With High Anxiety
description: The quality of golf was superb, but the outcome was shocking.

title: What It Costs to Make a Handbag
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday about embargoes -- release-date agreements to conceal book contents until publication -- misstated the final outcome of a 1979 suit against The Nation magazine for unauthorized publication of excerpts from the unpublished memoirs of President Gerald R. Ford. As noted in the column, Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled the publication a copyright infringement, and that ruling was reversed by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Ultimately, though, the Supreme Court sided against The Nation.

title: President? Why Not? Says a Man at the Top
description: Donald J. Trump was sitting in his office on the 26th floor of the Trump Tower the other afternoon, with Central Park stretching out 50 blocks behind him, and a desktop of newspaper clippings spilling out in front of him, all addressing Mr. Trump's latest venture: Presidential politics. And in case anyone finds the notion of President Trump unsettling, the real estate developer and casino owner was prepared with evidence to validate his potential candidacy.

title: Humanitarianism Without Limits
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON KESNER, SARA
description: CITRON KESNER-Sara. The children, family and friends of Sara Citron Kesner mourn deeply her passing on September 21st. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, she is survived by her children, Harvey Citron and Rebecca Nunberg and by her grandchildren, Samuel, Raphael and Isabelle Nunberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, JULIUS
description: HELLER-Julius. Beloved and devoted father of Marcia Gamliel and Marian. Dear brother of William and Al. Loving grandfather of Yasmin Amir and Nadav and Yuval. Great grandfather of Roi. Services Sunday. Call ''Parkside'' Chapels for further information 718896-9000.

title: Cramer, 17, Named To Fill In for Hamm
description: The teen-ager Aleisha Cramer will replace the injured Mia Hamm on the United States women's soccer team roster for tomorrow's game against Brazil in Denver.

title: Good Fortune by the Cupful; Brazil Coffee Producers Turn to the High-End Market
description: At an air-conditioned compound carved out of the rolling green hills of southeastern Brazil, the headquarters of the coffee plantation overseen by Washington Luiz Alves Rodrigues buzzes with the kind of intensity one expects at an Internet start-up.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Political Memo; On Display at City Hall, 2 Catholics, 2 Views
description: They are both Italian-Americans from boroughs outside Manhattan whose Roman Catholic upbringing often defines who they are. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yearns for the days when parochial school uniforms instilled a sense of order; City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone spends his free time organizing spiritual retreats.

title: Australians in Show of Force in East Timor
description: As departing Indonesian soldiers marched with their duffel bags toward this city's port today, the foreign troops who are replacing them staged an aggressive show of force, sealing off and searching the city center for hours as helicopters circled and clattered above them.

title: DRUGSTORE CHAIN IS PLANNING TO CUT ABOUT 830 WORKERS
description: The Rite Aid Corporation, the drugstore chain troubled by a plunging stock and a racketeering suit filed in Florida this week, said yesterday that it would dismiss about 830 workers. About 330 corporate and regional staff employees, many in the Harrisburg, Pa., area, were dismissed effective yesterday, and the company will close a distribution center in Ogden, Utah, next year, eliminating 500 more jobs. Rite Aid employs a total of 85,000 workers in its 3,800-store chain. Rite Aid stock has dropped 75 percent since reaching a 52-week high of $50.9375 in January as the retailer struggled to open stores and integrate acquisitions to compete against two larger rivals, the Walgreen Company and the CVS Corporation. Shares of Rite Aid fell $1, to $11 yesterday.

title: Bank Scandal and Timor Crisis Hurt Indonesia Recovery
description: SINGAPORE  The crisis in East Timor and a banking scandal with major political implications have undermined the confidence of international creditors and investors in the government of President B.J. Habibie of Indonesia, to the point of jeopardizing the recovery of the badly battered economy and financial system of the world's fourth most populous nation.

title: France Calls U.S. Callous For Allowing Iraq to Suffer
description: Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France today accused the United States of insensitivity to the ''human disaster'' in Iraq caused by economic sanctions.

title: Emerging From a Coma Into a Beckettian World
description: Some of the arid humor of Samuel Beckett drifts through Kiyoshi Kurosawa's droll, absurdist ''License to Live,'' a fable about a 24-year-old man who unexpectedly awakens from a decadelong coma and tries to piece together a world that has shattered during his slumber. That world is a far cry from the steel-and-concrete skyscrapers of modern Tokyo. It is more like a giant, sprawling junkyard.

title: YAHOO SITE IN CHINA
description: Yahoo Inc., the top Internet search service, said it would create an Internet directory site tailored for Web users in China, expanding its presence on the mainland even as the country moves to restrict foreign investment in its information technology. Under a joint venture with the Beijing Founder Electronics Company, a unit of Founder (Hong Kong) Ltd., the company will form Yahoo China, which will provide links to more than 20,000 Chinese-language Web sites and offer news, finance and technology information as well as E-mail and instant messaging.

title: ENGAGE TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO BUY ADKNOWLEDGE
description: Engage Technologies Inc., an Internet marketing company controlled by CMGI Inc., agreed yesterday to buy Adknowledge Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., for $193 million in stock to add customers and Web advertising services. CMGI, the United States Internet venture fund company, will initially acquire an 85 percent stake in Adknowledge for $170 million in CMGI shares. Engage will acquire the remaining 15 percent of Adknowledge for $23 million in Engage shares. In the third step, Engage will issue $170 million in Engage shares to CMGI for the 85 percent stake in Adknowledge that CMGI bought in the first step. Adknowledge provides consulting and marketing software that helps advertisers plan and execute their ad campaigns.

title: N.H.L. Seeks Aid to Keep Canada's Sport in Canada
description: In a bid to keep hockey, the Canadian national sport, in Canada, the National Hockey League has asked the Canadian Government to subsidize the country's six major-league hockey teams by more than $30 million a year.

title: Falcons Expect Chandler Back
description: Atlanta Falcons quarterback Chris Chandler is expected to start Sunday's game against the St. Louis Rams after missing Monday night's loss to Dallas with a strained hamstring, the team said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They really want the Bardot, but their wives object. One mayor came here with his wife and she was quite shocked when she saw the breasts. I managed to reassure her by telling her that most of the time, the statue wears a Tricolor sash that covers all that up.''

title: Welfare Officials To Search Records Of Drug Treatment
description: The Giuliani administration is planning to search thousands of medical billing records for evidence it can use to place welfare applicants in mandatory drug and alcohol treatment programs as a condition of receiving public assistance, city welfare officials say.

title: YankeeNets Business Deal Approved by Steinbrenner
description: Although the deal remains subject to approval by Major League Baseball and very likely by baseball owners, George Steinbrenner and his new partners have signed the papers creating a holding company called YankeeNets, a business executive with knowledge of the deal said yesterday.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING TO SPIN OFF ITS TESTING COMPANY
description: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., which tutors students and trains educators, said yesterday that it would spin off its computerized testing company, Prometric Inc., and sell as much as a 20 percent stake to the public. Prometric, which accounted for 41 percent of Sylvan's 1998 sales of $448.3 million, will use proceeds to expand internationally and pay Sylvan for past investments. Sylvan is based in Baltimore.

title: Some Shareholders Sue Bank of New York
description: A shareholders lawsuit was filed yesterday against the Bank of New York Company and its directors, accusing them of allowing Russian organized crime figures to launder billions of dollars through the bank illegally.

title: Cardinal Helps Propel Bid to Unionize Limousine Drivers
description: With a behind-the-scenes boost from John Cardinal O'Connor, a campaign to unionize New York's nearly 12,000 black-car drivers took a major step forward this week when a limousine company that has fought unionization for two years signed a union contract.

title: Excerpts From Buchanan's New Volume
description: Following are excerpts from the book ''A Republic, Not an Empire'' by Patrick J. Buchanan:

title: Journal; The Long Shadow of the Texas Sniper
description: Another killing, another show. When Larry Ashbrook opened fire in a Fort Worth church last week, this much was certain: the tragedy would trigger a new flood of sound and fury signifying very little. The mass murders of the past year have proved a fatal attraction for cable news networks seeking ratings and politicians seeking votes, and the Fort Worth installment might still be going on had not the potentially more lethal Hurricane Floyd drowned it out.

title: Its Eurex Exchange Humbles LIFFE for Coveted Bund Business : Frankfurt Makes It Into Big Leagues
description: FRANKFURT  To the uninitiated, this German banking city of 650,000 can seem appallingly provincial. Locals drink apple wine by the pitcher and night life can be hard to find.

title: Reform Party Unsettled By Quest for a Nominee
description: After struggling to create the most successful third party in 80 years, many longtime members of the Reform Party say they are growing more fearful by the day that they will be left as virtual bystanders if Patrick J. Buchanan or another famous person decides to flood the party with supporters in pursuit of its Presidential nomination.

title: Russian and Belgian Advance to Semis
description: Lina Krasnoroutskaya, a 15-year-old Russian playing in her second Women's Tennis Association event, defeated sixth-seeded Silvia Farina of Italy, 0-6, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $180,000 Seat Open in Luxembourg.

title: Man Charged in Attempt To Kill Subway Attacker
description: A Bronx man was charged with attempted homicide yesterday after stabbing a robber who had grabbed a woman's gold chain on the stairs to a subway station, the police said.

title: Arizona Governor Expected to Endorse Bush Over State's 2 Favorite Sons
description: Gov. Jane Dee Hull of Arizona, who held out longer than most other Republican governors before endorsing anyone for the party's Presidential nomination, has decided to back Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, according to people close to both politicians.

title: Family, Employees and Charities Named in Kennedy Will
description: John F. Kennedy Jr.'s personal belongings will go to his sister's children and his money to a multimillion-dollar trust benefiting relatives, friends, longtime family employees and two charities, according to documents filed yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMAN, SIDNEY
description: KRAMAN-Sidney. Beloved husband of Adely. Devoted father of Kathy Hayes and Richard and father-in-law of Jayne. Loving grandfather of Kyla, William, Maxwell and Luke. Dear brother of Hyman, sisters, Anne and Shirley. Service Sunday, 10 AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, NYC. The family requests that donations in his memory be sent to The Hassenfeld Center Brain Tumor Program, Attn: Dr. Jonathan Finlay, 317 E. 34 St., NY, NY 10016.

title: Dennis Rodman, a Terror for Terrorists
description: ''When did Interpol start hiring sideshow freaks?'' a character asks early in ''Simon Sez.''

title: Big Selloff Eases, but Investors Remain Concerned
description: After a volatile day of trading during which all the major indexes were down sharply, stocks rebounded yesterday and finished off slightly. But while the market held together after a big selloff Thursday, a host of concerns, including higher interest rates, a weaker dollar and overvalued technology stocks, will continue to trouble investors.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday on mercury in New York reservoirs misidentifed the party affiliation of Senator James Jeffords of Vermont. He is a Republican, not a Democrat. In addition, the location of the Neversink Reservoir was misstated. It is in Sullivan, not Delaware, County.

title: Humanitarianism Without Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bad Day In the Life Of a Bad Film Critic
description: French dinner parties are beginning to scare me. First there was that surrealistic one (or many) in ''The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeosie.'' Now there's a psychological nightmare of one in ''Rien sur Robert'' (''Nothing on Robert''), Pascal Bonitzer's quirky, enjoyable but sometimes off-putting comedy about a film critic who should just go back to bed.

title: Heroin Smuggler Files Lawsuit Over Surgery to Retrieve Drugs
description: In March 1998, William Meequaye Kanyi arrived at Kennedy International Airport from his home country, Ghana, and immediately aroused the suspicions of customs agents. Under questioning, he admitted he had swallowed 51 small, heroin-filled balloons before boarding his flight. He was arrested and taken to a hospital.

title: Taking Ty Cobb Down a Peg or Two (to .340)
description: When Ty Cobb played baseball 80-some years ago, he tyrannized pitchers. Since then that sharp-spiked outfielder has intimidated generations of hitters, none of whom have been able to match his proficiency at the plate.

title: Publisher Cancels Biography After Plagiarism Inquiry
description: A disputed biography by a prolific Scottish author who has repeatedly been accused of plagiarism was ordered withdrawn and destroyed by his publisher yesterday after a historian's report branded it a ''spectacular and sustained act of plagiarism.''

title: Mets Face a New Day, Without a Hint of Sunshine
description: Armando Benitez was slumped in a small gray couch with his sweaty legs stretched out in front of him and his thick arms draped behind him. Benitez was not moving or speaking. He stared blankly at a big-screen television a few feet in front of him. The television was turned off.

title: Rookie Makes First Hit Game-Winning Homer
description: Alfonso Soriano was just happy to step to the plate. Since joining the Yankees from Class AAA Columbus on Sept. 11, the slightly built infielder had been used almost exclusively as a pinch-runner. Usually, when it was time for him to bat, Soriano would be called back from the on-deck circle by Manager Joe Torre, having summoned Darryl Strawberry or Jim Leyritz to pinch-hit. It happened so often that on Tuesday, Ricky Ledee told Soriano to plug his ears so he wouldn't hear Torre shouting for him to return to the dugout.

description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stolen Uranium Intercepted By Georgia in the Caucasus
description: A cache of stolen uranium was intercepted by Georgian officials this week, underscoring the continuing danger of nuclear theft in the former Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor George C. Scott yesterday misspelled the name of the theater where he made his New York debut in ''Richard III'' in 1957 and misstated the location. The theater was the Heckscher, not Hecksher. It was at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, not in Central Park.

title: A Plotted Homage to a Noted Nonplotter

The court found that all three state laws placed an undue burden on abortion rights by outlawing even the procedures most commonly used prior to fetal viability.

title: PERDUE WEIGHS BAN OF GENETICALLY MODIFIED FEED
description: Perdue Farms Inc., the poultry company, said yesterday that it was considering feeding its chickens and turkeys only corn that was not genetically modified as consumer concerns over biotechnology rise. Such a move could be a blow to agricultural biotechnology companies, which have been battered by public fears around the world over health and environmental effects of the technology. The industry maintains that foods produced from genetically altered crops are harmless. A spokeswoman said a decision would be made soon, and before farmers have to buy their corn seeds for the next planting season. Closely held Perdue, which is based in Salisbury, Md., sells its products nationwide and exports to more than 50 countries.

The plant will begin making Chevrolet Tahoes and GMC Yukons in the second half of next year.

The source of the stock's popularity is not the company's profits but its promise: As the leading light in a burgeoning high-technology industry, it is expected by the public to transform not just business and the economy, but the whole of society, ushering in a new era of unprecedented prosperity. The company's three-letter acronym embodies American ingenuity, enterprise and economic vitality.

description: FOR their season that opens on Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Robert Spano and the Brooklyn Philharmonic have put together a set of programs to survey the 20th century from the vantage point of its end. This is a 20th-century season in two ways: not only does all the music come from the last hundred years, but the planning has a very 20th-century feel. Mr. Spano and his orchestra are concerned less with great composers than with great themes -- war, politics, pop culture, the environment, faith -- and there is no attempt to see that all the outstanding creative personalities are represented.
