title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Jefferson the Tourist
description: In 1787, while Thomas Jefferson was in Paris serving as Minister to France, he dislocated his wrist. It was slow to heal, and his doctor recommended that he go to Aix-en-Provence to soak it in the renowned thermal waters. In late February, he set off for what was to become a three-month journey in what he called ''the land of corn, wine, oil and sunshine.'' He went to Orange, then on to Nemes, Arles, Aix (the waters didn't help), Marseilles and Nice. He spent three brief weeks in Italy. He returned to Aix and from there visited Les Baux, St. Remy and Avignon. He took a trip through the Canal du Midi to Toulouse, and then back to Paris via Bordeaux and the Loire Valley. He loved practically every moment. Jefferson kept extensive notes of this trip, with observations on everything from Roman antiquities to the price of dung, but Roy and Alma Moore, the authors of THOMAS JEFFERSON'S JOURNEY TO THE SOUTH OF FRANCE (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95), choose to lean heavily on his enthusiastic letters to his friends. Jefferson's words are balanced by the Moores' photographs of the sites and cities Jefferson visited. There is a charming, informative introduction by Lucia C. Stanton, a historian at Monticello. The book, however, makes no pretension to scholarship. There isn't an index, for example, and some of the recipients of Jefferson's letters are cursorily identified. The photographs seldom show people, which makes sense; even so, there is something predictable about them. The juxtaposition of period prints and maps with modern-day photographs is effective, however. This book is a simple and easy introduction to this dazzling interlude in Jefferson's life. Richard Goodman

The rallying cry was never shouted; the insistent phrase was never capitalized in speeches or printed on buttons. But it has quietly gripped the nation and is doing its job of persuasion.

title: Corrections

title: 'I Did Not Join the Hebrew Faith -- I Returned'
description: I grew up on the island of Monserrat, and my parents were supposed to be Christian. But in the years that I was home I always wondered why my people were so particular about what they did. We did not eat pork. My uncles were all circumcised. We ate challah bread on Friday night. If we had an animal that died by itself we did not eat it -- we would kill an animal by tying the hind legs, cutting the throat and allowing the blood to fall back to the earth where it came from. All of that we did, and we did not know why we were doing it -- because they told us that we were Christians. But I knew something was wrong, see? My grandfather told my mother we came from West Africa. And many years later I heard that the people on Monserrat were Hebrews that were taken as slaves from Ghana and carried to the island. So that's why this was.

title: The Nation: Diagnosing Al Gore's Problem; You May or May Not Have Clinton Fatigue

The examples of Cartier's work draw from nature, architecture and such far-flung inspirations as maharajahs, Tutankhamen's tomb, and the ornate trinkets of the czars. description: TRONDHEIM has an image problem. It has no image. Go into a travel agency in Britain and ask how to get there, and the assistant's eyes will glaze over, she will make one or two desperate stabs at her computer, and then recommend that you try another travel agent down the road. On my fourth attempt I hit on someone who could find out how to get there, but the air fare she demanded seemed to include several hundred pounds for her trouble.

title: Leaving the 18th Century In Time for the Millennium
description: IAN C. MURRAY was down on one knee, clutching a ring of skeleton keys, peering into a deep, dark oak cabinet and hoping that, just maybe, he would come across that chunk of melted glass and human teeth from the wreckage of the great Crystal Palace fire on Fifth Avenue on Oct. 5, 1858.

title: September 19-25; Familiarity Stops the Presses
description: John Paul Jones famously declared ''I have not yet begun to fight'' but last week Grove/Atlantic gave up the ship, killing a disputed new biography of the American naval hero amid allegations of copyright piracy. The book, which had taken the hero's most famous line as its title, was by James Mackay, a prolific Scottish author of some 160 titles. But it was termed ''a spectacular and sustained act of plagiarism'' by a Columbia University history professor, David Armitage, who found that it mirrored a 1959 Jones biography by the late naval historian Samuel Eliot Morison.

title: An Express Train to Intriguing Tastes in Tokyo
description: TRUE to its name, the Tozai Sen (''east-west line'') connects two outermost sections of Tokyo -- Nishi Funabashi city in the Chiba prefecture in the east to Mitaka city in the west.

title: Pat Buchanan, War Strategist
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Adventures in Karma on India's Holiest River
description: I'd been tossed out of rafts before. But getting tossed out of a raft and into the Ganges felt different. It was an accident with cosmic overtones, caused, I now have no doubt, by my own bad karma. But we'll get to that later.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ANDY KAUFMAN REVEALED! Best Friend Tells All. By Bob Zmuda with Matthew Scott Hansen. Little, Brown, $21.

title: Study Finds Rise in Working Poor
description: A lagging minimum wage, job growth focused mainly at the low and high extremes of the pay scale and welfare reform have combined to increase the number of working poor families in New Jersey over the past decade, a child advocacy group says.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-26-99: The Ethicist; Pregnant Pause
description: What happens when a pregnant wife finds out the sex of the coming baby but asks that the doctor tell no one -- including her husband? If the husband wants to know, is the obstetrician ethically bound not to tell him at the order of his patient? Or does her husband have a right to know? /Sy Presten, New York

title: A Popular True-Crime Story, Told in a New Way
description: EVEN though Jim Williams was acquitted after his fourth trial, there's really no question that he gunned down his young lover, Danny Hansford. Williams, a brilliant, witty antiques dealer in Savannah, Ga., was even on the verge of abandoning his story that Hansford had fired at him first. Find it on page 346 of ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,'' the true-crime book set in a magical city whose mossy secrets rise like the dark side of Brigadoon.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about police officers who play police roles in movies and television series misstated the number of years ''Law and Order'' has been on the air. It is beginning its 10th season, not its 8th. The article also mispelled the surname of a star of the series ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' He is Dennis Franz, not Frantz.

title: POSTINGS: Pastel Walls Grace Housing for the Low-Income Elderly; Adding Color to E. 61st St.
description: There is more to the residential building nearing completion at 351 East 61st Street than meets the eye, although there is plenty to see as well. The front of the 15-story structure is faced with brick in shades ranging from dark red to light yellow. The windowless side walls and the back -- which includes windows -- are in a different color scheme, with sections of pastel blue, yellow and green.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about population control in India and China misstated the name of a health organization and misspelled the surname of its president. The group is the International Women's Health Coalition, not the Women's International Health Coalition. Its president is Adrienne Germain, not Germaine.

title: Who Wants a School Principal's Job in New York City?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Exhibit
description: To the Editor: As archivist at the Cunningham Dance Foundation, I want to add a comment to John Krich's article about Oporto (''A Legendary City Updates Itself,'' Aug. 15). Readers who plan to visit Oporto in the next few months may be interested to know that the exhibition on Merce Cunningham curated by Germano Celant, which was shown at the Fundacio Antoni Tapies in Barcelona earlier this year, is at the Serralves Museum in Oporto through Nov. 7. It includes sets, costumes, original designs, photographs, posters and videos, as well as an installation by Paul Kaiser and Shelley Eshkar showing the projections used in the dance Bipeid, seen recently at the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUMHOLTZ, ETHEL
description: KRUMHOLTZ - Ethel. Beloved wife of Morris. Cherished mother of Barry and Barbara, Philip and Gail. Dear sister of Anne Wernick. Adored grandmother of Jason, Dayna, Jaimee, Jessica and Jake. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave., Rego Park, NY.

title: Nicholas Shoumatoff, 81, Nature Enthusiast
description: Nicholas Shoumatoff, a nature enthusiast and mountain climber who won praise for a book on Central Asia, died on Sept. 13 at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 81 and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Jewelry With the Homey Touch
description: With homemade-looking accessories showing up on runways and Madison Avenue, some amateur jewelers are trying their own hands at beads, leather, stones and string ''just for fun'' -- more fun if their moonlight creations happen to sell at a happening boutique.

title: India's Election Marathon Lumbers Into Final Week
description: As India lumbers into the fourth and final week of marathon national elections, elephants bearing ballot boxes tramp into dense forests and ponies carrying election officials clop their way to dizzying heights in the Himalayas, all to make sure that every citizen -- no matter how remote -- gets a chance to vote.

title: Buchanan's Sister Shepherds Insurgent Race
description: Bay Buchanan sighed a bit in admitting that her brother Patrick, the quixotic Presidential candidate, was essentially a man without a party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DON
description: FINKEL-Don. Age 56, of Olympia, Washington, died on September 16, 1999, of non-Hodgkins lymphoma. Born to Helen and Leonard Finkel in 1943 in New Rochelle, NY. A summa cum laude graduate in philosophy from Yale, and received a doctorate in Social Relations from Harvard in 1970. He became a professor at The Evergreen State College in Olympia, Washington, 23 years ago where he became known for his inspirational and innovative teaching methods. He is the author of ''Teaching With Your Mouth Shut'', due to be published next spring and co-authored ''Educating for Freedom: The Paradox of Pedagogy'' with William Arney. He is survived by his wife of 33 years, Susan, formerly Susan Kolker of Scarsdale, NY; a daughter Zoe Finkel of Los Angeles; and three sons, David, Daniel and Benjamin, all of Olympia, Washington; a sister, Gail Calder and Leslie Gabosh and his mother Helen Finkel of Lenox, MA. An extended family of in-laws and nephews and nieces who all loved him dearly. Memorial donations can be made to the Don Finkel Scholarship for Study of the Humanities and Grants to faculty members in support of innovative teaching care of: The Evergreen State College, Olympia, Washington, 98505.

title: Conner Has Rehabilitated His Image Down Under
description: In proud, sports-loving New Zealand, Dennis Conner was the man everyone loved to hate. During the 1987 America's Cup trials in Australia, Conner, the four-time cup winner, cast aspersions on the Kiwi team's sportsmanship. He fanned the flames in 1988 by calling the New Zealand designer Bruce Farr a loser during the contentious United States catamaran defense off San Diego.

title: A Canadian Gourmet Shop For Cinema Connoisseurs
description: RALPH FIENNES sat alone at one of the big round tables that sprouted like mushrooms around the half-darkened hotel meeting room overlooking Bloor Street. He doodled idly on a small pad of lined yellow paper, geometric shapes wrapped around letters and half-finished faces. Empty water glasses and scraps of paper littered the tables.

title: Q&A;/Gene Wilder; Stamford Inspires Life, and Work, of Actor
description: OF all the places in the world he could live, Gene Wilder's top choice is Stamford, where he resides with his wife, Karen, in a centuries-old house.

title: Commercial Property /Stamford, Conn.; A Pioneer Business Park That Confounded Critics
description: HIGH RIDGE PARK, the iconic 32-year-old office campus in Stamford's leafy northern reaches that was a pioneer in accommodating the 70's flight of corporations to the suburbs, is up for sale. While an aggressive but brief marketing effort has come to a halt, the six-building center is still on the market.

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: As a young actor in Hollywood, I feel that Hirschberg's article only perpetuates a myth that my peers and I have worked very hard to deconstruct. We have learned that going to parties and leaving our names in cute places will not help us as much as talent and hard work. We are not at the Whisky Bar commenting on others' social lives, but at home preparing for tomorrow's scenes.

title: Seed for Grass, Hope (Warily) for Rain
description: Seed bare patches with cool-season grasses like drought-tolerant fescues. Unless it rains, seed may need gentle watering daily until germination. One application of fertilizer in fall produces good root development rather than top growth. Plant small early-blooming bulbs in lawn; snow crocus (Crocus chrysanthus), spring snowflake (Leucojum vernum) and snowdrop (Galanthus nivalis) are good for naturalizing.

title: Catherine Traiforou, Jan Vlasto
description: Catherine Traiforou, the daughter of Theodora Evmorfopoulou and Stelios Traiforos, both of Athens, was married yesterday to Jan Arie Vlasto, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Vlasto of Kent, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Timothy J. Keller performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in New York.

title: Delectable Options On the Grocer's Shelf
description: George T. Shaheen, the chief executive who helped build Andersen Consulting into the world's largest consulting firm, said last week that he was leaving to become the chief of Webvan Group, an Internet start-up in Foster City, Calif. It wasn't the first offer Mr. Shaheen received recently. Last year, he was wooed for a top job at E.D.S., but turned it down.

title: Writing a Screen-Turner
description: Plenty of New Jerseyans have published novels. A. L. Sirois, who lives in Flemington, is one of the few whose novels appears solely on the Web. His first novel, a science-fiction tale called ''Blood Relations,'' was ''published'' this month by the Cascade Mountain Publishing Web site. As a technical writer for Bear Stearns in Whippany, Mr. Sirois is comfortable with the electronic world, although he intended his novel for ink on paper. When it wasn't picked up by mainstream book publishers, he got in touch with a friend and fellow science-fiction writer who does Web publishing in Oregon. ''There went the fantasy of big advances,'' Mr. Sirois said, but he added that electronic publishers are good about passing along royalties. Readers pay by credit card and download the text of a book of their choice; ''Blood Relations'' costs $3.50 from www.cascadepublishing.com. Mr. Sirios, who has published short stories and a children's book, also rendered the ''cover'' art for his novel. He says he will produce his next book with the Web in mind, adding links to biographies of his characters and 3-D renderings of space creatures.

title: An Internet Stable Is Ahead of the Pack
description: DURING a summer of Internet flame-outs, the stock of Internet Capital Group was noteworthy for streaking higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, STEVEN W.
description: GREENSTEIN-Steven W., 46, died peacefully and without pain after living with AIDS for seven years. Survived by partner, family and friends, his courage and dignity will remain an inspiration to us all. Contributions in his memory may be made to Congregation Beth Simchat Torah, 57 Bethune St., NY NY 10014 or to the organization of your choice.

title: When More Than One Story Surrounds a Piece of Sculpture
description: AMERICAN audiences have become familiar with exhibitions that have a dynamic quality, that question or expose the philosophies that went into their making. The primary purpose of such shows is not to display fine objects, but to make a point and to alert the viewer to be more mindful about the presumptions behind any exhibition.

title: SOAPBOX; Cell-Phone True Confessions
description: Ugh, I can still taste the chicken fat! I think I'm gonna be sick!'' The woman let out a moan as she doubled over, clutching her stomach. You might think I overheard this in my doctor's waiting room. Actually, I was at the corner of Broadway, waiting to cross 49th Street. The woman in question was standing in the middle of a crowded sidewalk talking into her cell phone. As the woman continued to describe her close encounter with some schmaltz, my own stomach started to feel queasy. This was so much more than I wanted to hear, especially after having just finished a large pastrami sandwich for lunch.

title: The Singer Solution to World Poverty
description: When, in response to Singer's article, I called OxFam America to make my donation, the operator indicated that the agency had been flooded with calls, mostly in the $200 range. I suspect these calls were from people without much more to spare. While this is wonderful, I am still concerned that the article may not have put enough emphasis on those who can spare much more.

title: Painterly Flavors, Colored Red
description: Like Picasso, the delicious '98 Carchelo, an artful red blend, originates in Spain and finds inspiration in France. And like much of his viscerally powerful imagery, the painterly flavors are bold and striking.

title: The World: Democracy in Turkey; A Groundswell for More Human Rights
description: WHEN Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey meets with President Clinton and Congressional leaders in Washington this week, there will be much talk about earthquake relief, geopolitics, and obscure though important matters like trade arbitration and oil pipeline routes. But on Capitol Hill and elsewhere in the United States, those matters pale into insignificance. There the great question is at once simpler and more complex: How democratic is Turkey?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, CHARLES J., SR.
description: BRADY-Charles J., Sr. Funeral director, on September 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Anne E. (nee Burns). Loving father of Marie E., Charles J., Eileen A. Shea and Gregory J. Devoted ''Pappy'' of seven granddaughters. Fond father-in-law of Elizabeth Brady and Richard Shea. Funeral Tuesday, 9:30 AM, from McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 8225 Third Ave, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM, St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, NY.

title: School Bus Safety
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has recommended some sensible design changes for school buses to prevent injuries in side-impact collisions and rollovers. School buses are already one of the safer modes of transportation for youngsters. Last year there were only 29 school bus-related fatalities, 6 involving bus occupants and 23 involving pedestrians. Those figures seem small when compared with the 41,471 people killed in motor vehicle crashes in this country. But inadequate data collection at school bus accident sites has made it difficult to determine the number of injuries in school bus accidents, leaving the overall safety record unclear.

title: Movies for the Masses, Italian Style
description: IN the sweet repose that settles upon us after drubbing an Adam Sandler movie, we film critics sometimes become wistful. If only readers could look into our hearts! How we long to enjoy the same films as everyone else. How we yearn for the companionship of a public that would like our films.

title: Sports of The Times; Captain Crenshaw's Back-to-the-Wall Crapshoot in the Singles
description: RYDER Cup pressure, which is unlike that in any other golf event, has never hung like a guillotine over the United States golfers as it will in today's 12 concluding singles matches, especially over Tom Lehman, Hal Sutton and David Duval.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: Who would have thought the world would fall in love with a desperately hip, sweetly funny Carnaby Street secret agent who thinks he's still living in the 60's? (Understandably, since he was cryogenically frozen for 30 years.) In AUSTIN POWERS: INTERNATIONAL MAN OF MYSTERY (1997), Mike Myers, as Austin and as Dr. Evil, his longtime nemesis, mixes movie parody, culture shock and adolescent naughtiness, and it's hard to resist. Elizabeth Hurley is Austin's very 1990's love interest. Robert Wagner is No. 2, a sulky villain with an eye patch. No matter what anybody says, this is much better than the sequel -- Monday at 10:15 P.M. on Encore.

title: September 19-25; A Powerful Earthquake Devastates Taiwan
description: An earthquake registering 7.6 on the Richter scale left more than 2,000 people dead, thousands more hurt and more than 100,000 homeless in Taiwan. Days later, amid strong aftershocks and lingering power outages, rescuers continued to search for survivors trapped in the rubble.

title: Things Past, From Glaciers to Old-Fashioned Pies
description: FROM the Ice Age to the 19th century: this is the time span covered by a visit to Hacklebarney State Park. You can return to the late 20th century once you get home. But at the park you lose yourself amid glacial rocks and emerge for doughnuts and cider sold at a family orchard, a relic of the 1800's.

title: Vote for Me, Declares Argentine, I'm Boring
description: ''They call me boring,'' says the Mayor of Buenos Aires, Fernando de la Rua, in the opening of his presidential campaign's signature television commercial. The spot then cuts to some more exciting personalities: first, President Carlos Saul Menem posing in a flashy Ferrari and then an actor who it implies is a political ally of Mr. Menem pocketing a bribe.

title: Desperate to Seem 16
description: I was struck by how the young actors interviewed in your article never expressed a simple love of acting -- just lust for fame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLAMANA, JOAN SPENCER
description: VILLAMANA-Joan Spencer of Bronxville and Patterson, NY died at home on Tuesday, September 21, 1999. Mrs. Villamana is survived by her husband, Tom; her brother, Don Harris; her daughters, Luci Krusz, Kim Spencer and Molly Marshall; and four grandchildren, Robbie, Ronnie, Emily and Troy. A memorial service was held at Christ Church in Bronxville on Saturday, September 25th at 2 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to The Hole in the Wall Gang Fund, 555 Long Wharf Drive, New Haven, CT 06511. The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp is a camp for cancer and blood illnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, RUTH GERDA
description: LEVY-Ruth Gerda, 78 of Westwood, NJ., formerly of Rio Rancho, NM, passed away on September 24, 1999 in Ridgewood, NJ. Born May 22, 1921 in Germany. Beloved mother of Howard G. Sachs of Hershey, PA and Marvin C. Sachs of Westwood, NJ. Mother-in-law of Corinne and Martha, adored grandmother of David, Emily, Jonathan, Mark and Molly Sachs and granddaughter-in-law Pamela. Pre-deceased by loving husbands Ernest L. Sachs and Fred Levy. A pioneer in radiologic technology education, she was Director of Schools at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, NY and Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, NJ. Private services will be held. The family requests donations be made to The Myeloproliferative Disease Research Center, Inc., 115 East 72nd Street, NY NY 10021. For further information ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 800-522-0588.

title: Futuristic Works That Define Dimensions of Time and Space
description: EARLY this century, a group of Italian poets, painters and sculptors known as the Futurists rebelled against representing the world as a static place, opting for a dynamic that bordered on the out-of-control.

title: A FISCAL DEADLINE COULD FORCE G.O.P. TO BREAK A PLEDGE
description: As the new fiscal year approaches, a financial and political crisis confronts Republicans in Congress. They may have to break their repeated promises and raid Social Security to run the Government, their own staff and independent analysts say.

title: Where Fur Doesn't Fly
description: Are you an animal lover but a clothes horse? Well, now there's Trufaux, a guilt-free fur salon at 301 West Broadway (Canal Street). As the name implies, all of the clothing at the store is ''faux,'' or made from synthetic fabrics. There are bear-trimmed nylon shells ($275), pressed pink crocodile jackets ($300), knee-length leopard skirts ($250) and a Persian lamb peacoat ($550). The owners, Jenny Green, 28, and her stepmother, Susan Green, 38, opened the shop for people who think fur is easier to wear when it's fake. ''Even though people think it's luxurious, they are self-conscious about it,'' Jenny Green said. ''Ours you can wear and never think twice. It'll never be a conscience issue.'' And as she pointed out, a fake mink vest is more practical at a rock concert. Most designs are by Shannon McLean, on the Trufaux label. But there are also giraffe skirts by Uniform ($175), burgundy ultraleather motorcycle pants by Trina Turk ($295) and leopard cowboy hats by James Coviello ($240). The shop, which also offers custom clothes, is convincing. ''We have activists coming in all the time ready to be upset,'' Jenny Green said, recalling ''a group of gentlemen'' who asked for the owner. ''After inspecting it, they were pleased. Now they want to put us on their mailing list.'' CINDI COOK

title: Noise Just Makes Me Want to SCREAM
description: LIVING in this state is like having a running vacuum cleaner attached to your head all day: it's almost unendurably noisy. If a diesel truck isn't belching along your street, an airline flight path is materializing over your house. If the Mufflerless Motorcycle Club isn't having a convention at your favorite bar, the idiot on the next stool is holding court by cell phone.

title: Foster Seniors
description: I work for the Moore County Department of Social Services, in Carthage, N.C., with primary responsibility to our disabled and elderly population. I took James Bennet's article (Aug. 29) to work to share with my co-workers since the concept of foster-home placement for seniors is an innovative idea.

title: A Radium Tale: Three Years, $36 Million, One Playground
description: The wheelchair-accessible playground in Carteret Park in Glen Ridge is both touching and a little eerie, all things considered. The 3.5-acre park on Lorraine Street reopened this month after a $37 million, three-year Superfund cleanup by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The work began when cancer-causing radium was found in soil moved from a factory in Orange that made luminous watch dials to fill in low-lying areas of Glen Ridge, including this one.

title: Vytas Laitusis, Cara Cahalan
description: Cara Jean Cahalan, a daughter of Jean Cahalan-Pawlick of Danbury, Conn., and Dr. Joseph M. Cahalan of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Vytas Joseph Laitusis, a son of Klementina Laitusis of Union, N.J., and the late Jonas Laitusis. The Rev. Thomas Faiola performed the ceremony at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

title: Who Wants a School Principal's Job in New York City?
description: To the Editor:

title: No New ZIP Code
description: Although the United States Postal Service has twice denied Harrison's request for a new ZIP code, it is offering to reconsider the matter if the town builds a new post office.

title: If You're Seeking Fast Food, Here Is Where Quality Counts
description: LONG before anyone ever heard of Big Macs, there was fast food. That is, food rapidly prepared, served almost instantly and designed to be eaten quickly. This pre-Whopper world is much in evidence on Long Island.

title: What Is 'Right' Time for Wine?
description: GRAYING wine lovers may remember Orson Welles intoning ''We will sell no wine before its time'' in a commercial for Paul Masson wines.

title: Alexandra Porter, David Gissen
description: Alexandra Scott Porter, a daughter of Lorna S. Porter and G. Bruce Porter, both of Manhattan, was married yesterday to David Louis Gissen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Gissen of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Betty R. Zimmer, an interfaith minister and an aunt of the bridegroom, officiated at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: UNHALLOWED GROUND

title: What John Doe Drives in Anytown
description: NAMES, like wolves, run in packs. People who keep tabs on newborns say a lot of Pampers are currently wrapped around Michaels and Jessicas, not to mention Jacobs and Samanthas.

title: Time's Awasting, But He Swears It's Not His
description: IF I've ever wasted time, I don't know when. I don't consider this efficiency herculean or evidence that my internal engines run full speed at all times. I consider my life fairly ordinary, except for my collection of Foghorn Leghorn memorabilia, so my inability to waste time arises from no special hereditary power or family circumstance. I distinguish between wasting time and personal fulfillment; not everything I do is life enhancing or healthy.

title: Music From the Machine Age
description: How many airplane propellers does it take to produce perfect symphonic sonority? George Antheil wrestled with that question for years as he revised his provocative score ''Ballet Mecanique.'' Antheil, a Trenton native whose audacity and percussive rhythms had Paris arts-world heavies on the edge of their seats in the 1920's, is the subject of a concert by the Philadelphia Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra under Daniel Spaulding next Sunday at 7 P.M. at the War Memorial in Trenton, (609) 984-8400.

title: Clearer Water Reveals Sunken Ships
description: A decade ago, only a few, intrepid scuba divers plunged into the murk of Lake Erie. Parts of the lake were periodically glazed green with algae, and others were fouled with the same pollution that helped set ablaze the Cuyahoga River in 1969.

title: The World's Cheapest Spectator Sport; Tokyo
description: Japan prides itself on its homogeneity. From bank clerks in dark, rumpled suits to young beauties tottering around on four-inch platform shoes, visitors to Tokyo will tend to see types rather than individuals.

title: Bringing the Party to Sotheby's
description: IT was nearly 11 P.M., and Tiffany Dubin was seated at a vanity table on a hot-pink velvet chair in the dressing room of her Upper East Side apartment, wearing a baby-doll nightgown. Her day had begun with meetings at Sotheby's, where she is the head of the fashion department, continued with an afternoon trip to Chinatown to buy bar stools and after a quick change into a 1960's Norman Norell dress, wound down at a business dinner at Fressen in the meatpacking district.

title: Onward and Upward For a SoHo Cafe
description: As soon as Bari Omari found out that his upstairs neighbors were leaving, he knew he wanted to expand his restaurant, which has stood at Broadway and Spring Street in SoHo for six years. After 15 months of renovations, Mr. Omari added a second floor to Cafe Bari and renamed the upper floor simply Bari.

title: September 19-25; A Storm's Harsh Aftermath
description: Floyd, the monster hurricane that started rolling up the Atlantic Coast two weeks ago, lived up to its billing in pummeling shoreline homes, harbors and boats. Chickens and pigs too, creating an unanticipated kind of health hazard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLITZ, LEONARD
description: CARLITZ - Leonard. Former James B. Duke Professor of Mathematics at Duke University (1932-1977), passed away Friday morning, September 17, in Pittsburgh, PA. Born in Philadelphia in 1907, Carlitz was one of the most prolific and insightful mathematics researchers of all time. His 770 publications on number theory and related topics appeared in 110 different professional journals. He is survived by two sons, Michael and Robert, and two granddaughters, Natasha and Ruth. Clara, his wife of 59 years, died in 1990.

title: Need a Coverup? Try Some Violets
description: NOW that fall has arrived, it seems a good idea to take an assessment of the damage done to the garden by the long, hot summer.

title: Seductive Vibrato For Heartstrings
description: Suggestive CD covers and strapless dresses have become as compulsory as a Stradivarius in the classical music world, and now the musicians are starting to look like models -- perhaps because some of them are. Nina Kotova, 26, a Russian-born cellist, below, whose first CD is just out on Philips, spent her early 20's on runways and posing for magazines like Cosmopolitan and French Glamour. ''When I was modeling, the sense of beauty took a different form of expression,'' she said. ''Now it comes out when I write or perform music.'' The perennially decollete violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter adorns concert billboards and subscription brochures promoting her solos with the New York Philharmonic in January and her recording of Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' due in November.

title: Kenneth Zekavat, Suzanne Douglas
description: Suzanne Lizbeth Douglas and Kenneth Hamid Zekavat were married yesterday at the Plaza in New York. The Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Before the ceremony, Dr. Hashem Housseini, a matrimonial administrator, conducted a traditional Persian Muslim wedding.

title: Fancyspeak
description: Charles Harrington Elster offers the French esprit de l'escalier (''the spirit of the staircase'') as the preferred phrase to describe ''the apt remark one thinks of too late'' (On Language, Aug. 29). The late columnist Heywood Hale Broun created a delightful word for this ill-timed repartee. He called it ''departee.''

title: Passion Inspires Quirky Clocks
description: NICK Corcoran doesn't know what he is going to create when he sets the old cast-iron parts, auto gears, defective cylinder heads and intake manifolds from airplanes and other recycled materials onto the work table in his Hampton Bays studio.

title: David Kroon and Jody Hyman
description: Dr. Jody Lynn Hyman and Dr. David Fleming Kroon were married yesterday in Rumson, N.J., at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mary Jane and Richard E. Kroon. The Rev. David McKirachan, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: His Own School of Criticism
description: More Matter

title: Single File
description: When Stacey D'Erasmo writes, ''We're all single girls now,'' does she mean that the life style of a married woman is indistinguishable from that of a single woman (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 29)? I've been a single woman, a wife in an unhappy marriage, a single mother and now the happily married wife of a great guy. When we got married, I told him from my heart, ''Now all the problems will be on the outside.'' What I meant was that though problems would come -- his career hasn't taken off as he would like, two of our five children have cystic fibrosis, money and time are always tight, etc. -- that the palette of problems would be different.

title: Deep in the Spiritual Heart of France
description: ON A LATE afternoon in June, we sat in the empty 12th-century church mesmerized by the sunlit windows sparkling like jeweled mosaics in the distant sanctuary. It was so still that the scurrying monk startled us, dark robes churning at his ankles, as he crossed the polished marble floors. He bowed deeply toward the altar, and disappeared. Immediately, the organ growled, bass chords I could feel in my chest. A scramble of high notes followed, climbing the pale stone columns and filling every musty bay of the vast abbey church at Fontgombault. In an active Benedictine community it's probably not unusual for an organist to snatch a few minutes to rehearse, but for us, on a tour of French medieval abbeys, the impromptu recital at the end of the day was a delightful surprise.

title: Science Fiction
description: Kim Stanley Robinson is back on Mars. This is welcome news indeed for those of us who regard Robinson's recent trilogy (''Red Mars,'' ''Green Mars,'' ''Blue Mars'') as one of modern science fiction's finest achievements. Although it extends and deepens the impact of the earlier books, THE MARTIANS (Spectra/Bantam, $24.95) is not exactly a sequel. Instead it runs a series of variations on the grand theme of the trilogy. Human colonists arrive on Mars determined to ''terraform'' our airless and arid planetary neighbor into a near facsimile of Earth. Their success is indicated by the adjective ''blue.'' Staying just a few steps ahead of today's scientific knowledge, Robinson imagines a comfortably habitable Mars supplied with a breathable atmosphere and blue seas, home to the descendants of the human colonizers for whom the heroic events chronicled in the trilogy are already the stuff of history books and rapidly germinating legends.

title: Overwhelming A Private Home

On the bus, concertgoers are offered free manicures, makeovers, color consultations and sample products from companies like Aveda, Chanel and Christian Dior. Similarly, Brocato, the upscale hair-care line, will dispatch Brocato Red and Brocato Blonde, two revamped Greyhound buses, to travel Madison and Fifth Avenues starting on Oct. 4 to dispense products and tips. But there is at least one place where you can actually watch Angelenos in full herd mode: The Third Street Promenade in downtown Santa Monica. And a good time to do that is on Saturday morning when an open-air farmers' market springs up along Arizona Street with the promenade as its center point.

Believe it: black leather is all over the mode map, and there aren't that many hard rockers who do leather the way Joan Jett does. Practice makes perfect: at 15, Jett became the lead singer and rhythm guitarist for the all-girl band the Runaways, and that's when the biker chick leapt out of male fantasy and bloomed into flesh, blood and cool. In the 60's, Moby Grape rhapsodized about ''Motorcycle Irene'' while the cartoon loony R. Crumb drew those overripe, plug-ugly Amazons who could sink their teeth into heavy metal and spit it out. But it was Joan Jett and Suzi Quatro who turned sex-crazed teen-age girls into biker chicks. It was all in the attitude, the pose, the clothes.

title: Completing the Tax Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ship With No Captain
description: With the start of the regular season one week away, most of the question marks that surrounded the Islanders entering training camp have been answered.

title: Applying Strategic Pressure, Boris Gulko Wins U.S. Title
description: Boris Gulko, a 52-year-old Fairlawn, N.J., grandmaster, won the 1999 United States Championship, held in Salt Lake City from Aug. 23 to Sept. 10. Gulko, a former Soviet dissident, defeated Gregory Serper, a Mayfield Heights, Ohio, grandmaster, by 2 1/2- 1/2 in their four-game final match. Gulko was awarded the first prize, $12,000, and Serper took the runner-up prize, $7,500. Gulko also won the championship in 1994.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Change Comes to the Club That 'Fever' Made Famous
description: In the 1977 film ''Saturday Night Fever,'' John Travolta plays Tony Manero, a young Italian-American resident of Bay Ridge who spends his days working in a paint store and his nights holding court as the dance king of Odyssey 2001, the local disco. When Tony and his friends pass a gay couple in the street, they shout epithets.

title: Sometimes A Great Notion?
description: John T. Bulger is bursting with ideas to improve the world. But it's been a long time since anyone followed his advice.

title: Unions See Fertile Fields At Lower End of High Tech
description: IN a valley that celebrates its bumper crop of winners, you might count people like Julian Cornejo as among the losers. Mr. Cornejo, 55, a technician in computer-aided design, has spent the last 15 years working as a kind of high-tech gypsy for various temporary agencies, a situation that now leaves him nearly broke and on the brink of homelessness.

title: Tailor Fears Future Of Craft Is Limited
description: SEVEN years of apprenticeship, starting at age 11, was how Joseph Gresia honed his tailoring skills in Italy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts & Leisure section today about the Vienna Philharmonic refers incorrectly in some copies to the number of players. It is 135; 149 is the number in the parent Vienna State Opera Orchestra. Thus, based on the salary total of $8 million supplied by the orchestra, the average for Philharmonic players is $59,000, not $54,000. That average is some $25,000 below the base of the top American orchestras -- not $30,000 below.

title: Sleepy Bedroom Communities: The Untold Story
description: THE glaciers did it first, bulldozing down from the Arctic before getting tired and choosing this place to pull up, set down their immense loads of sand and stone and melt awhile. Migratory birds came later, followed by office workers on the 5:41 to Hicksville.

title: The World's Cheapest Spectator Sport; London
description: It started when I saw Andrew Morton, the biographer of Princess Diana and Monica Lewinsky, in shorts and sneakers, power-walking away on Parliament Hill Fields in north London. My own backyard, a stone's throw from where I live, in Highgate, adjacent to the Fields, had been brushed with celebrity.

title: Jonathan Lipton and Holly Speyer
description: Holly Ann Speyer, a daughter of Lynne T. Handler and Jerry I. Speyer, both of New York, was married last evening to Jonathan Alan Lipton, the son of Michael D. Lipton of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Arlene M. Lipton. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Shortages Are Slowing Construction Of Homes
description: FROM the pipes in the trenches to the trusses for the roof, from the panels for the walls to the insulation between the beams -- and, just as acutely, in the search for skilled workers to hammer it all together -- home builders in New York City and its suburbs are struggling with shortages of supplies and labor.

title: Visions of More Garbage Trucks Haunt Park Advocates
description: Plans for the new Hudson River Park have had many people looking forward to idle hours spent on shady riverside banks. But now some residents and officials are worried that the Gansevoort Peninsula, also known as Pier 52, will continue to be used as a parking lot for city garbage trucks for some time, perhaps even after that part of the park is finished.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Listening Tour Now Evolving Into Senate Campaign
description: In a pair of trial runs at a stump speech, Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded out the themes of her expected campaign for the United States Senate today, listing the weak upstate economy, affordable health care, education, the environment, Social Security and gun control as the most important issues facing New York.

title: The Prophet of Terre Haute
description: Harp Song

title: With Students Flowing In, Schools Are Forced to Juggle Space
description: WITH an exuberant swell of sound, the 25 students in Mary Ellen McGory's fourth-grade classroom at the Todd Elementary School here rapped out rhythms on tambourines, played songs on xylophones and raised their voices in a joyful noise on a wet, windy day.

title: A New Hotel Near the Forbidden City
description: Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts, a Hong Kong company, has opened its fourth hotel in Beijing and its 15th in China: the 487-room Kerry Center Hotel in the heart of the Chaoyang Commercial District, near the Forbidden City, Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People. The hotel has a sports and recreation center with an outdoor jogging and roller track, indoor tennis courts, a 114-foot heated lap pool and full gym. Three restaurants offer Cantonese and regional specialties and international fare.

title: High-Strung Mets Set to Snap
description: Bobby Valentine's face was riven with tension after the Mets lost by 4-2 to the Phillies today -- their fifth loss in a row -- and dropped into a tie with Cincinnati for the National League wild-card berth. Valentine has been drawn tight as a piano string in the last few weeks, but now the manager seized the anxiety and twisted it into something surreal.

title: See No Evil: Detective's New Insight
description: The music on the soundtrack grows agitated as a disembodied voice, taut with tension, describes the following scene: ''Tanner drives away from the curb, his wiper blades swinging back and forth, back and forth on the windshield. As he rounds the corner, his vision blurs. Parked cars smear together like streaks of passing light. Shapes collapse into a white glare, radiating from a central point. Suddenly recognizing a car, Tanner swerves sharply and slams into another car.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on page 44 of The Times Magazine today about the art collector Charles Saatchi and ''Sensation,'' a show of his collection scheduled to open this week at the Brooklyn Museum, includes an outdated reference to the possibility that the show will be less controversial in New York than it was in Europe.

title: The On-Line Trader Is Becoming the New Big Man on Campus
description: SHORTLY before 9 A.M. on Sept. 17, an alarm sounded on Derek O'Banion's personal computer -- the signal that Vitria Technology, an Internet business software developer, had begun its first day of trading on Nasdaq.

title: Lester Lives!
description: To the Editor:

title: Garth Brooks Plays the Rocker
description: FOR a music critic, the truest measure of an album's worth often comes after the review. While writing about a record, one is required to listen to it over and over until each song is etched into memory. But afterward, be the review positive or negative, free will takes over, and the best sign of an album's merit is how many times the critic -- with hundreds of CD's arriving in the mail weekly -- listens to it again, if at all. The R.E.M. album ''Monster,'' for example, feels over-rated in retrospect because the desire to listen to it has disappeared, while the Neil Young album ''Ragged Glory'' deserves all the praise it received because it survives prominently on the listening pile.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for BILL WALKER; Responding To a Call Of Disaster
description: THE devastating earthquake that struck Taiwan in the early hours of last Tuesday also shook the ground under many a technology executive's feet around the world. Taiwan plays a crucial role in the global computer industry: The country is the fourth-largest producer of semiconductors and a leader in memory chips, and its factories assemble a big chunk of the world's desktop, portable and notebook computers, many under contract for well-known American and Japanese brands.

title: In Fast Times, Who Has Time to Reflect?
description: THE brothers at Little Portion Friary in Mount Sinai offer the rare opportunity to be released from the demands of daily life, to relax and contemplate -- the chance, in effect, to lose time. And their guest house is usually full.

title: She Had to Relax. Her Editors Told Her So. It Wasn't Easy.
description: RELAXATION, like exercise, is no sport for amateurs.

title: Carl Hoyler 2d and Sarah Ansari
description: Sarah Ansari, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Rahman Ansari of Old Tappan, N.J., was married last evening in New Brunswick, N.J., to Carl Cyril Hoyler 2d, the son of Dr. Barbara-Ann K. Greenberg and Dr. Carl C. Hoyler, both of Princeton, N.J.

title: A Man Who Can Open Doors
description: When Bono, lead singer for U2, wanted to gain United States support for the global Jubilee 2000 campaign to cancel third-world debts, he began this spring by calling Bobby Shriver. As in, the son of Sargent and Eunice Kennedy Shriver, nephew of John F. Kennedy, brother of Maria Shriver. ''Take your pick,'' Mr. Shriver said. ''I prefer to be called the brother-in-law of Arnold Schwarzenegger.''

title: The Underdog's Bulldog
description: KAZ Peck an advocate for children with special needs, the mother of a child diagnosed with Down syndrome and a community spitfire -- fights for the underdog; she is one.

title: Tossing Religion In Your Face?
description: Q. I am a musician, and I supplement my income by painting and plastering apartments. Recently I took a job for three months helping to renovate a house; it's very good money and I like the work. But most of the other crew members are born-again Christians, and the boss likes to leave religious literature on the kitchen counter below a sign that says ''Christian propaganda.'' It makes me uncomfortable -- I'm Jewish, and a lot of the material talks about how the Jews betrayed and killed Christ. Is there some law against having this in the workplace?

title: Mary Ott, William Ambler
description: Mary Franklin Ott, the daughter of Mary Ott and Dr. F. Thomas Ott of St. Louis, was married yesterday to William Nash Ambler, the son of Louise Todd Ambler of Belmont, Mass., and Peter Wistar Ambler of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. James Purdy performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Ladue, Mo.

title: Day Care for the Dog, Peace for the Owner
description: DO you have pangs of guilt whenever you leave Rover to fend for himself all day? Take heart. Dog day-care centers, where dogs are left while their owners run errands, head to the office or simply clean house, are popping up all over.

title: When Is Enough Too Much?
description: PATRICIA DUFF knows what a 4-year-old girl needs to live a ''moderately luxurious'' life on a ''rough parity with an Upper East Side family'' -- about $4,400 a day. That covers lodging in a $5 million 10-room apartment on the Upper East side and a house in the Hamptons, $2,500 worth of ''prints'' for her closet and $1,450 a month for dining out.

title: The Interviewer
description: THE SPECTATOR

title: All the President's Men . . . and Women
description: Four years ago Aaron Sorkin, the author of stage and film versions of ''A Few Good Men,'' was researching and writing the screenplay for ''The American President,'' about a widowed President who is attracted to a lobbyist. ''There were all these stories I wanted to tell in 'The American President' about the senior staffers at the White House but didn't because it was about the romance of these two people,'' said Mr. Sorkin.

title: It Never Closes
description: Eastchester residents now have access to a virtual town hall -- the first of its kind in Westchester. Although most if not all municipalities have a Web presence, those sites are not updated daily, Eastchester's Supervisor, James E. Cavanaugh, said.

title: In Praise of Country Churches
description: EVERY fan of Sir John Betjeman, the late poet laureate of Britain, is aware that parish church-crawling is a national pastime in England. ''I know no greater pleasure than church-crawling,'' Sir John wrote. ''It leads you to the remotest and quietest country. It introduces you to the history of England in stone and wood and glass which is always truer than what you read in books. You meet all sorts of people on your travels.''

title: September 19-25; Awaiting the First Frost
description: ''It's like some crazy movie,'' said Scott Beck, a teacher in New Rochelle. ''I'm picturing these black helicopters where they drop these people out of the sky.'' Has World War III begun? Have terrorists landed? Is Judgment Day at hand?

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: An 'Anecdote' Has Made The Rounds for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama With a Vengeance
description: The bride runs off with her lover on her wedding night. The bridegroom hunts them down. It's a non-realistic play based on a real story.

title: Follow That Pack
description: To the Editor: ''The Avant-Garde: Follow That Backpack'' (Aug. 8) is excellent advice, and not just for the destinations. Although almost old enough to be the college-age backpackers' grandparents, my wife and I still gravitate to our old combipacks for any trip of more than one night. There is simply no unassisted way to carry so much so gracefully and take up so little space as with packs. Even better is the wholesome link between backpacks and the walking-public transportation mode of travel, which almost everywhere still means intimate contact with places and people, a low profile and no albatross of a rental car.

title: Creative Writing
description: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature have taken place in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you try to explain it, and what happened? If you're a boss, on the receiving end, what has been the most striking item you have encountered, and what did you do? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Taproom Wall in Princeton Boasts Bradley, Not a Forbes
description: The most reliable guide to successful Princeton graduates is probably whether they are hanging on the wall at the Tap Room, the basement bar at the Nassau Inn.

title: Returning River to Salmon, and Man to the Drawing Board
description: Of all the ways in which Americans have reshaped the land to suit their priorities, none is more audacious than the vast network of hydroelectric dams that stretches across the Pacific Northwest, taming wild rivers, opening shipping passages and bringing the region the cheapest electricity rates in the nation.

description: To the Editor:

title: An Area That Doesn't Want to Be a 'New Times Square'
description: Nine months after a judge ordered a topless club called Goldfingers closed in Rego Park, it has found a new home about five miles away, in an industrial area at the foot of the Queensboro Bridge and in the shadows of the elevated subway tracks.

title: In Home Ownership Data, A Hidden Generation Gap
description: RISING home ownership is billed as one of the great rewards of America's economic boom. And so it is: The percentage of households that live in their own homes has never been greater. But examine that touted superlative closely, and these gilded years come into more sober focus.

title: The Singer Solution to World Poverty
description: Singer's was about the most provocative article I have read in your magazine. No one has ever put quite so fine a point on the fact that huge numbers of people (myself included) have material concerns so incomprehensibly trivial as to be a grotesque joke to the large chunk of humanity who suffer painful, brutish and short lives.

title: What Underdogs? Europe Opens a Formidable Lead
description: With one day left in the Ryder Cup competition, the United States is running out of time, running out of matches and running out of chances.

title: Dr. Baicker and Dr. Durell
description: Dr. Katherine Baicker and Dr. Alan Durell, assistant professors of economics at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., were married yesterday at the Present Day Club in Princeton, N.J. Judge Eric Perkins of the Montgomery Township (N.J.) Municipal Court officiated.

title: Today the Anatomy, Tomorrow the World
description: IF you'd never seen Eve Ensler's one-woman show ''The Vagina Monologues'' and if you knew she had also written plays about Bosnian refugees, women in prison and nuclear war, you might expect her to be humorless, single-minded, even didactic. But to step into Ms. Ensler's apartment in Chelsea is to confront a positively bubbly figure, wearing bright red lipstick, her dark hair cut in a bob.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Tower That Flaunts Its Contradictions
description: I HOPE that the completion of the new Conde Nast headquarters last month will make people think twice before complaining about the Disneyfication of Times Square. Things are better than that, and worse.

title: The World's Cheapest Spectator Sport; New York
description: Anyone can go to New York's Museum of Modern Art to look at the art. But it is more fun if time is also spent looking at the people looking at the art. Writ large on their faces is an array of emotions: amusement, perplexity, excitement, annoyance, boredom, delight, weariness.

title: Corrections
description: A query in the Streetscapes column on Sept. 5, answering readers' questions, misspelled the surname of the executive for whom the mansion that once stood at 1069 Fifth Avenue was built. He was Frank Frueauff, not Frueaff. The answer to the query misspelled the maiden name of a later owner. She was Emily Van Beuren Reynolds, not Van Buren.

title: Vying for Mets Tickets With Fingers Crossed
description: It's tough being a Mets fan these days.

title: Chefs Don Headsets to Pace the Kitchen
description: THINK airports. Jumbo jets are backed up in the air, waiting for runways and gates. On the ground, an air-traffic controller is checking the radar screen for flight paths, assigning circling patterns and designating priorities for safe landings. That will give you some idea, on a smaller, less potentially disastrous scale, of what it's like at some top restaurants at prime time on Saturday nights.

description: To the Editor:

title: For a Battered Orange Warrior, Relief Approaches
description: The rusted, dented orange trash baskets that squat on street corners throughout the city will probably soon fall into the dustbin of history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALT, NORMAN
description: WALT-Norman. Memorial service Friday, October 1, Noon, Saint Michaels Church, North Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: Jennifer Bantz, Daniel Biddle
description: Jennifer Anne Bantz and Daniel Crews Biddle were married on Friday evening by the Rev. Paula Posman, an interfaith minister, at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Emily Heckman and Christian Burke
description: Emily Jane Heckman, a daughter of Joan M. Heckman and Dr. Robert E. Heckman of Dover, Del., was married yesterday to Christian McDonagh Burke, a son of Mari G. Craig of Rockville, Md., and Joseph McD. Burke of St. Paul. Msgr. Lawrence M. Connaughton performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Francis de Sales in Phoenicia, N.Y.

title: The Stock Auction, Take 3
description: The third time's the charm. At least that seems to be what the owners of Andover.net of Acton, Mass., are hoping.

description: The reading season has just opened, and here's your fall list. Pop quizzes to come.

title: The Singer Solution to World Poverty
description: Singer suggests that Bob had to divert the train, saving the child and destroying his car. But wouldn't he do far better if he allowed the train to run over the child, sold his car and, at $200 per life, saved 1,000 children?

title: It's Only a 3 1/2-Hour Ride to Work, if Trains Are on Time
description: STARS were shining over Peconic Bay and string lights twinkled in the windows of the darkened antiques stores as Bill Hayes made his way through the still sleeping town of Southold. It was 5:30 A.M., and he was about to begin his daily commute.

title: A Refuge for Urbanites in Back Country Virginia
description: BECAUSE it is in the rugged Blue Ridge Mountains and is not served by railroads or major highways, Rappahannock County's residential and commercial growth has lagged far behind the counties that abut it on three sides, which are considered part of the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area.

title: Why Is This Wedding Different From All Other Weddings?
description: SURROUNDED by Colonial red-brick buildings and bathed in golden afternoon light, the betrothed proceeded down the aisle, each carrying a single purple iris. Under a white canopy, festooned with purple, yellow and white gladioluses, the couple read their vows, professed their love and embraced. It was undeniably breathtaking, straight out of Martha Stewart Living Lesbian Weddings.

title: Habitats/Downtown Manhattan; Moving in With the Boss And Renovating a Co-op
description: FELICITAS OEFELEIN, a 30-year-old immigrant from Germany who works as an interior designer, has moved five times in seven years. Her boss, she says, jokes that when it's time to paint, it's time to move. And clearly, she agrees.

title: Conversations/Dr. Ian Stevenson; You May Be Reading This In Some Future Past Life
description: AFTER years of mockery from colleagues, Dr. Ian Stevenson, Director of the Department of Personality Studies at the University of Virginia, is finally getting respect. In ''Old Souls: The Scientific Evidence For Past Lives,'' (Simon & Schuster, 1999) Tom Shroder, a Washington Post editor, reviews the 80-year-old clinical psychiatrist's research on reincarnation and finds it hard to refute.

title: Ms. Alexandre And Mr. King
description: Catherine Mead Alexandre, a daughter of Mrs. Daniel J. Bills of Nantucket, Mass., and the late J. Henry Alexandre 4th, was married yesterday to Angus Stanley King 3d, a son of the Rev. Edith C. Hazard of Topsham, Me., and Gov. Angus S. King Jr. of Maine, who lives in Brunswick and Augusta. The Rev. Daniel Warren performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Paul in Nantucket.

title: A Topless Protester at Higbee Is Convicted but Unbowed
description: Arlene Vogt has lost one battle in her legal quest to reopen Higbee Beach in Lower Township to nude sunbathing. Ms. Vogt was convicted last week of defying a township ordinance prohibiting nudity. On Aug. 7, Ms. Vogt removed her bikini top on Higbee Beach, continuing a protest she and her husband, Bill, of Middle Township, have been waging this summer. The township pushed nude sunbathing off the state-owned beach earlier this year when the state Legislature enacted a law saying local governments could enforce their ordinances on state-owned land in their municipalities.

title: Recycling a Tale of Revived Romance
description: CONTRARY to theater legend, Alfred Lunt and Lynne Fontanne did not receive across-the-board raves in ''The Guardsman,'' Ferenc Molnar's comedy about infidelity, identity and theatrical excess.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Armed and Crazy
description: Michael Blaine's first novel, THE DESPERATE SEASON (Rob Weisbach/Morrow, $24), is a literate thriller about a what happens when a young mental patient named Maurice Coleman dismisses himself from an institution, throws away his medication, buys a semiautomatic rifle and holds his family hostage in a secluded cabin in the woods. Blaine tells this story from a variety of perspectives. Among the voices are Maurice's mother, Moira, a topiary gardener who sometimes dreams of escaping her past into a ''sudden, new life''; his younger sister, Crissie, whom Maurice desires carnally; and Nathan, Maurice's father, who loves him unconditionally. For much of the novel, these narrators describe scenes that take place before, or on the periphery of, the crisis at the cabin, so that we dangle over the drama's center with a sense of vertigo. That center might best have been seen obliquely; this novel's more subtle virtues are trampled by scenes of unbridled madness and violence. But this fault does not negate this book's strengths, especially Blaine's consideration of how a family feels complicit when a member goes astray. Nathan's lover, Julia, is fascinated by the idea of what she calls ''referred pain''; she thinks that the aches between Nathan's shoulders ''may have nothing to do with their own muscles,'' but might be reflecting grief elsewhere. Crissie realizes that pain can also be transferred between closely related people because ''everybody in a family with a kid like Maurice feels like it's their fault.'' Later, she confesses: ''Even when I think about myself I think about him.'' Charles Wilson

title: UPN's 'Moesha,' The Nonwhite Hit Nobody Knows
description: THE people who make the sitcom ''Moesha'' can't help wishing that more television executives -- and viewers -- would take a cue from Dorothy in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Remember when she's leaving Emerald City and realizes that to find her heart's desire she needn't look ''any further than my own backyard''?

title: A Spectacular Run Ends Comeback Bid
description: There were nine minutes left in today's New York Urban League Classic, and the Grambling State Tigers had a tiny bit of hope to cling to. Though down by two touchdowns, they had started the fourth quarter with an impressive scoring drive and now had Hampton pinned at its own 2-yard line.

title: On the Road to 2000
description: Some New Year's travelers will be listening to the whistle of a steam train; others will be hoping to hear the howling of wolves. What follows is a sampling of packages and trips available. Unless otherwise noted, prices are per person, double occupancy; deposit and cancellation policies can be strict.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-26-99: Salient Facts: Money Laundering; All Washed Up
description: JUST HOW DO YOU LAUNDER MONEY?

title: Vicki Fabricant, Scott Jeffery
description: Vicki Fabricant and Scott James Jeffery were married last evening by Rabbi Marcia Rappaport at the Red Oak Mansion at the Westchester Renaissance Hotel in White Plains.

title: Interview; In His Opinion
description: IT is unusual for a sitting Federal judge to offer any comment at all on the passing public scene, let alone produce something close to an instant book about the most cataclysmic event in recent domestic politics. Judge Richard A. Posner knew all that, of course, when he began last October to write about the sex scandal engulfing the Clinton Presidency. Yet he found the unfolding saga ''irresistible,'' he said in an interview in his chambers in the Everett M. Dirksen Federal Building in Chicago. Although when he began writing Posner had no idea how the story would end, the events engaged his scholarly interest in the intersection of law, politics and morality -- one of his 30 books is ''Sex and Reason'' (1992) -- as well as his judicial interest in prosecution tactics and the law of perjury.

title: Medals for Graves and Segal
description: Michael Graves, the Princeton architect who designed the Newark Museum expansion, and George Segal, the New Brunswick sculptor who creates lifelike human figures out of white plaster are among the 11 recipients of the National Endowment of the Arts medals to be awarded at the White House on Wednesday.

title: The World: Blowback; In Moscow, a Whiff of Terror From Afar
description: IT would be easy, and to some tempting, to say that it is Russia's turn -- that after years of Soviet gloating over Islam's attacks on the West, that after the K.G.B.'s goading of proxies like the East Germans to arm Middle Eastern terrorists, that after the brutal destruction of Chechnya in the civil war three years ago, it is well past time that Russia had her own Islamic extremist problem.

title: Abortion-Method Ruling May Spur Supreme Court
description: A Federal appeals court ruling against three state laws banning a late-term abortion procedure has propelled the issue toward a hearing by the Supreme Court and could complicate efforts in Congress to outlaw the procedure.

title: Sick of Paperwork? Some Office Workers Say It's the Paper
description: CARBONLESS copy paper is everywhere. Write something on the top sheet, and it is replicated on the sheets below, usually in a medium blue hue, without fuss or mess. Handle the stuff now and then, as most people do, and it is a great convenience. But handle it constantly and, some people say, it will make you sick.

title: Against Irony
description: In light of reports of gun toting, violent, sex-offending youngsters in the mosh pits of America's vacuous pop culture, Jed Purdy is a hopeful, if not anachronistic, player.

title: The Cardinal's Sorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; A McCain Mutiny
description: THE way Republicans were acting last week it was almost as if some of them could not decide which was more uncomfortable: having Pat Buchanan leave the party or John McCain stay in it.

title: They Volunteered to Pull the Plug, But Will They Ever Do It Again?; Diary of a Video-Game Deprived Youth
description: FOR the last six years, every birthday or holiday gift that Josh Gelb, 14, of Plainview has received has been related to video games -- the latest disc or cartridge, magazines and playing guides.

title: IN MY... BAG: Maria Elena Lagomasino
description: Visiting American, Asian and European clients of Chase Manhattan's Global Private Bank keeps Maria Elena Lagomasino on the road nearly half the year. The customers, individuals or families with a net worth of more than $10 million, often look to the bank for help in handling succession -- effectively, the passing of all that money on to the next generation.

title: Against Irony
description: Am I the only reader who went from hating pop culture to feeling homesick for it after two pages spent with this guy? ''He was born judging people.'' How swell! I wonder if he's free for dinner Saturday night?

title: Forget Memory Loss!
description: THE FORCE OF CHARACTER

title: Embracing the Private Life
description: Erskine Bowles, the investment banker turned Clinton White House chief of staff turned investment banker, continues to resist another trip back into the public sector. After some pondering, he recently turned down an offer to become interim chancellor of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Among the drawbacks: no guarantee that he would become permanent chancellor. The interim job eventually went to William O. McCoy, a retired BellSouth executive, while a broader search is under way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, HERBERT C., III.
description: PELL-Herbert C., III. Of Tucson, Arizona on September 24 in Newport, Rhode Island. Beloved husband of Eugenia Stillman Diehl Pell and loving father of Christina O'Donnell Pell and Herbert Claiborne Pell, IV. Son of former U.S. Senator Claiborne Pell and Nuala Pell. title: Bookend; Lolita and the Lawyers
description: IS it good or bad for literature that ''Lo's Diary'' will finally see the light of day? A reimagining of Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lolita'' from Lolita's point of view, the novel, by Pia Pera, comes out next month after narrowly avoiding an expensive and divisive lawsuit. ''Lo's Diary'' was originally published in Italy in 1995, but it was not until Farrar, Straus & Giroux announced plans for an English-language translation last year that Dmitri Nabokov, the author's son, sued. He claimed copyright infringement, maintaining that Pera's novel borrowed unacceptably from ''Lolita,'' that fewer people would buy Nabokov's masterpiece as a result, and thus that the new novel would ''inflict immeasurable losses'' on one of the ''towering literary works of this century.'' Farrar, Straus backed down, and there the matter stood until Barney Rosset, head of Foxrock Inc., stepped in. As the attorney representing Foxrock, I argued that Pera's work was transformative in nature, and thus encouraged under the law. In the end, we worked out an agreement that allowed Pera to publish her novel in the United States and Britain, with a preface by Dmitri Nabokov and half the author's share of royalties to be donated to PEN. Both sides wanted more, but each got enough.

title: 'More Matter'
description: "More matter, with less art," Queen Gertrude advises Polonius; she sounds like a modern magazine editor. The appetite in the print trade is presently for real stuff  the dirt, the poop, the nitty-gritty  and not for the obliquities and tenuosities of fiction. A writer is almost never asked to write a story, let alone a poem; instead he or she is invited to pen introductions, reviews, and personal essays, preferably indiscreet. (Pen them, then fax them. Instant modemed communication and rapidly overlapping semes are a la mode.) Human curiosity, the abettor and stimulant of the fiction surge between Robinson Crusoe's adventures and Constance Chatterley's, has become ever more literal-minded and impatient with the proxies of the imagination. Present taste runs to the down-home divulgences of the talk show  psychotherapeutic confession turned into public circus  and to investigative journalism that, like so many heat-seeking missiles, seeks out the intimate truths, the very genitalia, of Presidents and princesses. It is as if, here at the end of a millennium, time is too precious to waste on anything but such central, perennially urgent data. And so it has come to pass that, in the 1990s, as I turned sixty and then reached sixty-two (senior discount at the movies!) and then passed retirement age, instead of devoting myself wholly to the elaboration of a few final theorems and dreams couched in the gauzy genres of make-believe, I have cranked out, in response to many a plausible request, the mass of more or less factual matter, of assorted prose, which Knopf has herewith heroically, indulgently printed and bound, my fifth such collection and  dare we hope?  my last.

description: COMBER-Thomas E., a member of the Paulist Fathers who was active in the field of publishing and inaugurated a nation-wide prison ministry in 1994, died on September 25, 1999, in New York City. Raised in Elkins Park, PA, he joined the Navy in 1943 and served until 1946. After attending LaSalle College in Philadelphia, he joined the Paulist Fathers and was ordained a priest in 1955. From 1962 until 1978, Fr. Comber directed marketing at Paulist Press, and served both as Chairman and member of the Board of Directors of the Catholic Press Association. From 1978 to 1991, he served as pastor of churches in Minneapolis, Houston and Tucson. Since 1991, he devoted himself to ministry at the Paulist National Catholic Evangelization Association, during which time he began PNCEA Prison Ministry services, providing a newsletter and religious material in English and Spanish to over 900 prison chaplains. He will be waked at the Paulist Fathers' Rectory, 415 W. 59th St., New York, Tuesday from 2:00 PM to 8:00 PM. His funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Paul the Apostle Church, New York, Wednesday at 10:00, with burial at Oak Ridge, NJ. An esteemed colleague and teacher, he served Columbia Presbyterian for more than 20 years. Dr. Conley was recognized throughout the world as an outstanding leader, teacher, and scholar devoted to the field of head and neck surgery. He had a profound influence on generations of medical students and colleagues. His many outstanding contributions to medical eduation, research, and practice will remain as a legacy for future generations of otolaryngologists. A long-time friend and colleague whose many contributions enriched the Department of Otolaryngology, he will be greatly missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. Conley's family.
