description: Luminous and impassive, radiating a mysterious sadness from her wide brown eyes and chiseled Aubrey Beardsley lips, Chiara Mastroianni is more than an image of virtue in Manoel de Oliviera's film ''The Letter.'' In this Portuguese director's contemporary update of the 17th-century French novel ''La Princesse de Cleves'' by Madame de Lafayette, she is the apotheosis of the sort of fervent morality that is the private domain only of saints and fools.

title: Does the Mayor Know Anything About Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONIME, STANLEY
description: BONIME-Stanley, at the age of 75, of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of Eastchester, NY. Beloved husband of Arlene. Devoted father of Erica, and Jonathan and Heather. Adoring grandfather of Lauren and Joshua. He was a graduate of NYU and NYU Dental School and had his practice in Manhattan for 46 years. He was a lifetime member of The Free Masons. Service, Wednesday, 10 AM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to, The American Heart Association or The Scottsdale Healthcare Foundation.

title: Quayle Bids Farewell to the Presidential Race, and, Effectively, an Era of His Career
description: His voice firm but his eyes glistening, former Vice President Dan Quayle effectively bid farewell today to a national political career that has made him a household name -- and sometimes a household laughing-stock -- for more than a decade, announcing that he would abandon his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination for lack of money and support.

title: Trial Opens in Killing of Basketball Player
description: It apparently began as a scoring dispute in a basketball game, part of an after-school program to encourage teen-agers to stay out of trouble and do well in school. It became a murderous attack by members and supporters of one team against players on the other, law enforcement officials have said.

title: Treasurer Seeks Reparations For Kickbacks
description: The Connecticut State Treasurer said tonight that she would seek reparations from investment firms that were involved in a bribery and kickback scheme that her predecessor, Paul J. Silvester, has admitted running as he placed pension funds.

title: Metro Business; Bayer Plans Expansion
description: Bayer A.G., the second-leading drug maker in Germany, has announced plans to expand its pharmaceutical division in West Haven, Conn., and to add 200 jobs over two years.

title: Futility by Number for the Jets and Giants
description: Offense and quarterbacks rule in this era of professional football. Little wonder that New York pro football teams are 1-5 and without a victory at home.

title: In the Ethics Storm on Human Embryo Research
description: On the white paper tablecloth, Brigid Hogan is sketching a diagram with the children's Crayolas the restaurant has thoughtfully provided. The daughter of two artists, she draws rapidly and precisely. The structure of an embryonic lung billows across the table. Words like ''sprouty,'' ''breathless,'' ''branchless,'' playful names for the genes that control the process, appear alongside arrows and curlicues.

title: In Shift, Secretary Supports Bill That Overhauls Energy Dept.
description: Reversing course, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson says he will recommend that President Clinton sign a $289 billion Pentagon budget bill that overhauls the Energy Department, creating an agency within the department to oversee nuclear weapons programs.

title: Amid Swirl of Doubt, Mets Hope for Redemption
description: In an attempt to break out of the slump that has sent them plummeting in the standing and jeopardized their playoff chances, the Mets have tried everything short of joining hands to sing ''It's a Small World.'' Ah, for the good old days, one week ago, when the Mets were just one game out of the division lead and had a firm four-game grip on the wild-card slot.

title: New Publisher With a Little Bronx Attitude
description: HERE is the newly named publisher of El Diario-La Prensa, Rossana Rosado, perched in a most unpublisher manner on the arm of her couch.

title: The Threat to the Food Supply Starts at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about books on the Sydney-Hobart racing disaster misstated the ownership of Pocket Books. It is part of Viacom's Simon & Schuster unit -- not of Pearson, which purchased some of Simon & Schuster's education publishing operations last year.

title: F.A.A. Has Trouble Getting Views on Plan to Cut Airport Noise
description: Plane noise may be a big irritant in some places, but the Federal Aviation Administration has had trouble attracting many people to discuss its effort to redraw the air traffic routes around the New York area.

title: Women's group is set to present its Good, Bad and Ugly Awards.
description: TURN to the pages of the thesaurus where synonyms for ''sexist,'' ''demeaning'' and ''stereotype'' are found. Dust off the airbrushes for obscuring or deleting gratuitous pulchritude and smarmy double-entendres. And cue the CD of movie theme songs by Ennio Morricone. It's time for another annual installment of what are called the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Awards, meant to encourage improvement in how women are portrayed in advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILPERN, HERBERT
description: HEILPERN-Herbert. Of Englewood Cliffs, NJ, on September 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Lillian (nee Gooen). Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ on Wednesday, September 29, at 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPP, ALBERT O.
description: PHILIPP-Albert O. On September 27, 1999 in his 101st year. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Cherished father of Annette Radley and Ursula Tieger. Adored grandfather of Helen, Lisa, Jonathan, Rabbi Philip and Anthony. Devoted great grandfather of eleven. His extraordinary life of words and deeds is an inspiration to all who knew him.

title: Metro Business; Cablevision to Shed Outlying Properties
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, which serves 2.8 million cable television subscribers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said yesterday that it was pursuing options for cutting its debt load by seeking ''strategic alternatives'' for its cable systems outside the New York metropolitan region.

title: Victim's Parents Reconcile With Killer's
description: They had regarded each other in enmity and silence for two years, having become entangled for the most horrible of reasons, but today, the parents of Eddie Werner and the parents of Sam Manzie stepped forward somberly to say they were reconciling.

title: TV Producer Is From New Breed of Woman
description: Zhao Shujing became a feminist only in 1994, after she read ''The Second Sex'' by Simone de Beauvoir, then recently translated into Chinese. Today, she is the executive producer of China's most influential women's show, ''Half the Sky,'' which broadcasts three times a week on state television.

title: DQE TO SELL 7 POWER PLANTS TO ORION FOR $1.71 BILLION
description: DQE Inc. agreed yesterday to sell seven power plants in Ohio and Pennsylvania to Orion Power Holdings Inc. for $1.71 billion as it exits the generation business and focuses on transmitting electricity. Orion is a joint venture between Constellation Energy Group, owner of Baltimore Gas and Electric, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. The coal- and oil-fired plants can generate 2,614 megawatts of power, enough to light 2.6 million homes, and have a book value of $1.1 billion. DQE, which is based in the Pittsburgh suburb of Coraopolis, Pa., said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, RUTH RAY
description: HUNT-Ruth Ray. The Board and staff of The Sister Fund notes the passing of Mrs. H. L. Hunt, beloved mother of the foundation's President and founder, Helen LaKelly Hunt. The family has requested, in lieu of flowers, memorial donatoions be made to either the Ruth Ray Scholarship Fund, Criswell College, 4010 Gaston Avenue, Dallas, TX 75201 or Baylor Hospital, House Calls Program, (Attn Dr. Ziad Haydar), 4004 Worth Street, Dallas, TX. 75246.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVAK, ELLEN BETH
description: KOVAK-Ellen Beth. Of Wilton, CT. Beloved wife of Stan. Loving mother of Janet. Died at home on Saturday, September 25, 1999. A memorial service will be held at Saint Thomas Church, One W. 53 St, N.Y., Wednesday, September 29th, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to Connecticut Hospice, 30 Stevens Street, Norwalk, CT. 06850.

title: Review/Fashion; In London, the Rebels Find Their Causes
description: With some pride, British fashion designers used to be the most commercially inept in the world. They were too wayward and eccentric to do much more than, in effect, blow marvelous soap bubbles across the water at the French and the Italians, who instantly exploited their playpen ideas. And even now, one can't say that John Galliano and Alexander McQueen are bona fide English successes, since their money comes from abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYNE, SCHAEFER, COLLEEN
description: COYNE-SCHAEFER-Colleen. On Sunday, September 26, 1999. Colleen Dougheny Coyne-Schaefer, PhD. of South Orange formerly of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved wife of Michael C. Schaefer. Devoted mother of Sean P. and Sarah M. Coyne. Loving dughter of Eleanor Stoneburgh Dougheny. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral service at The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave, Maplewood, Thursday Sept. 30th at 11:00 AM. Interment in Fairview Cemetery, Westfield. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9 PM & Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Alzheimer's Northern NJ Chapter, 299 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, NJ 07054 would be appreciated.

title: A New Opera, Dead on the Vine? Trusting the Audience
description: Why do new operas, after the hoopla of their premieres, suffer such short shelf lives thereafter? Composers, the principal sufferers, are consulted in a recent article in these pages, part of a series on the birth of a new opera. Consulted too are intendants, music publishers and artist managers.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gold Soars but Its Future Is Cloudy
description: THE central banks of Europe, which own nearly half of the gold held by governments and institutions, have begun a rescue mission for gold, which slid to a 20-year low earlier this year.

title: Encephalitis Outbreak Teaches an Old Lesson
description: When you hear hoofbeats, don't think of zebras.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NETMANAGE INC., Cupertino, Calif., a networking-software company, said it planned to buy the Internet software maker Simware Inc., Ottawa, for $28 million in cash to strengthen its electronic-commerce business.

title: The Guggenheim Proposes Gehry Museum for New York
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum has submitted a proposal to New York City for a dramatic new curvilinear building designed by Frank O. Gehry that would rise as high as 45 stories on a platform over four East River piers near Wall Street.

title: Ecuador's Planned Default Does Not Jolt Latin Markets
description: Easing fears of market turbulence, stocks rose and currencies steadied across much of Latin America today, the first day of trading after weekend news that Ecuador would default on some foreign debt and that Colombia had abandoned its system for defending the foreign-exchange value of its currency.

title: Tight Security Blitz Aims to Prevent Protests in Beijing
description: As they complete preparations for extravagant festivities on Friday marking 50 years of Communist rule, the Chinese authorities are leaving nothing to chance. This week, as rehearsals involving hundreds of thousands of marchers, rumbling convoys of tanks and screaming squadrons of fighter jets taper down, the focus has shifted to security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, DOROTHY (NEE ISRAEL)
description: STEINBERG-Dorothy (nee Israel), formerly of Pittsburgh, PA. on September 25, 1999 at age eighty-eight. Dearly beloved wife of Abraam, loving mother of Susan and Mark, cherished grandmother of Lauren and Katherine. Memorial service will be held at a later date. For further information, contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 212-362-6600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSTEN, FREDA. YOUNG
description: ROSTEN-Freda. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the death of our esteemed, longtime member and extends our heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: REPRESENTATIVE RETURNING HOME
description: China's top negotiator in charge of securing his country's entry into the World Trade Organization held a single day of talks with his American counterparts in Washington, then said he was returning to Beijing for his nation's 50th anniversary celebrations. The brief trip by Shi Guangsheng left the Clinton Administration mystified. It scheduled the talks in an effort to secure Congressional approval of a trade accord this year.

title: GLOBAL INVESTMENT BOOM
description: Cross-border investments increased by almost 40 percent, to $644 billion, last year and may exceed $800 billion this year, with most of the flow among industrialized countries, the United Nations Trade and Development agency said. In its annual report, the agency attributed much of the investment rise to international mergers and acquisitions. The agency said that despite the Asia financial crisis, cross-border investment in Asian countries totaled $85 billion, down only 11 percent from the year before.

title: A Debate Over Safety Of Softeners For Plastic
description: They are called phthalates, and their job is to make plastic flexible so it can be used in tubes for blood transfusions, intravenous feeding and other life-support systems at hospitals and clinics around the world -- and in some children's toys.

title: Role Reversal In Merger Deal
description: The Westinghouse Air Brake Company and Motivepower Industries reversed roles today in a revised $475.3 million stock-swap merger that would create North America's largest rail-parts maker and build on rail-industry consolidation.

title: EGLOBE TO BUY TRANS GLOBAL FOR ABOUT $80 MILLION
description: Eglobe Inc., which provides telecommunications and information services over the Internet, agreed to buy the closely held Trans Global Communications Inc. for about $80 million in stock. Eglobe said Trans Global's emerging Internet voice network in the Middle East complements Eglobe's systems in Asia and Latin America. Trans Global expects more than $100 million in revenue this year, Eglobe said. Washington-based Eglobe, which had $30 million in 1998 sales, will assume $10 million of Trans Global's debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYE, GEORGE LEWIS
description: NYE-George Lewis, age 91, of Montclair, NJ, formerly of Upper Montclair, on September 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Alma (nee Capen) Nye. Devoted father of Margery Kerr of Harpswell, ME., Betty Gordon of Chapel Hill, NC., George Nye Jr. of Monterey, CA and Thomas C. Nye of Upper Montclair, NJ. Also survived by eight grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held 3PM Wednesday, Oct. 6, 1999 at the Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Ave., Upper Montclair, NJ. Services are under the direction of the Arthur K. Brown, Inc., 337 Belleville Avenue, Bloomfield. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the United Way of North Essex, 60 South Fullerton Ave., Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: Japanese Officials Insist Yen Policy Hasn't Changed
description: Japanese monetary officials have spent the last few days trying to dispel the impression that they changed monetary policy to weaken the yen as a result of foreign pressure at a weekend meeting of rich industrialized nations.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Is Questioned On Aid to Bush
description: A former Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives, Ben Barnes, was questioned today for more than five hours in a deposition in which he was expected to discuss his role in recommending George W. Bush for a pilot's slot in a National Guard unit during the Vietnam War.

title: America Online Unit to Reduce Subscription Costs in Britain
description: Hoping to stem its market slide in Britain, America Online said today that it would lower the monthly cost of subscribing to its service here.

title: Bail Is $5 Million in Killing of Bride-to-Be
description: A prominent businessman charged with murdering his former girlfriend on her wedding day was ordered held today on $5 million bail.

title: If Mencken Were Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Outbreak of Virus in New York Much Broader Than Suspected
description: Health and wildlife officials said yesterday that nearly twice as many people in the New York region as had previously been recognized had been stricken by a mosquito-borne illness, and they said the virus might be present in a far larger geographic area than they originally suspected.

title: Taking to the Court for Basketball 101
description: I have a pretty odd sports closet. For one thing, it's an armoire. For another, it's crammed with gear more suited to mountains, rivers and ''Rocky'' than the asphalt playground known as New York City. Open it and out tumbles a rock-climbing harness, ski wax, a headlamp and a mouth guard. And that's just the first wave. But you'll never be bonked by bats, clubs or balls; I've never been much for conventional sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARLOW, RICKI
description: TARLOW-Ricki. September 26, 1999. Devoted mother of Bill Schacter of Newton, Massachusetts, Peg Ryan of Plainville, Massachusetts, and Wendy Chava Schacter of West Fork, Arkansas. Loving grandmother of four grandchildren. She was a copy editor for Time, Inc. for more than 20 years. Memorial service at the U.N. Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza (1st Ave/44th. St.) on Wednesday at 2:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Center of Complex Systems, Brandeis University, 415 South Street, MS 126, Waltham, MA. 02454.

title: London Fog Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
description: London Fog Industries, one of the best-known names in raincoats, sought bankruptcy protection yesterday and said it would close about 110 of its 140 retail stores.

title: Young & Rubicam Takes Top Honors
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York has taken top honors, winning the most awards, at the seventh annual Cresta International Advertising Awards competition.

title: Irabu, Aiming for Post-Season, Fails a Test
description: There was nothing Hideki Irabu could do last night to force himself into the rotation for the post-season. The Yankees will use four starters, and Irabu has been the fifth option for more than a month. What Irabu is trying to prove to Manager Joe Torre is that he deserves to be on the 25-man roster as a long reliever. Even that probability is unsettled now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, MICHAEL J. JR.
description: O'LEARY-Michael J. Jr., MD, of Ossining, NY died suddenly on September 26, 1999. Dr. O'Leary was born on July 20, 1946 in Manhattan and was the son of Michael J. Sr. and Mary Regina O'Leary. He was a graduate of Iona College where he earned a B.A. Degree Cum Laude in 1968 and a B.S. Degree Cum Laude in 1969. He received his medical degree in 1974 from Downstate Medical College and completed residencies in family practice and ophthalmology at J.F.K. Medical Center in Edison, NJ and Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, NY. He entered private practice for Ophthalmology in Putnam County, NY in 1988 and had practiced emergency medicine several years prior. Since 1995 he had been a member of the voluntary teaching staff in the Department of Ophthalmology at Westchester County Medical Center-New York Medical College. On November 2, 1984, he married Anne Compton at Sacred Heart Church in Hartsdale, NY. He is survived by his wife Anne, his father Michael J. Sr, his stepmother Mary, three daughters Jeanmarie, Aileen and Meaghan, one son Michael J. III, his brothers John and Vincent, his sister Jean, and several nieces and nephews. Visiting hours will be held Tuesday, 7-9 and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Dorsey Funeral Home, 14 Emwilton Place, Ossining, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday at 10AM at St. Augustine's Church in Ossining. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the American Heart Association, 320 Westchester Avenue, Purchase, NY 10577.

title: Prosecutors Urged to Allow Appeals on DNA
description: A high-level study commission appointed by Attorney General Janet Reno today urged prosecutors across the nation to be more amenable to reopening cases where convictions might be overturned because of the use of DNA testing.

title: Copper Producers Consider Scuttling Merger Agreement
description: Asarco Inc. and the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company said yesterday that they would seek alternatives to their merger agreement of last July, which could result in putting both companies on the auction block.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the writer and producer Ivan Goff on Saturday misidentified a star of ''The Rogues,'' a television series he created in the 1960's with his partner, Ben Roberts. The series starred David Niven, Charles Boyer and Gig Young. Dick Powell was not in the cast.

description: ''Hallelujah! Forty-year-olds are sexy!''

title: Imitating NATO: A Script Is Adapted for Chechnya
description: Russia's military leaders have a simple explanation for the bombs raining down on Chechnya. They say they are copying NATO's air campaign against Yugoslavia.

title: Zuckerman Reluctantly Sells Atlantic
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman has sold the venerable 140-year-old magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, to David G. Bradley, a Washington millionaire who has been trying to raise the profile of a fledgling media empire, it was announced last night. The sale was for an undisclosed sum.

title: ARCH CHEMICALS BUYS BUSINESS FROM EASTMAN CHEMICAL
description: Arch Chemicals Inc., which was spun off by the Olin Corporation in February, said yesterday that it had bought a specialty-chemicals business from the Eastman Chemical Company to expand its products used to make tough plastics for skateboard wheels and other goods. Arch, based in Norwalk, Conn., bought Eastman's HQEE -- Hydroquinone Di Ether -- specialty-chemicals business for an undisclosed price. HQEE is used to make high-performance plastics for skateboard wheels, forklift tires, machine rollers and other products. This makes Arch the biggest United States supplier of HQEE and a major global supplier.

title: The Bright Young Stars of China's Future
description: Officially, power in China is concentrated in the hands of a small number of men, all career Communist politicians who were alive when the People's Republic was declared on Oct. 1, 1949.

title: Public Interests; A Birdie in the Bush
description: I don't know where you were Saturday night, but it now becomes clear that a small segment of the American population -- tiny in number but mighty in per capita income -- was worrying about whether our golf team could win the Ryder Cup.

title: After Last Week's 524-Point Drop, Dow Rebounds a Bit
description: Stock prices rebounded a bit yesterday as investors became selective buyers of shares that were hit particularly hard by last week's selloff.

title: 'Cav' and 'Pag' Pairing Opens the Met Season
description: Buried under all the news coming out of the Metropolitan Opera House last night there was opera -- two short ones, in fact. After the accountants had toted up the record-setting numbers, after first-nighters' sequins had fluttered to repose in the seats, and after an army of cafeteria union organizers had sung their final aria on the sidewalks outside, the Met opened its season with the beloved duo ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''I Pagliacci.''

title: Underwood Knifed Himself, According to the Police
description: The curious case of Dimitrius Underwood has taken a stunning turn, with the police in Lansing, Mich., saying today that the neck wound that Underwood, a Miami Dolphins defensive end, sustained on Sunday was self-inflicted.

title: Italy Sees Russian Mob Link Through Bank of New York
description: A two-year criminal investigation has turned up the first concrete evidence that suspected organized crime operators from Russia have funneled millions of dollars through the Bank of New York, prosecutors here say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, RUTH W.
description: TISHMAN-Ruth W. On September 26, 1999, at age ninety-four. Her children, family and friends mourn deeply her passing. Widow of Paul, beloved mother and grandmother, she is survived by two daughters Jean Harrison of CT and Ellen Rosenthal of Westchester, six grandchildren and ten great grandchildren.

title: Xoma Stock Drops on Setback for Drug
description: The shares of Xoma Ltd. lost more than half their value today after the concern, a biotechnology company, said it had halted a late-stage trial of its drug Neuprex for preventing infection in patients with severe blood loss from injuries.

title: Crowded Florida Keys A Paradise in Trouble
description: For a minute or two, as the tall, tanned, beautiful woman from Norway splashed and laughed in the shallows, it was just another picture-postcard moment in the blue-green waters of Key West.

Glasser, loving Mother of Nikki and Mark Arnstein and Dr. Morton P. Glasser, beloved Grandmother of David and Randi Arnstein, loving sister of William J. Tarr, cherished sister-in-law and aunt. description: Seeking to end a dispute with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over a controversial art exhibition, the chairman of the Brooklyn Museum of Art discussed with city officials yesterday the possibility of removing the painting that had become the flash point of the controversy: a dung-stained portrait of the Virgin Mary.

title: No Profits But Already He's Famous
description: In China, too, hackers and M.B.A.'s dream of silicon jackpots. Among the many start-ups trying to emulate everything from Yahoo to Ebay, three-year-old Sparkice I-Com Ltd. is already the Old Guard, and its 36-year-old founder Zeng Qiang -- Edward Zeng to foreigners -- is already famous. All this before his company has made a dime or seriously begun carrying out its plan for global e-commerce.

title: Clinton Visits Poor School to Voice Education Theme
description: A week after Sophie B. Wright Middle School was labeled ''academically unacceptable,'' President Clinton used the school's aging, overcrowded campus today as a backdrop for his call for beefed up education financing.

title: For a Jolt, Giants Turn to Montgomery
description: Troubled by an offense that cannot shake itself out of its annual early season disintegration, Giants Coach Jim Fassel will make some changes in his lineup.

title: Heeding Doctor's Orders on Gun Safety
description: Pediatricians routinely counsel families about the importance of seat belts and smoke alarms. The American Academy of Pediatrics has long urged its members to add gun safety to that list -- but with less success, according to a new study reported in the September issue of the journal Pediatrics.

title: Arbitrator Named To Rule on 22 Jobs
description: The hopes of 22 umpires to regain their jobs will rest with Alan Symonette, a Philadelphia arbitrator.

description: Merrill Lynch & Company plans to offer after-hours trading to its five million brokerage customers next year, the head of the firm's brokerage unit said at a conference in San Francisco yesterday.

description: Treasury bond prices fell for the first time in four sessions yesterday as stocks recovered a little of last week's declines, dampening the demand for bonds.

title: On-Line Grocer Appoints Chief Executive
description: Peapod Inc., an on-line grocer, said today that it had named an AT&T Corporation executive, Bill Malloy, as president and chief executive.

title: A Daring Central Duet Takes a Literal Approach
description: Dance Theater of Harlem's third program at City Center was varied and substantial on Friday night. George Balanchine's ''Bugaku'' and Glen Tetley's ''Dialogues'' were performed for the first time in the company's continuing season, along with a repeat of Geoffrey Holder's vibrant ''Dougla.''

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about Us magazine misstated the publication schedule to which it is being changed by Wenner Media. Us is becoming a weekly; it has been a monthly.

title: Spending Bills Cannot Meet The Deadline, G.O.P. Admits
description: With four days left before the start of the new fiscal year, Republican leaders in Congress formally conceded today that they would not meet the deadline for passing the annual spending bills, and the White House laid down a new deadline, three weeks away.

title: Growing Competitive Pressure Fuses 2 German Conglomerates
description: In a notable sign of the competitive pressures on European industry, the German energy and chemical conglomerates Veba A.G. and Viag A.G. agreed today on a $14.1 billion merger.

description: Now you see it, now you don't. Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has un-endorsed Vice President Al Gore in the increasingly heated campaign against former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: With 'Patriotic Challenge,' McCain Makes Run Official
description: In the state where he is hoping to pull off an upset, John McCain formally began his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination today, pledging to restore faith in government ''so that Americans can believe once again that public service is a summons to duty and not a lifetime of privilege.''

title: Excerpts from McCain's Speech Declaring Candidacy
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today in Nashua, N.H., by Senator John McCain of Arizona declaring his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Devils Lose Sutton And Williams
description: The Devils lost the experienced defenseman Ken Sutton and the minor league forward Jeff Williams in the National Hockey League's waiver draft yesterday before they trimmed their roster to 25 players.

title: A Record U.S. Fine at a Connecticut Nuclear Plant
description: The owner of the Millstone Nuclear Power Station in eastern Connecticut admitted today that it had falsified environmental records and deliberately promoted unqualified plant operators. The owner, Northeast Nuclear Energy Company, pleaded guilty to 23 Federal felonies and agreed to pay $10 million in fines, the largest penalty ever for a nuclear plant in this country.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the record for which Placido Domingo was headed, for the most opening-night performances at the Metropolitan Opera -- 18, surpassing Enrico Caruso's 17 -- misidentified one of Mr. Domingo's previous opening-night tenor roles. It was Wagner's Siegmund, not Siegfried.

title: Portrait of the Pope, Confronting the Tides of History
description: Tonight's thoughtful ''Frontline'' portrait of John Paul II presents the popular Pope as a man resisting, in the name of the church he leads, many of the century's movements of which he despairs. He has been a triumphant force against Communism, a somewhat embattled opponent of church reforms, particularly as they might affect women, and a critic of capitalism run amok. In powerful exhortations that sometimes cut across the usual ideological lines, he has become the world's voice against what he calls a prevailing ''culture of death,'' whether it be in the form of capital punishment or abortion.

title: 2 Boroughs' Garbage Going to New Jersey, Drawing Ire
description: In a move that, if only provisionally, goes a long way toward ending New York City's dependence on the Fresh Kills landfill, the city plans to truck all of Manhattan's and Staten Island's residential garbage to New Jersey starting next month, the Sanitation Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLL, MAE

Survived by her devoted daughter Ellen (Herbert) Pearlman, loving sister Rose Gallay, caring brother Harold Kester. Predeceased by brother Murray Kester. Services Tuesday, September 28, 1 PM, at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI

title: Freelancers Win Appeal in Copyright Suit
description: In a decision that could reshape copyright protections for the electronic age, a Federal appeals court has ruled that three major publishers could not include the work of freelance contributors in electronic data bases without their permission.

title: When a Disease Gets Wings
description: The West Nile virus outbreak has shocked New Yorkers with the realization that a single mosquito bite can be fatal. They may be even more shocked to know that such outbreaks are preventable.

title: Tobacco Giant Gave to Backer Of Pataki Trips
description: Four years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki took a widely publicized trip to Hungary to promote trade and trace his roots in the homeland of his paternal grandparents. Newly elected, the Governor cut a triumphant swath through the country, meeting political leaders in Budapest and distant cousins in ancestral villages. A year later, he visited again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRLIN, REUBEN (RUBY)
description: SIRLIN-Reuben (Ruby). The Westchester Jewish Center family deeply mourns the death of our Honorary Trustee and Past President, Ruby Sirlin, and extends our sympathy to his wife, Adeline, his son and Center member, Roger, and his wife, Ellen, his daughter, Fran, and her husband, John Suydam, and his son, Arnold. Our condolences also go to his sister, Marsha Greenberg, and his grandchildren, Cliff, Robin and Jeff, and great - grandchildren, Zachary, Rachel and Grant. He shall always be remembered as a warm and loyal friend, an individual of high integrity whose concern for the needs of others and our Center was evident through the years. His philanthropy and generosity to our Center and concern for our synagogue's well-being will be missed. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Randy Heller, President Jeffrey Segelman, Rabbi Dr. Irving Koslowe, Rabbi Em.

title: Lowe Group Creates The Octagon Brand
description: Lowe Group in London and New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is rebranding its sports marketing and entertainment operations under the name Octagon.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL PLANS TO SELL 3 OF ITS UNITS
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, an automotive parts maker, said yesterday that it planned to sell its lighting, wiper blade and fuel units. The company said it wanted to sell the operations to focus on its powertrain, sealing and brake system businesses. The units that are for sale have annual sales of about $700 million and employ 5,400 people, Federal-Mogul said. The company, based in Southfield, Mich., had 1998 revenue of $4.47 billion. Shares of Federal-Mogul closed at $24.875, up 37.5 cents. The shares fell to a 52-week low of $23 last Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: A Ballet Under the Sun, Courtesy of Melville and Legionnaires
description: Although the films of Claire Denis have always displayed a cool, vaguely hallucinatory appreciation of the surfaces of the world, none of this gifted French filmmaker's previous work has prepared us for the voluptuous austerity of ''Beau Travail.'' Loosely adapted from ''Billy Budd'' and set in a French Foreign Legion outpost in the East African enclave of Djibouti, the film is narrated by Sergeant Galoup (Denis Lavant), the movie's equivalent of Claggart, the sinister master-of-arms who destroys an innocent sailor in Melville's allegorical novella.

title: With Salsa, Singing A New Tune
description: Latin music, like no other genre, is full of contingency plans for the careers of its stars. At the moment, singers can move from freestyle (dance-club music sung in English), to salsa, to English-language pop, depending on their age and level of popularity; it has been proven several times within the last few years that it's possible to do so without damaging one's reputation.

title: Holding Fast to His Inspiration; An Artist Tries to Keep His Cool in the Face of Angry Criticism
description: Chris Ofili is hunkered down in his central London studio, screening the avalanche of phone calls he has been getting for the last few days and trying not to obsess about the uproar over ''The Holy Virgin Mary,'' his 1996 painting of a black Madonna with a clump of elephant dung on one breast and cutouts of genitalia from pornographic magazines in the background.

title: Misuse of Drug Treatment Records
description: The Giuliani administration's plan to use Medicaid billing records to steer welfare applicants into drug and alcohol treatment is a dangerous violation of medical confidentiality. Under the proposal, reported by Nina Bernstein in The Times, New York City's Human Resources Administration would search its Medicaid payment records for evidence that welfare applicants had in the past sought drug or alcohol treatment. Applicants whose names turned up in the records could then be forced into further drug treatment in order to get or keep benefits.

title: BRAZIL INFLATION HINT
description: A widely watched measure of inflationary pressure in Brazil is rising at a quicker pace, raising concern that the central bank may not reduce interest rates much further. Inflation in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, increased nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent in the 30 days that ended on Sept. 24, largely because of higher housing and entertainment costs, the Institute for Economic Research said. That compares with an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the previous 30 days.

title: JUST DON'T DO IT, NIKE IS TOLD
description: Spain's Supreme Court ruled that Nike International, a unit of the Oregon-based sportswear company Nike Inc., cannot sell Nike apparel in Spain because a Spanish company, Cidesport, has rights to the Nike clothing trademark, registered in 1932, long before the American company was founded. The ruling, made last Wednesday, does not affect Nike footwear, but it overturned two lower-court rulings that favored Nike in a decadelong dispute with its one-time local partner, Cidesport, based in a Barcelona suburb.

title: Russia's Chechen Gamble
description: Russia's bombing of Chechnya has been advertised by Defense Minister Igor Sergeyev as a plan to ''eliminate the bandits'' terrorizing Russian apartment dwellers and to create a zone of Russian security around Chechnya. It is a risky battle plan -- a pursuit of Islamic militants in the Caucasus that threatens to create political and military havoc not only in Chechnya but in Moscow as well.

title: INSIDE
description: A Future of Earthquakes

title: CRESVALE FILES A SUIT
description: The Tokyo branch of Cresvale International filed a criminal complaint against executives and employees at Princeton Economics International Inc. and its custody agent for suspected fraud. Cresvale, which sold funds run by Princeton to Japanese corporations, filed suit against its parent and Republic National Securities. Akira Setogawa, above, chairman of Cresvale in Tokyo, told 37 Japanese investors that about 109 billion yen ($1 billion) of their money was missing. Earlier, Martin A. Armstrong, chairman of Princeton, was charged in the United States with defrauding Japanese investors of about $1 billion.

title: Palmer Out 6 Weeks
description: University of Southern California quarterback Carson Palmer will be out at least six weeks with a broken right collarbone, Coach Paul Hackett said.

title: Sports of The Times; How to Keep Mets' Season In Perspective
description: FRED AND JUDY WILPON celebrated their 41st wedding anniversary yesterday. The Wilpons celebrated with a romantic dinner and pleasant thoughts about all the beautiful things they shared: a good marriage, a long marriage, three children and their grandchildren. For at least an evening the Wilpons could put the dismal events of the last week behind.

title: Scientists Discover New Clues to Earthquakes' Deadly Vibrations
description: When Dr. Yehuda Ben-Zion visited Turkey three days after the recent earthquake there, he saw the deadly capriciousness that is familiar to survivors of such cataclysms. The dividing line between a seemingly untouched building and a pile of rubble might be no more than a few yards wide, said Dr. Ben-Zion, a seismologist and geophysicist at the University of Southern California.

title: Musical Luxury From Handel, With British Gloss on Its Riches
description: Handel measures the New York City Opera's progress under Paul Kellogg's regime with considerable accuracy. ''Xerxes'' came as a pleasant surprise two seasons ago. ''Ariodante'' on Sunday afternoon was even better.

title: SHONEY'S TO CLOSE OR SELL 81 RESTAURANTS AND CUT JOBS
description: Shoney's Inc., which operates restaurant chains, said yesterday that it would close 72 sites and sell 9 more, cutting 2,351 jobs, to increase profits. Shoney's expects to close the company-owned restaurants by the end of October, and it will take a $5.3 million fourth-quarter charge. It will also sell five Charlotte, N.C., restaurants to the franchisee Graham Foods and four to Bud Foods for an undisclosed price. The closings and job cuts, which represent about 9 percent of its work force, come as Shoney's aims to return to profitability after reporting a loss of $107.7 million last year.

title: First Lady Assails Mayor Over Threat To Museum
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton joined a line of Democrats yesterday in denouncing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's threat to cut city financing to the Brooklyn Museum of Art for mounting an exhibition that Mr. Giuliani described as offensive to Catholics. Mrs. Clinton called it a ''very wrong response,'' although she also described the exhibition as objectionable.

title: He Skirts Boundaries Of the System
description: For the record, Liu Junning does political theory, not politics, which is why this 38-year-old scholar is able to do much of anything at all. As one of China's most influential liberal intellectuals -- that is liberal as in ''Western liberal democracy'' -- he operates on the boundaries of the permissible here, disseminating ideas that he thinks are vital to the country's progress.

title: Detecting Colon Cancer When It Is Curable
description: When a famous person is found to have a serious and potentially fatal disease, it often serves as a wake-up call for the rest of us. Just as Nancy Reagan's breast cancer stimulated a rush for mammography, the recently diagnosed colon cancer of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court should jolt all women (and men) over 50 -- and some younger people as well -- to take advantage of the tests that can detect this disease while it is still curable, perhaps even before it has become cancer.

title: Building Robot Aides To Follow Astronauts
description: Astronauts on the International Space Station may get tiny robot helpers to assist them in daily chores and to buzz around their orbiting outpost, monitoring its condition.

title: I.B.M. Will Provide Services to Dell Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation won a contract to provide $6 billion in services to the Dell Computer Corporation during the next seven years, enhancing Dell's effort to sell sophisticated computers to corporations, the companies said yesterday.

title: A Ruinous Yen Policy
description: Masaru Hayami, governor of the Bank of Japan, tantalized Western finance officials meeting over the weekend in Washington by hinting that the bank would begin printing more yen -- a necessary step if Japan is to pull itself out of a decade-long slump. But the governor issued no firm commitments. Indeed, he even denied that his words represented a change in policy.

title: Trial Opens For Pinochet With Listing Of 35 Crimes
description: Lawyers arguing that Gen. Augusto Pinochet should be extradited to Spain to stand trial on torture charges said at a hearing today that he faces ''some of the most serious allegations of crime ever to come before English criminal courts.''

title: Home Financing for the Clintons
description: President and Mrs. Clinton have reportedly given up on the idea of financing the purchase of their new house in Westchester County with a $1.35 million loan guarantee from Terry McAuliffe, a Democratic fund-raiser who has raised millions for the Clintons' legal defense fund and the Presidential library. The step may not do much to restore Mr. Clinton's record for financial appearances, but it is a smart move for Hillary Rodham Clinton. By securing a normal commercial mortgage, Mrs. Clinton can assure New York voters that if elected to the Senate, she would be acting for their good rather than for that of financial benefactors.

title: European Court Tells British To Let Gay Soldiers Serve
description: The European Court of Human Rights declared today that Britain's longstanding ban on homosexuals in the military was a violation of the basic human right to privacy.

title: Derring-Do Redone, Once More
description: In the annals of weight loss on Broadway, ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' stands out as a model dieter. Frank Wildhorn and Nan Knighton's retelling of Baroness Orczy's 1905 novel of derring-do and secret identity during the French Revolution was bloated, flabby and listless when it opened at the cavernous Minskoff Theater in 1997, a dinosaur blimp at a moment when even Lord Lloyd Webber was saying the overblown musical was dead.

title: Tips to Arrests, French Pursue a Mass Killing in Kosovo
description: The French police serving as peacekeepers in Kosovo today notified the families of 26 men missing from town for five months that the men had been killed by Serbs and dumped in a mass grave, and that four suspects had been arrested.

title: Gay British Soldiers Win
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled unanimously that Britain's longstanding ban on homosexuals in the military violated the basic human right to privacy. Human rights lawyers said the decision meant that Britain would almost certainly be forced to allow openly gay men and women into the military for the first time.

title: China's Bright Young Stars
description: They were only in their teens when Mao died in 1976; they came of age in the more outward-looking China of Deng Xiaoping. They do not know the fear and caution that their parents and grandparents imbibed with revolution and repression; they are not strangers to the world; they are not afraid of reform. And when the men who have led the Communist state through the half-century since its founding on Oct. 1, 1949, are gone, they may well be among its leaders. Who are they?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, PAMELA SPENCE SMIT
description: RICHARDS-Pamela Spence Smit. On September 20, 1999, at the age of 58, adored wife of J.W. Smit, beloved mother of Marijke and Guy, stepmother of Tijn and Michiel, sister of Antonia Girard. Pamela graduated from the Brearley School, Radcliffe College and received her doctorate from Columbia University. Pamela Richards was a professor at The School of Communications and Library Science of Rutgers University. She wrote several books and a great number of articles in the field of international scientific communication, several of which won awards. International relations in the library world had her special attention, focusing on the former Soviet Union where she taught as a visiting professor. Up until her death she was editing a book on international librarianship that will be published under the title of ''Constructing The Heritage Of Cultures.'' A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday September 30th at 5 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Instead of flowers, the family is requesting that gifts be made to The Pamela Richards Memorial Scholarship Fund, Rutgers Foundation, 7 College Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ 08901, or to a memorial fund to be established in Pamela's name at the Neuroscience Institute of JFK Hospital, 65 Saint James Street, PO Box 3059, Edison, NJ 08818, Attn: Dr. S. title: LOCKHEED TO SELL 8 BUSINESSES AND REORGANIZE
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the military contractor, said yesterday that it planned to sell eight businesses, replace its chief financial officer and cut management ranks. The businesses on the block have combined annual sales of $1.8 billion and include the Sanders warfare-electronics unit, which employs about 4,000 in New Hampshire. Its five main business sectors will be condensed to four: aeronautics, space, systems integration and technology services. Robert Stevens, vice president for corporate strategic development, who designed the reorganization, will become executive vice president-finance and financial chief. He will replace Philip Duke, who was named to a new position overseeing Lockheed's efficiency. Shares rose $1.5625 each, to $32.1875.

It was also a reflection on their long friendship and a valedictory for the country-rooted rock that built both women's careers.

title: Earthquakes: A Matter of Luck, Most of It Bad

The killer earthquakes that have shaken the globe in the last month and taken thousands of lives in Turkey, Greece and now Taiwan are no sign that the end is nigh. By all estimates, the number of large jolts around the globe is below average this year, and it is simply bad luck that the recent upheavals have ripped through populated areas, leveling thousands of buildings and leaving tens of thousands of people dead, missing and homeless.

title: FDX PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 15 MILLION SHARES

FDX, based in Memphis, runs the courier service Federal Express and has some 298 million shares outstanding. FDX's buyback program is the company's first ever. The stock has fallen drastically since FDX announced lower-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings on Sept. 16. Meeting in Paris, just before the company's annual shareholder meeting, the FDX board agreed to begin the buyback in an effort to increase confidence in the stock. Shares of FDX closed at $35.50, up 31.25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Knicks Acquire Lang to Help Fill the Gap Left by Ewing
description: In a bow to reality, the Knicks made more preparations yesterday to start the season without Patrick Ewing. They acquired the 11-year veteran Andrew Lang, the player whose collision with Ewing nearly two years ago in Milwaukee resulted in the Knick center's freakish wrist injury.

description: COLONY GIRL

title: Anneli Cahn Lax, 77, a Leader In the Publishing of Mathematics
description: Anneli Cahn Lax, a professor and editor who was a leader in the publishing of mathematical literature, died on Friday at her home on Manhattan's Upper West Side. She was 77.

description: A patient has died while undergoing gene therapy in a trial study at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column yesterday, about awards that praised and criticized images of women in advertising, included erroneous credits from the presenter, Advertising Women of New York, for some ads. A commercial for Nike Inc. that carried the theme ''We will take on the world as a team'' was created by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, not Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. And a campaign for Victoria's Secret featuring women wearing lingerie was not created by Tarlow Advertising in New York; most of the Victoria's Secret consumer marketing is created internally.

description: With this issue, The Times introduces two new Wednesday pages -- one covering the workplace and one on management issues. The Workplace page, on the front of a new free-standing section of classified advertising, includes a column by Lisa Belkin on work-life issues. SECTION G.

description: Paul Hill, the founder of the 160-voice Paul Hill Chorale and a leader in establishing Washington as one of the nation's principal centers for choral singing, died on Monday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 65.

title: Turk Is Empty-Handed After a Clinton Meeting
description: After a meeting between Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey and President Clinton that ended with no commitment for earthquake aid, the Administration announced today that it would send its new special envoy to Cyprus into the region to try to start talks between the two sides on the divided island.

title: McCain Outlines Voucher Program and How to Pay for It
description: Senator John McCain, now a full-fledged candidate for the Presidency, called today for a school voucher program that he said should be financed by cutting Federal subsidies on oil, gas, ethanol and sugar.

Peter Wallace, a chef and fisherman who owns Oran Mor on Nantucket, has been hired. Now, the only thing being smoked is the fish.

title: 'Lucia' Returns, Restored And With Fewer Frills
description: When Sir Charles Mackerras conducts Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan Opera tonight with the soprano Andrea Rost in the title role, he expects that many admirers of this opera may be a bit perplexed by what they hear. The affable, 73-year-old conductor is performing the opera in its original 1835 version, which has never been heard before at the Met, nor, to his knowledge, in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACCIALI, ISABELLE FRAINO
description: BRACCIALI-Isabelle Fraino. In Florence, Italy on September 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Marco, devoted mother of Susanna and Julie, cherished sister of Marie, Elissa, Christine and John.

title: Yugoslavia Gives NATO $100 Billion Damage Bill
description: The NATO bombing campaign last spring caused $100 billion worth of damages in Yugoslavia, the Foreign Minister in Belgrade said today. He demanded that NATO pay the costs.

title: Intel Online Begins Web Hosting Service
description: The Intel Corporation started a subsidiary today that will operate corporate computing systems over the Internet.

title: GEERLINGS & WADE AGREES TO A DEAL WITH LIQUID HOLDINGS
description: Geerlings & Wade Inc., the leading United States mail-order seller of fine wines, agreed to be acquired by the closely held Liquid Holdings Inc. for about $40 million in cash. Each share of Geerlings & Wade will be exchanged for $10 in cash. Geerlings & Wade sells wine by mail and over the Internet and has retail sites in 15 states. Its 105 employees will not be affected by the purchase, its chief executive, Jay Essa, said. Liquid Holdings, which was founded by Ronald Haft, has received $15 million in equity financing and a commitment for $35 million in debt financing from a financial institution. Shares of Geerlings & Wade rose 90.625 cents, or 12 percent, to $8.75.

title: Deal Will Open Competition In Internet Site Registration
description: Network Solutions Inc., the company that has held a lucrative monopoly on registering Internet addresses for six years, agreed today to open the process to competition -- but only after winning a key concession from the Clinton Administration that effectively limits the authority of the Internet's new governing body.

title: Making the Best of a Mess
description: This feature, which will appear regularly on this page, is a first-person account by a manager about some aspect of his or her career. Carly Fiorina is the Hewlett-Packard Company's new chief executive.

title: China Fetes Capitalists, but the Air Is Tense
description: China is celebrating 50 years of Communist rule this week, among other ways, by inviting more than 300 of the world's leading capitalists to gather for a conference in this city.

title: Brooklyn Museum Sues to Keep Mayor From Freezing Its Funds
description: In a pronounced escalation of the political and cultural conflict over an impending art exhibition, the Brooklyn Museum of Art filed a lawsuit in Federal court yesterday that accuses Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of violating the First Amendment by threatening to withdraw city funds from the museum because he finds some of the artworks offensive and insulting to religion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONLEY, JOHN J., M.D.
description: CONLEY-John J., M.D. The Sisters of Charity, Board of Trustees, Physicians, Nurses and entire staff of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of New York mourn the passing of our dear and gifted colleague, benefactor, and friend, Dr. John Conley. For over 50 years, as the Chief of Head and Neck Surgery at Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, Dr. Conley cured thousands of patients with cancer, ameliorated pain for countless others, and educated several generations of surgeons who were inspired by the artistry and precision of his surgical technique and his remarkable medical insights. Dr. Conley was a masterful surgeon and also a prolific poet, artist and in recent years, a leader in the emerging and critical endeavor of medical ethics. Through Dr. Conley's generosity and mentoring, and in partnership with the Sisters of Charity whom he loved and respected, the John J. Conley Department of Ethics was established in 1998 at Saint Vincents. In his life, Dr. Conley achieved well deserved international recognition and acclaim for his pioneering advances in surgical oncology. More important to him, as he wrote in one of his books of poetry, ''Vocal Painting'', Dr. Conley was completely ''dedicated to the hope that man will survive his evolution and carry the ethic of respect as part of his equivalents''. We will miss him greatly but will try to emulate him through all the years of our lives. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Conley's wife, Monika, other members of his family and so many others who were close to and enriched by knowing him. Sister Elizabeth Vermaelen President, Sisters of Charity Thomas A. Coleman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D., President and CEO Lambert N. King, M.D. Sr. VP and Medical Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELORE, ALPHONSE T.

Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTEN, C.J.
description: LUTEN-C.J. The Board of Directors of Harmonie Ensemble/New York and conductor Steven Richman note with sorrow the passing of a dear friend. His support and inspiration will not be forgotten.

title: Short Orders
description: The Mansfield Hotel, at 12 West 44th Street, has opened the M Bar in a spacious room with a domed Victorian skylight. Caviar, smoked salmon, foie gras terrine and a cheese-and-potato tart are the cocktail fare. Rita Pescatore, formerly of Torch, is overseeing the food.

title: Superintendent Is Shot to Death Trying to Check On a Tenant
description: When Hector Serrano, a building superintendent in Washington Heights, was asked to check on a tenant who had not been heard from for days, he went out of his way to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAX, ANNELI
description: LAX-Anneli. Age 77, at home peacefully on September 24, surrounded by family & friends, after a two year battle with pancreatic cancer. Professor of mathematics at New York University, retired in 1992. Beloved wife of Peter, mother of John and Jim, grandmother of Tommy, Timmy and Pierre. Mathematician, teacher, editor, mentor and friend of many, breadbaker extraordinary.

title: SEOUL TO TIGHTEN CREDIT WATCH
description: Conglomerates in South Korea with debt-to-equity ratios exceeding 200 percent will face credit limits from banks, with loans newly classified as substandard and deferred for just one month, Lee Hun-jai, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said. Creditor banks must set aside up to 30 percent of the risky loan amount as loss reserves under the new regulations and will be barred from extending new loans to an unreliable borrower, Mr. Lee said. He added that the Government would no longer inject public funds to calm the investment trust industry. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOLLE, MARIKA
description: SHOLLE-Marika, 83. September 26, at home in Ossining. Wife of Maurice. Survived by son Jon, sister Patricia Panson, daughter-inlaw Elizabeth, grandson Evan.

title: Suburbia Learns It Has Paved Over the Natural Defenses to Flooding
description: When the torrential rain and surging rivers from Tropical Storm Floyd drove thousands from their homes and knocked out essential infrastructure in New Jersey and the lower Hudson Valley, suburbanites there got a terrifying look at what can happen when rapid development compromises Mother Nature's fundamental system of flood control.

title: The Elusive Ronald Reagan
description: In all the years I worked with Ronald Reagan, he did thousands of television appearances but never once wore makeup. Never. It is inconceivable to people that this actor turned politician insisted on appearing just as he was. We remain convinced there had to be more to him than what we actually saw, a missing layer that needed to be peeled away so we could finally capture the essence of this remarkable man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, DAVID HARRIS
description: DAVIS-David Harris. Age 64, of Jackson Heights, NY, formerly of London, England. On September 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Philip, Andrew and Neil. Graduate of London University. Designed national data systems for large government projects helping thousands of families through Head Start and the Office of Aging. Director of Center for Human Services Management & Accu-Search, Inc. His wit, sensitivity, erudition and culinary gifts will be missed by friends and family members. He was a loving grandpa to Josh and Ashley. Services Thursday, September 30, at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: SJW, CALIFORNIA WATER UTILITY COMPANY, CONSIDERS SALE
description: The SJW Corporation, which owns a water utility with 971,000 customers in California, said yesterday that it had hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to help it consider strategic alternatives, including a sale of the company. SJW, which has a market value of $265.7 million, declined to comment further. Trading was halted yesterday after SJW shares rose $5.75, to $87.25, on Monday. Water companies are facing increased costs to meet environmental regulations, causing many to seek buyers. SJW, with sales of $106 million last year, is the parent company of San Jose Water and the SJW Land Company.

title: The Clintons Aren't Yet in Town, but Protest Is
description: There goes the neighborhood. President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have not even closed the deal on their house here, and already the first protest march is scheduled for Wednesday night.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STEADY. The yen held steady against the dollar, staying near a one-week low amid speculation that the Bank of Japan would increase the money supply. In New York, the dollar rose to 106.10 yen, from 106 on Monday.

title: Notebook; The New School Helm
description: While a committee searches for a permanent president of New School University in New York, an investment banker is taking on a second job, leading the New School in the temporary post of chancellor.

title: CANARY WHARF CHANGES ITS MIND
description: Only a day after announcing plans to sell stock, Canary Wharf Group P.L.C., the real estate developers of London's second financial district, halted the planned sale, which was to raise 214 million [pounds], or $352.3 million. The decision to halt the plan was a result of money managers' fear that big investors were considering liquidating their shares. Shares of the company fell 5.6 percent.

title: Butting Heads And Other Perilous Diversions
description: There were no safe havens in the two works Bill Young and Dancers offered on Sunday night as an attraction of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Both productions, choreographed by Mr. Young in collaboration with his cast, were designed by Luis Lara and had richly textured taped scores by Mio Morales that did much to suggest impending disaster.

title: Foreign Affairs; Give That Man a Cigar
description: American foreign policy toward Cuba is really unique among U.S. foreign policies. It isn't just 15 degrees off. It has the distinction of being 360 degrees wrong.

title: Long Distance By Bell Atlantic Expected Soon
description: Fifteen years after the court-supervised breakup of AT&T, a part of the old Ma Bell stands a good chance of being allowed to offer customers both long-distance and local service.

title: Aetna Shares Fall on Doubts Over Health Unit
description: Doubts that Aetna Inc. got its billion dollar's worth when it bought the Prudential health care business last year have sent Aetna shares tumbling more than 12 percent in the last two days.

title: Like Pesto, Only Newer
description: NO ONE ever has too many sauces for cold poached shrimp, but tomato is a cliche and mayonnaise types are too creamy for me. By this time every year I am even tired of pesto. But the pesto variation taught to me by Deborah Madison, who wrote ''Vegetarian Cooking for Everyone'' (Broadway Books, 1997), is a different story. It's based not on basil but on marjoram, an unheralded herb that grows well in the Northeast and can be found in good quantity almost anywhere fresh herbs are sold.

title: Gold Soars $28, to $308, in Biggest Rally in 2 Decades
description: The price of gold surged $28.20, or 9 percent, to $308.10 an ounce yesterday, the biggest one-day rally in almost two decades. Since the previous Tuesday, the price of gold has jumped $53.10, or 20.8 percent, wiping out all the losses for this year and is now the highest it has been since April 1998.

title: Atwater to Savor Oddity In Jets-Broncos Replay
description: Steve Atwater chuckled at the strangeness of it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTHROP, ROBERT
description: WINTHROP-Robert. The officers, Board of Directors and members of Ducks Unlimited, Inc. mourn the passing of Robert Winthrop who served as National President of our organization in 1955 and 1956, and as National Trustee Emeritus until the present. His dedication and commitment to the plight of migratory waterfowl across the North American continent was inspirational and he will be sorely missed by the conservation and sportsman communities.

title: Shoring Up the Volunteer Army
description: For the better part of two decades, the catchy advertising jingle ''Be All That You Can Be,'' along with promises of on-the-job training and money for higher education, helped the United States Army meet its recruiting goals and gave the country a high-quality volunteer force. But now the Army, along with other branches of the armed services, is facing a serious recruiting gap that is forcing it to rethink its hiring practices and marketing strategy. The proposed changes in tactics outlined in an article in Monday's Times seem like a good start on what is likely to be a long and difficult effort to turn things around. As a collateral benefit, these changes may help society as well.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about parity in the National Football League misidentified the team for which Neil O'Donnell is quarterback this season. It is the Tennessee Titans, not the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: The Whisk: So Simple, So Complex
description: LIKE an oar for rowing, the whisk is a perfect emblem for cooking. And rightly so: it is a wonderful invention. With rapid swipes, you can turn a slippery puddle of egg whites into feather-light fluff, cream into a stiff white cloud, and oil and vinegar into a uniformly viscous liquid. And it gives you control from the beginning to the finish, something you don't get with a mixer.

title: At Atlantic Monthly, a Tense Staff Sizes Up the New Owner
description: The Atlantic Monthly in Boston on Monday afternoon, staff members huddled around to hear the grim news.

title: Threats and Tire Blowout Disrupt Airport
description: When an explosion rang through the Delta Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport at 7:15 last night, minutes after a bomb threat had been phoned in to 911, the police officers who had just arrived to evacuate the terminal feared they might be too late.

title: Jose Gusmao: The Foe Indonesia Now Respects
description: Through the darkest years under Indonesian rule, one man, known by the nom de guerre Xanana, held almost magical promise for the East Timorese. Somewhere in the wooded hills, he led a guerrilla band far outnumbered and outgunned by the Indonesian Army.

title: WORK IS PROPOSED ON 2D AVE. SUBWAY
description: Aiming to capitalize on a booming economy while addressing some of the New York region's mass transit needs, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to spend $1.6 billion for a new Long Island Rail Road tunnel to Grand Central Terminal and $700 million to restart the long-dormant Second Avenue subway project.

title: Bad Things Happen to Good Coaches
description: There are times when this ''genius coach'' thing is more overrated than fat-free food. Mike Shanahan has John Elway, maybe the best quarterback in football history, wins two Super Bowls and his brain is suddenly larger than Einstein's. Bill Parcells takes a stacked, speedy defense, a good passer in Vinny Testaverde and runner in Curtis Martin, and two top wide receivers to the American Football Conference title game last season and he is so brilliant he could captain the Starship Enterprise.

title: And at Home: Water, Batteries And Caviar
description: OUT there in America, the fear of a Y2K meltdown reducing the country to a pre-industrial society has driven many folks to stockpile supplies of grains, powdered eggs, water, maybe some guns and ammo. In New York, millenarians are bunkering down in their own way: by laying in gallon jugs of Poland Spring and trying to figure out what wines work with cannellini beans and Italian tuna.

title: Inkster Goes Into the Hall While Out of the Spotlight
description: While the United States Ryder Cup team spent Sunday making a historic comeback, Juli Inkster was making history as well.

title: ALCATEL PLANS TO BUY GENESYS FOR $1.5 BILLION
description: Alcatel S.A., Europe's second-biggest phone equipment maker, said yesterday that it would acquire Genesys Telecommunications Laboratories Inc. for about $1.5 billion in stock to add a software company to its growing Internet and data-equipment businesses. Alcatel will pay 1.667 American depository shares for each Genesys share, about $45.50 based on its closing price on Monday. Alcatel's A.D.R.'s fell 31.25 cents, to $27, and Genesys rose $3.875 a share, to $44.75. Since last October the stock in the San Francisco-based Genesys has almost quintupled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWERD, ABRAHAM, CANTOR
description: SCHWERD - Abraham, Cantor. The Queens Jewish Center of Forest Hills, New York, expresses a profound sense of loss and sorrow at the passing of Cantor Emeritus, Abraham Schwerd of blessed memory. For more than 30 years he inspired the community with his beautiful, melodious and heartfelt rendition of the prayers. He was a great philanthropist, contributing generously to numerous communal organizations. He had a kind heart and will be missed by many people in the community and elsewhere. Our condolences to his wife Helen, his children Mala and Mendy Greenberger, Moshe and Barbara Schwerd, Rina Wachtel, Ted Wachtel, and his grandchildren, Daniel, Ariella, Sara Gila, Yehoshua Yisroel Yehuda, Tal Geula, Rachel, Sara Bracha and Hannah. Rabbi Joseph Grunblatt Steven J. Lerner, President Franklyn Snitow, Chairman, Board of Trustees

description: Only about one-quarter of American students can write at a proficient level, exhibiting ''solid academic performance and competency over challenging subject matter,'' according to a report released yesterday by the National Assessment of Educational Progress.

title: A Grass-Roots Garbage War; In South Bronx, a Bitter Split Over a Proposed Transfer Station
description: On a hot summer night inside Intermediate School 74 in the South Bronx, a community was at war. There was shouting, there were accusations, there were threats.

title: DAEWOO UNITS TO REFINANCE BONDS
description: Daewoo Heavy Industries and three other affiliates of the South Korean conglomerate Daewoo Group will be allowed to refinance corporate bonds and commercial papers as of the middle of October, the financial watchdog agency, the Financial Supervisory Commission, said. The four affiliates will be allowed to refinance bonds and commercial papers at prices that are 70 to 80 percent of book value, according to the commission. Besides Daewoo Heavy Industries, the other units are Daewoo Electronics, Daewoo Telecom and Orion Electric.

title: FREESERVE SHARES SLIDE
description: Shares of Britain's largest Internet access company, Freeserve P.L.C., slid 7 percent after it reported quarterly finances that were weaker than expected. Freeserve, which pioneered the subscription-free Internet sector, said losses widened to $:5.23 million, or $8.61 million, in the first quarter of the year as expenses increased. But the company had a strong gain in subscribers, jumping 19 percent, to 1.41 million subscribers. Sales also increased, to $:3.38 million, from $:1.65 million in the previous quarter.
