description: TOVSKY-Roslyn. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Roslyn Tovsky, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the entire Tovsky family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: An Outsider Keeps Digging
description: It was telling that on Sunday afternoon the Nashville singer, guitarist and songwriter David Olney chose to meet for an interview not at the Pancake Pantry, the music-establishment brunch spot here, but at a coffee shop called Fido a few doors south. After all, he has been in Nashville for 26 years yet he has never quite been accepted as an important part of the music milieu, which he is. Some say Mr. Olney is too literary: he writes songs about Barabbas, John Dillinger and John Barrymore, all in a dark, brooding style influenced by the Texas singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt. But if Mr. Olney's tight, powerful, empathetic and highly literate writing make him an outsider here, they're also what make him an insider in less commercial songwriting circles, with six albums recorded for the folk label Philo/Rounder all worth seeking out.

title: Council Weighs New Jobs Bill As Alternative To Workfare
description: The City Council is considering legislation that would provide an alternative to the city's workfare program by creating 10,000 hourly-wage jobs for former welfare recipients over the next five years in city agencies and nonprofit organizations.

title: Baligate, and Why It Matters; Indonesia's Recovery, and Democracy, Tested by Scandal
description: In the streets of Jakarta, students lob firebombs at police. In the ruins of East Timor, Indonesian soldiers seethe as foreign troops take over. In the desolate scrub of Ambon, Christians and Muslims kill each other with home-made guns.

title: Man Charged With Murder After Firing on Crowd
description: A Queens man who the police said fired on a group of men on a Manhattan street last week to try to put an end to a running dispute was arrested yesterday and charged with first-degree murder, the authorities said.

title: Cheaper by the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethnic Markets, Now a Click Away
description: A NEW Web site that sells ingredients for dishes from the world over has joined with the American Red Cross to raise money and contribute food for victims of last month's earthquake in Turkey. When visitors to the site, www.ethnicgrocer.com, click on a Turkish Earthquake Relief Fund icon on the home page and make a contribution, the company matches it with a food donation of equal value.

title: FRENCH NET BOOKSELLER ACQUIRED
description: France Telecom S.A. said it had acquired the Internet bookseller Alapage.com. Terms were not disclosed. France Telecom said in a statement that 600,000 visitors log on to Alapage.com's Web site each month, with orders reaching 14,000 items a month. Founded in 1987, Alapage.com has emerged as one of the leading E-commerce sites for French-language content.

title: Notebook; A Survey of Parents
description: While almost all Americans in a recent survey said parents should take an active part in their children's education, fewer than a third who had children in school spent time helping teachers in the classroom, and only 1 in 4 was a member in a parent-teacher organization.

title: Mets Never Get Started, but Look Finished
description: The sweat had barely beaded around Orel Hershiser's nose when he slinked back to the dugout, but the blankness in the Mets starter's face indicated a complete lack of understanding of how this fiasco could happen -- a helplessness with which his team has grown terribly familiar.

title: Blair Spurs Labor Party To Fulfill Dual Mission
description: In a speech aimed at stirring his party from any complacency over its success, Prime Minister Tony Blair today summoned Labor delegates to a crusade with the twin missions of winning the next election over the Conservatives and conquering the next century for the ''progressives.''

title: Networks Find Cause for Cheer
description: From the perspective of one full week of new shows, network executives have already declared the new television season a success. The big reason: the networks are down again in viewers, but the decline is far less steep than it was last year at this point.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
description: Hoping to insure that the nation's spies have the latest information technology in the rapidly changing Internet age, the Central Intelligence Agency has established a venture capital company to nurture high-tech companies, company executives and former C.I.A. officials said.

title: Kittles Role May Shift To the Nets' Sixth Man
description: While the Nets gathered their latest acquisition, Johnny Newman, in the press room of the team's practice facility today, Kerry Kittles spent hours on the practice floor and in the weight room well aware of what Newman's presence could mean to him.

title: Hardware Group Conducts a Search
description: The Truserv Corporation, the retail hardware cooperative, said yesterday that it had begun to search for an agency to handle national brand advertising, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million, as plans proceed to have as many stores as possible operate under the True Value name.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Despite a Big Board outcry against Levitt's single regulator, there may be room for compromise.
description: THE New York Stock Exchange appears to be headed for a showdown with the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission over how the exchange will be regulated when it converts to a publicly traded, for-profit business.

title: At Prayer Breakfast, Clinton Tells of a Year of Spiritual Recovery
description: Seven months after a divided Senate found him not guilty of impeachable offenses, President Clinton said this morning that he continued to squeeze regular spiritual counseling into his official schedule to recover from what he called ''one of the most difficult years in my life.''

title: EU Executive Hires Widely
description: BRUSSELS  Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, said Tuesday that he had succeeded in his aim of creating a more international and representative executive.

title: Finding New Ways to Share the Wealth Effectively
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wild Ride on the Swivel Chair
description: I hear them before I see them -- the 8-year-old, followed by the 5-year-old -- as they clomp up the stairs that lead to my office. They knock (when they remember), then in they come, dropping their backpacks at my feet like an offering. If I'm on the phone, they shush loudly at each other until I hang up. When I'm finally theirs, they fill my lap with a jumble of artwork and homework and memos from the P.T.A. I give hugs and praise and savor whatever nuggets they offer up about their day. All this serves to postpone, but never prevent, the final part of the ritual. The part where I notice the time, tell them I love them, then boot them out.

title: S.E.C. Charges 68 Companies and Individuals With Accounting Fraud
description: Fran Tarkenton, the National Football League quarterback who became a computer software entrepreneur, agreed to pay more than $150,000 yesterday to settle charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he directed a plan to report phony profits at Knowledgeware Inc., which he ran.

title: Judge Sets Trial Date in 1998 Bombings at U.S. Embassies
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan set a trial date yesterday for five suspects being held in the bombings last year of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania or other acts of terrorism.

title: Japan Gives American-Led Group Right to Acquire Big Bank
description: In a landmark decision that gives foreigners the go-ahead signal to take control of a Japanese bank, the Government today granted an American-led investor group the exclusive right to acquire the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, a former financial giant hobbled by bad loans.

title: Impressions Awash in the Golden Glow of Madness
description: With the dead cats and garbage heaps of ''Gummo'' behind him, Harmony Korine has directed a second feature better than his first. This can be viewed as inevitable. Less so is the intriguing pedigree of ''Julien Donkey-Boy'' as the first American film made in compliance with Dogma '95, the set of radical restrictions devised by Danish filmmakers including Lars von Trier (''Breaking the Waves'') and Thomas Vinterberg (''The Celebration'').

title: Umpires
description: The last time the Major League Umpires Association met, in Philadelphia on July 14, more than 50 members signed letters of resignation, and 22 wound up losing their jobs.

title: Patient Dies During a Trial Of Therapy Using Genes
description: A patient has died while undergoing gene therapy in a trial study at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

title: WELLS FARGO INTENDS TO BUY BACK 5% OF ITS SHARES
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it had planned to buy back as many as 82 million, or 5 percent, of its shares, worth as much as $3.2 billion at current prices. The San Francisco-based bank, the seventh largest in the United States, with more than $200 billion of assets, said the buyback was intended to meet the stock-issuance requirements of benefit plans and other needs, including acquisitions. Wells Fargo, which was formed when the Norwest Corporation purchased the old Wells Fargo & Company last year, has about 1.7 billion in common shares outstanding. Shares of Wells Fargo rose 37.5 cents, to $38.875.

title: On a New Year's Eve For the Ages, Some Restaurants Will Sit It Out
description: JO JO, the deluxe Upper East Side restaurant, celebrated New Year's Eve in characteristic style last year: it opened early and kept going until 5 A.M., offering a fixed-price dinner of $500 a head, plus wine. The restaurant was packed, for each of two seatings, as night turned to dawn.

title: Aviation Experts Bemoan Delays in the Sky
description: Flight delays across the nation were miserable last spring and summer and they may get worse, experts from the airlines and the air traffic controllers' union agreed yesterday, but they disagreed about why, who was to blame and how to fix the problem.

title: A Musical Mating In Dendur's Temple
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art maintains a reasonably full concert schedule, and has established itself as a comfortable place for an evening of 18th- or 19th-century chamber music in the Grace Rainey Rogers concert hall or early music in the Medieval Sculpture Hall. New music has not generally been a priority at the museum, but this year one of its attractions is a three-concert retrospective of works by Philip Glass, preceded last Friday by a showing of ''Powaqqatsi,'' the second of Godfrey Reggio's films for which Mr. Glass supplied an expansive soundtrack score.

title: Republican Chairman Appeals To Buchanan to Remain in Party
description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee met today with Patrick J. Buchanan and made his own appeal not to bolt the party and fracture Republican ranks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ALMA
description: MILLER-Alma. Loving wife of Dr. Benjamin Miller of East Williston, New York. On September 27, 1999. Mother of Frances Merkler and Dr. Kenneth Miller, grandmother of Alexander Merkler and Phillip, Rachel and Marissa Miller. Memorial service at Frances Merkler's home on Wednesday, September 29, at 11:30 A.M.

title: 2d Company Says It Too Has Tie to Group in Pataki Trips
description: A second major corporation with significant interests in Albany said yesterday that it was involved with a nonprofit group that paid for two trips that Gov. George E. Pataki took to Hungary. The acknowledgment by the corporation, Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceuticals conglomerate, came as state ethics officials were said to be considering whether to investigate links between the trips and Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker.

title: Warren Beatty Is Bathing In a New Kind of Spotlight
description: On Wednesday night, in a Beverly Hills hotel ballroom best known as the site of the Golden Globe ceremonies, Warren Beatty, actor, writer, producer, director and Democrat, will make a speech that friends say will touch on global trade, campaign finance and social justice. He may, or may not, say something about running for President of the United States.

title: Business Travel; Alaska Airlines plans to offer a system that allows passengers to check in on the Internet.
description: ALASKA AIRLINES, which pioneered the airline industry's adoption of electronic tickets, is using the Internet in an attempt to revolutionize checking in at airports, a process that is often arduous.

title: Ginsburg Leaves Hospital; Prognosis on Cancer Is Good
description: The colon cancer diagnosed in Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has apparently not spread, and was discovered at an early stage by accident because the Justice suffered symptoms from an unrelated abdominal infection, the Supreme Court announced today.

title: Met Season Opens With 'Cav' and 'Pag'
description: Buried under all the news coming out of the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night there was opera, two short ones in fact. After the accountants had toted up the record-setting numbers, after first-nighters' sequins had fluttered to repose in the seats and after an army of cafeteria union organizers had sung their final aria on the sidewalks outside, the Met opened its season with the beloved duo ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''I Pagliacci.''

title: Bradley Presents Health Plan For Almost All the Uninsured
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley today proposed a $65 billion-a-year plan that he said would make health care available to virtually all uninsured Americans through an ambitious expansion of Federal tax subsidies and insurance programs.

title: Devils Top Islanders In Preseason Finale
description: The Devils and the Islanders concluded their preseason schedule last night at Continental Arena, with the Devils posting a 4-3 victory after scoring the first three goals in the game.

title: Mayor Opposes Base Pay Rise
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came out against raising the minimum wage today, putting himself at odds with Hillary Rodham Clinton, his likely opponent in next year's race for United States Senator from New York.

title: Sponsor Pulls Muslims Out of Maritime College
description: A Kuwait-based shipping company has decided to withdraw 21 Muslim students from the State University of New York's Maritime College in the Bronx, where the company was sponsoring them, the school announced in a statement yesterday.

title: New for Managers In Business Day
description: With this issue, The Times introduces two new Wednesday pages -- one covering the workplace and one on management issues. The Workplace page, on the front of a new free-standing section of classified advertising, will deal with the world of work in all aspects. It includes a column by Lisa Belkin on work-life issues.

title: Chase Agrees to Acquire Hambrecht & Quist
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed yesterday to buy San Francisco-based Hambrecht & Quist for $1.35 billion, giving one of America's dominant traditional banks an entree into the world of Internet start-ups and bringing it a step closer to becoming a full-service financial concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, JAMES
description: KERN-James. Beloved husband of the late Ruth, loving father of Dorothe and Joe Levy and the late Henry. Cherished grandfather of Susan and Allan Deutsch and Debbi and Jerry Waters, adored great-grandfather of Hayley and Joshua Waters.

title: Think Alaska's Just Too Big to Bake?
description: NO cookbook is more difficult to write than a primer. The author can assume little, since novices lack the language necessary to begin. Questions like ''Is my stove gas or electric?'' ''What does simmer mean?'' and ''How do you strain a can of tomatoes?'' can reduce longtime recipe writers to sputtering impotence as they try to explain the fine points of scrambling an egg to people who wonder how to break one open.

description: In percent

title: The Maestro as Midwife; As Conductor, Dennis Russell Davies Brings Life to a New Opera
description: An opera is built like a puzzle; separate pieces are carved and fitted together. The music for ''A View From the Bridge,'' an adaptation of Arthur Miller's play that will have its premiere at Lyric Opera of Chicago on Oct. 9, was written in Ann Arbor, Mich., by William Bolcom. The libretto was written by a New Yorker, Arnold Weinstein; the set was designed by Santo Loquasto in New York and built in San Diego. The singers have been rehearsing for weeks now on a partially assembled set in a room on the second floor of the Civic Opera House here.

title: Congress Extends Spending by 3 Weeks
description: Unable to pass its spending bills before the new fiscal year on Friday, Congress resolved today to keep Federal agencies functioning for three weeks while Republicans negotiate with President Clinton over hundreds of billions of dollars of spending.

title: 3 in the Running For Lending Tree
description: Lending Tree Inc., a Web-based mortgage company in Charlotte, N.C., has narrowed a review for its first account to three finalists. Billings are estimated at $50 million. The finalists are Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., and two units of Lowe Group, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies: Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York and the Martin Agency in Richmond. A decision is expected by the end of October.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Energy Secretary Bill Richardson's recommendation that President Clinton sign a $289 billion Pentagon budget bill that revamps the Energy Department characterized the position of Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, incorrectly. He did not sign a House-Senate conference report on the bill, but he voted for the overall bill on the Senate floor.

title: Commercial Real Estate; 2 Arcades With a View on All Sides
description: Grand Central Terminal was once called the Gateway to a Continent, but the two pedestrian arcades that connect it to Park Avenue might best be described as the Gateway to a Bunch of Posters for Helmsley Hotels.

title: Cheese With a Keener Nip Than Autumn in Vermont
description: Slap. Slap. Slap. Slap. It's the only sound made by the cheese makers as they go about their work flipping 30-pound strips of glistening milk curds, the color of rich cream, in stainless steel vats. On the first day of autumn in this almost too perfect New England town, cheddaring is under way at the Grafton Village Cheese Company. It is a magical process that turns liquid into gold.

title: Mass Violence Has Roots That We Can Trace; Troubling Signs
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF; A Balancing Act Leads to a Variety of Quick Breads
description: I COUNT my plum-honey quick-bread recipe as my first professional culinary triumph -- and try to forget that it was developed in a state of panic. I was a college student and had been hired as the summer cook and housekeeper for a family that did not have a clue how inexperienced I was. I listened as I was told that I would be responsible for lunches, dinners and fresh baked sweets for breakfast, then ran to the library to read every cookbook. Thirty cookbooks and a little practice later, I learned the quick-bread secret: get the balance between the wet and dry ingredients right and you can vary the fruits, nuts and spices with abandon. This meant I could make a different quick bread every day, and I did.

title: Man Is Given 15 Years In Bank Robbery
description: A man who admitted his role in a Princeton bank robbery that resulted in the death of his accomplice was sentenced yesterday to 15 years and one month in prison, the United States Attorney's office announced.

title: Political Change in Germany
description: Over the last few decades, Germany and its workers have benefited from a generous social contract. High wages, short working hours and ample health care, pensions and welfare payments have not only allowed German workers to share fully in their nation's prosperity, they have also strengthened German democracy. But the world is changing, and Germany's social contract now contributes to unemployment and stagnation.

description: Corporate managers handle sexual harassment complaints all the time. Think the following example is a no-brainer? Think again.

description: He was back on the ice but not back on skates. Now retired, Wayne Gretzky was selling tires. Madison Square Garden, filled with cheering fans when he said goodbye in April, was now almost empty during this photo opportunity yesterday morning for Goodyear. For No. 99, the Great One, the year 1999 is a melancholy but good one, the beginning of the rest of his life.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: So you want to check your E-mail, but a computer isn't handy. Why not just pick up a telephone and have it read to you? A free service called Mytalk.com permits users to do just that. More than 100,000 people have signed up for the service (www.mytalk.com), which carries ads, since it began this summer, said Kevin Wray, director of Web strategy and programs for General Magic, the company that runs the service.

title: Searching For Less, Not More
description: IMAGINE New York's Greenwich Village with millions of jumbled streets, add Tokyo's chaotic street numbering system, have it grow faster than Las Vegas, Nev., with a million new addresses a day, add all the languages of the United Nations, and make sure that every map is hopelessly outdated. That is today's World Wide Web.

Their names are Amy Sedaris and Cynthia Nixon, and they currently share the stage of the Greenwich House Theater in the Drama Dept.'s production of ''The Country Club,'' Douglas Carter Beane's patchy comedy of rich white people behaving badly.

description: Kelly and Tim Nice, two brothers with big-agency experience, have started their own agency, Nice Advertising, in San Francisco.

title: Russian Ex-Premier, in the U.S., Says Corruption Is Exaggerated
description: The former Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, said today that accusations of Russian corruption and money-laundering had poisoned relations with the United States, and he urged political and business leaders in both countries to help keep the investigation from derailing the larger strategic relationship.

title: Art Dealer Arrested Over Bullets at Show
description: A prominent Manhattan art dealer was arrested at her Fifth Avenue gallery last night over a show that included a vase full of live 9-millimeter cartridges for visitors to take home as souvenirs, the police said.

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary on Monday reported the death of Judith Campbell Exner. It quoted assertions she had made over the years that she had had an affair with John F. Kennedy before and after he was elected President.

title: Umpire Calls the Game, But Before the Deluge
description: Umpire Durwood Merrill walked on the field and waved his arms dramatically, indicating for all fans at Camden Yards that tonight's game between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles was postponed. There was something missing from the picture, however: rain.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges Against Officers in Diallo Killing
description: A State Supreme Court Justice rejected defense motions yesterday to dismiss or reduce the charges against the four police officers who shot and killed Amadou Diallo and said their trial would start as planned on Jan. 3.

title: An Orchestra Navigates by the Stars
description: The conductorless Orpheus Chamber Orchestra has been plying its trade so well for so long (27 years) that a listener is occasionally tempted to take its consistently fine results for granted, something the players can never do. For though it is far from a circus, an Orpheus concert is invariably a tightrope act, requiring on a large scale the intense concentration and hair-trigger mutual responsiveness of a small chamber ensemble, and reaping their benefits.

description: The Security Council is preparing to consider whether to dispatch peacekeepers to Sierra Leone.

description: A refugee from the 1956 Hungarian uprising who came penniless to the United States will give the Smithsonian Institution $60 million, its largest donation ever, the Smithsonian said today.

title: SCANA TO SELL SOME ASSETS TO SUBURBAN PROPANE
description: The Scana Corporation said that it would sell its retail propane assets to Suburban Propane L.P., a unit of Suburban Propane Partners L.P., for $86 million. Scana will sell its Scana Propane Gas Inc., USA Cylinder Exchange Inc. and Scana Propane Storage Inc. units, a storage site in Tirzah, S.C., with a capacity of 60 million gallons, and a 62-mile pipeline. Scana, an energy company based in Columbia, S.C., reported revenue of $772 million for the six months ended June 30. description: ONE television commercial for Outpost.com featured gerbils shot out of a cannon. Another, for Ecampus.com, offered a college kid belching the alphabet.

title: Identifying Flying Objects
description: Look up and you won't see more than a trace of the more than 8,600 objects that are now orbiting Earth. But point your Web browser to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's J-Track 3D site, and you can get a three-dimensional picture of at least some of the satellites, rocket boosters and other debris floating in our skies at this very moment. The site, at liftoff.msfc.nasa.gov/RealTime /JTrack/3d, shows what looks like the Earth with dandruff: hundreds of white specks are sprinkled around it. Click on a white dot, and you get a shorthand description of the object, along with its current location and orbital path. In most cases, you can also retrieve details about the satellites like what they are and when they were launched.

title: Overtime Is Now Five Minutes in Hockey Heaven
description: Shortly before the 28 teams opened their training camps, the National Hockey League executive Steve Solomon attended the revival of ''Death of a Salesman'' on Broadway. Solomon, second in command to Commissioner Gary Bettman, spied a hockey-friendly journalist at intermission and went into sell mode. The topic was the N.H.L.'s new four-on-four overtime.

title: After a Life in Art, a Quest for the Art of Life
description: IT'S starting to bug Marcia Tucker, all these people wanting to know what she plans to do after she packs up her office next month at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, which she founded and has embodied for the last 22 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNDY, HAROLD DAVID, M.D.
description: DUNDY-Harold David, M.D. 89, died peacefully on September 28 in his home with his children and grandchildren at his side. A wily bridge player, avid Mets fan, devotee of Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Harold was a powerful force in our lives. His tenacity, tolerance and wit endure as an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. Susan and Warren Kossowsky Andy Kossowsky and Cori Richard and Alison Dundy Alisa, Jay, Sophie and Jessica Strauss

title: Irish Patterns With Stories That Bring a Tear
description: Clodagh, the New Age Irish interior designer, has in the past tended toward the impractical. But lately she has approached the consumer mainstream with a full line of affordably priced carpets for Lees of Glasgow, Va. The carpets are available in eight patterns and a range of 72 subtly shifting colors. Each one elicits a story from Clodagh that mists the eye. That rusty grey? A pair of ''perfect terra cotta'' linen pants she borrowed from a friend in Ireland. The Buncrana pattern (above), inspired by a County Donegal basket weave, is $22 to $26 a yard; (800) 523-5647.

title: The N.F.L. Likes Plan for Stadium In Hollywood Park
description: Despite the billionaire Marvin Davis's withdrawal from his brief campaign to own a National Football League franchise in Los Angeles, the league is looking to keep alive Davis's plan to build a stadium at the Hollywood Park race track.

title: Pecked Apart By Critics
description: Hey, how would you like to labor on something for a year or two or five or six and then be told it's rotten? It happens every day, and it happens eventually to every author, no matter how applauded: the howling wind of the bad review. Years of work, of lonely intellectual wandering, hit by the blast. And how does the writer learn the bad news?

Buchanan today, suggesting that ''personal vendettas'' may be driving their apparent alliance to have Mr. Buchanan seek the Reform Party nomination. Mr. Bush asserted that both men helped undermine his father's unsuccessful campaign for re-election to the White House in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SYLVIA
description: STEINBERG-Sylvia. Of Tamarac, Florida, passed away on Thursday, September 23, 1999. She leaves her husband of sixty-two years, Dr. Philip M. Steinberg, sons Dr. Alfred D. Steinberg and Richard M. Steinberg, grandchildren Dr. Bonnie Jean SteinbergJennis, Robert T. Steinberg, Dr. Ellen Beth Steinberg, Kathleen Triem, David A. Steinberg, Jonathan E. Steinberg, and Charles A. Frentz, and great-grandchildren Noah Jennis and Aaron Jennis. Sylvia Steinberg, the daughter of Benjamin Govern and Ada Rothrug Govern, was born in Brooklyn, New York and lived for many years in New York City and Great Neck, NY. She earned a Master's Degree in Geology at Columbia University. An expert on snow cover in New York State, she became the first woman professional to work for the national weather bureau. She also has a rock collection at the Smithsonian Institution which has been on public display for many years and has been used for research. Mrs. Steinberg was an extremely intelligent and thoughtful individual who provided critical advice to several generations. She was active in many charities and an officer and board member of several, including City of Hope and ORT. She was president of the PTA in Jackson Heights. A modern woman for her generation, she juggled responsibilities to work, family, and friends so effectively that she never seemed rushed or put out. She was always there to help people bridge differences. Her method of consensus building preceded by more than a generation the modern use of that technique. All of those that she touched deeply will forever be in her debt. She will be sorely missed.

title: Sports of The Times; A Fan Offers Scoresheet Inspirations
description: AS Bobby Valentine hurried into Shea Stadium for last night's game with the Braves, a middle-age fan, James McCahan of Brooklyn, handed the Mets' manager a big white envelope.

title: JAPAN's OUTPUT SOARS
description: Japanese industrial output rose 4.6 percent in August, the biggest monthly increase in 42 years, led by the Toyota Motor Corporation and other auto makers, amid demand for their new model cars. Still, manufacturers expect to slow production this month and next amid concern the stronger yen will crimp export sales, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. The rise in industrial production last month, the biggest since May 1957, and above economists' expectations of a 3.8 percent gain, is the latest in a string of indicators to show the recovery from last year's recession is taking hold.

title: Looking at Death With Old Age Near
description: The men and women who had gathered for a conference on aging and wisdom at Ghost Ranch, the mountain retreat where Georgia O'Keeffe once lived and painted, were asked by their workshop leader to imagine their own deaths.

title: Change of Fortune Means End of Slump
description: Evidence that the Mets' fortunes have changed abounded at Shea Stadium last night. Balls that in the previous week's worth of games would have been caught fell just out of the reach of Atlanta fielders. Balls hit by the Braves that would have eluded the Mets' fielders found their way into Mets' gloves.

description: It happens in front of your ears and eyes: a great work comes rolling off the stage. The Metropolitan Opera's production of Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' was glorious when it was first presented, in February. It is now overwhelming.

Dooley, great aunt of William, Margaret, Mary Kate & Patrick Dooley. Predeceased by two sisters Mary J. Naughton and Margaret Dooley. For information Dooley Funeral Home, 2170 Hwy 88, Brick, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, MAX
description: LANDAU-Max. Passed away on August 31st at his home in the West Village. He was 83. Born in New York City he grew up in The Hebrew Orphan Asylum that at seventeen awarded him a scholarship to the National Academy of Design. He then attended The School of Industrial Design. He worked on the Artist's Project of the WPA teaching sculpture at the Denishawn School of Dance in the Bronx and later at the YMHA on 92nd Street. After World War II, becoming interested in the new product, plastics, he acquired a vast knowledge of its properties, recognizing its future. He established Industrial Plastics Supply Company, the first retail and manufacturing outlet on Canan Street where he became legend, respected, admired. Surviving are his wife and soul mate, Dina Ghen, and his former wife, Emma Landau. A Memorial Service has been held. Appreciated would be donations in his name to The Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 1440 York Avenue P4, NYC, New York 10021.

title: Political Briefing; A Past With Alcohol Dogs a Candidate
description: In the political game, it is known as ''inoculation'' -- going public with a confession of some sin before your opponent can sting you with an accusation of it. And in an age when such stinging is on the rise, not only by opponents but also by the press, so is self-inoculating.

title: From Sickbed to Boyhood and Back, Echoing Proust
description: If there were a prize for sheer ambition at this year's New York Film Festival, it would justly go to ''Time Regained.'' The Chilean filmmaker Raul Ruiz has approached that literary Godzilla, Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' from the most challenging vantage point possible.

title: Avon's Stock Declines 27% After Warning About Profit
description: Avon Products Inc. yesterday became the latest multinational consumer products company to be pummeled by investors after management announced a surprise warning that it expected to report disappointing financial results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON STOLPER, SHIRLEY
description: JACOBSON STOLPER-Shirley. Our aunt, a woman of intelligence and wit. She leaves a legacy of unconditional commitment to family and friends. Our thoughts are with her sons Harlan, Andrew, and Stuart, and her loving sister and brother-in-law, Ruth and Seymour Raubvogel. Alissa and Jeffrey Hammerman Randy and Jay Raubvogel

title: New 5-Year Transit Plan Must Serve Many Masters
description: Everyone who matters wants something out of a huge new spending plan for subways, buses and commuter trains, and no one knows quite how to pay for it all. For those reasons, the plan is certain to be bitterly contested, and is likely to undergo significant changes before winning approval in the Capitol.

title: Exorcising The Bin Hex
description: Q. An E-mail message I received from an iMac has an attachment encoded in Bin Hex. Can a Windows 98 machine decode it?

title: Barking Coyotes Banished
description: What to do when a decorating trend goes south? Zona made a name for itself with Southwestern style. But when the fad became a parody of barking-coyote doorstops and too many Navajo blankets, Zona was up a creek. ''To say the trend tanked is too kind,'' said Lester Gribetz, who built Bloomingdale's famed furniture business in the 1980's. Mr. Gribetz was recently brought in to resuscitate Zona. The new inventory is primarily made in Europe, and it looks like a sleeker and more carefully edited version of, well, Bloomingdale's. A turned four-poster bed (right, $3,995) and plump sofas (Zona's label, but made by Mitchell Gold) share space with bookshelves from Japan. And there's not a coyote in sight. Zona is at 97 Greene Street (Prince Street); (212) 925-6750.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro strengthened against the dollar as comments by the vice president of the European Central Bank increased expectations the bank will raise interest rates. The euro rose to 1.0641 from 1.0554.

title: McCain's Two Stands Take Political Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLTEL CORP., Little Rock, Ark., which sells phone service in the Southeast and Midwest, said it would cut about 350 jobs in its rural long-distance business.

description: To the Editor:

description: DUTCH

description: To the Editor:

title: Penalties Adding Insult to Injuries For Struggling Jets
description: In a film clip from one of the Giants' victorious seasons, Bill Parcells preaches to the offensive line, telling them that this is the reason they have worked so hard in the weight room, have spent so much time preparing for this moment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCHI, FRANCESCA (NEE DEL COL)
description: MARCHI-Francesca (nee Del Col). Co-founder of Marchi's Restaurant, Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Lorenzo. Devoted mother of Mario, Robert and John. Loving sister of Basilio. Also survived by four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Funeral mass Saturday, 10A.M. Madonna Church on the Hill. Entombment Madonna Mausoleum. Visiting Thursday 7-9:30PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, NYC 10002 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYKER, MILDRED, ''BILLIE.''
description: WYKER-Mildred, ''Billie.'' On Sept. 26 in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Salie Wyker, loving mother of Pat Silbert and Bob Wyker, devoted grandmother of Michael Silbert, Scott Silbert, Laurie Dunning, Shelley Sharkey, Kenneth Wyker, Amy Campbell & ten great grandchildren. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC at 3PM on Sunday, October 3, 1999.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 in the special E-Commerce section, about business services provided by I.B.M., included a company erroneously among the 20 suppliers that sell their wares through an I.B.M. client, the E-Chemicals Web site. Dow Chemical is not among them.

title: Now Found in Bell Atlantic's Corner: New York Regulators
description: At about 8:30 yesterday morning, workers dispatched by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's biggest local telephone company, began unloading 30 boxes of documents from trucks outside the Washington offices of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: KOREAN GAS COMPANY SPINOFFS
description: South Korea will spin off and sell the gas import and wholesale affiliates of the state-run Korea Gas Corporation by 2001 as well as some Government stakes in the company's storage and pipeline operations, the Government said. Under a preliminary plan, the units of the gas company will be broken up from three to five independent spinoffs by next year and sold off by 2001.

title: Canada Is Taking a Tougher Line With Illegal Chinese Migrants
description: When the Canadian Navy made a group of undocumented Chinese migrants get off a ship here recently, one local man brought his dogs to the dock and encouraged them to bark at the men and women wrapped in blankets against the cold.

title: New Player From Sony Will Give a Nod to MP3
description: As Sony celebrates the 20th anniversary of its Walkman, the pocket-size cassette-tape player that revolutionized the way people listen to music, the company is introducing a revolutionary update that acknowledges that the face of portable music has changed.

title: One Slam Steadies The Ship
description: John Olerud had been having the quietest of .300 seasons, his batting average having dropped 53 points from last season's finish. He had been dreadfully silent during the Mets' recent slide, batting just .241. And he had even suffered in the field, committing a throwing error in the third game against Atlanta last week, leading to one run, and failing to get the ball out of his glove on a pickoff play that led to another run.

title: As He Slowly Goes Blind, A Detective Gains Insight
description: In creating ''Second Sight,'' Paula Milne began with an inspired notion: A vigorous, brilliant police detective contracts a rare eye disease that starts to rob him of his most important sensory tool. Too proud to give up the command of a high-profile murder investigation, he tries to work around his new limitation. But he cannot succeed alone, even as his other senses grow sharper to compensate for his diminishing sight.

title: For the People, by the Computer
description: IN San Diego, comments at public hearings can be submitted by E-mail. Boston residents can use the city's Web site to complain about broken street signs or to pay parking tickets and excise taxes. And in Indianapolis, taxpayers can get electronic copies of the city budget and rework them, then send them to Mayor Stephen Goldsmith just to show him how they would do his job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWLEY, MICHAEL DAVID
description: ROWLEY-Michael David. Resident of Darien for the last 18 years, passed away at home on September 27, 1999, age 53. Born in London, England in 1946, he moved to the US in 1981 and became a US citizen on April 15, 1989. Following a long career in Money Brokering, Michael was appointed president of a new operation for the then London-based firm of Kirkland Whittaker. During his career he worked with a number of other prestigious Wall Street companies. Most recently, he worked with Tradition North America and it was whilst with them he was offered the honor of ringing the closing bell at the Exchange, in April of this year. Michael will be most remembered for his ability to enjoy life to the fullest, packing two days into every one, and accepting everyone he encountered as a friend. He will be greatly missed by his wife Anita, three children, David, Andrew and Anuschka, greatson Callam and family as well as his wide circle of friends and colleagues. A service of tribute will be held at the United Congregational Church, Richards Avenue, Norwalk, Ct. on Saturday, October 2, 1999, at 12noon. Well wishers are invited to attend.

title: Robert Winthrop, 95, a Banker, Philanthropist and Sportsman
description: Robert Winthrop, an investment banker, philanthropist, sportsman, conservationist and man of many causes, died Saturday at his home in Upper Brookville, N.Y. He was 95.

title: Giuliani Raises $100,000, Plus $29 at Craps
description: As City Hall was locked in a tense standoff with the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised $100,000 for his almost-certain Senate campaign in a casino hotel where the fountains dance in nightly shows to the voices of Gene Kelly and Luciano Pavarotti.

title: Marymount School Buys Town House to Renovate
description: The Marymount School in Manhattan announced yesterday that it had paid about $10 million for a six-story town house across the street from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The town house will be renovated for Marymount's new middle school for grades four through seven, which is to open in September 2001.

title: The Knicks' New G.M. Remains Noncommittal
description: In keeping with his military haircut and soldier's posture, the Knicks' new general manager, Scott Layden, all but chose a cigarette and a blindfold over divulging any details concerning the future of Latrell Sprewell yesterday at a news conference.

title: Upgrading the Neighborhood, Mafia Style
description: MOB RULE does for Sim City what ''The Sopranos'' did for family drama. It uses Mafia mythology to goose a well-established genre. Substitute a crime syndicate for city government. Badda-bing badda-boom, you're playing a god game as the Godfather.

title: Spielberg Is Said to Plan a TV Series
description: Steven Spielberg has reached an agreement with NBC to create a new television drama series about the United States Marine Corps, an executive associated with the deal said yesterday.

title: Rise of the Golf Hooligan
description: Wherever golf is tolerated in Europe, and especially in Britain, the reaction to the come-from-behind American victory in the Ryder Cup on Sunday has been one of continuing outrage. The operative headline word, referring to the American team's boisterous celebration on the 17th green while the outcome was still in doubt, is ''disgraceful.'' Sir Michael Bonallack, the recently retired secretary of the Royal and Ancient Golf of St. Andrews in Scotland, symbol of the game's sanctity, described the overall tone of the occasion as a ''bear pit.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a memorial to victims of the earthquake in Taiwan misstated the number of people who are missing. It is about 140, not more than 8,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINDYCK, CHARLES
description: PINDYCK-Charles, on September 28, 1999 of Larchmont, NY, he was 92. Mr. Pindyck was a Veteran of WWII and later a manufacturer of infant wear. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Goldberg) and the devoted father of Larry and Bob and grandfather of Maya, Talia, Shira, Bradley and Zander. Services today, 12 Noon at the Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY. 914381-1809. Interment follows at Sharon Gardens.Memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice

title: G.O.P. Plan Would Delay A Tax Credit for Workers
description: Desperate for money to finance their spending bills without raiding Social Security, Congressional Republicans devised a plan today relying almost entirely on delaying billions of dollars in Federal tax breaks for millions of working-class families.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROMPAPAS, NICK
description: ROMPAPAS-Nick. 1929-1991. Like The Pines, your spirit is eternal. Your loving godson, Jaso

title: Poland's Glossy Capitalism Displays a Darker Underside
description: In the entrance to the offices of his growing movement, called Self-Defense, Andrej Lepper displays a framed quotation from Pope John Paul II: ''It is unacceptable to claim that after the fall of Communism, capitalism is the only alternative.''

title: Uncle Sam Needs You, and You
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DER WYK, JETTA
description: VAN DER WYK-Jetta. Beloved wife of the late Nathan, loving mother of Sonya Skriloff, Marylin Brook and Evelyn van der Wyk. Cherished grandmother of Nick and Jennifer Skriloff and Abby and Michael Kimble. Adored great grandmother of Kyle and Ben Skriloff. Rest in peace.

title: Reinventing the Wheel
description: No one used a helmet when mountain biking supposedly originated in the late 1970's in Marin County and Oakland, Calif. Now, mountain biking has evolved into a technical, high-performance Olympic sport (helmet required).

title: Bank of Scotland, Pushing for Natwest, Reports Earnings Rise
description: Top executives of the Bank of Scotland went on a roadshow of sorts today, traipsing around London in the rain in an effort to persuade shareholders of National Westminster Bank of the merits of their $34 billion hostile bid.

title: KOREA'S OUTPUT JUMPS
description: South Korea's industrial output rose 29.9 percent in August from a year earlier, helped by brisk shipments of semiconductors, computers and automobiles. But the August growth rate was lower than July's increase of 33.2 percent. Semiconductor output increased 31.2 percent in August from a year ago and computer output surged 150.5 percent. Automobile output also surged 150.3 percent. Financial markets fell, however, apparently because of concern about comments made by the Bank of Korea governor, Chon Chol-Hwan, that Korea might have to tighten its monetary policy.

title: Songs of the Homeland Wherever That Might Be
description: Across New York City, outside the concert halls and brand-name clubs, musicians with neighborhood audiences perform at parties and churches and community centers. In immigrant neighborhoods, the music offers memories of home, cultural reaffirmation and a good reason to dance. The Center for Traditional Music and Dance is devoted to bringing those performers to new listeners, and its annual Folk Parks program, held on Saturday at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, confirmed that the whole world has emissaries in New York City.

title: A Corporate Chess Game; Copper Industry Rivals in Nasty, Convoluted Negotiations
description: Last Friday, top executives from three of the nation's top copper companies secretly convened in a room at the Trump International Hotel in Manhattan to try to resolve one of the nastiest, most convoluted corporate takeover fights in recent years. When they emerged more than two hours later, it was nastier and more convoluted than ever.

title: Oil Is Losing Its Lease
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL; Astros Draw Even Atop N.L. Central
description: The race is back even.

title: The New Politics of Health Care
description: Bill Bradley has proposed a bold and expansive plan to make health insurance available to all Americans. Its details and sizable cost -- roughly $65 billion a year to be financed by the non-Social Security surplus -- will certainly provoke debate from all quarters, and that is a splendid development for the 45 million Americans who lack health insurance. Mr. Bradley and Vice President Al Gore, who proposed a more modest health plan earlier this month, have now made access to health care a central issue of their fight for the Democratic nomination. By elevating the issue in their party, these two Democrats make it harder for the Republican Presidential candidates to avoid engaging the issue.

title: Dell Markets Desktops For Lovers of Web Music
description: Another hardware company has heeded the siren call of MP3. Reporting that nearly three-quarters of its customers say they're mad for downloading music files, Dell Computer has begun tailoring models of its Dimension computer for such buyers.

title: Man Charged With Killing Superintendent
description: A Manhattan man with a history of violence was charged with murder yesterday in the shooting of an unarmed building superintendent who climbed through an apartment window to check on him at the request of concerned relatives and neighbors, prosecutors said.

title: Educators Focus on 'Pain' of Standards
description: Three years ago, when most of the nation's governors and dozens of corporate leaders joined President Clinton at an education summit meeting in Palisades, N.Y., only 14 states had standards outlining what students should know and be able to do.

title: Eye-Popping Movement, A Piston-Driven Score
description: Dance Theater of Harlem danced up a storm on Tuesday night in ''Twist,'' a mind-bending, impressive premiere by Dwight Rhoden, and in ''Banda,'' a colorful Caribbean genre piece by Geoffrey Holder.

title: For Internet Dating Site, a Seamy Surprise
description: SUSAN BERGIN, the creator of an on-line matchmaking service, recently used the Alta Vista search engine to determine how easy it was to find her Web site, called singleswithscruples.com. After typing ''singles with scruples'' into the search box, Ms. Bergin was glad to see her site come up first on the list of results.

title: Political Briefing; Nothing Wasted, Something Gained
description: In the end, nothing drives a candidate out of a race quicker than a shortage of campaign money.

title: Brooklyn Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Oblivion Can Wait: Olerud Halts Mets' Slide
description: Rey Ordonez sauntered over to the Mets bat rack about two hours before last night's game, puffing cigar smoke around the lumber, a sort of makeshift blessing for those very much in need of divine intervention.

title: Essay; Manichaean Madness
description: Let's assume the curator of the National Gallery in Washington came up with a show called ''Outrage.'' It featured a statue of Moses wearing a Nazi swastika on his chest, a painting of a violent Martin Luther King Jr. forcing Elizabeth Cady Stanton into submission, and an avant-garde collage of the cutest puppy you ever saw being tortured to death by a sadistic homosexual. As Mort Sahl used to say, ''Is there anybody I haven't offended?''

title: PHONE STOCKS DROP
description: Shareholders of Italy's largest phone company, Telecom Italia S.p.A., reacted angrily to a plan to strip the company of its most valuable business, the cellular phone unit, to help its controlling shareholder repay debt faster. The plan would transfer Telecom Italia's 60 percent stake in Telecom Italia Mobile S.p.A. to Tecnost S.p.A., the Olivetti S.p.A. unit that bought 52 percent of the former phone monopoly for $33 billion in May. Shares of all four plunged. Telecom Italia shareholders who rejected Olivetti's hostile bid are being forced to exchange ownership in one of Europe's fastest-growing companies for debt-laden Tecnost.

title: Governor Pataki's Ethics Problem
description: Gov. George Pataki's two trips to Hungary in 1995 and 1996 drew criticism because they were underwritten by a private group, the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce, raising at least the appearance of a conflict of interest. Now, according to two stories by The Times's Clifford Levy, the potential conflicts were even greater than originally thought. Much of the money that the chamber lavished on the Governor's travels apparently derived from big donations it received from two major corporations, Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, and Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceuticals conglomerate. The timing and size of their donations suggest they may have been using the chamber as a conduit to make gifts to the Governor that would be illegal under state law if made directly.

title: Software to Help Violinists Bring Tears to Listeners' Eyes
description: WHILE they cannot eliminate the need to practice, researchers at the University of Tulsa are offering help for aspiring violinists, adapting speech pathology software that may enable them to fine-tune their vibrato technique.

title: If the Phone Had a Cord, You Could Strangle the User
description: IT was an interruption whose time is coming far too frequently. During a recent performance of ''Death of a Salesman,'' its star, Brian Dennehy, was startled to hear a cell phone ring near the end of the second act.

title: Whispering Electronically
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; The Hardest Question: So, Is It a Date?
description: The devil is in the details when it comes to scheduling Presidential primaries and caucuses.

title: Detroit Silent As a Toyota Hits Market
description: Despite the soaring value of the yen, the Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a subcompact car today that will be imported from Japan and will be priced well below comparable models made by Detroit auto makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, GERTRUDE
description: KAHN-Gertrude. Age eighty-one. On September 28th, 1999 after a valiant battle with lymphoma. Beloved wife of the late Gustav. Mother of Joan. Grandmother of David and Allison. You will live in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, at 1PM on Friday.

title: New Devices Given Road Test By Business Students at Duke
description: James H. Sherrill sat in an oversize chair in a dimly lighted lounge, cradling a rectangular electronic device that was unlike anything he had seen. It was smaller than a laptop and bigger than a palmtop. It didn't have cables or a keyboard.

title: David Bowie Web Site on Art Show
description: As the Brooklyn Museum of Art's battle with City Hall continued yesterday, the rock musician David Bowie said that he would present an on-line version of ''Sensation: Young British Artists From the Saatchi Collection,'' the exhibit that has been attacked by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTEN, C. J.
description: LUTEN-C. J. We note with great sorrow the passing of our dear friend, C.J. Luten, in Sarasota, Florida, and express our sympathy to his wife, Carol, and daughters, Karen and Melanie. John McSorley Joseph Penner Lewis Shapiro

title: Part of the Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnnie Cochran Quits TV Job to Join Manhattan Law Firm
description: Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., best known as a criminal defense lawyer with star power and neon neckties, announced yesterday that he was trading in his Court TV program to join a personal injury law firm in Manhattan that advertises with a toll-free number.

title: As Market Booms, Real Estate Brokers Slip Their Chains
description: BOB LAMBRIGGER, 61, the owner of a small real estate company here in self-proclaimed Trout Town, U.S.A., wheeled his pickup truck into the dirt driveway of a printing contractor. He was picking up his new brochures -- the ones without the Century 21 logo.

title: European Commission Clears Exxon-Mobil Merger
description: The European Commission gave approval yesterday to the Exxon Corporation's planned takeover of the Mobil Corporation, which would create the world's largest publicly held oil company, on the condition that they shed assets in Europe to preserve competition.

title: State Takes Over East Orange Finances After 2d Year of Debt
description: Prompted by back-to-back deficits in the city's last two budgets, New Jersey officials voted yesterday to seize control of the municipal finances of East Orange. The move is required by state law whenever a city's deficit exceeds 4 percent for two consecutive years.

title: Charter Sets Terms of Public Offering
description: In a rare move for an initial public offering, Charter Communications Inc. will sell stock to investors at a price lower than that recently paid by its chairman, Paul Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft.

title: Accounts
description: * Mondera.com, New York, an on-line jeweler, to the Leo Burnett Co. and Starcom Worldwide, Chicago, both parts of Leo Group, to handle the creative and media parts, respectively, of its first account. Billings were estimated at $5 million for the fourth quarter.

title: ITALIAN REAL ESTATE OFFER
description: The holding company that controls the big Italian manufacturer of tires and telecommunication cables, Pirelli & Compagnie, began a $2.4 billion bid for Unione Immobiliare S.p.A. in a move that would create one of Italy's largest real estate companies. Italian real estate is emerging from a slump that lasted through much of the 1990's, and Pirelli has sought to cash in by expanding its real estate division, Milano Centrale, which is the vehicle for the bid.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Amazon Plans to Expand To an On-Line Warehouse

title: A Home-Beauty Makeover: If You Can't Leave It, Love It
description: WITH residential real estate sales hitting record highs and the New York rental market tighter than a whistling oyster, the world as you know it could stay the world as you know it for a long time to come. Welcome to it: the one view, two windows, three rooms, four walls of the place where you live now.

title: Clicking With Both Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dream Lives in a Grand Design
description: AT midday, Matt Roloff had already pounded nails into his four-level treehouse, mowed the soccer field, fed the llamas. Now, he was eyeing the telephone pole on the farm next door. Two men in hard hats were hooking a crane to the old pole, preparing to pull it from the ground, but Mr. Roloff had other ideas.

title: Uncle Sam Needs You, and You
description: To the Editor:

title: Typing for the Show-and-Tell Set: How Early Is Too Early?
description: READING is one thing, but should we also be worried if Johnny can't type?

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
