description: Building Cities

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
description: BY early next year, computing and communications devices will begin showing up on the market with a communications technology called Bluetooth built into them. Their arrival, the companies supporting the Bluetooth technology say, will signal the beginning of the personal-area network.

title: NABISCO BUYS A CANDY COMPANY FOR $475 MILLION
description: In a move that pairs Lifesavers with jelly beans, Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $475 million for the troubled candy company Favorite Brands International Inc. The purchase adds $700 million in annual sales to Nabisco's expanding confectionery business, pushing the division's sales to $1.25 billion. Favorite Brands, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., and owned by Texas Pacific Group, is the nation's No. 1 marshmallow maker. An amalgamation of candy companies and products that was started in the mid-1990's with the purchase of Kraft's Jet Puffed marshmallows, it grew quickly with acquisitions but landed in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this year.

title: California Racial Profiling Bill Is Vetoed
description: Playing both sides of a divisive racial issue, Gov. Gray Davis of California has vetoed a bill requiring law-enforcement agencies to provide information to determine whether they are stopping a disproportionate share of racial minority members.

title: Inventor Fills Girls' Desire for Their Own Gadgets
description: JANESE SWANSON, inventor and founder of Girl Tech toys, has some ideas about what little girls like. Even during a recent interview over lunch in Manhattan, she couldn't stop herself from brainstorming, thinking of new toy ideas.

title: Meting Out Stamps of Approval
description: In Germany, it costs 110 pfennigs, about 59 cents, to mail a standard letter -- well worth it for a new series of stamps released last month by the German Ministry of Finance. The stamps, which celebrate German design, feature a 1958 television by Herbert Hirche, a 1969 ergonomic water bottle, a monorail designed by Alexander Neumeister, and Mono-A, a stainless steel place setting from 1959 that seems timeless. Peter Raacke, who designed the flatware, said Mono-A was ''ecologically friendly,'' because it minimized the waste of stainless steel in production. Its minimalist look keeps the focus ''on the food, not the flatware,'' he said. Moss sells Mono-A for about $103 a place setting (note that the Germans do not use a salad fork) but, alas, does not carry the stamps. Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street).

title: OAKWOOD HOMES CUTS 1,300 JOBS AND TAKES A CHARGE
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation, the largest United States retailer of manufactured homes, said yesterday that it had dismissed 1,300 more workers and expected a fourth-quarter loss of $60 million to $65 million as it takes charges for plant closings and customer defaults and copes with its part of an industrywide glut of inventory. The company, based in Greensboro, N.C., said it was taking a $30 million charge for the closing of 40 sales offices and 4 plants. The charge also includes severance packages for 1,900 employees, which includes earlier job cuts. Oakwood is taking a $25 million charge for higher-than-expected customer defaults on loans it originated during 1998.

title: Brown Edging Closer To Return for Giants
description: For seven years, Gary Brown earned a reputation as one of pro football's workhorse running backs. Last year, his first with the Giants, he rushed for 1,063 yards.

title: Rome Journal; 'God's Parking Lot' Runs Into Ancient Grandeur
description: Workers building a ramp to a vast Vatican garage for pilgrims recently stumbled on walls of an ancient Roman villa.

title: Bishop Saw to Survival Of East Timor's 2d City
description: Unexpectedly from around the corner, a group of smiling teen-age girls appeared this afternoon, singing a United Nations song: ''Brothers and sisters of East Timor, it's time to come together.''

title: SHOE TRUCE
description: Argentine and Brazilian shoemakers reached an agreement limiting the export of Brazilian-made shoes to Argentina. Brazilian companies agreed to limit shipments to 11.2 million pairs this year and 4.4 million in the first half of next year, helping to ease pressure on the Argentine shoe industry. Government representatives said they hoped the agreement would be a precursor of private-sector accords that could relieve trade tensions between Brazil and its neighbors after the Brazilian currency devaluation early this year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: FINKELSTEIN-Samuel. 9/16/069/30/96. Your wit and wisdom enriched our lives and fill our memories. Together with laughter & tears we share those memories. Always in our hearts. Mim, Berne, Billy, Barbara and the children.

title: John R. Crews Is Dead at 76; Winner of the Medal of Honor
description: John R. Crews, who as an Army sergeant in World War II won the Medal of Honor by single-handedly capturing a German automatic-weapons position while severely wounded, died on Saturday in Oklahoma City, his hometown. He was 76.

title: BROOKLYN MUSEUM ACCUSED OF TRYING TO SPUR ART VALUE
description: Broadening its legal case to try to take over the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the Giuliani administration yesterday accused the museum of violating its lease and state law by conspiring with an auction house to inflate the value of the private art collection featured in a controversial exhibition.

title: GORE HEADS HOME IN MOVE TO REVAMP LAGGING CAMPAIGN
description: Vice President Al Gore, acknowledging that his flagging Presidential campaign needs a jolt, said today that he was moving his headquarters from Washington to his home state of Tennessee. The move is designed to pare down a top-heavy operation and to symbolize a break from the Beltway -- and the Clinton Administration.

title: Julius R. Lunsford, 84, Trademark Law Expert
description: Julius R. Lunsford Jr., a trademark lawyer who represented clients like the Coca-Cola Company, Little League baseball and the McIlhenny Company, the producer of Tabasco hot sauce, died Monday of emphysema at a hospice in Atlanta. He was 84 years old.

title: Where Rebates Come True
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Asks U.S. to Expand Nuclear Cleanup, Even to Secret Sites
description: Russia has asked the United States Energy Department to expand joint projects aimed at securing dangerous materials, including nuclear fuel, that could be turned into weapons, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said today on a visit here.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: A Material Boy's Swanky Seating
description: Last Thursday evening, Bernhardt Contract, a furniture manufacturer, introduced a new line of pieces designed by Christopher Ciccone. The party was at Oriont, a new restaurant in the Gansevoort Street meat-packing district that looks like a Shanghai bordello. The crowd that night was there to see more than chairs, or Mr. Ciccone, who designed Oriont and its furniture. Instead, people were hoping to see Mr. Ciccone's sister, Madonna. She didn't show.

title: Heavyweight Matchup Has Lost Its Punch
description: In the 1970's or 1980's, it would have been a glamour matchup: Notre Dame versus Oklahoma. But when the two teams meet Saturday in South Bend, Ind., it will be more like a desperate program meeting a resurgent one. And it is the Fighting Irish who are desperate.

title: Giants Stadium Will Be Grass for 2000 Season
description: When the time came to decide whether grass would become the permanent playing surface at Giants Stadium, there wasn't even a vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, MENACHEM
description: JACOBI-Menachem. The Labor Zionist Alliance mourns the passing of Menachem Jacobi, an honorary officer and longtime leader of our movement. We extend condolences to Edna and the family. Daniel Mann, National President

title: G.M. Announces Fuel-Cell Breakthrough
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had developed a fuel cell that can be chilled to 4 degrees below zero and still start, a key step for using fuel cells in cars.

title: Cut in Fiber Cable Disrupts Internet Traffic Nationwide
description: Internet traffic across the United States was severely disrupted yesterday when a gas company in Ohio accidentally sliced through a fiber cable with a backhoe.

title: New Setback With F.D.A. Hurts Stock Of Abbott
description: Shares of the drug maker Abbott Laboratories fell 6.3 percent today after regulators threatened to halt sales of some of its diagnostic products because of concerns about quality controls.

title: Uncle Sam Needs You, and You
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDISI, A. ALFRED
description: LANDISI-A. Alfred of West New York, NJ on September 29, 1999. Survived by wife Rita, a son Ronald. Sisters Rose Marzella and Theresa DelSordi. Two granddaughters, two great grandsons. Visitation on Friday, 3pm-7pm at Vainieri Funeral Home, North Bergen, NJ. Mass Saturday 9am at Our Lady of Libera Church. Holy Cross Mausoleum. No flowers, donations to church.

title: Where Rebates Come True
description: To the Editor:

title: Pledge of More Flood Aid Still Gets Angry Response
description: He came bearing a promise of $80 million in aid to businesses, farmers and homeowners flooded out by Tropical Storm Floyd, but the State Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, was met today by the jeers and angry shouts of local merchants.

title: Fannie Mae Eases Credit To Aid Mortgage Lending
description: In a move that could help increase home ownership rates among minorities and low-income consumers, the Fannie Mae Corporation is easing the credit requirements on loans that it will purchase from banks and other lenders.

title: Onyx Lamps Made Magical
description: Kae Yoshida once designed hand-dyed batik kimonos in Kyoto, Japan. These days, the designer, who now lives in New York City, creates elegant lamps made of an unlikely material, honey-colored onyx. Ms. Yoshida's lamps are carved from solid chunks of onyx in rural Indonesia. The hefty lamps come in a variety of sizes, from 8 to 14 inches tall, and in shapes that Ms. Yoshida says are ''feminine and fluid.'' Unlighted, they look like a fanciful kind of cheese; lighted from within (they can be regulated by a rheostat), they glow with a fabulous warmth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ROMAINE BRISTOW
description: ADAMS-Romaine Bristow. Of Austin, Texas, New York City, and Newport, R.I. and wife of Warren S. Adams II. Died peacefully in NYC on September 25, 1999. She was the beloved mother of Louise Wheeler Grosvenor. Adored grandmother of Charles Burnett Grosvenor Jr. of Austin, Texas, Leslie Grosvenor Holloway of New Canaan, Connecticut and a devoted great-grandmother of Madeline Louise Holloway, Alexander Grosvenor Holloway and Claire Cordelia Grosvenor. She was dearly loved by her family and greatly admired by her many friends. Her great-grandfather Benjamin Helm Bristow was Secretary of the Treasury in President Grant's Administration. She was the daughter of Louise and William Bristow of NYC and Newport. She was a member of the Colonial Dames of America, The Colony Club of NYC and the Spouting Rock Beach Association & the Clambake Club of Newport. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Youth Foundation, Inc., 36 West 44 St, NYC 10036. A funeral service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC 11AM on Tuesday, October 5, 1999.

title: Queens Fire Victim Had Been Beaten
description: As investigators began focusing yesterday on at least two suspects in the deadly Queens fire that killed three children and their father, a preliminary report by the city's medical examiner showed that one of the victims may have been assaulted before dying of smoke inhalation, the authorities said.

title: America Online Enters Hong Kong With Eye on Mainland
description: Stephen M. Case has planted his flag in Hong Kong, but his gaze is fixed on the Chinese mainland.

title: SLC TECHNOLOGIES TO BE ACQUIRED BY ITI TECHNOLOGIES
description: In a move to become a publicly traded company, SLC Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by ITI Technologies Inc. for $397.1 million in stock. The agreement is a reverse merger, which allows a private company to become public without filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue stock. SLC, which will be majority owner of the merged company, will receive about 15.2 million shares of ITI, valued at $397.1 million based on ITI's closing price on Tuesday. ITI holders can exchange up to 50 percent of ITI's shares for $36.50 a share in cash. SLC will own 63.5 percent of the merged company before the cash transaction or 78 percent if ITI holders exercise the cash transaction option. ITI shares rose $2.875 yesterday, to $29.

title: Vice Chairman of Chevron To Succeed Retiring Chairman
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that its vice chairman, David J. O'Reilly, would become chairman and chief executive, succeeding Kenneth T. Derr, who will retire after leading the company through a tumultuous 10 years.

title: Amazon.com Plans A Transformation To Internet Bazaar
description: Amazon.com announced yesterday that it would transform itself into an Internet shopping bazaar, opening its popular Web site to merchants large and small for a minimal fee. In return, the selling powerhouse, which started as an on-line bookstore, will gather huge amounts of information on the buying habits of consumers.

title: Art Dealer Is Arrested for Exhibition of Live Ammunition
description: A prominent Manhattan art dealer was arrested last night at her Fifth Avenue gallery, where an exhibition included a vase full of live 9-millimeter cartridges for visitors to take home as souvenirs, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a memorial service for the labor leader Lane Kirkland misstated his tenure as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. He led it from 1979 to 1995, not from 1975 to 1995.

title: Whispering Electronically
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Plan Serves Goals in Health and Politics
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley's health care proposal seeks to put the issue back on the national agenda after the failure to pass universal health insurance in 1994 humiliated President Clinton and the Democrats.

title: Hazy Legal Terrain
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art says its battle with the city is about free expression. The city says it is a landlord-tenant fight over taste and the proper role of museums: ''I think it is a disgusting show,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Tuesday.

title: As Iran's Reformer Speaks, Anti-Reformers Sit and Scowl
description: Thousands of jubilant university students gathered today to hail the country's reformist President inside the sprawling, golden-domed shrine to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the puritanical Muslim cleric who led Iran's Islamic revolution 20 years ago.

title: ALARM COMPANY TO SELL CANADIAN OPERATIONS TO VOXCOM
description: Protection One Inc., the security-alarm company, agreed to sell its Canadian operations to Voxcom Inc. of Edmonton, Alberta, for about $27 million in a shift of focus to its United States and European businesses. Protection One, which is based in Culver City, Calif., and is 85-percent-owned by Western Resources Inc., an electric utility company in Topeka, Kan., will get $23 million in cash and hold a 7 percent to 9 percent stake in Voxcom. Voxcom will gain 40,000 Protection One customers, and the two companies will develop joint marketing programs for home security and mobile services in Canada.

title: Software for Palm VII Widens E-Mail Access
description: Palm VII, the latest generation of the popular Palm electronic organizers, is getting help from a start-up company giving away software that lets Palm VII users retrieve E-mail from a variety of providers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''On summer nights when the breeze is blowing, I can still hear their cries, the little kids screaming.''

title: New William Morris Chief Dismisses 10 Talent Agents
description: At least 10 motion picture agents in New York and Los Angeles were dismissed today by the William Morris talent agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFIELD, MAX
description: GOLDFIELD-Max. Beloved husband of Anne, and honored father of Alfred, Michael and HP. Loving grandfather of six and greatgrandfather of one. Philanthropist, businessman, he loved everyone. We will all miss him.

title: Europeans Trail Americans In Time on Line, Survey Says
description: Ever since the days of de Tocqueville, Europeans and Americans have been comparing themselves. A survey being released today by PricewaterhouseCoopers adds an Internet angle: More Americans have home access to the Internet than their European counterparts, the survey says, and they spend more time logged on.

title: NUCOR TO SPEND CASH ON ACQUISITIONS OR SHARE BUYBACKS
description: The Nucor Corporation, the largest United States producer of steel beams and bars, plans to use cash of about $600 million to make acquisitions or repurchase stock to increase shareholder value. Nucor, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., could buy companies that make any of the types of steel it now produces, said Terry Lisenby, controller and vice president. Nucor wants to increase its ratio of debt to total capital to about 30 percent from 14 percent now -- excluding current cash holdings -- to finance the deals, he said. If it cannot find any acquisitions, Mr. Lisenby said, the company will instead consider buying back stock.

title: Top Executive to Leave Philharmonic Post
description: Deborah Borda, whose nine seasons as executive director of the New York Philharmonic have included artistic and fiscal high notes as well as offstage frictions with the players and the orchestra's music director, Kurt Masur, announced late yesterday that she would leave to take a top job with the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

title: Lax Follow-Up for Drug Offenders Is Cited
description: Criminals released on probation after pledging to enroll in drug treatment programs routinely break that promise without suffering sanctions, according to a study by New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi.

title: In America; Attention Must Be Paid
description: Alton Fitzgerald White, one of the stars of the Broadway musical ''Ragtime,'' let it be known this week that he plans to sue the city for false arrest. And on Tuesday he made an appearance at a parochial school in Harlem to commiserate with youngsters who have had their own ugly encounters with the police.

title: Clinton Widens Plan for Poor Debtor Nations
description: President Clinton announced a major expansion today in the American effort to forgive the debt of the world's poorest nations, saying those countries would not have to repay billions of dollars borrowed from American aid agencies if they could show the savings were being used for education and fighting poverty.

title: Headsets Get a Makeover To Match Their New Cachet
description: Headsets are cool. At least that's what Plantronics is hoping. The Silicon Valley company, which has been making telephone headsets since 1962, recently introduced a new line of headsets for cell and cordless phones with a decidedly younger, trendier customer in mind.

title: Beatty Makes No Declaration
description: In a discursive, sometimes impassioned half-hour speech to the Hollywood A-list and liberal advocates, Warren Beatty tonight denounced the conservative drift of the Democratic Party, the rise of corporate greed, the influence of big-money campaign contributions, lingering poverty and social injustice. And he suggested that he would ''keep talking'' about them loud and long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELEZ, JOE
description: VELEZ-Joe. Beloved friend on September 27, 1999 at ninty-one. Born Pamplona, Spain. Reposing Glascott Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: A SCORING DEBATE FOR REGENTS EXAM
description: With much fanfare, New York State three years ago announced that it would abolish its basic competency tests and require all high school students to pass its rigorous series of Regents tests before graduating, in the hope of sending a shock to a system that was providing many students with a second-class education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, DAVID HARRIS
description: DAVIS-David Harris. Age 64, of Jackson Heights, NY, formerly of London, England. On September 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Philip, Andrew and Neil. Graduate of London University. Designed national data systems for large government projects helping thousands of families through Head Start and the Office of Aging. Director of Center for Human Services Management & Accu-Search, Inc. His wit, sensitivity, erudition and culinary gifts will be missed by friends and family members. He was a loving grandpa to Josh and Ashley. Services Thursday, September 30, at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Early Practice As a Symbol

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZER, DORA
description: GLAZER-Dora. On September 28, 1999, in Palm Beach, Fl. Loving wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Alan and his wife Stephanie and the late Victor and his wife Marjorie. Cherished grandmother of Alison Harvey, Carolyn Cohen, Nancy Glazer, and Meredith Glazer; proud great-grandmother of Bryan, Rachel, and Michaela; beloved Aunt and dear sister. Service Friday, 10AM at Riverside, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc. 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407

title: A Fair Reading Of History
description: Patrick Buchanan has been accused of harboring pro-Hitler sympathies and of being an isolationist for his interpretation of World War II laid out in a recent book. But this interpretation is hardly beyond the pale of respectable discourse. Diplomatic historians have long made similar arguments.

title: National News Briefs; Chicago Foundation Gets New President
description: The Chicago Community Trust, the nation's third largest foundation and second oldest community foundation, announced today that Donald M. Stewart would become president and chief executive.

title: Albert Hadley Draws the Shades
description: ALBERT HADLEY, too diffident to accept the title of eminence grise of American design, announced last week that he is closing Parish-Hadley Associates, the 33-year-old firm that he has directed since the death of Sister Parish in 1994. At the news, a collective tear dropped onto the polished surface of seamlessly dignified upper-crust decor.

title: Lewis Plans to Attack From Start Against Holyfield
description: Lennox Lewis, who took a turn as Hamlet (to attack or not to attack?) in his heavyweight unification bout against Evander Holyfield last March, has been getting advice from all quarters since that match finished in a controversial draw. Even Prince Naseem Hamed, the hard-hitting featherweight who is Lewis's stablemate at his Poconos training camp, has weighed in with his opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPHAM, JOHN
description: UPHAM-John. Longtime organist of Temple Israel of Jamaica. The congregation mourns his loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JESSE
description: SCHWARTZ-Jesse. Engineer. Beloved husband of Ida. Devoted father of Barbara Litwin, William and Edward. Dear brother of Milton, Dorothy and Herbert. Loving grandfather of Jeremy, Alexandra and Amanda. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J., on Thursday, September 30, 1999 at noon.

title: Uncle Sam Needs You, and You
description: To the Editor:

title: Victims and the Constitution
description: The so-called victims' rights amendment slated for a vote today in the Senate Judiciary Committee trifles with the Constitution. It is also unnecessary. Just about everyone agrees that victims of crime deserve sympathy and respectful treatment in the criminal process, and most states and the Attorney General are already experimenting with various approaches to making the justice system more sensitive to victims. But adding a wordy and complex amendment to the Constitution could actually harm victims by interfering with what is undeniably their foremost right -- the right to the fair prosecution and conviction of the guilty.

title: Woman Sentenced to Jail In Fatal Auto Accident
description: The wife of a Philadelphia Eagles executive was sentenced to 360 days in the county jail yesterday after she pleaded guilty to a fatal hit-and-run accident following an Eagles football game last fall, the county prosecutor said.

title: BAYER MAY SEPARATE HEALTH CARE UNIT
description: Germany's second-largest drug maker and chemical maker, Bayer A.G., said it might separate its health care business from its chemical, polymer and agricultural products units. The company wants to build up its life-sciences businesses. It is looking to make a major purchase in the agricultural chemical industry and possibly set up a joint pharmaceutical venture with a United States company.

title: Officers Named At Marketing Group
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association has named officers for 1999-2000.

title: FRANCE TELECOM LEAVING GREECE
description: Europe's second-largest phone company, France Telecom S.A., plans to sell its 20 percent stake in Panafon Hellenic Telecom S.A., Greece's biggest mobile telephone company, in a transaction that could net $1.4 billion. France Telecom expects to sell about two-thirds of its stake to a combination of professional investors, individual Greek investors and Panafon employees.

title: Prolific Chinese Painter Is Anonymous No More
description: For 50 years, ever since the Chinese Communist Party came to power, a portrait of Mao has loomed over Tiananmen Square in the heart of the nation's capital.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Actively Managed Funds Outpace the S.& P. Index Again
description: BE careful what you ask for, the saying goes, because you may get it.

title: A Double Knockout Scored By a Most Unorthodox Team
description: The 1999 Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship reached a dramatic conclusion on Tuesday night at the Town Club, at 9 East 86th Street in Manhattan. Victory in the final, by a margin of just four imps, went to an unusually mixed team: John Solodar and Sylvia Moss, who were formerly married; this writer and Dorothy Truscott, who are currently married, and Ilya Levitin and Irina Levitina, who are brother and sister. This is the first time in its 33-year history that the title has been won by a team of three mixed pairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASANOFF, DANIEL, DDS
description: CHASANOFF-Daniel, DDS. On September 28, 1999. Beloved father of Stuart, Marc, and Susanne. Cherished father-in-law of Margot Lebenberg. Adoring grandfather of Jack. Loving fiancee of Sylvia Harris. Distinguished orthodontist, veteran and lover of opera. Service Friday, 12 noon, October 1st at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Leiter's 'Lucky' Bloop Sets Stage
description: Al Leiter kept peering toward center field with hopeful eyes. More than a week of frustration was buried beneath those eyes. Could the pop-up that Leiter had just flicked about 200 feet off Greg Maddux somehow land on the outfield grass? Could the Mets finally feel as if something had gone right?

title: Pentagon Says It Can Find No Proof of Massacre
description: Without denying that Korean civilians were killed at the Bridge of No Gun Ri 49 years ago, Pentagon officials said today that a search of their archives turned up no documents that prove that American soldiers massacred the civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTZKIN, DON
description: MOTZKIN-Don. Westchester Day School is deeply saddened by the loss of its former Chairman, President and long-time Trustee. The entire WDS family extends its sympathy to the Motzkin and Rasekh families. Rabbi E. Gottlieb, Headmaster Caren Hammerman, President David Savitsky, Chairman

title: Before Bell Atlantic Wins Approval
description: Bell Atlantic deserves eventually to become the country's first regional phone company to enter long-distance service, with the potential to provide customers a combination of local and long-distance services at lower prices than its competitors. But Bell Atlantic's application yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission is premature. Bell Atlantic has not yet satisfied the precise performance standards required by the New York State Public Service Commission.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: For More Brussels Sprouts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLODNER, HARRY, M.D.
description: GOLODNER-Harry, M.D. on Sept. 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Syril. Loving father of Ellen, Adam and Meg. Cherished grandfather to Caitlin and Sarah. Dear brother of Max & Larry. Services Thursday 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Diageo Sells Last of Four Liquor Brands
description: Diageo P.L.C., the world's largest liquor company, completed its auction of four European liquor brands today with the sale of Cinzano to Campari International of Italy for an undisclosed sum.

title: Mets Still Breathing
description: Baseball came easy last night for a Mets team that had made it look difficult the past 10 days. The ball took the right bounces and found holes in the defense. John Olerud, above, crushed a grand slam, one of eight straight hits in the fourth inning off the Atlanta ace Greg Maddux. The Mets' 9-2 victory ended a seven-game losing streak and kept them in the National League wild-card race. They trail Houston and Cincinnati by a game and a half.

title: Starving the State Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampling the Musicals Of Tomorrow Today
description: They had only 30 minutes, so they got right down to business. ''We're two guys describing a show about two guys describing a show,'' explained the heavier-set of the two, as their pianist fidgeted on his bench and adjusted the pages of his score.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Currents column on Sept. 9 about the Glow Worm lamp, made of spandex stretched over a steel frame in the shape of a cornucopia, misstated the name of its manufacturer. It is Joey Manic Inc., not Manic Lighting.

title: Baby in Parents' Bed in Danger? U.S. Says Yes, but Others Demur
description: Parents should never sleep in the same bed with infants or toddlers under the age of 2, the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission warned yesterday, because sleeping together poses a significant risk of accidental smothering or strangling.

title: Disdainful of Foreigners, the Japanese Blame Them for Crime
description: With a graph of its sales mirroring the path of lemmings falling from a cliff, Japan's largest lock maker, the Miwa Company, settled on a recent ad strategy that fanned Japanese fears of crime, and spiced it with a foreign twist.

title: Death Leads to Concerns For Future of Gene Therapy
description: The death of a patient in a gene therapy trial at the University of Pennsylvania is another disappointment in a field that could provide radical new treatments for many diseases but has had few successes.

title: City Sued Over Temporary Housing for Homeless People With AIDS
description: In his room at the Concourse Hotel in the Bronx, which the city uses to house homeless people with AIDS, Simon Vargas says he sleeps with the television and the lights on to keep the roaches and rodents away. He says that he has found crack vials in the mattress and that mice have slid through the seal of his refrigerator door to eat his food.

title: Russia Starts Inquiry at Moscow Bank Into Money Laundering
description: Russian prosecutors have opened the first criminal investigation into a Moscow bank since the Government was rocked by accusations of money laundering through the Bank of New York.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, ANN
description: HOLZER-Ann. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: Drug Treatment Plan Ignores Capacity for Care
description: To the Editor:

title: New Publisher Is Appointed At The Post
description: There was a changing of the guard at The New York Post yesterday, but the new guard bore a distinct resemblance to the old one. The editor in chief, Ken Chandler, who first joined the aggressive tabloid in 1978 and has been deputy publisher for slightly less than a year, was named publisher by The Post's owner, Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation.

title: Shepard's Brutal Passions, Preserved but Not Thawed
description: Making love and making war are one and the same to Eddie and May. He's the gasoline and she's the flame of Sam Shepard's incendiary ''Fool for Love,'' a play that suggests that the blazing passion shared by man and woman will endure as long as they can go on hurting.

title: Op-Art
Waste Management Offer to Employees
description: Waste Management Inc. is offering to repurchase company shares from employees who threatened to sue after stock that they bought earlier this year plummeted in value.

title: Two Teenagers Agree to Deals
description: The Islanders agreed to terms yesterday with the teen-agers Tim Connolly and Mathieu Biron, who will both start the season with the team. Connolly, 18, and Biron, 19, signed three-year contracts worth about $3 million.

title: Vintage Designs Reclaim a Space Above the Table
description: THE evolution of ceiling lights has been a steady movement from functionalism to glitter and back again. In the 1950's and 60's, fixtures became delightfully decorative, geared to the adventuresome tastes of the postwar mass market. Many vintage lights cast an ambient glow, thanks to reflectors and diffusers that hide brash bulbs. Which explains why they quickly migrated -- not always happily -- to corners of the living room, suspended beside tweed sectional sofas.

title: A Bigger Home for the Federal Courts in Brooklyn
description: After seven years of planning and delays, a major expansion of the Federal courthouse in Brooklyn will finally go forward, Government officials said yesterday, as they announced the award of a $184.7 million contract for the construction of a 15-story addition.

title: Frank Moore, 75, Composer and Filmmaker
description: Frank Ledlie Moore, a composer, filmmaker and author, died on Sunday at the home of his daughter Gabi Moore in Chester, Conn. He was 75.

title: Russian Prime Minister Refuses to Rule Out New Chechen War
description: As Russian and international agencies struggled to keep up with the tide of Chechen refugees fleeing air strikes by Russian warplanes, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin refused today to rule out a possible ground war against the rebellious southern province.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold fell 4 percent as banks and speculators made more of the metal available so that they could take advantage of higher prices. Gold for December delivery fell to $302 an ounce, from $308.10 the previous day.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Magic Carpets for Armchair Explorations
description: NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC MAPS

title: Image Spinner at the Center of a Web; Rubenstein, 'Dean of Damage Control' for New York's Powerful
description: Before Howard J. Rubenstein's party was over, the Mayor proclaimed him the world's ''dean of damage control.'' Leona M. Helmsley kissed him wetly. The Governor said New York was blessed to have him. The Duchess of York credited him with having given new meaning to her entire life. Manhattan real estate figures whispered about his Solomonic wisdom.

title: G.O.P. Would Delay Workers' Tax Credit
description: Desperate to finance spending bills without raiding Social Security, Congressional Republicans devised a plan relying almost entirely on delaying billions of dollars in tax breaks for working-class families.

title: Fifth Person Dies of Mosquito-Borne Virus
description: City health officials said yesterday that a a 79-year-old woman from Queens who died in early September was stricken with a form of the West Nile virus. The woman, whom officials did not name, is the fifth victim in the area and the fourth city resident known to have died from the disease since August; health officials have now confirmed that 31 people in New York City were infected with the virus, which was first thought to be St. Louis encephalitis.

title: McCain's Two Stands Take Political Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Crude Oil Up Again, Briefly Trading Over $25 a Barrel
description: The price of crude oil rose more than 1 percent yesterday, briefly trading above $25 a barrel for the first time in two and a half years, after a report of declining inventories signaled that the oil surpluses of early this year are gone.

title: A Colorful St. Peter's Raises Eyebrows
description: Baroque architecture was much inspired by the theater, and for centuries the grand facade of St. Peter's Basilica has been the central backdrop for the religious drama of the papacy. This week, with a show of fireworks and a solemn papal blessing by Pope John Paul II, the Vatican is rededicating Carlo Maderno's magnificent 17th-century facade after a three-year, $5.4 million restoration that has revived a passionate debate over preservation methods.

title: Ex-UCAR Chairman Set to Plead Guilty
description: A former chairman of UCAR International Inc., Robert Krass, has agreed to plead guilty to price-fixing and serve a 17-month prison term for his leading role in a global conspiracy to raise the price of a major steelmaking product, the United States Justice Department said today.

title: The Big City; Open Market For Artifacts Aids All Sides
description: THE Brooklyn Museum of Art is taking on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in court, but its officials haven't yet dared to strike the supreme blow for artistic freedom. They haven't thrown the city's money back in Mr. Giuliani's face.

title: Police Disrupt March to Milosevic's House
description: Police officers swinging riot sticks broke up a peaceful demonstration tonight, preventing 20,000 demonstrators from marching to the suburb where President Slobodan Milosevic lives.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Is Capitalism Innately Altruistic?
description: To the Editor:

title: It Can Hold a Head, Or It Can Hold Nuts
description: These molded wool-felt vessels look like colorful hornets' nests. They mark a new use for felt, a material best known for chalkboard erasers and poodle skirts. Molded by the Mitsuko Tarui Workshop in Tokyo, the soft vessels are attractive on their own, or can be used to hold dried flowers or nuts. Upside down, they could even be used as a cloche hat. In varying shades of orange, green and blue, the containers ($100 each) are expected to arrive around Dec. 1 at the new MOMA Design Store (44 West 53d Street), which reopens on Tuesday.
